name: El Presidente. –
text: The next item on the agenda is the debate on the basis of the Commission Declaration on the situation of the Energy Union (2015/2737(RSP)).

name: Maroš Šefčovič
text: Vice-President of the Commission. – Mr President, nine months ago we had a debate in this plenary when I was here to present the Energy Union strategy with a forward-looking climate policy which had just been adopted by the Commission. I was very encouraged by your reactions in this House. This gave the strategy important momentum from the very beginning. Nine months of intensive work and intensive contacts have passed since then. In the Commission this was very important collective work, involving 14 Commissioners on the Energy Union Project Team. I would like to thank them here in the plenary for this work. We have proved that the new Commission structure works and can deliver. Last week, we added a new instrument to our energy toolbox: the State of the Energy Union Report. This will become an annual exercise to take stock but also to provide concrete policy guidance for the year ahead. This will allow you – and us – to keep up the momentum and to have a debate every year about all the dimensions of the Energy Union. Your support and your commitment to this ambitious project are crucial. As co-legislator, you will have to set the legislative framework for the Energy Union and you can carry the debate into your capitals, cities and regions, and to the citizens in your constituencies. As you know very well, their support for the Energy Union will be decisive. Let me highlight four key messages that need political attention in 2016. The first is to highlight the fact that the EU must remain the leader in the transition to a low-carbon society. COP21 is only days away, where the EU, and notably our chief negotiator Miguel Arias Cañete, will spare no effort to get an ambitious, legally-binding agreement with a built-in review mechanism. The EU must also continue to lead the way after COP21. The Emissions Trading System (ETS) reform and the new electricity market design must give the right signals for clean and energy—efficient technologies. We will make proposals for a heating and cooling strategy and for the decarbonisation of transport. We will also propose the Effort Sharing Decision in the non-ETS sector. We will present legislation to ensure that we reach the 2030 targets on renewables and energy efficiency, the latter having in mind an EU level of 30%. In parallel, we will further develop our financing instruments, making them more suitable for financing needs at the local level and for energy efficiency needs in the building sector. My second main message is to highlight the fact that, if we want this fundamental energy transition to be successful, it has to be socially fair and consumer centred. We must empower our consumers, as we explained in the Communication that we discussed with you in plenary in September, together with the rest of the summer package. But I am also convinced that in 2016 we should pay particular attention to the increasing numbers of the energy poor. When we review our legislation next year, we should make sure that the interests of energy-poor consumers are duly taken into account. My third message focuses on the geopolitical challenges, because they will not go away in 2016 and we need to be on top of them. We have to keep pushing for the diversification of energy sources, routes and suppliers, especially through an ambitious liquefied natural gas (LNG) strategy which we will present in February. At the same time, we will present a revision of the Security of Gas Supply Regulation and proposals to revise the decision on intergovernmental agreements. Let me mention another issue to which I want to pay special attention. We have to speed up work on infrastructure projects. I am glad that we have also adopted the second Projects of Common Interest (PCI) list – a list that is more focused, moving from 248 to 195 projects of common interest, and much better aligned to the core objectives of the Energy Union. Let me also say a word about Nord Stream 3 and 4. I know this is a subject of huge interest and concern to this House, as reflected in President Buzek’s letter sent to Commissioner Arias Cañete and me two weeks ago on behalf of the Committee on Industry, Research and Energy. We have taken note of the plans of commercial companies to build further pipelines connecting Russia and Germany through the Baltic Sea. These pipelines, if built, will have to comply fully with EU law. But let me also state that this project would not give access to a new source of supply and even further increase excess transmission capacity from Russia to the EU. The EU will only support infrastructure projects that are in line with the core principles of the Energy Union, including the EU’s Energy Security Strategy. Diversification of energy sources, suppliers and routes is crucial for ensuring secure and resilient supplies to European Union citizens and companies. It is for these reasons that the Nord Stream project will not become a project of common interest and will not benefit from EU financing. But let me also clearly say this: Ukraine proved to be a reliable transit partner for Russian gas throughout the last winter, and the EU believes that it is in the interest of all parties that Ukraine remains an important transit country. Last but not least, my fourth message. With this State of the Energy Union, we are laying the first building blocks of a ‘governance mechanism’ that will bring more transparency and predictability to investors and businesses. The low-carbon and energy-efficient technologies are here, but they need investment. When ready, the governance mechanism will thus be based on three pillars. The first will be the State of the Energy Union Report with its policy conclusions and country fact sheets, all of which we will further develop in the coming years. In that way we will keep implementation of the Energy Union under close scrutiny. We will keep it regularly on the European agenda through discussion in this Parliament and in different Council formations. It will also allow the European Council to give continued guidance on this issue. The second pillar will be represented by national energy and climate plans with biannual progress reports, covering all five dimensions, covering the 2021—2030 period, and promoting regional cooperation between Member States. This year we are providing, firstly, guidance and key indicators for the progress reports. Next year we will come with a proposal to ensure that this monitoring and reporting system is firmly anchored in legislation. The third pillar will be represented by the sector-specific legislation that I mentioned before, in particular to ensure that we reach our 2030 targets. In all this, we will ensure that this Parliament will play its full part in making the Energy Union happen. So I think that I can say that we have got off to a good start in 2015, but my promise to you today is that 2016 will be the Energy Union’s ‘year of delivery’.

name: Krišjānis Kariņš
text: Mr President, Commissioner, ladies and gentlemen, i would like to thank the – Commissioner, i would like to begin by congratulating the rapporteur on The EPP Group is, of course, in favour of the Commission-driven creation of the Energy Union. This is our attempt to create a truly free market, to increase energy competition throughout the European Union, by reducing our import dependence, reducing CO2 emissions and increasing our energy security, hence security of supply. In this regard, I would like to emphasise two things in particular. Firstly, Commissioner, you are talking about reforming the emissions trading system. This is very important. We in the European Union must reduce CO2 emissions, but the request is for you to be very balanced, balancing both our target of reducing CO2 emissions and our objective of maintaining industry and jobs in the European Union. I can mention the steel industry as an example. The steel industry as such is not environmentally friendly. We all know that, but we in Europe consume and use steel, both in our automotive industry, in construction and elsewhere. So we're going to buy it somewhere. If this industry is 'rolled out' outside the European Union, we will not consume less steel, but perhaps it will be produced where there is no control at all. So, as you try to reduce CO2, be balanced in the industry. And the other thing I would like to highlight is exactly what you also mentioned about the Nord Stream pipeline expansion project. I call on the Commission to look very carefully at whether this project is at all compatible with our objectives of creating an Energy Union, because we see that it would not increase the security of our energy supply, on the contrary, it would increase our dependence on a single supplier, from Russia. Thank you for your attention.

name: Dan Nica
text: on behalf of the S&D Group – Commissioner, Vice-President, I congratulate you on your work and efforts to date to implement the Energy Union. The Social Democratic Group, through its parliamentary work, is ready to support the Commission's proposals and work closely with the other European institutions to implement the necessary measures for an integrated internal energy market. Our economy and society are facing energy imports from unstable regions that make prices volatile. The key to the Energy Union is to create a safe, sustainable, competitive and affordable energy market in order to increase the global competitiveness of the European economy by reducing and harmonising energy prices in Europe and between Member States. An integrated market would maximise benefits for new industries and technologies while ensuring protection and support for traditional labour and industries. I stress that we must ensure that the proposed objectives and targets are not met to the detriment of European industry and jobs. An integrated energy market must first and foremost bring tangible benefits to consumers. It is therefore regrettable that the electricity and gas markets do not have the expected performance. In addition to transparency of energy costs, both industrial consumers and citizens need lower energy prices. I also stress, Mr Vice-President, the importance of interconnections in order to have a genuine internal electricity market. Last but not least, we Social Democrats support the Commission's approach to combating energy poverty and protecting vulnerable consumers. But I stress that we need an integrated European approach. Good luck with that, Mr. Vice President.

name: Evžen Tošenovský
text: on the ecr group. – Mr President, energy, as a fundamental issue for Europe's future, must not be put in the context of the current and dramatic debate on migration and terrorism. I am therefore glad that the Commission (and Vice-President Šefčovič himself) is dedicated to the Energy Union with full commitment. However, Parliament is also carrying out its tasks and I must commend my colleague Gróbarczyk, now a minister in the new Polish Government, who has prepared a balanced report on ITRE.  Let me make a few comments. First, to the infrastructure. We need inter connectors, which is why I welcome the energy projects under the CEF approved last week as you mentioned them.  Furthermore, briefly on energy security, which should be based on the principle of solidarity. From this principle, however, the Nordstream II project is out of the way, rightly perceived by many as a threat. The issue of decarbonisation needs to be approached with reason, respecting the specificities of some states, especially those with a high share of coal in the energy mix, and its importance, for example, for heating.  And also respect nuclear power as a low-carbon energy source essential for many countries. We must avoid the negative effects of our policy, such as the high price of energy and deindustrialisation. On the contrary, the Energy Union must provide an impetus for an open energy market that will help the competitiveness of the Member States and our industry.

name: Morten Helveg Petersen
text: on behalf of the ALDE Group. – Mr President, I would like to thank the Commission for the excellent work done in this report, which helps to illustrate the scale of the challenge ahead of us. Europe needs a holistic approach to achieving an energy union. We need integrated solutions in order to get more renewables into the energy mix, cut our carbon footprint and use scarce energy supplies in the most efficient way. Doing so will cut costs for business and make Europe more competitive, reduce energy bills for ordinary citizens and help us innovate to become world leaders in the energy technologies of the future. But many EU countries have back—pedalled on even modest objectives and have then gone on to block efforts to strengthen Europe’s ambition. This cannot continue if we are to deliver on a true energy union. What I want to emphasise today is that we too, as Parliament, need to step up to this challenge. In the own-initiative report on the Energy Union, which we will hopefully adopt next part-session, we call for Parliament to play an active role in the governance of the Energy Union. But clearly, we can only play this role if we are able to work together to find common ground on the crucial issues which often divide us. This is a priority for me and my Group: looking to find pragmatic approaches, but also approaches that maintain our ambition and determination to deliver the fundamental changes that energy union must deliver over the coming years. I would again like to thank Vice-President Šefčovič for all the hard work, and clearly I hope that Parliament is also up to the challenge of achieving a true energy union.

name: Νεοκλής Συλικιώτης
text: on behalf of the GUE/NGL Group. Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, unfortunately the Commission's first report on the state of the Energy Union confirms what we knew. No substantive actions have yet been taken to remove states' energy isolation from energy networks, to ensure energy efficiency and supply, to tackle climate change, to reduce carbon dioxide emissions, to promote renewable energy sources and to reduce the Union's energy dependence.  Of particular concern, however, is the Failure of the Commission to take the necessary steps to combat the energy poverty that is causing more and more people in Europe. It is no longer enough to point out the problems. Time is running out and peoples' needs require - immediately - action. An important role in removing energy isolation and ensuring equal and cheap access for all people to the good of energy can and must be played by the Union's domestic energy sources.  We therefore continue to call on the Commission to build on the prospects created by natural gas deposits in the eastern Mediterranean, to support energy investment in the region, to promote the creation of a Mediterranean gas hub with pipelines, but also through the development of LNG production. It is equally important that we immediately develop a realistic, comprehensive plan to support and promote renewable energy sources.  Above all, however, we need to redefine our energy policy so that the needs and interests of people, consumers and local communities are at the heart.

name: Claude Turmes
text: on behalf of the Verts/ALE Group. – Mr President, I would like to address the Commissioner. Yes, you have made some progress over the last nine months by making south-eastern Europe a bit calmer after South Stream was cancelled, bringing Poland back on track on the Gas Interconnector Poland-Lithuania (GIPL) and working with the Baltic countries around the Baltic Sea. I think it is working, with Ukraine, to stabilise the relations with Russia. So on that front some progress has been made, and a lot of it is to your personal credit. But overall, what you presented last week is weak. It is a paper without a clear vision. I will identify this on three points: one is energy efficiency. “A binding 30% objective for energy efficiency by 2030 is, to me,” said Jean-Claude Juncker last year “the minimum if we want to be credible and forward-looking”. One year later, this is a completely broken promise. In your paper you speak of 27%, and this is not even binding. Can you please explain to us: what is the word of the President of the Commission if one year later it does not count any more? In the modelling exercise you are doing, our call for 40% is not even modelled, which I think is democratically not acceptable to this institution. On energy efficiency, what is the situation in the world? World investments in renewables have grown by 14%. Europe’s investments in renewables are almost stagnating. Where was the Commission in Spain on the retroactive changes? What concrete proposals have you made for Paris? Jean—Louis Borloo, the former French Minister under the Sarkozy government, is calling for a big plan for Africa, including for reasons of migration. Why do we not go for massive PV deployment in Africa? You have presented nothing this year on renewables but hostility towards renewables. On ETS: ETS has largely failed over the last ten years. Can you explain to me how we will bring back gas and phase out coal with this weak ETS price? How do you foresee phasing out coal? Yes, you are discussing Nord Stream at the Commission. But if Nord Stream goes ahead, then we will weaken Ukraine and make Eastern Europe so fragile that we will completely discredit the Energy Union. Please, stand up and be courageous, including on these particular French and German interests in Nord Stream. We need a vision. Do we need another energy crisis before Europe gets its act together? The Commission is active now in the crisis on migration, but unambitious when it comes to energy union.

name: Dario Tamburrano
text: Mr President, president, ladies and gentlemen, i.e. the european Union, the European Union and its Member States are Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, Commissioner, we welcome some of your statements and hope that certain promises will be kept. We are concerned about the lack of binding targets at the level of the individual States, because we believe that, when these 27% or 40% targets are not met, there would in fact be no responsibility on the part of the individual States; We therefore call for more ambitious and more binding targets to be set. I would like to invite you and my fellow Members to reflect, to the link we all know between the geopolitics of energy and the geopolitics of terror. We are all, in some way, responsible for a fossil-based development model. We are well aware that we have fed a huge flow of wealth to certain countries which now have the means, men and economic resources to go and create what happened in Paris only last week. In some way, we are responsible for our future. I therefore believe that binding targets and more ambitious targets are the European way to peace and prosperity: as long as we depend on external resources, as long as we depend on oil and gas for our development, we will somehow also be fueling the hand of terror that we find ourselves in our homes every day. And there is another issue that I do not think is being addressed: there has been talk of loosening the Stability Pact with regard to investment in security. I hope that these investments will be in real security, in intelligence on the ground, because in reality this phenomenon is taking on the aspect of domestic terrorism. But, given that the objectives of the energy transition are ambitious and in need of investment, we believe that the free market and that this economic model can in fact have the long-term vision necessary for investments based on private investment.  We therefore believe that we need a new deal, a new investment, a new quantitative easing to finance what is the European energy transition, because the challenge is truly great and extraordinary.

name: Barbara Kappel
text: Mr President, I would like to like to take a iendled with the ENF Group. Mr President, Commissioner, I would like to thank the Commissioner for his work and for his work You mentioned it, next week cop 21 begins in Paris. The European Union has set itself the goal of being at the forefront of climate policy and climate protection. In order for us to be able to take this leading role credibly, it is necessary for the European Union to meet the 2030 targets. As you know, this is the 40% reduction in greenhouse gases, at least 27% of renewable energy and also an improvement in energy efficiency of at least 27%.  We all know that these changes, that these points, these measures will lead to a complete change in the European electricity market. It is likely that up to 50% of renewable energy will be used in electricity generation, taking into account the efforts towards the Energy Union, the current state of play that you are telling us. But that is not enough. What to do? In addition to a functioning internal energy market, we need regional cooperation – as you have already mentioned today – ten per cent interconnectivity, cooperation between network operators, a reassessment of ACER, harmonisation of support schemes for the efficient development of renewable energy, the new role of end-users, which you have already taken into account in the summer package – we are talking here about the so-called prosumers, i.e. end-users, businesses and households are being more closely involved in energy production. , but also more resources for network expansion and for research and development – as we mentioned today – new financial instruments, but also almost fast-track procedures, so that the lines can be built really quickly. This brings me to the last important point, namely European energy security. We have already mentioned it today: diversification of networks, diversification of suppliers, diversification of sources, but also a secure and stable interconnection network, otherwise there will be no European security of supply. You have already set out some good intentions in the summer package. I raised the New Deal for consumers, there is energy labelling, but the new energy market design and capacity markets and, most importantly, the ETS reform and here please proceed with a sense of proportion. The steel industry has been mentioned. It is important that Europe remains competitive. We want to be at the forefront of climate policy, but we also want to remain the most competitive location in the world. (The speaker agreed to answer a question on the 'blue card' procedure under Rule 162(8) of the Rules of Procedure)

name: Hans-Olaf Henkel (ECR)
text: Question about the procedure of the "blue card". Mrs Kappel, I would like to thank Mrs Kappel for her work and You spoke of a pioneering role. I would like to ask: what happens when the European Union comes forward on its own and no one rides after it?

name: Barbara Kappel (ENF)
text: Answer to a question about the "blue card" procedure. That is a very good question, Mr Henkel. If Europe does not commit itself to meeting the climate targets and sets binding targets, no one is likely to do so. We see that neither China nor the US are prepared to make binding commitments, and we also see that few emerging countries are prepared to make binding commitments. This should lead us, as the largest donor of funds, to this, for example in development cooperation, which is linked to binding compliance and to the binding requirement of national action plans for climate protection. Indeed, Europe cannot be the only region that commits itself, and the others remain non-binding.

name: Zoltán Balczó (NI).
text: – Mr President, the objectives of the Energy Union Strategy include decarbonisation as a tool for EU climate policy. There is only one option for replacing fossil fuels in EU documents: renewable energy. This in itself is not a solution. Even Commissioner Šefčovič himself cannot get the wind to blow and the sun to come when consumers are in demand. And perhaps we also need to take into account the high cost of energy, the amount of support they need. Thus, the use of nuclear energy, which is considered clean energy in terms of CO2 emissions, should not be negliged. And I would like to point out that in the fall of 2014, four respected American scientists specializing in environmental protection issued an open letter in favour of the use of nuclear energy.

name: Françoise Grossetête (PPE).
text: Mr President, Commissioner, you have given us details on the Energy Union, this great project wanted by Jean-Claude Juncker, which must absolutely ensure the energy security of the European Union and at the same time the competitiveness of our companies. There would be a lot to say, but I will just focus on 2 points.  The first is to achieve the goal of improving energy efficiency, i.e. 20% by 2020. We know that we will find it very difficult to achieve this, because many Member States are not spending the necessary investments in this area. However, the Juncker plan has financed a number of projects, particularly in France. This must be emphasized, especially on heating and cooling, which are the main energy consumption points in the European Union, because existing buildings, 98% of buildings, cannot be left out of any energy improvement. I would therefore like to know, Commissioner, what you intend to do to really lead the Member States towards investments related to energy efficiency.  Secondly, with regard to the electricity and gas markets, we see that they are not working well: lack of interconnection, regional cooperation and cross-border trade. The internal market absolutely needs to be strengthened and integrated. Renewable energy makes this system a bit complex and, therefore, it is important and urgent to respond to the complexity of energy management with a real European strategy by focusing on so-called intelligent network management.  So there is still a lot of work to be done. With a view to reforming the carbon market to come, as my colleague Kari mentioned, it is important to take into account the interests of our industry and not to sacrifice our industrial base to a certain ideology; a proper balance should be taken into account and relocations should be avoided. In this context, Commissioner, you can count on our support.

name: Matthias Groote (S&D).
text: Mr President, I would like to thank the The Energy Union is a marathon, as is also evident in today's debate. We have only just started, and it is worth making every effort to really run this marathon to the finish line, because the competitiveness of European industry has often been mentioned. On the other hand, we have the issue of climate protection. We are most likely expecting 200 million climate refugees from other continents if we do not change course, unless there is a decisive agreement in Paris. That is why we should see the Energy Union as a whole. I must compliment him: the Commissioner is on the ground a lot, talking to stakeholders on the ground. It is not only decided in Brussels – in the ivory tower – and then laws are spit out, but on the ground they are discussed with each other. That is very positive. What must be the case at the end of the day – this has also become clear today in the debate: for example, in the area of energy efficiency, we need robust legislation, and we need specific provisions. This cannot be done on a voluntary basis, but the industry and those who want to take money and invest at the end of the day also need investment security. And that's why: clear conditions and ambitious but feasible goals, so that this can be implemented! This creates work at the end of the day. Every kilowatt hour, every tonne of oil that we do not have to burn or convert into electricity, is good. This strengthens the competitiveness of European industry and also ensures that energy policy is socially shaped. Once again, to the Member States, who all have their own agenda: I can only remind all the Member States that the European Energy Union is also the key to national energy problems at the end of the day. Only together will it become a shoe. We should also look back in history: something similar to that of the European Coal and Steel Community at that time, we should also start and knit with the Energy Union. It is an integration project.

name: Ian Duncan (ECR).
text: – Mr President, I think this is what I would term a ‘Goldilocks’ approach to things. It is not too hot, it is not too cold, it seems to occupy that middle ground, and in the middle ground you can disappoint people on either side. I think right now there are many interesting things within this: trying to move ourselves away from dependence upon Russian imports, so the PCIs are vital – I think that is important; the concept of interconnectivity at a regional level – not pan-European in one step, but rather regional, growing from the ground and lifting it up: that is a huge step forward, and I think that will help us make significant progress. Emissions abatement is also something we must look at, and into that we have to consider CCS – carbon capture and storage – and, indeed, carbon capture and usage. Those two concepts need to be integral. I am very struck just now that we must make sure our energy mix works and delivers. We must again, however, be looking at how to create a level playing field for all our sources of energy, and that will mean, I believe, looking at fossil fuel subsidies as well. There is much to thank from this report but still much again to be done.

name: Fredrick Federley (ALDE).
text: Mr President, I would like to begin by congratulating Mr Thank you Vice-President Šefčovič for being here taking the debate. I would like to start by saying that, as far as I am concerned, it is so extremely clear that this is one of the areas where we really need more of the European Union and where we need more market. There are some forces that criticise the EU and say that it is all about the market. Here we have the clear evidence that, in the field of energy, we have no common market at all. If we are to cope with the climate, we are going to do the jobs, we are going to manage the industry, we are going to manage the economy and security, then it is extremely important that we have a common energy union that is also very, very market-based. If we look at the example that exists in the EU that is north pole, which affects the Nordic countries and the Baltic countries, we can, for example, if we look at Estonia see how a common market has benefited the economy both for private households and for industry and how it has been possible to reduce the cost through more efficient energy use. It is also based on an increased interconnectivity which will enable us to ensure that in those parts of the Union where we have an energy surplus, we can compensate for those parts of the Union where we have an energy deficit. It also gives us greater security throughout the European Union. I would urge the House not to get too caught up in the details of what we have in this market since. Now we're going to create the system, security, the rules and the market. Then there are other instruments, such as the ETS, to ensure that we steer in the direction we want in the future. But we cannot cope with jobs, the economy or the climate unless we have a common energy union that is strong, clear and market-based.

name: Cornelia Ernst (GUE/NGL).
text: Mr President, I would like to thank the I had to do this morning to make it appear here on time, because there are again border controls at the german-French border. Given that, for all sorts of reasons, Europe is increasingly falling back into its principalities, it will be difficult to realize the dream of a modern energy union. The Commission's concepts also bow to the logic of the principalities, otherwise they would not co-finance a new nuclear power station for 35 years, otherwise they would not be pushing for the coal phase-out and fracking would be made fit for court again. Instead of small-scale statehood, we need European recognition of the global reality that climate change cannot be stopped with half-heartedness. What is needed is a clear advance of renewable energies before any fossil. With a cryptic 27% without national liabilities, there is no getting any further. We do not need a gas union. We need an Energy Union that combats greenhouse gases, that actually makes climate protection a first priority and that effectively protects consumers from energy poverty. The Commission is miles away from that.

name: Peter Eriksson (Verts/ALE).
text: Mr President, I would like to begin by congratulating Mr Gracias. I speak Swedish, I'm going to do that. I would like to thank the Commissioner. This is a very ambitious and important work that you have started in the Commission. I think you should be able to do it with even more confidence, because what has happened in recent years in the energy market is that we have had a revolution. The prices of renewable energy, wind energy and solar energy have fallen dramatically and this is changing the entire energy market. Especially if we implement what the Commission wants – to have a better interconnected energy system, where the whole of Europe can transport energy from different places. This allows us to invest where it is most efficient and also bring together competitive prices for the future. We should be able to stand up and talk about this as a proof of the future of the industry in the future as well. I therefore think that we should dare to say, more clearly, that we need to phase out coal. What I'm concerned about is the elephant in the room. You must have the courage to be clearer in this area, in order to have confidence in the other.

name: Roger Helmer (EFDD).
text: – Mr President, we seem to have developed a collective psychosis over electricity generation in Europe. Germany is building coal—fired power stations while we in my country, Britain, are closing them down. Germany is closing its nuclear fleet and France is cutting back, while we in Britain scramble to find Chinese funding for new nuclear capacity. But this is nothing compared to the disaster of our over—commitment to unreliable, intermittent and expensive renewables. We have forced up prices, undermined competitiveness and driven energy—intensive businesses out of Europe altogether, taking their jobs and their investment with them. As our colleague Antonio Tajani has said, we are creating an industrial massacre in Europe. The issues we are debating today – more flexibility, more interconnectors – may have merit in themselves, but compared to the crisis of competitiveness, we are merely fiddling at the margin. We are debating the wrong issues. As we say in my country: we are barking up the wrong tree.

name: Jean-Luc Schaffhauser (ENF).
text: Mr President, Commissioner, the Commission has made a mistake. I am not saying that you were wrong, I am saying that the Commission was wrong.  She was wrong about the concept of the energy market. It is a natural oligopoly where there are distortions of information, but you do not take into account the notion of power, the notion of capacity for peak consumption. You have also cut off the notions of production and distribution essential to the energy market, which is a natural oligopoly.  You were wrong about the notion of prioritizing environmental priorities, competition priorities and safety priorities. Security is first. You were wrong about the concepts of responsibility and solidarity. Responsibility, of course, is paramount to states. They are the ones who are responsible.  Today, you are faced with states that act alone. These are Great Britain, France, Germany and Nord Stream. No doubt you want to make an energy policy without France, without Germany, without Italy, without Great Britain. But who do you want to do it with?  The Commission was wrong about the concept of safety first. It was failing in the area of financial security. It is failing in the area of border security. It is now failing again in the field of energy security. It's a failure.

name: Janusz Korwin-Mikke (NI).
text: – (2) Mr President, I would like to begin by As a result of the various climate maniacs who have unfortunately mastered the European Union, we have energy three to four times more expensive than we might have, and we are sheding tears over the poor who do not have access to electricity. Since the time of Joseph Stalin, I have not heard as much about social justice as I have heard here. Well, as colleague Konrad Berkowicz says, poor people have a bigger problem than electricity. They don't have access to women. Women do not want to be associated with poor men.  I ask whether the European Commission wants to solve this problem in the framework of social justice as well? Well, I am afraid that this could happen, because in Poland there is an opinion about the European Union: come up with the greatest foolishness, and they will do it. Furthermore, I believe that the European Union should be destroyed.

name: Jerzy Buzek (PPE).
text: – (2) Mr President, I would like to begin by Mr Vice-President, I would like to thank the Rapporteur, Mr Schwa Thank you for your report. It is good that every year the European Commission will present such a report, because the European Parliament wants to have an impact on the management of this project. The first thing you have raised is that reducing greenhouse gas emissions should be done in a technologically neutral way, because our aim is to reduce emissions, not to eliminate one fuel or another. Secondly, consumer thinking is very right when building a common energy market, but our energy companies should also have fair access to the market and should compete in a sustainable way. And the third thing is diversification of energy sources, geopolitics. It can be said that one project – the nord stream expansion – brings together, as in the lens, the reasons why we need an Energy Union. I am concerned that the report does not contain such a clear statement as we heard here a month ago from Commissioner Cañete. Because there is only the provision "only projects that comply with the fundamental principles of the Energy Union" will receive support. What are the fundamental principles? And is nord stream expansion compatible with them? A month ago, the Commission had no doubt that it was not in agreement and that this project would never receive financial support or formal concessions from the European Union. (The speaker agreed to answer the question raised by raising the "blue card" (Article 162(8) of the Rules of Procedure))

name: Tibor Szanyi (S&D)
text: Blue card question. – Mr. Representative, I am a great admirer of the unheard-of work that you are doing personally in the field of European energy, but I would like to ask you respectfully: do you or your party have the courage to aim to get rid of all fossil fuels for a certain period of time, such as 2050, which, by the way, only emits carbon dioxide?

name: Jerzy Buzek (PPE)
text: answer to the question asked by raising the blue card. – I think that this is obviously possible in the long term, but we should not do it forcibly, too quickly, because our aim is to eliminate emissions, not a specific fuel. We have already made this mistake with first generation biofuels. We have wrong goals and ways of achieving these goals. Now we are withdrawing from first generation biofuels. So let us not hastily make similar decisions now. We reduce emissions, not necessarily specific fuels.

name: Flavio Zanonato (S&D).
text: Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, Vice-President Šefčovič and his report present us with an agenda of really important news, and I would like to say unprecedented. Credit should be given to this Commission for having put in place the conditions for the most ambitious draft revision, updating and simplification of European legislation in this area. The basic principles of this design, I believe, are broadly shared in this House.  The Eu ropean Union must remain a leader in the transition to a low-carbon economy; this transition must be socially sustainable and focused on real benefits for consumers and for the development of European industry; In building the Energy Union, Europe must continue to play its full role as a geopolitical player beyond its borders and, finally, and I will dwell on this, the Energy Union must be built on a basis of sound governance. On this point – governance – we must continue to look far ahead, we must think long-term. The system of governance of the Energy Union can be built minimally, that is, as the regulator of the decisions of the Member States in the form of the various national climate and energy plans, but it is much more far-sighted that the system of governance of the Energy Union is demanding and implements truly European choices, than being the sum of the national determinations made in the various capitals of Europe. This is also where the solutions to the problems that have been raised up to now are found, because here they can be dealt with and solved with a continental vision. We therefore applaud the Commission, but also a frank and direct call for governance to be closer to Europe and also to our Parliament.

name: Hans-Olaf Henkel (ECR).
text: Mr President, I would like to thank the Mr Vice-President, you have stated a number of objectives here, such as sustainable energy costs, security of supply, the decarbonisation of the economy, reliable energy sources and so on. Are you really aware that the German Federal Government's lonely decision to phase out nuclear energy is against all these objectives? Not only that, but it is also an act of insolidarity, because the Federal Government had not consulted any of its nine neighbours at all at the time. And it could not have done it at all if France had acted in a similar way, for example. I believe it is time for us to realise that there are now 400 nuclear power stations in the world, 70 new projects. That is why nuclear power must not be made a taboo. Incidentally – and now comes my well-known Ceterum censeo – I believe that the single euro in Europe only sows strife and discord and must therefore be abolished. (The speaker agreed to answer a question on the 'blue card' procedure under Rule 162(8) of the Rules of Procedure)

name: Klaus Buchner (Verts/ALE)
text: Question about the procedure of the "blue card". Mr Henkel, I would like to thank Mr Henkel for his work This phase-out of nuclear energy does not come from juxtaposition and madness.  It comes as two reasons: firstly, as we now see at Hinkley Point, nuclear energy is priceless. We pay far more for nuclear energy than for solar energy on large areas. My second point is that do you think that this number of deaths in the vicinity of nuclear power stations, which is clearly documented by statistics, is responsible, do you think that this is acceptable?

name: Hans-Olaf Henkel (ECR)
text: Answer to a question about the "blue card" procedure. First of all, I would like to point out that politicians should not get used to doing the business of fear. You have just done that again excellently. (Interjede by Klaus Buchner: Facts!) I do not believe that there is a risk of an earthquake in the North Sea and that a tsunami could sweep up the Elbe and the Rhine in order to damage German safe nuclear power stations. And as far as the view on the cost of nuclear power is concerned, you are quite right: this should indeed be left to the market.

name: Philippe De Backer (ALDE).
text: – The Energy Union is a very good initiative for me to finally start working on a single European energy market.  After all, we all know that the 28 small national networks, the 28 separate national regulators and the different forms of energy policy made in 28 countries are no longer sustainable. A genuine European energy strategy assumes that we are at least trying to work together and not take decisions that have an effect on others without discussing the consequences. That is why I am truly satisfied and can only welcome the fact that you are also ensuring a systematic follow-up with this State of the Energy Union. For me, it is especially important that we work quickly on clearly measurable objectives. A European regulator that follows that, an open and transparent market in which free competition can play and the stronger interconnecting of our networks to enable that market.  Investment security is crucial in this respect, because we need to move quickly to improve that connectivity and certainly the projects of common interest, such as the NEMO project between Belgium and the United Kingdom, must be given priority. It is clear that, as with migration policy or economic policy, we really need a European approach. We must stop the fragmentation. This is the only way consumers and businesses can benefit from affordable, secure and sustainable energy in the long term.

name: Paloma López Bermejo (GUE/NGL).
text: – Mr President, Commissioner, I have listened carefully to you and I share the Commission's concern about the possibility of reaching the 20% set for renewable generation.  You said that we will have to carry out and explain this strategy in our countries, but the truth is that, in the case of Spain, this is going to be very difficult when we have a government that has stood out for its retroactive cuts to the financing of renewables or for applying a tax on the sun; a government working in favour of the great oligopolies, which the European Union ignores in its analysis of the market, especially Spanish: it would be said that the Commission sees a pond but not the piranhas that are swimming in it.  New interconnectors or price liberalization are counterproductive when four companies continue to be allowed to manipulate their marginal costs or force the State to subsidize their fictitious, nuclear to combined cycle costs.  There is no need, without a doubt, another energy model: to bet on local savings and generation, from renewables to technological improvement of coal. Only then will we have an efficient and sovereign energy system.

name: Bas Eickhout (Verts/ALE).
text: – Mr President, I would like to thank Commissioner Šefčovič for pushing the Energy Union, because we know that one of the biggest problems we have in Europe, causing the high energy price, is the fragmented market. That is the real reason why the energy price is so high, and that is exactly what you are trying to address. But it really is time now – and you also say this in your plan – to act and not only to produce paper. We are looking forward to that, but therein lies the problem. Where is the Commission going to act to make sure that Europe as a whole is moving? A lot has been said about renewables and efficiency. I would like to address one of the biggest problems we have in Europe as well, and that is coal. Coal is one of the biggest problems we have in Europe, and we are subsidising it: every year coal companies in the EU get EUR 10 billion. So we are giving a lot of subsidies, and within the EU Emissions Trading Scheme (ETS) we are even giving free allowances until 2030. The EU is not leading on coal, and my very clear question to the Commission is this: what are you going to do, specifically, to make sure that our coal dependency goes down? (The speaker agreed to take a blue-card question under Rule 162(8))

name: Bill Etheridge (EFDD)
text: blue-card question. – I notice that you are complaining about high energy prices and you said that was due to a fragmented Europe, and you rail against subsidies to coal. Well, surely one of the main reasons for high energy prices is vast subsidies to renewables and not allowing a free market in energy when – certainly in Britain – we have massive amounts of coal that could be dug up and used. But instead of that, we are having to hit green targets and not dig it up but, in fact, actually to shut down coal production. Surely you reduce prices by giving the market more free rein, rather than following theories about global warming?

name: Bas Eickhout (Verts/ALE)
text: blue-card answer. – It is always fascinating to hear UKIP talk about these kinds of things as soon as ‘green’ is in it. Why exactly are you not making any point on the huge subsidy plans that are going to nuclear in Hinkley Point? Billions of euros you want to use to subsidise Hinkley nuclear. Is it not about time to start discussing that issue instead of the renewables where the prices go down, where people have own ownership of energy? That is something that you should strive for, instead of just going for centralised nuclear and big subsidies there. It is you who are barking up the wrong tree.

name: Rolandas Paksas (EFDD).
text: – Rolandas Paksas (EFDD). – The energy report tries to convince us that the European Union is still trying to speak with one voice on energy matters, but the real situation is completely different.  With a common determination to tackle energy problems, Europe has indeed turned its back on this objective and has been much more looking at how to meet the interests of individual European countries since the summer.  Gentlemen, but when you stop talking about a two-speed Europe in public, the problem has not disappeared anywhere. It is this faster Europe today that is looking at its interests, not a unified energy policy. For example, the agreement on a new gas pipeline with Russia on the bottom of the Baltic Sea – the so-called Nord Stream 2.  Five European companies from Germany, Austria, Great Britain, France and the Netherlands entered into the agreements in June. In September, contracts were signed for the establishment of the New European Pipeline Joint Undertaking, which will implement a pipeline development project of more than a thousand kilometres.  After such decisions, can we talk about a single energy market in Europe? Who is considered to be fools: MEPs, Parliamentarians of Community states or all the people of the Community who are spoken on their own and are being treated in the exact opposite way?  I propose that both the European Commission and the European Parliament distance themselves as soon as possible from such possible misunderstandings and not only to clearly identify European energy priorities, but also to respect them.

name: Gianluca Buonanno (ENF).
text: Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, in this Parliament we are talking about an Energy Union when we are unable to do monetary union, we are not capable of making the Union on the issues of terrorism, we are not capable of making the Union as far as immigration is concerned... and we want to be an energy Union, after the vast majority of you here have criticised and opposed Putin and do not want Russian gas to be transported to Europe. Now, however, Putin is comfortable because he goes to fight Isis, while here is a bunch of cowards who are afraid of Isis. Not to mention Germany, which demands everything. Do you know that 44% of the electricity in Germany is obtained from coal? Maybe because he likes Volkswagen? But this Europe is a Europe that sucks. Let us be ashamed of how this Europe is made! We have to be able to do things right. Instead, here in Parliament we are just great hypocrites: they say things and others are made.

name: Κωνσταντίνος Παπαδάκης (
text: NI). Mr President, today, given the development of science and technology, the finding of new sources, the new pipelines, what is the obstacle for people to enjoy cheap energy in order to have heating in winter, air conditioning in the summer, for energy workers to have labour rights, to reduce the energy dependence of countries such as Greece? The obstacle is the criterion of production. Capitalist profit. That is what the European Union and its governments serve. For example, in Greece, PPC is preparing new increases. It cuts power to thousands of popular households that are unable to pay.  Under the Energy Union with a timetable of 2019, energy is delivered to business groups, which will take off already inaccessible prices at the expense of working-class families.  This is the capital strategy that serves the profits of monopolies in the territory of fierce rivalries between the European Union, its Member States, Russia, China and the United States. This strategy to target their struggle, to overthrow it, to open a path of development based on popular needs.

name: Herbert Reul (PPE).
text: Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, I would like to thank the rapporteur for her excellent report and for the way in which After all, responsible energy policy means that we are as concerned with the issue of climate as we are with the question of competitiveness, with the question of what impact this has on jobs, what impact it has on industry, on the state's revenue through taxes. Especially at a time when we are talking about refugees and need funding, a realistic energy policy is one that takes both factors into account. In this respect, I think it is okay for you to present an annual report so that we can simply take stock, so that we can stop having everyone every day have a new plan for where the world should go. The race for higher numbers, higher percentages, new visions, and what else, quark, is real nonsense. We need a realistic energy policy, and that means how far the Member States have come and what needs to be done. And then decide pragmatically and not organize dream dancing. Pragmatically decide how we can do this with the expansion of the network. We are talking about this all the time, but what are we doing in practical terms? Why is no one building networks, why is that? Probably because it cannot make enough money. The question of what can be done is something that needs to be looked at. Or the question of promoting renewable energy with dozens of different pots in Europe. I think it is a good thing that a further step is now being taken to consider whether this cannot be concentrated on a Europe-wide level in a way that will ensure that the funds go where they are as effective as possible. Thirdly, it is a strength that the Member States have different energy mix concepts. That is not a weakness, it is a strength! I am against us talking to them just because there are some dream dancers on the way who say: nuclear energy is out of the question, coal is out of the question.

name: Theresa Griffin (S&D).
text: – Mr President, if properly implemented, the Energy Union strategy will benefit all EU Member States and citizens, who crucially need to be placed at centre stage, especially the energy-poor. I welcome the first stage of the Energy Union report published by the Commission last week, as I am particularly worried by the current situation in the UK. The state of the Energy Union highlights that the UK is failing to hit a 2013 interim target for renewable energy and is in serious danger of failing to meet the binding 2020 target. This is really unacceptable. The report also rightly claims that the UK needs to assess whether their policies and tools are sufficient and effective in meeting their renewable energy objectives. I am sure I am not alone in thinking that currently they are not. The UK Government policy on renewable energy is regressive, and there is a real danger that the UK will end up buying renewable energy from other countries, rather than growing the green jobs that the UK and our young people so desperately need. The UK Government urgently needs to modify its strategy and develop policy measures to promote energy efficiency – the first fuel – and renewables. This is precisely what the Energy Union is about: building a new, clean and secure energy system which is affordable to all EU citizens.

name: Ashley Fox (ECR).
text: – Mr President, the best way to ensure energy security for the whole of Europe and the lowest prices for our citizens is a properly integrated gas and electricity market. I want consumers and businesses in my constituency to be able to buy their energy from any company in the EU. Continued investment in infrastructure is key to securing sustainable and low-cost energy across the EU. I was pleased to see the Commission approve a number of infrastructure projects within the report, particularly new interconnection capacity between the United Kingdom and Ireland, France and Belgium. I urge the Commissioner to maintain his focus on infrastructure investment and give investors the regulatory certainty they need. Improving inter-connection also increases energy security. I want the European gas market to be so well connected that even if Mr Putin turns off the gas taps, we can supply the whole of the continent, businesses can keep going and no one will go cold in the winter.

name: Pavel Telička (ALDE).
text: – Mr President, I would like to thank the Vice-President for his introductory remarks and also for the reassurance that 2016 will be the year of deliveries. We will be happy to provide a helping hand in this respect. But in order to achieve energy union, I believe that we need a reform of the electricity market; and in order to do so, with the new market design, I think we need three elements to be in mutual balance. The first one is – and we need to pay really extraordinary attention to it – to provide for a secure integration of decentralised and renewable resources into the electro-energetic systems, and also to create appropriate conditions for those consumers that do produce energy for their own private consumption. The second element is that we need to renew the price signals to investors and thereby secure a sufficient amount and volume of energy resources. The third one would be to make sure that whatever measures we do enact, they will not overburden the end consumer and will not have a negative impact on competitiveness. One final remark goes outside the market design, and that is Nord Stream. I do appreciate what you have said on Nord Stream 2, but we will still have an infrastructure which, in fact, should always serve the strategic purpose of all EU Member States and the new neighbourhood. In this respect I think that Parliament will be strong in its next message.

name: João Ferreira (GUE/NGL).
text: – Mr President, Commissioner, first of all we would like to regret the fact that, when we are discussing this report, it is not yet available in all the official languages of the European Union, but only in German, English and French. The Commissioner will tell us why this is the case, but perhaps this is the best evidence of the interests that inspire the common energy market and the so-called Energy Union – a project tailored to the major European monopolies of the sector. In essence, these reports are nothing but your specifications. They are the ones to dictate the rules, both at the level of infrastructure development or at the level of the much-coveted integration of markets.  It follows that the answer to watery issues such as improving energy efficiency, diversification of sources, progress in renewables, sustainable exploitation of each country's endogenous potential, security of supply, among many other issues, the answer to these issues requires planning and public, democratic, energy sector, energy production and distribution of energy. This is the first big change we have to make.

name: Bronis Ropė (Verts/ALE).
text: – I think you will all agree that unity, solidarity and speaking with one voice in relations with third countries must be a fundamental principle of the European Union's energy policy. These values must also be built on the basis of the Energy Union. The Energy Union will only be strong if projects such as Nord Stream 2 are assessed holistically. And this will be done in a pre-emetive way, not when the gas pipelines are already built and operational, increasing the European Union's dependence on a single gas supplier. The citizens of the European Union, especially in Central and Eastern Europe, believe in the European Union and its unity. Projects such as Nord Stream 2 can seriously undermine this faith. So we expect and demand urgent and firm action from the Commission, in this case, to confirm that the vision of the European Energy Union is not just empty words.

name: David Coburn (EFDD).
text: – Mr President, we in UKIP reject a revision of the damaging EU ETS system. We believe that the EU Commission should recognise that the entire EU energy project has failed, causing higher energy prices in all Member States. Its policy has caused job losses, plant closures and a massive outflow of industry and investment to outside the EU. We oppose this proposal as we believe that neither EU climate policy nor the new Energy Union proposal is a solution to resolve the severe difficulties faced by industries in Europe, and Britain in particular. It is now clear that the EU’s obsessive green energy policy, together with a lack of regulatory coherence, has created great difficulties for all energy industries in Europe. Europe needs to become competitive – a strange word for you lot – but competitive, improve its resources, create jobs and increase productivity. Currently, unaffordable investment policy is damaging British industry and economy. Brussels must recognise that its energy policy has failed to deliver legal certainty to investors. Whilst threatening the free market system of investment and production, further EU illogical over-regulation will not promote the industrialisation of Europe; it will no doubt announce the end of it.

name: Λάμπρος Φουντούλης (
text: NI). Mr President, the European Union is at a critical time when it comes to its energy issues. In an environment of global instability, European peoples cannot afford to be dependent on fuel from the most dangerous zones on the planet. It is a fact that despite the relative reduction in pollutant emissions in Europe in recent years, levels are still very high with the known disastrous consequences for the environment.  Firstly, member states where, in recent years, usable hydrocarbon deposits, such as Greece and Cyprus have been found, should be strengthened in order to reduce dependence on third countries and to shield ourselves from price changes. On the issue of natural gas, Europe, which is heavily energy dependent on Russia, continuing its anti-Russian European policy, wants to import through Greece American LNG from shale gas, as agreed at political level during Prime Minister Alexis Tsipras' recent visit to America.  We must stop the sterile rivalry with Russia and look more at what unites us and not what may divide us. Closer cooperation between Member States and a shift towards those renewable or inexhaustible energy sources that are truly reliable and can guarantee energy autonomy and self-sufficiency, both at Union and State level, is needed.

name: András Gyürk (PPE).
text: – Mr President, I would like to talk about one aspect of a thorough and good Commission report, the question of competitiveness. European industry is suffering from high energy prices and regulatory burdens. A reduction in energy prices is essential to increase the competitiveness of the European economy. However, the road to a competitive European industry at low energy prices is often very bumpy. Allow me to cite Hungary as an example, where industrial consumers pay for gas above the OECD average, even though the country has invested hundreds of millions of euros in new infrastructure development in recent years. It has also built a new link to three neighbouring countries and built a two-way link to Ukraine.  Hungary has therefore done much to diversify and thus make gas prices competitive, yet we cannot see the results. This is because some of the new infrastructure is still operating in one direction, outwards from Hungary, and there are still no new sources available in the region, no diversification, no competitive prices. The solution, of course, is, on the one hand, to implement the missing bidirectionals and, on the other hand, to build the LNG terminal in Croatia, so that there is gas competition in the region. The lesson is that we can only reap the benefits of the single market if all actors strive to contribute to common goals. Only then can European industry be globally competitive.

name: Martina Werner (S&D).
text: Mr President, I would like to thank the In the first year of the Energy Union, the Commission has focused very much on cooperation with Member States, which is also very positive. However, only two legislative proposals have been submitted to Parliament. I would have liked to have had a little more vigour and assertiveness, for example in setting the energy and climate targets for 2030, for example in the national energy and climate plans, which the Member States must, yes, or, let us say, draw up.  So far, the focus has only been on voluntary action, and I think it will be difficult for us to get closer to the Energy Union. After all, energy diplomacy does not replace laws. I would also have liked to see a little more assertiveness in terms of the diversification strategy. There has not yet been a political breakthrough for gas supplies from Azerbaijan and Turkmenistan. So my question is this: what has the Commission achieved in the last year for greater diversification? What concrete alternatives do we have to Russian gas in the short term? It is always very easy to criticise the Nord Stream project. I still do not have the alternative proposals here. We are in a relationship of interdependence with Russia – with ups and downs, but the gas is being delivered.  There is, of course, no question that Russia must play by the rules of the game in Europe. But apropos rules of the game: these always apply, of course, to all EU Member States and not just to the issue of gas imports.

name: Николай Бареков (ECR).
text: – Commissioner, I am astonished to learn from the European Commission's report that you have included, in addition to Nord Stream-2 and Turkish Stream, as a priority of the European Commission rather than South Stream, which your Commission has suspended.  Why did you doom the Bulgarian people from the poorest Member State of the European Union to absolute and total dependence on Russian and Turkish gas at the same time? What is the guarantee that Turkey, which will buy Russian gas, will not sell it at any price on the Bulgarian, European market and as Turkish gas? Why did you support Nord Stream-2 and not work, as promised, for the resumption of the Nabucco project, which would supply Iranian gas to Europe and Bulgaria as an alternative to Russian gas?  Behind the backs of the Bulgarian people, Germany and Mrs Merkel are clearly very well negotiated with Mr Putin. The Commission's behaviour is indeed hypocritical and undermines the trust of Europe's citizens in the European Commission and in building a future common energy market and union.

name: Nils Torvalds (ALDE).
text: Mr President, I would like to begin by congratulating Mr Commissioner Šefčovič, i would like to thank you for your support. And all four of our audiences are up in the stands. One of the objectives of the Energy Union is to move away from a fossil fuel economy. This, in turn, will require strategic planning, and on this particular point the EUROPEAN Union does not always achieve its objectives. We have rather bad experience in the negotiations where the Council was unable to set the concrete objectives. The Commission is currently preparing a legislative package on renewable and sustainable energy, bioenergy. We'll get that next year for treatment. When we come to measures to bring about these changes, we know that we can now introduce, for technical reasons, a percentage of interference for petrol, a so-called blending mandate on the E20, i.e. 20% involvement. We can also introduce the corresponding targets in the area of diesel. When we put these in place, we must be aware that it must be done in small steps in order for the industry to somehow agree and so that it does not lead to us doing something that then in turn leads to Brazil or Indonesia encountering even greater problems with their forest areas. We therefore need concrete measures and a firm policy.

name: Lynn Boylan (GUE/NGL).
text: – Mr President, it is disappointing that the Commission’s energy strategy is weak in its proposals for a move to a low—carbon economy. We must shift the balance of energy needs to renewables and underline the absolute need for ambitious targets for efficiency. Last week’s State of the Energy Union Report by the Commissioner unfortunately seems to equate energy security with a ramping—up of gas and nuclear. Simply diversifying and changing gas suppliers ignores options which are safer politically and better for the climate. The Commission seems to favour a network of pipelines transporting gas, including via that bastion of human rights, Erdoǧan’s Turkey. The Commissioner speaks of putting energy first, but has already hamstrung ambitious targets and has gone against the principle of mutual respect between the institutions since this Parliament backed a 40% target in October. Perhaps I should not be surprised at the feebleness of the plan for energy and the climate, given that four out of every five meetings of the Climate and Energy Commissioners were with lobbyists for private energy and fossil fuel companies. (The speaker agreed to take a blue-card question under Rule 162(8))

name: David Coburn (EFDD)
text: blue-card question. – Would you agree with me that Professor James Lovelock, the great grandfather of all the Greens, has reluctantly come round to the idea that we must have nuclear energy as a stopgap before we move onto other things? Would you not agree with me that perhaps he was right? I know that the Lefties have given him the same treatment as the late Trotsky (who they seem to have fallen out with as well), but surely Professor Lovelock was right, was he not?

name: Lynn Boylan (GUE/NGL)
text: blue-card answer. – Absolutely not; I do not support nuclear energy. When we talk about barking up the wrong tree with our UKIP colleagues, I hope there is a tree high enough when the country is sinking due to climate change.

name: Indrek Tarand (Verts/ALE).
text: – Mr President, I would like to thank the Commissioner for giving us the opportunity to debate the energy issues – the new tool in the kit, Commissioner, as you said. But it is important to be careful that this tool does not turn out to be a toy, and that is why I would like to add my voice also to the chorus of those who have been objecting and criticising Nord Stream. Because Nord Stream is not so much about diversifying our portfolio and reducing coal production; it is nakedly about cutting off Ukraine first, and then Poland and other countries second, from the supply lines and thereby finishing the whole independence of Ukraine. So Commissioner and dear colleagues, just as we stopped the stupid French crazy idea to sell Mistral warships to Russia, we must now stop these awkward gas traders.

name: Pilar del Castillo Vera (PPE).
text: – Mr President, Mr Vice-President, consumers are a key player in the single energy market or the Energy Union. I will refer to three key areas that can actively contribute. First, price and cost transparency, because more information allows for a better decision.  Secondly, interoperability, for which standards are fundamental, and portability, because choosing or switching suppliers strengthens competition in the energy market, without the minor obstacles that still exist for that to occur. And thirdly, digitization: first, to develop intelligent networks that facilitate more efficiency in connection and distribution; and, second, to incorporate digital technologies that enable efficient management of individual consumption. In short, a more competitive market, strengthening information, interoperability and portability, together with digitisation, will determine the best consumer participation in the European energy market. Without consumers, this development of the Energy Union will actually be much more difficult and an actor will be lacking, a fundamental element.

name: Zigmantas Balčytis (S&D).
text: – Despite the important decisions taken in the past in the field of energy, many difficult challenges remain ahead of the full integration of the electricity and gas networks.  The Commission's report underlined the importance of important projects in the Baltic region, which will end the isolation of the Baltic gas markets. Klaipėda Liquefied Natural Gas Terminal and its role in creating a supply alternative for the first time in history in the Baltic gas market.  However, I would like to point out that Lithuania has built the Klaipeda terminal independently, without the direct support of the European Union. This project has not been included in the list of strategic items, although it is a strategic object for the whole region. But, of course, it is an expensive project for One Lithuania, but Lithuania did not want to depend on one gas source from the east for another 15 years under the previous Commission's proposals and pay a 30% higher price, but it wanted greater energy security and reached its own. This coincides with the objectives of the Energy Union and, for the sake of justice, not only political but also European financial support for this project should be provided.  I also want to ask why the Baltic region is seeking to reduce its dependence on gas from Russia, and part of the European Union is increasingly being clamped down on russia's gas supply network?  Commissioner, although you say that Nord Stream 2 is a project of common interest, commercial projects must also be in line with the European Union's energy objectives. Dependence on gas does not mean a reduction in electricity. The European Commission should make proposals for the development of additional electricity generation capacity in the Member States, as the question arises that the networks we have built will not be a pathway to further importing from ... (language incomplete).

name: Ryszard Czarnecki (ECR).
text: – (2) Mr President, I would like to begin by Commissioner, i would like to thank you for your comments. I have the impression that for the European Union the best common energy policy is the absence of a common energy policy. Let's look at reality: recently, information about the second strand of Nord Stream – the Northern Gas Pipeline. And here we are in a situation where we in Parliament can talk to each other and talk about a common EU energy policy, and then the big companies are doing their thing, they have what we are saying here, or what the Commission is saying. So there are two realities – this is some kind of political schizophrenia, although I have the impression that these big corporations are protected by some governments of the Member States, such as the German Government. It just needs to change.

name: Gerben-Jan Gerbrandy (ALDE).
text: – Mr President, from the far left to the far right, we are all concerned about jobs and growth in the European Union, and rightly so. Let’s face it: the competitiveness of our industry is also one of the central themes in the whole debate on the Energy Union, and it is obvious that Europe needs cheap, clean and independent energy. Desperately clinging to our fossil past will definitely not create competitiveness in the future. We see that new disruptive technologies are overhauling Europe’s energy system. Prices of solar technology are dropping sharply and energy efficiency is decoupling economic growth from our energy use. Key to affordable energy is giving certainties to investors. Energy infrastructure requires large, risky capital-intensive investments, and only governance arrangements based on EU legal mechanisms can create this stability and predictability. The current Energy Union is still far away from legislative action based on democratic decision-making. The Energy Union is, unfortunately, based on voluntary submissions from Member States, and the Commission should be more ambitious here. But the main obstacle is again the Member States. They seem to prefer having full ownership of their own national energy policies with expensive pollutive energy systems to being part of a full-scale European approach with astronomical benefits, and the absence of the Council here today is exemplary. Let us care about jobs and growth in Europe and push our Member States towards a true European Energy Union.

name: Νικόλαος Χουντής (
text: GUE/NGL). Mr President, Commissioner, you have presented us with the state of the Energy Union based on the same failed model of privatisation that cannot guarantee for our countries, nor energy security, nor the reduction of economic and environmental costs, nor the fight against energy poverty. Commissioner, the troika's demand in Greece is moving in the same direction, both in the first memorandum and in the recent discussions, in the discussions now taking place with the Greek Government, which call for the privatisation of the Public Electricity Company and the energy networks. Something that the Greek economy and Greek consumers will pay dearly.  So I ask you, Commissioner, why do you insist on the privatisation of the country's transport networks, as today's reports say, by 66%?  And yet, shouldn't the Commission finally stop imposing such disastrous policies in the name of economic interests and geopolitical aspirations that are detriment to the Greek public interest and consumers in Greece?

name: Peter Liese (PPE).
text: Mr President, Mr Vice-President of the Commission, ladies and gentlemen, I would like to thank the rapporteur for his excellent report and for the way in which she has been rapporteur for his excellent work. We have huge problems in Europe and in the Member States, such as terrorism and the refugee problem. Some may wonder why we are discussing the issue of energy, first and foremost the decarbonisation of the energy industry. I believe that this is true, firstly because there are many reasons, but because we also have direct links to our major problems of terrorism and refugees. The Islamic State, which threatens Europe, already owns oil wells and sells the oil, thereby also financing terrorism. A strong source of Islamic State funding is that rich Saudis and wealthy Qataris are supplying the money there. Where did they come from? Also because we have such a great hunger for energy. That is why part – not the whole strategy, but a part – of the strategy against the Islamic State is also to become more independent of imports from this area. When I raise the issue of refugees, it is certainly the case that we have to act very much in the area of climate protection so that we do not have large flows of refugees. That is why what the Commission is doing is right. However, I would like to encourage them to go one step further in terms of energy efficiency, from 27% to higher. And I would encourage them not to take a step without the European Parliament. Everything that has been in codecision up to now must also remain in codecision. There must be no new methods of governance that Parliament omits. (The speaker agreed to answer a question on the 'blue card' procedure under Rule 162(8) of the Rules of Procedure)

name: Paul Rübig (PPE)
text: Question about the procedure of the "blue card".
