Mr Liese, I would like to thank Mr Liese for his We are always talking about sustainable energy supply, and this is also about lifetime cycle costs, for example in the case of nuclear installations, but also, of course, in the case of fossil installations. We have seen that, if you look at it over the entire cost range – from refugees to terrorists – the cost of importing fossil fuels also includes, of course, external costs, which, if we look to the future, can become a major problem for us. How do you feel about this?

name: Peter Liese (PPE)
text: Answer to a question about the "blue card" procedure. Yes, I like to go into it. I believe that this is a very important point that we need to focus more on, that we see not only the direct costs, but also the indirect costs. Let me take an example of what the Commission now needs to calculate very precisely when it comes to energy efficiency. So far, the Commission has come up with relatively few ambitious figures: 27%, because it has taken into account very high discount rates. So she assumes that people don't do something that would actually make sense over the life cycle, for example, to insulate their house or buy a new heating system, because they can't find a suitable craftsman. I think that's our job as a policy to empower people to save over the cycle. If there are obstacles, then we must remove these obstacles and not say that it will not work.

name: José Blanco López (S&D).
text: – Mr President, Spain's national reform plan announced 17.1% compliance with the 20% renewable energy target by 2020, but both Eurostat and the European Commission consider the actual figure to be 15.8%, or 1.3% lower than what the Government announced.  Worryingly, however, that, having recognized the need to install 8 537 megawatts of renewable energy to meet the 20% target, the Spanish Government has only planned an auction of 700 megawatts.  Under these conditions, there is no time for renewable energy to meet the targets set. The National Market and Competition Commission itself considers this unlikely, bearing in mind that after the retroactive cut there have been no new investments in 2014 and 2015. Commissioner, the report on the situation of the Energy Union, presented today, warns Spain of the desirability of assessing its policies, whether they are sufficient and effective in meeting the renewable energy targets.  That is why I ask you the following question: Do you plan to wait until 2019 to warn of an advertised non-compliance or will you take some preventive measures to ensure that Spain meets the 20% renewable energy target by 2020?

name: Νότης Μαριάς (
text: ECR). Mr President, the Commission's report on the state of progress of the Energy Union and my country Greece is particularly interesting. Commissioner, the report rightly notes that Greece can become a regional energy hub both in terms of the electricity market and in terms of gas. This can only be done, however, if PPC is strengthened rather than discredited and ADMIE remains public property with a public administration.  At the same time, my country must make use of all its energy reserves, namely renewable energy sources and our mineral wealth in the Ionian and Aegean and south of Crete. Recent discoveries of deposits in Egypt and Cyprus strengthen this strategy. The construction of at least one additional LNG plant is particularly important in terms of the route, while the strengthening of the multiple southern energy corridors, which will pass through Greece, is an immediate priority.  All this must, of course, be done away from the long arm of the troika and the lenders, with the benefit of our people in mind for their well-being and the eradication of energy poverty.

name: José Inácio Faria (ALDE).
text: – Mr President, Commissioner, ladies and gentlemen, there is still much to do for the Energy Union to materialise in economic benefits for families, lowering energy costs and, for businesses, enabling them to be more competitive in the global market. The potential for job creation in the renewable energy and energy efficiency sector is also enormous. We must n't give up on him. Several Member States have done their homework on advancing the integration of renewable energy. Some of these renewable sources are already competitive in terms of generation costs. Those same Member States cannot now be penalised for the lack of adequate infrastructure to connect to the European internal market, which imposes unnecessary costs on it. The 10 % interconnection target is therefore essential, as is it essential that this objective is binding, especially in geographical regions where the minimum level of interconnection is decades behind, such as the Iberian Peninsula. I would remind you that the lack of interconnections is now a real obstacle to more investment in clean energy. We are on the eve of COP 21 and Europe needs to step up its focus on decarbonising the economy. Commissioner, I said that we started this well in 2015, but that 2016 will be the year of implementation. I hope, Commissioner, that your wish will be fulfilled and I support you for it... (The President withdraws his word to the speaker)

name: Miloslav Ransdorf (GUE/NGL).
text: – Mr President, the Energy Union is mainly a matter of energy security. I have four such short notes.  The first concerns the need for diversification of resources. We cannot be dependent only on a limited number of resources, and we need to participate in the economic adoption of Siberia together with the Russian Federation and to eliminate dependence on politically unstable areas.  The second point concerns nuclear energy. The Energy Security of the European Union cannot be without nuclear energy, and here everything really needs to be done to increase the share of the core.  The third note concerns inter connectivity. It showed at the time of the gas crisis in 2009 how crucial this is. The European Union has not made much progress in this regard so far, and everything really needs to be done to make progress in this area of inter connectivity.  The fourth note applies to stacks. It is necessary to have reserves of energy sources for the period of possible crisis, for the time of unforeseen events. That's a lesson from 2009, too.

name: Владимир Уручев (PPE).
text: – Mr President, colleagues, Commissioner, it is commendable that the Commission continues to work at a high pace on the issue of the Energy Union. Last week's communications on the state of this alliance make its outlines and objectives increasingly clear.  I welcome the Commission's initiative for concrete measurable indicators to track progress. However, these indicators are not for exposing individual Member States, but to identify activities and regions where more common efforts need to be focused on achieving the objectives in a timely manner. There is no doubt that the backbone of the Energy Union is the creation of a single energy market, which is currently almost completely fragmented. In this regard, the fastest results are achieved through the targeted creation of regional energy markets.  In this regard, taking into account good examples of regional cooperation in northern Europe, I recommend that the Commission focus more on the area of South-East Europe, where eu-wide efforts are clearly needed both to eliminate existing vulnerability and to diversify gas supply sources and routes throughout the European Union, including from own sources.

name: Carlos Zorrinho (S&D).
text: – Mr President, Commissioner, on the eve of the Climate Summit in Paris, the Energy Union is making progress and making its way. This is in itself excellent news and a reason for us to proceed even more vigorously. The European Union and the world need a robust and credible Energy Union. We must therefore move forward in all the strategic dimensions of the agenda and we must involve European citizens in a debate that will lead to concrete actions that have a concrete impact on their lives. This involvement needs clear and transparent information. The public debate on the Renewables Directive has to be based on free access to all relevant information on the direct and indirect costs of the various options. It is also important to improve on statistics, pricing, providing relevant information on energy security, nuclear safety, oil reserves, energy efficiency, consumption trends.  We need, to lead the energy transition, political intelligence, mobilize citizens, mobilize businesses, have regulatory flexibility, convergence of efforts between the 28 countries and ability to attract investment. And here, Commissioner, we're going to have to be able to mobilise the Strategic Investment Fund, the European Strategic Investment Fund. And the answer will have to be unequivocal, quick and appropriate to responsibilities. It is also very important to have interconnections, because without them there will be energy islands, and without a single energy market, there will be no energy union.

name: Anneleen Van Bossuyt (ECR).
text: – Do we want to meet the climate targets? Do we want green energy? Do we want to be independent in the field of energy? I think the answer is: loud and clear three times yes. But we also have to be realistic. So let us not use this mid-term review to slap ourselves in the chest. We need an ambitious policy, but above all a realistic policy. My region, Flanders, is doing well, but there are also limits for our small and densely populated region. Our potential is at sea. But off shore wind energy is very expensive. Who's going to pay for that? Are we going to pass the bill back on to the consumer? Eurorealism also means being able to choose the right priorities. First things first. And with a view to 2020 and 2030, it is important to stress, among other things, that the volatility of renewable energy calls for more connections between Member States and the development of new storage options.

name: Kaja Kallas (ALDE).
text: – Mr President, the main message of this report is very clear: it is that a lot has been done, but also a lot more needs to be done. Vice-President, you rightly point out that the electricity grids and gas pipelines are the backbone of the integrated energy markets, so what is absolutely key in this process is to identify the right projects to be cofinanced and supported from the European Union level. So we should say ‘no’ to all these projects that further protect national energy sovereignty, and ‘yes’ to projects that will improve energy security not only for the countries concerned, but also their neighbouring countries. Balticconnector is a good example of this. It is a gas pipeline between Finland and Estonia that will also improve gas supply for neighbouring countries and decrease our dependence on Russian gas. Another good example is the synchronisation of networks with Central European networks.

name: Seán Kelly (PPE).
text: – A Uachtaráin, ba mhaith liom cúpla focal a rá ar an ábhar tábhachtach seo agus díriú ar chúpla pointe ach go háirithe.  Firstly, I welcome the proposals from the Commission to date on Energy Union. This is absolutely vital for Europe, particularly the point that we need to utilise our resources within Europe as far as possible. In relation to renewables, these are obviously something that most people would desire, but we need also to create a climate where the fear that has taken place amongst many people in the public can be allayed so that they can see renewables as something environmentally very good – good for our resources and particularly good for them. Secondly, I also welcome the proposals to diversify supply where we have to import, and particularly the recent proposals on LNG. We have seen the effects in Lithuania, and I am glad that the Commission mentioned a project in my own constituency – Shannon LNG, which has had difficulties up to now, but being part of the European strategy hopefully means it can now get off the ground – because, first of all, LNG diversifies supply and, secondly, it is the ideal mix with renewables. This is particularly true for Shannon, because it is so close to America, and with that market probably coming on stream, this will be vital in the future. Finally, I would just like to say that I will be representing Parliament in Paris at the COP 21. We need a binding agreement, and an agreement where all the big emitters play their part, because we do not want a situation where we have a result that leads to carbon leakage from Europe.

name: Miroslav Poche (S&D).
text: – Mr President, I agree with all the previous leaders who say that the Energy Union project has already brought about a number of positive changes this year and has certainly had tangible results. Next year, some of your key proposals will be presented, such as the revision of the Energy Efficiency Directive, building efficiency or renewables.  However, let me mention two areas where, in my opinion, progress is not entirely sufficient. One of them, and one of the biggest problems of the Energy Union, is that the price of electricity to end consumers is the highest globally in the European Union, perhaps with the exception of Japan. And I think that, given that this has significant implications for a number of industries that are exposed to strong foreign competition, the Energy Union should change that. It should contribute rapidly to bring European prices closer to the global average, which would increase our competitiveness and reduce household costs.  The second area to be mentioned is how the Energy Union will be managed. How do we want it to have real results? Many of the initiatives we are discussing are non-binding. For example, in the area of energy efficiency, which is one of our key priorities and is a pillar of the project. It is a sign of a lack of ambition and also of political will. At the same time, we lack a unified yet comprehensive proposal on how the whole project will be financed and from what sources.

name: Jadwiga Wiśniewska (ECR).
text: – (2) Mr President, I would like to begin by The Energy Union is another incarnation of climate policy, which has the consequence of lowering energy security, reducing the competitiveness of European industry, escaping emissions and thus increasing unemployment, increasing energy poverty caused by high electricity prices.  Commissioner, you are talking about energy solidarity. On the Polish, I would like to express this alleged solidarity to you: firstly, the Energy Union is betting on decarbonisation, the consequences of which will most severely affect the Polish coal-based economy. Secondly, is it for the sake of energy security and energy solidarity that the Commissioner did not oppose Nord Stream-2? The absence of such an objection will prove that both energy security and energy solidarity are just an empty slogan and evidence of hypocrisy for you. The priority should be ...  (The President received the speaker's vote.)

name: Andrzej Grzyb (PPE).
text: – (2) Mr President, I would like to begin by Commissioner, i would like to thank you for your comments. For my country, the Energy Union would like to be an important project. It is above all energy security, security of supply, the common market – it should be an integration project.  Secondly, we have a climate policy. The Energy Union cannot be just an extension and complement, there should be synergies between them, but an energy union 100% subordinate to climate policy does not add value.  Thirdly, the Energy Union must reflect the differences between countries: for example, in terms of the energy mix, even the presence of coal. It would be wrong if she imposed one model on everyone. Instead, we should use the strengths of individual countries for the common good. Let's eliminate emissions, not fuel!  Fourthly, we criticise Nord Stream. Why? For the overarching principle should be not to support projects that may shake up the common market, including in the regulatory sphere, or to negatively affect countries not involved in the project, such as the Baltic States or neighbouring countries, such as Ukraine.  Fifthly, we need diversification of supply, infrastructure to dismantle energy islands. Here I would like to show a model of cooperation, Polish the Baltic States. Energy policy should serve to rebuild industry, jobs, but it should also be consumer-friendly.

name: Edouard Martin (S&D).
text: Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, Europe's energy is in crisis. We are in a lose-lose situation. Wholesale prices are generally too low to give energy companies investment prospects, but this trend does not benefit the end consumer, whether residential or industrial. Because, in retail, tariffs are often increased in a variable but considerable way, which weighs on the purchasing power of households and the balance sheet of companies. Relying on the market alone to solve everything would not make sense.  I do not believe that it is the invisible hand of the market that can multiply interconnections, replace our fossil power plants with renewable energies, insulate our buildings or accelerate research and development. Nor will the market alone guarantee us a prominent place on the industrial side of the energy transition. I want to prove our collective bankruptcy on the photovoltaic panel file.  Since there is no point in expecting the market to trigger this transition movement, it must be stimulated by European political impulses. The governance component will not be the easiest to negotiate because without treaty revisions how can national sovereignty and pan-European interests be reconciled? National energy plans would be a step forward in coordination, but let us not repeat the mistakes made with the European Semester and national reform programmes that are often considered too bureaucratic and not democratic enough. I therefore sincerely hope that this complex watchmaking will take place at a time of new challenges facing us in order to enable Europe to finally detach itself from its external energy dependencies and to continue to play a leading role in the fight against climate change.

name: Henna Virkkunen (PPE).
text: – Mr President, the objectives of the Energy Union – increasing self-sufficiency, reducing energy dependence, reducing dependence on imported energy, cutting emissions, functioning markets – are all extremely important objectives. However, I would particularly like to draw attention to one sector, which Commissioner Šefčovič briefly mentioned in that introductory speech. It's the transport sector. If we want to reduce oil dependency and the use of fossil fuels, we must also pay more attention to transport. It is responsible for a third of energy consumption throughout Europe, and we know that transport is very dependent on oil: 94% of transport still uses oil.  Europe has every opportunity to become a pioneer in clean transport in the world. It can be done in a very cost-effective way. We already have a lot of opportunities at the moment. We have advanced biofuels, electricity, hydrogen. New technologies are constantly emerging. It is important that we set targets, realistic targets, while encouraging companies to invest and develop new innovations in the field of clean transport. If we succeed in this, Europe will succeed in taking the lead in the world and our own industry could benefit significantly from it. I therefore encourage you, Commissioner, also more vigorously to tackle the transport sector in particular. There are many opportunities for the whole of Europe. (The speaker agreed to answer the blue card question (Rule 162(8)).

name: Maria Grapini (S&D)
text: Question put in accordance with the 'blue card' procedure. – Mr President, dear colleague, of course we agree that we need an Energy Union. My question to you is: do you believe that the Commission's report is putting enough emphasis on protecting vulnerable consumers by applying this strategy? Don't you think there should be a red thread in the legislative package so as not to exacerbate poverty?

name: Henna Virkkunen (PPE)
text: answer to the blue card question. – The functioning energy market in Europe is, of course, also in the interests of consumers. As legislator, we must set targets and ensure that competition works in Europe. We will build links so that there will be no energy islands in Europe, and this will strengthen the internal energy market, improve competition, increase transparency and also increase consumers' ability to make choices on energy. I think these are balanced with each other.

name: Miriam Dalli (S&D).
text: – Mr President, I would like to commend the Vice-President on the Energy Union tour because, when he was in Malta, I could see at first hand his efforts to bring the Energy Union closer to its citizens. It is precisely this point: citizens should remain at the heart of the Energy Union. They need to be empowered to make the right decisions, and this goes hand in hand with our fight against energy poverty and also with climate change. With high energy prices, the most vulnerable are always the worst hit. In Malta we know what a difference a significant reduction in electricity prices can make for consumers, whilst it gets the economy going as well. In this regard, we need a properly-functioning electricity market design which can help consumers control their energy consumption and production alike – one that can integrate properly all market players, including consumers as renewable energy providers, ultimately contributing to climate change action. If we keep our citizens at the core of our decisions, we can truly make 2016 the key year of delivery.

name: Janusz Lewandowski (PPE).
text: – (2) Mr President, I would like to begin by I will try not to repeat too much of what has been said for the two hours of discussion in this House. The Energy Union is different from other european unions that are founded within the European Union – namely, for example, the fiscal or banking union – that its importance goes far beyond economic issues. It is not just about the competitiveness of the economy, that is, prices – energy prices, which also determine the competitiveness of the economy. Nor is it just about protecting the environment. Indeed, security is at stake, an important thing in our unstable times – that is, the continuity of energy supply on a continent that is and will depend on external sources of energy generation. The very circumstances of the birth of this concept, namely the conflict in Ukraine or the use of gas as a tool of political blackmail, demonstrate the importance of security. And this has its own internal dimension, a little-tested – so-called interconnectivity – technical premise of solidarity between European countries. And a much more difficult external dimension – coordination of 28 countries in relations with external suppliers, especially with a single dominant supplier.  But if so, the credibility of the European institutions will indeed also be a measure of the reference to initiatives such as South Stream, now Nord Stream. This is a question not only of diversification, but also of the credibility of the European institutions. I wish you good luck.

name: Jeppe Kofod (S&D).
text: – Mr President, to realise the full potential of the Energy Union, both strong regulatory powers and ambitious targets are needed. We need a strong, fully-staffed and powerful ACER that can break down the barriers between Europe’s energy silos and tackle energy bottlenecks. But so far, it seems to me, the Commission has kept us guessing so far as to what, how and when these powers will come to ACER. ACER is woefully understaffed to fulfil even its present duties, let alone the new task that will follow from the Energy Union. Help has come with the result of the budget compromise. It is a start, but it does not really solve the problem in any meaningful way. I therefore ask the Vice-President once again: what new cross-border regulatory powers is the Commission ready to give ACER? And finally, a word on energy efficiency: as you know, this Parliament has on several occasions backed a 40% energy efficiency target for 2030. As such, I find it unacceptable that the Commission has apparently now decided to only model for 27-33% energy efficiency for upcoming legislative proposals. If we are to make a real impact – if we are to truly develop an energy union – we have to be both ambitious and visionary. Mr Commissioner, will you ensure that the Commission heeds the call of this Parliament and ensures modelling for a 40% energy efficiency target for 2030?

name: Markus Pieper (PPE).
text: Mr President, I would like to thank the Europe exceeds its ambitious CO2 targets for 2020. Europe exceeds the ambitious renewable energy expansion targets for 2020. Europe will also achieve energy efficiency as much as possible by 2020. In any case, the European Union is by far the global leader in environmental and climate protection. But at what price? We have the highest energy costs globally. We are unsettling the industry by constantly interfering with the emissions trading system, which leads to investment elsewhere. We are making energy legislation so complicated that, for example, many countries cannot keep up with energy efficiency.  Mr President, when Vice-President sefsovic now says that 2016 will be the year of events – and Climate Commissioner Caete is impatient to say, for him 2016 will even be the year of legislation – then I can only say: please use this to bring European environmental objectives more into line with the competitiveness of the European economy. In concrete terms, this means simplifying, focusing on the most important CO2 target.  We need to set a framework for the legislation that we still need, but nothing more. In concrete terms, this means that we should finally give renewable energies breathing space by harmonising support and by developing networks and border interconnection points. Give incentives for energy efficiency instead of the compulsion to save energy, which would then also affect green energy.  The energy transition must not be a cost driver or a brake on growth. (The speaker agreed to answer a question on the 'blue card' procedure under Rule 162(8) of the Rules of Procedure)

name: Claude Turmes (Verts/ALE)
text: Question about the procedure of the "blue card". You say here that energy costs are high in Europe. This may still be true for gas, but in the case of electricity we had a price of 60, 65 euros on the Leipzig Stock Exchange in 2008. Today we are under 35, in Scandinavia we are at 25. What facts do you rely on to claim that the price of electricity, which is actually the industrial price, ... (The President cut off the speaker)

name: Markus Pieper (PPE)
text: Answer to a question about the "blue card" procedure. – Unlike you, my dear colleague, I always take the standard of what the consumer costs, what the kilowatt-hour costs in the private household, and I take that as a yardstick for what the industry costs the kilowatt hour. I can tell you that, unfortunately, we are at the forefront of global comparison. I can prove this to you with any statistics, and that is also a result of our very regulatory policy.

name: Olle Ludvigsson (S&D).
text: Mr President, I would like to begin by congratulating Mr It is very welcome that we are now taking the step towards achieving an internal energy market and, at the same time, achieving a sustainable situation from both an environmental and supply perspective. One of the most important areas is energy efficiency for heating and cooling. The heating option that best complements investments in energy efficiency is district heating. Larger combustion plants have better purification and are more efficient than those you can have in the home, so already there are profits to be made, but there is also huge amounts of energy of residual heat from, for example, industrial processes that can be used. This means less emissions, less imports and, moreover, an opportunity for industry to create a market for energy that would otherwise have been wasted and thus a better competitive situation. I therefore hope that the Commission will see district heating and district cooling as an opportunity to strengthen the efforts already taken in terms of energy efficiency of buildings.

name: Ivo Belet (PPE).
text: I believe that the Energy Union - I hope we will agree on this - is the most important policy package of the next legislature. All the major policy areas and policy priorities come together here: energy, environment, economy, climate, employment, security. It all comes together here in this policy package. And it must be at the top of our list of priorities, at the top of the Commission's list of priorities, that is where it is, and also of the Council. 2016, you have said, Commissioner, is indeed the year of truth. We must then make great strides in terms of further increasing the share of renewable energy, further reducing our energy consumption and ensuring security of gas supply.  It is also the year of truth for our ETS system. The Paris climate conference starts in barely a week. The omens are unexpectedly good. We look forward to an enforceable agreement, an ambitious agreement, of course, and all sectors will have to contribute to it. Our companies, energy-intensive companies, will also make an important contribution to our reformed ETS system. We are, of course, counting on a good balance sheet so that they can maintain their international competitiveness. It must indeed remain, Commissioner, - one last idea - our aim of linking that ETS system to similar systems on other continents. Such a global emissions trading system would be the best tool to ensure low-carbon production worldwide.

name: Λευτέρης Χριστοφόρου (
text: PPE). Mr President, I believe that energy is a matter of the utmost importance to the European Union, to the Member States, but much more to European citizens. The key to energy is energy costs and it is a myth that energy costs in the European Union are very high.  We pay very dearly for energy in Europe. In order to be able to reduce energy costs, which must be our first objective, we must immediately become independent of the monopolistic energy situations in the European Union, taking advantage of our potential reserves or natural wealth deposits, which exist in many regions of the European Union.  I will tell you, characteristically, that it is time to make use - and Commissioner, you must also take initiatives as Vice-President - of energy reserves in the Eastern Mediterranean. There, my own country, Cyprus, is a member country of the European Union and it is a golden opportunity for the European Union to invest both with the Juncker Plan, but also with other initiatives in this direction, for its own benefit first and foremost. I believe that we can make use of these stocks, already large European companies, giants, are there and in this way we can reduce energy costs which will benefit both businesses and citizens.  At the same time, the European Union has a responsibility to reduce energy poverty. It is not understood that there is even a family of Europeans without access to energy. The use of renewable energy sources today when their costs are low, especially in countries with comparative advantages with sun, air, biofuels or other renewable energy sources, is our imperative and that is what we must do, Mr Vice-President.

name: Francisco José Millán Mon (PPE).
text: – Mr President, it is important that the European Union ensures its energy supply, which depends on more than 50% of the outside world. To do this we need to diversify our energy sources and reduce our dependence on Russia, for obvious reasons. Our energy imports from southern Mediterranean countries must be increasing. Energy cooperation with these nations should be a priority in the current review of European Neighbourhood Policy. Energy must also be prominent in the Transatlantic Trade and Investment Partnership negotiations with the United States to ensure at least natural gas from the United States. The ports of Galicia, the Spanish region from which I come, can be an authentic European platform for the supply of natural gas from across the Atlantic. And we also need energy at a reasonable price. Otherwise, our industry will be harmed by costs that will detract from competitiveness in a globalized world. Neither Europe, nor its prosperity, nor European employment can renounce its industrial base.

name: Costas Mavrides (S&D).
text: – Mr President, a lot has been said about energy supply security. The European Union has been blessed with some energy reserves in the eastern Mediterranean, particularly in the exclusive economic zone of the Republic of Cyprus. The Government of Cyprus, acting in line with European Union interests, promotes an energy coalition with Greece and Cyprus from the European Union on one side, and with Israel and Egypt on the other – something that might not be possible if the two (Israel and Egypt) were perceived to be cooperating directly. What is needed now is a more decisive position, a real push with determination from the part of the European Union, in order to secure this model of peaceful co-existence and cooperation between EU Member States and states outside of the European Union. And finally, yesterday we had an announcement: a big British gas group is acquiring a 35% stake in the consortium with Noble, and I would like to get your comment on that, because the European Union needs all its Member States.

name: Ivan Jakovčić (ALDE).
text: – Mr. President, Mr. Commissioner, I would like on this occasion when we talk about the Energy Union to draw your attention to the fact that as rapporteur of this Parliament on the Adriatic-Ionian Strategy I have put emphasis, which was adopted in this Parliament, on two things. This part of Europe can contribute to the single energy market first with renewable energy sources, especially with the hydro potential we have, especially in the Balkans, but also with the possibility of using the sun and wind as energy sources.  Another major project is LNG terminals, both the one in Albania and the one in Croatia, with perhaps a little too crowded in the northern Adriatic, and it would be very important for the Commission to clearly decide which LNG terminal it wants to decide. I believe that the Croatian LNG terminal on Krk is very interesting for a whole range of countries that can supply gas from this terminal and I hope that the European Commission will continue to support this project.

name: Davor Škrlec (Verts/ALE).
text: – Mr. President, Vice President Šefčović, for a year now I have been monitoring how much energy and time you invest in making the Energy Union come to life, for that I congratulate you, but I would still like to point out a few more facts that could actually improve how to bring the Energy Union into life.  Macro-regional approach, colleague Jakovcic mentioned the Adriatic-Ionian strategy earlier; We have three macro-regions in Europe – the Baltic, Danube and Adriatic-Ionian – that live and can actually be a very good basis for implementing as much energy efficiency as possible, as many new energy sources as possible, instead of the gas that we see that has reached a dead end in the Energy Union.  There are no citizens in the centre. We're talking about citizens, but we're not giving them strength. Thus, through better regulation, as Vice-President Timmermans says, ensure that citizens through various energy cooperatives and other quality schemes can really actively contribute to the energy transition to the Energy Union. Smart grids, smart city, we have technologies, we have funds, we have knowledge, why are we waiting?

name: Γεώργιος Κύρτσος (
text: PPE). Mr President, if we move properly, the Energy Union can be a great development opportunity for Greece and help overcome the known problems of the Greek economy.  Firstly, there must be initiatives to reduce the energy costs of industry, particularly energy-intensive, and thus strengthen its competitiveness and increase exports.  Secondly, the Public Electricity Company, which has traditionally been a factor in the development of the Greek economy, must be re-developed and developed.  Thirdly, the energy market must be liberalised quickly and effectively in a way based on attracting capital, the activation of the Cohesion Funds and the Juncker programme.  Finally, much can be done in the area of energy saving, as long as problems of financing businesses and households are solved.

name: Victor Negrescu (S&D).
text: – Mr President, I would like to congratulate you on the document you have drawn up, but I would have liked us to be more ambitious. I believe that we must not just build a common market in the field of energy, we must really build an energy Union. This means that there is indeed a concept and mechanisms at European level to help European consumers, be they private or private companies at European level. Unfortunately, I must say with sadness that a country that is relatively energy independent like Romania, like my country, does not have many benefits. We have increased the price of energy for private consumers, but unfortunately we are unable to export because there are no interconnections, because there is indeed no common market in the field of energy, and many countries are still protecting their market at European level. I trust that you know these problems, you know the need for consumers and private companies at European level to form a really effective, indeed independent, truly interconnected energy union, and I believe that we need to find the means by which we can implement such a Union in the field of energy.

name: Der Präsident. –
text: Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, I would like to thank the rapporteur for his excellent report, which Perhaps I should have said it beforehand: I have more than twice as many speeches as I can take into account. I would ask you to understand that I am using criteria. This concerns colleagues who have spoken before. It also concerns colleagues who come from groups where speakers have exceeded speaking time, so I have had to take the floor out of them.  All of this means that you can't take more people into the catch-the-eye process. I therefore ask for your understanding that I have a line here, but I am persevered in all the sittings. (End of catch-the-eye process)

name: Maroš Šefčovič
text: Vice-President of the Commission. – Mr President, honourable Members, firstly I would really like to thank you for a very rich debate which I think truly reflects the complexities and the challenges which we will be facing with our Energy Union project. I would also like to thank you very much for the support you clearly highlight towards the introduction of the State of the Energy Union Report, because I believe that we are equipping ourselves with a very important tool. We now have a very clear policy marker in the political calendar of the European Union. In the autumn we will have regular debates on how we are progressing with the Energy Union, what we have accomplished over the last year and what the challenges we are facing are and what the plans are for the next period. I think that is very important, because I see this as a very important founding stone of the strong robust governance that this House was calling for when we were introducing the Energy Union strategy. If you would allow me to react on some of the most frequent questions and topics which have been raised: first, COP 21. This very important – I would say historic – conference will start in only a few days, and I very much thank all of you for the support for the ambitious binding agreement we will all, from the European side, try to achieve in Paris. I think it is very important to see that all major economies – all the parties to this agreement – will show ambition and will show how decisively we are going to tackle climate change. I believe that Paris will really be a new beginning in this fight, that we will again get new mechanisms which will allow us to learn from the past and to have this five-year periodicity where we can access, compare and act on the figures and results, which will be much more precise than before, because it will be putting much more emphasis on true verification and precise monitoring of the efforts of all parties to that agreement. When it comes to our Energy Union in Europe, I think that several of you highlighted where the real problems are. First we need to make sure that we have our signals right, and by that I mean signals for carbon pricing – I agree with all of you that current carbon prices are not reflecting the cost and not driving in the necessary innovation we need in our energy and climate policies. Therefore, once again I would like to thank you very much for a very cooperative approach on the market stability reserve. I believe that it will be the same in the negotiations on the ETS reform, which we presented for the post-2020 period, because I believe that also by these activities we are already making very clear what the European policies are, how serious we are about a transition to the low—carbon economy and what kind of signals we want to send to investors. But when we are speaking about the price signals, we also have to speak about the price signals for electricity. It is quite clear that if you want to bring the investors in, and if we want to highlight how important active consumerism in this respect would be, we need to do much more for demand—side management, the flexibility of our electricity systems, better integration of renewables and giving more powers to consumers to decide if they want to produce the energy, from whom they want to buy and what kind of supply schemes they want to have for their households or for industries. All this is currently being assessed and will be presented to Members in the series of proposals we will be presenting to Parliament next year. Many of you spoke about energy security. Thank you very much for those strong words, because we are living in a political world, and I think that we also need to send very clear political messages that energy diversification is important, that if we speak about diversification we are talking about the routes but also sources of supply, that we want to have a wider range of energy suppliers and that LNG will play a very important role in this respect. When it comes to Nord Stream, I would like to assure you that, both with Commissioner Arias Cañete and with the other Commissioners, we are working hand-in-hand on this issue, and we will make sure that any project in Europe, including Nord Stream II, will have to fully comply with all EU laws; that all the proposals would really be verified and assessed with all the vigour which you have seen in the previous approach, which we assessed in a similar way; and that for us the transit route through Ukraine is very important. I think we should see it as a priority, not only for the European Commission, but for the whole Energy Union. When it comes to the internal energy market, I agree with all of the Members who said that it is high time we finally complete this, and that we complete it from the legislative point of view but also from the point of view of the hardware and software of the internal energy market. Therefore, it is very important that we agree on this new list for this project of common interest. I would like to make a proposal to you. Let us work on this list much better than before. Let us have regular monitoring and a kind of regular inventory of where we are with this energy infrastructure project. Are we on time? If we see that some projects are struggling, let us analyse why: how can we help these projects take off financially through the feasibility study, through technical assistance or sometimes also through political mediation? This was important for quite a few infrastructure projects mentioned in several of the interventions, because it is important to shorten the time from the current 10 to 12 years; we need to build interconnectors in three to four years, which would bring much more dynamism into our system. We need much more coherence and much closer coordination among our regulators. Therefore, I very much welcome the support for the new powers for ESA. We would like to present this proposal together with a new electricity market design and also the revision of the directive on renewables in the autumn of this year. We have already allocated, thanks to Members’ support for this as well, more staff for ESA, because we agree that the role of this agency is very important and will be even further increased. On energy efficiency: the first principle – and I think we are very clear here and we will be discussing with Members this issue on many further occasions – is that we want to operationalise energy efficiency first – when we assess all the legislative proposals next year and when the Member States consider new infrastructure, we will be calling upon them and discussing with them how at first to assess how much energy we can save, what we can do at national level, how we can improve our energy regions to make sure that, if we are progressing in this effort, we will do it on the most cost—efficient basis. We will be very ambitious on this front, and Parliament will see that we will be very ambitious, just as we have been very ambitious until today. Of course, we want to make sure that all these figures for 2030 line up, that we will deliver. Therefore, we need to make the next year, as several of you highlighted, the year of delivery, where we will put all the key elements on the legislative front on the table for Parliament and the Member States, and the Council, to start the true negotiations on how we will transform the Energy Union proposals into valid legislation. I want to put it on the table also because we want to call upon Member States to start working as early as 2017 on draft national energy and climate plans, to make sure that they also develop their vision for 2030 and that they will tell us how they want to implement all these plans at national level, so we can see if the figures are adding up and if we need some further action to be undertaken. Then we can actually have the process which would make it possible, despite the energy mixes which are decided at national level, to have a common European framework, a common European goal and, I believe, good common European results. One word, if you allow me, on energy poverty. We deliberately highlighted this as one of the key messages of the state of the Energy Union, because it is true: we have more than 10% of Europeans – more than 50 million European citizens – who are facing energy poverty and have problems paying for energy bills. We have to take action on these issues and equip the people with new skills if they are from the traditional industries and offer them a future in these new low—carbon economies. We need to equip them with new skills, and we will be working very closely on these proposals together with Commissioner Thyssen in the first months of next year. I see that time is flying, and there were a lot of questions. I would like to conclude by thanking this House and thanking the Members of the European Parliament for this very rich debate and for the many contacts we have had throughout the last nine months, here in Strasbourg and in Brussels. I also very much appreciate all those Members of the European Parliament who joined me on the Energy Union tour across European cities, across European enterprises and in all the citizen dialogues we had together. I very much appreciate this, because this helps us to bring this project to the places where it must be built – in our cities, our villages, our industry. I am very much encouraged by the support and the achievements we had over the nine months, and I can tell you all that I feel full responsibility to deliver on all the ambitious proposals we presented to you in 2016.

name: Marek Jurek (ECR).
text: – The procedure for the award of votes from the Chamber is the personal competence of each of the presenters, which is not subject to any discussion, but even personal competence is governed by the rules. I would like to point out that, in his from the chamber, the President has given the floor to members of some clubs up to twice, if not three times – I do not remember this – but at least twice, yet our group, the third group in Parliament, did not get a single vote. I pay attention to this.

name: Maria Grapini (S&D).
text: – Mr President, I also want to intervene on the procedure. I was on the speaker list until yesterday. Today, I came from eight-and-a-half and sat in the room to listen to the report and the debate. At half past nine, my assistant told me That I was no longer on the speaker list. I signed up for catch the eye. You didn't give me the word "catch the eye" either. Instead, you have given replies to the EPP between two MEPs and many have exceeded their speaking time. It is not fair to manage time to the detriment of other MEPs.

name: Der Präsident. –
text: Mrs Grapini, Mr Jurek, that is what this is all about.  It's about fairness. When I chair the sitting, you will notice that I always knock at the same time and always withdraw the floor at the same time when it is necessary.  I take the liberty of removing the floor from a representative of the group, then I will take away a catch-the-eye opportunity, because the procedure is not as spontaneous as Mr Jurek said.  We have had well over ten speeches, some of them have withdrawn immediately, and then I have to make a selection. And for you, it was the fact that I withdrew the floor from a representative of your group, because it is uncollegial to exceed the speaking time. It is at the expense of everyone else. Mrs Grapini, I did not give you the floor on the catch-the-eye procedure because they had a blue card. I cannot say for the fact that your group has taken you off the list of speakers again, and I do not know about that. That is your group's decision. But I make the decision here when and who I give the floor to in the catch-the-eye procedure. The timetable provides for five minutes, so that there are five speeches, and I cannot give more. Then not all the groups can always get involved. I have not given three speeches to any group, but I have given two speeches to the two large groups.  This time, the ECR did not come into play for the reasons already mentioned twice. The debate is closed. Written declarations (Article 162 OF the CRP)

name: Petras Auštrevičius (ALDE)
text: in writing. – Since the adoption of the Energy Union Framework Strategy, huge progress has been made towards achieving a genuine Energy Union among Member States. However, lack of unity in political decision-making in terms of external energy supply is threatening the Energy Union’s future, and we need to be extremely cautious about plans such as the Nord Stream II gas pipeline, which would further advance EU’s dependency on Russia. If we want to diversify Europe’s energy sources, Member States need to show a stronger political will to reduce energy dependence from the East as both its political and economic costs are unpredictable. In my opinion, the future of the Energy Union relies on ensuring not only affordable and environmentally friendly but also secure energy for EU citizens.

name: Simona Bonafè (S&D)
text: in writing. I welcome the Commission's commitment to achieving the objectives of the Energy Union Strategy. We need the development of an integrated energy agenda that is not simply the sum of the positions of European capitals. Strengthening ACER is a first step in this direction. Vice-President Šefčovič reminded us that we need to improve both the 'software' and the 'hardware' of the internal energy market. Massive infrastructure projects and investments are a key pillar of the plan, not least in the face of the geopolitical challenges we face. Investments that will also be possible thanks to greater flexibility and EFSI. Stronger cooperation between the EU and the Member States in the evaluation of national energy plans, together with the Energy Union's annual state-of-the-art reports, will make it possible to refine the strategy. Citizens are also the protagonists of change. In particular, I support the "new deal" with consumers for the fight against energy poverty and for the challenge of less, diversified and more efficient consumption of resources. COP21 is beginning, a once-in-a-lifetime opportunity to achieve binding targets on the decarbonisation of society globally: in this sense, vigorous European leadership such as the one we are developing will be crucial to its success.

name: Soledad Cabezón Ruiz (S&D)
text: in writing. – In recent years the price of electricity in the wholesale market has fallen significantly. However, the bills received by European households, far from reflecting this fall, are higher. Much of the blame has been the fees and taxes with which the bills we receive are taxed. Therefore, knowing what kind of charges each Member State imposes on its citizens is a very important step in ensuring transparency of energy costs and prices. For these reasons, I would like to draw attention to a document in the package that could go unnoticed: the proposal for a Regulation on European statistics on the prices of natural gas and electricity. Until now, there has been no obligation to provide Eurostat with data on the energy prices charged to households. Thanks to this proposal, when we approve the Regulation, we will have the data to work for more progressive billing that does not penalize the most vulnerable consumers or pose an obstacle to energy efficiency measures.

name: Michel Dantin (PPE)
text: In writing. Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, the Energy Union offers us a tremendous opportunity to build a common market that serves our common interests while taking into account national realities. In some sectors, energy prices account for a quarter or even one third of the cost of production. Yet Europe produces less than half of its energy and has few reserves. Ensuring supplies, improving energy efficiency, promoting low-carbon alternatives are therefore our priorities.  However, we must make efforts to ensure that Europe's energy policy, however ambitious, remains a job-creating and strengthens our competitiveness. Thanks to investments in new technologies, France is one of the states with the lowest per capita greenhouse gas emissions. This effort must be supported throughout Europe. Let us not forget that it is research and innovation that will make our industries competitive global export benchmarks. We therefore need to mobilise the Horizon 2020 financial instrument more to achieve our energy targets.

name: Doru-Claudian Frunzulică (S&D)
text: in writing. – The Energy Union is an ambitious strategy that will allow the diversification of the European energy supply, in particular Future Aviation Package gas imports, to move away from our dependence on Russia, and should therefore be one of our main priorities. I wish to see a much stronger focus on the citizen in the Energy Union and more measures to tackle energy poverty and help vulnerable consumers have affordable energy. I strongly support the request for a Commission communication and action plan on the state of the Energy Union. I believe that its governance, reporting and national plans on how Member States will meet the targets and other key indicators should be based on a legislative framework, not just on a voluntary basis, in order to ensure targets can be met. Finally, we should ensure that the energy transition is based on energy efficiency, renewable energies and smart infrastructure.

name: Adam Gierek (S&D)
text: I would like to write to the Commission. – The current process of energy management in the EU is chaotic, dominated by the climate priority. This one-sidedness has a strong Polish energy security and threatens energy poverty. We need to revalue the existing energy policy, an exaggerated, poorly justified and scientifically documented so-called European climate policy and to separate it from real energy policy. It cannot be shaped by strong lobbying by some countries and large gas and financial corporations.  A genuine Energy Union should lead to a change in the climate and energy package that would combat unfair competition between Member States. The Union's priority should be energy security, supply solidarity and the fight against energy poverty, infrastructure modernisation and transparency in negotiating energy prices from third countries, as well as the use of local energy sources, including coal. Decarbonisation should be the result not only of an increase in the share of RES, but above all of energy efficiency. An appropriate indicator of the increase in actual efficiency in the future ETS as well as the share of RES should be rewarded with a proportionate reduction in the obligation to purchase CO2 emission allowances.

name: Maria Grapini (S&D)
text: in writing. – I appreciate the Commission's initiative for the concern of having an energy union. It is important to have uniform rules and a competitive energy market in the EU, but we must ensure that the established indicators are achievable in all Member States. The state of improvement of energy infrastructure is different in each Member State and therefore the amount of investment is different, as is the time of implementation as well. Bear in mind, Commissioner, that we are talking about states that have energy efficiency in different buildings and energy mixes. I appreciate that you are proposing to review the 248 projects of common interest on energy infrastructure, but I suggest that you take into account concrete situations on the ground, particularly in the countries of Eastern Europe. I do not see any concrete measures that avoid the negative effects in certain countries in the implementation of the energy strategy. In addition to protecting vulnerable consumers, Commissioner, you must take into account the pace you are setting for lowering carbon emissions so as not to affect the transport sector and, obviously, jobs. Decarbonisation of energy is an important objective, but let us not forget to be cautious not to deindustrialise the European Union since the European Union is not the largest polluter in the world.

name: Tunne Kelam (PPE)
text: in writing. – The interconnectedness of the European electricity market is seeing some real progress. The Baltic States could soon be connected to the Nordic electricity market through the connections to Sweden and Poland that should be completed by December 2015. A true single energy market would also lower the price for the European citizens. Achieving lower prices is a priority for the EPP Group and we expect the EU to deliver on that. Energy security still remains a great concern. The so-called Nord Stream 2 (NS2), presented as a deal between private companies, is clearly a political project, dominated by Russian state monopoly Gazprom. As such it will undermine EU energy security, principles of fair competition and European solidarity. Using Nord Stream 2 will enable Russia to stop sending its gas through Ukraine and increase its hold on Kiev and the economy. As MEPs, we are highly concerned about such back-door energy deals and about the ease with which multinational companies can bypass EU rules on competition and unbundling. In particular, big international energy deals have to be fully transparent and provide for diversity of energy supplies, not increasing dependency on Russian gas. I support the Polish Government’s initiative to stop NS2. In fact, several European countries are against these plans. The EC must scrutinise this project with special care.

name: Elżbieta Katarzyna Łukacijewska (PPE)
text: I would like to write to the Commission. – EU security and the state of the environment depend greatly on the EU's energy strategy. I am therefore very pleased with the progress made in the Energy Union. This is an issue that the Union rightly puts forward as one of its priority actions. We must remember that only a common policy can bring rational and comprehensive solutions. A stable Europe is an energy-secure Europe. I hope that action in the areas of efficiency and use of renewable energy sources, climate policy, the emerging new energy market, energy security and adequate infrastructure will serve the policy well.  However, not everything is likely to be achieved, if only with the ambitious intention of achieving 40% pollution reduction rates by 2030, given the still high greenhouse gas emissions. Let us remember that similar regulations do not always have a positive effect. Polish entrepreneurs are often forced to make large additional investments or incur costs associated with various types of permits, which slows down the achievement of the intended effects of regulation. The EU must take into account the real impact of its actions on industry and services, depending on the country and wealth of both specific strategic companies and smaller companies, so that the overall balance sheet is fairly uniform across all EU countries. The planned regulations must not hamper the functioning of the industry. Only joint and several actions, such as energy policy, are able to strengthen the foundations of community.

name: Marian-Jean Marinescu (PPE)
text: in writing. – The annual reports submitted by the European Commission show that several steps have been taken this year towards strengthening the Energy Union, which will help to reduce dependence on imports and carbon emissions. However, several short-term objectives remain to be achieved: the rapid reform of the system of certificates that defend the interests of European industry and help to avoid its relocation; interoperability of European networks, protection of vulnerable consumers and price adaptation, digitisation of networks in order to increase energy efficiency. The Commission must come up with a legislative proposal to make an integrated internal energy market viable, based on cross-border regional cooperation and the exploitation of southern European own resources, as well as the new EastMed energy perspectives (Cyprus, Israel, Lebanon, Egypt). The Commission must find solutions to reduce dependence on the Russian monopoly and verify that the recent North Stream project is compatible with European rules. There is also a need for a legislative proposal on interconnectors that is favourable to all EU Member States and regions. Europe must intelligently manage its electricity and gas networks, take the necessary steps to ensure that the 28 energy policies currently in existence are based on common governance.

name: Csaba Molnár (S&D)
text: Writing. - Mr President, I would like to thank you for your support. Even in the maelstrom of the refugee crisis, we must pay sufficient attention to the energy security Hungary Europe and in it. We cannot go unsym short of the fact that Russia, once again using energy as a political weapon, can at any time block natural gas taps in the direction of Ukraine, thereby jeopardising the winter gas supply to Hungarian households. Not to mention that the Hungarian Government irresponsibly only filled the gas reservoirs for a third before the winter heating season. This once again highlights that only the European alliance can protect against Russian dependence. In the end, the juice of their special deal with the Russians, billions of dollars in nuclear energy investments, is finally being taken by a number of Hungarian households, while the few close to the government are rubbing their hands.  The DK consistently advocates the development of a European Energy Union as soon as possible. We believe that the Commission should negotiate energy agreements, on behalf of the European community of 500 million people, not national governments that fear for their national sovereignty. We can't just base our future on Russian gas. Over the past five years, however, we have lalaged behind for decades in both renewable energies and energy efficiency, with LNG investment delayed. In Lithuania, for example, where there is an alternative to Russian gas, heating bills have fallen by a quarter in months. The Energy Union is not a threat to our sovereignty, but a custodian of Hungarian energy security, persistently low Hungarian overhead bills.

name: Ева Паунова (PPE)
text: in writing. – The first State of the Energy Union report shows the importance of building a forward-looking energy strategy. One of the most important elements of this long-term strategy must be energy efficiency, because only through reduced energy consumption can Europe achieve true independence, which is important both economically and geopolitically. I welcome the Commission's decision in 2016 to come up with a new eco-design plan that will not only improve the circular economy, but also help energy efficiency in the Member States. Bulgaria adopted a National Energy Efficiency Programme worth BGN 1 billion. This will not only achieve lower levels of energy consumption, thermal comfort and higher quality of living environment for citizens, but will also reduce energy dependence on external sources. Improving energy infrastructure is another priority for the Bulgarian Government, which is why for us the inclusion of a large number of projects in the adopted list of projects of common interest is an extremely positive signal. I call on the EC to continue to consistently support these infrastructure projects in the country and the region until they are fully implemented in order to achieve the objectives of our energy policy.

name: Dariusz Rosati (PPE)
text: in writing. – I welcome the fact that the European Commission plans to annually issue a Communication on the State of the Energy Union. Still, when it comes to decarbonisation of the economy, we have to connect it to the R&I pillar of the Energy Union. The main aim of the Energy Union should not be to eliminate any source of energy, especially as we should use indigenous sources, but to lower the CO2 emissions. Hence, the EU should invest in, e.g., clean coal technologies and not treat coal as a ‘purely harming’ energy source. Moreover, I fear that the Commission insufficiently touches upon the ‘elephant in the room’. Knowing that the current Nord Stream capacity is not even fully used, is the extension of Nord Stream not something that the Commission should strongly criticize – not diversifying the energy sources’ country of origin and further reliance on one, non—credible, supplier not serving to guarantee stabilization in the EU’s neighbourhood? The Communication mentions that ‘the EU will only support infrastructure projects that are in line with the core principles of the Energy Union’. I hope that this relatively vague statement will not be further undermined by any actions concerning Nord Stream.

name: Czesław Adam Siekierski (PPE)
text: I would like to write to the Commission. – Europe is characterised by a large fragmentation of the energy market and significant differences in the state and capabilities of energy and transmission infrastructure. Despite the investments made at EU level and by the Member States themselves, although the situation is improving, this is not a sufficient improvement that would have a real impact on Europe's energy security and could provide access to energy at favourable prices for consumers and businesses. EU strategies often place great emphasis on reducing emissions, given their environmental impact and climate change. However, there should be no mis-understanding of this eu policy objective as a way to eliminate fossil fuels from the energy mix of Member States as soon as possible, as this is impossible in the short term. Excessive pressure and further restrictions on energy-intensive EU industries can only lead to a reduction in their competitiveness and the relocation of production outside the EU, resulting not only in capital outflows but also in the loss of hundreds of thousands of jobs. The Union should pursue its objectives in the context of reducing emissions in a way that is based on technological progress, enabling better use of certain resources and the inclusion of alternatives in long-term European and national strategies. Hasty decisions cannot be taken here that could weaken Europe, block the development of the internal energy market and jeopardise the status of transit countries such as Poland and Ukraine.

name: Olga Sehnalová (S&D)
text: Writing. – I welcome the fact that, in the first State of the Energy Union report, the Commission addresses, in addition to strategic issues of security, efficiency and infrastructure, equally important issues of social justice in the energy sector and places an overall emphasis on strengthening the role of consumers. I consider it important that the achievement of ambitious climate and energy targets be in line with the commitment to make end-consumers more important in energy markets, especially with a view to more affordable prices. The working document presented on consumer trends notes that, despite the progress made, the electricity and gas markets are still not functioning as they should. The Social Democrats have long called for addressing energy poverty and helping vulnerable consumers on energy affordability. We need concrete measures to reduce household energy expenditure and energy savings for households, for example by simplifying conditions allowing consumers to compare tariffs and choose the most advantageous supplier.

name: Claudia Tapardel (S&D)
text: in writing. – From an energy point of view, 2015 was marked by tensions in the east, the persistence of low oil prices, the new prospects opened by the Iran nuclear agreement, and a continuing decline in domestic fossil fuel production. Nine months ago we embarked on a framework strategy for the Energy Union, and today the Commission is telling us that we have made significant progress towards creating a true internal market for energy and the transition to a hypocarbonic, secure and competitive economy. As a Member of the European Parliament in Romania, a country that plays an important role in the current context of the regional energy market in South-Eastern Europe and where the energy sector is of strategic importance, I draw attention to a few things: we must make energy transform from a diplomatic instrument into an economic instrument that serves small and large consumers alike. The social dimension of the decarbonisation of the energy system is very important and needs to be addressed very carefully, as the transition to a low-carbon economy will involve a profound change in many sectors of the national economy in Member States such as Romania, affecting companies and, by implication, jobs.

name: Miguel Viegas (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. – The European Union wants to face a triple energy challenge. With few reserves and highly dependent on imports in this area, it seeks to ensure the security of its supplies. Rising energy prices are another challenge. Finally, climate change requires a reduction in greenhouse gas emissions. The EU imports more than 60% of its gas and more than 80% of its oil. If no other solutions are adopted, dependence on energy imports could reach 70% in 20 or 30 years, against 53 % today. However, this EU wants to solve this serious structural problem through the market by privatising the sector, preventing governments from directly or indirectly intervening, or even, amazingly, forcing the existence of a carbon emissions market that, in practice, has never worked. For our part, we remain convinced that only public control over key sectors of the energy sector can lead to lasting solutions.

name: Milan Zver (PPE)
text: Writing. – The European Union has some shortcomings, and energy malnutrition is one of the most fatal. You could even say that energy shares the European political scene more than it connects. It is in this area that the national egoisms that have led to the concept of the Energy Union falling into the water in the last year. However, we must continue to develop the concept of the energy community and include other neighbouring countries, especially Norway. Today, it often sounds like a false dilemma, whether we are going to build a low-carbon society or a competitive European industry (which is betting too much on carbon energy). For Europe's future, a low-carbon economy is a necessity (not an alternative), because only clean energy will save us from dependence on Russian gas and Arab oil. In transition time, we should make more bets on dives, renewable and alternative energy sources. However, this is a joint project that has no internal borders. When the EU "speaks with one voice" in this area and frees itself from this energy dependency, we will also be a major player on a global scale in the policy field.

name: Der Präsident. –
text: The next item on the agenda is the debate on werner Langen's supplementary report on behalf of the Committee on Economic and Monetary Affairs on the proposal for a Directive of the European Parliament and of the Council on insurance mediation (recast) (COM(2012)0360 - C7-0180/2012 - 2012/0175 (COD)) (A8-0315/2015).

name: Werner Langen
text: Rapporteur. Mr President, I would like to thank the I would like to express my sincere thanks to all those involved who have helped to bring this larger and longer-lasting project to a complete end. These are the members of Parliament, that is the Council, but it is also the Commission, which has been very constructive in the negotiations between the Council and Parliament on insurance mediation. After all, it took us three and a half years, and if, after today's adoption, the directive is implemented in all the Member States in 24 months' time, then we have successfully concluded this issue of financial market regulation. However, I would not just like to thank you, but i would like to mention the ten most important points. Firstly, the scope of application, which provides for exemptions for small insurance and for part-time placement. We have discussed this for a long time, we have been arguing about this for a long time. We have chosen a pro rata approach and a flat rate. I believe that this is a sensible way forward within the scope of application. Secondly, registration. The insurance companies are responsible for ensuring that their insurance distributors register properly. There will be a one-stop shop at EIOPA, in particular with regard to the freedom of services and establishment, which will ensure greater transparency of registrants in the EU. There is also the third point: qualification requirements. Contrary to what some Member States have advocated until the very end, the first registration is the qualification in the home Member State and not the one in which one has to go. However, the Member State in which you work has a certain say in continuing training. This was highly controversial. The training obligation was low, but better than nothing. And the Member States have the opportunity to check this. The fourth area is the commission bans that have been sought, including from parts of Parliament. There is no general prohibition of commission or an obligation to disclose the amount of the remuneration. Because of the very different structures of the insurance markets, member states have therefore been given several opportunities to lay down stricter information requirements, pending the opening up of commission bans. That was a demand from the Council, which we could not fend off. The fifth point is the product information sheet, which is part of our catalogue of measures to improve consumer protection. There has been a long resistance here. We discussed and decided on a concise product information sheet, the basic format of which EIOPA must make proposals for. The sixth point is product overview and management. In line with the Markets and Financial Instruments Directive, rules for product supervision and management have been introduced for all insurance products. There is a danger here that a bureaucratic instrument will end up if EIOPA is not put on the brakes on this issue.  Seventh, investment-based insurance products. No commission ban and obligation to provide independent advice have been established here, but Member States have the opportunity to introduce this. Moreover, similar rules have been adopted to those laid down in the Markets in Financial Instruments Directive. Then we have the transitional periods, the obligation to implement them in 24 months. There is a new annex which provides for the qualification requirements, knowledge for the provision of insurance. And we have taken over out-of-court dispute resolution, as decided by Parliament. Overall, we have succeeded in strengthening consumer protection. We have succeeded in establishing uniform rules in the insurance market for the distribution of insurance. Once again, I would like to thank very warmly all those who have taken the trouble to negotiate with the Council for three years. Finally, on the last day of the Latvian Presidency, we managed to reach a compromise on the whole. Thank you very much!

name: President. –
text: I want to inform you that during this debate we will not have blue cards. We also need to respect timing because at midday we have the LUX Prize.

name: Jonathan Hill
text: Member of the Commission. – Mr President, this directive is very much part of our overall drive to increase transparency and to improve consumer protection. It is going to give citizens more choice; it will make sure that those selling insurance understand the products that they are selling, and that those buying insurance better understand what they are buying. So I am very pleased that we have reached this point today and that I have got the chance to congratulate Werner Langen and the shadow rapporteurs for all their hard work over many months, indeed over many years, as we have heard, in getting this proposal into shape. The directive builds on national regimes of insurance distribution. It sets out a number of minimum standards for insurance distributors to follow, and it broadens the scope of distributors covered, to include companies that sell insurance as an add-on to their core business, like travel companies or car dealers. It also gives legal certainty to insurance companies that sell their products directly to consumers by clarifying how they can register their distributors and the information that they need to give to customers. As we have heard, there are stronger requirements around training and development, and when a product is packaged with an insurance policy as part of a special offer, it will in future be possible to separate the elements of the package so that you can buy the car or the holiday you want, with or without the extra insurance. We want people to be clearer about what they are paying for when they buy or invest in an insurance product. So the directive requires greater transparency on fee structures and on any financial incentives that the distributors may have. The requirement for non-life insurance to produce a simple and standardised product information document, which was added by Parliament, is a further strengthening of consumer protection. The directive also includes stronger requirements for the sale of life insurance products with investment elements.
