It requires suitability tests to be run to help determine whether a product fits a consumer’s profile, and because products covered by MiFID II and the IDD are often interchangeable, these rules have, as far as possible, been aligned. There is one small technical point I need to mention for the record. The view of our legal service is that recital 69 of the text is not fully in line with the Common Understanding on Delegated Acts. That said, in the context of a general compromise, the Commission can accept this wording because generally it does adhere to the Common Understanding, in accordance with which the Commission will, of course, continue to act. This directive ensures a level playing field between different insurance sellers and a more consistent level of consumer protection, in particular by increasing transparency. For me, transparency is essential if we are to legislate in a manner that is proportionate and that avoids unnecessary burdens. By making the right information available, we can help consumers make the right decisions and also encourage responsible behaviour in the sector. The insurance distribution directive is, I believe, an important step in that direction, and that is why I am very pleased today to have the chance to support it. COMMISSION’S WRITTEN STATEMENT The wording of the second sentence of recital 69 of the text is not fully in line with the Common Understanding on Delegated Acts because it refers to the need for appropriate contacts with Parliament and Council ahead of the adoption of the delegated act. In the context of a general compromise, the Commission can nevertheless accept this wording because it generally adheres to the Common Understanding that we remain committed to upholding. The Commission considers transparency in preparation of delegated acts of paramount importance. The Commission will continue to act in accordance with the Common Understanding and particularly declaration 39 in the area of financial services.

name: Burkhard Balz
text: Mr President, i.e. the Group of the European People's Party (Christian Democrats) and European Democrats Mr President, Commissioner, I would like to thank the commissioner for her work and for the work she has I would like to begin by thanking rapporteur Werner Langen very warmly for his really great work, as well as thankyouing the shadow rapporteurs. I believe that the directive strengthens consumer protection for insurance products in the Member States across all distribution channels. Consumers across Europe will now receive standardised briefings before purchasing products, and this will finally remove the confusion of different information sheets in the Member States. This will enable consumers to compare insurance products across borders. It is not the sheer mass, not the overloading of hundreds of pages, but the quality of the information and the information provider that is crucial.  We consider it very positive that the quality requirements for intermediaries should be laid down. Substantial training and training standards for insurance intermediaries should apply in all Member States. This is certainly a major step forward. We want to make it possible to continue existing advisory models in the Member States. Access to advice on different products and product models and the transparency of intermediaries should be essential. The directive has also succeeded in this. At the same time, we have ensured that proportionality is maintained. Micro-insurance and part-time placement are excluded from the directive. This is appropriate, because no consumer will want to have a long, comprehensive mediation interview before travelling for a few euros a year for foreign insurance.  As co-legislators, we have defined the requirements. Our view now goes to the European insurance regulator EIOPA. EIOPA wanted to become self-employed again, but EIOPA will have to realize here that the legislator sets the requirements. The ECON Committee will certainly follow closely how the Commission and EIOPA are now implementing concrete action in the spirit of the co-legislators.

name: Catherine Stihler
text: on behalf of the S&D Group. – Mr President, I would like to thank the rapporteur and shadows. The European insurance sector has trillions of euros worth of assets under its management, making it the backbone of our financial industry and an important contributor to GDP. The insurance distribution directive (IDD) is, along with Solvency II, just one piece of the puzzle of updated regulations aimed at strengthening European standards and encouraging cross-border purchases. A patchwork of national regulations, with some governments gold-plating the measures and others implementing the bare minimum necessary for compliance, has been the case across Europe for some years now. However, the agreement reached on IDD includes substantial achievements in consumer protection, notably on information for consumers, a ban on time practices and the prevention of conflicts of interest. This agreement includes substantial achievements in consumer protection, which was my priority and my group’s from the get-go. The implementation of this updated regulation will ensure consumers understand the risks, costs and features of all insurance products and that those selling them possess the relevant professionalism and competence. Part of a review by the Commission in 2008 found that a lack of transparency around remuneration was resulting in too many Commission-driven conflicts of interest in the market. The new directive requires Member States to lay down rules ensuring the intermediaries, insurers and reinsurers do not remunerate or assess the performance of employees in a way that conflicts with their duty to act in the best interests of consumers. Also, before a contract is concluded, an intermediary must disclose to customers the nature and basis – such as a fee, commission, or combination thereof – of the remuneration. This is a huge increase in transparency for the consumer. Insurance and reinsurance distribution can be carried out by insurers and reinsurers as well as intermediaries. So the scope of this regulation has been widened to reflect that. But in specified circumstances, such as ancillary insurance intermediaries, those whose principal activities are not insurance related are excluded from the scope. Another important achievement of IDD is ensuring that sellers’ professional qualifications match the complexity of the products they sell. Included in the directive is a requirement for at least 15 hours of professional training or development per year, although as part of our compromise with the Council, Member States may allow evidence of continuous training and development through successful completion of an exam. Under the existing directive, there will be requirements to disclose information to customers before a contract is concluded. So to remain competitive, there is a need for innovation – particularly digital innovation – and this will ultimately lead to huge potential for the provision of cross-border insurance sales. The adoption of IDD is an important step towards this, and I look forward to Parliament endorsing it during the plenary session.

name: Ashley Fox
text: on behalf of the ECR Group. – Mr President, the Insurance Distribution Directive will enhance consumer protection, increase competition and create a more level playing field between insurance and investment products. I am pleased that we have agreed upon a principle-based approach giving Member States flexibility to implement tougher rules where they see fit to do so. This is the most sensible way to go about legislating: allowing companies room to ensure they give consumers the best outcomes rather than worrying about tick-box style exercises. The product information document is a good example of this. We have been able to strip out many of the over-prescriptive one-size-fits-all requirements, instead focusing on the information that can actually benefit the consumer. It was vital to protect consumers’ interest in the wide variety of tied insurance products that currently save them time and money. I am pleased that consumers in my country, for example, will still be able to choose a bank account that includes travel insurance, should they wish to do so. Consumers will also benefit from a move towards aligning insurance distribution more closely with the rules laid out in MiFID II in order to create a level playing field between insurance and investment products. Overall, I am pleased at the final outcome of this report, and I look forward to seeing a positive outcome from its implementation.

name: Miguel Urbán Crespo
text: GUE/NGL Group. – Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, when the recasting of the Insurance Mediation Directive began, the Commission sold us a number of objectives which could have been of interest to end a market, that of insurance brokers, full of abuse and extremely opaque.  Ensuring common legislation on different types of insurance and ensuring comprehensive and transparent information for consumers are absolutely necessary objectives. However, we fear that once again the big bank, which is the one that increasingly centralizes and concentrates insurance distribution activities, will be favoured.  It is true that in some respects progress has been made and we hope in particular that, if implemented, the new Directive will help to put an end to misleading or fraudulent packages.  However, as far as the initial objectives are concerned, it is unacceptable that, if transparency is sought in the consumer-facing market, brokers can continue to charge commissions opaquely. It is difficult for a broker to provide objective information about the different products if, at the same time, it is receiving commissions from the insurers themselves. Moreover, once again, transparency requirements are restricted to certain products, without reaching the market as a whole.  It is clear that there are actors who fear transparency like vampires light. We're not going to take those vampires from the insurance market.

name: Sven Giegold
text: Mr President, For better, I would like to make a name for my free Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, I would like to thank the rapporteur for her excellent report and for the way in which Mr Langen, this was a difficult birth, this whole directive; I have rarely experienced such a tough thing here. It has to be said that the positions were far apart. The Commission had put forward a comparatively ambitious proposal. There were very different views of this report in Parliament, as well as in the Council. The insurance industry has insisted all the time that its products are different from bank-based products, although some of the suppliers and distributors are actually identical. Unfortunately, it is now the case that, while we are taking a step forward with the conclusion of this directive, we are taking a step forward in order to increase consumer protection in the area of insurance distribution, to greater transparency and also to increase competition, but that we nevertheless retain different rules, including for products that are in direct competition with each other. So, for example, a form-based life insurance policy is sold under distribution rules other than an investment fund or a bundle of investment funds. In the interests of fair competition, this makes no sense. For example, in the case of investment funds, commissions will have to be disclosed to consumers in future, while in the area of capital life insurance it remains the case for disclosure of the total costs, even though the same products are partly sold by the same distributors. After all, we have been able to ensure that a delegated act will now ensure that there are at least similar standards. It is important that we ensure that uniformity is allowed into the rules. So progress for more Europe and stronger consumer protection. But Parliament was not united in its commitment to uniform rules, so the Council was very much in charge of this. But it is always a step forward.

name: Steven Woolfe
text: on behalf of the EFDD Group. – Mr President, within this Chamber and within the Commission there are people who have genuinely good intentions in trying to create a framework where there is positive transparency in regulations and decency in relation to the protection of consumers in insurance products. They all come together around a philosophy that there should be a single market with a single rule book and with a single idea that every one thing is exactly the same. Unfortunately, that was a philosophy of the 1940s and the 1950s, and nowadays it is fully recognised that, when you put rules together in one bundle, it only helps the large institutions – the major corporates who have the funding of the large compliance offices and regulators. You always put at depth and in problems the smaller and medium-sized businesses, and this directive will do that again.

name: Edouard Ferrand
text: on behalf of the ENF group. Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, once it is not customary, we welcome this report which does not reproduce the mistakes made with the MIF II directive. Today, this report is very important because it will allow the full exercise of the activities of independent advisors in wealth management and insurance intermediation and therefore gives full satisfaction to a profession that was worried about its future. This report reinforces the idea that the independent intermediary will be able to operate without the banks and insurance companies being able to stifle and vassalize it. We think this report is very favourable, but I think we must also emphasise that tomorrow large financial institutions such as banks and insurance companies will also have to comply with the same directives as insurance intermediaries. It was time for the European Parliament to give all the powers so that this profession could be widely authorised, not only by banks and insurance companies, but also by financial intermediaries. I think the point of this report is to put the banking and insurance lobby in trouble, which thought it was the only one that could manage and organize this profession. Today, insurance intermediaries have the opportunity to exist. They are well-trained professionals with good experience who, I think, will be just as competent as the employees of banks and insurance companies.

name: Othmar Karas (PPE).
text: Mr President, Commissioner, ladies and gentlemen, I would like to thank the rapporteur for her excellent work and for the work she has said. First of all, a sincere thank you to the rapporteur, Werner Langen, because, throughout the process, he has tried not only to deal with an issue from the outside, so to speak, but to engage in intensive dialogue with consumer advocates, intermediaries and different cultures in the Member States in the provision of insurance, and has therefore become practical in the directive. It has three major advantages: on the one hand, it leads to improved consumer protection, on the other hand it leads to greater transparency and, on the other hand, it takes account of the different cultures in the Member States. I have always advocated improved consumer protection, also from the point of view of administrability and fair competition and the relationship of trust between intermediaries and customers.  Secondly, increased transparency is important because we must ensure that there are information requirements so that customers make independent decisions and the products on offer are comparable. I am glad that there is no general ban on commissions, because it distorts competition, contradicts cultures, has not brought anything to the consumer, but would probably even have made competition more difficult and would have driven up prices. In the sense of a good product!

name: Olle Ludvigsson (S&D).
text: Mr President, I would like to begin by congratulating Mr I welcome the fact that this regulatory framework is now finally in place. The consumer has long had a weak position in the insurance market. The abuses have been obvious. It has been all too common for the consumer to be left with the wrong insurance product at far too high a price. The new rules will bring significant improvements. The consumer will be given clearer information, more robust advice and, in general, stronger protection. A particularly important provision is that the consumer should not be forced to purchase such insurance offered in packages with another good or service. The item or service must be available for purchase without insurance. All this is a valuable step in the right direction. What is now crucial is that the directive is properly implemented at national level. The change in the rules must be accompanied by profound changes in the cultural market: the consumer must be seriously placed at the centre.

name: Stanisław Ożóg (ECR).
text: – (2) Mr President, I would like to begin by I am pleased that there have been so many positive developments in the negotiations on this report and that the ECR Group is ready to support the current shape of this project. The new Insurance Mediation Directive aims to effectively improve regulation in the retail insurance products market, ensure undistorted competition and protect consumers and integrate the market. I believe that extending the scope of the original directive and a number of practical facilities will increase the level of protection for policyholders and bring legal systems closer together throughout the European Union.

name: Markus Ferber (PPE).
text: Mr President, Commissioner, ladies and gentlemen, I would like to thank the commissioner for his excellent work and for the work she has done. The aim was, in principle, to close the gap in the Insurance Intermediary Directive, which has arisen from legislation in financial products, and, on the other hand, to overcome the consequences of imD1's fragmentation of insurance markets. I think the second has been achieved excellently. A European level playing field – as it is now called – to create a European set of rules that contributes to a unity of the market. On the issue of consumer protection, we in Parliament – and I would like to express my thanks to the rapporteur for this – have taken a very ambitious approach. It was actually my interest, also as rapporteur for financial market regulation, that we have coherence in consumer protection for financial and insurance products. I very much regret that the Member States were not prepared to do so. They had given us more at MiFID than they were willing to give to IMD or IDD, as it is now called. I would also have been pleased if the Commission had made a somewhat more committed contribution here. My concern is that we are now coming to dilution effects and substitution effects between financial products and insurance products. I do not think that was in the interests of the legislator. I am really concerned that we are coming to a regulatory arbitrage here, and I very much regret that.

name: Roberto Gualtieri (S&D).
text: Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, I believe that with this new directive on insurance distribution we are taking a small but important step towards strengthening the single market and deepening financial integration in the Union.  It was, of course, a difficult birth – a lot of work has been done and I would like to congratulate the rapporteur and the entire negotiating team, as well as thank the Commission for its contribution – but this difficulty is also understandable if we take into account the specificity and sensitivity of the subject covered by the directive. I therefore believe that the final result is positive and that it enables us to move towards the creation of a genuine single market in insurance products and to reduce the burden of cross-border access, at the same time, by identifying common principles for strengthening product transparency and consumer protection.  Firstly, the decision extends, as you know, the application of the directive, including direct distribution, and this is important in order to ensure regulatory coherence for all sales channels and, at the same time, I believe that a fair balance is maintained between the application of the rules and proportionality for minor insurance products, if sold by way of accessory. I also believe that some of Parliament's achievements are important: the single standardised document, which allows the consumer to receive all the relevant information on the product he is about to buy and, above all, I would like to add this positive element concerning cross-selling, that is, the possibility of guaranteeing a real choice for the consumer, putting an end to tying practices in certain insurance sectors.  So, overall, this is an important result of which we must rightly be proud.

name: Ildikó Gáll-Pelcz (PPE).
text: – Mr President, consumer protection has now become a central element of EU action. It wasn't all that way, five or six years ago, when these markets were on the brink of collapse, most consumers were unproted. That is why it is important for Mr Langen's work, which I thank you for, to be able to settle this issue reassuringly after three years of work. We are taking significant steps to increase transparency, increase trust and also increase self-care. The Member States have, of course, done theirs, and new legislation has been adopted. We are at the very time where we have 28 different pieces of legislation, and I think that a harmonisation step is needed. Of course, this harmonisation step cannot be another obstacle in this very market, but must be manifested in support.  There are steps in the amendment to the Directive that can be achieved with absolute uniform support, such as training, such as agreement on information requirements. There are also those where there has not been this great consensus: on transparency, especially on the issue of transparency in the remuneration of insurance intermediaries. I cannot support the idea of the European Commission telling me how much this fee is. I think that this depends very much on the culture of the Member States and on the capacity of the economy to dyn it. Transparency, however, and the report.

name: Romana Tomc (PPE).
text: – First of all, of course, my sincere congratulations to my colleague Langen on this legislative report. Every one of us has ever had a bad experience with insurance companies. When we searched for comparable offers, these were as different as in the bids of different car brands. Let's say, as an example, one offer contains something that the other excludes.  It is right that the European directive will touch on everyone involved in the insurance business, from insurance companies that have direct sales to intermediaries, banks and mediators. I am particularly pleased that my colleague Langen has also paid great attention to small and medium-sized entities in this regard.  The new directive provides, inter alia, for an end to cross-selling; I also support this, of course, and it seems right to me that some loan that we take out for personal insurance should not be linked to another insurance policy. However, the standard form, which will be in force from the end of 2017, will provide the main characteristics and prices of the insurance product and ensure an appropriate comparison. Insurance products are everyone's concern and it is important that we have a competitive and transparent market for these services.

name: Isabella De Monte (S&D).
text: – Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, Commissioner, the report on the proposal for a directive on insurance mediation is part of the wider review of all financial markets following the crisis. There are two points to be highlighted: the construction of a more cohesive and integrated single market and greater consumer protection.  This directive harmonises the insurance market, while allowing the national legislature to apply higher levels of protection. With this dual contribution, European citizens will be able to benefit from rules that are comparable between countries but also reflect the peculiarity of the Insurance Market of the Member State. It is also important to stress that insurance intermediaries already have many bureaucratic tasks which involve burdens on business activities, without a higher income being imposed in recent years. Consumer protection and corporate sustainability are two elements that must therefore be balanced, not least in order to allow for proper claims management.

name: Νότης Μαριάς (
text: ECR). Mr President, consumers should enjoy the same level of protection and have a level playing field regardless of the differences between distribution channels. It is also necessary to provide consumers with adequate and adequate information on any insurance product in order to strengthen the internal market. In addition, information should be provided in order to avoid misinformation that may be caused by misleading advertising, for example by consumers, which is why the insurance intermediary is needed.  Care should still be taken in the event of damage to policyholders and consumer confidence. More generally, in insurance mediation, consumer protection provisions should be in line with the Union's right to cover up the possibility of misinformation or damage. Moreover, in times of financial crisis, the insurance sector is being hit.  Finally, in Greece thousands of public and private sector policyholders are at risk of raising the retirement age, while the troika is demanding a redesign of the insurance system.

name: Nicola Caputo (S&D).
text: Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, I have repeatedly said, here too, that the principle of consumer protection is a key value. Recent imbalances in financial markets have shown that divergences in Western economic systems are a source of vulnerability. Very often, induced events manage to destabilise the European economic system, generating panic in the markets and a loss of consumer confidence. I therefore agree with the proposal for a directive harmonising insurance regulation, making the link with banking discipline more coherent and strengthening the resilience of the European financial system, compared to self-induced and hetero-induced events. I support the desire to increase the level of consumer protection, with reference to Directives 92 of 2002 and 65 of 2014 on investment products, to which this regulation must be fully aligned. In fact, if I think of the R.C. Auto Italia and Southern Italy sector, whose prices are far higher than in other countries, on average 45% more, I am convinced that the objective of savings on the policy, combined with the mitigation of distorting factors on competition for the insurance sector, necessarily steps towards a European strengthening of consumer protection in the insurance sector , with the creation of common standards across Europe.

name: Jonathan Hill
text: Member of the Commission. – Mr President, as we have heard, it has been a long gestation, but I think the sense of this debate is that it was worth waiting for. I think there is very broad support for this package of measures. In terms of the themes that were raised, there is a great deal of consistency around the themes of transparency and the importance of proportionality. Here the regime does allow a graduated approach, with a lighter regime for some kinds of business and some businesses in ancillary services excluded altogether. In terms of the consistency between different pieces of legislation, I think we have made good progress. For instance, all the risks on sale standards are a hundred percent aligned with the Markets in Financial Instruments Directive (MiFID), so that is a step forward. We talked about the importance, obviously, of consumer protection and of citizens being better able to understand risks. Here again, I think we have made big steps forward. We have also talked about the necessity of making it possible for there to be innovation, particularly in the field of digital services. In that respect, later this year we will be publishing a Green Paper on retail financial services that will look, in particular, at the question of digital financial services and how we can make further progress there. One of the aspects on insurance that I am keen to look at as well is this question of insurance in the car rental market, where again I think we can make progress in making that market more transparent. So I think this directive will improve transparency. I am very much committed, as we go forward, to striking this right balance between protecting consumers and supporting insurance distribution. Putting in place the level 2 rules for the directive is now the priority. We will work closely with the European Insurance and Occupational Pensions Authority (EIOPA) to develop clear and workable implementing rules in line with the directive, and I know that colleagues in the Parliament will help make that work a success. But for today, I really would just like to thank everyone for their contributions to this debate, and particularly Mr Langen and the shadow rapporteurs for all their hard work over three and a half years. It has been worth it and I think we have made some good progress here with this directive.

name: Werner Langen
text: Rapporteur. Mr President, I would like to thank the I would like to protect the Commission. Mr Ferber is no longer here; he said that the Commission has not worked constructively on all points. I disagree and would like to express my thanks. Of course, the markets have been fragmented, and finding uniform regulation there is not so easy. We have achieved the best there, and iedly thank the Commission very much. Secondly, Mr Giegold said that the Council has prevailed. Mr President, however, only on the points on which you wanted to go further, in the others. We have shared our share of the fact that the title has been changed. Overall, I believe that it is sensible regulation, and it also meets the different needs of the different markets that have developed. For example, in line with the rules in the northern European countries, we have given the Member States the possibility of a ban on commissions and mandatory advice. But Mr Giegold was the only one besides me who survived the change of mandate from the former shadow rapporteurs, so that we can observe continuity better. Mr Woolfe said that we need to think of insurance intermediaries, small and medium-sized enterprises. He obviously did not read the text. This was the starting point for all our efforts: not only to strengthen the large insurance companies and to fulfil their will, but also the total of one million self-employed small and medium-sized insurance intermediaries in the European Union. Finally, I would like to contradict the Commissioner on one point, namely in the note point 69. You said, Commissioner Hill, that the legal services have concerns. I would like to remind you of the March 2014 meeting, when it was a matter of obtaining delegated acts in good time. Mr Barnier has read out a communication from President Barroso that in future the Commission will transmit delegated acts at an early stage, regardless of the legal situation, so that Parliament can examine them and will not be overrun. I assume, Commissioner, that this regulation also applies to the new Commission.

name: Presidente. –
text: The debate is closed. The vote will take place today, Tuesday, 24 November 2015. Let us now turn to the announcement of the winner of the LUX Prize and its award. As the person responsible for the prize, I would like to thank all the Members who contributed to the decision and all the citizens who took part in the vote for the special mention, which will be made on the basis of the consent expressed by the citizens. The vote will take place at the end of the LUX Prize. (The sitting was suspended at 12.00 p.m.) (from 12.00 p.m. to 12.30 p.m., Parliament meets on the occasion of the award of the LUX Prize) (The sitting was resumed at 12.30 p.m.)

name: Presidente. –
text: We shall now proceed to the vote.

name: João Ferreira (GUE/NGL).
text: – Mr President, the measures implementing the Statute for Members provide that the President may justify prolonged absences of Members on health, pregnancy or maternity leave, among others. However, incomprehensibly, the Statute does not provide for the possibility of temporary replacement of the Member or Member, so they wish and express freely. This impossibility is an unjustified damage, first ly to the Member and to his political strength, but also to the voters, who thus find themselves deprived of representation, and to Parliament itself, for its proper functioning. Is it permissible, for example, that in a situation of pregnancy or maternity leave of a Member this triple injury results? What example is this institution doing? It is this reflection that we wanted to raise here in order to take the necessary measures to amend the Statute for Members in this area.

name: Presidente. –
text: Thank you, Mrs Ferreira, for your proposal, but we need to change the rules. Thank you, however, for your proposal.

name: Presidente. –
text: We shall now proceed to the explanations of vote.

name: William (The Earl of) Dartmouth (EFDD)
text: in writing. ‒ Although the measures to repeal old EU legislation only covers Schengen (which the UK is not part of), UKIP will always vote to repeal EU laws. The only people that should create laws are democratically elected and accountable national governments, not unelected bureaucrats in Brussels.

name: Marina Albiol Guzmán (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. I voted in favour of this report to repeal certain acts of the Schengen acquis, as some of this legislation was obsolete and did not apply because of the new regulatory framework that emerged after the Lisbon Treaty. Despite our opposition to it, there would be no point in voting otherwise and maintaining unapplicable regulations.

name: Marie-Christine Arnautu (ENF)
text: In writing. Unfortunately, contrary to what the title of this report might suggest, this is not a question of going back to the Schengen area.  The text is in fact intended to clarify the legal nature by repealing acts that have become obsolete, as temporary or recycled in subsequent acts. Together with my colleagues from the National Front, we have always opposed the Schengen area on the grounds that it constitutes an abandonment of dangerous sovereignty. The latest events prove us right: the Schengen area is a sieve that promotes mass immigration and allows terrorists to come and go on the territory of the Member States of the European Union with impunity.  As this report only discusses clarifying certain acts, but we do not wish to endorse the Schengen area, I have chosen to abstain.

name: Jonathan Arnott (EFDD)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of this technical repeal, although sadly it is unlikely to cut the regulatory burden as the relevant acts were already obsolete.

name: Jean Arthuis (ALDE)
text: In writing. I voted in favour of this deliberation as advocated by the committee on its merits.

name: Zigmantas Balčytis (S&D)
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of this proposal repealing obsolete legislation.

name: Gerard Batten (EFDD)
text: in writing. ‒ Although the measures to repeal old EU legislation only covers Schengen (which the UK is not part of), UKIP will always vote to repeal EU laws. The only people that should create laws are democratically elected and accountable national governments, not unelected bureaucrats in Brussels.

name: Nicolas Bay (ENF)
text: In writing. I abstained on this text, which does not change anything: it is simply a matter of repealing acts that have become obsolete, either because they were temporary or because their content was taken up by subsequent acts. These acts were related to the "area of freedom, security and justice" that would be the wonderful Schengen area. Despite the attacks that hit France on 13 November, the Eurocrats are still not ready to question their Schengen dogma. How many attacks, how many deaths will it take for them to agree to acknowledge their mortal mistakes?

name: Hugues Bayet (S&D)
text: In writing. I voted in favour of this report, which aims to abolish provisions relating to the area of freedom, security and justice that are outdated or have been replaced by more recent texts.

name: Joëlle Bergeron (EFDD)
text: In writing. The achievements of Schengen are now an informed set of decisions and regulations that are considered to be obsolete for many of them either because of their temporary nature or their content taken up by subsequent acts. I support the joint initiative of the Council, the Commission and Parliament to repeal these provisions. This objective of transparency of EU law is indeed an essential part of the strategy to better legislate and to make European rules more acceptable as a substitute for national rules where appropriate. However, I remain very skeptical about this report, which does not go far enough or at the end of its logic of overhauling a system that today shows all its shortcomings. If I were to describe this report, I would say that it is a cataplasm on a wooden leg, both the desired Schengen system, and in particular the abolition of internal border controls, carries within itself all the elements of insecurity and the development of trafficking of all kinds: human, arms and drugs. Repealing only certain acts of the Schengen acquis is not, in my opinion, sufficient. I therefore abstain on this report.

name: Izaskun Bilbao Barandica (ALDE)
text: in writing. I voted in favour of this report in the context of the expiry of the transitional period set out in Protocol No 36 on the Schengen acquis assessment and legal instruments, as a number of acts have been detected which have become obsolete. In the spirit of 'better legislating' I voted in favour.

name: Dominique Bilde (ENF)
text: In writing. I preferred to abstain on this text which, if it is in line with a certain logic, since it aims to repeal obsolete acts relating to Schengen, does not go to the end of things by acting on the obsolescence of Schengen itself. The acts abrogated by the report are finally recognized as outdated, either because of their temporary nature or because they have already been the subject of subsequent acts. For the sake of transparency, it was therefore essential to move towards their legal suppression. However, the tragedy of the recent attacks in Paris and the flight of terrorists who have been able to take full advantage of free movement in the European Union have, once again, tragically brought to light the failure of a sieve Europe and the need, more than ever, to restore our national borders. This report from Parliament therefore does not go far enough again and abstention was therefore required.

name: Mara Bizzotto (ENF)
text: in writing. \u2012 The recent terrorist attacks in Paris and the threats that are affecting Italy and all other European countries are proof that we need more security and more controls. Schengen does not work and needs to be radically reformed.  The text we are voting on is, on the other hand, a simple technical update of the rules in force; That is why I did not intend to support it with my vote. I am convinced that the Schengen Agreement must be radically revised and that we can no longer limit ourselves to minor updates.

name: José Blanco López (S&D)
text: in writing. A number of acts belonging to the Schengen acquis are no longer relevant because of their temporary nature or because their content has been incorporated into successive acts, although they have not been repealed. These are acts that have become obsolete, in particular eleven decisions of the Schengen Executive Committee, the content of which has been incorporated into successive acts and Council Regulation (EC) No 189/2008 of 18 February 2008 on the tests of the second generation Schengen Information System (SIS II), which exhausted its legal effects with the entry into operation of SIS II on 9 April 2013.  That is why I voted in favour of its repeal.

name: Vilija Blinkevičiūtė (S&D)
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of this report because the purpose of this Regulation is to repeal a certain part of the obsolete European union legislation of the Schengen acquis. In view of the end of the transitional period laid down in the Protocol on transitional provisions annexed to the Treaties, the Commission has assessed the Schengen acquis and legal instruments in the field of police cooperation and judicial cooperation in criminal matters. Several pieces of legislation were found to be obsolete as their content was transposed into subsequent legislation or was of a temporary nature.  After consulting the EP's Legal Service and taking into account the amendments proposed by the Council in its general approach on this Commission proposal, the European Parliament proposes to change the form of the legislation from a decision to a regulation. This Regulation is binding in its entirety and directly applicable in all Member States and will be better suited to the objective of the proposal, namely the repeal of legislation considered obsolete.

name: Andrea Bocskor (PPE)
text: Writing. \u2012 Improving the transparency of EU law is an essential element of the better law-improving strategy, which is being implemented by the EU institutions. In this context, it is appropriate to repeal acts which no longer serve any purpose. Many acts covered by the Schengen acquis are no longer relevant, either because of their provisional nature or because their content has been adopted by subsequent acts. It follows from the foregoing that I voted in favour of the adoption of this report.

name: Franc Bogovič (PPE)
text: Writing. On 14 June this year, we marked the 30th anniversary of the Schengen Agreement on the free movement of people between the Member States of the so-called Schengen area, which we undoubtedly mark as one of the greatest achievements of European integration. But the migrant crisis we have seen over the past year puts the so-called crisis at ease. Schengen to the greatest test ever. It also shows that many of the provisions of the agreement work perfectly in ideal situations, with a manageable number of border crossings, while not being anywhere near the current crisis situation. In these, each country finds itself in its own way, not least by agreement. However, such situations lead to mutual recriminations between the Member States of the Schengen area and expose countries that are at the EU's Schengen or external border. These countries, either because of a lack of resources or for other reasons, are not in a proper way able to secure their borders properly, so upgrading Schengen is necessary. If the EU wants to preserve the Schengen area, the EU as a whole must ensure that external or Schengen borders are protected, not leave it to a handful of the most exposed countries. The proposed decision to repeal certain acts governing the Schengen area is purely harmonious in nature and I have, of course, supported it. At the same time, however, this is also an opportunity to revise the rules that are urgently needed. Otherwise, Schengen will become a thing of the past.

name: Biljana Borzan (S&D)
text: Written. ‒I support these Repeal Reports of certain acts because they have their footholds in legal legislation. All acts to be abolished are no longer legally relevant, which is because they have been replaced by new acts, which is because they were temporary in nature.

name: Marie-Christine Boutonnet (ENF)
text: In writing. A number of acts that are part of the Schengen acquis are no longer relevant because of their temporary nature or because their content has been taken up by subsequent acts. In the interests of transparency and "better legislation", they must be repealed. We consider, of course, that Schengen per se is no longer relevant. This report does not involve Schengen, I abstained.

name: Renata Briano (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 The Schengen Convention represents a major step forward in the process of European integration, allowing the free movement of persons within the Union and overcoming the old national border management. Today we are updating the Convention because a number of acts forming part of the Schengen acquis are no longer relevant because of their temporary nature, while others are outdated because their content has been reformulated by subsequent acts although they have not yet been repealed.

name: Steeve Briois (ENF)
text: In writing. A number of acts that are part of the Schengen acquis are no longer relevant because of their temporary nature or because their content has been taken up by subsequent acts. In the interests of transparency, this report recommends repealing them, in particular in order to lighten and simplify the current legislation.  These repeals make sense and we believe that it would not be at all appropriate to maintain these acts as they stand. Nevertheless, we have always been in favour of the abolition of the Schengen area, which is a real sieve for illegal migrants, among whom there are a number of jihadists, as evidenced by the attacks on Friday 13 November in Paris.  Not wishing to endorse the free movement of individuals within the European Union, I abstained on this text.

name: Daniel Buda (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 The problem of achieving clarity and legislative coherence is one that is met by all systems, from national to international. Of course, within the Union, its stringise is felt from the perspective of both The Member States and the litigants, the former because they have to harmonise their national legislation within the Union, and the latter in order to benefit from the Union provisions, transparency or, more accurately, to know their rights as citizens of the Union. In order to achieve this legislative coherence, we must not only be very careful when developing laws, but also follow their progress and application, check and optimise procedures. The Commission has assumed these objectives in accordance with the commitments of the Interinstitutional Agreement on Better Regulation and its policy on appropriate regulation, and will continue to implement them by identifying transitional normative acts which have already achieved their purpose or normative acts the content of which has already been taken over by other normative acts. I voted in favour of repealing this series of acts which have been identified as obsolete because maintaining them would only mislead the Member States and citizens.

name: Gianluca Buonanno (ENF)
text: in writing. \u2012 I am voting against. These three reports signed by the EFF Moraes respond to the need to update the rules in force by repealing a number of acts forming part of the Schengen acquis. These legislative texts are no longer relevant because of their temporary nature or because their content has been taken up in subsequent acts which, however, have not repealed them. On the substance, this can be seen as a positive measure but, given also the developments taking place, especially in recent months, and the firm will on the part of our delegation to completely review the Schengen Agreement, I voted against it. On schengen policies, we cannot just update them, but we need a complete reform.

name: Nicola Caputo (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted today in favour of the report on the proposal for a decision of the European Parliament and of the Council on the repeal of certain acts in the field of freedom, security and justice.  In order to improve the transparency of Union law and to implement the strategy implemented by the Union institutions, known as 'Better lawmaking', it is necessary to remove from existing legislation certain acts that no longer have any reason to remain in force. In particular, there are certain rules in the Schengen acquis which are no longer relevant because of their provisional nature or because their content has been transcribed into subsequent acts. For reasons of legal certainty and clarity, obsolete decisions should therefore be repealed. All these elements are contained in this report, and that is why I have chosen to vote for its acceptance.

name: Matt Carthy (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of this technical file which is essentially a ‘clean-up’ exercise for redundant pieces of legislation which are either no longer necessary or have been incorporated into other acts or texts.  This practice is part of an exercise by the European Commission which it highlighted through its ‘Regulatory Fitness and Performance Programme’ (REFIT) in 2014. The texts in question relate to issuance of Schengen visas, exchange of statistical information, stamping of passports and liaison officers, among others. These texts have since been updated so are no longer needed.

name: James Carver (EFDD)
text: in writing. ‒ Although the measures to repeal old EU legislation only covers Schengen (which the UK is not part of), UKIP will always vote to repeal EU laws. The only people that should create laws are democratically elected and accountable national governments, not unelected bureaucrats in Brussels.

name: David Casa (PPE)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of this report as the acts outlined in it have become irrelevant because they were either temporary by nature or simply succeeded by newer legislation.

name: Fabio Massimo Castaldo (EFDD)
text: in writing. \u2012 The end of the transitional period provided for in Protocol 36 annexed to the Treaty requires the repeal of obsolete acts, replaced by others adopted in accordance with the procedures described in the Treaty of Lisbon. I therefore voted in favour of repeal.

name: Λευτέρης Χριστοφόρου (
text: PPE), in writing. \u2012 Improving the transparency of Union law is an essential element of the better regulation strategy implemented by the Union institutions. In this context, it is appropriate to delete from existing legislation acts which no longer serve any purpose. This is how we support the report, a proposal – a decision of the European Parliament and the Council.

name: Salvatore Cicu (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the measure. In the Interinstitutional Agreement of 16 December 2003, the European Parliament, the Council and the Commission agreed on the need to reduce the volume of the Union's body of legislation and simplify it, including through the repeal of obsolete acts.  On the basis of its examination, in line with the commitments under the Interinstitutional Agreement and its policy on regulatory adequacy, the Commission has put forward a proposal to repeal, as obsolete, 11 decisions of the Schengen Executive Committee because their content has been taken up in subsequent acts, and Council Regulation (EC) No 189/2008 of 18 February 2008 on the technical testing of the Second Generation Schengen Information System (SIS II), which has exhausted its legal effect since SIS II was launched in April 2013.  The measures covered by this proposal are obsolete, either because their content has been taken up in subsequent acts, or because they are no longer relevant because of their temporary nature. Repealing these measures is therefore in accordance with the principles of subsidiarity and proportionality It also helps to improve the transparency of legislative production and to strengthen the concept of legal certainty.

name: Alberto Cirio (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of this report because I agree with the aim of the proposal for a regulation, namely the repeal of a number of obsolete EU acts forming part of the Schengen acquis. I also believe that improving the transparency of EU law is the essential part of the 'Better Lawmaking' strategy implemented by the European institutions.

name: David Coburn (EFDD)
text: in writing. ‒ Although the measures to repeal old EU legislation only covers Schengen (which the UK is not part of), UKIP will always vote to repeal EU laws. The only people that should create laws are democratically elected and accountable national governments, not unelected bureaucrats in Brussels.

name: Carlos Coelho (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 The instruments of the so-called Area of Freedom, Security and Justice, in particular with regard to the Schengen acquis, were initially incorporated by the Treaty of Amsterdam into the Legal Order of the Union. Progressively, many have been updated, reformulated, strengthened and, in some cases, simply become obsolete. This Regulation ensures the repeal of these acts and ensures that, in certain cases, a transitional period is ensured.

name: Jane Collins (EFDD)
text: in writing. – Although the measures to repeal old EU legislation only covers Schengen (which the UK is not part of), UKIP will always vote to repeal EU laws. The only people that should create laws are democratically elected and accountable national governments, not unelected bureaucrats in Brussels.

name: Lara Comi (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 Following the European Commission's assessment of the Schengen acquis", some legislative acts have been described as obsolete because of their temporary nature or because their content has been incorporated into subsequent legislation. The Schengen acquis is the legislative set of policies relating to external border controls, asylum, immigration and judicial cooperation in civil and criminal matters. In order to improve the transparency and certainty of European law, it is essential to reduce the volume of Community legislation and simplify it. I therefore support the report proposing the repeal of eleven decisions taken by the Schengen Executive Committee, which have become obsolete, and the regulation governing the technical testing of the Schengen Information System, as this act has exhausted its legal effect with the implementation of the Schengen Information System. The aim of the proposal cannot be achieved effectively by the Member States alone, but at Community level through measures in accordance with the principles of subsidiarity and proportionality. In this regard, I support the proposal to amend this legislative act in a regulation, so as to make all its elements compulsory and allow its direct application within the Member States.

name: Therese Comodini Cachia (PPE)
text: in writing. ‒ A number of acts that relate to migratory flows have become obsolete after the entry into force of other EU legislative acts such as regulations. Legal certainty and transparency require the deletion of such legislative acts so that citizens may be better advised. I voted in favour.

name: Ignazio Corrao (EFDD)
text: in writing. \u2012 As part of the expiry of the transitional period provided for in Protocol 36 on transitional provisions annexed to the Treaties, the Commission carried out an assessment of the Schengen acquis and legal instruments in the field of police and judicial cooperation in criminal matters. A number of acts have been identified as obsolete because their content has been taken up by subsequent acts or because they were temporary in nature. In the Interinstitutional Agreement of 16 December 2003, Parliament, the Council and the Commission agreed on reducing the volume and simplifying Union law, including by repealing obsolete acts. Such as: 11 decisions of the Schengen Executive Committee because their content has been taken up in subsequent acts, and Council Regulation (EC) No 189/2008 of 18 February 2008, on evidence of the second generation of the Schengen Information System (SIS II), which exhausted its legal effectiveness once SIS II became operational on 9 April 2013. The rapporteur also proposes amending the type of act from decision to regulation, which is therefore binding in its entirety and directly applicable in all Member States. I have chosen to vote in favour because I agree with the rapporteur's explanatory statement.

name: Javier Couso Permuy (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. I voted in favour of this report to repeal certain acts of the Schengen acquis, as some of this legislation was obsolete and did not apply because of the new regulatory framework that emerged after the Lisbon Treaty. Despite our opposition to it, there would be no point in voting otherwise and maintaining unapplicable regulations.

name: Pál Csáky (PPE)
text: Writing. \u2012 Many acts of the Schengen acquis are no longer relevant as they are provisional in nature or have been adopted by subsequent acts, but the original acts have not been repealed. On the basis of its due diligence, the Commission has put forward a proposal to repeal the following outdated acts: Decisions of the Schengen Executive Committee 11, because their content has been taken over by subsequent legislation and Council Regulation (EC) No 189/2008 of 18 February 2008 on the testing of the second generation of the Schengen Information System (SIS II) (OJ L 57, 7.4.2013, p. 1), which exhausted its legal effect when SIS II started operating on 9 April 2013. The report, which supports the repeal of outdated acts, was voted on.

name: Edward Czesak (ECR)
text: I would like to write to the Commission. \u2012 Already in 2003, the European Parliament, the Council and the Commission agreed on the need to take action to reduce the number of EU rules, simplify them and increase transparency. In order to meet these demands, the Commission m.in a specific regulatory fitness and performance programme (REFIT). The programme's activities focus on analysing existing EU legislation and finding those that have become obsessive, either by their temporal nature or by incorporating them into other acts. In the draft regulation repealing certain legal acts relating to the area of freedom, security and justice, the Commission points out a number of such provisions: 11 decisions of the Executive Committee on the Common Visa Policy (SCH/Com-ex) and one Council Regulation, the duration of which is unnecessary because they no longer serve any purpose.  I fully support the refit programme and believe that outdated decisions and regulation should be repealed. I am pleased that the form of the 'decision' act voted on has finally been changed to 'regulation', as the regulations have direct effects in EU law and do not require further bureaucratic measures to implement them. I remain hopeful that the REFIT programme will continue by the Commission and that unnecessary and outdated acts will be removed from EU law.

name: Miriam Dalli (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ As part of the Commission’s policy on regulatory fitness, three related instruments will repeal a number of legal acts in the field of police and judicial cooperation and a number in relation to the Schengen acquis. These acts are no longer legally relevant, either because they have been replaced by more up-to-date legislation or are of a temporary nature. For this reason, I found no objection in supporting this report.

name: Daniel Dalton (ECR)
text: in writing. ‒ This REFIT proposal relates to certain provisions of the Schengen acquis, to which the United Kingdom does not subscribe. As such, the UK will not be bound by this. Therefore, whilst I welcome the repeal of this obsolete measure, as previously on justice and home affairs matters which do not pertain to the UK, I decided to abstain.

name: Michel Dantin (PPE)
text: In writing. This legislative report proposes to repeal certain obsolete acts of the Schengen acquis, relating to the executive committee and the second-generation tests of the Schengen information system. It also recommends changing the legal nature of the Commission's proposal from a decision to an EU regulation, which is considered more appropriate to ensure the immediate and complete repeal of these acts in all Member States. Supporting these objectives and technical changes, I voted in favour of the report.

name: Rachida Dati (PPE)
text: In writing. As these acts have become obsolete, I support this repeal measure because it contributes to greater clarity of European legislation in the area of the area of freedom, security and justice.

name: Mireille D'Ornano (ENF)
text: In writing. These two reports were intended to repeal various temporary acts relating to the Schengen area in the area of police cooperation and judicial cooperation in criminal matters in particular.  Opposed to this area of free movement without control or borders, which is not economically, socially and culturally unspoken, I refuse to participate in these issues of organizing a system that I consider illegitimate and harmful. I therefore abstained in the vote on these two reports by the socialist Claude Moraes.

name: Ian Duncan (ECR)
text: in writing. ‒ These REFIT proposals relate to certain provisions of the Schengen acquis, to which the UK does not subscribe. As such, the UK will not be bound by them. Therefore, whilst I welcome the repeal of obsolete measures, in accordance with our long-standing position on JHA matters which do not pertain to the UK, I will abstain.

name: Ангел Джамбазки (ECR)
text: in writing. \u2012 This report is part of the European Commission's REFIT programme, which aims to repeal European legislative instruments that are no longer valid for Member States. After an evaluation of the acts in the field of police and judicial cooperation, the Ec established several instruments of a temporary nature or the content of which is reflected in follow-up texts. I support the REFIT programme and have supported the repeal of certain acts relating to the Schengen acquis. Furthermore, Bulgaria is not part of the Schengen area and this renders those acts invalid for it because they do not legally bind it.

name: Γεώργιος Επιτήδειος (
text: NI), in writing. \u2012 Concerns the repeal of 11 decisions of the Schengen Executive Committee and Council Regulation 189/2008, due to their incorporation into subsequent acts and the start-up of SIS II, respectively, which is typical, since the previous decisions become obsolete or temporary in nature. Changing the title of the act from "decision" to "regulation" means that the Schengen acquis is binding on member states under Article 228 of the SLEE.

name: Bill Etheridge (EFDD)
text: in writing. – Although the measures to repeal old EU legislation only covers Schengen (which the UK isn’t part of), UKIP will always vote to repeal EU laws. The only people that should create laws are democratically elected and accountable national governments, not unelected bureaucrats in Brussels.

name: José Manuel Fernandes (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 This report reports on the results of the evaluation of the Schengen acquis and legal instruments in the field of police cooperation and judicial cooperation in criminal matters. Several acts were considered obsolete either because of the integration of their content into subsequent acts or because of their temporary nature. The proposal involves repealing 11 decisions of the Schengen Executive Committee, as its content was resumed in subsequent acts, and Council Regulation (EC) No 189/2008 of 18 February 2008 on the second generation testing of the Schengen Information System (SIS II), which ceased to produce legal effects when SIS II became operational on 9 April 2013. I agree with the repeal proposal put forward.

name: Edouard Ferrand (ENF)
text: In writing. I abstained on this vote because I am not involved in decisions on federalist texts.

name: João Ferreira (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. \u2012 The Committee on Freedoms of the European Parliament has decided to frame this report in the Simplified Procedure – Article 50(2) of the Rules of Procedure. The report includes a set of three on the repeal of acts from the Schengen acquis and acts in the field of police cooperation and judicial cooperation in criminal matters. Several acts belonging to the Schengen acquis are no longer relevant because of their temporary nature or because their content was taken up by subsequent acts, although they have not been repealed, making them considered obsolete. This report is therefore of an eminently technical nature. The fact is that, in practical terms, between obsolete acts and those that replace them there are no substantive improvements, so, despite the above, we reaffirm our substantive critical position on Schengen and its acquis. And, as well, with regard to police cooperation and judicial cooperation in criminal matters. These are areas for which we have been critical of the EU's approach and attempts at federal deepening, with increased limitations on member states' decision-making capacity in areas that go to the heart of state sovereignty.

name: Raffaele Fitto (ECR)
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of this proposal for a decision on the repeal of certain acts of the Schengen acquis. I believe that this decision is progressing in terms of transparency and efficiency, greater regulation and renewed commitment to resolving the refugee crisis.

name: Monika Flašíková Beňová (S&D)
text: Writing. \u2012 In the context of the proclaimed intention to better shape and simplify European Union legislation, including through the repeal of obsolete acts, the European Commission's proposal in question repeals obsolete acts on the basis of a review and changes the form of this act to a regulation.

name: Lorenzo Fontana (ENF)
text: in writing. \u2012 The vote on these three reports will be against as there is no need to revise Schengen but to reform it completely.

name: Λάμπρος Φουντούλης (
text: NI), in writing. \u2012 I am voting here on the report on the abolition of certain acts in the field of freedom, security and justice, because while in many of its articles it gives the EU the power to achieve its foreign policy, on the other hand there are important negative points that show that ultimately its participation in this game is not what it should be in order to be the most important influence factor for the global political and geopolitical changes that are taking place , since once again it's tied to the U.S. tank.

name: Doru-Claudian Frunzulică (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ In the context of the expiry of the transitional period set out in Protocol 36 on transitional provisions, annexed to the Treaties, the Commission has performed an assessment of the Schengen acquis and of the legal instruments in the field of police cooperation and judicial cooperation in criminal matters. A number of acts have been identified as obsolete because their content has been taken up by subsequent acts or because they are temporary in nature. In the Inter-institutional Agreement of 16 December 2003 the European Parliament, the Council and the Commission agreed on reducing the volume of, and simplifying, Union law, including by repealing obsolete acts. On the basis of its screening and in line with the commitments in the inter-institutional agreement on better law-making and its policy on Regulatory Fitness, the Commission submitted a proposal to repeal as obsolete the following acts: - 11 decisions of the Schengen Executive Committee because their content had been taken up in subsequent acts, and - Council Regulation (EC) No 189/2008 of 18 February 2008 on the testing of the second generation Schengen Information System (SIS II), the legal effect of which was exhausted once the SIS II became operational on 9 April 2013.

name: Kinga Gál (PPE)
text: in writing. ‒ We from the Fidesz Party (EPP Group) voted in favour of this report on the proposal for a decision of the European Parliament and of the Council repealing certain acts in the Area of Freedom Security and Justice. The Committee on Civil Liberties, Justice and Home Affairs recommended that the position of the European Parliament adopted at first reading under the ordinary legislative procedure should amend the Commission proposal. With this vote we change the type of act from ‘decision’ to ‘regulation’. In accordance with the Article 288 TFEU, a regulation is binding in its entirety and directly applicable in all Member States and will better serve the purpose of the proposal to repeal the acts deemed to be obsolete. With this vote we also seek to improve the drafting of the act, including an addition in the title stating that the repealed acts in question are part of the Schengen acquis. We also clarify that Denmark is not bound by the regulation or subject to its application, but that it shall decide, within a period of six months after the Council has decided on this regulation, whether to implement it in its national law.

name: Ildikó Gáll-Pelcz (PPE)
text: Writing. \u2012 I would like to explain my vote by knowing that the Commission has put forward a proposal on the basis of its due diligence and in line with its commitments under the Interinstitutional Agreement and its policy on regulatory fit for purpose and concluded that a number of outdated acts should be repealed. This was the result of an investigation carried out by the Commission, in the context of the expiry of the transitional period attached to the Treaty on the Functioning of the European Union, with regard to the Schengen acquis and the existing legal instruments in the field of police and judicial cooperation in criminal matters. The Commission found that a number of acts were outdated because their content had been taken over by subsequent acts or because they were of a temporary nature.

name: Francesc Gambús (PPE)
text: in writing. I voted in favour of the finding that a number of acts have become obsolete, either because their content has been incorporated into successive acts or because they were temporary acts.

name: Elena Gentile (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the resolution on the proposal for a decision of the European Parliament and of the Council on the repeal of certain acts in the area of freedom, security and justice for which Mr Moraes is rapporteur.  I believe, in fact, that a number of acts covered by the Schengen acquis are now obsolete, temporary or already incorporated into subsequent rules. In order to streamline and simplify EU regulation, it is necessary to reduce the EU's legislative body and make red tape easier for professionals but also for European citizens who want to better understand EU legislation.

name: Arne Gericke (ECR)
text: Writing. I voted today in favour of the report on the repeal of certain pieces of legislation from the Schengen acquis, as I believe that the further development and updating of the Schengen Agreement is essential, especially at this time.

name: Jens Gieseke (PPE)
text: Writing. Some of the pieces of legislation under the Schengen acquis are outdated or out of date. Either the relevant content has been revisited in other legal acts, or it is limited in time. That is why the Commission's proposal to repeal these acts is correct. This improves the clarity of existing rules.

name: Neena Gill (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of the report on the proposal for a decision of the European Parliament and of the Council repealing certain acts in the areas of freedom, security and justice, which aims to revoke measures that are no longer relevant because of their temporary nature or because their content has been taken up by successive acts.

name: Juan Carlos Girauta Vidal (ALDE)
text: in writing. A number of acts belonging to the Schengen acquis are no longer relevant because of their temporary nature or because their content has been incorporated into successive acts, although they have not been repealed. An example is Regulation (EC) No 189/2008, which exhausted its legal effects with the entry into operation of the second generation Schengen Information System (SIS II) on 9 April 2013. For reasons of legal certainty and clarity, such outdated legal instruments should be repealed.

name: Tania González Peñas (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. This repeal is exempt from political content and is simply about the overcoming, through successive acts, of certain regulations, which are therefore exceeded or contained in others. That's why we voted in favour.

name: Theresa Griffin (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of this proposal. Improving the transparency of Union law is an essential element of the better law-making strategy that the institutions of the Union are implementing. In that context it is appropriate to remove from the legislation in force those acts which no longer serve any purpose. A number of acts belonging to the Schengen acquis are no longer relevant due to their temporary nature or because their content has been taken up by successive acts, even though they have not been repealed.

name: Françoise Grossetête (PPE)
text: In writing. On Tuesday 24 November, I voted in favour of three reports aimed at repealing certain acts of the Schengen acquis. These texts aim to undo a number of legal measures related to the area of freedom, security and justice, as well as legal provisions in the field of police and judicial cooperation in criminal matters, which have become obsolete. The acts here repealed are, in fact, no longer relevant because of their temporary nature or because their content has been taken up by subsequent acts. The aim here is to be consistent and to improve the transparency of EU law in order to better legislate in the interests of European citizens.

name: Antanas Guoga (ALDE)
text: in writing. ‒ I have voted for the report on the proposal for a decision of the European Parliament and of the Council repealing certain acts in the areas of freedom, security and justice because I believe that improving the transparency of Union law is an essential element of the better law-making strategy that the institutions of the Union are implementing. It is appropriate to remove those acts which no longer serve any purpose so as not to cause any confusion for the implementation.

name: Τάκης Χατζηγεωργίου (GUE/NGL)
text: Writing. Given the technical nature of this 'clearance' procedure, which also contributes to legal clarity, we are voting in favour of the report.

name: Brian Hayes (PPE)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted for this report which proposes to change the type of the act from ʽdecision’ to ‘regulation’. A regulation will be binding in its entirety and directly applicable in all Member States and will better serve the purpose of the proposal to repeal the acts deemed to be obsolete. A number of acts have been identified as obsolete because their content has been taken up by successive acts or because they are temporary in nature.

name: Roger Helmer (EFDD)
text: in writing. ‒ Although the measures to repeal old EU legislation only covers Schengen (which the UK isn’t part of), UKIP will always vote to repeal EU laws. The only people that should create laws are democratically elected and accountable national governments, not unelected bureaucrats in Brussels.

name: Hans-Olaf Henkel (ECR)
text: Writing. In three decisions, the Commission proposed to repeal acts belonging to the Schengen acquis either for a limited period of time or for their content to be incorporated into subsequent legal acts. The aim is to achieve better regulation by achieving greater transparency of Union law. We support de-bureaucratisation and have also voted in the LIBE Committee to repeal outdated legislation. Alfa is in favour of legal certainty and legal clarity. The measures proposed in the reports are likely to reduce EU legislation and simplify Union law. I strongly support these concerns and have therefore voted in favour of the report. Incidentally, I believe that the euro must be abolished because it leads to strife and discord in Europe!

name: Brice Hortefeux (PPE)
text: In writing. I supported the proposal to repeal the Schengen acquis in the area of police and judicial cooperation in criminal matters, which have become obsolete because of their temporary nature or because their content has been taken up by subsequent acts. It is absolutely not a question of questioning what works in Schengen, but of simplifying the European regulations, which I have often deplored as cumbersome and incongruised. This vote, however, allows me to renew my call for realism. My party has long called for an overhaul of Schengen to adapt to new realities and threats that are breaking free of national borders.  The urgent need is for tighter control of external borders and systematic control of third-country nationals as well as European citizens.

name: Ivan Jakovčić (ALDE)
text: Written. ‒ I voted for a draft legislative resolution of the European Parliament on the proposal for a decision by Parliament and the Council to repeal certain acts in the area of freedom, security and justice on the basis that the content of such acts is present in the new acts or has been limited in validity. In this context, I support the reduction and simplification of union legal texts, including the repeal procedure. Therefore, I support, in this case, the repeal of the provisions and individual decisions concerning Schengen. Clarity and transparency of civil liberties and justice law is essential for the functioning of the entire Union system.

name: Jean-François Jalkh (ENF)
text: In writing. Contrary to what the title of this report might suggest, this is not a question of going back to the Schengen area.  It is really a question of clarifying a legal nature by repealing acts that have become obsolete, as temporary or recycled in subsequent acts. Together with my colleagues from the National Front, we have always opposed the Schengen area on the grounds that it constitutes an abandonment of dangerous sovereignty. The latest events prove us right: the Schengen area is a sieve that promotes mass immigration and allows terrorists to come and go on the territory of the Member States of the European Union with impunity.  Since this report only discusses clarifying certain acts, but we do not wish to endorse the Schengen area, I abstained.

name: Diane James (EFDD)
text: in writing. – Although the measures to repeal old EU legislation only covers Schengen (which the UK isn’t part of), UKIP will always vote to repeal EU laws. The only people that should create laws are democratically elected and accountable national governments, not unelected bureaucrats in Brussels.

name: Petr Ježek (ALDE)
text: Writing. \u2012 The Commission's proposal to repeal certain parts of EU legislative acts was supported by an overwhelming majority of Members, including me. This is merely a legal update, with the eliminated of several temporary measures and legislative acts that have expired. The aim of this update is to make european Union law more clear.

name: Marc Joulaud (PPE)
text: In writing. I voted in favour of my colleague Claude Moraes' report on the repeal of certain acts of the Schengen acquis. Indeed, certain acts concerning legal measures on the area of freedom, security and justice were temporary or were included in other acts after the fact. It was therefore necessary to repeal them in order to clarify and simplify the acts.  This report was adopted by a large majority, which I welcome.

name: Philippe Juvin (PPE)
text: In writing. I voted in favour of this report because it removes a number of obsolete acts concerning the area of freedom, security and justice. The aim was to improve transparency, clarity and consistency for better European legislation.

name: Barbara Kappel (ENF)
