text: Writing. This report concerns the repeal of certain acts relating to the area of freedom, security and justice. These are technical changes and these acts are considered to be outdated. On the basis of fundamental considerations on the Schengen Agreement, I am abstaining from voting.

name: Afzal Khan (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ These acts are no longer relevant because of their temporary nature or because their content has been taken up by successive acts. Therefore, for reasons of legal certainty and in order to bring acts in the area of freedom, security and justice in line with the Lisbon Treaty, I voted in favour of repealing these acts.

name: Bernd Kölmel (ECR)
text: Writing. In three decisions, the Commission proposed to repeal acts belonging to the Schengen acquis either for a limited period of time or for their content to be incorporated into subsequent legal acts. The aim is to achieve better regulation by achieving greater transparency of Union law. In this context, the rapporteur, Claude Moraes, believes that it is appropriate to remove from the existing acquis acts that are no longer of use. According to the Commission, this is to be achieved by means of three decisions. Unlike the Commission, the rapporteur recommends changing the nature of the act from a decision to a regulation. After consulting the European Parliament's Legal Service, Claude Moraes has also identified two other obsolete acts which are part of the Schengen acquis and are no longer relevant because they were temporary or were incorporated into subsequent legal acts. The ECR supports the REFIT programme in the sense of de-bureaucratisation and has also voted in the LIBE Committee for the repeal of outdated legislation. The ALFA is in favour of legal certainty and clarity. The measures proposed in the reports are likely to reduce EU legislation and simplify Union law. I strongly support these concerns and have therefore voted in favour of the report.

name: Béla Kovács (NI)
text: Writing. – The European Parliament has also put on the agenda 3 substances today in connection with the clarification and legal clarification of the oversold provisions of the Schengen Agreement. Obviously, as the most important thing to do in connection with border surveillance. I can almost see the picture: an old man in slippers in an armchair, wrapped in a plaid blanket, puffing contentedly from his pipe, browsing a 20-year-old newspaper with his back to the fireplace. Meanwhile, the carpet was already on fire from the scorked embers, the curtains were on fire, and then the whole house was on fire.

name: Giovanni La Via (PPE)
text: in writing. In line with the commitments made in the inter-institutional agreement on a regulatory policy, the European Parliament, the Council and the Commission agree on the need to reduce the volume of the Union's body of legislation, simplifying and improving it. Specifically, it concerns the repeal of 11 decisions of the Schengen Executive Committee and Council Regulation (EC) No 189/2008 on the technical testing of the Second Generation Schengen Information System (SIS II).  I have chosen to vote in favour because the content of certain decisions of the Schengen Executive Committee has indeed been taken up in subsequent acts or because of their temporary nature.

name: Constance Le Grip (PPE)
text: In writing. I voted in favour of the report on the proposed decision by the European Parliament and the Council to repeal certain acts related to the area of freedom, security and justice, which have become obsolete. In order to improve the effectiveness of the act, we have proposed the modification of the type of act, from 'decision' to 'regulation', which is compulsory in all its elements and directly applicable by the Member States. Furthermore, the Republicans and I call for a major overhaul of the Schengen Agreements, which are inappropriate in their current form and functioning to the reality of the threats that the countries of the Union now face.

name: Marine Le Pen (ENF)
text: In writing. A number of acts that are part of the Schengen acquis are no longer relevant because of their temporary nature or because their content has been taken up by subsequent acts. In the interests of transparency and "better legislation", they must be repealed. However, recent events demonstrate once again that Schengen itself is no longer relevant. The external borders are no longer guarded, so the system is out of date. That is why I abstained on the proposal to repeal only certain acts.

name: Philippe Loiseau (ENF)
text: In writing. I abstained in this vote. Some texts and acts that are part of the Schengen acquis are no longer relevant, either because they had a purely temporary vocation or because subsequent acts replaced them. Repealing them is therefore a logical decision, for the purpose of transparency and relief of legislation.  Nevertheless, we question the overall opportunity of Schengen. Voting for it might therefore have sent a signal of endorsement of this European utopia, when voting against would be tantamount to wanting to maintain obsolete acts. Abstention was therefore the only possible political and technical choice.

name: Paloma López Bermejo (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. I voted in favour of this report to repeal certain acts of the Schengen acquis, as some of this legislation was obsolete and did not apply because of the new regulatory framework that emerged after the Lisbon Treaty. Despite our opposition to it, there would be no point in voting otherwise and maintaining unapplicable regulations.

name: Bernd Lucke (ECR)
text: Writing. In three decisions, the Commission proposed to repeal acts belonging to the Schengen acquis either for a limited period of time or for their content to be incorporated into subsequent legal acts. The aim is to achieve better regulation by achieving greater transparency of Union law. In this context, the rapporteur, Claude Moraes, believes that it is appropriate to remove from the existing acquis acts that are no longer of use. According to the Commission, this is to be achieved by means of three decisions. Unlike the Commission, the rapporteur recommends changing the nature of the act from a decision to a regulation. After consulting the European Parliament's Legal Service, Claude Moraes has also identified two other obsolete acts which are part of the Schengen acquis and are no longer relevant because they were temporary or were incorporated into subsequent legal acts. The ECR supports the REFIT programme in the sense of de-bureaucratisation and has also voted in the LIBE Committee for the repeal of outdated legal acts. The ALFA is in favour of legal certainty and clarity. The measures proposed in the reports are likely to reduce EU legislation and simplify Union law. I strongly support these concerns and have therefore voted in favour of the report.

name: Ivana Maletić (PPE)
text: Written. In order to simplify the law and abolish outdated laws, the Commission carried out an assessment of the Schengen acquis and legal instruments. It was concluded that many acts are no longer relevant because of their temporary nature or because their content is covered by subsequent acts, although they have not been repealed.  The Commission has submitted a proposal to abolish the 11 decisions of the Schengen Executive Board and Council Regulation No 11. 189/2008. After consulting the Legal Service of the European Parliament, it is also proposed to change the type of act in the 'decision' to 'regulation', as the rules under Article 288 of the TFEU are fully binding and directly applicable in all Member States. I supported MeP Claud Moraes' report, as I believe that the abolition of outdated rules is necessary to ensure the legal certainty and transparency of UNION law, which is a key element for better law-making.

name: Andrejs
text: Mamikins (S&D), in writing. \u2012 When a case – in this case the law – no longer fulfils its functions, there are different options for what can be done. The first is to modify this legislation to bring it into line with today's real ones and to continue to serve effectively for the tasks originally set. The second option is to repeal those acts if they are already completely obsolete and cannot continue to fulfil their primary functions. The third option (which often goes together and actually complements the second one) is to adopt new legislation that would take over the role of obsolete acts. In particular, the regulation proposed here (former decision) was necessary in order to repeal the 11 decisions relating to the functioning of the Schengen area, as well as the tests of the second generation Schengen Information System, which still expired more than two years ago with the entry into force of the system. Among these 11 decisions were visa policy, the fight against illegal immigration, the issuing of Schengen visas or the exchange of statistical information. While these things are undoubtedly very important and the functioning of the Schengen area is very necessary, not to mention the European Union's own action in the field of border protection, these decisions are obsolete and replaced by the latest legislation, so it simply made no sense to keep them between active legal acts.

name: Vladimír Maňka (S&D)
text: Writing. \u2012 Regular revision of EU legislation should be an obvious part of legislative activity. Some legislation in the area of freedom, security and justice does not fulfil its purpose or is of a temporary nature, is outdated and does not serve effectively the needs of real practice.  Therefore, the proposed repeal will contribute to increasing the transparency of legislation, easier orientation and, ultimately, easier interpretation of standards in the areas concerned.

name: Νότης Μαριάς (
text: ECR), in writing. \u2012 I am voting in favour of the report on the proposal for a decision of the European Parliament and of the Council on the repeal of certain acts in the area of freedom, security and justice, because it is complete and documented.

name: Dominique Martin (ENF)
text: In writing. I abstained on this vote. We believe that the Schengen area is no longer relevant, especially in light of recent events which have shown its futility. Voting for this repeal would be a guarantee of Schengen, and a vote against is useless since it would only serve to keep obsolete acts and would not even call into question the space itself. Abstention is the only valid choice.

name: David Martin (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ I supported this proposal. Improving the transparency of Union law is an essential element of the better law-making strategy that the institutions of the Union are implementing. In that context it is appropriate to remove from the legislation in force those acts which no longer serve any purpose. A number of acts belonging to the Schengen acquis are no longer relevant due to their temporary nature or because their content has been taken up by successive acts, even though they have not been repealed.

name: Fulvio Martusciello (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 Improving the transparency of Union law is a substantial part of the 'Better Lawmaking' strategy implemented by the Union institutions. It is therefore useful to remove from the legislation in force acts which no longer have any reason to be in force because these acts are considered obsolete because their content is taken up in subsequent acts or because of their temporary nature. That is why I voted in favour of the report on the repeal of certain acts of the Schengen acquis.

name: Georg Mayer (ENF)
text: Writing. This is a purely technical report on the Schengen acts. The current situation confirms our critical attitude to the Schengen laws. The report only reflects the current legal situation. Since it does not bring about any change in content, I abstain from my voice.

name: Jean-Luc Mélenchon (GUE/NGL)
text: In writing. In this report, the Commission proposes to repeal a dozen obsolete legislative acts since the integration of the Schengen acquis directly into the European treaties. Thus, "the obligation on Schengen states to exchange statistical information to better control migration at external borders" has been abolished because it has become obsolete since regulation (EC) 2007/2004 came into force, which entrusted THE FRONTEX agency with the management and analysis of the situation at external borders. Strange deprivation in the current context! Although this is a technical report aimed at "simplifying" EU law, I am voting against it to disagree with these measures, which have revealed their profound inefficiency. It is not to be welcomed that they are integrated into the treaties and thus made even more difficult to change.

name: Joëlle Mélin (ENF)
text: In writing. The idea in this report is not to return to the Shengen space but to clarify its legal framework, by repealing acts that have become obsolete because they are temporary or recycled in subsequent acts.  The National Front is opposed to the Shengen space, a tool detrimental to our country, as evidenced by recent events. Since this report only discusses clarifying certain acts, but he does not wish to endorse the Schengen area, I abstain on this vote.

name: Nuno Melo (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 The European Commission has assessed the Schengen acquis and existing legal instruments in the context of judicial and police cooperation in criminal matters, taking into account Protocol No 36 annexed to the Treaties on transitional provisions. In the case of obsolete provisions - either by their exclusively temporary nature or by changing their content by subsequent acts - with a view to simplifying the legislation, with gains in certainty and legal certainty, better regulation means the repeal of those acts. I have therefore voted in favour of the proposal for a decision of the European Parliament and the Council repealing certain acts in the field of freedom, security and justice.

name: Roberta Metsola (PPE)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of repealing obsolete acts from the Schengen acquis as it will lead to more efficient and transparent EU legislation.

name: Miroslav Mikolášik (PPE)
text: Writing. \u2012 Improving the transparency of acts is an important factor in the development of Union law. Regulations and acts are being repealed due to their temporary nature or the takeover of their content into more recent regulations. In assessing the Schengen acquis, many acts have been labelled as obsolete, so the Commission has put forward a proposal to abolish them. A total of 11 acts are repealed, including the exchange of information, the issuance of Schengen visas, the fight against illegal immigration or the verification of documents. The aim of the Regulation is to adopt measures at Union level which are equally binding in their entirety on The Member States. I therefore support the decision to repeal obsolete and temporary acts, the content of which is obsolete or taken into subsequent acts.

name: Marlene Mizzi (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ I have voted in favour of the report on repealing certain acts from the Schengen acquis, which is as part of the Commission policy on Regulatory Fitness. This related instrument will repeal a number of legal acts in the field of police and judicial cooperation and a number in relation to the Schengen Acquis. All of the acts to be repealed are no longer legally relevant either because they have been replaced by a more up-to-date legal act or they are of a temporary nature.

name: Csaba Molnár (S&D)
text: Writing. \u2012 The Commission stated in its analysis of the Schengen acquis and police and judicial cooperation in criminal matters that that 11 decisions of the Schengen Executive Committee are obsolete because their content has been adopted by subsequent legislation and that Council Regulation (EC) No 189/2008 of 18 February 2008 on testing the second generation of the Schengen Information System (SIS II) was obsolete when SIS II began its operation on 9 April 2013. It has therefore proposed to adopt a decision of the European Parliament and of the Council repealing them.  In its report, the Committee on Civil Liberties, Justice and Home Affairs recommended the draft to Parliament for adoption by proposing to change the type of act from decision to regulation, since the Regulation is fully binding and directly applicable in all Member States and better serves the purpose of the proposal. I supported the draft.

name: Bernard Monot (ENF)
text: In writing. A number of acts that are part of the Schengen acquis are no longer relevant because of their temporary nature or because their content has been taken up by subsequent acts. In the interests of transparency and legislative clarity, it is proposed to repeal them. However, we consider that it is the Schengen agreements themselves that are no longer relevant. It is therefore their complete suppression that must be considered, this technical repeal calls for no other position than abstention.

name: Cláudia Monteiro de Aguiar (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 According to the European Better Regulation strategy, which presupposes greater transparency of EU law, and with the main objective of simplifying and making European regulation more effective, all acts which become obsolete both because of their content and their temporary character should be repealed. To this extent, certain acts in the field of freedom, security and justice have become obsolete within the Schengen acquis. The content of 11 decisions of the Schengen Executive Committee was resumed in subsequent acts and Council Regulation (EC) No 189/2008 of 18 February 2008 on the testing of the second generation of the Schengen Information System (SIS II) ceased its legal effects when this system became operational.  In view of the various amendments, it has become necessary to change the type of "decision" act to "regulation", as the latter is mandatory and is directly applicable to the Member States, and is better in keeping with the objective of the report in question. I am voting in favour of this proposal, as its adoption meets the objectives of clarity and legal certainty which must be achieved under EU law.

name: Sophie Montel (ENF)
text: In writing. This report relates to a proposal to simplify the law. Indeed, the relevance of certain Schengen provisions has been called into question because they have been taken up by subsequent acts. This is part of a transparency approach and within the framework of the Better Regulation Policy put in place by the European Commission.  However, while I support this desire to simplify and clarify positive law, I condemn the very idea of the Schengen agreements. However, to vote in favour of this report would be to give a blank answer to the absence of national borders. I can therefore only vote against this proposal, which does not call into question the Schengen agreements.  I have therefore decided to abstain in the vote on this text.

name: Nadine Morano (PPE)
text: In writing. I voted in favour of this report on the repeal of certain acts related to the area of freedom, security and justice. Improving the transparency of EU law is an essential part of the strategy to better legislate, which the EU institutions are currently implementing. Some legal measures are no longer relevant because of their temporary nature or because their content has been taken up by subsequent acts. They should therefore be removed from existing legislation.

name: Renaud Muselier (PPE)
text: In writing. I was not able to vote for this report, but I fully support the position of the EPP Group and the French delegation to adopt this report. A number of acts that are part of the Schengen acquis are no longer relevant because of their temporary nature, so they should be repealed.

name: József Nagy (PPE)
text: Writing. \u2012 I support the proposals for the repeal of certain acts in the area of freedom, security and legal cooperation and police and judicial cooperation in criminal matters, as I consider it important to ensure transparency and clarity of laws. In any case, the topicality of European Union legislation can be seen as a positive one, which is why we must not forget the outdated regulations, which no longer serve any purpose and should be repealed.

name: Victor Negrescu (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ I have voted for this report that is adapting the content of certain acts in the area of freedom, security and justice deemed to be obsolete because they have been taken up by successive acts or because they have temporary nature.

name: Norica Nicolai (ALDE)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of this text as it was high time to update the Schengen acquis. Having an unclear or outdated text at this sensitive time was needlessly damaging for the interests of both Member States who are inside and those Members who are yet to join the Schengen area, but should do so soon and would have had trouble, otherwise, with the outdated text.

name: Franz Obermayr (ENF)
text: Writing. This report refers to a Commission proposal for a decision to repeal certain acts relating to the area of freedom, security and justice. This is a purely technical report, which is why I abstained.

name: Younous Omarjee (GUE/NGL)
text: In writing. I supported this report to approve the Commission's decision to repeal legislation rendered obsolete by the integration of Schengen's achievements into the European treaties. This report removes the acts allowing Member States to exchange statistical information on migration flows at external borders, which was forwarded to Frontex after the adoption of REGULATION EC 2007/2004. The simplification of European legislation is important and necessary.

name: Urmas Paet (ALDE)
text: Writing. \u2012 I supported because over time many laws have expired or their content has been transposed into other acts.

name: Margot Parker (EFDD)
text: in writing. ‒ Although the measures to repeal old EU legislation only covers Schengen (which the UK isn’t part of), UKIP will always vote to repeal EU laws. The only people that should create laws are democratically elected and accountable national governments, not unelected bureaucrats in Brussels.

name: Aldo Patriciello (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 The issues at the heart of the current discussions have led the EU institutions to review the Schengen legislation and to conclude that it needs simplification in order to better address issues relating to both migration and the terrorist threat. I contribute to this work not only by renewing my commitment to working with colleagues on this issue, but also by voting positively.

name: Marijana Petir (PPE)
text: Written. ‒ This Regulation repeals 11 acts relating to the regulation of entry and exit control from Member States within the Schengen area. As these issues are regulated by more recent acts, such as the exchange of statistics carried out by FRONTEX today, these decisions are outdated. One such regulation is the Schengen Information System Tests Regulation, which have been in use for a long time. I supported this Report because I believe it is necessary to remove from the Schengen acquis all those acts that no longer have the purpose of existence in order to simplify and make legislation more transparent. This is a key element of the better law-making strategy implemented by the Union institutions. Although the Republic of Croatia is not yet a member of the Schengen area, Croatia's goal is to enter Schengen. Therefore, it is also in my interest as members, but also for all Citizens of Croatia, that the rules of the acquis commuliness along the Schengen area be accessible and understandable to everyone.

name: Florian Philippot (ENF)
text: In writing. This report relates to a proposal to simplify the law. Indeed, the relevance of certain Schengen provisions has been called into question because they have been taken up by subsequent acts. This is part of a transparency approach and within the framework of the Better Legislation policy put in place by the European Commission.  However, while I support this desire to simplify and clarify positive law, I condemn the very idea of the Schengen agreements. However, to vote in favour of this report would be to give a blank answer to the absence of national borders. I can therefore only vote against this proposal, which does not call into question the Schengen agreements.  I have therefore decided to abstain in the vote on this text.

name: Tonino Picula (S&D)
text: Written. I support the Commission's proposal to abolish a total of 11 decisions of the Schengen Executive Board and one Council regulation. The decisions were mainly about changes in visa policy and migration control issues. It is interesting to note that in several cases the new REGULATIONS have fully assumed the function of Member States in old decisions, such as exchanging migration statistics and controlling migration at the external borders. Similarly, Europol has been entrusted with tasks related to the exchange of information on the fight against irregular migration, and a new legal framework of cooperation on external border control has been introduced between Member States, including the deployment of immigration liaison officers to third countries.  In the last few months, we have witnessed sudden and serious threats to the Schengen free zone, and instead of maintaining a common security framework, some Member States are acting on their own and temporarily suspending the Schengen regime in line with the growing public fear of uncontrolled migration. Following the tragic events in Paris, it is expected that there will be a need to re-evaluate the Schengen provisions so far and the likely circumvention of the rules by individual Member States that are part of Schengen.

name: Andrej Plenković (PPE)
text: Written. ‒For the sake of the credibility and transparency of EU law, I consider it necessary to remove acts that no longer serve a purpose from the legislation in force. In addition to new acts leading to the need to repeal old people, new functioning organisations have been set up accordingly, taking on jobs that would be the responsibility of Member States and other organisations and bodies. The repeal of a number of outdated Union acts from the Schengen acquis at Union level provides legal certainty and clarity that cannot be sufficiently achieved at Member State level. Consequently, I consider it justified the repeal of all 11 proposed decisions of that Council Regulation (EC) No 11. 189/2008.

name: Salvatore Domenico Pogliese (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 The better regulation strategy was created in order to ensure greater transparency and promote legal certainty. According to it, acts adopted by the EU which have exhausted all their effects, or which are no longer relevant because of their temporary nature or because their content has been taken up in subsequent acts, may be repealed. The text of this report proposes to repeal certain acts relating to freedom, security and justice, which have become obsolete because their content has been incorporated into subsequent acts. For all this, I have chosen to vote in favour of repealing these pieces of legislation.

name: Jiří Pospíšil (PPE)
text: Writing. \u2012 I am very glad that, in addition to the constant adoption of new legislative standards, the European Parliament has also decided at this meeting to repeal acts that are no longer needed. I believe that this imaginary window, when we are dealing with the revision of EU legislation, will be repeated in our next negotiations.

name: Franck Proust (PPE)
text: In writing. I voted to repeal this text because it had become legally obsolete. We must adopt clear texts to effectively strengthen our area of freedom, security and justice.

name: Paulo Rangel (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 This Commission proposal provides for the repeal of a number of acts belonging to the Schengen acquis, which have become obsolete either by virtue of the integration of their content into subsequent acts or because of their temporary nature. In this particular case, the repeal of eleven decisions of the Schengen Executive Committee and Regulation (EC) No 189/2008 of 18 February 2008 on the testing of the second generation of the Schengen Information System is at stake.  With a view to the end of the transitional period set out in Protocol No 36, annexed to the Treaties and considering the objectives of simplification and reduction of the volume of legislation included in the Better Regulation strategy, I voted in favour.

name: Julia Reid (EFDD)
text: in writing. ‒ Although the measures to repeal old EU legislation only covers Schengen (which the UK isn’t part of), UKIP will always vote to repeal EU laws. The only people that should create laws are democratically elected and accountable national governments, not unelected bureaucrats in Brussels.

name: Liliana Rodrigues (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 Relates only to the revocation of obsolete acts (mostly related to visas, passports and exchange of information).

name: Inmaculada Rodríguez-Piñero Fernández (S&D)
text: in writing. A number of acts belonging to the Schengen acquis are no longer relevant because of their temporary nature or because their content has been incorporated into successive acts, although they have not been repealed. These are acts that have become obsolete, in particular eleven decisions of the Schengen Executive Committee, the content of which has been incorporated into successive acts and Council Regulation (EC) No 189/2008 of 18 February 2008 on the tests of the second generation Schengen Information System (SIS II), which exhausted its legal effects with the entry into operation of SIS II on 9 April 2013.  That is why I voted in favour of its repeal.

name: Claude Rolin (PPE)
text: In writing. In the context of the expiry of the transitional period set out in Protocol 36 on transitional provisions, attached to the treaties, the European Commission has carried out an assessment of the Schengen acquis and legal instruments in the field of police and judicial cooperation in criminal matters.  A number of acts have been identified as obsolete because their content has been taken up by subsequent acts or because of their temporary nature. The Commission has put forward a proposal to repeal, because of their obsolescence, the decisions of the executive committee SCH/Com-ex 14 (anti-narcotics trafficking) and 52 (police cooperation memento), the statement of the executive committee SCH/Com-ex decil. 13, Rev. 2 (abduction of minors) and the Council's 2008/173/JAI decision of 18 February 2018 on testing the second generation Schengen Information System (SIS II). So I supported that report.

name: Fernando Ruas (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 After analysis by the Commission, it has been found that there are a number of legal acts relating to the "Schengen acquis"- area of freedom, security and justice - which are no longer relevant because of their temporary nature or because their content has been replicated in subsequent acts.  The purpose of this report is then to repeal a number of legal measures in relation to these matters, which have been identified as obsolete. To that extent, in the case of an eminently technical report and in view of the question of matters of legal certainty and certainty, I have given my vote in favour.

name: Tokia Saïfi (PPE)
text: In writing. I voted in favour of this text, which proposes to amend the type of legislation so that this decision becomes a regulation; moreover, an addition to the title specifies that the repealed acts in question are part of the Schengen acquis.  Thus, the regulation will repeal eleven decisions of the Schengen Executive Committee, due to the fact that their content was taken up by subsequent acts, as well as the 2008 regulation on testing of the second generation Schengen Information System (SIS II), which exhausted its legal effects when SIS II became operational on 9 April 2013.

name: Massimiliano Salini (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the report on the repeal of certain acts of the Schengen acquis as I agree with the decision of the European Parliament and the Council to update and simplify EU law and to delete a number of acts deemed obsolete. Specifically, the report repeals 11 decisions of the Schengen Executive Committee and Regulation (EC) No 189/2008 of 18 February 2008.

name: Lola Sánchez Caldentey (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. This repeal is exempt from political content and is simply about the overcoming, through successive acts, of certain regulations, which are therefore exceeded or contained in others. That's why we voted in favour.

name: Lidia Senra Rodríguez (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. I voted in favour of this report to repeal certain acts of the Schengen acquis, as some of this legislation was obsolete and did not apply because of the new regulatory framework that emerged after the Lisbon Treaty. Despite our opposition to it, there would be no point in voting otherwise and maintaining unapplicable regulations.

name: Remo Sernagiotto (ECR)
text: in writing. \u2012 With today's vote, Parliament repeals 11 decisions of the Schengen Executive Committee and Council Regulation (EC) No 189/2008 on the technical testing of the SIS II Information System, a system that helps to increase security and facilitate freedom of movement in the Schengen area.  These acts have become obsolete because their content has been taken up in subsequent acts. I have therefore chosen to vote in favour of this decision.

name: Jill Seymour (EFDD)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of this as it repeals European Union acts.

name: Siôn Simon (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ This co-decision decision makes sense within the Commission’s policy on regulatory fitness and cutting down on unnecessary parts of the body of EU law. The repeal of this act was not politically motivated, and I am glad to see that it was passed unanimously in committee.

name: Monika Smolková (S&D)
text: Writing. \u2012 I agree that the Commission is fulfilling its decision to simplify EU legislation by repealing obsolete legal acts. In this context, the Commission has also carried out an assessment of Schengen legislation and legal instruments in the field of police and judicial cooperation in criminal matters. Since it concluded that many acts were already obsolete and their content was taken into account in subsequent acts or were of a temporary nature, it is only possible to support its proposal to repeal them.  This will result in the annulment of 11 decisions of the Schengen Executive Committee, as their content has been taken up in subsequent acts. The Council Regulation on tests of the second generation Schengen Information System will also be repealed, as this system has already been launched in the meantime. Simplifying the legal system in the current situation is essential, both for its abundance and opaqueness, and for increasing citizens' credibility.

name: Joachim Starbatty (ECR)
text: Writing. In three decisions, the Commission proposed to repeal acts belonging to the Schengen acquis either for a limited period of time or for their content to be incorporated into subsequent legal acts. The aim is to achieve better regulation by achieving greater transparency of Union law. In this context, the rapporteur, Claude Moraes, believes that it is appropriate to remove from the existing acquis acts that are no longer of use. According to the Commission, this is to be achieved by means of three decisions. Unlike the Commission, the rapporteur recommends changing the nature of the act from a decision to a regulation.  After consulting the European Parliament's Legal Service, Claude Moraes has also identified two other obsolete acts which are part of the Schengen acquis and are no longer relevant because they were temporary or were incorporated into subsequent legal acts. The ECR supports the REFIT programme in the sense of de-bureaucratisation and has also voted in the LIBE Committee for the repeal of outdated legal acts.  The ALFA is in favour of legal certainty and clarity. The measures proposed in the reports are likely to reduce EU legislation and simplify Union law. I strongly support these concerns and have therefore voted in favour of the report.

name: Ivan Štefanec (PPE)
text: Writing. \u2012 From the point of view of legal certainty and clarity, it is desirable that obsolete and unused regulations and decisions in these areas be repealed, while at the same time creating scope for improving the transparency of Union law, its clarity and effectiveness.

name: Davor Ivo Stier (PPE)
text: Written. ‒I support this proposal, as improving the transparency of Union law is a key element of the better law-making strategy implemented by the Union institutions. I also believe that the legislation should remove acts in the areas of freedom, security and justice that are in force and do not serve a purpose.  Decision of the Executive Board sch/com-ex (98) 18 rev, which established that the procedure to be followed by Schengen states having serious difficulties in obtaining repatriation passes for irregular migrants and the possibility to investigate the need for another at Union level, more binding measures against third countries are outdated as the Union has concluded readmission agreements with a large number of third countries, which set out the obligations and procedures that third country and Member State authorities must fulfil in relation to the repatriation of illegally residing foreign nationals in the Union.

name: Catherine Stihler (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of this report. A number of acts adopted in recent decades have exhausted all their effects. They are no longer relevant because of their temporary nature or because their content has been taken up by successive acts. For reasons of legal certainty it is necessary to revoke the measures in question in order to bring acts in the area of freedom, security and justice in line with the Lisbon Treaty.

name: Dubravka Šuica (PPE)
text: Written. The aim of this legislative proposal is to revoke outdated legal measures in the areas of freedom, security and justice. In June 2014, the European Commission, in cooperation with the police and judicial authorities, began assessing the acquis and legal instruments related to the field of crime. The Commission has now completed the assessment and decided that many acts are no longer relevant due to their temporary nature or because their content is covered by subsequent acts, although they have not been repealed. Accordingly, the Commission proposes to the European Parliament and the Council, the withdrawal of 12 acts adopted in the area of freedom, security and justice.  I support this proposal, as I believe that the abolition of outdated rules ensures legal certainty and transparency of Union law, which is a key element for better law-making.

name: Richard Sulík (ECR)
text: Writing. \u2012 I supported the proposal as it aims to simplify legislation without changing its effects. I welcome all similar activities, which have resulted in greater clarity of legislation and, ideally, a lower regulatory burden.

name: Pavel Svoboda (PPE)
text: Writing. \u2012 I supported the European Parliament's legislative resolution, which, as a result, agrees with the proposal for a decision by the EP and the Council on the repeal of certain acts in the area of freedom, security and justice. The repeal of these acts has nothing to do with the fight against terrorism or the solution to the migration crisis. It concerns only the abolition of now redundant regulations, which are no longer of any relevance, such as the Regulation on testing the second generation of the Schengen Information System (SIS II). Testing of this SIS II has already taken place and the system is now in operation.

name: Kay Swinburne (ECR)
text: in writing. ‒ As the UK is outside of the Schengen area and this proposal does not impact the UK in any way, I have abstained.

name: Νεοκλής Συλικιώτης (
text: GUE/NGL), in writing. \u2012 As part of the programme to improve the suitability and efficiency of the regulatory framework, the Commission stated that it had conducted a "screening" of the acquis in the field of police and judicial cooperation in criminal matters. The aim was to identify acts which could be repealed at the end of the transitional period set by the Treaties.  The Commission has completed the evaluation of legal acts in the area of Freedom, Security and Justice, and has proposed three proposals concerning the repeal of some twenty legal measures.  We have therefore voted in favour of these reports relating to the above acts, as they contribute to legal clarity by indicating which acts are considered obsolete because of their temporary nature, but also because they have been replaced by subsequent acts under the Treaty of Lisbon.

name: Tibor Szanyi (S&D)
text: Writing. \u2012 I supported the proposal because I consider the high quality and transparency of European Union legislation to be a priority. In the case of the regulation covered by the Schengen Agreement, this is a particularly topical aspect in order to meet the new challenges that are now facing (e.g. terrorism). As the report points out, the acts proposed to be repealed, or some of their elements, either proved to be obsolete in the course of the review after the transitional period set by the legislation, or their role has since been taken over by a new piece of legislation or contained provisions which are partly intended to be temporary.  The proposed amendments also take into account the specific legal relationship with which the EU, in its cooperation under the Schengen Agreement, applies both with certain Member States (Denmark, the United Kingdom) and with certain non-Member States (Iceland, Norway, Switzerland, Liechtenstein).

name: Claudia Tapardel (S&D)
text: in writing. With the aim of making European legislation more efficient and transparent, the European Commission has set out to reassess the need for certain legislation at a certain time. The report that I voted on today concerns the withdrawal from force of 11 acts in the field of police and judicial cooperation in the Schengen acquis, which are considered to have fallen because of their temporary nature or because their objectives have been taken over by acts succeeding them. The repeal of these acts cannot be carried out at the level of each Member State, which is why the measure will be carried out at Union level. I believe that the withdrawal of obsolete legislation can only make the enforcement of the territory of the Member States more efficient, which is why I voted in favour of this report.

name: Marc Tarabella (S&D)
text: In writing. I voted in favour of Mr Moraes' text. Improving the transparency of EU law is an essential part of the strategy to better legislate, which the EU institutions are currently implementing. In this context, acts that no longer have any reason to exist should be removed from existing legislation.

name: Pavel Telička (ALDE)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of repealing certain acts in the Area of Freedom, Security and Justice. An assessment by the Commission found that a number of acts belonging to it are no longer relevant because their content has been taken up by subsequent acts or because they are of a temporary nature. The proposal should take the form of a regulation. It suggests repealing eleven decisions of the Schengen Executive Committee and Council Regulation (EC) No 189/2008 on the testing of the second generation Schengen Information System (SIS II), the legal effect of which was exhausted once the SIS II became operational in April 2013.

name: Ruža Tomašić (ECR)
text: Written. ‒ I supported a regulation repealing certain acts in the Schengen acquis, which I consider necessary to abolish outdated acts that have passed the transitional period set out in the Treaty on the Functioning of the European Union or have been replaced by new acts.  In my view, the abolition of these acts is particularly useful in order to avoid overlapping legal provisions in EUROPEAN Union legislation. With a view to simplifying legislation, this Regulation abolishes decisions on: visa policy, the exchange of statistics, the issuance of Schengen visas, evidence under readmission agreements, the working group, difficulties in obtaining passes, stamping, the fight against illegal immigration, document counsellors and liaison officers, as well as the Council Regulation on SIS II tests.  I believe that these proposals are met by the European Commission with the objectives of refit programmes aimed at ensuring the coherence and efficiency of the rules, so I supported this Regulation.

name: Romana Tomc (PPE)
text: Writing. \u2012 I supported the report on the European Parliament's amendment to the Commission proposal for a regulation of the European Parliament and of the Council repealing certain acts of the Schengen acquis, as I believe that it is necessary to repeal some obsolete acts of the Schengen acquis and replace them with new, more effective acts. Nowadays, among other things, we are facing mass migration, which poses a major challenge for the whole of Europe, particularly when implementing the Schengen Agreement. As the current situation is of concern and the guarantee of people's security is questionable, a good, modernised information system for external border control and a more effective exchange of information between Member States is urgently needed, allowing better monitoring of migration at the external borders and preventing irregular migration.

name: Estefanía Torres Martínez (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. This repeal is exempt from political content and is simply about the overcoming, through successive acts, of certain regulations, which are therefore exceeded or contained in others. That's why we voted in favour.

name: Ramon Tremosa i Balcells (ALDE)
text: in writing. ‒ Schengen is a fundamental pillar of our political project. I hope that in the coming months and years we are able to protect it and fund our external borders better in order to maintain what has been beyond any doubt, one of the greatest success of our European project.

name: Mylène Troszczynski (ENF)
text: In writing. A number of acts that are part of the Schengen acquis are no longer relevant because of their temporary nature or because their content has been taken up by subsequent acts. In the interests of transparency and "better legislation," they must be repealed. Voting against this text makes no sense, since it would mean keeping obsolete acts when this report does not involve Schengen. So I opt for abstention.

name: István Ujhelyi (S&D)
text: Writing. Improving the transparency of EU law is an essential element of the better law strategy, which is being implemented in the EU institutions. In this context, it is appropriate to remove from the legislation in force those which no longer serve any purpose. That is why I voted in favour of the proposal.

name: Traian Ungureanu (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 European Union legislation contains a number of acts that are no longer applied. These acts are no longer relevant because of their temporary nature or because their content has been taken over by subsequent acts. In order to improve transparency and ensure a higher degree of legal certainty for European citizens, such acts are withdrawn from the Union's legislative acquis. In view of this, and in view of the expiry of the transitional period provided for in Protocol 1 to the Agreement between the European Economic Community and the European Economic Community, the Commission shall, in accordance with the procedure laid down in Article 18 of The Treaty, decide on 36 annexed to the Treaties, the Commission carried out an assessment of the Schengen acquis. Following this assessment, the Commission proposed the repeal of 11 decisions of the Schengen Executive Committee and the Second Generation Schengen Information System TestIng Regulation (SIS II), which exhausted its legal effects when SIS II began operating on 9 April 2013. The Executive Committee's decisions concerned, inter alia, visa policy, the exchange of statistical information, the affixing of stamps to passports, the fight against illegal immigration, the fight against illegal immigration. The European Parliament's legislative resolution supports the repeal of these obsolete acts. I voted in favour of this resolution.

name: Miguel Urbán Crespo (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. This repeal is exempt from political content and is simply about the overcoming, through successive acts, of certain regulations, which are therefore exceeded or contained in others. That's why we voted in favour.

name: Ivo Vajgl (ALDE)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of the resolution on a proposal for a decision of the European Parliament and of the Council repealing certain acts in the Area of Freedom Security and Justice because I believe improving the transparency of Union law is an essential element of the better law- making strategy that the institutions of the Union are implementing. In this context, it is appropriate to repeal those acts which no longer serve any purpose. A number of acts belonging to the Schengen acquis are no longer relevant due to their temporary nature or because their content has been taken up by subsequent acts. Since the objective of this regulation, namely the repeal of a number of obsolete Union acts belonging to the Schengen acquis, cannot be sufficiently achieved by the Member States, but rather can be better achieved at Union level, the Union may adopt measures, in accordance with the principle of subsidiarity as set out in Article 5 of the Treaty on European Union (TEU). In accordance with the principle of proportionality, as set out in that article, this regulation does not go beyond what is necessary in order to achieve that objective.

name: Ramón Luis Valcárcel Siso (PPE)
text: in writing. We are talking about the repeal of eleven decisions of the Schengen Executive Committee, the content of which has already been incorporated into successive acts and the repeal of Regulation (EC) No 189/2008 of 18 February 2008 on the tests of the Schengen II Information System (SIS II), which ceased to have legal effects following the implementation of that system. This is intended to repeal these outdated acts and to move forward with the simplification of European legislation in a correct way, so I think it is necessary to vote in favour.

name: Ángela Vallina (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. I voted in favour of this report to repeal certain acts of the Schengen acquis, as some of this legislation was obsolete and did not apply because of the new regulatory framework that emerged after the Lisbon Treaty. Despite our opposition to it, there would be no point in voting otherwise and maintaining unapplicable regulations.

name: Hilde Vautmans (ALDE)
text: Written. 'I voted today in favour of the withdrawal of a number of acts of law from the Schengen acquis. An investigation by the European Commission shows that some of these provisions are no longer up-to-date.

name: Miguel Viegas (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. \u2012 Various acts belonging to the Schengen acquis - exchange of statistical information, issuing Schengen visas, evidence and evidence under readmission agreements, task force, difficulties in obtaining a safe conduct, stamping on the passport, combating illegal immigration, combating illegal immigration, documentconsultants, liaison officers and SIS II tests - no longer relevant because of its temporary nature or because its content was taken up by subsequent acts , although they have not been repealed, making them consider themselves obsolete. Despite the technical nature of this document, it deals with a number of matters of a political nature to which certain positions have already been taken.

name: Harald Vilimsky (ENF)
text: Writing. This is a purely technical report on the Schengen acts. The current situation confirms our critical attitude to the Schengen laws. The report only reflects the current legal situation. Since it does not bring about any change in content, I abstain from my voice.

name: Daniele Viotti (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of this report because I believe it is of fundamental importance to ensure transparency in the European legislative process. I agree with the 'Better Lawmaking' strategy developed by the European institutions and, in particular, the legislative simplification action that has been put in place. A number of acts within the Schengen acquis are now obsolete or simply no longer have any reason to exist because they were born as temporary rules. In other cases, the rules have been superseded by subsequent legislation. That is why I agree with the repeal of all the acts that no longer have any reason to be.

name: Udo Voigt (NI)
text: Writing. A number of the developments in the Schengen acquis listed in the report do not in fact constitute a 'further development' in the sense of a fully-fledged border regime of the EU Member States, but on the contrary an erosion, for example where the implementation of 'Schengen assets' is being brought about by the demonstrably completely overwhelmed European border agency Frontex. In my view, therefore, there is no reason to repeal rules originally codified in the Schengen Agreement.

name: Beatrix von Storch (ECR)
text: Writing. Legal acts that are no longer useful can be repealed in good conscience. That is why I voted in favour of this resolution. Several pieces of the Schengen acquis are no longer relevant because they are either not respected by national governments anyway, have been limited in time or have been incorporated into subsequent legal acts. These include the following areas: visa policy, exchange of statistical information, issuing of Schengen visas, evidence under readmission agreements, task force, difficulties in obtaining a laissez-passer, stamping of passports, combating illegal immigration, document advisers, liaison officers and SIS II verification. I do not have much confidence in the EU and its institutions that oversee the Schengen acquis, and the current asylum crisis shows that we cannot trust the political institutions. German Chancellor Angela Merkel (CDU) has also knowingly broken EU law with regard to the Schengen acquis and provoked the current asylum crisis. Why should we still vote on legal acts if the CDU-CSU-SPD-led federal government disregards these EU acts anyway?

name: Θεόδωρος Ζαγοράκης (
text: PPE), in writing. \u2012 I supported this initiative, as did the majority of colleagues on the Committee on Civil Liberties, Justice and Home Affairs, which improves the act.

name: Jana Žitňanská (ECR)
text: Writing. \u2012 A large number of European Union legislation and constant developments requiring a rapid response often mean that legislation that no longer has its application in practice, because the situation for which it was created or outdated and their role has been taken over by other legislation, continues to be formally in force. This can cause legal uncertainty and chaos when trying to navigate European legislation. I therefore support the European Commission's REFIT programme, in which the Commission gradually focuses on individual areas of legislation and proposes the abolition of those that are no longer needed for the above reasons. As there have been several in the area of Schengen law, I supported this and two other reports on the repeal of unnecessary legal acts.

name: Inês Cristina Zuber (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. \u2012 Various acts belonging to the Schengen acquis - exchange of statistical information, issuing Schengen visas, evidence and evidence under readmission agreements, task force, difficulties in obtaining a safe conduct, stamping on the passport, combating illegal immigration, combating illegal immigration, documentconsultants, liaison officers and SIS II tests - no longer relevant because of its temporary nature or because its content was taken up by subsequent acts , although they have not been repealed, making them consider themselves obsolete. Despite the technical nature of this document, it deals with a number of matters of a political nature against which we have spoken. We do not, however, agree with subsequent acts for continuing the policy of repression and securitization. For the foregoing, the abstention vote.

name: Milan Zver (PPE)
text: Writing. \u2012 For a legislative resolution of the European Parliament and of the Council repealing certain acts of the Schengen acquis in the area of freedom, I voted in favour of security and justice (COM(2014)0713 – C8-0277/2014 – 2014/0337(COD)) because it complies with the principle of legal certainty and contributes to improving the transparency of Union law in order to repeal legal acts which no longer have legal effect or are reproduced in subsequent acts. I also voted in favour of changing the type of legal act from 'Decision of the European Parliament and of the Council' to 'Regulation of the European Parliament and of the Council' in order to allow it to become directly applicable in all Member States in accordance with Article 288 TFEU.

name: William (The Earl of) Dartmouth (EFDD)
text: in writing. ‒ Although the measures to repeal old EU legislation only covers Schengen (which the UK isn’t part of), UKIP will always vote to repeal EU laws. The only people that should create laws are democratically elected and accountable national governments, not unelected bureaucrats in Brussels.

name: Marina Albiol Guzmán (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. I voted in favour of this report to repeal certain acts in the field of police and judicial cooperation in criminal matters, as the acts in question were obsolete and did not apply because of the new regulatory framework that appeared after the Lisbon Treaty. Despite our opposition to it, there would be no point in voting otherwise and maintaining unapplicable regulations.

name: Marie-Christine Arnautu (ENF)
text: In writing. As with the other Moraes report (66 - A8-0250/2015), this text repeals acts that are part of the "Schengen acquis" and which are no longer relevant today because of their temporary nature or the resumption of their content in subsequent acts.  Nevertheless, the National Front has always opposed the Schengen acquis and there is no question of us endorsing it. That is why I abstained on this report.

name: Jonathan Arnott (EFDD)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of this technical repeal, although sadly it is unlikely to cut the regulatory burden as the relevant acts were already obsolete.

name: Jean Arthuis (ALDE)
text: In writing. I voted in favour of this deliberation as advocated by the committee on its merits.

name: Zigmantas Balčytis (S&D)
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of this proposal repealing obsolete legislation.

name: Gerard Batten (EFDD)
text: in writing. ‒ Although the measures to repeal old EU legislation only covers Schengen (which the UK isn’t part of), UKIP will always vote to repeal EU laws. The only people that should create laws are democratically elected and accountable national governments, not unelected bureaucrats in Brussels.

name: Nicolas Bay (ENF)
text: In writing. I abstained on this text, which does not change anything: it is simply a matter of repealing acts that have become obsolete, either because they were temporary or because their content has been taken up in subsequent acts. These acts focused on police and judicial cooperation... Brussels refuses to strengthen. Despite the attacks that hit France on 13 November, the Eurocrats are still not ready to question their Schengen dogma. How many attacks, how many deaths will it take for them to agree to acknowledge their mortal mistakes?

name: Hugues Bayet (S&D)
text: In writing. I have approved this report which aims to abolish certain provisions of the Schengen acquis in the field of judicial or police cooperation in criminal matters which are outdated or have been replaced by other more recent texts.

name: Izaskun Bilbao Barandica (ALDE)
text: in writing. I voted in favour of this report in the context of the expiry of the transitional period set out in Protocol No 36 on Schengen acquis assessment and legal instruments as a number of acts have been detected have become obsolete. The area of police and judicial cooperation in criminal matters is very important and it is fundmental to improve the wording of the act in force

name: Dominique Bilde (ENF)
text: In writing. Another parliamentary report which, starting from a good intention, does not dare to go to the end of its original reasoning! Mr Moraes' text was aimed at repealing obsolete acts in the field of police cooperation and judicial cooperation in criminal matters in the context of the Schengen acquis. While it is commendable to want to carry out a legal update so that the legislative framework corresponds to reality and that duplicates are avoided, it is clear that the most obsolete act of all — Schengen — is still not in question! The recent terrorist attacks in Paris and the new security measures taken in Brussels have unfortunately brought to life the reality in pain since at least three of the jihadists involved were able to use the total absence of borders to carry out their misdeeds and, for one of them, to flee as he pleased. In the face of this lack of realism, and despite some common-sense efforts by Parliament, I have therefore had to abstain on this text.

name: Mara Bizzotto (ENF)
text: in writing. \u2012 The recent terrorist attacks in Paris and the threats that are affecting Italy and all other European countries are proof that we need more security and more controls. Schengen does not work and needs to be radically reformed.  The text we are voting on is, on the other hand, a simple technical update of the rules in force; That is why I did not intend to support it with my vote. I am convinced that the Schengen Agreement must be radically revised and that we can no longer limit ourselves to minor updates.

name: José Blanco López (S&D)
text: in writing. A number of acts adopted in the field of police and judicial cooperation in criminal matters, belonging to the Schengen acquis, have ceased to be relevant because of their temporary nature or because their content has been incorporated into successive acts, although they have not been repealed. These are acts that have become obsolete, including the Decisions of the Executive Committee SCH/Com-ex (93) 14 (combating narcotics trafficking) and (98) 52 (police vademécum), the Statement of the Executive Committee SCH/Com-ex (97) decl. 13, 2nd rev (child abduction) and Council Decision 2008/173/JHA of 18 February 2008 on the tests of the second generation Schengen Information System (SIS II) as they have become obsolete.  That is why I voted in favour of its repeal.

name: Vilija Blinkevičiūtė (S&D)
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of this report, which supports the repeal of certain legislation relating to police cooperation and judicial cooperation in criminal matters (Schengen acquis). In view of the end of the transitional period laid down in the Protocol on transitional provisions annexed to the Treaties, the Commission has assessed the Schengen acquis and legislation relating to police cooperation and judicial cooperation in criminal matters. Several pieces of legislation have been found to be obsolete as their content has been transposed into subsequent legislation or is of a temporary nature. In accordance with the relevant amendment proposed by the Council in its common approach, supported by the Commission, the European Parliament proposes to include in the list of repealed acts a decision of the Executive Committee on the Agreement on cooperation in proceedings in the event of a breach of road traffic rules. The reason for repealing this Decision is that this Agreement has never entered into force and that no Member State has made a declaration of application of the agreement between states which have ratified it. Moreover, it cannot be regarded as an internal act of the Schengen acquis because it was not concluded not only by the Member States but also by two third countries (Iceland and Norway).

name: Andrea Bocskor (PPE)
text: Writing. \u2012 Improving the transparency of EU law is an essential element of the better law-improving strategy, which is being implemented by the EU institutions. In this context, it is appropriate to repeal from the legislation in force those which no longer serve any purpose. A number of acts adopted in the field of police and judicial cooperation in criminal matters and falling within the Schengen acquis are no longer relevant, either because of their temporary nature or because their content has been adopted by subsequent acts. In line with the PP delegation, I voted in favour of the adoption of this report.

name: Franc Bogovič (PPE)
text: Writing. \u2012 Like the previous report on the proposal for a decision repealing certain acts resulting from the Schengen Agreement, I also supported this report. It is about repealing obsolete acts in the field of police and judicial cooperation in criminal matters, which have been identified as obsolete by the Commission in its assessment of the Schengen acquis in these two areas. Their content was summarised by subsequent acts or that those acts were only of a temporary nature. With a view to the immediate implementation of the amendments, I also welcome the rapporteur's intention to establish the repeal decision as a regulation, as it is directly applicable in all EU Member States. The Schengen Agreement is one of the EU's greatest achievements, and I agree that the rules that result from it must be in line with the acquis and their direct implementation is extremely important. Unfortunately, we have forgotten this area recently, which can have a profound impact on the security of European citizens.

name: Marie-Christine Boutonnet (ENF)
text: In writing. This is the abrogation of acts adopted in the field of police cooperation and judicial cooperation in criminal matters and part of the Schengen acquis. In the interests of transparency and "better legislation," they must be repealed. However, Schengen is not in question, so I abstained.

name: Renata Briano (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 The free movement of persons within the Union is a major achievement of the Process of European Integration. With this act of updating the Schengen Convention, we intend to maintain the recognition of the value of that path but also to reduce the body of legislation of the Union by repealing acts that are now obsolete, having already been taken up by successive European agreements and conventions.

name: Steeve Briois (ENF)
text: In writing. A number of acts that are part of the Schengen acquis in the field of police and judicial cooperation are no longer relevant because of their temporary nature or because their content has been taken up by subsequent acts.  In the interests of transparency, this report recommends repealing them in particular in order to lighten and simplify the current legislation. These repeals make sense and we believe that it would not be at all appropriate to maintain these acts as they stand. Nevertheless, we have always been in favour of the abolition of the Schengen area, which is a real sieve for illegal migrants, among whom there are a number of jihadists, as evidenced by the attacks on Friday 13 November in Paris.  Not wishing to endorse the free movement of individuals within the European Union, I abstained on this text.

name: Daniel Buda (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 In the context of the increasing exercise of citizens' right to free movement, it becomes a reality that many of the facts that may enter the criminal sphere may occur partly on the territory of several Member States, which makes it necessary for the judicial cooperation of those States in order to discover the facts and persons involved, the administration of evidence and other aspects related to the imposition of sanctions. The importance of this communication and collaboration by the authorities of all Member States has been demonstrated during the conclusion of several normative acts and commitments within the Union, and the efforts of the Commission, the Council and the European Parliament have also been felt from the perspective of the citizens, who are in greater certainty wherever they are in the Union. I welcome this initiative to reduce the over-legislation and burden of the legislative system, given the uncertainty that such legislative maculatura scans can create if they are maintained. In accordance with Article 288 TFEU, the regulations are binding in their entirety and directly applicable in all Member States, the form of regulation thus better serving the purpose of the proposal to repeal acts considered obsolete. That is why I voted in favour of this report.

name: Gianluca Buonanno (ENF)
text: in writing. \u2012 These three reports signed by mep Moraes respond to the need to update the rules in force by repealing a number of acts forming part of the Schengen acquis. These legislative texts are no longer relevant because of their temporary nature or because their content has been taken up in subsequent acts which, however, have not repealed them. On the substance, this can be seen as a positive measure but, given also the developments taking place, especially in recent months, and the firm will on the part of our delegation to completely review the Schengen Agreement, I voted against it. On schengen policies, we cannot just update them, but we need a complete reform.

name: Nicola Caputo (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted today in favour of the report on the proposal for a decision of the European Parliament and of the Council on the repeal of certain acts in the field of police cooperation and judicial cooperation in criminal matters. During an assessment of the Schengen acquis and legal instruments in the field of police cooperation and judicial cooperation in criminal matters, the Commission identified some outdated provisions, either because their content has been incorporated into subsequent acts or because of their purely provisional nature. It therefore proposes their repeal and the elimination of the cooperation agreement in the challenge of road traffic offences, which, by the way, has never even entered into force. The European institutions agree on the need to reduce and simplify the volume of the Union's body of legislation, including through the repeal of obsolete acts. This text proposes effective action in this direction, and that is why I have chosen to vote in favour of its acceptance.

name: Matt Carthy (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of this technical report, which is part of the ‘regulatory fitness’ programme. The Commission identifies acts which can be repealed in the context of expiry of the transitional period set out in the treaties. These acts are no longer relevant because of their temporary nature or because their context has been taken up by successive acts. The texts in question relate to police cooperation in criminal matters but are no longer being used.

name: James Carver (EFDD)
text: in writing. ‒ Although the measures to repeal old EU legislation only covers Schengen (which the UK isn’t part of), UKIP will always vote to repeal EU laws. The only people that should create laws are democratically elected and accountable national governments, not unelected bureaucrats in Brussels.

name: David Casa (PPE)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of this report because we need to update our legislation in order for it to remain applicable and in line with the constantly changing trends. Outdated legislation can often pose serious problems and we cannot allow this, especially in the area of security.

name: Fabio Massimo Castaldo (EFDD)
text: in writing. \u2012 Due to the end of the transitional period provided for in Protocol 36 annexed to the Treaty, the repeal of obsolete acts, replaced by others adopted within the new institutional framework, was put to the vote. The vote in favour concerns the repeal of acts of the Schengen acquis in the field of police cooperation and judicial cooperation in criminal matters.

name: Caterina Chinnici (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 The repeal of a number of acts of the Schengen acquis – relating to police cooperation and judicial cooperation in criminal matters – is part of the European 'Better Lawmaking' strategy, through which the Commission intends to review existing legislation, improve it and make it more effective in order to achieve the union's political objectives. This strategy also includes the repeal of decisions that have become obsolete over time because they are temporary or because their content has been taken up in subsequent acts, as in the case of the Regulation on technical testing of the new SIS II information system, which has exhausted its legal effect following the entry into force of Regulation (EC) No 189/2008 provided for in that system. I therefore agree with the report voted on today in plenary, which repeals 11 decisions of the Schengen Executive Committee, and I agree with the rapporteur that, in addition to the decisions referred to above, the regulation referred to above should be amended in addition to the decisions mentioned above, both for reasons of legal certainty and in order to guarantee the immediate production of effects in all Member States. These are the reasons why I voted in favour.

name: Λευτέρης Χριστοφόρου (
text: PPE), in writing. \u2012 Since the objective of this Regulation, namely the abolition of certain obsolete Union acts in the field of police and judicial cooperation in criminal matters covered by the Schengen acquis, cannot be better achieved at Union level, the Union cannot adopt measures in accordance with the principle of subsidiarity. In accordance with the principle of proportionality, as set out in that Article, this Regulation does not go beyond what is necessary to achieve that objective. We therefore support the report positively.

name: Salvatore Cicu (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the measure. In the Interinstitutional Agreement of 16 December 2003, the European Parliament, the Council and the Commission agreed on the need to reduce the volume of the Union's body of legislation and simplify it, including through the repeal of obsolete acts.  On the basis of its examination, in line with the commitments under the Interinstitutional Agreement and its policy on regulatory adequacy, The Commission has put forward a proposal to repeal, as obsolete, the Executive Committee's decisions on the fight against drug trafficking and the police manual, the Statement by the Executive Committee on the abduction of children and Council Decision 2008/173/JHA on technical testing of the Second Generation Schengen Information System (SIS II).  The European Parliament has proposed including in the list of repealed acts the decision of the Executive Committee for the Cooperation Agreement in the challenge of road traffic offences. Streamlining the legislative acquis will help to improve the transparency of legislative production and strengthen the concept of legal certainty.

name: Alberto Cirio (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of this proposal because the vote was a mere formal step in a broader design now almost completely realized. From a legal point of view, this is a fundamental piece, which there would be no point in denying. On a practical level, it is the acceptance of a process that has been going on for decades and cannot be cancelled by a group of terrorists.

name: David Coburn (EFDD)
text: in writing. ‒ Although the measures to repeal old EU legislation only covers Schengen (which the UK isn’t part of), UKIP will always vote to repeal EU laws. The only people that should create laws are democratically elected and accountable national governments, not unelected bureaucrats in Brussels.

name: Carlos Coelho (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 The instruments of the so-called Area of Freedom, Security and Justice, in particular with regard to the Schengen acquis, were initially incorporated by the Treaty of Amsterdam into the Legal Order of the Union. Progressively, many have been updated, reformulated, strengthened and, in some cases, simply become obsolete. This Regulation ensures the repeal of these acts and ensures that, in certain cases, a transitional period is ensured.

name: Jane Collins (EFDD)
text: in writing. – Although the measures to repeal old EU legislation only covers Schengen (which the UK isn’t part of), UKIP will always vote to repeal EU laws. The only people that should create laws are democratically elected and accountable national governments, not unelected bureaucrats in Brussels.

name: Lara Comi (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 I welcome the report on the proposal to repeal certain obsolete acts in the field of police and judicial cooperation. Acts which no longer have reason to be applied because of their temporary nature and their resumption or replacement in subsequent legislation should be removed from the legislation in force. Legislative acts concerning the organisation and cooperation of police and judicial forces on operations to combat drug trafficking and to monitor the abduction of children have been the subject of more recent legislation than the decisions taken by the Schengen Executive Committee, which are therefore inappropriate and obsolete.  It is therefore necessary to update the body of legislation of the European Union, thereby ensuring greater transparency and clarity of Community law in the field of police and judicial cooperation. In this regard, I support the proposal to amend this legislative act in a regulation in order to ensure its direct and inescapable application in national law.

name: Therese Comodini Cachia (PPE)
text: in writing. ‒ A number of acts that are part of the Schengen acquis and certain legal instruments for the field of police and judicial cooperation in criminal matters have been identified as unnecessary due to their temporary nature and the redundant nature of the acts. The Commission’s proposal to repeal legislative acts which are no longer applicable helps to improve transparency and legal certainty for citizens. I voted in favour.

name: Ignazio Corrao (EFDD)
text: in writing. \u2012 As part of the expiry of the transitional period provided for in Protocol 36 on transitional provisions annexed to the Treaties, the Commission carried out an assessment of the Schengen acquis and legal instruments in the field of police and judicial cooperation in criminal matters. A number of acts have been identified as obsolete because their content has been taken up by subsequent acts or because they were temporary in nature. In the agreement of 16 December 2003, Parliament, the Council and the Commission agreed on the reduction of the volume and simplification of UNION law, including through the repeal of obsolete acts, such as: decision of the SCH/Com-ex Executive Committee (93) 14 and (98) 52, SCH/ Com-ex Declaration (97) decl. 13 Rev 2 and Council Decision 2008/173/ JHA on technical tests for the second generation Schengen Information System (SIS II).
