With regard to cooperation in the challenge of traffic offences, the reason arises from the fact that this agreement never entered into force. Furthermore, it cannot be regarded as an internal Schengen act as it has not only been concluded between EU Member States, but also with two third countries (Iceland and Norway). For the reasons given above, I have chosen to vote in favour.

name: Javier Couso Permuy (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. I voted in favour of this report to repeal certain acts in the field of police and judicial cooperation in criminal matters, as the acts in question were obsolete and did not apply because of the new regulatory framework that appeared after the Lisbon Treaty. Despite our opposition to it, there would be no point in voting otherwise and maintaining unapplicable regulations.

name: Pál Csáky (PPE)
text: Writing. \u2012 A number of acts adopted in the field of police and judicial cooperation in criminal matters and covered by the Schengen acquis are no longer relevant as they are provisional in nature or have been adopted by subsequent acts, but the original acts have not been repealed. In the framework of the Interinstitutional Agreement of 16 December 2003, the European Parliament, the Council and the Commission agreed with each other on the numerical reduction and simplification of EU legislation, including through the repeal of outdated legislation. On the basis of its due diligence, the Commission has put forward a proposal for outdated decisions of the Executive Committee (on combating drug trafficking) SCH/Com-ex (93) 14 and (98) 52 (police manual), and to repeal the outdated declaration of the Executive Committee (on the abduction of minors) SCH/Com-ex (97) decl 13 rev 2 and the council decision of 2008/173/IB on the testing of the second generation of the Schengen Information System (SIS II) and decision SCH/Com-ex (98) 52 (combating drug trafficking). I voted in favour of this report, which supports the repeal of outdated acts, because it contributes to the numerical reduction and simplification of EU legislation.

name: Edward Czesak (ECR)
text: I would like to write to the Commission. \u2012 The institutions of the European Union should ensure the best possible regulation, including ensuring its transparency. Unfortunately, legislative sloppyness can often be observed, consisting in the absence of derogations of acts, the further validity of which after the introduction of new ones is unnecessary or the absence of abrogation of acts that have already exhausted their legal effects. In assessing the Schengen acquis and legal instruments in the area of police and judicial cooperation in criminal matters, the Commission has identified a number of pieces of legislation that should be repealed on the basis of these criteria. These included Decision SCH/Com-ex (93) 14, Declaration SCH/Com-ex (97) Dekl. 13 rev 2 and Decision SCH/Com-ex (98) 52, the last of which was incorporated into the new act, while the first two were dealt with exhaustively in newer legislation. The draft EP Regulation repealing certain legal acts within the framework of the Schengen acquis in the field of police and judicial cooperation in addition to the acts I mentioned was to repeal Council Decision 2008/173/JND, which exhausted its legal effects in 2013, and Decision SCH/Com-ex (99) 11 rev. Article 2 adopting an agreement which never entered into force and remained in the legal system in fact without force. Believing that this would contribute to increasing the transparency of EU law and reducing the validity of unnecessary provisions, I voted in favour of the draft regulation.

name: Miriam Dalli (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ This vote pertains to the repeal of a number of legal acts in the field of police and judicial cooperation in criminal matters which are no longer relevant to European legislation, or are temporary in nature. These were repealed on the basis of the Commission’s REFIT policy, which aims at making EU law simpler and more effective. For this reason I supported this report.

name: Daniel Dalton (ECR)
text: in writing. ‒ This REFIT proposal relates to certain provisions of the Schengen acquis, to which the United Kingdom does not subscribe. As such, the UK will not be bound by this. Therefore, whilst I welcome the repeal of this obsolete measure, as previously on justice and home affairs matters which do not pertain to the UK, I decided to abstain.

name: Michel Dantin (PPE)
text: In writing. This legislative report proposes to repeal some outdated acts in the area of judicial and police cooperation in crime. These acts concern the executive committee and the second-generation tests of the Schengen information system.  It also recommends changing the legal nature of the Commission's proposal from a decision to an EU regulation, which is seen as more appropriate to ensure the immediate and complete repeal of these acts in all Member States. Supporting these objectives and technical changes, I voted in favour of the report.

name: Rachida Dati (PPE)
text: In writing. As these acts have become obsolete, I support this repeal measure as it contributes to greater clarity of European legislation in the area of police and judicial cooperation in criminal matters following the adoption of the Lisbon Treaty.

name: Mireille D'Ornano (ENF)
text: In writing. These two reports were intended to repeal various temporary acts relating to the Schengen area in the area of police cooperation and judicial cooperation in criminal matters in particular. Opposed to this area of free movement without control or unreasonable borders, both economically, socially and culturally, I refuse to participate in these issues of organizing a system that I consider illegitimate and harmful. I therefore abstained in the vote on these two reports by the socialist Claude Moraes.

name: Ian Duncan (ECR)
text: in writing. ‒ These REFIT proposals relate to certain provisions of the Schengen acquis, to which the UK does not subscribe. As such, the UK will not be bound by them. Therefore, whilst I welcome the repeal of obsolete measures, in accordance with our long-standing position on JHA matters which do not pertain to the UK, I will abstain.

name: Ангел Джамбазки (ECR)
text: in writing. \u2012 This report is part of the European Commission's REFIT programme, which aims to repeal European legislative instruments that are no longer valid for Member States. After an evaluation of the acts in the field of police and judicial cooperation, the Ec established several instruments of a temporary nature or the content of which is reflected in follow-up texts. I support the REFIT programme and supported the repeal of certain acts in the field of police cooperation and judicial cooperation in criminal matters, because I believe that a reduction in volume and simplification of Union law is necessary, including by repealing obsolete acts.

name: Γεώργιος Επιτήδειος (
text: NI), in writing. \u2012 Concerns the abolition, as obsolete, of acts of the Schengen Executive Committee to combat drug trafficking, child abduction, the SIS II system, the police manual and procedures for infringements of the MRL. For these, alone, changing the type of act from "decision" to "regulation" better serves the purposes of the proposal, which is the abolition of outdated acts.

name: Bill Etheridge (EFDD)
text: in writing. – Although the measures to repeal old EU legislation only covers Schengen (which the UK isn’t part of), UKIP will always vote to repeal EU laws. The only people that should create laws are democratically elected and accountable national governments, not unelected bureaucrats in Brussels.

name: José Manuel Fernandes (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 This report reports on the results of the evaluation of the Schengen acquis and legal instruments in the field of police cooperation and judicial cooperation in criminal matters. Several acts were considered obsolete either because of the integration of their content into subsequent acts or because of their temporary nature. The proposal envisages repealing the obsolete decisions of the SCH/Com-ex Executive Committee (93) 14 (combating drug trafficking) and the SCH/Com-ex Executive Committee (98) 52 (vade-mécum of police cooperation), as well as the Statement of the Sch/Com-ex Executive Committee (97) decl. 13 rev 2 (child abduction) and Council Decision 2008/173/JAI of 18 February 2008 on second generation testing of the Schengen Information System (SIS II). It is also suggested that the Decision of the Executive Committee SCH/Com-exe (99) 11 rev 2 on the cooperation agreement on road traffic offences is also suggested. The reason for repealing this decision is that that agreement has never entered into force and that none of the Member States has submitted a declaration pursuant to Article 20(3) concerning the application of that agreement between the Member States which have ratified it. I agree with the repeal proposal put forward.

name: Edouard Ferrand (ENF)
text: In writing. I abstained on this vote because the reference text is a federalist text that I do not recognize.

name: João Ferreira (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. \u2012 The Committee on Freedoms of the European Parliament has decided to frame this report in the Simplified Procedure – Article 50(2) of the Rules of Procedure. The report includes a set of three on the repeal of acts from the Schengen acquis and acts in the field of police cooperation and judicial cooperation in criminal matters. Several acts belonging to the Schengen acquis are no longer relevant because of their temporary nature or because their content was taken up by subsequent acts, although they have not been repealed, making them considered obsolete. This report is therefore of an eminently technical nature. The fact is that, in practical terms, between obsolete acts and those that replace them there are no substantive improvements, so, despite the above, we reaffirm our substantive critical position on Schengen and its acquis. And, as well, with regard to police cooperation and judicial cooperation in criminal matters. These are areas for which we have been critical of the EU's approach and attempts at federal deepening, with increased limitations on member states' decision-making capacity in areas that go to the heart of state sovereignty.

name: Raffaele Fitto (ECR)
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of this proposal for a decision on the repeal of certain acts of the Schengen acquis in the field of police cooperation and judicial cooperation in criminal matters, the simplification of which would lead to a positive outcome to the commitments made in the inter-institutional agreement 'Better lawmaking'.

name: Lorenzo Fontana (ENF)
text: in writing. \u2012 The vote on these three reports will be against as there is no need to revise Schengen but to reform it completely.

name: Λάμπρος Φουντούλης (
text: NI), in writing. \u2012 I am voting in favour of this report as changing the type of act from 'decision' to 'regulation' better serves the purposes of the proposal, which is to abolish outdated acts.

name: Doru-Claudian Frunzulică (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ In the context of the expiry of the transitional period set out in Protocol 36 on transitional provisions annexed to the Treaties, the Commission has performed an assessment of the Schengen acquis and of the legal instruments in the field of police cooperation and judicial cooperation in criminal matters. A number of acts have been identified as obsolete because their content has been taken up by subsequent acts or because they are of a temporary nature. In the Inter-institutional Agreement of 16 December 2003 Parliament, the Council and the Commission agreed on reducing the volume of, and simplifying, Union law, including by means of repealing obsolete acts. On the basis of its screening and in line with the commitments in the inter-institutional agreement on better law-making and the its policy on Regulatory Fitness, the Commission submitted a proposal to repeal as obsolete decisions of the Executive Committee SCH/Com-ex (93) 14 (combating drug trafficking) and (98) 52 (police handbook), Declaration of the Executive Committee SCH/Com—ex (97) decl. 13 rev 2 (abduction of minors) and Council Decision 2008/173/JHA of 18 February 2018 on the tests of the second generation Schengen Information System (SIS II).

name: Kinga Gál (PPE)
text: in writing. ‒ We from the Fidesz party (EPP Group) voted in favour of this report on the proposal for a decision of the European Parliament and of the Council repealing certain acts in the field of police cooperation and judicial cooperation in criminal matters. The Committee on Civil Liberties, Justice and Home Affairs recommended that the position of the European Parliament adopted at first reading under the ordinary legislative procedure should amend the Commission proposal. With this vote we change the type of act from ‘decision’ to ‘regulation’. In accordance with the Article 288 TFEU a regulation is binding in its entirety and directly applicable in all Member States and will better serve the purpose of the proposal to repeal the acts deemed to be obsolete. The new text will improve the drafting of the act, including an addition in the title specifying that the repealed acts in question belong to the Schengen acquis, and adapting the recitals to the UK’s position after the expiry of the transitional period set out in Protocol No 36 to the Treaties.

name: Ildikó Gáll-Pelcz (PPE)
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of this report, in which, in line with the relevant amendment proposed by the Council in its general approach and adopted by the Commission, the rapporteur proposes that the decision of the Executive Committee on cooperation in road traffic infringement procedures be included in the withdrawn acts. Furthermore, in view of the amendments made by the Council to the Commission's proposal, after consulting the Legal Service of the European Parliament, the rapporteur proposes to change the type of act from decision to regulation. According to Article 288 TSI, the Regulation is fully binding and directly applicable in all Member States and better serves the purpose of the proposal, namely the repeal of acts considered obsolete.

name: Francesc Gambús (PPE)
text: in writing. I voted in favour in the context of the expiry of the transitional period laid down in Protocol No 36 on transitional provisions, annexed to the Treaties. The Commission has carried out an assessment of the Schengen acquis and legal instruments in the field of police and judicial cooperation in criminal matters. It has thus been detected that a number of acts have become obsolete, either because their content has been incorporated into successive acts, or because they were temporary acts.

name: Arne Gericke (ECR)
text: Writing. I voted today in favour of the report on the repeal of certain pieces of legislation from the Schengen acquis in the field of police and judicial cooperation in criminal matters, as I believe that the further development and updating of the Schengen Agreement is essential at this very time.

name: Jens Gieseke (PPE)
text: Writing. Some of the pieces of legislation under the Schengen acquis in the field of police and judicial cooperation are outdated or out of date. Either their content has been revisited in other legal acts, or they are limited in time. That is why the Commission's proposal to repeal these acts is correct. This improves the clarity of existing rules.

name: Neena Gill (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of this report, which aims to revoke measures that are no longer relevant because of their temporary nature or because their content has been taken up by successive acts.

name: Juan Carlos Girauta Vidal (ALDE)
text: in writing. A number of acts adopted in the field of police and judicial cooperation in criminal matters, belonging to the Schengen acquis, have ceased to be relevant because of their temporary nature or because their content has been incorporated into successive acts, although they have not been repealed. For reasons of legal certainty and clarity, such outdated legal instruments should be repealed.

name: Tania González Peñas (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. This repeal is exempt from political content and is simply about the overcoming, through successive acts, of certain regulations, which are therefore exceeded or contained in others. That's why we voted in favour.

name: Theresa Griffin (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted for this proposal. Improving the transparency of Union law is an essential element of the better law-making strategy that the institutions of the Union are implementing. In that context it is appropriate to remove from the legislation in force those acts which no longer serve any purpose. A number of acts adopted in the field of police cooperation and judicial cooperation in criminal matters, and belonging to the Schengen acquis, are no longer relevant due to their temporary nature or because their content has been taken up by successive acts, even though they have not been repealed.

name: Françoise Grossetête (PPE)
text: In writing. On Tuesday 24 November, I voted in favour of three reports aimed at repealing certain acts of the Schengen acquis.  These texts aim to undo a number of legal measures related to the area of freedom, security and justice, as well as legal provisions in the field of police and judicial cooperation in criminal matters, which have become obsolete.  The acts here repealed are no longer relevant because of their temporary nature or because their content has been taken up by subsequent acts. The aim here is to be consistent and to improve the transparency of EU law in order to better legislate in the interests of European citizens.

name: Antanas Guoga (ALDE)
text: in writing. ‒ I have voted for the report on the proposal for a decision of the European Parliament and of the Council repealing certain acts in the field of police cooperation and judicial cooperation in criminal matters. I believe that if acts adopted in the field of police cooperation and judicial cooperation in criminal matters, and belonging to the Schengen acquis, are no longer relevant due to their temporary nature or because their content has been taken up by successive acts, they should be repealed.

name: Τάκης Χατζηγεωργίου (GUE/NGL)
text: Writing. Given the technical nature of this 'clearance' procedure, which also contributes to legal clarity, we are voting in favour of the report.

name: Brian Hayes (PPE)
text: in writing. ‒ I chose to support this report as a number of acts have been identified as obsolete because their content has been taken up by successive acts or because they are temporary in nature. In changing the acts type from ‘decision’ to ‘regulation’ it will allow the act to be binding in its entirety which will better serve the purpose of the proposal to repeal the acts deemed to be obsolete. The report also contains several amendments which will improve the drafting of the act.

name: Roger Helmer (EFDD)
text: in writing. ‒ Although the measures to repeal old EU legislation only covers Schengen (which the UK isn’t part of), UKIP will always vote to repeal EU laws. The only people that should create laws are democratically elected and accountable national governments, not unelected bureaucrats in Brussels.

name: Hans-Olaf Henkel (ECR)
text: Writing. In three decisions, the Commission proposed to repeal acts belonging to the Schengen acquis either for a limited period of time or for their content to be incorporated into subsequent legal acts. The aim is to achieve better regulation. I voted in favour. Incidentally, I believe that the euro must be abolished because it leads to strife and discord in Europe!

name: Brice Hortefeux (PPE)
text: In writing. I supported the proposal to repeal the Schengen acquis in the area of police and judicial cooperation in criminal matters, which have become obsolete because of their temporary nature or because their content has been taken up by subsequent acts. It is absolutely not a question of questioning what works in Schengen, but of simplifying the European regulations, which I have often deplored as cumbersome and incongruised. This vote, however, allows me to renew my call for realism. My party has long called for an overhaul of Schengen to adapt to new realities and threats that are breaking free of national borders. There is an urgent need for tighter control of external borders and systematic control of third-country nationals as well as European citizens.

name: Ian Hudghton (Verts/ALE)
text: in writing. ‒ Whilst this report is primarily technical in nature, it notes that the UK took the decision to withdraw from police and judicial cooperation. At a time when international cooperation in combatting criminal behaviour is increasingly important, it is shameful that this decision was taken.

name: Ivan Jakovčić (ALDE)
text: Written. ‒ I voted for the European Parliament's draft legislative resolution on the proposal for a decision by Parliament and the Council to repeal certain acts in the area of police and judicial cooperation in criminal matters, on the basis that it is necessary to ensure that EUROPEAN Union law is as clear and effective as possible for the benefit of all citizens, but also of the competent authorities concerned. In my view, aged acts must be repealed as soon as possible to ensure the certainty and consistency of the acquis, in particular when it comes to criminal matters. Simplifying rights also contributes to increasing the transparency that the European institutions need, and I therefore support this report.

name: Jean-François Jalkh (ENF)
text: In writing. This report repeals acts that are part of the "Schengen acquis" and which are no longer relevant today because of their temporary nature or the resumption of their content in subsequent acts.  Together with my colleagues from the National Front, we have always opposed the Schengen acquis, which we are not going to endorse. I abstained.

name: Diane James (EFDD)
text: in writing. – Although the measures to repeal old EU legislation only covers Schengen (which the UK isn’t part of), UKIP will always vote to repeal EU laws. The only people that should create laws are democratically elected and accountable national governments, not unelected bureaucrats in Brussels.

name: Petr Ježek (ALDE)
text: Writing. \u2012 The Commission's proposal to repeal certain parts of EU legislative acts was supported by an overwhelming majority of Members, including me. This is merely a legal update, with the eliminated of several temporary measures and legislative acts that have expired. The aim of this update is to make european Union law more clear.

name: Marc Joulaud (PPE)
text: In writing. I voted in favour of my colleague Claude Moraes' report on the repeal of certain acts of the Schengen acquis in the area of police and judicial cooperation in criminal matters.  Indeed, certain acts concerning legal measures on the area of freedom, security and justice in criminal matters were temporary in nature or were included in other acts after the fact. In the interests of clarification and simplification, it was useful to repeal these acts.  This report was adopted by a large majority, which I welcome.

name: Philippe Juvin (PPE)
text: In writing. I voted in favour of this report, which repeals certain acts already present in other texts or expired, which are related to judicial and police cooperation in criminal matters.  The aim was to improve transparency, clarity and to be consistent in order to improve European legislation.

name: Barbara Kappel (ENF)
text: Writing. This report concerns the repeal of certain acts from the Schengen acquis in the field of police and judicial cooperation in criminal matters. These are technical changes, as these acts are now considered obsolete. I am abstaining from voting on the basis of fundamental considerations on the Schengen Agreement.

name: Afzal Khan (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ These acts are no longer relevant because of their temporary nature or because their content has been taken up by successive acts. Therefore, for reasons of legal certainty and in order to bring acts in the area of freedom, security and justice in line with the Lisbon Treaty, I voted in favour of repealing these acts.

name: Bernd Kölmel (ECR)
text: Writing. In three decisions, the Commission proposed to repeal acts belonging to the Schengen acquis either for a limited period of time or for their content to be incorporated into subsequent legal acts. The aim is to achieve better regulation by achieving greater transparency of Union law. In this context, the rapporteur, Claude Moraes, believes that it is appropriate to remove from the existing acquis acts that are no longer of use. According to the Commission, this is to be achieved by means of three decisions. Unlike the Commission, the rapporteur recommends changing the nature of the act from a decision to a regulation. After consulting the European Parliament's Legal Service, Claude Moraes has also identified two other obsolete acts which are part of the Schengen acquis and are no longer relevant because they were temporary or were incorporated into subsequent legal acts. The ECR supports the REFIT programme in the sense of de-bureaucratisation and has also voted in the LIBE Committee for the repeal of outdated legislation. The ALFA is in favour of legal certainty and clarity. The measures proposed in the reports are likely to reduce EU legislation and simplify Union law. I strongly support these concerns and have therefore voted in favour of the report.

name: Constance Le Grip (PPE)
text: In writing. I voted in favour of the report on the proposed decision by the European Parliament and the Council to repeal certain acts of the Schengen acquis in the area of police and judicial cooperation in criminal matters, which have become obsolete.  In order to improve the effectiveness of the act, we have proposed the modification of the type of act, from 'decision' to 'regulation', which is compulsory in all its elements and directly applicable by The Member States. Furthermore, the Republicans and I call for a profound overhaul of the Schengen Agreements, which are inadequate in their current form and functioning to the reality of the threats that the countries of the Union now face.

name: Giovanni La Via (PPE)
text: in writing. In the inter-institutional agreement of 16 December 2003, the European Parliament, the Council and the Commission agreed on the need to reduce the volume of the Union's body of legislation and simplify it, including through the repeal of obsolete acts. Specifically, it concerns the repeal of certain acts of the Schengen acquis relating to police cooperation and judicial cooperation in criminal matters. In view of the provisions of the Better Regulation Agreement, I have chosen to vote in favour of the proposal.

name: Marine Le Pen (ENF)
text: In writing. A number of acts that are part of the Schengen acquis are no longer relevant because of their temporary nature or because their content has been included in subsequent acts.  These are acts adopted in the field of police cooperation and judicial cooperation in criminal matters and part of the Schengen acquis. In the interests of transparency and "better legislation," they must be repealed.  However, recent events demonstrate once again that Schengen itself is no longer relevant. The external borders are no longer guarded, so the system is out of date. That is why I abstained on the proposal to repeal only certain acts.

name: Paloma López Bermejo (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. I voted in favour of this report to repeal certain acts in the field of police and judicial cooperation in criminal matters, as the acts in question were obsolete and did not apply because of the new regulatory framework that appeared after the Lisbon Treaty. Despite our opposition to it, there would be no point in voting otherwise and maintaining unapplicable regulations.

name: Bernd Lucke (ECR)
text: Writing. In three decisions, the Commission proposed to repeal acts belonging to the Schengen acquis either for a limited period of time or for their content to be incorporated into subsequent legal acts. The aim is to achieve better regulation by achieving greater transparency of Union law. In this context, the rapporteur, Claude Moraes, believes that it is appropriate to remove from the existing acquis acts that are no longer of use. According to the Commission, this is to be achieved by means of three decisions. Unlike the Commission, the rapporteur recommends changing the nature of the act from a decision to a regulation. After consulting the European Parliament's Legal Service, Claude Moraes has also identified two other obsolete acts which are part of the Schengen acquis and are no longer relevant because they were temporary or were incorporated into subsequent legal acts. The ECR supports the REFIT programme in the sense of de-bureaucratisation and has also voted in the LIBE Committee for the repeal of outdated legal acts. The ALFA is in favour of legal certainty and clarity. The measures proposed in the reports are likely to reduce EU legislation and simplify Union law. I strongly support these concerns and have therefore voted in favour of the report.

name: Ivana Maletić (PPE)
text: Written. ‒ The Commission carried out an assessment of the Schengen acquis and legal instruments in the area of police and judicial cooperation in criminal matters for the purpose of assessing and simplifying the law, and found that a number of acts were outdated.  The Commission submitted a proposal to abolish decisions of the Executive Board on combating drug trafficking and the police manual, the Declaration of the Executive Board on the Abduction of Minors and the Council Decision 2008/173. The rapporteur also proposes the abolition of the Agreement on Cooperation in Road Crime Proceedings, as it has never entered into force and the change of the type of act signed by the 'decision' to 'regulation'. I supported MP Claude Moraes' report because I think the abolition of outdated regulations is necessary to ensure the simplicity of the system.

name: Andrejs
text: Mamikins (S&D), in writing. \u2012 As in the case of the first of today's three votes on the repeal of certain obsolete legislation, it is difficult to disagree here with the European Commission's initial proposal for the repeal of some decisions and of a single declaration. While this legislation, such as combating drug trafficking or the abduction of minors, covers various aspects of the functioning of the Schengen area and is clearly absolutely necessary to ensure security both at our borders and within the European Union, it is obsolete and not only does not fulfil its functions, but continues to be a weight of self-weight in the EU's legislative framework. In the case of a decision on road traffic offences, which the rapporteur has added to this list in addition, it is not fully effective at all, although quite a bit of time has already elapsed. I would like to point out further that the interinstitutional agreement between the European Parliament, the Commission and the Council on the reduction and gradual simplification of The Level of European Union law with the repeal of old acts, which has been in operation for almost 12 years, is one of the main mechanisms for streamlining the Community governance structure. It can therefore only be welcomed that this agreement continues to function today, creating at least a partial balance between the ever-increasing number of EU legislation and their overlaps.

name: Vladimír Maňka (S&D)
text: Writing. \u2012 The proposal repeals the rules on combating drug trafficking, abduction of minors, traffic offences, police manual and tests of the second generation Schengen Information System. The reason for the repeal is the obsolescence and temporaryity of the regulations, while the issue of some acts has already been taken into account in newer regulations.

name: Νότης Μαριάς (
text: ECR), in writing. \u2012 I am voting in favour of the report on the proposal for a regulation of the European Parliament and of the Council on the repeal of certain acts in the field of police cooperation and judicial cooperation in criminal matters.

name: Dominique Martin (ENF)
text: In writing. I abstained on this vote. As with the previous vote, we believe that the Schengen area is no longer relevant, especially in light of recent events which have shown its futility.  Voting for this repeal would be a guarantee of Schengen, and a vote against is useless since it would only serve to keep obsolete acts and would not even call into question the space itself.  Abstention is the only valid choice.

name: David Martin (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted for this proposal. Improving the transparency of Union law is an essential element of the better law-making strategy that the institutions of the Union are implementing. In that context it is appropriate to remove from the legislation in force those acts which no longer serve any purpose. A number of acts adopted in the field of police cooperation and judicial cooperation in criminal matters, and belonging to the Schengen acquis, are no longer relevant due to their temporary nature or because their content has been taken up by successive acts, even though they have not been repealed.

name: Fulvio Martusciello (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 Favourable to the report on the repeal of certain acts of the Schengen acquis in the field of police cooperation and judicial cooperation in criminal matters.  The Commission has carried out an assessment of the Schengen acquis and legal instruments in the field of police cooperation and judicial cooperation in criminal matters, as a result of which certain acts are therefore identified as no longer relevant. The aim of this Regulation is, in fact, to repeal these obsolete acts of the European Union in the field of police cooperation and judicial cooperation in criminal matters and forming part of the Schengen acquis, since their content is taken up in subsequent acts even if they have not been repealed.

name: Georg Mayer (ENF)
text: Writing. This is a purely technical report on the Schengen acts. The current situation confirms our critical attitude to the Schengen laws. The report only reflects the current legal situation. Since it does not bring about any change in content, I abstain from my voice.

name: Jean-Luc Mélenchon (GUE/NGL)
text: In writing. In this report, the Commission proposes to repeal a number of legislative acts in the area of police and judicial cooperation in criminal matters that have been rendered obsolete mainly since the integration of the Schengen acquis directly into the European treaties.  These acts include mutual legal assistance in criminal matters between states, the fight against drug trafficking and the sharing of information and information between customs authorities, as well as the most controversial Schengen Information System.  Keystone of the migrant sorting system that came into operation in 2013, this programme of stripping everything entering the UNION, similar to the North American version that inspired it, is already a financial abyss for the results we know in the fight against terrorism.  It should also be remembered that 6 of the 7 murderers in Paris were Europeans and not foreigners. Although this is a technical report aimed at 'simplifying' EU law, I am voting against it to disagree with these ineffective measures.

name: Joëlle Mélin (ENF)
text: In writing. As with the other Moraes report (66 - A8-0250/2015), this text repeals acts that are part of the so-called 'Schengen acquis' and which no longer seem relevant, because of their temporary nature or their recycling in subsequent acts.  Nevertheless, the National Front has always opposed the Schengen area and there is no question of endorsing its legal changes. That is why the member is abstaining on this issue.

name: Nuno Melo (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 The European Commission has assessed the Schengen acquis and existing legal instruments in the context of judicial and police cooperation in criminal matters, taking into account Protocol No 36 annexed to the Treaties on transitional provisions. In the case of obsolete provisions - either by their exclusively temporary nature or by changing their content by subsequent acts - with a view to simplifying legislation, with gains in legal certainty and certainty, better regulation means the repeal of those acts.  I have therefore voted in favour of the proposal for a decision of the European Parliament and the Council repealing certain acts in the field of police cooperation and judicial cooperation in criminal matters.

name: Roberta Metsola (PPE)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of this regulation as the repealing of obsolete acts will allow for better efficiency and cohesion in the EU with regards to police cooperation and judicial matters.

name: Miroslav Mikolášik (PPE)
text: Writing. \u2012 The European institutions have concluded an agreement to reduce the amount of Union legislation in order to increase transparency and simplify lawmaking. For this reason, the Regulation repeals obsolete acts the content of which has been provisional or taken over in subsequent acts. In particular, the proposal in question is the acts of the Schengen acquis in the field of police cooperation and judicial cooperation in criminal matters, which the Commission has presented in accordance with the Better Law-Making Agreement. I therefore fully agree with the proposal on the table and am voting in favour of its adoption.

name: Marlene Mizzi (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ I have voted in favour of the report on repealing certain acts from the Schengen acquis, which is essential in the field of police cooperation and judicial cooperation in criminal matters. As part of the Commission policy on Regulatory Fitness, this related instrument will repeal a number of legal acts in the field of police and judicial cooperation and a number in relation to the Schengen Acquis. All of the acts to be repealed are no longer legally relevant either because they have been replaced by a more up-to-date legal act or because they are of a temporary nature.

name: Csaba Molnár (S&D)
text: Writing. \u2012 In its analysis referred to in the preceding paragraph, the Commission found that the Decision of the Schengen Executive Committee (on combating drug trafficking) SCH/Com-ex (93) 14 and (98) 52 (police manual) and the Commission's (minor abduction) SCH/Com-ex (97) decl 13 rev 2 declaration had become obsolete because their content had been transferred to subsequent acts. Council Decision 2008/173/IB on the testing of the second generation of the Schengen Information System (SIS II) has also become obsolete since SIS II started operating on 9 April 2013. It has therefore proposed to adopt a decision of the European Parliament and of the Council repealing them.  In its report, the Committee on Civil Liberties, Justice and Home Affairs recommended the draft to Parliament for adoption, with the decision of the Executive Committee on cooperation in road traffic infringement proceedings to be included in the withdrawn acts. This Decision has never entered into force and no Member State has made a declaration under Article 20(3) on the application of the Agreement between the Member States which have ratified it. The report also proposes to change the type of act from a decision to a regulation, since the Regulation is fully binding and directly applicable in all Member States and better serves the purpose of the proposal. I supported the draft.

name: Bernard Monot (ENF)
text: In writing. This report calls for the same remarks and the same abstention position as the european Parliament and Council's proposal for a decision repealing certain acts related to the area of freedom, security and justice.

name: Cláudia Monteiro de Aguiar (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 As regards police cooperation and judicial cooperation in criminal matters, in the area of the Schengen acquis, and with a view to the expiry of the transitional period laid down in Protocol No 36 on transitional provisions annexed to the Treaties, a number of acts have been considered obsolete.  The repeal of such acts, in particular the decisions of the SCH/Com-ex Executive Committee (93) 14 on drug trafficking, of the SCH/Com-ex Executive Committee (98) 52 on the vade-mécum of police cooperation, the Declaration of the Executive Committee SCH/Com-ex (97) decl, is considered essential. 13 Rev. 2 on the abduction of minors and Council Decision 2008/173/JAI of 18 February 2008 on the second generation testing of the Schengen Information System (SIS II), as they were temporary only or their content was taken up by subsequent legislative instruments.  I agree with the proposal referred to here, as well as to call the legal act a 'regulation' rather than a 'decision', since legislative transparency and legal certainty must be ensured by the European institutions, thus being compulsory and directly applicable to the Member States.

name: Sophie Montel (ENF)
text: In writing. This report, like the previous report, concerns the simplification by repeal of certain measures that could be confusing.  These are provisions adopted in the field of police and judicial cooperation in criminal matters and part of the Schengen acquis. Absolutely opposed to the Schengen agreements, but in support of this simplification approach, I have decided to abstain.

name: Nadine Morano (PPE)
text: In writing. I voted in favour of this report on the repeal of certain acts in the area of police and judicial cooperation in criminal matters.  Improving the transparency of EU law is an essential part of the strategy to better legislate, which the EU institutions are currently implementing.  Some legal measures are no longer relevant because of their temporary nature or because their content has been taken up by subsequent acts. They should therefore be removed from existing legislation.

name: Renaud Muselier (PPE)
text: In writing. I have not been able to vote for this report, but I fully support the position of the EPP Group and the French delegation to adopt this report.  A number of acts adopted in the field of police cooperation and judicial cooperation in criminal matters and part of the Schengen acquis are no longer relevant because of their temporary nature. They should therefore be repealed.

name: Victor Negrescu (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ I have voted for this report, which will abolish the Decision of the Executive Committee SCH/Com-ex (99) 11 rev. 2 on the Agreement on cooperation in proceedings for road traffic offences, taking into consideration the fact that this agreement has never entered into force.

name: Norica Nicolai (ALDE)
text: in writing. ‒ I supported this decision to repeal the outdated acts concerning police cooperation and judicial cooperation in criminal matters from the Schengen acquis, as the application of those lateral protocols was already mostly taken into account through newer and better formulated documents.

name: Franz Obermayr (ENF)
text: Writing. The report refers to a Commission proposal for a decision to repeal certain acts in the field of police and judicial cooperation in criminal matters. This is a purely technical report, which is why I abstained.

name: Younous Omarjee (GUE/NGL)
text: In writing. I supported this report to approve the Commission's decision to repeal legislation rendered obsolete by the integration of Schengen's achievements into the European treaties.  The aim here is to remove from EU law acts governing relations in criminal matters between Member States, since they were conceived as transitional provisions or their content was transcribed in subsequent acts, including the Lisbon Treaty in 2009.  The repeal of obsolete acts is necessary in order to simplify European legislation.

name: Urmas Paet (ALDE)
text: Writing. \u2012 I supported because over time many laws have expired or their content has been transposed into other acts.

name: Margot Parker (EFDD)
text: in writing. ‒ Although the measures to repeal old EU legislation only covers Schengen (which the UK isn’t part of), UKIP will always vote to repeal EU laws. The only people that should create laws are democratically elected and accountable national governments, not unelected bureaucrats in Brussels.

name: Aldo Patriciello (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 I reiterate my confidence in the importance of simplifying the Schengen acquis. In particular, I welcome the decisions taken in the field of police and judicial cooperation: the work carried out by the Parliamentary Committee on Civil Rights, Human Rights, Common Security and Reform party, including with missions by some of my colleagues in the places most affected by the migration phenomenon (I am also referring to southern Italy), has highlighted the need to focus on this particular aspect of border management policy. I am voting in favour.

name: Marijana Petir (PPE)
text: Written. ‒ This Regulation abolishes acts regulating police and judicial cooperation in criminal matters between Schengen Area Member States. Situations where one parent unlawfully takes a child across the border or when a Member State refuses to cooperate in the fight against drug trafficking are clearly covered by subsequent acts, therefore outdated acts belonging to the Schengen acquis no longer make sense and need to be revoked. I also agree to the abolition of the Council Decision on schengen Information System 2 tests, which is already in the use phase. I supported this Report because I believe it is necessary to revoke all those acts that no longer have a purpose. Legal certainty in the application of the acquis at issue also achieved by revoking outdated acts is a key element of the strategy for better drafting legislation implemented by the Union institutions to simplify and make EU documents transparent.

name: Florian Philippot (ENF)
text: In writing. This report, like the previous one, concerns the simplification by repeal of certain measures that could lead to confusion. These are provisions adopted in the field of police and judicial cooperation in criminal matters and part of the Schengen acquis.  Absolutely opposed to the Schengen agreements, but in support of this simplification approach, I have decided to abstain.

name: Tonino Picula (S&D)
text: Written. ‒ I support the Commission's proposal to repeal the seven Joint Council actions on the fight against organised crime, drug addiction and drug trafficking and cooperation on public policy and security. The most important powers have been granted to Europol, which has become responsible for strengthening cooperation between Member States' law enforcement authorities in preventing and combating terrorism, and advising member state authorities on investigative procedures. The European Evidentiary Order has also been repealed as an instrument for cooperation in criminal matters, as the European Investigative Order applies among the 26 Member States. In these areas, it is of utmost importance to set common rules and a security framework, as drug trafficking and organised crime remain major threats to European security.

name: Andrej Plenković (PPE)
text: Written. —The European Union, as a supranational union to which Member States have ceded certain sovereign rights, has the right and duty to fulfil all the obligations arising therein in order to achieve its objectives. Legislative role is one of the most important in this regard, as EU law has a major direct impact on member states' national law. In his report on the proposal for a decision by the European Parliament and the Council on the repeal of certain acts in the area of police and judicial cooperation in criminal matters, Claude Moraes' colleague justifiably stresses that a key element of the better law-making strategy is to improve the transparency of Union law and that those acts in force but no longer serve a purpose should be removed to this effect , i.e. not relevant because of their legal nature or because their content is covered by subsequent acts. Those decisions and declarations which are outdated in this regard should be repealed for reasons of legal certainty and clarity.

name: Salvatore Domenico Pogliese (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 The European Commission has carried out an assessment of the Schengen acquis and legal instruments in the field of police cooperation and judicial cooperation in criminal matters. As a result of this assessment, a number of legislative acts have been identified as obsolete because their content has been taken up in subsequent acts.  This report proposes the repeal of the following regulatory provisions: Decision SCH/Com-ex (93) 14 (combating drug trafficking); declaration SCH/Com-ex (97) 13 2nd Rev. (abduction of minors); DECISION SCH/Com-ex (98) 52 (police vademecum); Decision SCH/Com-ex (99)11 2a Rev. (road infringements) and Council Decision 2008/173/JHA (technical tests of SIS II).  I am voting in favour because the repeal of these measures is in accordance with the principles of subsidiarity and proportionality.

name: Jiří Pospíšil (PPE)
text: Writing. \u2012 I was very pleased, as I said on the previous point, that we are not only here today to adopt new standards, but finally the European Parliament has decided to repeal acts that are already superfluous in the EU legal order. Let us hope that this is not an isolated shot, but that we will continue to cut through the imaginary legislative jungle in a similar way.

name: Franck Proust (PPE)
text: In writing. I voted to repeal this text because it had become legally obsolete. We must adopt clear texts to effectively strengthen our area of freedom, security and justice.

name: Paulo Rangel (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 This Commission proposal provides for the repeal of a number of acts belonging to the Schengen acquis adopted in the field of police and judicial cooperation in criminal matters, which have become obsolete either by virtue of the integration of their content into subsequent acts or because of their temporary nature.  In this particular case, the repeal of the obsolete decisions of the SCH/Com-ex Executive Committee (93) 14 (combating drug trafficking) and the Executive Committee SCH/Com-ex (98) 52 (vade-mécum of police cooperation), as well as the Declaration of the Executive Committee SCH/Com-ex (97) decl. 13 rev 2 (child abduction) and Council Decision 2008/173/JAI of 18 February 2008 on second generation testing of the Schengen Information System (SIS II). With a view to the expiry of the transitional period set out in Protocol No 36, annexed to the Treaties, and considering the objectives of simplification and reduction of the volume of legislation included in the Better Regulation strategy, I voted in favour.

name: Julia Reid (EFDD)
text: in writing. ‒ Although the measures to repeal old EU legislation only covers Schengen (which the UK isn’t part of), UKIP will always vote to repeal EU laws. The only people that should create laws are democratically elected and accountable national governments, not unelected bureaucrats in Brussels.

name: Liliana Rodrigues (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 Relates only to the repeal of obsolete acts, either by virtue of the integration of their content into subsequent acts or by virtue of their temporary nature.

name: Inmaculada Rodríguez-Piñero Fernández (S&D)
text: in writing. A number of acts adopted in the field of police and judicial cooperation in criminal matters belonging to the Schengen acquis are no longer relevant because of their temporary nature or because their content has been incorporated into successive acts, although they have not been repealed. These are acts that have become obsolete, including the Decisions of the Executive Committee SCH/Com-ex (93) 14 (combating narcotics trafficking) and (98) 52 (police vademécum), the Statement of the Executive Committee SCH/Com-ex (97) decl. 13, 2nd setback (child abduction) and Council Decision 2008/173/JHA of 18 February 2008 on the testing of the second generation Schengen Information System (SIS II) as they have become obsolete. That is why I voted in favour of its repeal.

name: Claude Rolin (PPE)
text: In writing. In the context of the expiry of the transitional period set out in Protocol 36 on transitional provisions, attached to the treaties, the European Commission has carried out an assessment of the Schengen acquis and legal instruments in the field of police and judicial cooperation in criminal matters. A number of acts have been identified as obsolete because their content has been taken up in subsequent acts, or because of their temporary nature. In the inter-institutional agreement of 16 December 2003, the European Parliament, the Council and the Commission agreed to simplify EU legislation and reduce its volume, including by repealing acts that have become obsolete.  The Commission has put forward a proposal to repeal, because of their obsolescence, the following acts: 11 decisions of the Schengen Executive Committee due to the fact that their content has been taken up in subsequent acts, and regulation (EC) 189/2008 of the Council of 18 February 2008 relating to the testing of the second generation Schengen information system (SIS II), which exhausted its legal effects when SIS II became operational on 9 April 2013.  I voted in favour of this report, which endorses the proposal of the EU executive.

name: Fernando Ruas (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 This report by Mr Moraes concerns a proposal for a decision of the European Parliament and the Council repealing certain acts in the field of police and judicial cooperation in criminal matters. This proposal follows an assessment by the Commission of the acquis on police and judicial cooperation in criminal matters, which identified some acts that could be repealed. If there is no obstacle to its approval and in view of the desirability of eliminating from the legislation in force acts which are no longer useful, I voted in a favourable way.

name: Tokia Saïfi (PPE)
text: In writing. I voted in favour of this text, which proposes to amend the type of legislation so that this decision becomes a regulation; moreover, an addition to the title specifies that the repealed acts in question are part of the Schengen acquis.  A regulation is compulsory in all its elements and directly applicable in any Member State; it will thus serve more effectively the proposal to repeal acts deemed obsolete, since their content has been taken up in subsequent acts.

name: Massimiliano Salini (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the Decision of the European Parliament and of the Council on the repeal of certain acts of the Schengen acquis in the field of police cooperation and judicial cooperation in criminal matters because I consider the decisions of the Executive Committee SCH/Com-ex (93) 14 (fight against (98) 52 (police manual), the declaration of the SCH/Com-ex Executive Committee (97) decl 13 2a rev. (child abduction) and Council Decision 2008/173/JHA, of 18 February 2018, on the technical tests of the Second Generation Schengen Information System (SIS II).

name: Lola Sánchez Caldentey (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. This repeal is exempt from political content and is simply about the overcoming, through successive acts, of certain regulations, which are therefore exceeded or contained in others. That's why we voted in favour.

name: Lidia Senra Rodríguez (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. I voted in favour of this report to repeal certain acts in the field of police and judicial cooperation in criminal matters, as the acts in question were obsolete and did not apply because of the new regulatory framework that appeared after the Lisbon Treaty. Despite our opposition to it, there would be no point in voting otherwise and maintaining unapplicable regulations.

name: Remo Sernagiotto (ECR)
text: in writing. \u2012 With today's vote, Parliament repealed certain acts of the Schengen acquis in the field of police cooperation and legal cooperation in criminal matters which have become obsolete.  Their content has, in fact, been taken up in subsequent acts or has exhausted its legal effect. I have therefore chosen to vote in favour.

name: Jill Seymour (EFDD)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of this as it repeals European Union acts.

name: Siôn Simon (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ This is the second of three instruments which we voted to repeal. Just like the previous one which was more generally titled ʽRepealing certain acts from the Schengen acquisʼ (A8-0250/2015), it was not politically motivated and makes sense in legislative terms.

name: Monika Smolková (S&D)
text: Writing. \u2012 The Commission is fulfilling its decision to simplify EU legislation by repealing obsolete legal acts. In this context, the Commission has also carried out an assessment of Schengen legislation and legal instruments in the field of police and judicial cooperation in criminal matters. Since it concluded that many acts were already obsolete and their content was taken into account in subsequent acts or were of a temporary nature, it is only possible to support its proposal to repeal them.  This will result in the annulment of the Executive Committee's outdated decisions on combating drug trafficking, on the police manual, as well as on the Executive Committee's statement on the abduction of minors. A decision on the cooperation agreement in traffic offences procedures will also be included in the list of repealed acts, as this Agreement has never entered into force. In addition, there will be technical adaptations to the Schengen acquis when the type of act is changed from a 'Decision' to a 'Regulation' or a title is added specifying that the repealed acts fall within that adaptation. Although such technical changes are made, they are important for the overall consistency of the legal system.

name: Joachim Starbatty (ECR)
text: Writing. In three decisions, the Commission proposed to repeal acts belonging to the Schengen acquis either for a limited period of time or for their content to be incorporated into subsequent legal acts. The aim is to achieve better regulation by achieving greater transparency of Union law. In this context, the rapporteur, Claude Moraes, believes that it is appropriate to remove from the existing acquis acts that are no longer of use. According to the Commission, this is to be achieved by means of three decisions. Unlike the Commission, the rapporteur recommends changing the nature of the act from a decision to a regulation. Claude Moraes has also identified two other obsolete acts, after consulting the European Parliament's Legal Service, which are part of the Schengen acquis and are no longer relevant because they were temporary or were incorporated into subsequent legal acts. The ECR supports the REFIT programme in the sense of de-bureaucratisation and has also voted in the LIBE Committee for the repeal of outdated legal acts. The ALFA is in favour of legal certainty and clarity. The measures proposed in the reports are likely to reduce EU legislation and simplify Union law. I strongly support these concerns and have therefore voted in favour of the report.

name: Ivan Štefanec (PPE)
text: Writing. \u2012 The interest of legal certainty and clarity of the Union legal order is currently no less important in the area of cooperation between Member States at police and judicial level in criminal matters. I therefore support the abolition of obscene legal acts which have lost the relevance of their further existence over time.

name: Davor Ivo Stier (PPE)
text: Written. I support this proposal because many acts adopted in the field of police and judicial cooperation in criminal matters are no longer relevant due to their temporary nature. Furthermore, the decision of the Executive Board sch/com-ex (98) 52 adopted the Schengen Handbook on cross-border police cooperation that assists Member States in carrying out cross-border activities. In my view, this decision is outdated after the content of the manual is included in the recent updated catalogue of recommendations for the proper application of the Schengen acquis and best practice. I therefore support the proposal to repeal these outdated decisions and declarations for legal certainty and clarity. This proposal should repeal many outdated Union acts in the area of police and judicial cooperation in criminal matters and cannot be achieved at Member State level but only at Union level.

name: Catherine Stihler (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of this report. A number of acts adopted in recent decades have exhausted all their effects. They are no longer relevant because of their temporary nature or because their content has been taken up by successive acts. For reasons of legal certainty it is necessary to revoke the measures in question in order to bring acts in the area of freedom, security and justice in line with the Lisbon Treaty.

name: Dubravka Šuica (PPE)
text: Written. ‒ Many acts adopted in the field of police and judicial cooperation in criminal matters, belonging to the Schengen acquis, are no longer relevant due to their temporary nature or because their content is covered by subsequent acts. The Commission submitted a proposal to abolish decisions of the Executive Board on combating drug trafficking and the police manual, the Declaration of the Executive Board on the Abduction of Minors and the Council Decision 2008/173. The rapporteur also proposes the abolition of the Cooperation Agreement in Road Crime Proceedings, as it has never entered into force, and a change in the type of act in the decision to a regulation, as the regulations comply with Art. 288 TFEUs are fully binding and directly applicable in all countries. I support the proposal to abolish acts in the field of police and judicial cooperation in criminal matters, which belong to the Schengen acquis, as it represents a good strategy for better drafting of legislation by the Union institutions.

name: Patricija Šulin (PPE)
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the report on the proposal for a decision of the European Parliament and of the Council repealing certain acts in the field of police and judicial cooperation in criminal matters. I support the repeal of obsolete acts either because they were only temporary in nature or because they are no longer relevant. Since the repeal of acts in the field of police and judicial cooperation in criminal matters cannot be adopted by the Member States alone, we need to adopt a regulation at European Union level which will also repeal all those acts.

name: Kay Swinburne (ECR)
text: in writing. ‒ As the UK is outside of the Schengen area and this proposal does not impact the UK in any way, I have abstained.

name: Νεοκλής Συλικιώτης (
text: GUE/NGL), in writing. \u2012 As part of the programme to improve the suitability and efficiency of the regulatory framework, the Commission stated that it had conducted a "screening" of the acquis in the field of police and judicial cooperation in criminal matters. The aim was to identify acts which could be repealed at the end of the transitional period set by the Treaties.  The Commission has completed the evaluation of legal acts in the area of Freedom, Security and Justice, and has proposed three proposals concerning the repeal of some twenty legal measures. We have therefore voted in favour of these reports relating to the above acts, as they contribute to legal clarity by indicating which acts are considered obsolete because of their temporary nature, but also because they have been replaced by subsequent acts under the Treaty of Lisbon.

name: Tibor Szanyi (S&D)
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of repealing the acts contained in the proposal in the report, given that I consider the high quality and transparency of European Union legislation to be of paramount importance. In the case of legislation falling within the scope of Schengen cooperation, it is particularly important and useful to clean up the agreement at the end of the transitional period from elements which are already intended to be transitional or which have since proved to be obsolete or covered by new legislation, on which the report provides an accurate overview and a sound proposal. I have also considered with emphasis the current aspect that a clear, flexible, modern legal environment for effective law enforcement and enforcement is the most essential to meet the new Challenges in Europe today (terrorism, drug abuse, etc.) in the police and judicial field.

name: Claudia Tapardel (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 The interinstitutional agreement signed between the European Parliament, the Council and the European Commission calls, inter alia, for a reduction in the volume of European legislation. On the basis of better regulation, the European Commission has proposed the repeal of a list of measures in the field of police cooperation and judicial cooperation in criminal matters. I agree with the rapporteur on the inclusion of a decision (SCH/Com-ex (99) 11 rev. 2(8)), in which the Executive Board adopted a cooperation agreement on road crime. The cooperation agreement, concluded only between certain Member States with two third countries (Iceland and Norway), is not an internal act of the Schengen acquis, nor has it ever entered into force.

name: Marc Tarabella (S&D)
text: In writing. I voted in favour of Mr Moraes' proposal. Improving the transparency of EU law is an essential part of the strategy to better legislate, which the EU institutions are currently implementing. In this context, acts that no longer have any reason to exist should be removed from existing legislation.

name: Pavel Telička (ALDE)
text: in writing. ‒ In order to simplify EU law and in line with the Inter-Institutional Agreement, I voted in favour of this report, regarding obsolete legal instruments in the field of police cooperation and judicial cooperation in criminal matters. To make it more binding, Parliament has proposed that the act become a regulation rather than a decision. It repeals several decisions of the Executive Committee SCH/Com-ex on combating drug trafficking, the police handbook, road traffic offences and abduction of minors, as well as Council Decision 2008/173/JHA on the testing of the second generation Schengen Information System (SIS II).

name: Ruža Tomašić (ECR)
text: Written. ‒ I supported the removal of acts from EUROPEAN Union legislation that no longer serve a purpose to improve the transparency of Union law. As part of a REFIT programme aimed at a clearer, more stable and predictable regulatory framework for the European Union, the European Commission is proposing to abolish acts that are outdated or replaced by new ones.  In order to achieve the purpose of this programme, this Regulation will abolish decisions on combating drug trafficking, the police manual and traffic offences, as well as the statement on the abduction of minors and the Council decision on SIS II tests.  As the contents of these acts have subsequently been entered into other legal provisions of the European Union, I believe that the abolition of these acts will help to reduce the regulatory burden and increase the efficiency of the law.

name: Romana Tomc (PPE)
text: Writing. - I supported the report on the proposal for a regulation of the European Parliament and of the Council repealing certain acts in the field of police and judicial cooperation in criminal matters, as past events have once again reminded us of the importance of strengthening counter-terrorism surveillance. It is also necessary to promote the development of competent authorities in investigative procedures and investigations in order to ensure the highest possible level of security for all citizens. I believe that this report promotes good and effective mutual cooperation between member states' law enforcement authorities and cross-border cooperation.

name: Estefanía Torres Martínez (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. This repeal is exempt from political content and is simply about the overcoming, through successive acts, of certain regulations, which are therefore exceeded or contained in others. That's why we voted in favour.

name: Ramon Tremosa i Balcells (ALDE)
text: in writing. ‒ I fully support all efforts to reinforce and improve police and judicial cooperation between EU Member States. It is essential to cooperate better and exchange information forgetting national borders on issues of security and threats! The recent sad events in Europe remind us of this urgency! Terrorists and criminal gangs operate in all countries and cross frontiers!

name: Mylène Troszczynski (ENF)
text: In writing. A number of acts that are part of the Schengen acquis are no longer relevant because of their temporary nature or because their content has been taken up by subsequent acts.  In the interests of transparency and "better legislation," they must be repealed. Voting against this text makes no sense, since it would mean keeping obsolete acts when this report does not involve Schengen.  These are acts adopted in the area of police cooperation and judicial cooperation in criminal matters. So I opt for abstention.

name: István Ujhelyi (S&D)
text: Writing. \u2012 A number of acts adopted in the field of police and judicial cooperation in criminal matters and covered by the Schengen acquis are no longer relevant as they are provisional in nature or have been adopted by subsequent acts, but the original acts have not been repealed. I therefore voted in favour of the proposal.

name: Traian Ungureanu (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 European Union legislation contains a number of acts that are no longer applied. These acts are no longer relevant because of their temporary nature or because their content has been taken over by subsequent acts. In order to improve transparency and ensure a higher degree of legal certainty for European citizens, such acts are withdrawn from the Union's legislative acquis. The European Commission shall regularly carry out a screening of the legislative acquis with a view to identifying acts that could be repealed, in view of the expiry of the transitional period provided for in the Treaties. The European Parliament's legislative resolution concerns the proposal for a regulation repealing certain acts in the field of police cooperation and judicial cooperation in criminal matters. Through this proposal for a regulation, the Commission calls for the repeal of obsolete decisions on combating drug trafficking, kidnapping of minors, the police manual and the testing of the second generation Schengen Information System (SIS II). The European Parliament's legislative resolution supports the repeal of these obsolete acts. I voted in favour of this resolution.

name: Miguel Urbán Crespo (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. This repeal is exempt from political content and is simply about the overcoming, through successive acts, of certain regulations, which are therefore exceeded or contained in others. That's why we voted in favour.

name: Viktor Uspaskich (ALDE)
text: Writing. – Enhancing the transparency of Union law is a crucial element of the better law-making strategy implemented by the Union institutions. In this context, it is appropriate to remove from the legislation in force those acts which have become pointless.

name: Ivo Vajgl (ALDE)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of the resolution on the proposal for a decision of the European Parliament and of the Council repealing certain acts in the field of police cooperation and judicial cooperation in criminal matters because I believe that improving the transparency of Union law is an essential element of the better law-making strategy that the institutions of the Union are implementing. In that context, it is appropriate to repeal those acts which no longer serve any purpose. A number of acts adopted in the field of police cooperation and judicial cooperation in criminal matters, and belonging to the Schengen acquis, are no longer relevant due to their temporary nature or because their content has been taken up by subsequent acts. The resolution also addresses the decision of the Executive Committee about the Schengen handbook on cross-border police cooperation, assisting Member States in carrying out cross-border operations. This decision became obsolete after the handbook’s content was included in the updated ‘catalogue of recommendations for the correct application of the Schengen acquis and best practices in police cooperation, Handbook on cross-border operations and Compendium on law enforcement liaison officers’.

name: Ramón Luis Valcárcel Siso (PPE)
text: in writing. We are talking about the repeal of three decisions and a statement by the Executive Committee and the repeal of Council Decision 2008/173/JHA on the testing of the Schengen Ii Information System (SIS II). This is intended to repeal these outdated acts and to move forward with the simplification of European legislation in a correct way, so I think it is necessary to vote in favour.

name: Ángela Vallina (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. I voted in favour of this report to repeal certain acts in the field of police and judicial cooperation in criminal matters, as the acts in question were obsolete and did not apply because of the new regulatory framework that appeared after the Lisbon Treaty. Despite our opposition to it, there would be no point in voting otherwise and maintaining unapplicable regulations.

name: Hilde Vautmans (ALDE)
text: Written. 'This withdrawal logically also simplifies European law in the area of police and judicial cooperation, as some legal instruments from the Schengen acquis have fallen into disuse. Many of these acts have been replaced or clarified over the years by more recent and clear legislation. That is why I have chosen to support this proposal.

name: Miguel Viegas (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. \u2012 Several acts belonging to the Schengen acquis - combating drug trafficking, child abduction, police cooperation vade-mécum, road offences, SIS II tests - are no longer relevant because of their temporary nature or because their content has been taken up by subsequent acts, although they have not been revoked, making them considered obsolete. Despite the technical nature of this document, it deals with a number of matters of a political nature for which certain positions have already been taken.  For the foregoing, the abstention vote.

name: Harald Vilimsky (ENF)
text: Writing. This is a purely technical report on the Schengen acts. The current situation confirms our critical attitude to the Schengen laws. The report only reflects the current legal situation. Since it does not bring about any change in content, I abstain from my voice.

name: Daniele Viotti (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 Many of the pieces of legislation incorporated into the Schengen acquis are now obsolete acts, particularly in the area of police cooperation and judicial cooperation in criminal matters. That is why I voted in favour of abolishing those unnecessary and outdated rules.

name: Udo Voigt (NI)
text: Writing. A number of the developments in the Schengen acquis listed in the report do not in fact constitute a "further development" in terms of effective police and judicial cooperation between EU Member States. There is therefore no reason to repeal regulations originally codified in the Schengen Agreement, especially since, in the course of the current development of the EU, it must also be expected that the degree of European integration that has already been achieved cannot be sustained in the long term.

name: Beatrix von Storch (ECR)
text: Writing. Legal acts from the Schengen acquis in the field of police and judicial cooperation in criminal matters that are no longer useful or are not fully implemented anyway can be repealed with a clear conscience. That is why I voted in favour of this resolution. These acts are now being repealed: — Decision SCH/Com-ex (93) 14 (Combating the illicit trade in narcotics), — SCH/Com ex (97) decl. 13 Rev. 2 (abduction of minors), - Decision SCH/Com-ex (98) 52 (Guide to Cross-border Police Cooperation), - Decision SCH/Com-ex (99) 11, Rev. 2 (infringements of traffic rules) and - Decision 2008/173/JHA (SIS II audits).

name: Θεόδωρος Ζαγοράκης (PPE)
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the rapporteur's proposal, which has taken into account all the parameters for the improved amendment of the text.

name: Janusz Zemke (S&D)
text: I would like to write to the Commission. \u2012 Claude Moraes has submitted a draft legislative resolution of the European Parliament on a draft regulation of parliament and of the Council repealing certain legal acts in the field of police cooperation and judicial cooperation in criminal matters. I believe that this resolution deserves support. It rightly proposes to limit the number of provisions of EU law by repealing outdated acts. The analysis shows that 7 previous but still existing pieces of legislation have already been incorporated into later solutions. This applies in particular to the exchange of objects and documents to be used in criminal proceedings. In addition, the previous rules on Europol staff are being abolished as they have been replaced by the EU Regulation on europol.

name: Inês Cristina Zuber (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. \u2012 The LIBE Committee has decided to frame this report in the Simplified Procedure – Article 50(2) of the Rules of Procedure. Mrs Cornelia Ernst, who suggests voting in favour, followed this report. Several acts belonging to the Schengen acquis - combating drug trafficking, child abduction, police cooperation, road offences, SIS II tests - are no longer relevant because of their temporary nature or because their content has been taken over by subsequent acts, although they have not been repealed, making them obsolete. Despite the technical nature of this document, it deals with a number of matters of a political nature to which we have spoken against. We do not, however, agree with subsequent acts for continuing the policy of repression and securitization. For the foregoing, the abstention vote.

name: Milan Zver (PPE)
text: Writing. \ I voted in favour of the European Parliament's legislative resolution on the proposal for a regulation of the European Parliament and of the Council repealing certain legal acts in the field of judicial cooperation in criminal matters and police cooperation (COM(2014)0714 – C8-0279/2014 – 2014/0338(COD)) because I believe that it contributes to improving the transparency of Union law and allows for better law-making. Many acts in the field of police and judicial cooperation in criminal matters falling within the Schengen acquis, namely by their provisional nature or because their content have been summarised by subsequent acts, are no longer relevant, even if they have not been repealed. I also voted in favour of changing the type of legal act from 'Decision of the European Parliament and of the Council' to 'Regulation of the European Parliament and of the Council' in order to allow it to become directly applicable in all Member States in accordance with Article 288 TFEU.

name: William (The Earl of) Dartmouth (EFDD)
