text: in writing. ‒ Although the measures to repeal old EU legislation only covers Schengen (which the UK isn’t part of), UKIP will always vote to repeal EU laws. The only people that should create laws are democratically elected and accountable national governments, not unelected bureaucrats in Brussels.

name: Marina Albiol Guzmán (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. I voted in favour of this report to repeal certain acts in the field of police and judicial cooperation in criminal matters, as the acts in question were obsolete and did not apply because of the new regulatory framework that appeared after the Lisbon Treaty. Despite our opposition to it, there would be no point in voting otherwise and maintaining unapplicable regulations.

name: Marie-Christine Arnautu (ENF)
text: In writing. This report also aims to repeal obsolete acts; but, unlike the other two Moraes reports, these acts are not related to the Schengen acquis.  Again, legal clarification by repealing outdated or duplicate acts with other legal texts is a good thing. However, we cannot support the federalization of jurisdiction, especially in areas as sensitive as police and judicial cooperation in criminal matters.  Together with my colleagues from the National Front, we have therefore logically chosen to abstain.

name: Jonathan Arnott (EFDD)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of this technical repeal, although sadly it is unlikely to cut the regulatory burden as the relevant acts were already obsolete.

name: Jean Arthuis (ALDE)
text: In writing. I voted in favour of this deliberation as advocated by the committee on its merits.

name: Zigmantas Balčytis (S&D)
text: Writing. \u2012 The Commission has assessed the Schengen acquis and legislation relating to police cooperation and judicial cooperation in criminal matters. Several pieces of legislation have been found to be obsolete as their content has been transposed into subsequent legislation or is of a temporary nature. I support the proposal to reduce and simplify the number of Union legislation, including by repealing obsolete legislation.

name: Gerard Batten (EFDD)
text: in writing. ‒ Although the measures to repeal old EU legislation only covers police and judicial measures which the UK Government has already opted out of in 2014, UKIP will always vote to repeal EU laws. The only people that should create laws are democratically elected and accountable national governments, not unelected bureaucrats in Brussels.

name: Nicolas Bay (ENF)
text: In writing. I abstained on this text, which does not change anything: it is simply a matter of repealing acts that have become obsolete, either because they were temporary or because their content has been taken up in subsequent acts. These acts focused on police and judicial cooperation... Brussels refuses to strengthen in a sustainable way.

name: Hugues Bayet (S&D)
text: In writing. I have approved this report which aims to remove provisions in the area of judicial or police cooperation in criminal matters that are outdated or have been replaced by other more recent texts.

name: Izaskun Bilbao Barandica (ALDE)
text: in writing. I voted in favour of this report in the context of the expiry of the transitional period set out in Protocol No 36 on Schengen acquis assessment and legal instruments as a number of acts have been detected have become obsolete. On the basis of "legislating major" I voted in favour. Cooperation in the field of police and judicial matters in criminal matters must be well defined and covered in the acquis communautaire

name: Dominique Bilde (ENF)
text: In writing. On the face of it, police cooperation and judicial cooperation in criminal matters are relevant ideas, especially in the climate of insecurity that has been europe's in recent years. The repeal of obsolete acts in this area therefore seems to be an issue of efficiency. While I am in favour of this type of cooperation between Member States, I have had to abstain on this text which threatens the sovereignty of our nations by the temptation to federalise essential security powers. It should be remembered that police and judicial cooperation are never as effective as when they are maintained by sovereign states, which both have proximity, knowledge of the field and also a capacity of intermediary that supranational organisations do not have; thus, in the case of the terrorists responsible for the attacks in Paris, it was operational intelligence, coupled with information provided by Moroccan services, that enabled Abaaoud to be neutralized. The notorious failure of federal Europe in all areas, particularly in the area of security, has therefore led me to abstain on this text, which, as is often the case, was based on a good intention to make legal compliance.

name: Mara Bizzotto (ENF)
text: in writing. \u2012 The Moraes report analyses the repeal of certain acts in the field of police cooperation and judicial cooperation in criminal matters. It is a purely technical text which aims to update the existing legislation and harmonise it.  Having noted that the recent attacks in Paris have definitively demonstrated the failure of the Schengen system, I would have preferred more decisive action to amend the Agreement decisively.  For these reasons, I abstained.

name: José Blanco López (S&D)
text: in writing. Several acts adopted in the field of police and judicial cooperation in criminal matters have become obsolete because their content has been incorporated into successive acts, although they have not been repealed. This is Joint Action 96/610/JHA (directory of counter-terrorism powers), Joint Action 96/699/JHA (chemical drug profile), Joint Action 96/747/JHA (directory) competences in the fight against organised crime), Joint Action 96/750/JHA (combating drug addiction and trafficking), Joint Action 97/339/JHA (cooperation in the field of drug trafficking) Security and public policy), Joint Action 97/372/JHA (cooperation between customs authorities), Council Act 98/C 216/01 and Convention of 17 June 1998 (deprivation of the right to drive), Joint Action 98/427/JHA (good practices of judicial assistance in criminal matters), and Framework Decision 2008/978/JHA (European exhortation for evidence).  That is why I voted in favour of its repeal

name: Vilija Blinkevičiūtė (S&D)
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of this report, which supports the repeal of certain legislation in relation to police cooperation and judicial cooperation in criminal matters.  On the basis of the verification carried out and in accordance with the obligations of the Interinstitutional Agreement on better law-making and the provisions of the regulatory quality policy, the Commission has submitted a proposal to repeal the seven Council Joint Actions, the content of which has been transposed into subsequent acts, and Council Act 1999/C 26/07 laying down europol staff Staff Regulations. The latter applies only to a very limited number of employment contracts concluded before the adoption of Council Decision 2009/371/JHA on Europol. Only a few such contracts remain in force and will soon expire. The European Parliament's report also contains amendments to improve the drafting of legislation, amendments explaining the UK's position on its decision under Article 10(4) of Protocol No 36, and a new recital underpinning the use of the Regulation as a legal instrument to repeal certain legal acts, the legal basis of which requires a directive following the entry into force of the Treaty of Lisbon.

name: Andrea Bocskor (PPE)
text: Writing. \u2012 Improving the transparency of EU law is an essential element of the better law-improving strategy, which is being implemented by the EU institutions. In this context, it is appropriate to repeal from the legislation in force those which no longer serve any purpose. Many of the acts adopted in the field of police and judicial cooperation in criminal matters are no longer relevant, either because of their temporary nature or because their content has been adopted by subsequent acts. In the light of the above, I voted in favour of this report.

name: Franc Bogovič (PPE)
text: Writing. I also supported the proposed report because, like the previous two, it repeals acts which have become meaningless for various reasons. The report repeals various acts and measures on transnational cooperation in areas such as the fight against terrorism, chemical drug profiling, the fight against organised crime, the fight against drug and trafficking, cooperation in the field of law and order and security, cooperation between customs authorities, etc. As in the previous two reports, this is also about the repeal of acts in the area of the Schengen acquis which were either of a temporary nature or were replaced by new acts.

name: Marie-Christine Boutonnet (ENF)
text: In writing. This is the repeal of acts adopted in the field of police cooperation and judicial cooperation in criminal matters, but unrelated to the Schengen acquis. Even though I am not opposed to police and judicial cooperation between Member States, I remain committed to national sovereignty and do not want the federalisation of these powers.

name: Renata Briano (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 This act allows us to repeal two additional acts to the Schengen Convention: the Convention of 17 June 1998 on the withdrawal of driving licences (Council Act 98/C 216/01) and Council Framework Decision 2008/978/JHA on the European mandate for the search for evidence for the acquisition of objects, documents and data to be used in criminal proceedings (MER), which are now largely outwe overcome by the facts and Directive 2014/41/EU of the European Parliament and of the Council on the European Criminal Investigation Order (OEIP). Since MER would remain applicable only between two Member States, it has lost its value as an instrument of cooperation in criminal matters and should be repealed to ensure the linearity of criminal law, subject to a transitional provision providing that Council Framework Decision 2008/978/JHA will continue to apply to MER issued before the transposition of the OEIP Directive until the criminal proceedings for which they have been issued have been concluded by a final decision.

name: Steeve Briois (ENF)
text: In writing. A number of acts in the area of police and judicial cooperation are no longer relevant because of their temporary nature or because their content has been included in subsequent acts. In the interests of transparency, this report recommends repealing them in particular in order to lighten and simplify the current legislation.  These repeals make sense and we believe that it would not be at all appropriate to maintain these acts as they stand. Although we are not opposed to balanced police and judicial cooperation between Member States, particularly in order to combat Islamist fundamentalism, a real scourge of the 21st century, we believe that this proposal is akin to a federalisation of criminal powers.  Resolutely committed to national sovereignty, I abstained on this text.

name: Daniel Buda (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 European legislation must constantly adapt to the new realities evolving on the union territory, in order to serve as faithfully as possible the citizens it protects. This adaptation requires, at all times, active monitoring of the evolution and application of legislation in the territory, and that is precisely what the Commission has set out to do, namely, to carry out an assessment of the Schengen acquis and legal instruments in the field of police cooperation and judicial cooperation in criminal matters. Proposals to repeal seven actions put forward by the Commission, together with the rapporteur's two proposals on the repeal of two other normative acts and a good determination of the seat of the matter in Europol legislation are the result of thorough analysis and are the right steps by which we can achieve greater legislative clarity and legal certainty. I voted in favour of this report because I believe that all the proposed measures are the appropriate means to achieve transparency of European Union law and to provide European citizens with normative acts that have practical correspondence in judicial instruments.

name: Gianluca Buonanno (ENF)
text: in writing. \u2012 These three reports signed by mep Moraes respond to the need to update the rules in force by repealing a number of acts forming part of the Schengen acquis. These legislative texts are no longer relevant because of their temporary nature or because their content has been taken up in subsequent acts which, however, have not repealed them. On the substance, this can be assessed as a positive measure, but also in view of the developments taking place, especially in recent months, and the firm will on the part of our delegation to completely review the Schengen Agreement, I voted against it. On schengen policies, we cannot just update them, but we need a complete reform.

name: Nicola Caputo (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted today in favour of the report on the proposal for a regulation of the European Parliament and of the Council on the repeal of certain acts in the field of police cooperation and judicial cooperation in criminal matters. There are many acts contained in the Schengen acquis concerning police and judicial cooperation in criminal matters, which today have no function and no longer have any connection with the other rules. Although they have not yet been repealed, they remain unenforceable, because their content has been poured into successive and more recent rules. For example, decisions improving the practice of judicial cooperation in the fight against drug trafficking have become obsolete due to the entry into force of successive rules, specifically concerning judicial assistance in criminal matters between Member States. This text proposes repeals of outdated rules, which is why I have chosen to vote in favour of its acceptance.

name: Matt Carthy (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of this technical report, which identifies acts that are no longer relevant because of their temporary nature or because their context has been taken up by successive acts. Between this vote and two other votes repealing acts part of other policy cooperation matters, there are 20 legal measures to be repealed. Many of these are due to the fact that the Lisbon Treaty amended the way EU countries dealt with police cooperation. Therefore the acts to be repealed no longer apply.

name: James Carver (EFDD)
text: in writing. ‒ Although the measures to repeal old EU legislation only covers police and judicial measures which the UK Government has already opted out of in 2014, UKIP will always vote to repeal EU laws. The only people that should create laws are democratically elected and accountable national governments, not unelected bureaucrats in Brussels.

name: David Casa (PPE)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of this report because the removal of the obsolete acts will make our legislation more efficient and effective and will improve transparency and help in combating crime.

name: Fabio Massimo Castaldo (EFDD)
text: in writing. \u2012 The vote concerns the repeal of acts linked to the old institutional framework as part of the expiry of the transitional period under Protocol 36 on transitional arrangements (annexed to the Treaty of Lisbon). In particular, this is a Convention and a framework decision in the field of police cooperation and criminal judicial cooperation. I voted in favour.

name: Λευτέρης Χριστοφόρου (
text: PPE), in writing. \u2012 Certain acts adopted in the field of police and judicial cooperation in criminal matters, even if they have not been repealed, have become obsolete as their content has been incorporated into subsequent acts. In view of the European Commission's proposal and acting in accordance with the ordinary legislative procedure, we support it positively.

name: Salvatore Cicu (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the measure. In the Interinstitutional Agreement of 16 December 2003, the European Parliament, the Council and the Commission agreed on the need to reduce the volume of the Union's body of legislation and simplify it, including through the repeal of obsolete acts.  On the basis of its examination, in line with the commitments contained in the Interinstitutional Agreement and its policy on regulatory adequacy, the Commission has presented a proposal to repeal seven Council joint actions, the content of which has been incorporated in subsequent acts and of Council Act 1999/C 26/07 establishing the Staff Regulations applicable to Europol employees.  The European Parliament is presenting amendments to repeal two additional acts, which have also become obsolete: the Council Convention of 17 June 1998 on the withdrawal of driving licences and Council Act 98/C 216/01 and Council Framework Decision 2008/978/JHA on the European mandate for the search for evidence for the acquisition of objects, documents and data for use in criminal proceedings (MER).

name: Alberto Cirio (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 The Council's Joint Action established a directory of specialist expertise, skills and knowledge in the field of counter-terrorism in order to make them more widely and promptly available to the services of all Member States, which became obsolete when Europol was given the task of supporting and strengthening mutual cooperation between the law enforcement authorities of the Member States. I voted in favour of this proposal in order to avoid overlapping the competences of Europol with those of the existing bodies.

name: David Coburn (EFDD)
text: in writing. ‒ Although the measures to repeal old EU legislation only covers police and judicial measures which the UK Government has already opted out of in 2014, UKIP will always vote to repeal EU laws. The only people that should create laws are democratically elected and accountable national governments, not unelected bureaucrats in Brussels.

name: Carlos Coelho (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 The instruments of the so-called Area of Freedom, Security and Justice, in particular with regard to the Schengen acquis, were initially incorporated by the Treaty of Amsterdam into the Legal Order of the Union. Progressively, many have been updated, reformulated, strengthened and, in some cases, simply become obsolete. This Regulation ensures the repeal of these acts and ensures that, in certain cases, a transitional period is ensured.

name: Jane Collins (EFDD)
text: in writing. – Although the measures to repeal old EU legislation only covers police and judicial measures which the UK Government has already opted out of in 2014, UKIP will always vote to repeal EU laws. The only people that should create laws are democratically elected and accountable national governments, not unelected bureaucrats in Brussels.

name: Lara Comi (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 One of the objectives of the European Union's strategy is to simplify legislation on Community legislative acts. In order to effectively lighten the volume of Community legislation, it is appropriate to eliminate acts whose content has been taken up by successive legislation, the so-called obsolete acts. In particular, this report highlights the usefulness of repealing certain acts on police cooperation and judicial cooperation in criminal matters.  In this context, seven Council actions have become obsolete: they concern customs control, judicial assistance in criminal matters, the European mandate for the acquisition of evidence for use in criminal proceedings, and the fight against terrorism, organised crime and drug trafficking. More recent legislation has been adopted for these policies and I therefore support the proposal to repeal previous ones, thereby lightening Community legislation and contributing to greater transparency and clarity in European law.

name: Therese Comodini Cachia (PPE)
text: in writing. ‒ A number of acts that include driving disqualifications, the European evidence warrant and establishing minimum rules concerning the definition of criminal offences and sanctions have become obsolete either because they have been changed by other laws or never came into effect. The Commission’s proposal to repeal legislative acts which are no longer applicable helps to improve transparency and legal certainty for citizens. I voted in favour.

name: Ignazio Corrao (EFDD)
text: in writing. \u2012 As part of the expiry of the transitional period provided for in Protocol 36 on transitional provisions annexed to the Treaties, the Commission carried out an assessment of the Schengen acquis and legal instruments in the field of police and judicial cooperation in criminal matters. A number of acts have been identified as obsolete because their content has been taken up by subsequent acts or because they were temporary in nature. In the Interinstitutional Agreement of 16 December 2003, Parliament, the Council and the Commission agreed on the reduction of the volume and simplification of Union law, including through the repeal of obsolete acts, such as: 1) the Convention of 17 June 1998 on driving licences and Council Act 98 / C 216/01; (2) Framework Decision 2008/978/JHA on the European Mandate for the Acquisition of Objects, Documents and Data for Use in Criminal Proceedings (MER) replaced by Directive 2014/41/EU on the European Criminal Investigation Order (OEI). As they are really obsolete, I think it is appropriate to vote in favour of it.

name: Javier Couso Permuy (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. I voted in favour of this report to repeal certain acts in the field of police and judicial cooperation in criminal matters, as the acts in question were obsolete and did not apply because of the new regulatory framework that appeared after the Lisbon Treaty. Despite our opposition to it, there would be no point in voting otherwise and maintaining unapplicable regulations.

name: Pál Csáky (PPE)
text: Writing. \u2012 The European Commission has carried out an analysis of the Schengen acquis and the existing legal instruments in the field of police and judicial cooperation in criminal matters. The Commission concludes that a number of acts are outdated either because their content has been taken over by subsequent acts or because they were inherently provisional in nature.  On the basis of its due diligence, the Commission has put forward a proposal to repeal the seven Joint Actions of the Council, the content of which was adopted by subsequent acts, and the Council act establishing a Staff Regulations for Europol staff. I voted in favour of this report, which supports the repeal of outdated acts, because it contributes to the numerical reduction and simplification of EU legislation.

name: Edward Czesak (ECR)
text: I would like to write to the Commission. \u2012 The draft regulation of the European Parliament and of the Council repealing certain legal acts in the field of police cooperation and judicial cooperation in criminal matters is another document aimed at eliminating unnecessary regulations and outdated legal acts from the European legal system. With the entry into force of the Convention on Assistance in Criminal Matters between Member States and the 2009 Council Decision establishing the European Police Office (Europol), some of this matter has been fully standardised, forgetting the derogation of the provisions previously in force. The adoption of the Regulation will have a positive impact on the organisation and transparency of current procedures for cross-border police cooperation and justice. In addition to eliminating dead and outdated rules, the Commission has proposed to repeal the Council Framework Decision on the EEW, arguing that it has lost its usefulness as it currently applies only between two EU Member States. It seems to me justified to take such a pragmatic approach to the subject of removing from the legal system acts no longer for any purpose. As a supporter of reducing the number of EU law provisions and simplifying them without hesitation, I supported the draft regulation.

name: Miriam Dalli (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of this report as it focuses on the repeal of certain acts within the field of policy cooperation and judicial cooperation in criminal matters which are no longer relevant to European legislation. The repeal of these acts is not politically motivated and comes as part of the Commission’s policy on regulatory fitness, which aims at keeping EU legislation simple and relevant.

name: Daniel Dalton (ECR)
text: in writing. ‒ This REFIT proposal relates to certain provisions of the Schengen acquis, to which the United Kingdom does not subscribe. As such, the UK will not be bound by this. Therefore, whilst I welcome the repeal of this obsolete measure, as previously on justice and home affairs matters which do not pertain to the UK, I decided to abstain.

name: Michel Dantin (PPE)
text: In writing. This legislative report proposes to repeal some outdated acts in the area of judicial and police cooperation in crime. These acts relate to joint actions, the Convention on the Forfeiture of the Right to Drive and the European Mandate for Evidence. It also recommends changing the legal nature of the Commission's proposal from a decision to an EU regulation, which is considered more appropriate to ensure the immediate and complete repeal of these acts in all Member States.  Supporting these objectives and technical changes, I voted in favour of the report.

name: Rachida Dati (PPE)
text: In writing. As these acts have become obsolete, I support this measure as it contributes to greater clarity of European legislation in the area of police and judicial cooperation in criminal matters.

name: Ian Duncan (ECR)
text: in writing. ‒ These REFIT proposals relate to certain provisions of the Schengen acquis, to which the UK does not subscribe. As such, the UK will not be bound by them. Therefore, whilst I welcome the repeal of obsolete measures, in accordance with our long-standing position on JHA matters which do not pertain to the UK, I will abstain.

name: Ангел Джамбазки (ECR)
text: in writing. \u2012 This report is part of the European Commission's REFIT programme, which aims to repeal European legislative instruments that are no longer valid for Member States. After an evaluation of the acts in the field of police and judicial cooperation, the Ec established several instruments of a temporary nature or the content of which is reflected in follow-up texts. On the basis of its review and in line with its commitments in the Interinstitutional Agreement on Better Law-Making and its regulatory fitness policy, the Commission has submitted a proposal to repeal 7 joint Council actions, the content of which is reflected in follow-up acts, and Council Act 1999/C 26/07 laying down staff regulations applicable to persons employed at Europol. The latter act applies only to a very limited number of employment contracts concluded before the adoption of Council Decision 2009/371/JHA on Europol. Only a few such contracts are still in force and their effects will expire soon. I supported their repeal because I believe that a reduction in volume and simplification of Union law is necessary, including by repealing obsolete acts.

name: Γεώργιος Επιτήδειος (
text: NI), in writing. \u2012 Concerns the abolition, as obsolete, of 7 joint actions, 1 act and 1 framework decision on matters relating to police and judicial cooperation between Member States. For these, and only, this Regulation best serves the purposes of the proposal, which is the abolition of obsolete acts.

name: Bill Etheridge (EFDD)
text: in writing. – Although the measures to repeal old EU legislation only covers police and judicial measures which the UK Government has already opted out of in 2014, UKIP will always vote to repeal EU laws. The only people that should create laws are democratically elected and accountable national governments, not unelected bureaucrats in Brussels.

name: José Manuel Fernandes (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 This report reports on the results of the evaluation of the Schengen acquis and legal instruments in the field of police cooperation and judicial cooperation in criminal matters. Several acts were considered obsolete either because of the integration of their content into subsequent acts or because of their temporary nature. The proposal in question proposes the repeal of the seven Council joint actions, the content of which has been taken up in subsequent acts and the Council Act 1999/C 26/07 approving the Staff Regulations of Europol. This last act of the Council applies to a very limited number of employment contracts and will soon expire. There is also the proposal to repeal the Convention of 17 June 1998 on Driving Disqualification Decisions and Council Act 98/C 216/01 and Council Framework Decision 2008/978/JAI on the European Warrant for obtaining objects, documents and data for use in criminal proceedings (MEOP). I agree with the suggested repeals.

name: Edouard Ferrand (ENF)
text: In writing. I abstained on this vote because the reference text is a federalist text that I do not recognize.

name: João Ferreira (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. \u2012 The Committee on Freedoms of the European Parliament has decided to frame this report in the Simplified Procedure – Article 50(2) of the Rules of Procedure. The report includes a set of three on the repeal of acts in the field of police cooperation and judicial cooperation in criminal matters and acts of the Schengen acquis. Several acts belonging to the Schengen acquis are no longer relevant because of their temporary nature or because their content was taken up by subsequent acts, although they have not been repealed, making them considered obsolete. This report is therefore of an eminently technical nature. The fact is that, in practical terms, between obsolete acts and those that replace them there are no substantive improvements, so, despite the above, we reaffirm our substantive critical position on Schengen and its acquis. And, as well, with regard to police cooperation and judicial cooperation in criminal matters. These are areas for which we have been critical of the EU's approach and attempts at federal deepening, with increased limitations on member states' decision-making capacity in areas that go to the heart of state sovereignty.

name: Lorenzo Fontana (ENF)
text: in writing. \u2012 The vote on these three reports will be against as there is no need to revise Schengen but to reform it completely.

name: Λάμπρος Φουντούλης (
text: NI), in writing. \u2012 I am voting in favour of this report as this Regulation best serves the purposes of the proposal, which is the abolition of obsolete acts.

name: Doru-Claudian Frunzulică (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ In the context of the expiry of the transitional period set out in Protocol 36 on transitional provisions annexed to the Treaties, the Commission has performed an assessment of the Schengen acquis and of the legal instruments in the field of police cooperation and judicial cooperation in criminal matters. A number of acts have been identified as obsolete because their content has been taken up by subsequent acts or because they are of a temporary nature. In the Inter-institutional Agreement of 16 December 2003, Parliament, the Council and the Commission agreed on reducing the volume of, and simplifying, Union law, including by means of repealing obsolete acts. On the basis of its screening and in line with the commitments in the inter-institutional agreement on better law-making and the its policy on Regulatory Fitness, the Commission submitted a proposal to repeals seven Council Joint Actions whose content has been taken up in successive acts, and Council Act 1999/C 26/07 laying down the staff regulations applicable to Europol employees. The latter applies only to very limited number of employment contracts concluded before the adoption of Council Decision 2009/371/JHA on Europol. Only few such contracts are still in force and they will soon come to an end.

name: Kinga Gál (PPE)
text: in writing. ‒ We from the Fidesz party (EPP Group) voted in favour of this report on the proposal for a regulation of the European Parliament and of the Council repealing certain acts in the field of police cooperation and judicial cooperation in criminal matters. The Committee on Civil Liberties, Justice and Home Affairs recommended that the position of the European Parliament adopted at first reading under the ordinary legislative procedure should amend the Commission proposal. Among other things, we introduced a transitional provision stipulating that any European evidence warrant executed under Framework Decision 2008/978/JHA shall continue to be governed by that instrument until the relevant criminal proceedings have been concluded with a definitive decision. The new text will improve the drafting of the act, clarifying the position of the UK in view of its decision in accordance with Article 10(4) of Protocol 36 and the use of a regulation as a legal instrument for repealing certain acts whose legal basis after the Lisbon Treaty requires adoption of a directive.

name: Ildikó Gáll-Pelcz (PPE)
text: Writing. \u2012 In order to ensure legal certainty and clarity, I agree with the priorities set out in the report.  In accordance with the amendments proposed by the Council in its general approach and adopted by the Commission, and after consulting the Legal Service of the European Parliament, the rapporteur will table amendments to repeal the outdated act relating to the 17 June 1998 Convention on Driving Disqualification and Council Act 98/C 216/01. This is an important issue for the reason that the entry into force of the Convention requires its reinforcement by all 15 signatory Member States. However, the Convention has only been ratified by seven Member States and has never entered into force. It has therefore lost its relevance to EU legislation and should therefore be repealed.

name: Francesc Gambús (PPE)
text: in writing. I voted in favour of the finding that these instruments are no longer applicable to any Member State, have lost their relevance in EU law and should be repealed.

name: Arne Gericke (ECR)
text: Writing. I voted today in favour of the report on the repeal of certain pieces of legislation in the field of police and judicial cooperation in criminal matters, as I believe that the further development and updating of the Schengen Agreement is essential at this very time.

name: Jens Gieseke (PPE)
text: Writing. Some of the pieces of legislation under the Schengen acquis in the field of police and judicial cooperation are outdated or out of date. Either their content has been revisited in other legal acts, or they are limited in time. That is why the Commission's proposal to repeal these acts is correct. It improves the clarity of existing rules.

name: Neena Gill (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of this report, which aims to revoke measures that are no longer relevant because of their temporary nature or because their content has been taken up by successive acts.

name: Juan Carlos Girauta Vidal (ALDE)
text: in writing. A number of acts adopted in the field of police and judicial cooperation in criminal matters have become obsolete because their content has been incorporated into successive acts, although they have not been repealed. For reasons of legal certainty and clarity, such outdated legal instruments should be repealed.

name: Tania González Peñas (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. This repeal is exempt from political content and is simply about the overcoming, through successive acts, of certain regulations, which are therefore exceeded or contained in others. That's why we voted in favour.

name: Theresa Griffin (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted for this proposal. Improving the transparency of Union law is an essential element of the better law-making strategy that the institutions of the Union are implementing. In that context it is appropriate to remove from the legislation in force those acts which no longer serve any purpose. A number of acts adopted in the field of police cooperation and judicial cooperation in criminal matters have become obsolete because their content has been taken up by successive acts, even though they have not been repealed.

name: Françoise Grossetête (PPE)
text: In writing. On Tuesday 24 November, I voted in favour of three reports aimed at repealing certain acts of the Schengen acquis. These texts aim to undo a number of legal measures related to the area of freedom, security and justice, as well as legal provisions in the field of police and judicial cooperation in criminal matters, which have become obsolete.  The acts here repealed are no longer relevant because of their temporary nature or because their content has been included in subsequent acts. The aim here is to be consistent and to improve the transparency of EU law in order to better legislate in the interests of European citizens.

name: Antanas Guoga (ALDE)
text: in writing. ‒ I have voted for the report on the proposal for a regulation of the European Parliament and of the Council repealing certain acts in the field of police cooperation and judicial cooperation in criminal matters because it is appropriate to remove from the legislation in force those acts which no longer serve any purpose for legal certainty and clarity.

name: Τάκης Χατζηγεωργίου (GUE/NGL)
text: Writing. Given the technical nature of this 'clearance' procedure, which also contributes to legal clarity, we are voting in favour of the report.

name: Brian Hayes (PPE)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted for this report because a number of acts have been identified as obsolete due to their content being taken up by successive acts or due to the fact that they are temporary in nature. The report will in turn improve the drafting of the act with several of the amendments it contains. Simplifying and reducing the volume of European Union law will lead to more clarity and efficiency throughout the EU.

name: Roger Helmer (EFDD)
text: in writing. ‒ Although the measures to repeal old EU legislation only covers police and judicial measures which the UK Government has already opted out of in 2014, UKIP will always vote to repeal EU laws. The only people that should create laws are democratically elected and accountable national governments, not unelected bureaucrats in Brussels.

name: Brice Hortefeux (PPE)
text: In writing. I supported the proposal to repeal the Schengen acquis in the area of police and judicial cooperation in criminal matters, which have become obsolete because of their temporary nature or because their content has been taken up in subsequent acts. It is absolutely not a question of questioning what works in Schengen, but of simplifying the European regulations, which I have often deplored as cumbersome and incongruised. This vote, however, allows me to renew my call for realism. My party has long called for an overhaul of Schengen to adapt to new realities and threats that are breaking free of national borders.  The urgent need is for tighter control of external borders and systematic control of third-country nationals, as well as European citizens.

name: Ivan Jakovčić (ALDE)
text: Written. ‒ I voted for the European Parliament's draft legislative resolution on the proposal for a regulation by Parliament and the Council to repeal certain acts in the area of police and judicial cooperation in criminal matters in order to ensure clarity and certainty of rights. In this context, I support the procedure for repealing those acts that are outdated, i.e. whose content is present in the new acts or whose validity is limited. In my view, the transparency of EU law benefits all citizens, but also the competent authorities concerned, fostering the certainty and credibility of the acquis, and raising the level of consistency of the Union.

name: Jean-François Jalkh (ENF)
text: In writing. This text repeals obsolete acts that are not related to the Schengen acquis.  Again, legal clarification by repealing outdated or duplicate acts with other legal texts is a good thing. However, we cannot support the federalization of jurisdiction, particularly in the areas of police and judicial cooperation in criminal matters.  I abstained.

name: Diane James (EFDD)
text: in writing. – Although the measures to repeal old EU legislation only covers police and judicial measures which the UK Government has already opted out of in 2014, UKIP will always vote to repeal EU laws. The only people that should create laws are democratically elected and accountable national governments, not unelected bureaucrats in Brussels.

name: Petr Ježek (ALDE)
text: Writing. \u2012 The Commission's proposal to repeal certain parts of EU legislative acts was supported by an overwhelming majority of Members, including me. This is merely a legal update, with the eliminated of several temporary measures and legislative acts that have expired. The aim of this update is to make european Union law more clear.

name: Marc Joulaud (PPE)
text: In writing. I voted in favour of my colleague Claude Moraes' report on the repeal of certain acts in the field of police and judicial cooperation in criminal matters.  Indeed, certain acts of police and judicial cooperation in criminal matters were temporary in nature or were included in other acts after the fact. It was therefore useful to repeal them in order to clarify and simplify the acts.   This report was adopted by a large majority, which I welcome.

name: Philippe Juvin (PPE)
text: In writing. I voted in favour of this report because it allows the repeal of obsolete acts of police and judicial cooperation. The aim was to improve transparency, clarity and to be consistent in order to improve European legislation.

name: Barbara Kappel (ENF)
text: Writing. This report concerns the repeal of certain acts in the field of police and judicial cooperation in criminal matters. These are technical changes, as these acts are now considered obsolete. I am abstaining from voting on the basis of fundamental considerations on the Schengen Agreement.

name: Afzal Khan (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ These acts are no longer relevant because of their temporary nature or because their content has been taken up by successive acts. Therefore, for reasons of legal certainty and in order to bring acts in the area of freedom, security and justice in line with the Lisbon Treaty, I voted in favour of repealing these acts.

name: Bernd Kölmel (ECR)
text: Writing. In three decisions, the Commission proposed to repeal acts belonging to the Schengen acquis either for a limited period of time or for their content to be incorporated into subsequent legal acts. The aim is to achieve better regulation by achieving greater transparency of Union law. In this context, the rapporteur, Claude Moraes, believes that it is appropriate to remove from the existing acquis acts that are no longer of use. According to the Commission, this is to be achieved by means of three decisions. Unlike the Commission, the rapporteur recommends changing the nature of the act from a decision to a regulation. After consulting the European Parliament's Legal Service, Claude Moraes has also identified two other obsolete acts which are part of the Schengen acquis and are no longer relevant because they were temporary or were incorporated into subsequent legal acts. The ECR supports the REFIT programme in the sense of de-bureaucratisation and has also voted in the LIBE Committee for the repeal of outdated legislation. The ALFA is in favour of legal certainty and clarity. The measures proposed in the reports are likely to reduce EU legislation and simplify Union law. I strongly support these concerns and have therefore voted in favour of the report.

name: Giovanni La Via (PPE)
text: in writing. On the basis of the commitments under the Interinstitutional Agreement on the Better Lawmaking Programme, the rapporteur has made a number of amendments to repeal the Council Framework Decision on the European Evidence Warrant for the Acquisition of Objects, Documents and Data for Use in Criminal Proceedings (MER); the Convention of 17 June 1998 on the withdrawal of driving licences; delete the reference to Council Act 1999/C 26/07 of 3 December 1998 laying down the Staff Regulations applicable to Europol employees.  Since these acts are obsolete, because they are taken up in subsequent acts or because of their temporary nature, I have decided to give my support.

name: Constance Le Grip (PPE)
text: In writing. I approved the report on the proposed regulation of the European Parliament and the Council repealing certain acts in the area of police and judicial cooperation in criminal matters that have become obsolete. In order to improve the wording of the act, we have also tabled amendments to clarify the POSITION of the United Kingdom and justify the use of a regulation for the repeal of certain legal acts. Furthermore, the Republicans and I call for a profound overhaul of the Schengen Agreements, which are inappropriate in their current form and functioning to the reality of the threats that the countries of the Union now face.

name: Marine Le Pen (ENF)
text: In writing. A number of acts in the area of police and judicial cooperation in criminal matters are no longer relevant because of their temporary nature or because their content has been included in subsequent acts.  In the interests of transparency and "better legislation," they must be repealed. However, recent events demonstrate once again that police and judicial cooperation at EU level is lacking. The police services of Member States must cooperate, but I oppose any attempt to communitize security policy. That is why I abstained on the proposal to repeal certain acts.

name: Paloma López Bermejo (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. I voted in favour of this report to repeal certain acts in the field of police and judicial cooperation in criminal matters, as the acts in question were obsolete and did not apply because of the new regulatory framework that appeared after the Lisbon Treaty. Despite our opposition to it, there would be no point in voting otherwise and maintaining unapplicable regulations.

name: Bernd Lucke (ECR)
text: Writing. In three decisions, the Commission proposed to repeal acts belonging to the Schengen acquis either for a limited period of time or for their content to be incorporated into subsequent legal acts. The aim is to achieve better regulation by achieving greater transparency of Union law. In this context, the rapporteur, Claude Moraes, believes that it is appropriate to remove from the existing acquis acts that are no longer of use. According to the Commission, this is to be achieved by means of three decisions. Unlike the Commission, the rapporteur recommends changing the nature of the act from a decision to a regulation. After consulting the European Parliament's Legal Service, Claude Moraes has also identified two other obsolete acts which are part of the Schengen acquis and are no longer relevant because they were temporary or were incorporated into subsequent legal acts. The ECR supports the REFIT programme in the sense of de-bureaucratisation and has also voted in the LIBE Committee for the repeal of outdated legal acts. The ALFA is in favour of legal certainty and clarity. The measures proposed in the reports are likely to reduce EU legislation and simplify Union law. I strongly support these concerns and have therefore voted in favour of the report.

name: Ivana Maletić (PPE)
text: Written. ‒ Interinstitutional Agreement 16 December 2003 The European Parliament, the Council and the Commission have agreed to reduce and simplify the laws, with the abolition of the obsolete. Accordingly, the Commission reviewed the Schengen acquis and legal instruments in the area of police and judicial cooperation in criminal matters, and found that a number of acts were outdated.  The Commission submitted a proposal to abolish: • 7 Councils of Joint Action • Council Act 1999/C 26/07, And the Convention on Disqualification of Driving • Council Framework Decisions 2008/978/PUP on the European Evidentiary Order I supported the report of Claude Moraes MP, because I believe that the abolition of outdated regulations in the field of police and judicial cooperation is necessary, in order to make the rules as clear and transparent as possible, as this makes citizens' trust in the justice system greater.

name: Andrejs
text: Mamikins (S&D), in writing. \u2012 This Regulation concerned the repeal of legislation, the age of which in some cases exceeded almost 19 years.  I would like to note, however, one thing that politicians, experts and the general public have been very active in the last week and a half. Although this Regulation abolished the same joint action on the directory of counter-terrorism knowledge, as there is a more modern version of the cooperation-specific act, it is likely that, in the context of mass killings in Paris, over the Sinai Peninsula, In Africa, Syria and Iraq and elsewhere in the world, those relating to cooperation between the relevant authorities of the Member States and the Member States as a whole are clearly obsolete or simply ineffective in terms of counter-terrorism. Even if it were assumed that this legislation is still relevant from a legislative point of view, what has happened in Paris suggests that this is not the case at all from the point of view of practicality. Although it is not part of the issues examined today, it is worth noting that there are quite a few things among European Union legislation that, being obsolete, never fully entered into force, have been functionally replaced with others long enough, etc. Of course, given the complexity of our community governance structure, every piece of legislation that is to be repealed must not be given close attention, so that no problems of any kind arise.

name: Vladimír Maňka (S&D)
text: Writing. \u2012 Due to their temporary nature or obsolescence, certain acts in the field of chemical profiling of drugs, the list of capabilities to combat organised crime, the fight against drug addiction and drug trafficking, cooperation in the field of law, order and safety, cooperation between customs authorities, driving bans, good practice in the field of mutual legal assistance in criminal matters and the European evidence-gathering order are abolished.

name: Νότης Μαριάς (
text: ECR), in writing. \u2012 I am voting in favour of the report on the proposal for a regulation of the European Parliament and of the Council on the repeal of certain acts in the field of police cooperation and judicial cooperation in criminal matters.

name: Dominique Martin (ENF)
text: In writing. I abstained on this vote. These are acts adopted in the field of police and judicial cooperation in criminal matters, acts unrelated to the Schengen acquis.  We do not oppose police and judicial cooperation between Member States, quite the contrary, but the decision to cooperate must come from the Member States themselves. We defend national sovereignty, and we do not want those powers to be federalized.

name: David Martin (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ Improving the transparency of Union law is an essential element of the better law-making strategy that the institutions of the Union are implementing. In that context it is appropriate to remove from the legislation in force those acts which no longer serve any purpose. A number of acts adopted in the field of police cooperation and judicial cooperation in criminal matters have become obsolete because their content has been taken up by successive acts, even though they have not been repealed.

name: Fulvio Martusciello (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the report on the repeal of certain acts in the field of police cooperation and judicial cooperation in criminal matters. In the Interinstitutional Agreement of 16 December 2003, the European Parliament, the Council and the Commission agreed on the need to reduce the volume of the body of legislation and simplify it, including through the repeal of obsolete acts. The objective of this Regulation is, in fact, the repeal of these obsolete acts of the Union in the field of police cooperation and judicial cooperation in criminal matters, since their content is taken up in subsequent acts even if they have not been repealed.

name: Georg Mayer (ENF)
text: Writing. The report only shows the current legal situation. Since it does not bring about any change in content, I abstain from my voice.

name: Jean-Luc Mélenchon (GUE/NGL)
text: In writing. In this report, the Commission proposes to repeal a number of legislative acts in the area of police and judicial cooperation in criminal matters that have been rendered obsolete mainly since the integration of the Schengen acquis directly into the European treaties.  Thus 'the Council's joint action 97/339/JAI has enabled cooperation and established information sharing between Member States during large-scale events involving large numbers of people from several Member States, in order to ensure public order and security, to protect people and their property, and to prevent wrongdoing" has been abolished because it has become obsolete since the 2008/615/JAI decisions came into force, 2002/348/JAI and 2007/412/JAI of the Council, which established new rules on the exchange of personal data, other forms of cooperation for the maintenance of public order and security at major events.  Although this is a technical report aimed at 'simplifying' EU law, I am voting against it to disagree with these ineffective measures.

name: Joëlle Mélin (ENF)
text: In writing. This report also aims to repeal obsolete acts; but this time it concerns police and judicial cooperation. The repeal of outdated or duplicated acts with other legal texts allows for effective legal clarification. However, the National Front is not in favour of federalizing criminal powers, challenging the precious state sovereignty in such an area. That is how the member abstains from this issue.

name: Nuno Melo (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 The European Commission has assessed the Schengen acquis and existing legal instruments in the context of judicial and police cooperation in criminal matters, taking into account Protocol No 36 annexed to the Treaties on transitional provisions. In the case of obsolete provisions - either by their exclusively temporary nature or by changing their content by subsequent acts - with a view to simplifying legislation, with gains in legal certainty and certainty, better regulation means the repeal of those acts.  I have therefore voted in favour of the proposal for a regulation of the European Parliament and the Council repealing certain acts in the field of police cooperation and judicial cooperation in criminal matters.

name: Roberta Metsola (PPE)
text: in writing. ‒ I chose to support this regulation as it is important that Parliament continues to strive for the advancement of police and judicial cooperation within the European Union in relation to criminal matters.

name: Miroslav Mikolášik (PPE)
text: Writing. \u2012 The Commission carried out a wide-ranging review of legal acts in the area of police cooperation and judicial cooperation in criminal matters, on the basis of which several acts were marked as obsolete. In view of the agreement between the EU institutions to reduce and simplify Union legislation, transparency and clarity in law-making need to be increased, so I consider it important to repeal obsolete acts the content of which is temporary or taken over in subsequent acts. The proposed Regulation repeals obsolete acts, including, for example, uniform cooperation in counter-terrorism capability, the fight against drug addiction, or cooperation in the field of law, order and security, but individual areas are adequately regulated in subsequent acts.

name: Marlene Mizzi (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ I have voted in favour of the report on repealing certain acts in the field of police cooperation and judicial cooperation in criminal matters. As part of the Commission policy on Regulatory Fitness, this related instrument will repeal a number of legal acts in the field of police and judicial cooperation and a number in relation to the Schengen Acquis. All of the acts to be repealed are no longer legally relevant either because they have been replaced by a more up-to-date legal act or they are of a temporary nature.

name: Csaba Molnár (S&D)
text: Writing. \u2012 In its analysis of the Schengen acquis and police and judicial cooperation in criminal matters referred to in point 1, the Commission found that the Council's seven joint actions were outdated because their content had been adopted by subsequent acts. Furthermore, the Council act establishing a Staff Regulations for Europol staff is outdated because it applies only to a very limited number of employment contracts concluded before the adoption of Council Decision 2009/371/IB on Europol, and very few such contracts are currently in force and their scope is about to expire. In its report, the Committee on Civil Liberties, Justice and Home Affairs recommended the draft to Parliament for adoption, by proposing to repeal the Convention of 17 June 1998 on driving disqualification and Council Act 98/C 216/01 and Council Framework Decision 2008/978/IB on a European warrant for the taking of evidence for the purposes of obtaining objects, documents and data to be used in criminal proceedings. The former no longer applies to any Member State and has therefore lost its relevance to EU legislation, and the latter has been replaced by Directive 2014/41/EU of the European Parliament and of the Council on a European Investigation Decision in criminal matters. Finally, the report recommends improving the wording of the legislation and the insertion of a new recital. I supported the draft.

name: Bernard Monot (ENF)
text: In writing. These are acts adopted in the field of police cooperation and judicial cooperation in criminal matters, but unrelated to the Schengen acquis. Even if we are not opposed to police and judicial cooperation between Member States, we remain committed to national sovereignty and we do not want the federalisation of these powers, which is why we abstain.

name: Cláudia Monteiro de Aguiar (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 In the field of police cooperation and judicial cooperation in criminal matters, certain legal acts which no longer have their effects should be repealed, thereby promoting the Better Regulation strategy adopted by the European institutions.   In this context, the content of certain common actions of the Council was taken up by subsequent acts making those acts obsolete. The Convention of 17 June 1998 laid down by Council Act 98/C 216/01 on Driving Disqualification Decisions was ratified only by seven Member States and never entered into force, thus making its repeal clear. In addition, Council Framework Decision 2008/978/JAI on the European Evidence Warrant was replaced by Directive 2014/41/EU of the European Parliament and the Council on the European Research Decision, thereby resuming the matter in question and not using its directive.  I am voting in favour of this proposal for a regulation, which I consider to be a necessary legislative instrument to continue to ensure the legal clarity and certainty of the legislation adopted within the European Union.

name: Sophie Montel (ENF)
text: In writing. This report, like the previous ones, is part of a simplistic process and aims to repeal certain acts that have become less relevant as a result of their subsequent questioning. This time it concerns the area of police and judicial cooperation in criminal matters, but unrelated to the Schengen acquis.  If I am not opposed to the cooperation of the judicial and police authorities of the Member States of the European Union, I remain committed to national sovereignty. I therefore consider that this must be through bilateral agreements and not through Brussels. I have therefore decided to abstain on this report.

name: Nadine Morano (PPE)
text: In writing. I voted in favour of this report on the repeal of certain acts in the area of police and judicial cooperation in criminal matters.  Improving the transparency of EU law is an essential part of the strategy to better legislate, which the EU institutions are currently implementing. Some legal measures are no longer relevant because of their temporary nature or because their content has been incorporated into subsequent acts.  They should therefore be removed from existing legislation.

name: Renaud Muselier (PPE)
text: In writing. I have not been able to vote for this report, but I fully support the position of the EPP Group and the French delegation to adopt this report.  A number of acts adopted in the field of police cooperation and judicial cooperation in criminal matters have become obsolete because their content has been taken up in successive acts. They should therefore be repealed.

name: Victor Negrescu (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ I have voted for this report, which will bring a better drafting of the document through its amendments and will abrogate the following two additional acts that have become obsolete: 1. Convention of 17 June 1998 on Driving Disqualifications and Council Act 98/C 216/01; 2. Council Framework Decision 2008/978/JHA on the European evidence warrant for the purpose of obtaining objects, documents and data for use in proceedings in criminal matters (EEW).

name: Norica Nicolai (ALDE)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of this decision as it is always very important to avoid the doubling or contradiction of legislation. As newer protocols, decisions and directives supplanted most of the outdated documents, we needed to make sure there are no longer any old and contradictory parts regulating important institutions such as Europol.

name: Franz Obermayr (ENF)
text: Writing. The report refers to a Commission proposal for a decision to repeal certain acts in the field of police and judicial cooperation in criminal matters. As this is also a technical report, I abstained from voting here too.

name: Younous Omarjee (GUE/NGL)
text: In writing. The report proposes to approve the repeal of a number of legislative acts relating to police and judicial cooperation in criminal matters between Member States. The regulations concerned here included, among other things, the exchange of personal information between the customs and police authorities of the Member States. However, the Council subsequently adopted new rules on the exchange of personal data, thus rendering the previous provisions obsolete. The simplification of EU law is necessary, so these acts that are no longer relevant should be repealed. I voted in favor.

name: Urmas Paet (ALDE)
text: Writing. \u2012 I supported because over time many of the legislation has expired, lost its relevance or their content has been transposed into other acts.

name: Margot Parker (EFDD)
text: in writing. ‒ Although the measures to repeal old EU legislation only covers police and judicial measures which the UK Government has already opted out of in 2014, UKIP will always vote to repeal EU laws. The only people that should create laws are democratically elected and accountable national governments, not unelected bureaucrats in Brussels.

name: Aldo Patriciello (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 After having seen the documents taken into account by the Assembly (the Council Convention of 17 June 1998 and Act 98/C 216/01 and Council Framework Decision 2008/978/JHA), I agree with it that they hinder the effectiveness of the Schengen acquis. I give all of you my support by voting in favour.

name: Marijana Petir (PPE)
text: Written. ‒ I supported the Report on the proposal for a regulation by the European Parliament and the Council on the repeal of certain acts in the field of police and judicial cooperation in criminal matters, because I believe that it is necessary to revoke all those acts that are outdated and no longer fulfil their legal purpose.   This Regulation revokes seven joint Council actions in the field of police and judicial cooperation in criminal matters, including the fight against drug addiction and drug trafficking, a list of capabilities related to the fight against organised crime, cooperation in the field of public policy and security and cooperation between customs authorities, as well as joint council action with good practice in providing mutual legal assistance in criminal matters. The Council Act on Disqualifications in Driving as well as the Framework Decision on the European Evidentiary Order shall also be abolished.   All these acts need to be revoked because this specific matter is now regulated by acts of a more recent date.

name: Florian Philippot (ENF)
text: In writing. This report, like the previous ones, is part of a simplistic approach and aims to repeal certain acts that have become less relevant as a result of their subsequent questioning. This time it concerns the area of police and judicial cooperation in criminal matters, but unrelated to the Schengen acquis.  If I am not opposed to the cooperation of the judicial and police authorities of the Member States of the European Union, I remain committed to national sovereignty. I therefore consider that this must be through bilateral agreements and not through Brussels.  I have therefore decided to abstain on this report.

name: Tonino Picula (S&D)
text: Written. ‒ Simplification and reduction of the volume of Union legislation is important to achieve legal certainty and clarity, and the Commission is also working on this through regular checks on the Schengen acquis and the repeal of acts that are no longer relevant, either because of its temporary nature or subsequently adopted acts covering their content. This Commission proposal concerns the abolition of the three decisions and statements of the Schengen Executive Board. For example, a Decision adopting a manual on cross-border police cooperation has been repealed, as the content of it is included in the updated catalogue of recommendations for the correct application of the Schengen acquis. It also repeals the Decision adopting the Cooperation Agreement on Traffic Offences, as it is not an internal act of the Schengen acquis and has never entered into force. This process will facilitate the coordination of police and judicial forces within the EU, avoiding unnecessary complications and double rules, which is why I supported it.

name: Andrej Plenković (PPE)
text: Written. —The European Union, as a supranational union to which Member States have ceded certain sovereign rights, has the right and duty to fulfil all the obligations arising therein in order to achieve its objectives. Legislative role is one of the most important in this regard, as EU law has a major direct impact on member states' national law. In his report on the proposal for a decision by the European Parliament and the Council on the repeal of certain acts in the field of police and judicial cooperation in criminal matters, colleague Claude Moraes justifiably stresses that a key element of the better law-making strategy is to improve the transparency of Union law and in this regard should remove those acts that are in force but no longer serve a purpose, i.e. are not relevant because of their legal nature or because their content is covered by subsequent acts. Those decisions and declarations that are outdated should be repealed for reasons of legal certainty and clarity.

name: Salvatore Domenico Pogliese (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 In the context of the expiry of the temporary period on transitional arrangements annexed to the Treaties, the European Commission has carried out an assessment of the Schengen acquis and legal instruments in the field of police cooperation and judicial cooperation in criminal matters.  On the basis of its screening, and in line with its commitments on the adequacy of European regulation, a number of acts have been identified as obsolete because their content has been taken up in subsequent acts or because of their temporary nature.  The Commission has therefore presented a proposal to repeal seven Council joint actions, the content of which has been incorporated into subsequent acts, in accordance with the principles of subsidiarity and proportionality. With the aim of making European legislation clearer, I voted in favour of repealing these acts.

name: Jiří Pospíšil (PPE)
text: Writing. \u2012 Thirdly, I want to express my joy that, after today, the number of existing legislative standards in the field of police and judicial cooperation will be reduced, even by nine standards. In the future, let us not hesitate to actively seek what is no longer necessary in all areas of EU legislation and, in addition, to fight for the simplification of the entire EU legal order.

name: Franck Proust (PPE)
text: In writing. I voted to repeal this text because it had become legally obsolete. We must adopt clear texts to effectively strengthen our area of freedom, security and justice.

name: Paulo Rangel (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 This Commission proposal provides for the repeal of a number of acts adopted in the field of police and judicial cooperation in criminal matters, which have become obsolete, either by virtue of the integration of their content into subsequent acts or because of their temporary nature. In this particular case, the repeal of seven common council actions, the content of which has been taken up in subsequent actions, Council Act 98/C 216/01 and the Convention of 17 June 1998 and Framework Decision 2008/978/JAI are at issue. With a view to the expiry of the transitional period set out in Protocol No 36, annexed to the Treaties and considering the objectives of simplification and reduction of the volume of legislation included in the Better Regulation strategy, I voted in favour.

name: Julia Reid (EFDD)
text: in writing. ‒ Although the measures to repeal old EU legislation only covers police and judicial measures which the UK Government has already opted out of in 2014, UKIP will always vote to repeal EU laws. The only people that should create laws are democratically elected and accountable national governments, not unelected bureaucrats in Brussels.

name: Liliana Rodrigues (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 It relates to the repeal of obsolete acts (mostly related to customs cooperation and the specification of powers).

name: Inmaculada Rodríguez-Piñero Fernández (S&D)
text: in writing. Several acts adopted in the field of police and judicial cooperation in criminal matters have become obsolete because their content has been incorporated into successive acts, although they have not been repealed. This is Joint Action 96/610/JHA (directory of counter-terrorism powers), Joint Action 96/699/JHA (chemical drug profile), Joint Action 96/747/JHA (directory) competences in the fight against organised crime), Joint Action 96/750/JHA (combating drug addiction and trafficking), Joint Action 97/339/JHA (cooperation in the field of drug trafficking) security and public order), Joint Action 97/372/JHA (cooperation between customs authorities), Council Act 98/C 216/01 and the Convention of 17 June 1998 (deprivation of the right to drive), Joint Action 98/427/JHA (good practices of judicial assistance in criminal matters), and Framework Decision 2008/978/JHA (European exhortation for evidence). That is why I voted in favour of its repeal.

name: Claude Rolin (PPE)
text: In writing. In the context of the expiry of the transitional period set out in Protocol 36 on transitional provisions, attached to the treaties, the European Commission has carried out an assessment of the Schengen acquis and legal instruments in the field of police and judicial cooperation in criminal matters. A number of acts have been identified as obsolete because their content has been taken up in subsequent acts or because of their temporary nature. The Commission has put forward a proposal to repeal seven joint Council actions, the content of which has been included in subsequent acts, and the Council's Act 1999/C 26/07 adopting the status of Europol staff. The European Parliament has also proposed amendments to repeal two other acts, also obsolete: the Convention of 17 June 1998 on decisions to forfeit the right to drive and The Council's Act 98/C 216/01 and the Council's 2008/978/JAI framework decision on the European mandate to obtain evidence to collect objects, documents and data for use in criminal proceedings. I voted in favour of this report.

name: Fernando Ruas (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 In the context of the end of the transitional period provided for in the Treaties, the Commission carried out an assessment of the Schengen acquis and legal instruments in the field of police cooperation and judicial cooperation in criminal matters, having concluded by their obsolescence, thanks to their temporary nature and/or the integration of the content into subsequent acts. In view of the commitment made in the Interinstitutional Agreement on Better Regulation, which is taking place in a battle to simplify and reduce the volume of European legislation, the Commission has proposed to repeal seven common Council actions, the content of which has been taken up in subsequent acts. With no reason to approve this report, which is markedly technical, I have given my vote in favour.

name: Tokia Saïfi (PPE)
text: In writing. I voted in favour of this text, which calls for certain acts to be repealed, their content having been taken up in subsequent acts.  The aim is for the European Union to improve its effectiveness and actions on the repertoire of counter-terrorism competences; Determining the chemical characteristics of drugs; The directory of skills in the fight against organised crime; the fight against drug addiction and drug trafficking; cooperation in the area of public order and security and cooperation between customs authorities.

name: Massimiliano Salini (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the measure repealing the Convention of 17 June 1998 on the withdrawal of driving licences established by Council Act 98/C 216/01 and Council Framework Decision 2008/978/JHA on the European mandate for the search for evidence for the acquisition of objects, documents and data for use in criminal proceedings (MER) as I consider these acts to be obsolete.

name: Lola Sánchez Caldentey (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. This repeal is exempt from political content and is simply about the overcoming, through successive acts, of certain regulations, which are therefore exceeded or contained in others. That's why we voted in favour.

name: Lidia Senra Rodríguez (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. I voted in favour of this report to repeal certain acts in the field of police and judicial cooperation in criminal matters, as the acts in question were obsolete and did not apply because of the new regulatory framework that appeared after the Lisbon Treaty. Despite our opposition to it, there would be no point in voting otherwise and maintaining unapplicable regulations.

name: Remo Sernagiotto (ECR)
text: in writing. \u2012 With today's vote, Parliament repeals certain acts in the field of police cooperation and judicial cooperation in criminal matters, which have become obsolete. Their content has been taken up in subsequent acts. I have therefore chosen to vote in favour.

name: Jill Seymour (EFDD)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of this as it repeals European Union acts.

name: Siôn Simon (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ This is the third and final of three instruments that have been repealed today as part of the Commission’s policy on regulatory fitness. All of these acts no longer have any legal relevance and have either been replaced with more up-to-date legal acts or are temporary in their very nature, hence none of them have been politically motivated and it makes a lot of sense to have these aspects removed from EU law.

name: Monika Smolková (S&D)
text: Writing. \u2012 I am glad that the Commission is fulfilling its decision to simplify EU legislation by repealing obsolete legal acts. In this context, the Commission has also carried out an assessment of Schengen legislation and legal instruments in the field of police and judicial cooperation in criminal matters. Since it concluded that many acts were already obsolete and their content was taken into account in subsequent acts or were of a temporary nature, it is only possible to support its proposal to repeal them.  The Commission has submitted a proposal for the repeal of the 7 Council Joint Actions, the content of which has been taken up in subsequent acts, and a Council act laying down the Staff Regulations applicable to Europol staff. These adjustments concern only a small number of employment contracts and will expire shortly. In addition, two obsolete acts will be repealed. One is the Convention on the Prohibition of Driving, which has been ratified by only 7 out of 15 signatory Member States and has therefore not entered into force anywhere. The Council Framework Decision on a European evidence-gathering order for the purpose of obtaining objects, documents and data in criminal matters shall also be repealed. This Decision is replaced by the EP and Council Directive on the European Investigation Order in criminal matters. Technical adaptations of this type contribute to legal certainty and legal clarity, so it is important that the Commission continues to apply this approach.

name: Joachim Starbatty (ECR)
text: Writing. In three decisions, the Commission proposed to repeal acts belonging to the Schengen acquis either for a limited period of time or for their content to be incorporated into subsequent legal acts. The aim is to achieve better regulation by achieving greater transparency of Union law. In this context, the rapporteur, Claude Moraes, believes that it is appropriate to remove from the existing acquis acts that are no longer of use. According to the Commission, this is to be achieved by means of three decisions. Unlike the Commission, the rapporteur recommends changing the nature of the act from a decision to a regulation. After consulting the European Parliament's Legal Service, Claude Moraes has also identified two other obsolete acts which are part of the Schengen acquis and are no longer relevant because they were temporary or were incorporated into subsequent legal acts. The ECR supports the REFIT programme in the sense of de-bureaucratisation and has also voted in the LIBE Committee for the repeal of outdated legal acts. The ALFA is in favour of legal certainty and clarity. The measures proposed in the reports are likely to reduce EU legislation and simplify Union law. I strongly support these concerns and have therefore voted in favour of the report.

name: Ivan Štefanec (PPE)
text: Writing. \u2012 In view of the temporary nature of certain legal acts, or as a result of their derogation by a new legal act, I consider it right to update the Union legal order in order to ensure its effectiveness, clarity and legal certainty.

name: Davor Ivo Stier (PPE)
text: Written. I support this proposal as the Joint Council Action 96/610/PUP has created a list of specific counter-terrorism capabilities, skills and expertise to make them more easily and quickly accessible to agencies in all Member States.
