I also support a proposal repealing a number of outdated Union acts in the area of police and judicial cooperation in criminal matters. Such cooperation can be better achieved at Union level. The EU may adopt measures in accordance with the principle of subsidiarity referred to in Article 5. Treaty on European Union. Furthermore, according to the principle of proportionality, as set out in that Article, this Regulation does not go beyond the scope necessary to achieve that objective.

name: Catherine Stihler (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of this report. A number of acts adopted in recent decades have exhausted all their effects. They are no longer relevant because of their temporary nature or because their content has been taken up by successive acts. For reasons of legal certainty it is necessary to revoke the measures in question in order to bring acts in the area of freedom, security and justice in line with the Lisbon Treaty.

name: Dubravka Šuica (PPE)
text: Written. ‒Improving the transparency of Union law worked on by the Union institutions is a key element of the better law-making strategy. In this context, it is appropriate to remove from the legislation those acts that no longer serve a purpose. Many acts adopted in the area of police and judicial cooperation in criminal matters are outdated because their content is covered by subsequent acts, although they have not been repealed. Members proposed to abolish the following acts: • 7 joint actions as their content is taken from successive acts • Council Act 98/C 216/01 and the Convention of 17 June 1998 (driving disqualifications) • Framework Decision 2008/978/PUP (European Evidentiary Order) I support the proposal to repeal these acts. These acts should be removed from the acquis of the European Union, improving transparency and security for all citizens and countries.

name: Kay Swinburne (ECR)
text: in writing. ‒ As the UK is outside of the Schengen area and this proposal does not impact the UK in any way, I have abstained.

name: Νεοκλής Συλικιώτης (
text: GUE/NGL), in writing. \u2012 As part of the programme to improve the suitability and efficiency of the regulatory framework, the Commission stated that it had conducted a "screening" of the acquis in the field of police and judicial cooperation in criminal matters. The aim was to identify acts which could be repealed at the end of the transitional period set by the Treaties.  The Commission has completed the evaluation of legal acts in the area of Freedom, Security and Justice, and has proposed three proposals concerning the repeal of some twenty legal measures. We have therefore voted in favour of these reports relating to the above acts, as they contribute to legal clarity by indicating which acts are considered obsolete because of their temporary nature, but also because they have been replaced by subsequent acts under the Treaty of Lisbon.

name: Tibor Szanyi (S&D)
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the amending package contained in the report on certain areas of police and judicial cooperation between Member States, in particular in order to ensure better quality, modernity and transparency of European Union legislation. The report also highlights the aspect of legal certainty, which I consider to be a priority for citizens' confidence in EU cooperation.  Outdated legislation or legislation that is not intended to be used by the original legislature (such as the Convention on Driving Disqualifications) or legislation which has since been replaced by more modern and broader legislation (such as the 2014 Framework Decision on a European Investigative Decision replacing the European Order for The Taking of Evidence) should be repealed. I am convinced that, by approving these proposals, the EP will make cooperation between Member States more effective in police and judicial work, which is essential in order to successfully combat cross-border crime and strengthen the security of European citizens.

name: Marc Tarabella (S&D)
text: In writing. I voted in favour of Mr Moraes' proposal. Improving the transparency of EU law is an essential part of the strategy to better legislate, which the EU institutions are currently implementing. In this context, acts that no longer have any reason to exist should be removed from existing legislation.

name: Pavel Telička (ALDE)
text: in writing. ‒ As in the case of the two previous reports, I also supported this one, with a view to reduce the volume of EU law. The obsolete acts to be removed by it include seven Council Joint Actions the content of which has been taken up by subsequent acts, the Council Act 98/C 216/01 and the Convention of 17 June 1998 on driving disqualifications; and the Framework Decision 2008/978/JHA on European evidence warrant. This report also seeks to justify the use of a regulation as a legal instrument for repealing certain acts whose legal basis after the Lisbon Treaty requires adoption of a directive.

name: Ruža Tomašić (ECR)
text: Written. ‒ I supported the regulation on the repeal of certain acts in the field of police and judicial cooperation in criminal matters, as I consider that acts, which no longer serve a purpose or are in new acts, should be removed from European Union legislation in order to improve the transparency of rights and facilitate their availability to relevant agencies.  In particular, this Regulation repeals joint actions on the list of counter-terrorism capabilities, the determination of chemical characteristics of drugs, the capability list in relation to the fight against organised crime, the fight against drug addiction and drug trafficking, cooperation in the field of public policy and security, cooperation between customs authorities, good practice in providing mutual legal assistance in criminal matters, as well as council act and the Convention on Disqualification in Driving, and the Framework Decision on european evidentiary order.  I believe that this will greatly help to achieve the objective of reducing the burden, i.e. I believe that the institutions of the European Union, as well as citizens, will be greatly facilitated by the understanding of EUROPEAN Union law and accordingly, and to act in accordance with those rights.

name: Romana Tomc (PPE)
text: Writing. I supported the report on the proposal for a decision of the European Parliament and of the Council repealing acts in the field of police and judicial cooperation in criminal matters, as I believe that it is essential to take action to ensure the security and control of external borders and to strengthen police and judicial cooperation between Member States through the amended legislation.

name: Estefanía Torres Martínez (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. This repeal is exempt from political content and is simply about the overcoming, through successive acts, of certain regulations, which are therefore exceeded or contained in others. That's why we voted in favour.

name: Ramon Tremosa i Balcells (ALDE)
text: in writing. ‒ I fully support all efforts to reinforce and improve police and judicial cooperation between EU Member States. It is essential to cooperate better and exchange information forgetting national borders on issues of security and threats! The recent sad events in Europe remind us of this urgency! Terrorists and criminal gangs operate in all countries and cross frontiers!

name: Mylène Troszczynski (ENF)
text: In writing. A number of acts are no longer relevant because of their temporary nature or because their content has been included in subsequent acts. These are acts adopted in the area of police cooperation and judicial cooperation in criminal matters.  Even if we are not opposed to police and judicial cooperation between Member States, we remain committed to national sovereignty and we do not want the federalisation of these powers. Voting against this text makes no sense, since it would mean keeping acts obsolete. So I opt for abstention.

name: István Ujhelyi (S&D)
text: Writing. Improving the transparency of EU law is an essential element of the better law strategy, which is being implemented in the EU institutions. In this context, it is appropriate to remove from the legislation in force those which no longer serve any purpose.

name: Traian Ungureanu (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 The European Commission regularly carries out a screening of the legislative acquis with a view to identifying acts that could be repealed, in view of the expiry of the transitional period provided for in the Treaties. These acts are no longer relevant because of their temporary nature or because their content has been taken over by subsequent acts. In order to improve transparency and ensure a higher degree of legal certainty for European citizens, such acts are withdrawn from the Union's legislative acquis. Following this assessment, the European Commission presented a proposal to repeal 7 joint Council actions, the content of which was taken up in subsequent acts, and Council Act 1999/C 26/07 establishing the status of employees applicable to Europol employees. The European Parliament resolution supports the repeal of these obsolete acts and also proposes the repeal of two more acts that have become obsolete, namely the Convention on the Loss of the Right to Drive and the Council Framework Decision on the European Mandate to Obtain Evidence for the Purpose of Obtaining Objects, Documents and Data for Use in Criminal Matters. I voted in favour of this resolution.

name: Miguel Urbán Crespo (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. This repeal is exempt from political content and is simply about the overcoming, through successive acts, of certain regulations, which are therefore exceeded or contained in others. That's why we voted in favour.

name: Viktor Uspaskich (ALDE)
text: Writing. – Part of the legislation in the field of police cooperation and judicial cooperation in criminal matters has lost relevance, but has not been repealed, because its content has been transposed into subsequent legislation.

name: Ivo Vajgl (ALDE)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of the resolution on the proposal for a regulation of the European Parliament and of the Council repealing certain acts in the field of police cooperation and judicial cooperation in criminal matters. The resolution addresses the topics of combating illegal drug trafficking in the Union, the role of Europol in supporting and strengthening mutual cooperation between the law enforcement authorities of the Member States in preventing and combating terrorism and other forms of serious crime, and cooperation and mandated information sharing between Member States regarding large-scale events which are attended by large numbers of people from more than one Member State, in order to maintain law and order, protect people and their property, and prevent criminal offences. I believe that cooperation among Member States on these issues is highly important: therefore I voted in favour.

name: Ramón Luis Valcárcel Siso (PPE)
text: in writing. U2012 We are talking about the repeal of seventy-eight joint actions whose content has been incorporated into successive actions, repeal of Council Act 98/C 216/1 and the Convention of 17 June 1998 on decisions depriving the right to drive, as well as the repeal of Framework Decision 2008/978/JHA on the European Exhortation for Evidence. This is intended to repeal these outdated acts and to move forward with the simplification of European legislation in a correct way, so I think it is necessary to vote in favour.

name: Ángela Vallina (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. I voted in favour of this report to repeal certain acts in the field of police and judicial cooperation in criminal matters, as the acts in question were obsolete and did not apply because of the new regulatory framework that appeared after the Lisbon Treaty. Despite our opposition to it, there would be no point in voting otherwise and maintaining unapplicable regulations.

name: Hilde Vautmans (ALDE)
text: Written. 'As with the previous two proposals, I also support this report. The repeal of these rules will lead to a desired reduction in the number of legislative provisions in the EU. That is why I voted in favour of this report.

name: Miguel Viegas (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. \u2012 Several acts belonging to the Schengen acquis - directory of anti-terrorism powers, chemical characterization of drugs, repertoire of competences in the fight against organised crime, fight against drug addiction and drug trafficking, cooperation in public order and security, cooperation between customs authorities, driving disqualification decisions, good practices in legal aid in criminal matters, European evidence warrant - are no longer relevant because of their temporary nature or because their content has resumed subsequent acts, although they have not been repealed, making them considered obsolete. Despite the technical nature of this document, it deals with a number of matters of a political nature for which certain positions have already been taken.  For the foregoing, the abstention vote.

name: Harald Vilimsky (ENF)
text: Writing. The report only shows the current legal situation. Since it does not bring about any change in content, I abstain from my voice.

name: Udo Voigt (NI)
text: Writing. Some of the developments in the Schengen acquis listed in the report do not in fact constitute a "further development" in terms of effective police and judicial cooperation between EU Member States. There is therefore no reason to repeal regulations originally codified in the Schengen Agreement, especially since, in the course of the current development of the EU, it must also be expected that the degree of European integration that has already been achieved cannot be sustained in the long term.

name: Beatrix von Storch (ECR)
text: Writing. Legislation in the field of police and judicial cooperation in criminal matters that is no longer of any use must be upplayed. That is why I voted in favour of this resolution. The following acts are now repealed: Joint Action 96/610/JHA (Directory of counter-terrorism skills and expertise), Joint Action 96/699/JHA (preparation of chemical profiles of drugs), Joint Action 96/747/JHA (list of skills and expertise in the field of the fight against organised crime), Joint Action 96/750/JHA (Fight against drug addiction and drug trafficking), Joint Action 97/339/JHA (cooperation in the field of public policy and security), Joint Action 97/372/JHA (customs cooperation), Council Act 98/C 216/01 and Convention of 17. June 1998 (disqualification of driving licence), Joint Action 98/427/JHA (application of best practices in mutual legal assistance in criminal matters) and Framework Decision 2008/978/JHA (European Evidence Order). These specific joint measures have not been repealed per se, but have already been integrated into other legal texts. However, we can now ask ourselves why the EU still has to regulate the withdrawal of driving licences for all Member States!

name: Θεόδωρος Ζαγοράκης (PPE)
text: Writing. \u2012 I also gave my vote in favour in this case. The rapporteur's wording of the text satisfies the positions of our group, as expressed in the ep committee responsible.

name: Inês Cristina Zuber (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. \u2012 The LIBE Committee has decided to frame this report in the Simplified Procedure – Article 50(2) of the Rules of Procedure. Mrs Cornelia Ernst, who suggests voting in favour, followed this report. Various acts belonging to the Schengen acquis - repertoire of anti-terrorism competences, chemical characterization of drugs, repertoire of powers in the fight against organised crime, the fight against drug addiction and trafficking, cooperation in public order and security, cooperation between customs authorities, driving disqualifications, good practices in legal aid in criminal matters, european mandate to obtain evidence - they are no longer relevant because of their temporary nature or because their content was taken up by subsequent acts, although they have not been repealed, making them consider obsolete. Despite the technical nature of this document, it deals with a number of matters of a political nature to which we have spoken against. We do not, however, agree with subsequent acts for continuing the policy of repression and securitization. We abstained.

name: Milan Zver (PPE)
text: Writing. I voted in favour of the European Parliament's legislative resolution repealing certain acts in the field of police cooperation and judicial cooperation in criminal matters because it is in line with legal certainty and clarity and contributes to the transparency of Union legislation, that acts which no longer serve any purpose are repealed.

name: William (The Earl of) Dartmouth (EFDD)
text: in writing. ‒ This involves the EU signing an international convention intended to be signed by states. We therefore oppose it, not because we do not care about the tuna – we care very much and want numbers to grow – but because this is another instance of the EU behaving like a state. What this does is to give the EU a vote in a convention in which voting is the prerogative of full members who are nation states.

name: Marina Albiol Guzmán (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. I voted in favour of this report because it is a strengthening of scientific cooperation in relation to the conservation of southern bluefin tuna. The world population of different types of tuna has been at risk, but there are signs of recovery, at least in some of its varieties. That is why scientific cooperation is necessary to have better information at the global level on this resource. Both the survival of this important species and that of the communities that have historically engaged in its artisanal exploitation depend on sustainable and well-founded fisheries policies. Such is the case of Atlantic bluefin tuna and almadraba, which is an important indicator of its population; sharing this information must be critical to raising sustainable fisheries policies. For all of the above, I have decided to vote in favour of this report.

name: Martina Anderson and Lynn Boylan (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. – While we have reservations about the EU representing the Member States in certain capacities, we supported this report with the view that bluefin fish stocks will be better protected from international IUU fishing with the EU as a full Member of CCSBT amongst other members like Japan and South Korea, who have a poor record when it comes to sustainability and overexploitation of stocks.

name: Marie-Christine Arnautu (ENF)
text: In writing. The aim of this report is to make the European Union a member of the regional organisation of the Commission for the Conservation of Southern Bluefin Tuna (CCSBT). The EU would thus extend its action to protect bluefin tuna to the Indian Ocean. There are two problems. The first is our principled opposition to this transfer of sovereignty, which would force the Member States to align themselves with the position of Brussels. The second problem is that European vessels are prohibited from fishing more than 10 tonnes of southern bluefin tuna as an incident catch (i.e., when longliners accidentally fish).  Finally, participation in this organisation is estimated at an annual fee of 70,000 euros. Considering the protection of tuna as necessary, I nevertheless believe that this accession of the Union is not really justified. So I abstained.

name: Jean Arthuis (ALDE)
text: In writing. I voted in favour of this deliberation because it is intended to authorise the exchange of letters between the European Union and the Enlarged Commission of the Southern Bluefin Tuna Conservation Convention (CCSBT). The signing of this instrument of international law will enable the European Union to become a full member of the enlarged CCSBT based on its current status as a cooperating non-contracting party. This new cooperation is in line with the policy of the European Union, which is very active in all regional fisheries management organisations (ORPPs) in order to contribute to the rational and sustainable management of marine resources and to the fight against illegal, unreported and unregulated fishing.

name: Zigmantas Balčytis (S&D)
text: Writing. – I voted in favour of this proposal, which aims to give the EU full participation in the CCSBT. The CCSBT is an advanced commission of the Australian Tuna Conservation Convention. By signing the agreement, the EU would become a full member of this commission instead of an entity cooperating with the CCSBT's extended commission but not part of it.

name: Gerard Batten (EFDD)
text: in writing. ‒ This involves the EU signing an international convention intended to be signed by states. We therefore oppose it, not because we do not care about the tuna – we care very much and want numbers to grow – but because this is another instance of the EU behaving like a state. What this does is to give the EU a vote in a convention in which voting is the prerogative of full members who are nation states.

name: Nicolas Bay (ENF)
text: In writing. The southern bluefin tuna quotas allocated to our vessels do not exceed 10 tonnes and in fact cover only accidental catches. This accession did not really seem justified to me, I chose to abstain, concerned in principle with the protection of fish stocks, in this case bluefin tuna in the Indian Ocean.

name: Hugues Bayet (S&D)
text: In writing. I voted in favour of this proposal, which aims to authorise the European Union's participation in the Convention for the Conservation of Southern Bluefin Tuna (CCSBT), thus contributing to the responsible management of fisheries resources.

name: Izaskun Bilbao Barandica (ALDE)
text: in writing. I voted in favour of this report as the proposal aims to authorise the redemption of notes between the EU and the enlarged Commission of the Convention on the Conservation of Southern BlueFin tuna. The signing of this instrument of international law will enable the EU to move from being a non-party to the enlarged CCSBT Commission to a full member of the CCSBT.

name: Dominique Bilde (ENF)
text: In writing. A new failed act for the European Union on this subject which led me to abstain in the vote of this text. Of course, the primary intention may seem laudable, since it would be to give the Union a place in the discussions and votes on the monitoring and protection of bluefin tuna in the Indian Ocean, even though it has been a non-contracting party to the Convention since 2006; however, the defence of European interests in this area does not hold when we know that the Union has already been allocated a quota of 10 tonnes of southern bluefin tuna, but only as an incidental catch.  Given that the annual participation in this organisation is estimated at 70,000 euros and that this amount is related to the small quantities of southern bluefin tuna caught by European ships, we cannot realize any real added value with full membership of this committee. Finally, this would also be at the expense of national industries, since if the European Union joined the Convention, the Member States would be forced to align themselves with the official positions of the Union.

name: Mara Bizzotto (ENF)
text: in writing. \u2012 The EU's accession to the enlarged Commission of the Convention for the Conservation of Southern Bluefin Tuna will enable Europe to become a full member of this Assembly, acquiring an active role and greater decision-making power. That is why I wanted to support this text with my vote.

name: José Blanco López (S&D)
text: in writing. From the point of view of global fisheries governance, it is important that the European Union leads the promotion and implementation of sustainable fisheries management. This proposal for EU entry into the Commission for the Conservation of Southern BlueFin tuna (CCSBT) as a full member, thus abandoning the status of 'non-party co-operator' it has been maintaining so far, goes in this regard. That is where I support it, as rapporteur for the S&D Group. This new framework will serve to promote coherence of EU approaches across all oceans, for example between southern bluefin tuna management (CCSBT) and Atlantic bluefin tuna (ICCAT), while strengthening its commitment to long-term conservation and sustainable use of fishery resources globally.

name: Vilija Blinkevičiūtė (S&D)
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted on this report, which deals with the agreement between the European Union and the Commission for the Conservation of Australian Tunas. The International Commission for the Conservation of Atlantic Tunas (ICCAT) is of paramount importance to the European Union. ICCAT is responsible for the conservation of tuna and tuna species in the Atlantic Ocean and adjacent seas. This organisation was established through the Conference of Plenipotentiaries, which prepared and adopted the International Convention for the Conservation of Atlantic Tunas, which was signed in Rio de Janeiro in 1966. Following ratification, the Convention officially entered into force in 1969.  The Commission for the Conservation of Australian Tunas (SI) CCSBT) is a regional fisheries management organisation (RSVO) responsible for managing the australian tuna stock living in all waters. The Convention for the Conservation of Australian Tuna entered into force on 20 May 1994. Since 2006, the European Union has been cooperating with the CCSBT Extended Commission but not a member.  In the area of the prevalence of Australian tuna, catches of Australian tuna by the EU fleet are made up mainly of the Indian Ocean Tuna Commission (IA). In the IOTC Convention Area, a small quantity of Australian tuna is caught as by-catch in the longline tuna and species associated with them. Since 2006, by-catches of Australian tuna caught in THE EU in CCSBT waters have been subject to an annual quota of 10 tonnes.

name: Franc Bogovič (PPE)
text: Writing. The purpose of that Recommendation is to approve the Exchange of Letters between the European Union and the Extended Commission of the Convention for the Conservation of Southern BlueFin Tuna on behalf of the European Union (CCSBT), which in fact means that the EU is becoming a full member of that CCSBT Commission. Although the EU has been a non-member since 2006, the EU has been a non-member. In practice, this means that the EU acquires voting rights in the management of the CCSTB, thus have a direct impact on the management of southern bluefin tuna wherever it is located. Until recently, only individual countries could be included in the CCSBT, which did not give the EU the possibility of obtaining full membership. However, since 2013, regional integration organisations such as the EU have been able to join the enlarged Commission, thus having a greater direct impact on all bluefin tuna-related activities – sustainable management of marine resources and the fight against illegal, unreported and unregulated fishing. I supported the proposed recommendation.

name: Marie-Christine Boutonnet (ENF)
text: In writing. Given the accidental nature of European fishing vessels catching bluefin tuna in Indian Ocean waters, we believe that this issue is not of strategic interest to the Union. On the other hand, the sum of 70,000 euros in contributions to join this convention could be more usefully affected. The 10-tonne fishing quota that we have will not be affected anyway. Nevertheless, we will be watching with interest the evolution of bluefin tuna stocks in the Indian Ocean. Therefore, I abstained.

name: Renata Briano (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 Accession to the Enlarged Commission of the Convention for the Conservation of Southern Bluefin Tuna (CCSBT) is an act confirming the EU's international role in this tuna protection organisation. The European Union has been a non-cooperating party to the CCSBT's Enlarged Commission since 2006.  The European Union has pursued a very active participation policy in all regional fisheries organisations, with the aim of contributing to the rational and sustainable management of marine resources and the fight against illegal, undeclared and unregulated fishing. Some of these organisations deal with all fish stocks in a specific area, while others manage highly migratory species – particularly tuna – in large geographical areas.  The most significant for the European Union is the International Commission for the Conservation of Atlantic Tunas (ICCAT), which deals with the conservation of tuna and similar species in the Atlantic Ocean and adjacent seas. The Southern Bluefin Tuna Conservation Commission (CCSBT) is important for our seas because it deals with the management of southern bluefin tuna in all its distribution areas.

name: Steeve Briois (ENF)
text: In writing. The Southern Bluefin Tuna Conservation Commission is an organization responsible for the management and protection of this species. Since 2006, the European Union has been a non-contracting party to the convention, which came into force in 1994.  The report calls on the EU to join the Convention so that it has the right to join and vote in this committee, with the aim of strengthening European action on the protection of bluefin tuna. We are in favour of the protection of this species and the regulation of the bluefin tuna fishery, particularly in the Indian Ocean. Nevertheless, we know full well that the Member States will have to align their position with that of the European Union in the event of accession, which will limit our national sovereignty.  Moreover, the accession of the Union, even in order to monitor and protect bluefin tuna stocks in the Indian Ocean, is not really justified insofar as the quotas of southern bluefin tuna allocated to our ships do not exceed 10 tonnes and in fact only cover accidental catches. I therefore abstained on this text.

name: Daniel Buda (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 The proposal for a decision on accession to the enlarged Commission under the Southern Convention for the Conservation of Bluefin Tuna (CCSBT) aims to approve the exchange of letters between the Union and the CCSBT so that the EU can become a full member, given that the European Union has been a cooperative non-contracting party since 2006. The Union has actively contributed to the sustainable and rational management of marine resources and to the fight against illegal, unreported and unregulated fishing, leading to a policy of cooperation with all regional fisheries management organisations (RGMOs). These organisations are set up by the Countries interested in fisheries in certain areas and have both an advisory and administrative role, with competences in the technical field and in the control obligations sector. Thus, only countries can join the CCSBT Convention. As a result, the Union, although it has an active role in regional tuna fisheries management organisations, is excluded from accession. I voted in favour of this report because I believe that the Union's active involvement in the management of regional fisheries organisations must be translated into the granting of full rights.

name: Gianluca Buonanno (ENF)
text: in writing. \u2012 The purpose of the proposal is to authorise the exchange of letters between the EU and the Enlarged Commission of the Convention for the Conservation of Southern Bluefin Tuna (CCSBT).  The signing of this instrument of international law will enable the EU to become a full member of the CCSBT's enlarged committee from its current status as a cooperating non-contracting party (which does not allow it to have the right to vote, while having to comply with technical stock management guidelines).  It is therefore in favour so that it can at least play an active role in management choices.

name: Alain Cadec (PPE)
text: In writing. The Commission for the Conservation of Southern Bluefin Tuna (CCSBT) is a regional fisheries management organisation (ORGP) responsible for the management of southern bluefin tuna in all its distribution areas. The Southern BlueFin tuna conservation convention came into force on May 20, 1994.  On 1 December 2009, the Council authorised the European Commission to request, on behalf of the European Union, an amendment to the CCSTB regulations to allow the European Union to become a contracting party. Given that ships flying the flag of eu Member States exploit resources within the range of bluefin tuna in the South, it is in the EU's interest to play an effective role in the implementation of the Convention.  I voted in favour of this report, which will allow the European Union to join and vote in the enlarged CCSBT and the enlarged scientific committee.

name: Nicola Caputo (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 I have today voted in favour of the proposal on the accession of the Union to the enlarged committee of the Convention for the Conservation of Southern Bluefin Tuna. The exchange of letters should be concluded in order to complete the legal process. The Union can no longer afford to retain its current role as a non-contracting party, which has been going on since 2006. This accession is consistent with the Policies of the European Union, since it is competent to adopt measures for the conservation of marine biological resources within the framework of the common fisheries policy and to conclude agreements with third countries and international organisations. Above all, however, this action line will promote coherence in the Union's conservation approach in all oceans and strengthen its commitment to long-term conservation and sustainable use of fisheries resources worldwide. I would remind you that the main interest in the EU is the similarities between the management of southern bluefin tuna (CCSBT) and that of Atlantic bluefin tuna (ICCAT). Lastly, let us not forget that ships flying the flag of the Member States of the Union are exploiting existing resources in the southern bluefin tuna distribution area. It is therefore in the Union's interest to play an active role in the application of the Convention.

name: Matt Carthy (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of this report on the EU joining a body for conservation of bluefin tuna. As a result the EU will become a full member of the Commission for the Conservation of Southern Bluefin Tuna (CCSBT), which is an intergovernmental organisation responsible for the management of southern bluefin tuna throughout its global distribution. The EU has already been a cooperating, extended member of this organisation since 2006. Cooperating non-members participate fully in the activities of the CCSBT and are required to comply with CCSBT management and conservation measures. However, they are not entitled to vote. Becoming a full member will allow the EU to have a voice in this commission. This organisation was established in the 1980s when it became apparent that the southern bluefin tuna stock was at a level where management and conservation was required. The organisation operates through a voluntary management arrangement. The largest fishers of southern bluefin tuna remain Australia, New Zealand and Japan.

name: James Carver (EFDD)
text: in writing. ‒ This involves the EU signing an international convention intended to be signed by states. We therefore oppose it, not because we do not care about the tuna – we care very much and want numbers to grow – but because this is another instance of the EU behaving like a state. What this does is to give the EU a vote in a convention in which voting is the prerogative of full members who are nation states.

name: David Casa (PPE)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of this report because my opinion is that the EU can only benefit from membership of the Extended Commission for the Conservation of Southern Bluefin Tuna (CCSBT). Up till now, we only participated in its activities but did not have the right to vote: this now changes with the consent of Parliament.

name: Fabio Massimo Castaldo (EFDD)
text: in writing. \u2012 The CCSBT Convention, the Southern Bluefin Tuna Conservation Commission, to which the European Union has been a cooperating non-contracting party since 2006, was open only to States and excluded regional economic integration organisations such as the European Union. In October 2013, at its twentieth meeting, the CCSBT amended the resolution on the Enlarged Committee to allow regional economic integration organisations that so wish to become members of the Enlarged Commission through an exchange of letters in which the requesting body firmly engages with the CCSBT to comply with the terms of the Convention and to comply with the decisions of the CCSBT's Enlarged Committee. The aim is to give the EU the possibility of full participation in the activities of the Convention for the Conservation of Southern Bluefin Tuna (CCSBT). I therefore voted in favour.

name: Λευτέρης Χριστοφόρου (
text: PPE), in writing. \u2012 The proposal aims to approve the Exchange of Letters between the EU and the Enlarged Committee of the Southern Hemisphere Tuna Conservation Convention (CCSBT). With the signing of this instrument of international law, the EU will be able to become a full member of the enlarged CCSBT Committee , which has enjoyed the status of cooperating non-Contracting Party since 2006. The Council therefore submits this proposal for a decision, with which we agree.

name: Salvatore Cicu (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 I chose to support the measure. On the basis of the commitments made in the provisions of the United Nations Convention of 10 December 1982 on the Law of the Sea, the European Union pursued a policy of very active participation in all regional fisheries organizations, with a view to contributing to the rational and sustainable management of marine resources and to the fight against illegal, undeclared and unregulated fishing.  The aim of the proposal is to authorise the exchange of letters between the EU and the Enlarged Commission of the Convention for the Conservation of Southern Bluefin Tuna (CCSBT), a regional fisheries management organisation (ORGP) responsible for managing southern bluefin tuna in all its distribution areas. The Convention for the Conservation of Southern Bluefin Tuna entered into force on 20 May 1994.  The signing of this instrument of international law will enable the EU to become a full member of the CCSBT's enlarged commission from its current status as a cooperating non-contracting party, a role it has played since 2006.

name: Alberto Cirio (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the proposal to authorise the exchange of letters between the EU and the CCSBT (Southern Bluefin Tuna Conservation Committee). In my opinion, the European Union must commit itself, as it is rightly doing, to contributing to the rational and sustainable management of marine resources and must combat undeclared and unregulated illegal fishing, and that is why it has a very active participation in all regional fisheries organisations. In this particular case, with regard to bluefin tuna, I feel I must support and support Carlos Iturgaiz's report in order to be able to control, regulate and, in this way, preserve the trade in southern bluefin tuna.

name: David Coburn (EFDD)
text: in writing. ‒ This involves the EU signing an international convention intended to be signed by states. We therefore oppose it, not because we do not care about the tuna – we care very much and want numbers to grow – but because this is another instance of the EU behaving like a state. What this does is to give the EU a vote in a convention in which voting is the prerogative of full members who are nation states.

name: Jane Collins (EFDD)
text: in writing. – This involves the EU signing an international convention intended to be signed by states. We therefore oppose it, not because we do not care about the tuna – we care very much and want numbers to grow – but because this is another instance of the EU behaving like a state. What this does is to give the EU a vote in a convention in which voting is the prerogative of full members who are nation states.

name: Lara Comi (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 I fully support the European Parliament's draft legislative resolution on the Council decision on the conclusion of the agreement in the form of an exchange of letters between the European Union and the Committee on the Conservation of Southern Bluefin Tuna. I believe it is important to protect maritime heritage and, in order to safeguard it, I believe that we need the use of this instrument, which will enable the European Union to become a full member of the CCSBT's enlarged committee. In this way, it will achieve full participation in the committee's activities, including the right to vote.

name: Therese Comodini Cachia (PPE)
text: in writing. ‒ This proposal solidifies the EU’s goals to maintain sustainable use of fisheries on a global scale by allowing the EU to participate in and obtain membership of the Commission for the Conservation of Southern Bluefin Tuna (CCSBT) to protect and provide necessary means of harvesting bluefin tuna while also allowing the population to grow. I voted in favour.

name: Javier Couso Permuy (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. I voted in favour of this report because it is a strengthening of scientific cooperation in relation to the conservation of southern bluefin tuna. The world population of different types of tuna has been at risk, but there are signs of recovery, at least in some of its varieties. That is why scientific cooperation is necessary to have better information at the global level on this resource. Both the survival of this important species and that of the communities that have historically engaged in its artisanal exploitation depend on sustainable and well-founded fisheries policies. Such is the case of Atlantic bluefin tuna and almadraba, which is an important indicator of its population; sharing this information must be critical to raising sustainable fisheries policies. For all of the above, I have decided to vote in favour of this report.

name: Edward Czesak (ECR)
text: I would like to write to the Commission. \u2012 The European Union is actively involved in all fisheries organisations aimed at ensuring a rational and sustainable management of marine resources and combating illegal fishing. One such organisation is the Extended Commission of the Convention for the Conservation of Southern Tuna (CCSBT), in which the EU has been a cooperating non-member entity since 2006. The CCSBT is responsible for the conservation and management of southern tuna stocks throughout the range. The adoption of a resolution agreeing to the conclusion of the agreement will allow the EU to become a member of the CCSBT and participate fully in its work. Today, the EU, as a cooperating entity, binds m.in. catch limits set by the CCSBT, over which the EU quota is not affected (cooperating entities fully participate in ccsbt activities but do not have the right to vote). As vessels flying the flags of Member States fish in the southern tuna area, it is in the EU's interest to become a full member of the CCSBT. In view of the above, I supported the motion for a resolution.

name: Miriam Dalli (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ I gave my consent to the conclusion of this agreement as it allows the EU to become a full member of the CCSBT Extended Commission, having enjoyed cooperating non-member status since 2006 through its representation by the European Commission. The Commission for the Conservation of Southern Bluefin Tuna (CCSBT) is a Regional Fisheries Management Organisation (RFMO) responsible for the management of the species of southern bluefin tuna wherever it is to be found.

name: Michel Dantin (PPE)
text: In writing. This non-legislative report gives a positive opinion to the Council's draft decision on the European Union's accession to the Commission for the Conservation of Southern Bluefin Tuna (CCSBT).  As the Union is very active in regional organisations on the issue of rational and sustainable management of marine resources and in the fight against illegal fishing, I support this accession which should strengthen the Union's influence within the CCSBT by granting it a right to vote.  I therefore voted in favour of this text.

name: Rachida Dati (PPE)
text: In writing. I supported this report because the accession of the European Union to the enlarged Commission of the Convention for the Conservation of Southern Bluefin Tuna is accompanied by the right to vote in this committee.  This measure will enable the Union to assert its influence in the field of bluefin tuna fishing.

name: Andor Deli (PPE)
text: Writing. \u2012 In line with the direction of the European People's Party, I voted in favour of the accession of the EU as a regional economic integration organisation to the Committee for the Conservation of Southern Bluefin Tuna. The EU has already taken full control of the recommendations of the committee in question, which clearly show that the European Union is being forced to impose appropriate restrictions on sea fishing in order to maintain marine fish stocks. 30% of the earth's seas are overfished and marine fish stocks are at risk. Justified steps to maintain them will result in a continuous and significant reduction in the amount of marine fish fish fished. Therefore, the common fisheries policy should pay much more attention to sustainable fish farming, i.e. aquaculture, and in particular freshwater fish farming.  A significant number of fish ponds in Hungary are located in Natura 2000 sites. These farms do not pose any threat to the natural assets of these areas. Moreover, in many cases it is precisely because of our closed-system fish ponds that they have created or preserved individual wetland associations. Consequently, freshwater aquaculture should be prioritised and given as much EU support as possible. Furthermore, this area should be freed from unduly stringent and unnecessary sustainability standards, which are justified only for sea fishing.

name: Mireille D'Ornano (ENF)
text: In writing. The aim of this report was to change the status of the European Union vis-à-vis the enlarged Commission of the Southern Bluefin Tuna Conservation Convention (CCSBT). By establishing a contractual relationship between the Union and the CCSBT, this report wanted the Union to join the commission. Thus, the Union would have had a greater right of review and decision on the national fisheries policies of the Member States. This transfer of sovereignty in secret is obviously not acceptable, which is why I abstained in the vote.

name: Ангел Джамбазки (ECR)
text: in writing. \u2012 Red tuna is an undeniable delicacy especially for Japanese-loving dishes. The fact is that these huge fish, reaching hundreds of pounds, can be sold even for hundreds of thousands of dollars. All these things provide a huge prerequisite for increased interest in catching this fish. We all know that the European Union has one of the highest environmental standards in the world. That is why I supported the proposal to sign this agreement with the Commission for the Conservation of Southern Bluefin Tuna, and I hope that our high standards will be carried over to the Commission and we will be able to protect this fish. I will monitor with interest the work of this committee and report on irregularities with particular rigour.

name: Γεώργιος Επιτήδειος (NI)
text: Writing. \u2012 Positive, because compliance with international fisheries agreements and respect for species such as tuna are the guarantee for the conservation and proper management of these species.

text: in writing. – This involves the EU signing an international convention intended to be signed by states. What this does is to give the EU a vote in a convention in which voting is the prerogative of full members who are nation states.

name: José Manuel Fernandes (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 The proposal aims to authorise the exchange of letters between the EU and the Enlarged Commission of the Convention for the Conservation of Southern Tuna (CCSBT). The European Union has adopted a very active policy of participation in all Regional Fisheries Management Organisations (ORPs) with the aim of contributing to the rational and sustainable management of marine resources and to the fight against illegal, unreported and unregulated fishing. ORGP are international organisations consisting of countries with fishing interests in a given area. Some manage all stocks in a given region, others are concentrated in highly migratory species, such as tuna, covering vast geographical areas.  Catches of BFS taken by the EU fleet in its distribution zone consist of by-catches and are limited to tuna and tuna fishing with longliners, mainly in the Indian Ocean Tuna Commission Convention (IOTC) area. Since 2006, the European Union has benefited from an annual quota of 10 tonnes of BFS for by-catches in the CCSBT area. I voted in favour.

name: Edouard Ferrand (ENF)
text: In writing. I abstained on this resolution because it does not really take European interests into account.

name: João Ferreira (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. \u2012 The signing of the Agreement in the form of an Exchange of Letters between the European Union and the Commission for the Conservation of Southern Tuna (CCSBT) on EU membership of the Enlarged Commission of the Convention for the Conservation of South Tuna will allow the EU to become a member of the Enlarged Commission of CCSBT, a multilateral instrument for managing fisheries resources in international waters. A management methodology with which we agree, where cooperation between stakeholders allows the definition of common rules, which everyone commits voluntarily and responsibly. This Commission, in particular, is of particular importance because of the importance of the resource exploited, South tuna. We voted in favour.

name: Raffaele Fitto (ECR)
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of this recommendation on the conclusion of the Southern Bluefin Tuna Conservation Agreement (CCSBT). This instrument of international law will allow the EU to become a full member of the CCSBT's enlarged commission from its current status as a cooperating non-contracting party, thus obtaining the right to vote on that committee.

name: Monika Flašíková Beňová (S&D)
text: Writing. \u2012 The European Union has an interest in becoming a full member of the Commission of the Convention for the Conservation of Southern Tunas, as it has been a cooperating non-member of the Commission since 2006. The cooperating non-members shall participate fully in the activities of the Commission, but shall not be entitled to vote and shall have an obligation to comply with the Commission's management and safeguard measures.

name: Lorenzo Fontana (ENF)
text: in writing. \u2012 I am voting in favour of this report authorising the exchange of letters between the EU and the Enlarged Commission of the Convention for the Conservation of Southern Bluefin Tuna (CCSBT).

name: Λάμπρος Φουντούλης (
text: NI), in writing. \u2012 I am voting in favour of the report on accession to the enlarged Committee of the Convention on the Conservation of Southern Hemisphere Tuna, because compliance with international fisheries agreements and respect for species such as tuna are the guarantee for the conservation and proper management of these species.

name: Doru-Claudian Frunzulică (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ The proposal concerns authorisation of the exchange of letters between the EU and the Extended Commission of the Convention for the Conservation of Southern Bluefin Tuna, (CCSBT). name: Ildikó Gáll-Pelcz (PPE)
text: Writing. \u2012 In my opinion, it is of the utmost importance that the EU already plays an active role in 6 regional fisheries management organisations dealing with tuna management. The proposal aims to authorised an exchange of letters between the EU and the Extended Commission for the Conservation of Southern Bluefin Tuna (CCSBT). By signing this instrument of international law, the EU would gain full membership of the CCSBT Extended Committee instead of the status of a non-current non-member cooperating party. The European Union is the cooperating party to the CCSBT Extended Committee which has not been a member since 2006. On the basis of the relevance of this issue and the foregoing, I support the Council's proposal for a decision to participate as a full member of the CCSBT, with which the rapporteur fully agrees, and calls on the Committee to give a favourable opinion on the proposal.

name: Francesc Gambús (PPE)
text: in writing. I voted in favour of accession so that the EU can go from cooperating non-part of the enlarged CCSBT Commission to being a full member of the CCSBT, with the aim of contributing to the rational and sustainable management of marine resources and the fight against illegal, undeclared and unregulated fishing.

name: Arne Gericke (ECR)
text: Writing. I voted in favour of the recommendation to join the enlarged Commission of the Southern Bluefin Tuna Convention, as I consider the conservation of this species in our waters to be an important contribution by Europe to biodiversity. The per-human consumption of fish increases by one to two percent every year. In addition, the number of people is growing by just over one percent per year. So humanity demands two to three percent more fish on the table every year. All species of bluefin tuna are on the International Conservation Organisation's Red List. The southern species is considered "endangered", that of the Atlantic and the Mediterranean is considered "highly endangered", and the Pacific bluefin tuna has been considered "vulnerable" since last November. This must be stopped.

name: Jens Gieseke (PPE)
text: Writing. This decision consistently continues the previous objectives of a sustainable policy. The protection of highly migratory species is a particular challenge. That is why it is important for states to exchange ideas intensively with each other.  The problem of illegal fishing must continue to be addressed. By joining the enlarged Commission, Europe continues to assume responsibility here.

name: Neena Gill (S&D)

name: Juan Carlos Girauta Vidal (ALDE)
text: in writing. ‒ I chose to support this proposal, as accession to the Extended Commission of the Convention for the Conservation of Southern Bluefin Tuna is a positive step in encouraging a rational and responsible marine conservation. We need to ensure the responsible management and conservation of marine resources, including blue fin tuna, and this proposal encourages their sustainable and responsible harvesting. Therefore, I voted in favour of it.

name: Sylvie Goddyn (ENF)
text: In writing. This report focuses on the European Union's accession to the Extended Commission of the Southern BlueFin tuna Conservation Convention (CCSBT). This convention is a regional fisheries organization (ORGP).  The aim is to have the Union accede to this convention so that it has the right to join and vote in the CCSBT, with the aim of strengthening the Union's action in the protection of bluefin tuna, because of the similarities between the management of the southern bluefin tuna (Indian Ocean) and that of the Atlantic. If the intention is laudable, it does not pose any less two problems: On the one hand, once this accession is effective, the Member States will be invited to align their positions with that of the Union. It is therefore an "underground" transfer of sovereignty. On the other hand, the annual contribution, estimated at 70,000 euros, is not justified by the quotas of southern bluefin tuna allocated to Europe, which are reduced to 10 tons and cover only the accidental catches of our ships.  I therefore abstained, because it is not appropriate for the European Union to join all the PMOs in the world, even with the stated aim of monitoring the evolution of stocks.

name: Tania González Peñas (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. We voted in favour of the proposal, as the proposal aims to authorise the redemption of notes between the EU and the enlarged Commission of the Southern BlueFin tuna conservation convention (CCSBT).  The signing of this instrument of international law will enable the EU, which since 2006 has been cooperating not part of the enlarged CCSBT Commission, to be a full member of it.  The CCSBT Convention was only open to States, and regional economic integration organisations (ORIEs), such as the EU, were therefore excluded. The CCSBT amended during its twentieth meeting, held in October 2013, the resolution governing the enlarged Commission, in order to allow ORIEs wishing to do so to become members of the enlarged Commission (until then, the only statute they could access was that of non-Parties co-operators) through a note-following procedure in which the applicant agency expresses its strong commitment to respect for the CCSBT the terms of the Convention and compliance with the decisions of the Enlarged Commission of the CCSBT.

name: Theresa Griffin (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of the recommendation that the European Union accede to the Extended Commission of the Convention for the Conservation of Southern Bluefin Tuna because I strongly believe that conservation and efforts to maintain our ever-dwindling animal populations are integral to the survival of our planet. With our membership I believe that we will be in a better position to protect this fish population, and that this will have a knock-on effect for conservation elsewhere in the ecosystem.

name: Antanas Guoga (ALDE)

name: Brian Hayes (PPE)
text: in writing. ‒ I chose to support this proposal as it will enhance the bid to contribute to rational and sustainable management of marine resources and combat illegal, unreported and unregulated fishing. The responsible management in relation to the setting of catch and fishing limits, as well as technical aspects and mandatory inspections are vital to ensure responsible fishing practices in our waters. The responsible conservation of tuna among other species in the Atlantic Ocean and the adjoining waters is crucial for the future of the European Union.

name: Anja Hazekamp (GUE/NGL)
text: Written. 'Although the name of the Southern Bluefin Tuna Conservation Commission (CCSBT) suggests otherwise, the CCSBT is mainly about the exploitation of tuna and not about the protection of tuna. Every year, the CCSBT sets the quotas for catches for bluefin tuna in the southern hemisphere oceans, while bluefin tuna is threatened with extinction and the catch is actually stopped. The CCSBT policy is merely a destructive mismanagement: the CCBST offers no chance of recovery for bluefin tuna. Europe is likely to represent the interests of French and Spanish tuna fishermen, but it is also expected that Europe will counterbalance the CCSBT policy, which is now mainly determined by Japan and Korea. Nevertheless, I voted in favour of this report in the hope that, as a member of the CCBTS, the EU will be able to stop the increase in quotas and pursue a total ban on the catch of bluefin tuna. I will keep a close eye on the EU's future contribution to the CCBTS.

name: Richard Howitt (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ I welcome this further step to improve the European Union’s role to advance marine conservation. Already this month in the Mediterranean there has been international agreement to maintain the bluefin tuna recovery plan, but I hope the EU will back efforts from the Worldwide Fund for Nature to improve traceability for this species everywhere, which remains an obstacle to the eradication of illegal fishing.  As far as the southern bluefin tuna is concerned, it has become a victim of the international popularity of sushi, a single bluefin tuna selling for no less than USD 175 000 in a Japanese fish market. Pound for pound, it has been said to be as valuable as silver.  Our efforts are not to destroy the trade but to return it to one of sustainable fishing. I welcome the recent commitment of the European Commissioner on Fisheries Mr Vella to close loopholes which allow for tuna overfishing, and I hope he – and we – can use this new European Union role to help us to do so.

name: Ivan Jakovčić (ALDE)
text: Written. ‒ I voted for the European Parliament's draft legislative resolution on the Council's draft decision to conclude, on behalf of the European Union, the Agreement in the form of an exchange of letters between the European Union and the Commission for the Conservation of Southern Bluefin Tuna (CCSBT) concerning the Union's membership in the extended commission of the Southern Bluefin Tuna Conservation Convention on the basis that it strengthens the Union's cooperation with the CCSBT, which began in 2006. , and especially because southern bluefin tuna is an endangered species.  I believe it is essential to act with rational and sustainable management of marine resources in mind, and to oppose unregulated and illegal harvesting. The marine ecosystem represents one of the key values of the entire planet that must be preserved at the highest level, and therefore I support all regional and other international organizations operating in this regard. However, in order to achieve such efforts, synergy and joint cooperation between the international community needs to be established, as of course these are issues of global proportions.

name: Jean-François Jalkh (ENF)
text: In writing. The European Union is to join the regional organisation of the Commission for the Conservation of Southern Bluefin Tuna (CCSBT). The Union wants to extend its action in the protection of bluefin tuna to the Indian Ocean. The accession of the Union would inevitably lead to the in line with the national regulations of its Member States, which would take all the traits of a quiet shift in sovereignty. For the past ten years, the European market has been restricted to the import of 10 tonnes of southern bluefin tuna, which comes mainly and only from accidental fisheries. If we relate this figure to the EUR 70,000 in annual fees for participation in this organisation, we are entitled to believe that this initiative is irrelevant in principle, but is even less relevant to European interests. So I abstained.

name: Diane James (EFDD)
text: in writing. – This involves the EU signing an international convention intended to be signed by states. My fellow MEPs and I therefore oppose it, not because we do not care about the tuna – we care very much and want numbers to grow – but because this is another instance of the EU behaving like a state.  What this does is to give the EU a vote in a convention in which voting is the prerogative of full members who are nation states.

name: Marc Joulaud (PPE)
text: In writing. I voted in favour of my colleague Carlos Iturgaiz's report on the recommendation on EU membership of the Extended Commission of the Southern Bluefin Tuna Conservation Convention. To date, the European Union was a non-contracting party and therefore could not vote in this committee. The Union, through this accession, will be able to play a more important and effective role in the implementation of the Convention for the Conservation of Southern Bluefin Tuna.  This recommendation was adopted by a large majority, which I welcome.

name: Philippe Juvin (PPE)
text: In writing. I voted in favour of this report because it approves the Accession of the European Union to the Commission for the Conservation of Bluefin Tuna of the South (CCSBT), thus granting the Union a right to vote, which will be able to take an active part in the implementation of the Convention on the Preservation of this species.

name: Barbara Kappel (ENF)
text: Writing. This report covers the Union's membership of the enlarged Commission of the Southern Bluefin Tuna Convention (CCSBT). The signing of this international instrument will enable the EU to become a full member of the enlarged CCSBT Commission, of which it has been a cooperating non-member since 2006. As I welcome a European role in the conservation of bluefin tuna, I voted in favour of the report.

name: Afzal Khan (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ I supported the report, as EU membership in the CCSBT Extended Commission will promote consistency in the Union’s conservation approach across oceans and reinforce its commitment to the long—term conservation and sustainable use of fisheries resources globally.

name: Giovanni La Via (PPE)
text: in writing. The proposal we are debating today aims to authorise the exchange of letters between the EU and the enlarged Commission of the Convention for the Conservation of Southern Bluefin Tuna (CCSBT). Until 2013, the only status allowed for regional organisations was that of a "cooperating non-contracting party", but this state of affairs subsequently changed, allowing these organisations to become members of the enlarged commission. The proposal is therefore closely linked to this change and I have chosen to vote in favour because it aims to achieve full participation in the activities of the CCSBT.

name: Marine Le Pen (ENF)
text: In writing. If the EU joins the Southern BlueFin tuna Conservation Convention, Member States will be asked to align their positions with that of the Union. It is therefore a small "underground" transfer of sovereignty, against which I am opposed in principle.  Since 2006, the EU has been allocated a quota of 10 tonnes of southern bluefin tuna, but only as bycating catches (i.e. when longliners accidentally fish). The annual participation in this organisation, estimated at 70,000 euros, therefore does not seem relevant in view of the small quantities of southern bluefin tuna caught by EU vessels. However, it is a matter of having an eye on how the stock evolves. So I abstained.

name: Philippe Loiseau (ENF)
text: In writing. The text dealt with the EU's accession to the committee, which is responsible for managing bluefin tuna reserves in the Indian Ocean. While the importance of keeping an eye on this problem is obvious, it is not an issue that we would like to see attributed to the European Union.   Firstly, if the EU were to join this committee (of which it has been a non-contracting member since 2006), Member States would have to align themselves with European positions. A transfer of national sovereignty that does not say its name, to which we are opposed in principle. In addition, since 2006, the EU has been allocated a quota of 10 tonnes of bluefin tuna, provided it is bycating or accidental catches. Membership of this commission would involve an annual EU participation of around 70,000 euros. This commitment is too heavy, given the low interest of 10 "accidental" tonnes of fish caught by and for the EU. I abstained on this vote.

name: Paloma López Bermejo (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. I voted in favour of this report because it is a strengthening of scientific cooperation in relation to the conservation of southern bluefin tuna. The world population of different types of tuna has been at risk, but there are signs of recovery, at least in some of its varieties. That is why scientific cooperation is necessary to have better information at the global level on this resource. Both the survival of this important species and that of the communities that have historically engaged in its artisanal exploitation depend on sustainable and well-founded fisheries policies. Such is the case of Atlantic bluefin tuna and almadraba, which is an important indicator of its population; sharing this information must be critical to raising sustainable fisheries policies. For all of the above, I have decided to vote in favour of this report.

name: Petr Mach (EFDD)
text: Writing. \u2012 Fisheries policy is to be addressed and coordinated by the countries concerned, not by the EU as a whole. Similarly, the EU should not become a member of international organisations as it is not a state.

name: Ivana Maletić (PPE)
text: Written. ‒ The International Commission for the Protection of Atlantic Tuna (ICCAT) is responsible for the preservation of blue-tailed tuna in the Atlantic Ocean, but also in neighbouring seas. As it is an endangered species, the Commission has prescribed countries conditions, harvesting periods and annual quotas based on fishing fleets they own and data in archives. The Southern Bluefin Tuna Conservation Commission was also established, adopting a Resolution in 2013 allowing non-members to participate in the enlarged Composition of the Commission, while respecting certain conditions. I supported mep Carlos Iturguiz's report, as I believe that membership of the enlarged Commission is necessary to contribute to rational and sustainable management of marine resources, and to combat illegal fishing, all with a view to maintaining a natural balance in the sea.

name: Andrejs
text: Mamikins (S&D), in writing. \u2012 As a result of the long-term discussions two years ago, the Southern Tuna Conservation Commission amended the resolution on the enlarged commission, thanks to which regional economic integration organisations could join its activities. Given that the European Union, not to mention the self-evident active participation of its Member States, wanted to be fully involved for quite a long time in the activities of the Enlarged Commission for the conservation of southern tuna, becoming a full member, the support for this draft decision was perfectly logical. The European Commission is actively cooperating with various regional and international bodies whose operational tasks include both monitoring of marine resources and the protection of endangered species. It is well known that the same catch quotas within our community are partly focused on this objective. Southern tuna has been described as a critically endangered species under the International Union for the Conservation of Nature and Natural Resources, so that the implementation of measures relating to their rationally limited catches and conservation is of paramount importance. I cannot say that, in the case of my country, Latvia, this balance fully exists, especially under the circumstances of the current quota and embargo on the part of the Russian Federation.

name: Νότης Μαριάς (
text: ECR), in writing. \u2012 I am voting in favour of the recommendation on the draft Council Decision on the conclusion, on behalf of the European Union, of the Agreement in the form of an Exchange of Letters between the European Union and the Committee for the Conservation of Southern Hemisphere Tuna (CCSBT), with a view to the Union's acquisition of membership in the enlarged Committee for the Conservation of Southern Hemisphere Tuna , because it is complete and documented.

name: Dominique Martin (ENF)
text: In writing. I abstained on this vote. The aim of this vote is to get the Union to join the Commission for the Conservation of Southern Bluefin Tuna (CCSBT), whose convention has been in force since 1994 and of which the Union was until now a non-contracting party. We believe that this accession of the Union, even to monitor and protect bluefin tuna stocks, is not justified by European interests: the Union has only a fishing quota of 10 tonnes (only as accidental catches), yet the annual participation in the CCSBT costs 70,000 euros, a sum that is greatly exaggerated for such a small quantity. It should also be noted that if the Union joins this organisation, the Member States will have to align themselves with the Union, and will lose a small part of sovereignty.

name: Fulvio Martusciello (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the recommendation on EU accession to the enlarged committee of the Convention for the Conservation of Southern Bluefin Tuna. The primary objective of this committee is the management of southern bluefin tuna in all its distribution areas. Since 2006, the European Union has been a non-cooperating non-contractor of the CCSBT's Enlarged Commission, and this implies compliance with the conservation and management measures of that committee. The EU has as one of its priorities to contribute to the rational management of marine resources and to participate in the fight against illegal fishing. It is therefore essential for the European Union to become a full member of the enlarged Commission.

name: Georg Mayer (ENF)
text: Writing. The proposal allows for exchanges between the EU and the CCSBT (Commission for the Conservation of Southern Bluefin Tuna). If adopted, the EU may also vote in this platform. I am therefore in favour of this report.

name: David Martin (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ The European Union must remain very active with all regional fisheries organisations in a bid to contribute to the rational and sustainable management of marine resources and combat illegal, unreported and unregulated fishing. I welcome this cooperation on bluefin tuna.

name: Jean-Luc Mélenchon (GUE/NGL)
text: In writing. The Expanded Commission of the Southern Bluefin Tuna Conservation Convention (CCSBT), established in 1994, aims to ensure, through good management, the optimal conservation and use of southern bluefin tuna. Until 2013, only states could join the CCSBT Convention; Regional Economic Integration Organizations (IEROs), such as the European Union, were therefore excluded. These organizations are now allowed to join. The text before us is intended to allow the Union to join this committee in order to strengthen its commitment to the long-term conservation and sustainable exploitation of fisheries resources around the world. Concerned about fish issues, I'm voting for.

name: Joëlle Mélin (ENF)
text: In writing. The Eu is joining the regional organisation of the Commission for the Conservation of Southern Bluefin Tuna (CCSBT). The Union wants to extend its action in the protection of bluefin tuna to the Indian Ocean. EU membership would inevitably lead to a uniformity of national regulations in this area and an additional loss of sovereignty. For the past ten years, the European market has been restricted to the import of 10 tonnes of southern bluefin tuna, mainly from accidental fisheries. At the same time, the annual fee to participate in this organisation costs 70,000 euros. It therefore appears to the National Front that this initiative is irrelevant and not a priority. Therefore, I abstain.

name: Nuno Melo (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the Recommendation on the draft Council decision on the conclusion, on behalf of the European Union, of the Agreement in the form of an Exchange of Letters between the European Union and the Commission for the Conservation of Southern Tuna (CCSBT) on the union's joining of the Enlarged Commission of the Convention for the Conservation of Southern Tuna. The EU, taking into account the commitments made in the provisions of the UN Convention on the Law of the Sea, should continue to set an example with regard to the rational and sustainable management of marine resources, and in the fight against illegal, unreported and unregulated fishing. The exchange of information is fundamental for the balance and conservation of South Tuna.

name: Roberta Metsola (PPE)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of the EU’s accession to the Extended Commission of the Convention for the Conservation of Southern Bluefin Tuna, as the EU’s active cooperation with regional fisheries organisations is essential in order to contribute to the sustainable management of marine resources and combat illegal, unreported and unregulated fishing.

name: Louis Michel (ALDE)
text: In writing. I welcome the European Parliament's approval of the European Union's accession to the enlarged Commission of the Southern BlueFin tuna Conservation Convention (CCSBT). Now a full member of this regional fishing organisation, the Union will be able to take part in the vote and play the crucial role that is now its promoter of sustainable fishing activities. Through its external policy on fisheries in general and within regional fisheries management organisations (ORPPs) in particular, the Union can and must promote on the international stage the principles it applies internally such as the sustainability of fisheries or the ecosystem approach. At a time when many fish stocks are under threat and illegal, unreported and unregulated fishing is dramatically exacerbating the overexploitation of our seas and oceans, the Union must work towards responsible management of fisheries resources on a global scale. It is not only about the survival of fishing communities around the world, but also about our food security for all of us.

name: Marlene Mizzi (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of the report on accession to the Extended Commission of the Convention for the Conservation of Southern Bluefin Tuna (CCSBT), which concerns authorisation of the exchange of letters between the EU and the Extended Commission. The signing of this instrument of international law will allow the EU to become a full member of the CCSBT Extended Commission, having enjoyed cooperating non-member status since 2006. That is why I voted in favour of the report.

name: Bernard Monot (ENF)
text: In writing. The issue here is to have the Union accede to the Southern Bluefin Tuna Conservation Convention so that it has the right to join and vote on it. The main objective is to strengthen the Union's action in the protection of bluefin tuna, knowing that there are similarities between the management of the southern bluefin tuna (Indian Ocean) and that of the Atlantic. This accession is not really justified by European interests. Moreover, the quotas of southern bluefin tuna allocated to our ships do not exceed 10 tons and in fact cover only accidental catches. For this reason, we abstain.

name: Cláudia Monteiro de Aguiar (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 The Convention for the Conservation of Southern Tuna is a Regional Fisheries Management Organisation (ORGP) responsible for the management of southern tuna in all its distribution areas and has been in force since 20 May 1994. Since the UN Convention on the Law of the Sea in 1982, the EU has adopted a very active policy of participation in all ORGp with the aim of contributing to the efficient, rational and sustainable management of marine resources and to the fight against illegal, unreported and unregulated fishing. This proposal aims to authorise the exchange of letters between the European Union and the Enlarged Commission of the CCSBT, of which it has been a non-cooperating Member since 2006. The conclusion of this Agreement will allow the EU to be a full member of the enlarged CCSBT committee and thus be able to participate fully in its work.  The CCSBT was only open to states, but the October 2013 amendment allowed regional economic integration organisations, such as the EU, to become members of that committee. I support the conclusion of the Agreement so that the EU can be a full member of ccsbt.

name: Sophie Montel (ENF)
text: In writing. This Iturgaiz report concerns the Expanded Commission of the Southern Bluefin Tuna Conservation Convention. This commission (CCSBT) is a regional fisheries organisation responsible for the management of southern bluefin tuna. The Union has been a non-contracting party since 2006. The aim of this report is therefore to have it accede to the 1994 convention establishing this commission to grant it the right to join and vote in the CCSBT. However, there are several problems, such as the requirement to adopt a single position for all EU countries, thus characterizing a further transfer of sovereignty. In addition, since 2006, the EU has been allocated a quota of only 10 tonnes of southern bluefin tuna.
