However, participation in this organization is estimated at 70,000 euros, which is hardly worth it. So I decided to abstain.

name: Nadine Morano (PPE)
text: In writing. The EU has initiated legal proceedings to join the Enlarged Commission of the Southern Bluefin Tuna Conservation Convention (CCSBT). To the extent that Member State-flagged vessels exploit resources in the area covered by this Convention, it is in the EU's interest to play an effective role in its implementation. That is why I voted in favour of this text which will enable the Council to conclude the procedure initiated, at the end of which the Union will have the right to join and vote in the CCSBT.

name: Renaud Muselier (PPE)
text: In writing. I was not able to vote for this report, but I fully support the position of the EPP Group and the French delegation to adopt this report. The Commission for the Conservation of Southern Bluefin Tuna (CCSBT) is a regional fisheries management organisation responsible for the management of southern bluefin tuna in all its distribution areas. The European Union is a non-contracting party cooperating with the CCSBT. On 1 December 2009, the Council authorised the European Commission to request, on behalf of the European Union, an amendment to the CCSTB regulations to enable the European Union to become a contracting party. This report is to approve this accession.

name: Victor Negrescu (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ The Commission for the Conservation of Southern Bluefin Tuna (CCSBT) is a regional fisheries management organisation (RFMO) responsible for the management of southern bluefin tuna wherever it is to be found. The Convention for the Conservation of Southern Bluefin Tuna entered into force on 20 May 1994. The European Union has been a cooperating non-member of the CCSBT Extended Commission since 2006. I voted for this report which will allow the EU to become a full member.

name: Liadh Ní Riada (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. ‒ While we have reservations about the EU representing the Member States in certain capacities, we supported this report with the view that bluefin fish stocks will be better protected from international IUU fishing with the EU as a full Member of CCSBT amongst other members like Japan and South Korea, who have a poor record when it comes to sustainability and overexploitation of stocks.

name: Norica Nicolai (ALDE)
text: in writing. \u2012 I support this report with my vote today, because it supports the Council's decision to authorise the exchange of official letters between the EU and the Commission for the Conservation of Bluefin Tuna in the South, with the aim of eu affiliation with this regional organisation. It is in the EU's interest to become part of this organisation, as vessels flying the flag of the Member States fish in the waters concerned, which also involve by-catches of bluefin tuna. At the same time, this affiliation is part of the EU's objectives of protecting and managing fish stocks in a sustainable way.

name: Franz Obermayr (ENF)
text: Writing. I voted in favour of this proposal as it allows for exchanges between the European Union and the CCSBT (Commission for the Conservation of Southern Bluefin Tuna). This allows the European Union to participate fully in the work of the CCSBT.

name: Younous Omarjee (GUE/NGL)
text: In writing. I voted in favour of this report to approve the European Union's accession to the enlarged Commission of the Convention for the Conservation of Southern Bluefin Tuna (CCSBT). The CCSBT is an international organization responsible for the management of bluefin tuna stocks in all maritime areas where it is present. As the accession of regional organisations to this committee has been possible since 2013, it is important that the Union participates in the coherence and sustainability of European policies on the conservation and exploitation of fisheries resources around the world.

name: Urmas Paet (ALDE)
text: Writing. \u2012 I supported. This will give the EU the opportunity to become a full member of the Commission for the Protection of BlueFin tuna and, in this context, to participate in the Work of the Commission as a fully-fledged member.

name: Rolandas Paksas (EFDD)
text: Writing. \u2012 I agree with the conclusion of this agreement. It is essential that the EU becomes a full member of the Extended Commission of the Astral Tuna Conservation Convention and also acquires the right to vote.  It should be noted that the European Union is actively engaged in a policy of participation in all regional fisheries organisations in order to contribute to the rational and sustainable management of marine resources and to the fight against illegal, unreported and unregulated fishing.  It is in the EU's interest to contribute effectively to the implementation of the Convention by vessels flying the flag of EU Member States fishing for stocks in the Australian tuna area. In addition, membership of this organisation would contribute to a consistent application of the principle of conservation in all oceans, and would also reinforce the commitment to the preservation and sustainable exploitation of fisheries resources throughout the world for a long time.

name: Margot Parker (EFDD)
text: in writing. ‒ This involves the EU signing an international convention intended to be signed by states. We therefore oppose it, not because we do not care about the tuna – we care very much and want numbers to grow – but because this is another instance of the EU behaving like a state. What this does is to give the EU a vote in a convention in which voting is the prerogative of full members who are nation states.

name: Aldo Patriciello (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 I am pleased to be able to renew my commitment to the protection of biodiversity in Europe today, on which I and my colleagues in the ENVI Committee discussed this month in depth.  In addition to having also contributed to amending the dossiers in this area and with motions for resolutions to the Commission, I am voting in favour here for the conservation of southern bluefin tuna.  I would like to thank my colleagues in the Committee on Fisheries for their work and I would like to see a constant dialogue on the subject of species conservation.

name: Marijana Petir (PPE)
text: Written. ‒I welcome the inclusion of the European Union in the extended commission of the Southern Bluefin Tuna Conservation Convention. Southern bluefin tuna has been on the International Federation for Conservation of Nature's (IUCN) Red List of Endangered Species for a long time. Overfishing leads to undermining stocks of this economically significant kind, but also to friction in economic relations between major Asia-Pacific economies such as Austria, New Zealand and Japan, as well as other countries in the world.   Europe, through its overseas and non-European territories, also participates in the fishing of southern bluefin tuna and this fishing also represents an important economic income for European fisheries. Europe has good experience in managing atlantic bluefin tuna stocks through a similar managing authority. In my view, the EU's main interest in the Southern Bluefin Tuna Conservation Commission is to continue to promote a coherent Union approach to tuna conservation in all oceans, thus reaffirming its commitment to the long-term conservation and sustainable use of fishing resources worldwide. That's why I supported this legislative resolution.

name: Florian Philippot (ENF)
text: In writing. This Iturgaiz report concerns the Enlarged Commission of the Southern Bluefin Tuna Conservation Convention. This commission (CCSBT) is a regional fisheries organisation responsible for the management of southern bluefin tuna. The Union has been a non-contracting party since 2006. The aim of this report is therefore to have it accede to the 1994 convention establishing this commission to grant it the right to join and vote in the CCSBT.  However, there are several problems, such as the requirement to adopt a single position for all EU countries, thus characterizing a further transfer of sovereignty.  In addition, since 2006, the EU has been allocated a quota of only 10 tonnes of southern bluefin tuna. However, participation in this organization is estimated at 70,000 euros, which is hardly worth it. So I decided to abstain.

name: Tonino Picula (S&D)
text: Written. ‒ I welcome the efforts towards full inclusion of the European Union in the Southern Bluefin Tuna Conservation Commission (CCSBT). This is an important progress in institutional cooperation in working together to combat illegal fishing and foster rational and sustainable management of marine resources. The European Union has already proven ready to cooperate in regional bodies of this type, and full membership of the CCSBT will give it an even more active role. Tuna farming is certainly the most important activity within the Croatian mariculture, which with a total annual amount contributes about HRK 300 million to the export balance. According to reports this year, supplies of Atlantic bluefin tuna are increasing, which is why ICCAT decided to increase Croatia's catch quotas for the Adriatic.

name: Miroslav Poche (S&D)
text: Writing. \u2012 I am very glad that the European Parliament supported the EU in its decision to become a full member of the Commission of the Convention for the Conservation of Bluefin Tuna (CCSBT). The Commission of the Convention for the Conservation of Bluefin Tuna is the regional fisheries management organisation responsible for managing bluefin tuna stocks throughout its area of occurrence. Until now, membership of the CCSBT convention has only been open to states, and transnational or regional organisations have been excluded from it. At its 20th meeting in October 2013, the CCSBT extended the resolution on the enlarged commission, enabling candidates from regional economic integration organisations to become members. It is certainly a step in the right direction. The European Union pursues a very active fisheries policy and engages with all regional fisheries organisations in order to contribute to the rational and sustainable management of marine resources and the fight against illegal, unreported and unregulated fishing. Bluefin tuna stocks have decreased by more than sixty percent over the past decade in the Mediterranean and Atlantic Oceans, and in the current situation there is a very real danger that it will become extinct altogether. The European Union must continue to advocate greater protection and regulation of fishing for this fish, as well as for the agreed rules of the game to be respected.

name: Salvatore Domenico Pogliese (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 This is a technical report defining the conclusion of the legal process that began in 2013 that will allow the EU to become a full member (with voting rights) of the Commission for the Conservation of 'Southern Bluefin Tuna' (CCSBT).  On the basis of the commitments made in the provisions of the United Nations Convention of 10 December 1982 on the Law of the Sea concerning the conservation and management of transnational fish stocks and highly migratory fish stocks, the European Union has pursued a policy of active participation in all regional fisheries organizations (GPOs).  The EU's main aim is to contribute to the rational and sustainable management of marine resources and the fight against illegal fishing. These organisations carry out management functions, set limits for catches and fishing effort and set technical measures and control obligations. In order to achieve the full participation of the European Union in the activities of the CCSBT, the Community executive, through an exchange of letters, undertakes with the CCSBT to respect the terms of the Convention and to comply with the decisions of the CCSBT's Enlarged Committee.  I am voting in favour of this decision in order to ensure that fish stocks are used more responsibly and fairly.

name: Franck Proust (PPE)
text: In writing. I voted in favour of this report for the European Union to join the enlarged Commission of the Southern Bluefin Tuna Conservation Convention. It makes sense that the European Union can join as an entity, it has an interest in it. European vessels work in the range of bluefin tuna in the South. This will allow it to play an effective role in the implementation of the convention.

name: Paulo Rangel (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 The Commission for the Conservation of Southern Tuna (CCSBT) is a Regional Fisheries Management Organisation (ORGP) responsible for the management of southern tuna (SBF) in all its distribution areas. The Convention for the Conservation of Southern Tuna entered into force on 20 May 1994.  The European Union has been a non-cooperating Member of the enlarged CCSBT Committee since 2006. Non-cooperating Members participate fully in CCSBT's activities but are not entitled to vote.  In October 2013, CCSBT amended the resolution governing the enlarged committee to allow regional economic integration organisations wishing to become members of that committee (until then, they could only accede to the status of non-cooperating Member) by means of an exchange of letters in which the applicant organisation must express to CCSBT a firm commitment to comply with the provisions of the Convention and to comply with the decisions of the enlarged CCSBT committee.  This proposal is precisely aimed at authorising the exchange of letters between the EU and the enlarged CCSBT committee. The signing of this instrument of international law will thus allow the EU to be a full member of the enlarged CCSBT Commission. I voted in favour.

name: Julia Reid (EFDD)
text: in writing. ‒ This involves the EU signing an international convention intended to be signed by states. We therefore oppose it, not because we do not care about the tuna – we care very much and want numbers to grow – but because this is another instance of the EU behaving like a state. What this does is to give the EU a vote in a convention in which voting is the prerogative of full members who are nation states.

name: Liliana Rodrigues (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 With this membership, the EU becomes a full member of the enlarged CCSBT Commission, of which it has been a non-cooperative Member since 2006.

name: Inmaculada Rodríguez-Piñero Fernández (S&D)
text: in writing. From the point of view of global fisheries governance, it is important that the European Union leads the promotion and implementation of sustainable fisheries management. This proposal for EU entry into the Commission for the Conservation of Southern BlueFin tuna (CCSBT) as a full member, thus abandoning the status of 'non-party co-operator' it has been maintaining so far, goes in this regard. Hence my support for it. This new framework will serve to promote coherence of EU approaches across all oceans, for example between southern bluefin tuna management (CCSBT) and Atlantic bluefin tuna (ICCAT), while strengthening its commitment to long-term conservation and sustainable use of fishery resources globally.

name: Claude Rolin (PPE)
text: In writing. I voted yesterday in favour of the agreement between the European Union and the Commission for the Conservation of Southern Bluefin Tuna (CCSBT) on the EU's accession to this regional fishing organisation. The signing of this instrument of international law will enable the European Union to become a full member of the CCSBT. It should be noted that since 2006, the Union has been a non-contracting party cooperating with the enlarged CCSBT. Non-contracting cooperating parties are fully involved in the activities of the CCSBT, but are not entitled to vote. Since 2006, the European Union has been allocated a quota of 10 tonnes of southern bluefin tuna per year for by-catch in the CCSBT convention area.

name: Fernando Ruas (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 This proposal for a recommendation deals with a proposal for a decision so that the European Union can participate fully in the work of the Enlarged Commission of the Convention for the Conservation of Southern Tuna.  With the signing of this instrument of international law, which covers the form of exchange of letters between the European Union and the Commission for the Conservation of South Tuna, the European Union will become a full member of this enlarged Commission, which is an important multilateral instrument for managing fisheries resources in international waters. Like the rapporteur, I fully support the proposal put forward, which is why I voted in favour of this report.

name: Tokia Saïfi (PPE)
text: In writing. I supported this text on the European Commission's accession to the Southern BlueFin tuna Conservation Convention (CCSBT) responsible for the management of southern bluefin tuna in all its distribution areas. At its 20th meeting in October 2013, the CCSBT amended the resolution on the enlarged Commission to allow the European Union to become a member of the CCSBT through an exchange of letters. Until now, the Union was a non-contracting party cooperating with the CCSBT. It is important that the Union plays an effective role in the implementation of the Convention as ships flying the flag of EU Member States exploit resources within the range of bluefin tuna in the South. Once this procedure is complete, the European Union will have the right to join and vote on the enlarged CCSBT and the enlarged scientific committee.

name: Massimiliano Salini (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the proposal concerning the accession of the European Union to the enlarged Commission of the Convention for the Conservation of Southern Bluefin Tuna as I consider it essential that the European Union should have an active and decisive role in the activities of the CCSBT or the Regional Fisheries Management Organisation (ORGP).

name: Lola Sánchez Caldentey (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. We voted in favour of the proposal as the proposal aims to authorise the redemption of notes between the EU and the enlarged Commission of the Southern BlueFin tuna conservation convention (CCSBT). The signing of this instrument of international law will enable the EU to move from non-party to the enlarged Commission to a full member of it. The European Union has been a non-Part of the Commission," which has been expanded since 2006. The CCSBT Convention was only open to States, and regional economic integration organisations (ORIEs), such as the EU, were therefore excluded. The CCSBT amended during its twentieth meeting, held in October 2013, the resolution governing the enlarged Commission, in order to allow ORIEs wishing to do so to become members of the enlarged Commission (until then, the only statute they could access was that of non-Parties co-operators) through a note-following procedure in which the applicant agency expresses its strong commitment to respect for the CCSBT the terms of the Convention and compliance with the decisions of the Enlarged Commission of the CCSBT.

name: Lidia Senra Rodríguez (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. I voted in favour of this report because it is a strengthening of scientific cooperation in relation to the conservation of southern bluefin tuna. The world population of different types of tuna has been at risk, but there are signs of recovery, at least in some of its varieties. That is why scientific cooperation is necessary to have better information at the global level on this resource. Both the survival of this important species and that of the communities that have historically engaged in its artisanal exploitation depend on sustainable and well-founded fisheries policies. Such is the case of Atlantic bluefin tuna and almadraba, which is an important indicator of its population; sharing this information must be critical to raising sustainable fisheries policies. For all of the above, I have decided to vote in favour of this report.

name: Remo Sernagiotto (ECR)
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the European Parliament recommendation on the full participation of the European Union in the activities of the Southern Bluefin Tuna Conservation Commission (CCSBT).  Since 1982, the year of the UNITED Nations Convention on the Law of the Sea, the EU has pursued a policy of active participation in all regional fisheries organisations (GPOs) to ensure that fisheries resources are managed rationally and sustainably.  In order to play an active role in the CCSBT, Parliament has today voted on the decision that will allow the European Union to participate fully in the activities of this organisation in the tuna fisheries sector.

name: Ricardo Serrão Santos (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 The proposal aims to authorise the exchange of letters between the EU and the Enlarged Commission of the Convention for the Conservation of Southern Tuna (CCSBT). The signing of this instrument of international law will allow the EU to become a full member of the enlarged CCSBT committee, of which it has been a non-cooperating member since 2006.  I believe that the european Union's presence in international conventions relating to the exploitation of marine resources is crucial. In addition to a history oriented towards the sustainability of fisheries, the European Union has strengthened and sustained processes of international cooperation that have culminated in a more responsible use of the seas. For all these reasons, I voted positively for this proposal.

name: Jill Seymour (EFDD)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted against this as it involves the EU signing an international convention which should be signed by nation states, not the EU.

name: Siôn Simon (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of the recommendation that the European Union accede to the Extended Commission of the Convention for the Conservation of Southern Bluefin Tuna because I strongly believe that conservation and efforts to maintain our ever dwindling animal populations is integral to the survival of our planet. With the membership I believe that we will be in a better position to protect this fish population and this will have a knock-on effect for conservation elsewhere in the ecosystem.

name: Igor Šoltes (Verts/ALE)
text: Writing. The Recommendation states that the proposal for a Council decision is intended to approve the Exchange of Letters between the European Union and the Extended Commission of the Convention for the Conservation of Southern BlueFin Tuna on behalf of the European Union (CCSBT). The signing of this instrument of international law would make the European Union a full member of the enlarged CCSBT Commission. It is a regional organisation engaged in fisheries management and is responsible for managing southern bluefin tuna wherever it is located. The European Union has been a non-member of the commission since 2006 and would also have full membership and would also have the right to vote. The catch of southern bluefin tuna in EU fleets is due to limited by-catches in tuna and tuna-related longline species. Since 2006, the EU has allocated a quota of 10 tonnes of southern bluefin tuna per year for by-catches in the CCSBT area. I believe that it is important for the EU to participate in regional fisheries organisations, enabling it to contribute to the rational and sustainable management of marine resources and to the fight against illegal, unreported and unregulated fishing. For all the reasons previously written, I voted in favour of the Recommendation by the European Parliament.

name: Davor Ivo Stier (PPE)
text: Written. ‒I support this proposal because the EU is responsible for adopting measures to conserve marine resources under the Common Fisheries Policy and to conclude agreements with third countries and international organisations. On 1 December 2009, the Council authorised the European Commission to request on behalf of the European Union to amend the rules of the Convention for the Conservation of Southern Bluefin Tuna. As vessels flying the flag of the Member States of the European Union hunt fish resources in the area of distribution of southern bluefin tuna, it is in the Union's interest to play an effective role in the implementation of the Convention. In my view, this proposal will promote consistency of the Union's approach to conservation in all seas and reaffirm its commitment to the long-term conservation and sustainable use of fishing resources worldwide.

name: Dubravka Šuica (PPE)
text: Written. \u2012 The Southern Bluefin Tuna Conservation Commission (CCSBT) is the regional fisheries management organisation (RFMO) responsible for managing southern bluefin tuna (SBF) in all areas where it is widespread. Since 2006, the European Union has been a participating non-member of the expanded CCSBT Commission. Non-members participate fully in CCSBT activities but do not have the right to vote. The adoption of the objectives and measures in terms of management and conservation set out in the CCSBT is necessary to obtain the status of non-member. With its proposal for a Council Decision on signature, the European Commission recommended to the Council the signature and provisional application of the exchange of letters in order to gain membership of the enlarged CCSBT Commission.  Due to the similarities between southern bluefin tuna (CCSBT) and Atlantic bluefin tuna (ICCAT), the EU's main interest under the CCSBT is to continue to promote consistency of the Union's approach to conservation in all oceans.  I support this proposal as it seeks to end the legal process initiated by the signing and provisional application of the exchange of letters to gain membership of the enlarged CCSBT Commission, and reaffirms the Union's commitment to the long-term conservation and sustainable exploitation of fishing resources worldwide.

name: Richard Sulík (ECR)
text: Writing. \u2012 I supported the proposal and welcome the full participation of the European Union in this convention.

name: Patricija Šulin (PPE)
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the recommendation on the proposal for a Council decision on the conclusion, on behalf of the European Union, of the Agreement in the form of an Exchange of Letters between the European Union and the Commission for the Conservation of Southern BlueFin Tuna (CCSBT) concerning the Union's membership of the Extended Commission of the Convention for the Conservation of Southern BlueFin tuna. The European Union will thus become a full member of the enlarged Commission, in which a non-member is now a participating member. I support the European Union's participation in all those organisations where it can contribute to the sustainable management of marine resources and to illegal fishing.

name: Kay Swinburne (ECR)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of this proposal, which will allow the EU to become a full member of the Extended Commission of the CCSBT. I welcome EU efforts to ensure international conservation measures are complied with: these measures are essential to protecting stocks of southern bluefin tuna and making sure it does not become endangered.

name: József Szájer (PPE)
text: Writing. \u2012 The EU has already fully adopted the recommendations of the Committee for the Conservation of Southern Bluefin Tuna, which clearly shows that the European Union is being forced to impose appropriate restrictions on sea fishing in order to maintain marine fish stocks. 30% of the earth's seas are overfished and marine fish stocks are at risk. Justified steps to maintain them will result in a continuous and significant reduction in the amount of marine fish fish fished. Therefore, the common fisheries policy should pay much more attention to sustainable fish farming, i.e. aquaculture, and in particular freshwater fish farming.

name: Claudia Tapardel (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 Tuna fishing is closely monitored by certain regional tuna fisheries management organisations. The European Union has pursued a very active policy of cooperation with all regional fisheries management organisations, in line with its commitments under the provisions of the United Nations Convention on the Law of the Sea of 10 December 1982, with regard to the conservation and management of anadromous fish stocks and high migratory fish stocks. The ultimate objective is a rational and sustainable management of marine resources and, last but not least, the fight against illegal, unreported and unregulated fishing. The European Union plays an active role in six of these organisations. The signing of the Convention for the Conservation of Southern Bluefin Tuna (CCSBT), an instrument of international law, will give the Union full membership, although the Union, through the voice of the European Commission, has cooperated with ccSBT since 2006.

name: Marc Tarabella (S&D)
text: In writing. We fully support this text. The proposal is intended to allow the exchange of letters between the European Union and the Enlarged Commission of the Southern BlueFin tuna Conservation Convention (CCSBT). The signing of this instrument of international law will enable the European Union to become a full member of the enlarged CCSBT based on its current status as a cooperating non-contracting party. The European Union has been a non-contracting party to the enlarged CCSBT since 2006. Following commitments in the provisions of the UN Convention on the Law of the Sea of 10 December 1982 on the conservation and management of straddling fish stocks and large migratory fish stocks, the European Union has pursued a very active policy of participation in all regional fisheries management organisations (PMOs) in order to contribute to the rational and sustainable management of marine resources and the fight against the fight against illegal, unreported and unregulated fishing.

name: Pavel Telička (ALDE)
text: in writing. ‒ In this report, which I supported, Parliament gave its consent to an agreement between the European Union and the Commission for the Conservation of Southern Bluefin Tuna (CCSBT) concerning the membership of the EU in the Extended Commission. The EU can thus become a full member of the CCSBT Extended Commission, replacing the status of cooperating non-member that it has had since 2006. The CCSBT is responsible for the management of southern bluefin tuna wherever it is to be found. This move should further the EU’s contribution to the sustainable management of marine resources and combat illegal and unregulated fishing.

name: László Tőkés (PPE)
text: Writing. \u2012 In line with the direction of the European People's Party, I voted in favour of the accession of the EU as a regional economic integration organisation to the Committee for the Conservation of Southern Bluefin Tuna. The EU has already taken full control of the recommendations of the committee in question, which clearly show that the European Union is being forced to impose appropriate restrictions on sea fishing in order to maintain marine fish stocks. 30% of the earth's seas are overfished and marine fish stocks are at risk. Justified steps to maintain them will result in a continuous and significant reduction in the amount of marine fish fish fished. Therefore, the common fisheries policy should pay much more attention to sustainable fish farming, i.e. aquaculture, and in particular freshwater fish farming.  A significant number of fish ponds in Hungary are located in Natura 2000 sites. These farms do not pose any threat to the natural assets of these areas. Moreover, in many cases it is precisely because of our closed-system fish ponds that they have created or preserved individual wetland associations. Consequently, freshwater aquaculture should be prioritised and given as much EU support as possible. Furthermore, this area should be freed from unduly stringent and unnecessary sustainability standards, which are justified only for sea fishing.

name: Valdemar Tomaševski (ECR)
text: Writing. \u2012 The European Union, in developing the commitments set out in the 1982 Provisions of the United Nations Convention on the Law of the Sea relating to the Conservation and Management of Fish Stocks of Close Migration and Mass Migration, is leading a very active policy of participation in all regional fisheries organisations in order to contribute to the rational and sustainable management of marine resources and to the fight against illegal, unported and unregulated fishing. The protection of tuna-like species and similar species in the Atlantic Ocean and adjacent seas is therefore desirable and worthy of support.

name: Ruža Tomašić (ECR)
text: Written. ‒As shadow rapporteur, I supported a report confirming the full membership of the European Union in the extended commission of the Southern Bluefin Tuna Conservation Convention, one of the most valuable marine species.  Since 2006, the European Union has been an external associate of that commission and participates in its activities, but although it must comply with conservation measures, it has no role in decision-making. Southern bluefin tuna is found in waters off the coast of Australia and the Indian Ocean, and is classified as a critically endangered species, meaning it is directly threatened with extinction.  Since 2006, the European Union has been awarded an annual quota of 10 tonnes of accidental catches of the southern bluefin species in this area, which will remain the same as full membership of the enlarged commission. Given that the International Union for Conservation of Nature has found that the southern bluefin tuna population has decreased by 80% in the last three generations, I think it is of utmost importance that the European Union makes a compliance with the terms of the convention and acts in accordance with the commission's decisions, with a view to ensuring and protecting southern bluefin tuna through appropriate management, conservation and optimal use of resources and through measures to prevent illegal catches and black market sales.

name: Romana Tomc (PPE)
text: Writing. - Recommendation on the proposal for a Council decision on the conclusion, on behalf of the European Union, of the Agreement in the form of an Exchange of Letters between the European Union and the Commission for the Conservation of Southern BlueFin Tuna (CCSBT) concerning the Union's membership of the Extended Commission of the Convention for the Conservation of Southern Bluefin Tuna, as the signing of this instrument will give the European Union the status of full member of the extended CCSBT Commission. This will also give EU Member States an important right to vote, which they have not had before.

name: Estefanía Torres Martínez (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. We voted in favour of the proposal as the proposal aims to authorise the redemption of notes between the EU and the enlarged Commission of the Southern BlueFin tuna conservation convention (CCSBT). The signing of this instrument of international law will enable the EU to move from non-party to the enlarged Commission to a full member of it. The European Union has been a non-Part of the Commission," which has been expanded since 2006. The CCSBT Convention was only open to States, and regional economic integration organisations (ORIEs), such as the EU, were therefore excluded. The CCSBT amended during its twentieth meeting, held in October 2013, the resolution governing the enlarged Commission, in order to allow ORIEs wishing to do so to become members of the enlarged Commission (until then, the only statute they could access was that of non-Parties co-operators) through a note-following procedure in which the applicant agency expresses its strong commitment to respect for the CCSBT the terms of the Convention and compliance with the decisions of the Enlarged Commission of the CCSBT.

name: Ramon Tremosa i Balcells (ALDE)
text: in writing. ‒ Any action taken by this Parliament for the rational and sustainable management of marine resources and to combat illegal fishing will have my support. Marine resources are limited and we must ensure the conservation and management of straddling fish stocks and highly migratory fish stocks.

name: Mylène Troszczynski (ENF)
text: In writing. This accession of the European Union, even to monitor and protect bluefin tuna stocks in the Indian Ocean, is not really justified by European interests. Moreover, the quotas of southern bluefin tuna allocated to our ships do not exceed 10 tons and in fact cover only accidental catches. So I choose abstention.

name: István Ujhelyi (S&D)
text: Writing. \u2012 The proposal aims to authorised an exchange of letters between the EU and the Extended Commission for the Conservation of Southern Bluefin Tuna (CCSBT). By signing this instrument of international law, the EU would gain full membership of the CCSBT Extended Committee instead of the status of a non-current non-member cooperating party. I supported the proposal.

name: Miguel Urbán Crespo (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. We voted in favour of the proposal as the proposal aims to authorise the redemption of notes between the EU and the enlarged Commission of the Southern BlueFin tuna conservation convention (CCSBT). The signing of this instrument of international law will enable the EU to move from non-party to the enlarged Commission to a full member of it. The European Union has been a non-Part of the Commission," which has been expanded since 2006. The CCSBT Convention was only open to States, and regional economic integration organisations (ORIEs), such as the EU, were therefore excluded. The CCSBT amended during its twentieth meeting, held in October 2013, the resolution governing the enlarged Commission, in order to allow ORIEs wishing to do so to become members of the enlarged Commission (until then, the only statute they could access was that of non-Parties co-operators) through a note-following procedure in which the applicant agency expresses its strong commitment to respect for the CCSBT the terms of the Convention and compliance with the decisions of the Enlarged Commission of the CCSBT.

name: Ivo Vajgl (ALDE)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of the resolution on the draft Council decision on the conclusion, on behalf of the European Union, of the Agreement in the form of an Exchange of Letters between the European Union and the Commission for the Conservation of Southern Bluefin Tuna (CCSBT) concerning the membership of the Union in the Extended Commission. It concerns the authorisation of the exchange of letters between the EU and the CCSBT Extended Commission. The signing of this instrument of international law will allow the EU to become a full member of the Extended Commission, having enjoyed cooperating non-member status since 2006, and I agree that the EU, represented by the Commission, should play an active role in the six regional tuna fisheries management organisations.

name: Ramón Luis Valcárcel Siso (PPE)
text: in writing. We are talking about a proposal to authorise the redemption of notes between the EU and the Enlarged Commission of the Southern BlueFin tuna conservation convention (CCSBT). By signing this instrument of international law, the EU goes from cooperating non-part of the enlarged CCSBT Commission to being a full member of the CCSBT. That is why I think it is appropriate to vote in favour of this proposal.

name: Ángela Vallina (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. I voted in favour of this report because it is a strengthening of scientific cooperation in relation to the conservation of southern bluefin tuna. The world population of different types of tuna has been at risk, but there are signs of recovery, at least in some of its varieties. That is why scientific cooperation is necessary to have better information at the global level on this resource. Both the survival of this important species and that of the communities that have historically engaged in its artisanal exploitation depend on sustainable and well-founded fisheries policies. Such is the case of Atlantic bluefin tuna and almadraba, which is an important indicator of its population; sharing this information must be critical to raising sustainable fisheries policies. For all of the above, I have decided to vote in favour of this report.

name: Hilde Vautmans (ALDE)
text: Written. 'I have chosen the EU's accession to the Comprehensive Commission of the Convention for the Conservation of Southern Bluefin Tuna because I am convinced that this membership will bring more coherence to the European approach to better protect maritime areas. In addition, this membership demonstrates the European commitment to maintain and use the global fish stock in a sustainable manner.

name: Miguel Viegas (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. \u2012 This agreement will allow the EU to become a member of the enlarged committee of CCSBT, a multilateral instrument for the management of fisheries resources in international waters. A management methodology with which we agree, where cooperation between stakeholders allows the definition of common rules, which everyone commits voluntarily and responsibly. This Commission, in particular, is particularly relevant because of the importance of the resource exploited, South tuna. We voted in favour.

name: Harald Vilimsky (ENF)
text: Writing. The proposal allows for exchanges between the EU and the CCSBT (Commission for the Conservation of Southern Bluefin Tuna). If adopted, the EU may also vote in this platform. I am therefore in favour of this report.

name: Daniele Viotti (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of this recommendation because I am convinced of the need for the EU to play a strategic role in the conservation and management of transnational fish stocks and highly migratory fish stocks. The fisheries sector is one of the most important economic sectors of European territory and that is why the institutions must ensure that a policy of active participation in all regional fisheries organisations is put in place in order to ensure rational and sustainable management of fishery resources and a clear and determined fight against illegal, undeclared and unregulated fishing.

name: Beatrix von Storch (ECR)
text: Writing. The resolution on Southern bluefin tuna (Thunnus maccoyii) is not about the mutual exchange of tried and tested kitchen recipes for the production of sushi and sashimi, but about further regulation of the EU's external fisheries relations for the protection of the most overfished tuna species. Since, understandably, this problem cannot be settled by a single Member State on its own, a common EU position makes sense here. That is why I voted in favour. The European Commission is already involved in six regional tuna fisheries organisations. The EU is now becoming a full member of the "Extended Commission of the Convention on the Conservation of Southern Bluefin Tuna (CCSBT)". This resolution gives the green light to this. The signing of this international instrument will enable the EU to become a full member of the enlarged CCSBT Commission, of which it has been a cooperating non-member since 2006. However, it remains critical to monitor how and whether the EU, with its legitimate demands against the permanent overfishing of tuna, can prevail, especially with regard to Japan. And then we wait and see when the House will table a resolution on an EU-wide ban on tuna consumption.

name: Θεόδωρος Ζαγοράκης (PPE)
text: Writing. \u2012 This initiative, which I voted for, was adopted by a large majority by the committee responsible for fisheries. The text lays down the conditions for better cooperation and participation of the regional organisations concerned.

name: Inês Cristina Zuber (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. \u2012 The signing of the Agreement in the form of an Exchange of Letters between the European Union and the Commission for the Conservation of Southern Tuna (CCSBT) on EU membership of the Enlarged Commission of the Convention for the Conservation of South Tuna will allow the EU to become a member of the Enlarged Commission of CCSBT, a multilateral instrument for managing fisheries resources in international waters. A management methodology with which we agree, where cooperation between stakeholders allows the definition of common rules, which everyone commits voluntarily and responsibly. This Commission, in particular, is of particular importance because of the importance of the resource exploited, South tuna. We voted in favour.

name: Milan Zver (PPE)
text: Writing. \u2012 I supported the European Parliament's legislative resolution on the draft Council decision on the conclusion, on behalf of the European Union, The Agreement in the form of an Exchange of Letters between the European Union and the Commission for the Conservation of Southern Bluefin Tuna (CCSBT) concerning the Membership of the Union in the Extended Commission of the Convention for the Conservation of Southern BlueFin Tuna (07134/2015), C8-0323/2015 – 2015/0036(NLE)) as the signing of this instrument of international law would make the European Union a full member of the enlarged CCSBT Commission. I support the Union's very active participation in all regional fisheries organisations and contribute to the rational and sustainable management of marine resources and the fight against Illegal, Unreported and Unregulated Fishing.

name: Andrejs Mamikins (S&D).
text: – The prospective directive on insurance mediation is one of the most important steps in improving the rights of citizens of the European Union. This applies both to natural and legal persons travelling, working or simply present in the territory of their Own Member State and beyond its borders. Regardless of where the beneficiary of the insurance policy is located, the protection received must be of equal quality. The same shall apply to the receipt of information, advice and, in general, any other assistance that the insured person may receive from the policy distributor and its associated bodies. An important aspect of this draft directive is also the incenti up of free competition between insurance distributors, as well as the ability of insurance intermediaries to operate throughout the Community. As regards the dissemination of information and guaranteeing its availability, it should also not be noted that this Directive could help to level the likelihood of the consumer also facing previously unknown or clearly unspecification costs. I voted in favour.

name: Daniel Hannan (ECR).
text: – Mr President, completing the single market in services means two very different things. Most people would understand it to mean free trade in services. If you can sell a product in one Member State, it should be equally available in other Member States. In other words, mutual product recognition just like we have for traded goods. But, of course, that is not what is contained in this report. What is contained here is an idea for a common regulatory structure where, instead of simply enabling more free circulation of services, we are laying down rules on consumer protection, etc. that must be evenly applied across all Member States. We thereby raise barriers to entry and we create a more regulated, more restricted, and tighter market than we would otherwise have. This has been the fundamental flaw in the European market model right from the beginning: instead of extending consumer choice, we restrict it for the sake of vested interests and established producers. In Britain we want a common market – we do not want a common regulatory structure. That is why I hope my countrymen will vote to leave.

name: Jonathan Arnott (EFDD).
text: – Mr President, this report does call for the level of consumer protection to be raised, and of course I commend that. But it only does so within the context of reducing the need for national measures, reducing the ability of national governments to take their own decisions on matters such as this. It is designed to increase the scope of firms that are covered by EU regulation and by the EIOPA. So I have a problem with it fundamentally for that reason. This is something which would be better done at Member State level than by the European Union. But I have another problem with it, which is that it gives the Commission power to issue delegated acts; it gives it power, effectively, for legislation to be created without it ever coming back through this place. So it will be the unelected Commission, not the elected Parliament, that takes decisions on this in future, which is fundamentally wrong in my view.

name: William (The Earl of) Dartmouth (EFDD)
text: in writing. ‒ Whilst the legislation calls for the level of consumer protection to be raised, it does so only to reduce the need for varying national measures. It increases the scope of firms covered by EU regulation and the powers of EIOPA and, although it reduces the regulatory burden for SMEs selling travel and car rental insurance, it gives the Commission more powers to issue delegated acts.

name: Clara Eugenia Aguilera García (S&D)
text: in writing. I voted in favour of this proposal for a Directive which aims to increase transparency and consumer rights in the insurance market. In particular, it seeks to prevent financial service users from being forced to accept the purchase of insurance when they contract with financial institutions. Such rules help to ensure strict regulation of markets and financial products, which is especially necessary in the after-the-summer crisis of 2007, which highlighted the very negative consequences of deregulation promoted by neoliberal policies. The agenda for financial regulation is a priority of the European Socialists and Social Democrats, and therefore we will continue to work along this line throughout this legislature.

name: Marina Albiol Guzmán (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. I have not been able to vote in favour of this report because, despite containing positive elements on consumer protection, the outcome of the tripartite dialogue will not contribute to improving the transparency of the sector.  The Directive provides for greater consumer protection, as well as improved information and transparency in certain products. However, it leaves out the insurance of investments and financial products, which is a complex framework that can sometimes hide speculative transactions based on risk management. In order to avoid impacts that can even reach sovereign debt, as happened during 2012, full transparency in relation to these activities is necessary, something that this Directive does not propose. That's why I haven't been able to vote for it.

name: Pascal Arimont (PPE)
text: Writing. As a member of the Committee on the Internal Market and Consumer Protection in the European Parliament (IMCO), I particularly welcome the new directive on insurance mediation adopted in plenary, which is due to enter into force at the end of 2017, as it will better protect against misconsultation in this area, which is sometimes very complex, make the business with insurance more transparent and raise the overall level of consumer protection. In future, European consumers will be better informed, advised and able to compare the various offers more easily when buying insurance. The latter is also to be achieved, among other things, by means of standardised fact sheets. However, in order not to unnecessarily confuse consumers and for reasons of equal treatment, the new rules will apply not only to insurance companies and insurance brokers, but also to all companies that sell insurance, including, for example.B travel agencies and car rental companies.

name: Marie-Christine Arnautu (ENF)
text: In writing. This report supports regulation of the insurance intermediation market that is favourable to policyholders and the self-employed. It fundamentally changes the MIF2 Directive and the basis for the practice of the brokering profession, particularly with regard to the definition of an independent intermediary. Insurance companies and banks will no longer be able to stifle independent advisors and exercise a monopoly on this professional activity. There was an urgent need for the European Parliament to take away the powers of the banking and insurance lobbies. I therefore voted in favour of this report.

name: Jean Arthuis (ALDE)
text: In writing. I voted in favour of this report, which aims to inform insurance consumers about the nature of the distributor's remuneration and, for some complex life insurance products, the total cost of the insurance contract, including advice and services costs.

name: Inés Ayala Sender (S&D)
text: in writing. I voted in favour of this proposal for a Directive which aims to increase transparency and consumer rights in the insurance market. In particular, it seeks to prevent financial service users from being forced to accept the purchase of insurance when they contract with financial institutions. Such rules help to ensure strict regulation of markets and financial products, which is especially necessary in the after-the-summer crisis of 2007, which highlighted the very negative consequences of deregulation promoted by neoliberal policies. The agenda for financial regulation is a priority of the European Socialists and Social Democrats, and therefore we will continue to work along this line throughout this legislature.

name: Zigmantas Balčytis (S&D)
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of this proposal, which aims to update the rules on insurance mediation aimed at ensuring greater protection for policyholders, preventing the provision of false and misleading information and harmonising the requirements for the provision of insurance services.  The new rules state that all insurers will have to be registered with the competent authorities of the EU countries where they are domiciled and the staff of insurance undertakings will have to be properly trained. Persons acquiring insurance will have to obtain unambiguous standard information about the identity of the agent selling insurance, the type of insurance, the buyer's obligations, the risks covered, the insurance premiums, the contract price, etc. before the contract is signed. In order to protect customers from the insolvency of insurance intermediaries, insurers will have to ensure that 4% of annual premiums, but at least EUR 18 750, are always freely available.

name: Gerard Batten (EFDD)
text: in writing. ‒ Whilst the legislation calls for the level of consumer protection to be raised, it does so only to reduce the need for varying national measures. It increases the scope of firms covered by EU regulation and the powers of EIOPA and, although it reduces the regulatory burden for SMEs selling travel and car rental insurance, it gives the Commission more powers to issue delegated acts.

name: Nicolas Bay (ENF)
text: In writing. The report supports regulation of the insurance intermediation market that is favourable to policyholders and the self-employed. It substantially changes the MIF2 Directive and the basis for the practice of the broker profession. Insurance companies and banks will no longer be able to stifle independent advisors and exercise a monopoly on this professional activity. That is why I voted in favour of this report, which I think is going in the right direction.

name: Hugues Bayet (S&D)
text: In writing. The European Parliament has just voted on a legislative update on insurance. From now on, when they buy an insurance product, citizens will be better informed, better protected. Measures are also planned for insurance distributors and sales staff to more effectively meet customer needs. Distributors of insurance products will be required to register, this registration will be with a competent authority in their Home Member State. In addition, regular training and updating will be required for sales staff. Continuous vocational training of at least 200 hours over five years will also have to be provided. This amendment is a real step forward in this area and I fully support it.

name: Izaskun Bilbao Barandica (ALDE)
text: in writing. I would like to thank the rapporteur for his work in reaching such an important agreement on insurance mediation with the Council which lays down rules on access to and exercise of insurance distribution activities within the Union. It shall apply to a natural or legal person established in or wishing to establish himself in a Member State to undertake and exercise the distribution of insurance and re-insured products.

name: Dominique Bilde (ENF)
text: In writing. I voted in favour of this text, which calls for an overhaul of the DIA1 directive on insurance intermediation from a consumer protection perspective. It offers, in fact, a complete regulation of the insurance sector by integrating all intermediaries which ensures customers more complete information. This new directive, known as DIA2, extends its scope to all channels for the distribution of insurance products, which updates the legal framework by taking into account new players such as bank insurers, comparators, travel agencies or any other intermediary. In addition, the registration process is subject to new conditions to create a single register that will centralize information on market participants. Finally, the requirements of professional skills and the duty of advice are strengthened. It is therefore a report that is in line with the defence of the interests of consumers.

name: Mara Bizzotto (ENF)
text: in writing. \u2012 The Langen report analysing the updating of the text in force since 2002 on insurance mediation is acceptable and well thought out.  I believe that the choice of a directive, rather than a regulation, will guarantee, when applying the text, the prerogatives of each individual Member State, ensuring the right balance between the legitimate interests of the market and the requirements of consumer protection.  For all these reasons, I wanted to vote in favour of it.

name: José Blanco López (S&D)
text: in writing. I voted in favour of this proposal for a Directive which aims to increase transparency and consumer rights in the insurance market. In particular, it seeks to prevent financial service users from being forced to accept the purchase of insurance when they contract with financial institutions. Such rules help to ensure strict regulation of markets and financial products, which is especially necessary in the after-the-summer crisis of 2007, which highlighted the very negative consequences of deregulation promoted by neoliberal policies. The agenda for financial regulation is a priority of the European Socialists and Social Democrats, and therefore we will continue to work along this line throughout this legislature.

name: Vilija Blinkevičiūtė (S&D)
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted on this report, which deals with the distribution of insurance products. Insurance products can be distributed by various persons or institutions, such as agents, brokers and bank insurance operators, insurance companies, travel agents and car rental companies. Equal treatment between operators and customer protection requires all those persons or authorities to be covered by this Directive. This Directive is intended only for minimum harmonisation and member states should not be prevented from maintaining or adopting more stringent provisions in order to protect consumers, provided that such provisions are compatible with European Union law, including this Directive. Consumers must enjoy the same level of protection, regardless of the different distribution channels. In order to ensure a uniform level of protection for consumers and to enable consumers to benefit from comparable standards, in particular in the area of disclosure, it is important to create a level playing field for distributors.

name: Andrea Bocskor (PPE)
text: Writing. \u2012 The regulation of the activities of insurance brokers and insurance intermediaries has already been put on the agenda of all governments around the world, including the Hungarian Government. The European Commission has also recognised the importance of consumer protection, as it has in the past sought to promote cross-border mediation through various internal market measures, but we now know that consumer protection in itself contributes to the growth of the internal market. Greater harmonisation is necessary in the interests of all parties concerned, but for some Member States the standards may prove so stringent that they constitute a market barrier.  As far as information requirements are concerned, I believe that transparency in the remuneration system is indeed necessary where requested by customers, but top-down regulation can lead to unnecessary bureaucracy. I believe that, in the end, a system has been developed that works in the interests of consumers. Of course, many of the 28 Member States believe that their system is the best, but this does not mean a single internal market. If a person has passed a qualification system, it must be recognised in other Member States. The current proposal will alleviate the often cumbersome functioning of the current system, which is why I voted in favour of it.

name: Simona Bonafè (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 I strongly supported Mr Langen's report on insurance mediation. This new directive, the result of three years of work, is a small but decisive instrument towards a stronger single market in insurance products. The Directive regulates direct distribution by giving uniform rules, legal certainty and regulatory coherence to all sales channels in the sector. From its entry into force, it will be implemented within the territory of the Union in twenty-four months. There are many advantages, primarily for consumers: in addition to specific measures to protect them, common principles are recognised to ensure greater transparency. In addition, the burden of cross-border access to insurance products is reduced, allowing european citizens to have a wider choice. Other important measures concern the registration and qualification of insurance companies, as well as the provision of a strengthened system of product surveillance. It is a new result towards consolidating the financial integration of the European Union.

name: Biljana Borzan (S&D)
text: Written. ‒ I support this Insurance Brokerage Report. I believe that this Agreement will improve the way insurance products are sold, and ensure better protection of consumers and investors, in particular through greater transparency of prices and costs, prevention of conflicts of interest and better information and advice when selling insurance products.

name: Steeve Briois (ENF)
text: In writing. This Intermediation Directive (DIA2) follows the DIA1 directive of 9 December 2002 which was to strengthen competition and regulation governing the activity of insurance intermediaries. The 2008 financial crisis exposed the shortcomings of the old legislation, particularly in terms of market distortions. Hence the interest of this new directive, which extends its scope to all channels for the distribution of insurance products. DIA2 also recommends better informing clients about how salespeople are paid, but also about the risk of capital loss they incur on certain financial investments. We welcome this new directive which supports the self-employed in the face of large financial institutions. Registered insurance intermediaries will now be allowed to access and operate insurance intermediation activity in the EU under both free establishment and free provision of services. Finally, we are pleased to see that customers will benefit from better information about the increasingly complex financial products to which they subscribe. So I voted for this report.

name: Daniel Buda (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 The European Parliament's draft legislative resolution on insurance intermediation aims to reform Directive 2002/92/EC with the aim of harmonising national provisions in the insurance distribution sector with a view to applying the same level of consumer protection. Insurance and reinsurance intermediaries have a primary role to play in the distribution of insurance and reinsurance products within the Union. Thus, since insurance products may be distributed by different categories of persons or institutions such as agents, brokers and agents of bank insurance, insurance undertakings, travel agents and car rental companies, it is necessary that all such persons or institutions are covered by this Directive with a view to ensuring equal treatment between agents and consumer protection. The proposed Directive results in the creation of the same level of protection for consumers, irrespective of distribution channels, while ensuring a level playing field between distributors. Given that there are still considerable differences between the provisions of national law which prevent access to insurance and reinsurance distribution activities and the pursuit of these activities in the internal market, the draft legislative resolution becomes appropriate in strengthening the internal market for the intermediation of insurance products, which is why I voted in favour of this report.

name: Gianluca Buonanno (ENF)
text: in writing. \u2012 Positive vote. Insurance distribution is, in fact, a sector affected by a level of harmonisation which differs from the general rules of the Union's internal market. In this case, we are faced with the express intention of having a minimum harmonisation of the insurance sector (and this is, in itself, a good thing for our delegation). The text also gives attention to consumer standards, which, on the other hand, must maintain a certain level of protection in each Member State. In our opinion, this directive seems to maintain the right balance between the legitimate interest of the market (in accordance with the principle of freedom of establishment) and the requirements for the protection of users of insurance services. This directive should bring us closer to an internal market for 'life' and 'non-life' insurance products and services. The text defines precisely the scope, the excluded sectors and the tasks of the Authorities of the Member States (exchange of information, provision of points of single contact). The directive, which does not intend to impose new burdens on companies, will have to be reviewed five years after its entry into force also in order to assess its correct application of the principle of proportionality. Among the changes made by the agreement with the Council is also the same title as the directive that will become: 'Insurance distribution', rather than brokerage. I am voting in favour.

name: Soledad Cabezón Ruiz (S&D)
text: in writing. I voted in favour of this proposal for a Directive which aims to increase transparency and consumer rights in the insurance market. In particular, it seeks to prevent financial service users from being forced to accept the purchase of insurance when they contract with financial institutions. Such rules help to ensure strict regulation of markets and financial products, which is especially necessary in the after-the-summer crisis of 2007, which highlighted the very negative consequences of deregulation promoted by neoliberal policies. The agenda for financial regulation is a priority of the European Socialists and Social Democrats, and therefore we will continue to work along this line throughout this legislature.

name: Alain Cadec (PPE)
text: In writing. I voted in favour of the insurance distribution directive. It is important that policyholders benefit from excellent service in the European market. Harmonizing the rules of insurance distributors and intermediaries was essential to increase the level of transparency and consumer protection. The information provided to customers will be more important so that customers can choose their products with full knowledge of the facts. Distributors and intermediaries will have to register with the competent authority of the Member State of origin in order to create a register that reveals the identity of the latter. All of these rules will contribute to a more transparent and efficient insurance market.

name: Nicola Caputo (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 After careful consideration and discussion in this House, I voted in favour of the supplementary report on the proposal for a directive of the European Parliament and of the Council on insurance mediation, as I believe that the principle of consumer protection is a key value.  I therefore agree with the proposal for a directive harmonising insurance regulation, making the link with banking discipline more coherent and strengthening the resilience of the European financial system to self-induced and hetero-induced events. I support the objective of increasing the level of consumer protection, in particular through greater transparency about the price and cost of insurance, better and more comprehensible information, and rules on business conduct, in order to prevent consumers from buying products that do not meet their needs. I firmly believe that the objective of saving on insurance policy, combined with the mitigation of distortions of competition for the insurance sector, necessarily requires harmonisation of the system at European level and a European strengthening of end-user protection.

name: Matt Carthy (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. ‒ This legislative resolution provides users of insurance products with strengthened consumer rights across the EU. A positive aspect of the report is the placing of an obligation on insurance companies to show systematically that they have taken consumers’ needs into account from the commencement of any insurances product’s development. However, the proposed directive does not provide the requisite level of transparency on the insurance business as a whole: transparency rules are currently in place for investment funds and other investment products, and they should also extend to insurance investment products. Furthermore, insurance intermediaries will be able to continue receiving commissions without having to disclose them, which I find particularly disconcerting. While it is recognised that the new rules strengthen consumer protection to some degree, particularly in comparison to the predecessor IMD I, the lack of transparency meant that I abstained on this resolution.

name: James Carver (EFDD)
text: in writing. ‒ Whilst the legislation calls for the level of consumer protection to be raised, it does so only to reduce the need for varying national measures. It increases the scope of firms covered by EU regulation and the powers of EIOPA and, although it reduces the regulatory burden for SMEs selling travel and car rental insurance, it gives the Commission more powers to issue delegated acts.

name: David Casa (PPE)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of this report because the directive currently in place needed to be updated in order to ensure more transparency and conditions for fairer competition on the market. The new directive will aim to protect policyholders better and generally to enhance the services offered to them.

name: Fabio Massimo Castaldo (EFDD)
text: in writing. \u2012 The European Commission proposed to introduce an obligation to provide full information on the level of compensation received by intermediaries. Unfortunately, this obligation has disappeared in the final text. As a result, intermediaries would now be free to continue receiving commissions without the obligation to "disclose". If the final text brings with it significant improvements, such as new transparency rules and consumer information protection, we have chosen to abstain.

name: Λευτέρης Χριστοφόρου (
text: PPE), in writing. \u2012 Having regard to the Commission's proposal to the European Parliament and the Council and having regard to the supplementary report of the Committee on Economic and Monetary Affairs and considering that, according to the Advisory Group of the Legal Services of the European Parliament, the Council and the Commission, the Commission's proposal contains no substantial amendments other than those identified in that proposal. In addition, the Commission is asked to resubmit the proposal if it intends to make significant amendments to it or replace it in a new text. That is why the report is important and we support it positively.

name: Κώστας Χρυσόγονος (
text: GUE/NGL), in writing. \u2012 In the report on the proposal for a directive of the European Parliament and of the Council on insurance mediation I decided to abstain in the final vote. Indeed, the report contains many positive elements, strengthening consumer protection and paying great attention to consumers' right to information on insurance products. However, the proposed directive does not provide sufficient guarantees of transparency, in particular as regards the procurement of insurance intermediaries, thus leaving consumers exposed to exploitation.

name: Salvatore Cicu (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the recast proposal for a directive on insurance mediation (Directive 2002/92/EC). This proposal aims to improve the regulation of the retail insurance market, to ensure a level playing field between all participants involved in the sale of insurance products and to strengthen the protection of policyholders.  The new directive should extend the scope of Directive 2002/92/EC to all distribution channels; clarify the exercise of freedom of establishment, the freedom to provide services, and the powers of supervisory authorities; identify, manage and mitigate conflicts of interest; increase the level of harmonisation of sanctions and administrative measures in the event of a breach of the key provisions of the current directive; improve the adequacy and objectivity of consumer advice; ensure that the professional qualifications of sellers correspond to the complexity of the products sold; simplify and harmonise the procedure for cross-border entry to insurance markets across the EU. Finally, the new directive should ensure greater transparency and information for the benefit of consumers.

name: Alberto Cirio (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of Werner Langen's report on insurance mediation. I think, like the rapporteur, that this directive needs to be amended in order to clarify matters. In order to be more useful, the directive should aim better at coordinating national provisions on access to insurance distribution activities, which must also be facilitated by changes that would benefit those who may be interested in taking out insurance on an asset he has purchased.  With regard to these transactions, I think that in order to benefit the client we must work on intermediation, and in this I am in line with the honourable Member's report, which I can fully support.

name: Deirdre Clune (PPE)
text: in writing. ‒ We are going to see more transparency and quality for consumers and sellers alike. Consumers will receive substantial information on the type and origin of bonuses for intermediaries. This means a strengthened role for the customer. Member States will mutually recognise the qualifications of insurance mediators, and there will be regular training and quality-check requirements. Supervisory authorities will exchange information to prevent bad practice and to be able to improve risk assessments. The new rules have been agreed on by Parliament and the Member States and will enter into force in late 2017.

name: David Coburn (EFDD)
text: in writing. ‒ Whilst the legislation calls for the level of consumer protection to be raised, it does so only to reduce the need for varying national measures. It increases the scope of firms covered by EU regulation and the powers of EIOPA and, although it reduces the regulatory burden for SMEs selling travel and car rental insurance, it gives the Commission more powers to issue delegated acts.

name: Birgit Collin-Langen (PPE)
text: Writing. I voted in favour of the report because the new rules on insurance distribution will bring much more clarity, transparency and legal certainty to not only the consumer, but also to small insurance offices through better information. This also applies to the costs of the remuneration of insurance intermediaries. In addition, a single level-playing field will be created, so that the same level of protection will apply to all insurance distribution channels. I support the introduction of uniform product sheets, because this will enable consumers to compare the basic information of various insurance offers in other Member States, as is already provided for in other financial products.

name: Jane Collins (EFDD)
text: in writing. – Whilst the legislation calls for the level of consumer protection to be raised, it does so only to reduce the need for varying national measures. It increases the scope of firms covered by EU regulation and the powers of EIOPA and, although it reduces the regulatory burden for SMEs selling travel and car rental insurance, it gives the Commission more powers to issue delegated acts.

name: Lara Comi (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 The proposal for a directive on insurance mediation aims to improve the regulation of the insurance market. This proposal aims to ensure a level playing field between all those involved in the sale of insurance products, while also offering greater protection to the underwriters of these contracts. I have chosen to vote in favour of this report because, thanks to regulatory changes, consumers and investors who decide to buy insurance products will be able to obtain many benefits. Firstly, greater transparency will be ensured: insurance agents will have to be more transparent in terms of the price and cost of their products, having an obligation to offer the customer detailed and well-compred information, so that consumers can make more informed decisions. Secondly, the new rules on transparency and business conduct will ensure that consumers are not sold products that do not fully meet their needs.

name: Therese Comodini Cachia (PPE)
text: in writing. ‒ This directive is an updated revised edition to replace existing EU standards that pertain to transparency and standards for the allocation of rewards to agents and mediators. This directive is not confined to one part of the distribution chain but applies to all sections of direct sale through the insurance company to banks or mediators. Also the report eliminates conditions where the sale of a home loan is determined by the additional purchase of insurance. I voted in favour.

name: Ignazio Corrao (EFDD)
text: in writing. \u2012 This is an update of the Insurance Brokerage Directive (IMD 1) dating back to 2002. The text was amended and voted on in the ECON Committee during the last parliamentary term. During the current one, trilogues were held with the Council and the Commission (again with the rapporteur himself).  The most important innovations introduced by IMD 2 are: extension of the scope of the legislation to all categories of intermediaries, to those performing ancillary functions and, above all, to insurance companies operating in a direct sales model; introduction of many transparency rules and much more consumer information; request for higher professional requirements and good repute for insurance intermediaries; request for a detailed analysis of the appropriateness of the instruments sold to consumers; greater alignment with MIFID.  However, the original proposal provided for the introduction of the obligation to provide full information on the level of remuneration received by intermediaries.
