This obligation does not appear in the final text. Intermediaries will therefore be free to continue receiving commissions without the disclosure obligation. However, this is the only critical point of the Directive. For the rest, IMD 2 is still a step ahead of IMD1. That is why I have chosen to abstain in plenary.

name: Javier Couso Permuy (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. I have not been able to vote in favour of this report because, despite containing positive elements on consumer protection, the outcome of the tripartite dialogue will not contribute to improving the transparency of the sector.  The Directive provides for greater consumer protection, as well as improved information and transparency in certain products. However, it leaves out the insurance of investments and financial products, which is a complex framework that can sometimes hide speculative transactions based on risk management. In order to avoid impacts that can even reach sovereign debt, as happened during 2012, full transparency in relation to these activities is necessary, something that this Directive does not propose. That's why I haven't been able to vote for it.

name: Andrea Cozzolino (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 The resolution contains the compromise text reached between the European Parliament and the Council and aims to improve the regulation of the retail insurance market and regulate distribution activities through greater harmonisation of national legislation.  I voted in favour of this resolution because it will bring considerable benefits for both insurance operators and European consumers. In particular, it will help to ensure a level playing field between all those involved in the sale of insurance products, strengthen the protection of policyholders, and finally simplify and harmonise the procedures to ensure the exercise of the activity of insurance intermediaries in the European single market.

name: Miriam Dalli (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ This first reading agreement on insurance mediation is aimed at improving the way insurance products are sold and to improve protection for consumers and retail investors, notably through greater transparency on price and costs, prevention of conflicts of interest, better information and advice when selling products and more sellers’ professional qualifications to match the complexity of products. As this report reinforces the position of our citizens in the process of buying an insurance product, I supported this report.

name: Michel Dantin (PPE)
text: In writing. This legislative report proposes a revision of existing insurance intermediation legislation, with the aim of providing a level playing field for all players involved in the sale of insurance products and strengthening the protection of insurance policyholders. With this new text, consumers and investors in insurance products will benefit from more transparency on the prices of insurance products, and more accurate and comprehensive information on insurance products, allowing them to make an informed choice when shopping. They may also decide not to take out insurance when it is offered in addition to a purchase of a good or service (e.g. a car). Considering that this report contributes to strengthening consumer protection, I voted in favour.

name: Rachida Dati (PPE)
text: In writing. I voted in favour of this report, which provides for stricter requirements for information and protection for policyholders of insurance products. The updating of the European provisions in this area will allow european standards to be raised and new sanctions against insurance providers to be introduced, thereby providing insurance policyholders with more security.

name: Isabella De Monte (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 This report is part of the wider review of all financial markets following the financial crisis. There are two main elements: the construction of a more cohesive and integrated single market and greater consumer protection. This directive succeeds in harmonising the insurance market, while allowing the national legislature to apply higher levels of protection in particular cases. In this way, the citizen will be able to benefit from comparable rules between the various countries, but which also reflect the peculiarities of the insurance market of the Member State.  The main elements introduced are: rules to encourage the exchange of information in European formats; the distinction between investment services and insurance services for greater security for the citizen who decides to stay away from the most dangerous financial transactions and finally, in view of the fact that some operators were able to open agencies in Member States where there were lower forms of control and then operate in other States with a considerable competitive advantage , with this directive, legislators have moved the control center to the country where the operations take place as a priority, in this way the Italian citizen can be safe from possible fraudulent operations.

name: Marielle de Sarnez (ALDE)
text: In writing. To better protect consumers in the insurance sector, it is imperative to strengthen a common legislative framework. The new EU provisions improve the obligations of insurance distributors in Europe towards their customers. They will now have to be registered with a competent national authority. Intermediaries should clearly mention the information about their products and in particular their cost.

name: Andor Deli (PPE)
text: Writing. \u2012 The regulation of the activities of insurance brokers and insurance intermediaries has already been put on the agenda of all governments around the world, including the Hungarian Government. The European Commission has also recognised the importance of consumer protection, as it has in the past sought to promote cross-border mediation through various internal market measures, but we now know that consumer protection in itself contributes to the growth of the internal market. Greater harmonisation is necessary in the interests of all parties concerned, but for some Member States the standards may prove so stringent that they constitute a market barrier.  As far as information requirements are concerned, I believe that transparency in the remuneration system is indeed necessary where requested by customers, but top-down regulation can lead to unnecessary bureaucracy. I believe that Mr Langen has developed a system that works in the interests of consumers. Of course, many of the 28 Member States believe that their system is the best, but this does not mean a single internal market. If a person has passed a qualification system, it must be recognised in other Member States. The current proposal will alleviate the often cumbersome functioning of the current system, which is why I voted in favour of it.

name: Gérard Deprez (ALDE)
text: In writing. I voted to strengthen the European provisions on information and advice offered by insurance sellers. It seems to me essential to simplify but also to make it more secure to subscribe to an insurance contract by introducing new information and consumer protection requirements that are the same for all insurance distribution channels. I am particularly in favour of the obligation to provide purchasers of insurance contracts with all the information concerning the nature of the distributor's remuneration and, for certain complex life insurance products, the total cost of the insurance contract, including the costs of advice and services. It seems to me essential that before signing a non-life insurance contract, the underwriters should receive, in plain language, an information document on the product containing standard information on the type of insurance, the obligations related to the contracts, the risks insured and excluded, as well as the means of payment and premiums.

name: Tamás Deutsch (PPE)
text: Writing. – The regulation of the activities of insurance brokers and insurance intermediaries has already been put on the agenda of all governments around the world, including the Hungarian Government. The European Commission has also recognised the importance of consumer protection, as it has in the past sought to promote cross-border mediation through various internal market measures. However, we now know that consumer protection in itself contributes to the growth of the internal market. Greater harmonisation is necessary in the interests of all parties concerned, but for some Member States the standards may prove so stringent that they constitute a market barrier.  As far as information requirements are concerned, I believe that transparency in the remuneration system is indeed necessary where requested by customers, but top-down regulation can lead to unnecessary bureaucracy. I believe that, thanks to Mr Langen's sacrifice, a system has finally been developed that works in the interests of consumers. Of course, many of the 28 Member States believe that their system is the best, but this does not mean a single internal market. If a person has passed a qualification system, it must be recognised in other Member States. The current proposal will alleviate the often cumbersome functioning of the current system, which is why I voted in favour of it.

name: Mireille D'Ornano (ENF)
text: In writing. This report validated the directive, which aimed to introduce stronger competition within the single market, while standardising benefits. By wishing to further regulate the insurance sector and all its intermediaries, the Union is once again interfering in national affairs and civil society. And even if the initial idea was laudable because it related to consumer protection, the causes of this dysfunction come primarily from the single market. I therefore abstained in the vote, not wishing to endorse the European single market.

name: Ian Duncan (ECR)
text: in writing. ‒ Whilst I voted against this report in the committee vote before trilogues began, many of the problematic elements were resolved during trilogues, with outcomes including fewer prescriptive requirements on the content of product information documents and much more proportionate requirements for professional development than the originally proposed 15 hours per year. I therefore voted in favour of the trilogue outcome.

name: Ангел Джамбазки (ECR)
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the proposal for a directive of the European Parliament and of the Council on insurance mediation, as it should ensure that the same level of consumer protection is applied and that all consumers can benefit from comparable standards. This Directive should promote a level playing field between intermediaries, whether or not they are linked to an insurance undertaking. It is beneficial for consumers if insurance products are distributed through different channels and through intermediaries with different forms of cooperation with insurance undertakings, provided that they are required to apply similar consumer protection rules.

name: Γεώργιος Επιτήδειος (
text: NI), in writing. \u2012 We are voting against the proposal for a directive as it is in fact necessary for Member States to follow and adopt specific positions on the distribution of insurance or reinsurance products. But a state with a fragile economy cannot cope with these positions like a state with a healthy economy. The content of the proposal does not correspond to the Greek reality.

name: Norbert Erdős (PPE)
text: Writing. \u2012 The regulation of the activities of insurance brokers and insurance intermediaries has already been put on the agenda of all governments around the world, including the Hungarian Government. The European Commission has also recognised the importance of consumer protection, as it has in the past sought to promote cross-border mediation through various internal market measures, but we now know that consumer protection in itself contributes to the growth of the internal market. Greater harmonisation is necessary in the interests of all parties concerned, but for some Member States the standards may prove so stringent that they constitute a market barrier.  As far as information requirements are concerned, I believe that transparency in the remuneration system is indeed necessary where requested by customers, but top-down regulation can lead to unnecessary bureaucracy. I believe that, through Mr Langen's sacrifitic work, a system has finally been developed that works in the interests of consumers. Of course, many of the 28 Member States believe that their system is the best, but this does not mean a single internal market. If a person has passed a qualification system, it must be recognised in other Member States. The current proposal will alleviate the often cumbersome functioning of the current system, which is why I voted in favour of it.

name: Bill Etheridge (EFDD)
text: in writing. – Whilst the legislation calls for the level of consumer protection to be raised, it does so only to reduce the need for varying national measures. It increases the scope of firms covered by EU regulation and the powers of EIOPA and, although it reduces the regulatory burden for SMEs selling travel and car rental insurance, it gives the Commission more powers to issue delegated acts.

name: José Manuel Fernandes (PPE)
text: in writing. I agree with the amendments proposed in this report because they propose, for example, that consumers should benefit from the same level of protection, despite differences between distribution channels. In order to ensure that the same level of protection is applied and that consumers can benefit from comparable standards, in particular in the field of information disclosure, it is essential to promote a level playing field between distributors. Another important aspect is the certification that insurance brokers and insurance undertakings that advise or sell insurance-based investment products to small investors have an adequate level of knowledge and skills in relation to the products offered. This requirement is particularly relevant in view of the increasing complexity and ongoing innovation in the design of insurance-based investment products. Buying an insurance-based investment product carries a risk, so investors should be able to rely on the information and quality of the assessments provided.

name: Jonás Fernández (S&D)
text: in writing. I voted in favour of this proposal for a Directive which aims to increase transparency and consumer rights in the insurance market. In particular, it seeks to prevent financial service users from being forced to accept the purchase of insurance when they contract with financial institutions. Such rules help to ensure strict regulation of markets and financial products, which is especially necessary in the after-the-summer crisis of 2007, which highlighted the very negative consequences of deregulation promoted by neoliberal policies. The agenda for financial regulation is a priority of the European Socialists and Social Democrats, and therefore we will continue to work along this line throughout this legislature.

name: Edouard Ferrand (ENF)
text: In writing. I voted for this resolution because it goes against the MIF 2 directive, which I am fighting.

name: João Ferreira (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. \u2012 The recast of the Insurance Mediation Directive has as key elements, among others: extending the scope to all distribution channels, such as car rental; clarify some concepts and powers of the home and host supervisory authorities; identify, manage and mitigate conflicts of interest; raise the level of harmonisation of administrative measures and sanctions; improve the adequacy and objectivity of consumer advice. Although the recast is aimed at harmonising national provisions, the coordination of rules and the guarantee of a level playing field for consumers and competition for distributors, it should be noted that it should not prevent Member States from maintaining or introducing stricter provisions to protect customers. We also welcome all improvements in the information provided to consumers, together with the guarantee of continuous training and professional development of workers. However, we believe that the Directive will continue to do not provide the desired level of transparency in the insurance sector as a whole. Furthermore, we do not welcome the concern to promote an internal market for life and non-life insurance products and services, as it will only benefit the interests of large financial companies.

name: Raffaele Fitto (ECR)
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of this draft legislative resolution on insurance mediation, as it aims to harmonise national provisions on insurance distribution without preventing Member States from maintaining or adopting stricter provisions to protect consumers.

name: Monika Flašíková Beňová (S&D)
text: Writing. \u2012 The European Parliament directive has been recast, mainly for the sake of clarity, but also for better consumer protection. It aims at minimum harmonisation and thus allows Member States to retain the original provisions in their own discretion or to introduce stricter ones, but the primary objective should be to protect consumers. In particular, it is intended to ensure the same level of protection for the buyer's customer and to cover the scope of this Directive not only to insurance undertakings and their intermediaries, but also to other market participants selling insurance products in the course of ancillary activities.

name: Lorenzo Fontana (ENF)
text: in writing. \u2012 I am voting in favour of this report as the minimum harmonisation of the planned insurance sector seems to meet the demands of EU citizens.

name: Λάμπρος Φουντούλης (
text: NI), in writing. \u2012 I am voting against the proposal for a directive as it is in fact necessary for Member States to follow and adopt specific positions on the distribution of insurance or reinsurance products. But a state with a fragile economy cannot cope with these positions like a state with a healthy economy. The content of the proposal does not correspond to the Greek reality.

name: Doru-Claudian Frunzulică (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ I welcome the supplementary report by Werner Langen, whom I would like to congratulate on the outcome of the directive’s recast. I also welcome the outcome of the negotiations with the Council to broaden the scope of the directive, to strengthen rules on transparency and to align the rules regarding investment products with the Markets in Financial Instruments Directive (MIFID). I believe it will improve the way insurance products are sold and the level of protection for consumers and retails investors. And these outcomes are achievable only through greater transparency on price and costs, the prevention of conflicts of interest, and better information and advice when selling products. I strongly support the reinforcement of the ‘tying practices’ rules, so that when insurance products are offered with another good or service, consumer will have the option of buying the main good without insurance. Sanctions and reporting infractions are also important: Member States have to ensure, when transposing the directive, that their competent authority will impose administrative sanctions and other measures applicable to all infringements of the national provisions, and take all necessary measure to ensure that they are implemented.

name: Kinga Gál (PPE)
text: Writing. \u2012 The regulation of the activities of insurance brokers and insurance intermediaries has already been put on the agenda of all governments around the world, including the Hungarian Government. The European Commission has also recognised the importance of consumer protection, as it has in the past sought to promote cross-border mediation through various internal market measures, but we now know that consumer protection in itself contributes to the growth of the internal market. Greater harmonisation is necessary in the interests of all parties concerned, but for some Member States the standards may prove so stringent that they constitute a market barrier.  As far as information requirements are concerned, I believe that transparency in the remuneration system is indeed necessary where requested by customers, but top-down regulation can lead to unnecessary bureaucracy. I believe that, at the end of Mr Langen's sacrifitic work, a system has finally been developed that works in the interests of consumers. Of course, many of the 28 Member States believe that their system is the best, but this does not mean a single internal market. If a person has passed a qualification system, it must be recognised in other Member States. The current proposal will alleviate the often cumbersome functioning of the current system, which is why I voted in favour of it.

name: Ildikó Gáll-Pelcz (PPE)
text: Writing. \u2012 For me, the protection of consumers' interests is a key issue, which is why I support the directive, which targets minimum harmonisation and should not prevent Member States from upstreating or introducing stricter provisions to protect customers if these provisions are in line with EU law, including this Directive. I agree that, despite the differences between distribution channels, consumers should receive the same level of protection.  In order to ensure an equal level of protection and to ensure that consumers benefit from comparable standards, in particular in the disclosure of information, it is essential to ensure a level playing field between salespeople. I welcome the fact that general principles, such as conflicts of interest, transparency and customer information, are given special attention in the report.

name: Francesc Gambús (PPE)
text: in writing. I voted in favour considering that the Commission's proposal does not contain any substantive changes and that it is limited to a pure and simple codification of existing texts, without any substantial amendment thereof. The main purpose of recasting is to harmonise national provisions on the distribution of insurance and should therefore not exclude Member States from maintaining or adopting stricter provisions to protect customers.

name: Iratxe García Pérez (S&D)
text: in writing. I voted in favour of this proposal for a Directive which aims to increase transparency and consumer rights in the insurance market. In particular, it seeks to prevent financial service users from being forced to accept the purchase of insurance when they contract with financial institutions. Such rules help to ensure strict regulation of markets and financial products, which is especially necessary in the after-the-summer crisis of 2007, which highlighted the very negative consequences of deregulation promoted by neoliberal policies. The agenda for financial regulation is a priority of the European Socialists and Social Democrats, and therefore we will continue to work along this line throughout this legislature.

name: Eider Gardiazabal Rubial (S&D)
text: in writing. I voted in favour of this proposal for a Directive which aims to increase transparency and consumer rights in the insurance market. In particular, it seeks to prevent financial service users from being forced to accept the purchase of insurance when they contract with financial institutions. Such rules help to ensure strict regulation of markets and financial products, which is especially necessary in the after-the-summer crisis of 2007, which highlighted the very negative consequences of deregulation promoted by neoliberal policies. The agenda for financial regulation is a priority of the European Socialists and Social Democrats, and therefore we will continue to work along this line throughout this legislature.

name: Elisabetta Gardini (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the Insurance Brokerage Directive, which will introduce long-awaited innovations from 2017 from consumers and insurance intermediaries. There will finally be more transparency, consumers will finally be able to have more clarity on the real data of an insurance product, from costs to duration, up to the bonuses provided, more consumer protection but also greater enhancement of the role of insurance intermediaries and more control by the supervisory authorities.

name: Elena Gentile (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the EP legislative resolution accepting the agreement with the Council on the Directive on insurance brokerage and distribution (IDD), because it completes the single market in insurance services and specifically stems the excessive fragmentation of intermediaries and insurance products caused by the financial crisis, promoting fair competition and strengthening consumer rights. Member States will have two years to transpose the new legislation into national law. The latter sets itself very ambitious targets, which is an important step forward in relation to the directive on insurance mediation, since it also extends the scope to insurance distribution. The new directive aims to create a level playing field in the retail insurance and related intermediaries market, to reduce cross-border access charges (increasing choice), and establishes a single registration system for intermediaries. It also introduces a proportionality principle in favour of insurance product intermediaries. Finally, the EP has helped to introduce qualifying aspects into the directive, specifically the rules aimed at strengthening the qualification requirements of intermediaries, the transparency of seller fees, the standardisation of information documents, aimed at explaining the risk, type and scope of insurance products.

name: Arne Gericke (ECR)
text: Writing. I voted today in favour of the report on the proposal for a Directive of the European Parliament and of the Council on Insurance Mediation (IDD), as I support the approach and have been able to give my ECR Group many impulses for greater consumer friendliness. With the IDD, the rules for insurance brokerage now apply to all market participants who sell insurance – for example, travel agencies and car rental companies, unless they are "microinsurance". In addition, insurance companies must provide customers with information on the type of remuneration their employees receive when distributing insurance products and, for certain complex life insurance products, also on the total cost of the insurance contract, including consultancy and service costs. This is good for consumers.

name: Jens Gieseke (PPE)
text: Writing. With today's report, we are increasing transparency for the consumer. At the same time, it is guaranteed that smaller insurance companies in particular will enjoy greater legal certainty in the future. It also improves access to cross-border insurance systems. Customers can compare services from individual providers better and faster.

name: Neena Gill (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of this report because it is crucial consumers understand the risks, costs and features of all insurance products. It is also important that those selling insurance have relevant knowledge and competence. By ending the fragmentation of insurance rules across Europe we can help foster cross-border sales and build on the single market.

name: Juan Carlos Girauta Vidal (ALDE)
text: in writing. ‒ Today I supported this report as it aims to improve how insurance goods are sold to consumers. It encourages greater clarity and understanding of the cost and process involved in all insurance goods and products. I welcome this legislation as it outlines means to achieve a level playing field for all those involved in the insurance selling sector.

name: Tania González Peñas (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. This Directive amends the above legislation on the sale of insurance by intermediaries (or insurance brokers). The legislation seeks to increase transparency in the market by ensuring a level playing field for different actors. However, the Directive has not gone as far as it could: brokers are still not obliged to inform clients of the fees they charge and the transparency requirements will not apply to the insurance market as a whole. That is why we have chosen to abstain from voting.

name: Theresa Griffin (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ I support this legislation as it ensures consumers understand the risks, costs and features of all insurance products. Those selling insurance will also be required to have relevant knowledge and competence. By ending the fragmentation of insurance rules across Europe it should also help foster cross-border sales and build on the single market.

name: Françoise Grossetête (PPE)
text: In writing. On Tuesday, November 24, I voted in favour of a text to strengthen the rules governing the insurance sector within two years, in order to better control the activity of brokers and other intermediaries and to improve information provided to consumers. More than 70% of insurance products are sold without adequate advice from the consumer. With this text, sellers of insurance contracts will have to register with the authorities of their country, but also with the European Insurance and Occupational Pensions Authority, based in Frankfurt, which will verify that they are properly qualified.

name: Antanas Guoga (ALDE)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted for the supplementary report on the proposal for a directive of the European Parliament and of the Council on insurance mediation because it means Member States shall ensure that competent authorities monitor the insurance and reinsurance markets, including the market for ancillary insurance products which are marketed, distributed or sold in, or from, their Member States.

name: Sergio Gutiérrez Prieto (S&D)
text: in writing. I voted in favour of this proposal for a Directive which aims to increase transparency and consumer rights in the insurance market. In particular, it seeks to prevent financial service users from being forced to accept the purchase of insurance when they contract with financial institutions. Such rules help to ensure strict regulation of markets and financial products, which is especially necessary in the after-the-summer crisis of 2007, which highlighted the very negative consequences of deregulation promoted by neoliberal policies. The agenda for financial regulation is a priority of the European Socialists and Social Democrats, and therefore we will continue to work along this line throughout this legislature.

name: András Gyürk (PPE)
text: Writing. \u2012 The regulation of the activities of insurance brokers and insurance intermediaries has already been put on the agenda of all governments around the world, including the Hungarian Government. The European Commission has also recognised the importance of consumer protection, as it has in the past sought to promote cross-border mediation through various internal market measures, but we now know that consumer protection in itself contributes to the growth of the internal market. Greater harmonisation is necessary in the interests of all parties concerned, but for some Member States the standards may prove so stringent that they constitute a market barrier.  As far as information requirements are concerned, I believe that transparency in the remuneration system is indeed necessary where requested by customers, but top-down regulation can lead to unnecessary bureaucracy. I believe that, as a result of the reporter's sacrifice, a model has finally been developed that works in the interests of consumers. The current proposal will alleviate the often cumbersome functioning of the current system, so I voted in favour of it as a member of the Hungarian delegation to the People's Party.

name: Τάκης Χατζηγεωργίου (
text: GUE/NGL), in writing. \u2012 The Cypriot economy consists of micro and small and medium-sized enterprises for which the common European market has played a very negative role. We believe that the directive on the relocation of companies tramples on workers' labour and collective rights, as it allows companies to settle in Member States with lower taxation and social benefits, thus pushing down social security and workers' wages.   The result was the appropriate attitude in this report because while it contains some positive elements, it does not improve the directive so much that it can be voted on. The report on the one side promotes and facilitates the relocation of insurance companies throughout the territory of the Union, with the obligations of companies remaining in the State of origin. On the other hand, it at least guarantees the rights of the host State of the company to act in the event of fraud and with criminal penalties, not only administrative.

name: Marian Harkin (ALDE)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of the revised Insurance Mediation Directive (IMD2). This proposal addresses cross-sectoral inconsistencies which, when combined with a low level of cross-border purchasing, are detrimental to consumers. In comparison to IMD1, the new rules clearly reinforce consumer protection. Of particular use to the everyday consumer is the fact that the directive clarifies tying practices, so when insurance products are purchased together with goods, the consumer must be informed about the prices of all the individual components and must be offered the opportunity to buy the products separately. From a seller’s perspective, the proposal differentiates between the various selling channels for insurance products and therefore imposes a less burdensome registration and professional qualification requirement on those selling simple insurance products. Overall, this proposal aims to ensure a level playing field for all those involved in selling insurance products and to improve policyholder advice, transparency and protection.

name: Brian Hayes (PPE)
text: in writing. ‒ I supported this proposal as it seeks to improve regulation in the retail insurance market. Crucially it aims to ensure a level playing field between all participants involved in the selling of insurance products and also attempts to strengthen policyholder protection. Under this new proposal both consumers and retail investors buying insurance products will benefit from greater transparency with better and more comprehensible information.

name: Roger Helmer (EFDD)
text: in writing. ‒ Whilst the legislation calls for the level of consumer protection to be raised, it does so only to reduce the need for varying national measures. It increases the scope of firms covered by EU regulation and the powers of EIOPA and, although it reduces the regulatory burden for SMEs selling travel and car rental insurance, it gives the Commission more powers to issue delegated acts.

name: Hans-Olaf Henkel (ECR)
text: in writing. ‒ The Insurance Mediation Directive proposal has now been agreed in trilogue with Council. It covers sales of general insurance products and takes into account the whole distribution chain. The Directive’s approach is geared towards minimum harmonisation, which means that the Member States would have enough flexibility to continue with existing practices. This Directive includes enhanced information about prices and costs of products, the indication of whether the seller has an incentive or receives a commission for selling a product and the introduction of a Standardised Product Information document for non-life insurance products, aiming to give consumers key elements in a standard format to help them make an informed decision. Since many of the problematic elements (such as the requirements for professional development, which were subsequently set at a more proportionate 15 hours a year, and the possibility to unbundle a product from its insurance) were resolved during trilogue, I voted in favour of the report. By the way, in my opinion, the euro must be abolished: it leads to dissension and discord in Europe.

name: György Hölvényi (PPE)
text: Writing. \u2012 The regulation of the activities of insurance brokers and insurance intermediaries has already been put on the agenda of all governments around the world, including the Hungarian Government. The European Commission has also recognised the importance of consumer protection, as it has in the past sought to promote cross-border mediation through various internal market measures. However, we now know that consumer protection in itself contributes to the growth of the internal market. Greater harmonisation is necessary in the interests of all parties concerned. However, for some Member States the standards may prove to be so strict that they constitute a market barrier.  As far as information requirements are concerned, I believe that the transparency of the remuneration system is indeed necessary where requested by customers. In particular, top-down regulation can lead to unnecessary bureaucracy. I believe that, through Mr Langen's sacrifitic work, a system has finally been developed that works in the interests of consumers. Of course, many of the 28 Member States believe that their system is the best, but this does not mean a single internal market. If a person has passed a qualification system, it must be recognised in other Member States. The current proposal will alleviate the often cumbersome functioning of the current system, which is why I voted in favour of it.

name: Ian Hudghton (Verts/ALE)
text: in writing. ‒ This proposal will strengthen consumers’ rights in the field of insurance products. I welcome the changes and I voted in favour of the report.

name: Ivan Jakovčić (ALDE)
text: Written. ‒ I voted for a report on the proposal for a directive from the European Parliament and the Council on insurance intermediation that brings modifications to some parts with a view to ensuring a level playing field between all participants involved in the sale of product insurance and strengthening policy protection under specific conditions. Compared to IMD1, the new rules in IMD2 clearly reinforce consumer protection. First of all, the new Directive clarifies the so-called bonding practices. Whenever an insurance product is sold in addition to the goods (e.g. air ticket and insurance with it), the consumer must be informed of the prices of the individual components and offered the opportunity to buy them separately. Furthermore, the new rules also mention extending the scope of IMD1 application to all distribution channels (e.g. car rental). In my view, this contributes to a greater degree of transparency and better action in the field of insurance.

name: Jean-François Jalkh (ENF)
text: In writing. This text promotes regulation of the insurance intermediation market that is favourable to policyholders and the self-employed. The report amends the MIF2 directive and the basis for the practice of the brokering profession, in particular with regard to the definition of an independent intermediary.  Insurance companies and banks will no longer be able to stifle independent advisors and exercise a monopoly on this professional activity.  The objective of regulating the entire insurance industry by integrating all intermediaries and providing customers with more complete information is a real step forward that we welcome. I voted for it.

name: Diane James (EFDD)
text: in writing. – Whilst the legislation calls for the level of consumer protection to be raised, it does so only to reduce the need for varying national measures. It increases the scope of firms covered by EU regulation and the powers of EIOPA and, although it reduces the regulatory burden for SMEs selling travel and car rental insurance, it gives the Commission more powers to issue delegated acts.

name: Ramón Jáuregui Atondo (S&D)
text: in writing. I voted in favour of this proposal for a Directive which aims to increase transparency and consumer rights in the insurance market. In particular, it seeks to prevent financial service users from being forced to accept the purchase of insurance when they contract with financial institutions. Such rules help to ensure strict regulation of markets and financial products, which is especially necessary in the after-the-summer crisis of 2007, which highlighted the very negative consequences of deregulation promoted by neoliberal policies. The agenda for financial regulation is a priority of the European Socialists and Social Democrats, and therefore we will continue to work along this line throughout this legislature.

name: Petr Ježek (ALDE)
text: Writing. \u2012 I supported the proposed directive on insurance mediation for two main reasons. The first was to increase transparency and clarity in the market for European consumers, for whom the issue of insurance is extremely complicated nowadays, which some intermediaries use. The second reason is the clear introduction of Pan-European rules, which will also be welcomed by companies doing business on the EU market.

name: Marc Joulaud (PPE)
text: In writing. I voted in favour of my colleague Werner Langen's report on insurance intermediation. This report establishes a new directive on distribution in insurance, to better organize the trades of insurance intermediaries. These trades will have to comply with information, advice and customer protection requirements and will be required to be registered in their Home Member State in order to operate anywhere in Europe. From now on it will be easier and safer for consumers to buy insurance.  This report was adopted by a large majority, which I welcome.

name: Philippe Juvin (PPE)
text: In writing. The aim of this report is to strengthen consumer protection in the insurance sector and, more specifically, to control the activity of intermediaries and insurance brokers by imposing a number of obligations on them, including information and transparency of offers. I therefore voted in favour of this text.

name: Barbara Kappel (ENF)
text: Writing. I voted in favour of this report because the existing proposal for a directive on insurance mediation dates back to 2002 and urgently needs to be amended. In the meantime, major adjustments need to be made, as the insurance and financial sector has undergone many substantial changes over the past 14 years. At the same time, it should also be borne in mind that the insurance sector is partly held jointly responsible for the financial crisis, as there is a charge that many customers have been lured into completing insurance polies for purely speculative purposes. An attempt is now being made to meet the requirements of the European Financial Supervisory Authorities ESMA (Securities and Market Supervision) and EIOPA (Insurance and Occupational Pensions), while providing the end customer with more transparency, more flexibility and more information.

name: Krišjānis Kariņš (PPE)
text: Writing. \u2012 At the European Parliament plenary session in Strasbourg, I voted in favour of the proposal for a directive of the European Parliament and of the Council on insurance mediation. This Law provides for the extension of the scope covered by this Directive to which it should be complied with to all service providers. The rules for the supervision and punishment of these service providers in the European Union have been harmonised. The new rules introduce a product information document that will better inform the buyer about the service he purchases.  Improvements to the law will give the consumer greater protection in all Member States. They are also expected to allow the consumer to choose the insurer most suitable for himself at the lowest price. In the light of the above considerations, I voted in favour of this proposal for a directive.

name: Afzal Khan (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of this legislation as it ensures consumers understand the risks, costs and features of all insurance products. Those selling insurance will also be required to have relevant knowledge and competence. By ending the fragmentation of insurance rules across Europe it should also help foster cross-border sales and build on the single market.

name: Ádám Kósa (PPE)
text: Writing. \u2012 The regulation of the activities of insurance brokers and insurance intermediaries has already been put on the agenda of all governments around the world, including the Hungarian Government. The European Commission has also recognised the importance of consumer protection, as it has in the past sought to promote cross-border mediation through various internal market measures, but we now know that consumer protection in itself contributes to the growth of the internal market. Greater harmonisation is necessary in the interests of all parties concerned, but for some Member States the standards may prove so stringent that they constitute a market barrier.  As far as information requirements are concerned, I believe that transparency in the remuneration system is indeed necessary where requested by customers, but top-down regulation can lead to unnecessary bureaucracy. I believe that, at the end of Mr Langen's sacrifitic work, a system has finally been developed that works in the interests of consumers. Of course, many of the 28 Member States believe that their system is the best, but this does not mean a single internal market. If a person has passed a qualification system, it must be recognised in other Member States. The current proposal will alleviate the often cumbersome functioning of the current system, which is why I voted in favour of it.

name: Giovanni La Via (PPE)
text: in writing. I have decided to vote in favour of this proposal for a directive of the European Parliament and of the Council. This measure lays down new rules for insurance and reinsurance distributors in the EU, for the benefit of citizens and consumers. In order to guarantee the latter, all persons distributing insurance services are registered with a competent authority. Also for the purpose of safeguarding consumer rights, there are a number of rules that ensure that marketing communications addressed to customers of insurance distributors are correct and never misleading.

name: Marine Le Pen (ENF)
text: In writing. I voted in favour of the european Parliament and the Council's proposal for a directive on insurance intermediation. The report supports regulation of the insurance intermediation market that is favourable to policyholders and the self-employed. It substantially changes the MIF2 Directive and the basis for the practice of the broker profession. Insurance companies and banks will no longer be able to stifle independent advisors and have a monopoly on this professional activity, which is a positive thing.

name: Paloma López Bermejo (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. I have not been able to vote in favour of this report because, despite containing positive elements on consumer protection, the outcome of the tripartite dialogue will not contribute to improving the transparency of the sector.  The Directive provides for greater consumer protection, as well as improved information and transparency in certain products. However, it leaves out the insurance of investments and financial products, which is a complex framework that can sometimes hide speculative transactions based on risk management. In order to avoid impacts that can even reach sovereign debt, as happened during 2012, full transparency in relation to these activities is necessary, something that this Directive does not propose. That's why I haven't been able to vote for it.

name: Petr Mach (EFDD)
text: Writing. \u2012 The legal framework for providing insurance is to be addressed by states at their level, not by the EU.

name: Ivana Maletić (PPE)
text: Written. ‒ Recent financial turbulence has highlighted the importance of ensuring effective consumer protection and harmonising the distribution of insurance products. It is the duty of the Member States to enable insurance, reinsurance and additional insurance intermediaries to carry out their tasks in an orderly manner throughout the Union, and to carry out effective risk-a-risk supervision. The Directive also applies to undertakings whose regular activity is to provide investment services or carry out investment activities on a professional basis. The Directive also promotes equal competition. I supported Representative Langen's report, because I believe the insurance market remains very fragmented. It is important to ensure better transparency and availability of all rules applicable to insurance distribution. These are preconditions for establishing a single market and protecting investors.

name: Νότης Μαριάς (
text: ECR), in writing. \u2012 I am abstaining from voting on the supplementary report on the proposal for a directive of the European Parliament and of the Council on insurance mediation, because it is not sufficiently documented.

name: Dominique Martin (ENF)
text: In writing. I voted for it. This Intermediation Directive (IAD 2) follows the December 2002 IAD Directive which aimed at greater competition in the single market while standardising products offered to consumers, all with control over the competence and honourability of intermediaries. The IAD 2 is an overhaul of DIA 1, which expands its scope to include newer players offering insurance such as bank insurers, comparators, travel agencies... It also reinforces the requirements of professional skills and their duty of advice. This will allow the entire insurance industry to be regulated and provide customers with the most complete information possible, while moving away from banking lobbies.

name: David Martin (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ I supported this proposal. The main objective of this recast is to harmonise national provisions concerning insurance distribution, and, since that activity is carried out across the Union, this new directive should be based on Article 53(1) and Article 62 of the Treaty on the Functioning of the European Union (TFEU). The form of a directive is appropriate in order to enable the implementing provisions in the areas covered by the directive to be adjusted, as necessary, to any existing specificities of the particular market and legal system in each Member State. This directive should also aim at coordinating national rules concerning access to the activity of insurance and reinsurance distribution. However, the Directive is aimed at minimum harmonisation and should therefore not preclude Member States from maintaining or introducing more stringent provisions in order to protect customers, provided that such provisions are consistent with Union law, including this directive.

name: Fulvio Martusciello (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the report on the proposal for a directive of the European Parliament and of the Council on insurance mediation.  The main purpose of the report is to establish national provisions and rules on insurance distribution in the EU, so that these provisions are adapted, where necessary, to the specificities of the market of each Member State, in the areas covered by the Directive.

name: Georg Mayer (ENF)
text: Writing. The current directive dates back to 2002. Since then, the insurance and financial sector has changed considerably due to numerous other regulations and the creation of agencies, so that adjustments must also be made in the placement of insurance companies, which offer the customer more transparency, more flexibility and more information about outages, coverage, etc. In the context of ESMA and EIOPA, this adjustment makes perfect sense, as the insurance industry was also partly responsible for the financial crisis and unsuspecting customers often took out insurances aimed at speculating on a default. I therefore agree with this report.

name: Jean-Luc Mélenchon (GUE/NGL)
text: In writing. Intermediation in insurance or reinsurance is the activity of presenting, proposing or assisting in entering into insurance or reinsurance contracts or carrying out other preparatory work to their conclusion. The report before us aims to clarify and bring new elements to harmonize the work of insurance intermediaries in the European Union. Although the text strengthens the supervision of these intermediaries, its main aim is nevertheless to "promote a genuine internal market for life and non-life insurance products and services". Opposed to ever-increasing penetration of markets by private insurance schemes, I abstain on this text which regulates them at the margin.

name: Joëlle Mélin (ENF)
text: In writing. The report supports regulation of the insurance intermediation market that is favourable to policyholders and the self-employed. It substantially changes the MIF2 Directive and the basis for the practice of the brokering profession, particularly with regard to the definition of an independent intermediary. Insurance companies and banks will no longer be able to stifle independent advisors and exercise a monopoly on this professional activity. It was time for the European Parliament not to give all the powers to the banking and insurance lobbies and to allow equally competent people to carry out this profession in a sustainable way. I therefore welcome the intelligence of this report. The objective of regulating the entire insurance industry by integrating all intermediaries and providing customers with more complete information is a real step forward. Therefore, I vote in favour.

name: Nuno Melo (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the draft legislative resolution of the European Parliament on the proposal for a recast of the Insurance Mediation Directive. This is a proposal to recast Union legislation in which Parliament tabled amendments to the Union proposal. The new Insurance Mediation Directive reviews the legislative framework governing the distribution of insurance in the various Member States of the European Union, promoting transparency of activity and consumer knowledge of insurance products.

name: Roberta Metsola (PPE)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of this proposal as it aims to ensure a level playing field for all those involved in the selling of insurance products and to improve the protection of insurance policyholders.

name: Louis Michel (ALDE)
text: In writing. I am pleased that the European Parliament has adopted this directive which aims to ensure fair competition for insurance products and to strengthen consumer rights. In this sensitive sector, it was important to ask insurance distributors to register with a competent authority in their Home Member State. In addition, given the complexity of some insurance products, it was essential that consumers have clear information about the total costs of insurance contracts. In the same vein, they will also need to receive a plain language document informing about the product before they sign a contract.

name: Miroslav Mikolášik (PPE)
text: Writing. \u2012 The directive aims to harmonise national provisions in the activity of insurance distribution, since in order to ensure effective protection and non-discrimination, it is necessary to ensure a level playing field between service distributors in the internal market, mutual recognition of knowledge and to strengthen customer confidence. The Directive applies to persons active in the provision of insurance or reinsurance to third parties and to persons whose activity consists in providing information on insurance contracts.  Member States have the right to maintain or introduce stricter provisions aimed at protecting customers and consumers, given that the Directive is intended to lay down minimum obligations to be complied with in informing customers by service distributors. I see positively that the adoption of the directive should not be a burden on small and medium-sized distributors.

name: Marlene Mizzi (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of the report on insurance mediation, which will improve the way insurance products are sold and will improve consumers’ and retail investors’ protection, notably through greater transparency on price and costs, the prevention of conflicts of interest, better information and advice when selling products, and more professional qualifications for sellers to match the complexity of products. This will allow the way that insurance products are sold to be improved, notably regarding the information and advice delivered to consumers.

name: Csaba Molnár (S&D)
text: Writing. \u2012 The Commission proposed in 2012 the adoption of a Directive of the European Parliament and of the Council on insurance mediation. On the basis of the opinion of the Committee on the Internal Market and Consumer Protection and the Committee on Legal Affairs, the Committee on Economic and Monetary Affairs adopted a report, which was discussed by the European Parliament at its meeting on 26 February 2014 and made amendments on the basis of it. In its decision of 18 September 2014, the Conference of Presidents classified the issue as an unfinished business for the seventh parliamentary term. In order to conclude the issue, the Committee on Economic and Monetary Affairs adopted an additional report recommending the Commission's proposal to palament for adoption with amendments. I supported the draft.

name: Bernard Monot (ENF)
text: In writing. This report focuses on the amendment to the 2002 Insurance Intermediation Directive (IAD1) to allow for greater competition in the single market. However, the implementation of DIA1 was complicated and created market distortions, and the 2008 financial crisis pushed to increase the stability of the insurance market. DIA2 therefore aims to correct the defects of DIA1 by ensuring better protection of the policyholder and better regulation of the insurance intermediation activity. First, DIA2 extends its scope to all insurance product distribution channels and the registration process is modified to create a single registry. DIA2 also provides for the availability for the customer or for the search for new information such as the payment method of the seller and the status of the intermediary. The requirements for professional skills and the duty of advice are strengthened. Finally, by adopting the measures provided for by the MIFID Directive, DIA2 integrates the verification of the client's financial and insurance skills, and the provision of capital loss risks to the underwriter.

name: Sophie Montel (ENF)
text: In writing. This report concerns the Insurance Intermediation Directive (DIA2), which follows the 2002 DIA1, which aimed to allow greater competition in the single market while standardising the products made available to the consumer and imposing control over the competences of intermediaries. The 2008 crisis revealed the shortcomings of this scheme and the very free interpretation of the IAD1 Member States. In 2012, the Commission therefore adopted DIA2, which extends its scope to all the distribution channels of newly emerged insurance products that form the basis of shadow banking. Transparency measures for the customer are also provided such as information on the payment method of the seller and the status of the intermediary. Similarly, the issue of broker conflicts of interest is raised. Considering that these are provisions in the direction of greater transparency for consumers, I have decided to vote for this text.

name: Nadine Morano (PPE)
text: In writing. I voted in favour of this report on insurance intermediation. Adopted by a very large majority, this text endorses a trilogue agreement reached on 30 June 2015, which establishes a new directive on distribution in insurance, in lieu of that dating back to 2002. The aim is to better organize trades in this sector and in particular to strengthen the requirements in terms of professionalism, financial capacity and the honourability of insurance intermediaries. I support this text which calls for easier access to the contact information of registered insurance and reinsurance intermediaries and will allow better protection for customers.

name: Renaud Muselier (PPE)
text: In writing. I was not able to vote for this report, but I fully support the position of the EPP Group and the French delegation to adopt this report. It endorses a trilogue agreement reached on 30 June 2015, which establishes a new directive on distribution in insurance. The redesign of the directive strengthens the requirements and recalibrates them according to the trades covered. The main objectives include ensuring the professionalism and competence of insurance intermediaries; Protecting the interests of customers Compliance with minimum professional requirements, such as easy public access to the contact information of registered insurance and reinsurance intermediaries; and appropriate and effective out-of-court dispute resolution procedures.

name: Victor Negrescu (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted for this report, which is the only EU legislation that regulates the point of sale for insurance products so as to ensure the rights of the consumer. The revised directive seeks to improve regulation in the retail insurance market in an efficient manner. It aims to ensure a level playing field for all those involved in the selling of insurance products and to improve policyholder protection.

name: Luděk Niedermayer (PPE)
text: Writing. \u2012 I supported the report on insurance mediation, which culminates in several years of difficult negotiations between the EP and the Council. This results in improving the way insurance products are sold, increasing policyholders' protection, improving the quality of information provided to customers and creating a code of conduct for insurance intermediaries. Insurance providers will need to be more transparent about the prices and costs of their products, so it will be clear what the consumer is paying and what is not. In this context, I would like to mention that in the Czech Republic, an amendment to the Insurance Act, which was in many ways ahead of the time, was recently introduced under the table, i.m. by developments in the field of European legislation. Unfortunately, it was swept away as a result of a dispute over intermediary commissions, which is a serious problem, but it could have been deleted from this legislation. It will therefore be necessary to resubmedite the amendment and ideally limit it to the elements of the regulation related to the directive currently adopted on insurance mediation. We will have to work on its content in our legal system and we should not underestimate this task.

name: Андрей Новаков (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 THE EP has declared the protection of consumers of insurance in the EU. The institution insisted on more information, quality advice and protection of European natural and legal persons when purchasing insurance. Insurance sellers will have to register with the competent authorities in their own Member State and the sales staff will have to be professionally trained to meet the customer's questions and needs. Equivalent access to information will be provided and customer protection will exist in case the insurer is unable to pay a premium.

name: Franz Obermayr (ENF)
text: Writing. I voted in favour of this report because the current directive dates back to 2002 and has changed a lot in the insurance and financial sectors since then. Adaptation is urgently needed, as the customer needs to be offered more transparency. In addition, the customer will receive more information in the future. In the context of ESMA and EIOPA, this adjustment makes perfect sense, as the insurance industry was also partly responsible for the financial crisis and unsuspecting customers often took out insurances aimed at speculating on a default.

name: Urmas Paet (ALDE)
text: Writing. \u2012 I supported. The aim is to make it easier and safer for consumers to buy insurance by harmonising information sharing and consumer protection requirements.

name: Rolandas Paksas (EFDD)
text: Writing. \u2012 I agree with the updated rules on insurance mediation. In particular, these rules will provide greater protection for policyholders and will harmonise the requirements for the provision of insurance services. In order to prevent the provision of incorrect and misleading information, insurance acquirers should be provided with unambiguous standard information on the identity and contacts of the agent selling insurance, the type of insurance, the buyer's obligations, the risks covered, the exemptions and premiums, as well as the total cost of the contract, before the contract is signed.  Particular attention should be paid to the protection of customers, in particular in the event of insolvency of insurance intermediaries. In this context, I support the proposal, which imposes an obligation on insurers to ensure that 4% of annual premiums, but at least EUR 18 750, are always freely available. In addition, it is necessary to lay down penalties which are proportionate and adequate for the infringements and damage sought.

name: Margot Parker (EFDD)
text: in writing. ‒ Whilst the legislation calls for the level of consumer protection to be raised, it does so only to reduce the need for varying national measures. It increases the scope of firms covered by EU regulation and the powers of EIOPA and, although it reduces the regulatory burden for SMEs selling travel and car rental insurance, it gives the Commission more powers to issue delegated acts.

name: Aldo Patriciello (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 The commitment of the European institutions to consumer protection is fundamental, and I am pleased to be able to contribute here with my positive vote on the text presented. I have taken careful note of the amendments that have been made to you and I am confident in the commitment of the Member States to comply with European provisions: only in this way will a major breakthrough in this area be possible, making economic recovery more effective as well.

name: Eva Paunova (PPE)
text: in writing. – Insurance products concern everyone and it is essential to have fair competition and transparency in a country’s market, as well as across borders. The EU insurance sector is strong, it plays a leading role in the global insurance business and it should continue to do so. That is why I voted in favour of the report, which sets out clear requirements for transparency in the standard information sheet and in relation to the remuneration of agents or mediators.

name: Marijana Petir (PPE)
text: Written. The proposed Directive lays down the rules for establishing and carrying out insurance and insurance distribution and insurance operations in the Union, and these tasks constitute a significant part of member states' financial systems. The report recognised the need for minimum harmonisation between Member States through the proposal for a directive, noting that it does not pre-border Member States from maintaining existing or introducing stricter national provisions with a view to protecting consumers. The new directive seeks to cover many areas relevant to the transparent performance of insurance intermediation activities, and I consider in particular the obligation to register with the competent authorities and to request an adequate level of expertise of persons carrying out insurance and reinsurance distribution activities. I am strongly committed to certifying all persons engaged in these tasks, especially at national level. In order to protect themselves and their clients, intermediaries should definitely use professional liability insurance and I think we must insist on this because there are frequent cases in which consumers are left without years of paid premiums due to negligence or ignorance of intermediaries. Furthermore, I consider that advising and informing consumers is a condition without which a policy should not be concluded, with a view to exposing them to minimal risk. The report on the proposal for an insurance intermediation directive supports the positive changes that come with the new directive and I have therefore supported it.

name: Florian Philippot (ENF)
text: In writing. This report concerns the Insurance Intermediation Directive (DIA2), which follows the 2002 DIA1, which aimed to allow greater competition in the single market while standardising the products available to the consumer and imposing control over the competences of intermediaries.  The 2008 crisis revealed the shortcomings of this scheme and the very free interpretation of the IAD1 Member States. In 2012, the Commission therefore adopted DIA2, which extends its scope to all the distribution channels of newly emerged insurance products that form the basis of shadow banking. Transparency measures for the customer are also provided such as information on the payment method of the seller and the status of the intermediary. Similarly, the issue of broker conflicts of interest is raised.  Considering that these are provisions in the direction of greater transparency for consumers, I have decided to vote for this text.

name: Tonino Picula (S&D)
text: Written. ‒I support the objective of this directive, which seeks to harmonise regulations and rules on trade and insurance and reinsurance mediation, in order to facilitate cross-border business and greater transparency for consumers. In view of the latter, it is important that this harmonisation does not jem up the possibility for Member States to introduce stricter consumer protection provisions. The Directive guarantees timely and exhaustive consumer information, which is particularly important in relation to the price when signing the contract, and identifies preventive measures to prevent situations of conflict of interest. Furthermore, it insists on a high degree of professionalism of insurance intermediaries, which unfortunately is often not the case, so all intermediaries should be fully familiar with the terms of the policies they distribute. The aim is, inter alia, to ensure the ability of intermediaries to provide a quality and personalised recommendation to the consumer. Finally, it is important that when an insurance product is offered with another product or service, the directive ensures that the consumer must be informed whether it is possible to purchase them separately, or that the consumer has the possibility to purchase the basic product without insurance.

name: Andrej Plenković (PPE)
text: Written. ‒ I support colleague Werner Langen's report on the proposal for a directive from the European Parliament and the Council on insurance mediation. The European insurance market is very fragmentary and it is important to emphasise the diversity of legal regulation of insurance and reinsurance intermediaries in the Member States. There is therefore a need to further strengthen the internal market and create a genuine European internal market for insurance and security and security services in the Union. It is necessary to ensure the application of the same level of consumer protection or to ensure the same standards, thereby fostering equality and competition on equal terms between intermediaries. EIOPA proposes the introduction of a single electronic database with the records of each insurance and reinsurance intermediary and the introduction of a principle of arranging mutual recognition of the knowledge and capacity of intermediaries. Ensuring a high degree of professionalism and competence of intermediaries and cooperation and exchange of information between competent authorities are essential to achieve the objectives and purposes of the proposed directive.

name: Miroslav Poche (S&D)
text: Writing. \u2012 I am pleased that the European Parliament has approved by a large majority a directive on the regulation of insurance mediation. This agreement simplifies the way insurance and its products are marketed, while improving consumer protection and increasing the prevention of conflicts of interest. With greater transparency in prices and costs, the customer will have better visibility and access to information. Due to the complexity of the products, the qualification of sellers and the availability of advice should also be increased. In my opinion, it is very important that people's confidence in the benefits of insurance, be it health or supplementary insurance, is increased, and this directive should clearly help its creditability.

name: Salvatore Domenico Pogliese (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 The report sets out the rules for insurance distributors in the EU, with some exceptions, such as when insurance is complementary to the provision of goods or services and covers the risk of damage or theft.  The main objective of this report is to harmonise national provisions on insurance distribution, such as information and advice offered by sales staff. To this end, the sales staff of the insurance companies will have to be well prepared to meet the demands and needs of customers, following at least 15 hours of continuous vocational training each year.  The Member States, for their part, must be able to monitor and evaluate effectively the knowledge and skills of the sales staff of insurance companies, both when they start their activities and on an ongoing basis.  I am voting in favour of adopting this report because I believe that this will make the distribution and sale of insurance policies easier and safer by introducing new consumer protection requirements.

name: Jiří Pospíšil (PPE)
text: Writing. \u2012 I personally welcome the more sophisticated regulation in the area of insurance mediation. I believe that the proposed adjustment will lead to greater consumer protection without at the same time overloading the market with excessive bureaucracy. For this reason, I support the report.

name: Franck Proust (PPE)
text: In writing. We have reached a trilogue agreement on this directive to make the 2002 directive on insurance intermediation more effective and strengthen. It was important to support this text, in order to organise the trades and especially those of insurance intermediaries.

name: Paulo Rangel (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 The application of Directive 2002/92/EC has shown that a number of provisions will have to be better clarified in order to facilitate the exercise of the insurance distribution activity and that consumer protection requires extending the scope of that directive to all sales of insurance products. The objective of this proposal for the recast of Directive 2002/92/EC is precisely to introduce amendments to improve the regulation of the insurance market. I voted in favour.

name: Julia Reid (EFDD)
text: in writing. ‒ Whilst the legislation calls for the level of consumer protection to be raised, it does so only to reduce the need for varying national measures. It increases the scope of firms covered by EU regulation and the powers of EIOPA and, although it reduces the regulatory burden for SMEs selling travel and car rental insurance, it gives the Commission more powers to issue delegated acts.

name: Liliana Rodrigues (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 This Directive aims at minimum harmonisation in the EU, not preventing Member States from maintaining or introducing stricter provisions to protect customers, provided that they are in line with EU law.

name: Inmaculada Rodríguez-Piñero Fernández (S&D)
text: in writing. I voted in favour of this proposal for a Directive which aims to increase transparency and consumer rights in the insurance market. In particular, it seeks to prevent financial service users from being forced to accept the purchase of insurance when they contract with financial institutions. Such rules help to ensure strict regulation of markets and financial products, which is especially necessary in the after-the-summer crisis of 2007, which highlighted the very negative consequences of deregulation promoted by neoliberal policies. The agenda for financial regulation is a priority of the European Socialists and Social Democrats, and therefore we will continue to work along this line throughout this legislature.

name: Claude Rolin (PPE)
text: In writing. At this plenary session of the European Parliament, I was asked to vote on the supplementary report on the european Parliament and Council's proposal for a directive on insurance intermediation. The aim was to update insurance legislation to better regulate these professions and to better protect customers. These changes include simple, standardized and free pre-contract information on the types of insurance contracts that must be provided to clients so that they can understand the nature and risks of the insurance-based investment product offered to them; a registration requirement for insurance and reinsurance intermediaries and for intermediaries engaged in insurance intermediation activity as an incidental basis - this registration must be done with a competent authority in their Home Member State-; an obligation for these intermediaries to be covered by professional liability insurance relating to liability resulting from malpractice. Many other regulatory obligations come to supervise these professions and protect clients. In line with this regulatory reinforcement, I voted in favour of this report.

name: Fernando Ruas (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 This proposal aims to reformulate Directive 2002/92/EC on insurance mediation with a view to extending its scope, to clear up some concepts and competences and to improve the harmonisation of measures in this area in order to ensure the protection of consumer confidence and rights and to ensure a level playing field for the various market players. I agree, overall, with the improvements proposed in the report, in particular as regards the differentiation of channels for the sale of insurance products, simplification and ease of registration and the requirement of professional qualifications appropriate to the exercise of these professionals. To that extent, I have given my vote in favour of this supplementary report, the aim of which is to ensure a level playing field between all participants involved in the sale of insurance products, while also strengthening the protection of policyholders.

name: Tokia Saïfi (PPE)
text: In writing. I voted in favour of this report, which makes it easier and safer to subscribe to insurance. This text makes it possible to modernise the 2002 directive by strengthening the European provisions on information and advice offered by insurance sales staff. The aim is to introduce reassessed requirements in terms of information and consumer protection. Distributors of insurance products will be required to provide clear information on the costs of an insurance contract and in particular on the costs associated with their consulting activity. Consumers will need to receive all insurance policy information in plain language. At the same time, and in order to increase consumer protection, insurance intermediaries will have to register with the relevant authority in each Member State. I have therefore supported this report, which ensures that insurance policyholders have better information, clearer and more transparent advice and better protection.

name: Massimiliano Salini (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the supplementary report on the proposal for a directive of the European Parliament and of the Council on insurance mediation, as it guarantees greater information and transparency in the insurance market and increases the level of consumer protection. This directive also requires insurance intermediaries to be more professional and good-repute requirements.

name: Matteo Salvini (ENF)
