text: in writing. \u2012 I have decided to vote in favour as the directive seems to maintain the right balance between the legitimate interest of the market and the needs of protecting users of insurance services.

name: Lola Sánchez Caldentey (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. This Directive amends the above legislation on the sale of insurance by intermediaries (or insurance brokers). The legislation seeks to increase transparency in the market by ensuring a level playing field for different actors. However, the Directive has not gone as far as it could: brokers are still not obliged to inform clients of the fees they charge and the transparency requirements will not apply to the insurance market as a whole. That is why we have chosen to abstain from voting.

name: Lidia Senra Rodríguez (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. I have not been able to vote in favour of this report because, despite containing positive elements on consumer protection, the outcome of the tripartite dialogue will not contribute to improving the transparency of the sector.  The Directive provides for greater consumer protection, as well as improved information and transparency in certain products. However, it leaves out the insurance of investments and financial products, which is a complex framework that can sometimes hide speculative transactions based on risk management. In order to avoid impacts that can even reach sovereign debt, as happened during 2012, full transparency in relation to these activities is necessary, something that this Directive does not propose. That's why I haven't been able to vote for it.

name: Remo Sernagiotto (ECR)
text: in writing. \u2012 The Insurance Distribution Directive (IDD) voted on today in Parliament aims to create a single European insurance market in order to establish conditions that foster fair competition between insurance intermediaries and strengthen consumer rights. Thanks to this directive, sellers will have to comply with a set of rules concerning their qualifications and will have to communicate any fees and commissions to consumers. "Standardised information documents" explaining the risk, type and scope of the insurance products offered, as well as the terms and duration of any contracts, will also be introduced. Greater transparency and uniformity in the insurance system will therefore be ensured, in order to protect the consumer and certify the best quality of the service offered. For these reasons, I voted in favour.

name: Jill Seymour (EFDD)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted against this as it gives the Commission more power to issue delegated acts.

name: Siôn Simon (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ This legislation ensures that consumers understand the risks, costs and features of all insurance products, and generally substantially improves the way insurance products are sold. Companies and individuals selling insurance will be required to have particular knowledge and competence relevant to the industry. I would also add that by ending the fragmented rules for insurance across the EU, it should also help create cross-border sales of the best insurance products and further aid the completion of the single market in this aspect.

name: Branislav Škripek (ECR)
text: Writing. \u2012 When voting on the European Parliament's legislative resolution on the proposal for a directive on insurance mediation, I voted in favour of adopting this resolution. At present, it is very difficult for consumers to know the convoluted system of insurance companies and their intermediaries. The proposal for a directive in question is aimed at helping the consumer in this area. The Directive will guarantee the client the provision of basic information about the contract, regardless of the form of mediation, and clients will also be informed about the type of remuneration for the intermediary, the amount and form of which will no longer be able to be secret.

name: Monika Smolková (S&D)
text: Writing. \u2012 The aim of this modification of the Insurance Mediation Directive is to increase consumer protection so that they have access to more detailed information on insurance products. I therefore support the proposal for a directive by the EP and the Council, on the basis of which we will impose certain minimum information and advice requirements on sellers.  Under the new rules, insurance intermediaries will have to register with the competent authorities of the Member States and will have to provide clients with all information on the costs of the insurance contract in advance. Among other things, brokers and sellers should also have at their disposal established financial reserves in order to be able to satisfy clients' claims where necessary. This Directive should make the insurance product market more transparent, transparent and more accessible to the client. The seller will in all circumstances be obliged to provide clear information about the type of insurance, obligations arising from the contract, insurance risks, exemptions or the method of payment for insurance.  Because if the contracts are to be advantageous to both the seller and the client, it is first of all necessary that the client is not exposed to surprises that could have been avoided.

name: Igor Šoltes (Verts/ALE)
text: Writing. Directive 2002/92/EC of the European Parliament and of the Council on insurance mediation regulates the activities of introducing, proposing or carrying out other preparatory work prior to the conclusion of insurance contracts or the concluding of such contracts. The application of this Directive has shown that a number of provisions require further definition in order to facilitate the execution of insurance and reinsurance products and that consumer protection requires an extension of the scope to all sales of insurance products and services. I agree that, despite the differences between sales channels, the level of consumer protection must be the same. In order to ensure this and to benefit consumers from comparable standards, in particular in the area of disclosure of information, it is essential that the playing field is leveled for all sellers. The Directive should promote a level playing field and also take into account differences between the different types of sales channels. The inability of insurance intermediaries to operate freely throughout the EU hinders the proper functioning of the internal insurance market. Therefore, the new directive would represent a step forward in the area of better consumer protection and market integration. For the reasons set out above, I voted in favour of the report.

name: Renato Soru (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the report on insurance mediation, which updates European legislation in this area ensuring greater protection for consumers who purchase insurance services. The revision of the current directive contains rules which significantly improve the way insurance products are sold, in particular as regards the information and warnings given to consumers. From this point of view, the new rules ensure greater transparency on the sale of policies, as they require the seller to inform the seller on time who takes out an insurance policy about the type of remuneration envisaged and any conflict of interest. Furthermore, we can claim as a success for the Social Democrat Group to strengthen the rules on package sales: when insurance products are sold together with other goods or services, consumers will be able to choose whether to buy the main asset without insurance, thus avoiding unnecessary expenses.

name: Ivan Štefanec (PPE)
text: Writing. \u2012 Detailed and truthful consumer information is especially important when it comes to insurance products. The directive that we have approved sets minimum common standards that every intermediary must meet and cleanse the market from high-speed experts into the world of finance.

name: Davor Ivo Stier (PPE)
text: Written. ‒I support this report because the main objective and subject to this modification is to harmonise national provisions concerning the distribution of insurance as this activity is carried out across the Union. This Directive seeks to harmonise national rules concerning access to the performance of insurance and reosurance distribution activities. I also support this directive as it seeks to achieve minimum harmonisation and its provisions should not prevent Member States from maintaining or introducing stricter provisions with a view to consumer protection, provided that those provisions comply with EU law, including this directive. This Directive should ensure an equal level of consumer protection so that all consumers can benefit from comparable standards. It would also promote equality and competition on a level playing field between intermediaries regardless of whether they are affiliated with an insurance company or not.

name: Catherine Stihler (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ I support this legislation as it ensures consumers understand the risks, costs and features of all insurance products. Those selling insurance will also be required to have relevant knowledge and competence. By ending the fragmentation of insurance rules across Europe it should also help foster cross-border sales and build on the single market.

name: Dubravka Šuica (PPE)
text: Written. \u2012 The main objective and subject to this modification is the harmonisation of national provisions concerning the distribution of insurance. Given that this activity is carried out across the Union, it is necessary to ensure the necessary degree of harmonisation that will offer investors a high degree of protection and allow investment firms to provide services throughout the Union as an internal market.  This Directive should also seek to harmonise national regulations concerning access to the performance of insurance and insurance distribution and insurance operations. The purpose of this Directive is to cover undertakings whose regular activity or business is to provide investment services and/or carry out investment activities on a professional basis.  The scope of this Directive should therefore not apply to persons carrying out any other professional activity. Persons providing investment services and/or carrying out investment activities covered by this Directive should be subject to authorisation for the operation of their home Member States to protect investors and the stability of the financial system.  Taking into account how the financial crisis has revealed weaknesses in the functioning and transparency of financial markets, I support this proposal. I think transparency will be increased and investors better protected.

name: Richard Sulík (ECR)
text: Writing. \u2012 I did not support the proposal as it increases the regulatory burden and thus damages the business environment. While the increased regulatory burden is intended to protect the customer, the deterioration of the business environment in the field of insurance intermediation will necessarily come at the expense of limiting competition, which will ultimately also harm the customer himself.

name: Patricija Šulin (PPE)
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the additional report on the proposal for a directive of the European Parliament and of the Council on insurance mediation. As in other areas, we need a single market in the insurance sector. This directive brings greater unity, transparency and greater consumer protection. I welcome the fact that the directive was created in close cooperation both between Member States and in cooperation with consumer protection organisations. The provision of information by providers will be much more transparent so that the consumer can make the right choice. This will also create greater trust between the consumer and the provider.

name: Kay Swinburne (ECR)
text: in writing. ‒ I was pleased to support this agreement on the ‘Insurance Distribution Directive’. These new rules will cover general insurance products, including car insurance and also life insurance and they will ensure clearer information and greater choice for consumers when buying insurance products. Conservative MEPs have worked hard to ensure that this legislation will deliver clear advantages for consumers, whilst minimising the burdens on insurance retailers.

name: Νεοκλής Συλικιώτης (
text: GUE/NGL), in writing. \u2012 As ACPL we have the position that the common European market has played a very negative role for micro and small and medium-sized enterprises, of which the Cypriot economy consists. We also believe that the directive on the relocation of companies is destroying workers' labour and collective rights, as it allows companies to settle in Member States with lower taxation and social benefits, thus pushing down social security and workers' wages.  The insurance industry is just one such example, in which the above apply.  The report on the one side promotes and facilitates the relocation of insurance companies throughout the territory of the Union, with the obligations of companies remaining in the State of origin. On the other hand, it at least guarantees the rights of the host State of the company to act in the event of fraud and with criminal penalties, not only administrative.   Our abstention stance is based on the fact that the report has some positive elements, but it does not improve the directive so much that it is possible to vote in favour, since we completely disagree with the directive to which it refers.

name: Tibor Szanyi (S&D)
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the supplementary report on insurance mediation, which added important safeguards to the original document. I think it is right that the report now contains the addition that Member States may maintain even stricter provisions to protect customers, if they are in line with EU directives. The protection of consumer rights and interests and the improvement of the quality of life and well-being of consumers are among the core values of the European Union.  The Union should strive to ensure that these values are applied in all areas, such as the sale of insurance products. I therefore welcome and support the new guarantees that the supplementary report has put in place to facilitate this. These include, for example, the requirement for close cooperation between host and home Member States, or the establishment of a central information point to ensure high-quality service and effective consumer protection. I welcomed the rapporteur's highlighting of the need for consumers to receive the same level of protection, despite differences between sales channels. To do this, we must raise the standard of consumer protection and ensure a level playing field throughout Europe.

name: Claudia Tapardel (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 The supplementary report on the Insurance Intermediation Directive clarifies a number of clauses, seeks to harmonise national provisions in the insurance distribution sector and updates the text of the Directive in the light of new trends in the internal insurance market. Insurance and reinsurance intermediaries are the main players in the distribution of insurance and reinsurance products on the European Union market. Insurance may be distributed by natural or legal persons, such as agents, brokers and bank insurance agents, insurance undertakings, travel agents and car rental companies. In order for the objective to be achieved, the European Insurance and Occupational Pensions Authority must regularly create, publish and update a database with each insurance and reinsurance intermediary operating in the internal market. In parallel, Member States should establish a single information point for citizens to give them access to this register or database.

name: Marc Tarabella (S&D)
text: In writing. The European Parliament has just voted on a legislative update on insurance. From now on, when citizens buy an insurance product, they will be better informed and better protected. Measures are also planned for insurance distributors and sales staff to more effectively meet customer needs. Distributors of insurance products will be required to register; registration will be made with a competent authority in their Home Member State.  In addition, regular and up-to-date training will be required for sales staff. Continuous vocational training of at least 200 hours over 5 years will also have to be provided.  As for the benefits to the customer, citizens who subscribe to an insurance product will need to be informed of the total costs of the contract.  They will also receive, before the conclusion of the agreement, standard, clear, understandable and free information on the type of insurance, contract obligations, insured and excluded risks, as well as payment methods and premiums.

name: Pavel Telička (ALDE)
text: in writing. ‒ I supported this report that seeks to improve regulation in the retail insurance market in the EU. The recast Directive lays down rules concerning insurance and reinsurance distribution in the EU, while maintaining minimum harmonisation. It aims at achieving a level playing field among all participants involved in the selling of insurance products and at strengthening policyholder protection. In addition, one of its priorities is consumers’ rights. To this end, it proposes measures to increase the transparency of an insurance contract and providing customers with objective information about the insurance product. Among other things, the report introduces new measures relating to breach of obligations when providing services in a host Member State. It empowers the competent authority of the host Member State, holding that it should be entitled to intervene if the home Member State fails to take appropriate measures. In other provisions, the report specifies measures regarding professional knowledge that the home Member States should control and assess.

name: Patrizia Toia (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 This directive on insurance mediation is extremely important for strengthening the single market, increasing transparency and improving consumer protection. The adoption of this text will make it possible to give citizens more choice, providing them with all the information they need to understand what they are buying. The directive, which is based on national insurance distribution schemes, sets minimum standards for distributors, allowing Member States' legislators to apply higher levels of consumer protection.  This directive ensures greater regulatory coherence for all sales channels and, at the same time, maintains the right balance between the application of the rules and proportionality for smaller insurance products, if sold by way of accessories. It must be increasingly clear to citizens what they are paying for a purchase or investment in an insurance product. Our objective of balancing consumer protection with corporate sustainability, through this text, has been achieved.

name: Valdemar Tomaševski (ECR)
text: Writing. \u2012 In today's vote, I supported Werner Langen's report on the objective of ensuring a uniform level of protection for customers, regardless of the channel through which they buy the insurance product, that is, regardless of the insurance company or insurance agent. The scope of this Directive should also be extended to other market participants who sell insurance products as non-core products, e.g. travel agents and car rental companies, unless they fulfil the conditions for exemption. Because when creating and implementing the insurance law, we must first of all respect the welfare of people who use insurance, not the temporary interests of the company. We need to act according to the rule: first of all, a person, in this case a customer.

name: Ruža Tomašić (ECR)
text: Written. I voted for a directive covering the entire insurance intermediation distribution chain, as I believe that the proposed minimum compliance approach greatly allows Member States to adapt implementing provisions with existing market specifics and the legal system in each Member State. I therefore consider it appropriate to propose that Member States foresee and impose criminal penalties, as well as to ensure that, in the event of non-compliance with the provisions of this Directive, those sanctions are implemented. In order to protect consumer rights, I believe that it will be of utmost importance to set minimum consumer information obligations, i.e. to provide additional information on the price and cost of the product and whether the seller receives commission from the sale of the product. The implementation of the proposed measures will also ensure a minimum level of expertise of insurance intermediaries, as well as the conditions of expertise for the distribution of policies, and I believe that this will also contribute to better informing consumers about the products offered. Since I believe that the provision of key information on insurance products in the standard form will help consumers to make decisions about insurance products, I supported this directive.

name: Romana Tomc (PPE)
text: Writing. I supported the additional report on the proposal for a directive of the European Parliament and of the Council on insurance mediation, as I believe that the new directive sets clearer standards and allows for greater transparency in the field of insurance. In addition, from the end of 2017, a standard form will provide a comparison that will ensure the main characteristics and prices of the insurance product.

name: Estefanía Torres Martínez (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. This Directive amends the above legislation on the sale of insurance by intermediaries (or insurance brokers). The legislation seeks to increase transparency in the market by ensuring a level playing field for different actors. However, the Directive has not gone as far as it could: brokers are still not obliged to inform clients of the fees they charge and the transparency requirements will not apply to the insurance market as a whole. That is why we have chosen to abstain from voting.

name: Ramon Tremosa i Balcells (ALDE)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of this directive because I believe that there is a need to further strengthen the internal market and promote a true internal market for life and non-life insurance products and services. What is more, in order to guarantee that the same level of protection applies and that all consumers can benefit from comparable standards in the insurance sector, in particular in the area of the disclosure of information, a level playing field between distributors as enforced by this directive is essential.

name: Mylène Troszczynski (ENF)
text: In writing. The report supports a regulation of the insurance intermediation market that is favourable to policyholders and the self-employed. It substantially changes the MIF2 Directive and the basis for the practice of the broker profession. Insurance companies and banks will no longer be able to stifle independent advisors and exercise a monopoly on this professional activity. So I'm voting for it.

name: István Ujhelyi (S&D)
text: Writing. \u2012 Insurance products can be sold by several types of persons and institutions, such as agents, brokers, "bank insurance" intermediaries, insurers, travel agencies or even car landlords. Equal treatment of intermediaries and protection of customers require the application of this Directive to all these persons and entities. In order to ensure that the same level of protection applies, irrespective of the channels through which customers purchase insurance products, either directly from the insurer or indirectly from an insurance intermediary, this Directive should cover not only insurers or intermediaries, but also other operators which sell insurance products on an ancillary basis, such as travel agencies or car rental companies, unless they fulfil the exemption conditions. I voted in favour of the proposal.

name: Miguel Urbán Crespo (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. This Directive amends the above legislation on the sale of insurance by intermediaries (or insurance brokers). The legislation seeks to increase transparency in the market by ensuring a level playing field for different actors. However, the Directive has not gone as far as it could: brokers are still not obliged to inform clients of the fees they charge and the transparency requirements will not apply to the insurance market as a whole. That is why we have chosen to abstain from voting.

name: Viktor Uspaskich (ALDE)
text: Writing. – In order to ensure a uniform level of protection for consumers and to enable consumers to benefit from comparable standards, in particular in the area of disclosure, it is important to create a level playing field for distributors.

name: Ivo Vajgl (ALDE)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of the resolution on the proposal for a Directive of the European Parliament and of the Council on insurance mediation because I fully support the main objective and subject-matter of this recast, which is to harmonise national provisions concerning insurance and reinsurance distribution. The form of a directive is appropriate in order to enable the implementing provisions in the areas covered by this Directive, when necessary, to be adjusted to any existing specificities of the particular market and legal system in each Member State. This Directive should also aim at coordinating national rules concerning access to the activities of insurance and reinsurance distribution. However, this Directive is aimed at minimum harmonisation and should therefore not preclude Member States from maintaining or introducing more stringent provisions in order to protect customers, provided that such provisions are consistent with Union law, including this Directive. I agree that the consumers should benefit from the same level of protection despite the differences between distribution channels. In order to guarantee that the same level of protection applies and that the consumer can benefit from comparable standards, a level playing field between distributors is essential.

name: Ramón Luis Valcárcel Siso (PPE)
text: in writing. The proposed Directive will cover the entire insurance distribution chain and replace the 2002 Insurance Directive. With this new Directive, consumers and retail investors who purchase insurance products will benefit from greater transparency and more complete information regarding the products they purchase. We are therefore talking about a substantial improvement in the existing Directive which will benefit citizens, so I consider it necessary to vote in favour of this report.

name: Elena Valenciano (S&D)
text: in writing. I voted in favour of this proposal for a Directive which aims to increase transparency and consumer rights in the insurance market. In particular, it seeks to prevent financial service users from being forced to accept the purchase of insurance when they contract with financial institutions. Such rules help to ensure strict regulation of markets and financial products, which is especially necessary in the after-the-summer crisis of 2007, which highlighted the very negative consequences of deregulation promoted by neoliberal policies. The agenda for financial regulation is a priority of the European Socialists and Social Democrats, and therefore we will continue to work along this line throughout this legislature.

name: Marco Valli (EFDD)
text: in writing. \u2012 IMD 2 updates the 2002 Directive on insurance mediation. The most important innovations in IMD 2 are the following: it extends the scope of European legislation to all categories of intermediaries; introduces many transparency rules for the benefit of consumers; requires more professional requirements from insurance intermediaries; calls for greater responsibility for instruments sold to consumers; it ensures alignment with existing European legislation. However, the original proposal provided for the obligation to provide full information also on the level of remuneration received by intermediaries (whether fixed or variable). This obligation no longer appears in the final text. Intermediaries will therefore be free to continue to receive commissions without the obligation to make them public. The negotiation process of this text has been very long. This was, in fact, amended and voted on in the ECON Committee during the previous parliamentary term. During the current one, negotiations with the Council and the Commission were concluded, but this length of time did not allow us to make any changes to the text of the directive. In total, the outcome of the negotiations left us satisfied. IMD 2 is certainly a step forward compared to IMD 1. However, there remains the critical ity of the lack of transparency on remuneration. That is why we thought it appropriate to abstain during the vote in this House.

name: Ángela Vallina (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. I have not been able to vote in favour of this report because, despite containing positive elements on consumer protection, the outcome of the tripartite dialogue will not contribute to improving the transparency of the sector.  The Directive provides for greater consumer protection, as well as improved information and transparency in certain products. However, it leaves out the insurance of investments and financial products, which is a complex framework that can sometimes hide speculative transactions based on risk management. In order to avoid impacts that can even reach sovereign debt, as happened during 2012, full transparency in relation to these activities is necessary, something that this Directive does not propose. That's why I haven't been able to vote for it.

name: Derek Vaughan (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ This is a vital directive that I support wholeheartedly. I support it because it ensures consumers understand the risks, costs and features of all insurance products. It is vital that those taking out products of this nature are aware of all of the relevant information to allow them to make an informed decision that is suitable for them. Those selling insurance will also be required to have relevant knowledge and competence. This is a vital protection not only for the consumer, but for the industry, to ensure that the industry and those it employs are not brought into disrepute by those who would exploit the vulnerable. By ending the fragmented insurance rules across Europe it should also help foster cross-border sales and build on the single market and facilitate transnational trade and co-operation within the European Union.

name: Hilde Vautmans (ALDE)
text: Written. 'I support this report because it aims to provide a better understanding of how insurance products are sold to European consumers. Moreover, this proposal will contribute to the development of a level playing field for all parties involved in the sale of insurance products.

name: Miguel Viegas (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. \u2012 Although the recast is aimed at harmonising national provisions, coordinating rules and ensuring a level playing field for consumers and competition for distributors, it should be noted that it should not prevent Member States from maintaining or introducing stricter provisions to protect customers. We also welcome all improvements in the information provided to consumers, including ensuring the continued training and professional development of workers and standardising and improving the information provided. However, we believe that the directive will continue to provide the desired level of transparency in the insurance sector as a whole. Furthermore, we do not welcome the concern to promote an internal market for life and non-life insurance products and services, as it will only benefit the interests of large financial companies.

name: Harald Vilimsky (ENF)
text: Writing. The current directive dates back to 2002. Since then, the insurance and financial sector has changed considerably due to numerous other regulations and the creation of agencies, so that adjustments must also be made in the placement of insurance companies, which offer the customer more transparency, more flexibility and more information about outages, coverage, etc. In the context of ESMA and EIOPA, this adjustment makes perfect sense, as the insurance industry was also partly responsible for the financial crisis and unsuspecting customers often took out insurances aimed at speculating on a default. I therefore agree with this report.

name: Daniele Viotti (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour because I consider this directive to be a step forward in insurance legislation and an instrument for consumer protection. The agreement clarifies, on the one hand, the rules for the sale of insurance products and, on the other, clarifies everything that concerns advice. The work that has been done is a step in the right direction and is a good thing for the sector.

name: Jarosław Wałęsa (PPE)
text: in writing. ‒ I have voted in favour of the Insurance Mediation Directive 2 (IMD2). The proposed directive is a follow up to the former directive regarding the same matter called IMD1. It is designed to ensure an equal playing field between everyone involved in the retail insurance market. The IMD2 seeks to expand the scope of application of the former directive to all distribution channels. This is supposed to enhance the effectiveness of the insurance sector. Furthermore, since the proposal covers the entire distribution chain, it is likely to benefit both consumers as well as retail insurance investors in the following ways:  The most important change is the improvement in transparency. This means that insurance distributors will have to be more lucid about their prices, which will hopefully boost the level of competitiveness in this sector. Also, the provisions of this directive seek to ensure the greater access to the information regarding all insurance products offered by the insurance dealers so that it will be unambiguous and clearer for the customers. All of the above is an interesting combination which will have a positive impact on each one of us as soon as it becomes real.

name: Jadwiga Wiśniewska (ECR)
text: I would like to write to the Commission. \u2012 The report concerns the sale of insurance services. Through negotiations, the newly amended title of the Directive integrates intermediaries and representatives into the distribution network. Insurance products, m.in cars or life insurance, are also covered. In accordance with the existing principle of flexibility for commercial practices, questions arise as to whether or not the sale of insurance should be pre-empted by advice and whether Member States will benefit from reciprocal guidance systems.  As a result, consumers and retail customers will receive information on the price and costs associated with the insurance of the product concerned, as well as whether the insurance seller has financial support and receives orders to sell the product. There will also be a model that will provide key data on insurance products and make it easier for the consumer to make a decision. This will not apply to life insurance. The requirements for professional training were also a contentious issue for me. The introduction of 15 hours of training per year is a more balanced and appropriate proposal. I have therefore voted in favour of the text of the report.

name: Anna Záborská (PPE)
text: Writing. \u2012 I supported the new directive because it will increase consumer protection. At the same time, it will make it easier for the customer to purchase insurance products. The rules adopted will apply throughout the EU and will guarantee that sellers and intermediaries will provide the same minimum level of information and advice. As a result, consumers will be better protected, either before the conclusion of the contract or in the event of problems in providing claims, for example because the intermediary, through its negligence, causes the insurance undertaking not to have to provide such a benefit.

name: Θεόδωρος Ζαγοράκης (PPE)
text: Writing. \u2012 I followed the rapporteur's proposal by voting in favour of the resolution of the Committee on Economic and Monetary Affairs, as did most political groups.

name: Marco Zanni (EFDD)
text: in writing. \u2012 We have today voted on an update of the Insurance Brokerage Directive (IMD 1) dating back to 2002. The most important innovations introduced by IMD 2 are: the extension of the scope of the legislation to all categories of intermediaries, to those performing ancillary functions and, above all, to insurance companies operating in a direct sales model; the introduction of many rules on transparency and much more information to consumers; the demand for increased professional requirements and good repute for insurance intermediaries and the request for a detailed analysis of the appropriateness of the instruments sold to consumers. Finally, greater alignment with MIFID is ensured. However, the original proposal provided for the introduction of the obligation to provide full information on the level of remuneration received by intermediaries (whether fixed or variable), but this obligation does not appear in the final text. Intermediaries will therefore be free to continue receiving commissions without the disclosure obligation. Despite the fact that the directive is a step ahead of IMD 1, this last critical point led me to abstain.

name: Jana Žitňanská (ECR)
text: Writing. \u2012 The proposal for a directive on insurance mediation concerns all insurance providers and intermediaries. In practice, this means, in particular, greater clarity, information and protection for the consumer. I consider the provision of clear, comprehensible and non-misleading information to be an important step in protecting clients. For example, the consumer will be sure that he will be provided with sufficient information to make an informed decision and that he will be granted protection in the event of a dispute, including with a foreign provider. Furthermore, it will be assured that insurance intermediaries have expertise in the products they recommend and their expertise will be checked by the Member States. I hope that this measure will prevent the currently abunding work of various unskilled intermediaries and advisers. Another important advantage for consumers is that they will no longer be able to be forced into insurance when buying a product. Finally, I also appreciate the provisions that should ensure that insurance providers no longer make brokers' remuneration subject to the recommendation of specific products that are most profitable to them but do not meet the needs of the client. This will mean greater certainty for the client that the product offered to him meets his requirements as much as possible and has not been selected only for the sake of a higher broker's remuneration. All these elements have persuaded me to support the report.

name: Inês Cristina Zuber (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. \u2012 Although the recast is aimed at harmonising national provisions, coordinating rules and ensuring a level playing field for consumers and competition for distributors, it should be noted, as a positive point, that it should not prevent Member States from maintaining or introducing stricter provisions to protect customers. We also welcome all improvements in the information provided to consumers, including ensuring the continued training and professional development of workers and standardising and improving the information provided. However, we believe that the directive will continue to provide the desired level of transparency in the insurance sector as a whole. Furthermore, we do not welcome the concern to promote an internal market for life and non-life insurance products and services, as it will only benefit the interests of large financial companies.

name: Milan Zver (PPE)
text: Writing. \ I voted in favour of the European Parliament legislative resolution on the proposal for a directive of the European Parliament and of the Council on insurance mediation (recast) (COM(2012)0360 – C7-0180/2012 – 2012/0175(COD)) to bring about the necessary amendments to unify national provisions relating to the distribution of insurance and reinsurance products, thus ensuring the same level of protection and comparable standards for consumers in the Member States of the Union.

name: Jiří Pospíšil (PPE).
text: – Mr President, I supported this report because I consider it a major problem as the phenomenon of child poverty in Europe increases. More than 1.6 million children have been affected by the problem of child poverty in the European Union in the last five years, and as this trend is increasing and negative, it is essential that we here at European Union level also address this problem and look for a solution. As a right-wing politician, I support the restrictive fiscal policies of individual nation states in an effort to maintain balanced budgets. On the other hand, it must be said that austerity measures should not affect children and should not increase their poverty, they should not affect their social security and access to the education system, because in the future we are creating a problem for an uneducated and socially weak generation, which can be a major problem for Europe and within the framework of internal security.

name: Andrejs Mamikins (S&D).
text: – Children are our future. These are not empty words for a very ordinary reason – if there are no children, there is no future. Pure after fact. Consequently, the development of any policy and its consistent implementation must be based precisely on the principle that we must guarantee the need for our children, access to quality life, education, and further employment and active involvement in the life of the state and society. At present, unfortunately, every year, despite the number of projects and programmes implemented and a series of legislative acts, the number of children living in poverty today in the European Union is increasing in the European Union. Given the complex nature of poverty as a phenomenon, our Member States, together with the relevant EU institutions and institutions, in particular the European Commission, must do much more to guarantee children access to food, clothing, housing, quality education and so on. We must fight for these values. Support.

name: Deirdre Clune (PPE).
text: – Mr President, I was happy to support this report and I thank the rapporteur for bringing it to the floor today, because child poverty and the fact that we are told that one in four children in Europe lives below the poverty line is unacceptable. We have this knowledge and we need to act on it in terms of investing in education, in particular. Education is key and reduces poverty, and it is not good enough just to provide education facilities for children; we also need to involve families, parents and guardians in that mission to ensure that they fully buy into the fact that an education is a ticket for the children to relieve them from poverty. There is also much more we can do in the area of health care, housing and nutrition programmes, and for all of us here in this Parliament who know we are an ageing society: we are growing old. We will need these children in the future, and so there is not only a moral obligation to invest in these children right now, but it also makes sense from an economic and a societal point of view.

name: Филиз Хюсменова (ALDE).
text: – Mr President, according to Eurostat data, the percentage of children living in poverty and social exclusion for countries such as Bulgaria, Romania and Hungary reaches 40 percent. Child poverty leads to a lack of access to quality food, healthcare, dropping out of school. Limited opportunities form a vicious circle of social isolation.  That is why I support the report on reducing child inequality and poverty, and I believe that our policies should aim at addressing the causes of child poverty and supporting children and their development, unemployed parents, single mothers and parents of disadvantaged children. There is also a need for a specific strategy to invest in children under the European and Social Fund and the Fund to Support the Most Deprived, as well as to include overcoming child poverty among the Europe 2020 objectives.

name: Lucy Anderson (S&D).
text: – Mr President, I am pleased to vote for this report calling for a real commitment from Member States to tackle child poverty and reduce social inequalities. Across the EU, one in four children are living in poverty, and in my own constituency of London this increases to a shocking 37%. Many MEPs in this House were proud to support the report’s call for a child guarantee fund for each child to have access to free healthcare, childcare and education, as well as decent housing and adequate nutrition. Tomorrow in the UK Parliament, the Conservative Government will pursue further its shameful plans to cut in-work social security and will push an estimated 640 000 more children in London into poverty next year. In contrast, under Labour Governments before 2010, the number of children living in absolute poverty fell substantially. I and my colleagues will therefore continue to fight for child poverty to be eradicated everywhere.

name: Stanislav Polčák (PPE).
text: – Mr President, I also want to say that I voted in favour of this report, albeit with some embarrassment. It has been said that there is an increasing trend in the number of children at risk of poverty. This is undoubtedly true, and for this reason too, I considered it my duty to support this report. However, I do think that the state cannot replace a caring parent, and I am glad that some of the proposed provisions in that report have not been met, such as setting minimum standards for children's housing. Undoubtedly, it is important that children also live in reasonable conditions, but if parents can not provide this accommodation, then who will replace them? State? Or will it be the European Union? I am glad that some of the calls for social security have not been heard in this report, because it is beyond what the states can afford at the moment. But otherwise, I was happy to support this report.

name: Seán Kelly (PPE).
text: – A Uachtaráin, vótáil mé i bhfabhar na tuarascála seo mar is tuarascáil an-tábhachtach í. Táimid ag caint faoi leanaí óga agus iad i mbochtanas agus téann sé sin i gcoinne geallúintí a tugadh do leanaí óga i gCoinbhinsiún na Náisiún Aontaithe agus caithfimid rud éigin a dhéanamh faoi.  Dar ndóigh, nuair a bhíonn leanaí bocht, ní féidir leo aon rud a bheith acu. Agus gach rud a ghabhann le bochtanas, cuireann sé isteach orthu: easpa bia, easpa tithíochta, easpa seirbhísí sláinte, easpa seirbhísí oideachais agus fiú amháin gan seans a bheith acu súgradh agus cluichí a imirt. Ós rud é go bhfuil an tAontas Eorpach ar cheann de na réigiúin is saibhre ar domhan caithfimid a bheith an-fheargach i ndáiríre faoi seo; níl aon chiall leis. B’fhéidir go raibh leithscéal againn i rith an chúlaithe eacnamaíochta, ach ós rud é go bhfuil an geilleagar ag fás anois caithfimid díriú air seo go práinneach, agus gach seans a thabhairt do leanaí óga saol maith a bheith acu. Baineann sé seo le mo thír féin agus leis na tíortha eile san Aontas.

name: Csaba Sógor (PPE).
text: – Mr President, the children of today are citizens of the Europe of the future. Rising child poverty and persistent extreme poverty are among the most pressing challenges facing Europe of our time. It is alarming that the proportion of malnourished children in 21st-century Europe is increasing and diseases long thought to be defeated have reappereated. The risk of child poverty is also present in many Member States for families with high work intensity. The Commission should set out a roadmap to overcome these challenges, make the fight against child poverty and rising school drop-outs a priority for the management of the European Semester and the Europe 2020 strategy, and set sub-targets for reducing child poverty and social exclusion in the framework of the same strategy. This time, I would also like to draw the attention of all Member States to the importance of combating child poverty, which is the key to the future of our continent.

name: Monica Macovei (ECR).
text: – Mr President, the right to education, the right to healthcare, the right to have a roof over your head, the right to participate in decisions concerning them and much more are guaranteed for children in the UN Convention on the Rights of the Child. However, many children have not heard of this and many governments do not seem to hear about it and do not want to apply these provisions. In the Union it is a very serious situation. One in four children now lives on the edge of poverty and we are in the European Union, a rich world. This is the result of irresponsible government policies on the part of some governments. I voted for this report because it provides for measures to improve this situation, to have the capacity to change children's lives, to take measures on access to education, to health, to housing. I hope that these recommendations will also be implemented. Child poverty is the poverty of parents who do not have a job and who cannot afford to keep their children in schools. A Greek proverb says that a civilization blooms when people plant trees in the shadow of which they will never stand. Let's plant these trees. Without children there is no future.

name: Daniel Hannan (ECR).
text: – Mr President, my generation has seen the most severe fall in world poverty in human history. The number of people in severe poverty as defined and measured by the United Nations has fallen by two thirds over the last 25 years. The sharpest drops have been in Africa and Asia. And what has fuelled that extraordinary and happy story? Free trade: the integration of these markets into the global markets and the naked pursuit of profit by mobile phone companies and others bringing investment to these regions. I hate to break this to you in this house, but it was not caused by a vote on reducing inequalities with a special focus on child poverty: we have not contributed a jot or a tittle to these happy falls in global poverty. The best thing we can do in this Chamber is to release the genius of a free people. All we have to do is stop regulating, stop interfering and stand aside.

name: Diane Dodds (NI).
text: – Mr President, it is a sign of the times that, in a report focusing on the very important issue of inequality and child poverty, we are yet again debating an issue for which national governments should have primary responsibility. Member States, their authorities and their local representatives are best placed to identify where improvements can and must be made to ensure that each of their citizens has a fair and equal stake in society. It does not need Europe to dictate this. That said, there are a number of conclusions that can be drawn from the text of this report. I hold a balanced view on how to drum out inequalities and improve quality of life for everyone. We believe that, on the one hand, we in the United Kingdom as a nation are blessed and well equipped to provide proportionate, effective and accessible welfare benefits to those in our society who need them most; incentives for those who want to make the transition to the workplace; and protection for the most vulnerable. On the other hand, we feel a driving economic growth and creating jobs is the key to raising the quality of life for all.

name: Jonathan Arnott (EFDD).
text: – Mr President, you may believe in a high level of public services and a high tax economy; you may oppose privatisation; you may support wealth redistribution and income redistribution; and you may take a view that, fundamentally, universal benefits are better than means-tested benefits. Those are all positions which many people hold. But to my mind, it is fundamentally and morally wrong to misuse the very serious issue of child poverty as a vehicle to push these left—wing policies. I personally feel that there is far more that we should do, as a nation, within the United Kingdom to tackle child poverty. My problem with this report, however, was that it had so much content on issues that are so different to the issue of child poverty. Therefore I could not support the report as a whole.

name: William (The Earl of) Dartmouth (EFDD)
text: in writing. ‒ UKIP abstained on this non-legislative and non-binding report because we do not oppose actions to tackle the very serious issue regarding child poverty. However, we do oppose calling for any more EU initiatives and interference as the EU is completely undemocratic and the only people that should decide how we tackle child poverty should be our own elected government, not bureaucrats in Brussels. The EU’s own policy on this is a failure, as they have admitted they are very unlikely to hit their own target by 2020 on poverty and social exclusion. Also, if the UK didn’t pay £55 million a day to the EU, we could do so much more to help children who are in poverty. The EU is one of the problems, not the solution.

name: Isabella Adinolfi (EFDD)
text: in writing. \u2012 The document in analysis admirably illustrates the close connection between the persistence of social and economic inequalities and the increase in the rate of child poverty in the Member States. The financial, administrative and work obstacles that disadvantaged families or otherwise belonging to discriminated communities encounter inevitably have dramatic effects on children as they grow up. In this respect, it is hoped that the Member States will take substantial action to develop social policy instruments to prevent and combat this phenomenon. Improving the integration of marginalised communities, facilitating their access to the world of work and providing for qualitatively more significant social welfare instruments will undoubtedly improve the living conditions of the children themselves. To this end, I voted in favour.

name: Clara Eugenia Aguilera García (S&D)
text: in writing. I voted in favour because I find it unacceptable that today, in Europe, one in four children is at risk of poverty and social exclusion and twenty million do not have access to a hot meal a day. It is imperative that we ensure that all children have access to health care, education, decent housing and adequate food.  That is why the Socialists have proposed establishing a child guarantee as part of an integrated European plan to combat child poverty, which also encompasses programmes that provide aid and opportunities for parents to get out of situations of social exclusion and integrate into the labour market. In this regard, we deeply regret that the proposal is not accompanied by a specific guarantee fund, since the European right as a whole has not supported its creation.  The report also calls on the Commission to make the fight against child poverty a central priority of the new Annual Growth Survey 2016, because investing in children is not only investing in the future of the EU, but is a matter of social justice.

name: Marina Albiol Guzmán (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. I voted in favour of this report because it places the causes of child poverty in its true structural framework and not in the family sphere, as is often the case in neoliberal proposals. The fundamental role of the right to health, education and social protection, as well as the right to decent work, to combat child poverty is recognized. This highlights the need to build another society, and not just to adopt other policies, to end this serious social problem.

name: Martina Anderson (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. – I voted in favour of this very progressive report, which was authored by my GUE/NGL colleague. As a result of the economic crisis and the austerity measures that have been imposed, many social indicators have deteriorated, including the level of child poverty in Europe.  Between 2008 and 2012 the number of children at risk of poverty in the EU rose by almost one million. By 2013, one in four children in the EU was living at risk of poverty or social exclusion. This report understands child poverty as a multidimensional phenomenon, which needs to have a multidimensional solution. The solutions proposed in this report are based on policies that promote access to universal, public, free and quality education, health and social security services, promoted by Member States to children and their families. The proposals also guarantee cultural inclusion, democratic participation, nutrition and adequate housing.  Most importantly, this report acknowledges that child poverty cannot be viewed in isolation from the broader family and community context that children are raised in. As a result, the solutions proposed deal with tackling unemployment, promoting job security, parenting support and public development of social-educative networks.

name: Max Andersson (Verts/ALE)
text: Written. 'I voted in favour of a rejection of paragraph 47 second part because I believe that all children should have access to healthcare, education and childcare, but the way this is organised in the budgetary terms of the different Member States of the European Union is different. In Sweden, for example, this concerns, above all, municipal and regional budgets. The Member States should continue to have the right to design this according to their systems, and that is why I am voting against all Member States allocating a specific budget line for this issue.

name: Marie-Christine Arnautu (ENF)
text: In writing. This proposal fully incorporates the provisions of the United Nations Convention on the Rights of Children: education, health, housing, protection, recreation, free time, nutrition, and care in the family environment. Considering that child poverty continues to rise in the Eu, the European Parliament calls on the Commission to act by increasing ESF endowments and applying the principle of the European minimum income (European Parliament Resolution 2010/2039 INI). As for the Member States, they are asked to generally extend to children free access to public education, etc. Of course, child poverty is scandalous. Nevertheless, we should start by questioning the reasons for this poverty: broken families, widespread unemployment, neighbourhoods downgraded due to insecurity, uncontrolled immigration... The state no longer has the means to support its public services. Asking for them to be universal and free is unthinkable in the current situation. The fight against poverty starts with a return to full employment and a stable traditional family model. I voted in favour of the new proposal put forward by my National Front colleague, Dominique Marti. Since the latter did not obtain a majority, I voted against this report.

name: Jean Arthuis (ALDE)
text: In writing. I voted in favour of this deliberation because it calls on Member States to step up their efforts to tackle social inequalities, in particular against child poverty. Check out our map to learn more about the numbers in different countries.

name: Inés Ayala Sender (S&D)
text: in writing. I voted in favour because I find it unacceptable that today, in Europe, one in four children is at risk of poverty and social exclusion and twenty million do not have access to a hot meal a day. It is imperative that we ensure that all children have access to health care, education, decent housing and adequate food.  That is why the Socialists have proposed establishing a child guarantee as part of an integrated European plan to combat child poverty, which also encompasses programmes that provide aid and opportunities for parents to get out of situations of social exclusion and integrate into the labour market. In this regard, we deeply regret that the proposal is not accompanied by a specific guarantee fund, since the European right as a whole has refused to support its creation.  The report also calls on the Commission to make the fight against child poverty a central priority of the new Annual Growth Survey 2016, because investing in children is not only investing in the future of the EU, but is a matter of social justice.

name: Zigmantas Balčytis (S&D)
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of this proposal, which aims to encourage EU countries to step up their efforts to tackle child poverty, which has been exacerbated by the economic crisis. According to statistics on the 26 million people in the eu-25, the eu-25 member states are in the same climate as children in the EU are at risk of poverty and social exclusion. According to 2014 data, romania (51 %) (51%), Bulgaria (45.2 %) and Hungary (41.4 %) were the most children on the poverty line. In Lithuania, this figure was slightly higher than the EU average last year, reaching 28.9%. Compared to the period 2010-2013, the proportion of children at risk of poverty in Lithuania decreased by several percentage points. I agree that Member States need to increase the number and effectiveness of support and social rights initiatives specifically aimed not only at children but also on parents, and promote labour laws that guarantee families social protection and combat precarious work. I support the calls for Member States to provide the necessary subsidies to guarantee the right of all children to culture, sport and leisure.

name: Gerard Batten (EFDD)
text: in writing. ‒ UKIP abstained on this non-legislative and non-binding report because we do not oppose actions to tackle the very serious issue regarding child poverty. However, we do oppose calling for any more EU initiatives and interference as the EU is completely undemocratic and the only people that should decide how we tackle child poverty should be our own elected government, not bureaucrats in Brussels. The EU’s own policy on this is a failure, as they have admitted they are very unlikely to hit their own target by 2020 on poverty and social exclusion. Also, if the UK didn’t pay £55 million a day to the EU, we could do so much more to help children who are in poverty. The EU is one of the problems, not the solution.

name: Nicolas Bay (ENF)
text: In writing. The wise proposal of another resolution tabled by my group, Europe of Nations and Freedoms, was rejected, and I voted against this text proposed by the Vice-President of the Committee on Women's Rights and Gender Equality, Inês Cristina Zuber. Not a plenary without at least one report motivated by the fatal "gender theory". It should come as no surprise that I voted against the report of this Portuguese communist.

name: Hugues Bayet (S&D)
text: In writing. I have obviously supported this report, which recommends that Member States engage proactively in the development of policies to combat child poverty, focusing on correcting the main factors that contribute to child poverty. While one in four children in the EU is at risk of poverty, a multi-sector approach is needed to stop this dramatic and unacceptable phenomenon. This obviously involves appropriate social policies and aids, but also proactive measures in the area of employment, the fight against school drop-out, access to culture or all social activities. Helping vulnerable parents is also fundamental.

name: Beatriz Becerra Basterrechea (ALDE)
text: in writing. More than one in four children in the EU are at risk of poverty and social exclusion. This number has increased worryingly as a result of the economic crisis and continued social cuts by some European governments, such as the Government of the People's Party in Spain. More importantly, a Unicef report on children in Spain revealed that investment in children fell by 14.6% between 2010 and 2013, i.e. EUR 775 per child was cut, thus turning to pre-2007 figures. This report shows once again Parliament's commitment to combating child poverty, in line with its commitments under the United Nations Convention on the Rights of the Child and the 2030 Agenda for Sustainable Development.  That is why we voted in favour, although we deeply regret that no agreement has been reached for the creation of a specific fund to combat child poverty, which would have enabled greater investment, more efficient use of funds and better monitoring of their use.

name: Izaskun Bilbao Barandica (ALDE)
text: in writing. I voted in favour of the report on reducing inequalities, especially with regard to child poverty.  I voted in favour of the need to introduce a child guarantee with a specific fund as well as a section with binding objectives in the Annual Growth Index of the European Semester. In the European Union we have to put in place all the necessary mechanisms to end the scourge of child poverty, it is inadmissible. Our sons and daughters are our future.

name: Dominique Bilde (ENF)
text: In writing. The Zuber report is unfortunately a victim of its good intentions. Based on the fact that child poverty has increased significantly in recent years in Europe, the text disseminates a series of unrealistic proposals by making the wrong basis. Of course, the proposal covers all the rights of the child, including those mentioned in the United Nations convention on the subject. However, rapporteur Zuber forgets that the family environment depends on the well-being of the child, and that a viable solution to the problem of child poverty cannot be solved without the fight against the professional and social precariousness of parents. That is why I voted against this proposal and supported the one tabled by Dominique Martin on behalf of the ENL group. More realistically, my colleague's other motion for a resolution reminds us that it is by reducing parental unemployment in Europe that the future of children will be assured. On the other hand, it must be remembered that it is European austerity policies that are responsible for the decline of national social policies. It is therefore necessary to restore decision-making power to the Member States, which will therefore be able to implement genuine reforms of education and health systems for the benefit of children.

name: Mara Bizzotto (ENF)
text: in writing. \u2012 I fully agree with the aims of the text, which aims to set up a strategy to combat child poverty, ensuring children's access to education and care.  On the other hand, I do not agree with the methods and instruments proposed by the rapporteur to achieve these important objectives. The governance model of the European Semester, called for in the report, as well as greater interference by the Commission in social policies, have already proved to be more opportunities for failed and counterproductive instruments.  I abstained for all of these.

name: José Blanco López (S&D)
text: in writing. I voted in favour because I find it unacceptable that today, in Europe, one in four children is at risk of poverty and social exclusion and twenty million do not have access to a hot meal a day. It is imperative that we ensure that all children have access to health care, education, decent housing and adequate food.  That is why the Socialists have proposed establishing a child guarantee as part of an integrated European plan to combat child poverty, which also encompasses programmes that provide aid and opportunities for parents to get out of situations of social exclusion and integrate into the labour market. In this regard, we deeply regret that the proposal is not accompanied by a specific guarantee fund, since the European right as a whole has refused to support its creation.  The report also calls on the Commission to make the fight against child poverty a central priority of the new Annual Growth Survey 2016, because investing in children is not only investing in the future of the EU, but is a matter of social justice.

name: Vilija Blinkevičiūtė (S&D)
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the crucial report on combating extreme child poverty. The paradox is that, at present, in the European Union, the most developed continent, more than one in four children live in poverty, and in many countries poverty is more at risk for children than adults. I am therefore convinced that we need new concrete measures, as I propose and the Social Democratic Group. We urge the Commission and the Member States to create a Children's Guarantee that enables every needy child to receive free health and childcare, education, decent accommodation and adequate nutrition. This could be a similar measure to the youth employment initiative that is already in place. I am pleased that today the majority in the European Parliament supported the Children's Guarantee. In order to reduce child poverty, we need to create a special EU budget for this, because without money we will not be able to do anything. We now have different instruments to reduce child poverty, but they are not harmonised and, in most cases, money from the funds is allocated to other areas, and the money for investing in children simply is no longer there. So we need to combat poverty from as young age as possible, so that all children have equal opportunities and are not condemned to poverty. If we provide such opportunities from an early age, then there is a high probability that we will avoid extreme youth unemployment in the future and that we will not need to develop additional measures to combat such unemployment.

name: Andrea Bocskor (PPE)
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the report adopted today on reducing inequalities and, in particular, on child poverty. The main elements of the decision supported the measures introduced by the Hungarian Government in recent years. Nevertheless, the report adopted by the left-wing majority took into account the figures for older statistics and surveys, which significantly distorted the data and trends on the current situation.  In the course of the vote, I followed the People's Party position and I agree that job creation is a priority, just as high energy prices and the reduction of overheads contribute to the fight against poverty. Making children's meals free of charge and its more general accessibility have been one of the first priorities in the report, which I support. I also think it is right to say that easing household debt can also significantly improve and improve people's situation.

name: Franc Bogovič (PPE)
text: Writing. The UN Convention on the Rights of the Child stipuls states that all children must be guaranteed the right to education, healthcare, housing, protection, leisure, balanced nutrition and growing up in a family environment. Unfortunately, in the EU, we are witnessing that the provisions of the Convention are not being put into effect, and many children are only in greater distress. Poverty is deepening. The proportion of poor children of parents with lower levels of education has been increasing since 2008, with a higher risk of poverty among children born in socially deprived neighbourhoods and in ethnically unsuited communities. Therefore, the need to integrate all people from third countries already living in the EU, as well as those arriving in the EU in migrant waves, even in the light of the fight against child poverty, is urgent.  During my time in the mayorals of Krško, I devoted a great deal of time and energy to improving the situation of Roma and Roma children. Awareness of the importance of obtaining an education is particularly crucial. Social inequality is passed down from generation to generation, and children can suffer the consequences of poverty and social exclusion for the rest of their lives. Therefore, in tackling poverty, a set of vertical and horizontal measures is needed, which must go towards reducing social exclusion. One of the key conditions for this is the creation of quality jobs. I, of course, supported the report.

name: Simona Bonafè (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 More than one in four children in the European Union is at risk of poverty or social exclusion. Rising inequalities and child poverty are therefore realities that we cannot ignore. Among the factors which have underlined this trend are the austerity policies and their effects on socio-economic conditions and the labour market in the various countries, which have once again demonstrated the link between policies for the redistribution of wealth and employment and the widening of the social gap.  In the light of this, this report, which I support, aims to give greater visibility to the fight against child poverty, reminding us that an integrated approach is needed to tackle this problem. While it is necessary to strengthen the system of social protection services within the Union, so that they are able to guarantee all children access to health care and quality education, housing and balanced nutrition, we must also put families, especially the most disadvantaged, in a position to offer their children the best possible living conditions. , increasing existing opportunities in the labour market and ensuring a better work-family balance for parents.

name: Lynn Boylan (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of this report because it clearly calls for children to be prioritised in Member States when it comes to housing, education, health care and nutrition. Austerity policies have created a situation where 27.7% of children are at risk of poverty and social exclusion. In my home country, Ireland, the figure is above average and has actually doubled since the economic crash in 2008. Extremely worrying is the fact that 1 500 children are currently homeless in Ireland. This report addresses issues such as social exclusion and the need to tackle unemployment and promote job security, which will help to lift families out of poverty. The report encourages a holistic approach to dealing with the issue of child poverty and references the UN Convention on the Rights of the Child that guarantees all children universal access to housing, education, nutrition and healthcare.

name: Renata Briano (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 Austerity policies are creating social disasters in Europe: it is now clear to everyone that the cut in social services and investment by states has doubled the number of families living in poverty and social exclusion in Europe. The people most affected by austerity are children and single mothers: the proportion of children living in absolute and long-term poverty (over 3 years) is increasing. In countries such as Estonia, Greece and Italy, the number of children who cannot eat meat, chicken or fish has doubled for two consecutive days in a month. The increase in poverty also affects access to kindergartens, education and health services: since 2008, the number of families who cannot send their children to kindergarten or higher education and who give up medical or surgical services for lack of money has increased in all Member States. Rising inequalities and poverty exacerbate social fragmentation and early school leaving, depressing consumption and risking triggering major recessionary spirals. It is therefore clear that austerity has failed: we must reverse course and understand that no accounting data is worth as much as the health of our children.

name: Steeve Briois (ENF)
text: In writing. Child poverty has increased significantly in Europe as social inequalities are rising as a result of austerity measures in most Member States. The report recommends that the Commission introduce a European minimum income, increase the ESF budget and be more lenient with Member States on budgetary rigour. In addition, the rapporteur calls on the national authorities to guarantee free public schools and public transport for children. National governments are also required to improve public services and increase the number of social housing units. After imposing ultra-austerity policies in all EU states, the European institutions play the role of the arsonist. The recommendations are unenforceable in times of structural crisis aggravated by totally uncontrolled migratory pressure. That is why Dominique Martin, on behalf of the ENF Group, has tabled another motion for a resolution to introduce national preference in the allocation of social benefits in order to directly favour our most vulnerable nationals, victims of the consequences of savage globalisation and ultra-liberal policies applied in the European Union. So I voted against it.

name: Daniel Buda (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 The report on reducing inequalities, in particular child poverty, aims to develop policies to combat child poverty by reducing poverty factors and strengthening social support for children. In order to achieve the Europe 2020 strategy target of reducing the number of people affected by poverty by at least 20 million by 2020, it is necessary to give greater visibility to these policies on combating child poverty at the highest political levels of the Union. Given that one fifth of the total population of the Union is under the age of 18 and one in four children live on the edge of poverty or social exclusion throughout the EU, it is necessary that Member States resort to immediate measures to combat poverty and pay more attention to the use of the Union Structural Funds to increase overall well-being. I voted in favour of the report on reducing inequalities, in particular child poverty, believing that it was time for the Member States to act promptly in the development of policies to prevent and combat poverty, guaranteeing the right of all children to prosperous living conditions and equal access to culture, health and well-being.

name: Gianluca Buonanno (ENF)
text: in writing. \u2012 The report recommends the establishment of a roadmap for the implementation of the three-pillar approach adopted in the recommendation "Investing in children: breaking the vicious circle of social disadvantage", developing precise and specific indicators of the level of child poverty and the areas most affected by this phenomenon. The Member States will thus have to implement the specific recommendations issued by the Commission under the European Semester. The aims are noble and acceptable (the fight against child poverty, children's access to free public education and affordable care...), but I do not see how they can be achieved by insisting on the failed and a-democratic governance model represented by the European Semester. Furthermore, calling for a greater role for the Commission in the field of social assistance foreshadows excessive interference in the competences of the Member States.

name: Cristian-Silviu Buşoi (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 All children should be guaranteed the right to education, health services, protection, housing, the right to recreational activities and leisure time, balanced eating, the right to be raised in a family and the right to participate in decisions affecting them, in accordance with the UN Convention on the Rights of the Child. The Convention is far from being achieved within the EU, with all reports indicating an increase in child poverty levels in Europe. The risk of poverty and social exclusion increased between 2008 and 2012 from 26,5 % to 28 %, and in 2013 (according to Eurostat data) in the EU 28, 26.5 million children were at risk of poverty and social exclusion. I support the EP motion for a resolution on reducing inequalities, in particular child poverty, considering it necessary for Member States to provide subsidies to guarantee the right to culture, sport and recreational activities for all children, with a particular focus on children living in poverty, children in remote areas, children with disabilities and migrants.
