I also consider it important to strengthen the social rights guaranteed by the state in order to protect children from abuse, violence and neglect.

name: Soledad Cabezón Ruiz (S&D)
text: in writing. I voted in favour because I find it unacceptable that today, in Europe, one in four children is at risk of poverty and social exclusion and twenty million do not have access to a hot meal a day. It is imperative that we ensure that all children have access to health care, education, decent housing and adequate food.  That is why the Socialists have proposed establishing a child guarantee as part of an integrated European plan to combat child poverty, which also encompasses programmes that provide aid and opportunities for parents to get out of situations of social exclusion and integrate into the labour market. In this regard, we deeply regret that the proposal is not accompanied by a specific guarantee fund, since the European right as a whole has refused to support its creation.  The report also calls on the Commission to make the fight against child poverty a central priority of the new Annual Growth Survey 2016, because investing in children is not only investing in the future of the EU, but is a matter of social justice.

name: Alain Cadec (PPE)
text: In writing. The UN Convention on the Rights of the Child stipulates that all children are guaranteed the right to education, health services, housing, protection, recreation and free time, as well as a balanced diet and care in a family environment. However, there are still many problems with respect for children's rights in Europe. The report highlights these shortcomings and proposes some measures to eliminate poverty and social exclusion among children. We must ensure that children live in the best possible conditions both inside and outside the European Union. I voted in favour of this report.

name: Nicola Caputo (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted today in favour of the report on 'Reducing inequalities, with a particular focus on child poverty', because around 13 million children and adolescents in the European Union lack the basic elements necessary for their development. Too many children and adolescents still do not have access to basic goods or services necessary for their development in countries that have all the means to provide them with the possibility of complete development and determination. Inequalities between EU countries are increasing and it is alarming that the proportion of children suffering from malnutrition is increasing. The percentage of children who cannot afford to eat meat, chicken or fish for two consecutive days has dramatically doubled since 2008. The Member States must make a real effort to develop policies to combat child poverty, which focus on correcting the factors of child poverty and increase the effectiveness and quantity of social support specifically aimed at children.

name: James Carver (EFDD)
text: in writing. ‒ UKIP abstained on this non-legislative and non-binding report because we do not oppose actions to tackle the very serious issue regarding child poverty. However, we do oppose calling for any more EU initiatives and interference as the EU is completely undemocratic and the only people that should decide how we tackle child poverty should be our own elected government, not bureaucrats in Brussels. The EU’s own policy on this is a failure, as they have admitted they are very unlikely to hit their own target by 2020 on poverty and social exclusion. Also, if the UK didn’t pay £55 million a day to the EU, we could do so much more to help children who are in poverty. The EU is one of the problems, not the solution.

name: David Casa (PPE)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of this report because it outlines many measures which I believe will be effective in the elimination, or at least reduction, of child poverty and social exclusion. We need to make sure that the youngest members of our society meet their basic needs but also that they have access to quality education and health services.

name: Fabio Massimo Castaldo (EFDD)
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of this report because I believe it is essential that Member States increase support and social rights specifically aimed at children, but also at parents (such as unemployment benefits or increased maternity and paternity rights) in terms of quantity, amount, scope and effectiveness, and promote labour laws that guarantee social rights and family safety and combat precarious work , the illegal recruitment and exploitation of workers, implementing or strengthening universal social benefits for children as an intrinsic right of the child. I am pleased that the final text has included amendments calling for more protection for low-income families who are most at risk of poverty, given that child poverty is generated by family poverty. We have also pointed out in our amendments that there are still financial, administrative and other practical obstacles to education for children belonging to marginalised groups, that there is also a need for social support for unemployed parents such as the appropriate minimum income, also highlighting the phenomenon of the poor worker, and the need to increase public spending with a view to achieving objectives to combat child poverty.

name: Nessa Childers (S&D)
text: in writing. – We need to offer a future to our next generation by breaking the vicious circle of poverty at the youngest age possible. This means ensuring that every child at risk of poverty has access to free healthcare, free education, decent housing and adequate nutrition. In the last few years, the Commission has neglected this area of work, and it is about time that they put it back on the agenda, be it through pressure from the European Parliament or from the Member States’ citizens and civil society. Europe will fail the current and future generations if it does not address inequalities in access to basic human services, for European children, which are once again widening on our Continent. We call on the Commission to introduce a child guarantee, with a specific fund, ideally with the revision of next year’s multiannual financial framework. The child guarantee could be a long—term tool to offer equal opportunities to a whole generation as well as support for parents to come out of social exclusion situations and to integrate into the labour market.

name: Caterina Chinnici (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 The most recent data on the situation of children in Europe show a reality characterised by profound unacceptable inequalities. Indeed, the latest reports on child poverty present us with a worrying picture. From 2008 to 2012, the number of children at risk of poverty increased by about one and a half million: most of them do not have access to healthy eating, education and live in inadequate environments.  Faced with these figures, I believe that the objective of the Europe 2020 Strategy of reducing people at risk or in poverty and social exclusion by at least 20 million will hardly be achieved. We need to improve the coordination of European policies, but above all we need to 'invest in children', as was pointed out in the written declaration that we are promoting together with other colleagues. The debate on the review of the Europe 2020 Strategy will soon open and I really hope that this will be an opportunity to identify actions and measures aimed at designating long-term programmes to reduce poverty, but above all to give the European Union a real social dimension. I hope that the Commission will accept Parliament's request to introduce a guarantee for children with a specific fund. For these reasons, I voted in favour.

name: Λευτέρης Χριστοφόρου (
text: PPE), in writing. \u2012 Child poverty stems from the poverty of families. It is a fact that one fifth of the total EU population is under the age of 18 and that despite the commitments made, more than one in four children are currently at risk of poverty or social exclusion. It is also important to mention that women are at greater risk of poverty than men and that tackling women's poverty is not only important as an end in itself, but is also vital for efforts to reduce child poverty. So the report is very important and it is supported by us.

name: Κώστας Χρυσόγονος (
text: GUE/NGL), in writing. \u2012 The report on reducing inequalities with particular emphasis on child poverty leads to well-placed formulations on the need to protect a particularly sensitive social group, which is why I voted in favour.  However, my vote in favour is not an endorsement of the policy pursued by the European Union which exacerbates inequalities and child poverty. It is typical that in 2008-2012 alone the number of children at risk of poverty in Europe increased by one million. In Greece, one of the countries hardest hit by the economic crisis and austerity policies, the proportion of children living below or below the poverty line reached 37% in 2014, according to Eurostat. This grim reality is a major challenge for all of us to stand by weak social groups in every way to achieve an improvement in living conditions. It is obvious that the reports are not enough and Europe is finally called upon to make tangible and brave decisions.

name: Salvatore Cicu (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the report on reducing inequalities, with a particular focus on child poverty. According to the United Nations Convention on the Rights of the Child, all children must be guaranteed the right to education, health services, housing, protection, to participate in decisions affecting them, leisure and leisure activities, a balanced diet and growth within a family. However, within the European Union, the Convention is far from being satisfied. According to recent reports, children in Europe are also increasingly under the threat of poverty and social exclusion. Therefore, the European Parliament, with this report, calls on the Member States to take effective measures as soon as possible in order to respond to these challenges and to implement the objectives of the United Nations Convention on the Rights of the Child.

name: Alberto Cirio (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the report considering that the fight against child poverty must be given greater visibility at the highest European political level, so that the EU can achieve the europe 2020 strategy target of reducing the number of people affected by poverty by at least 20 million by 2020, and also considering that social inequalities, which have increased due to irresponsible and financially unsustainable public and budgetary policies , greatly encourage the increase in child poverty, and that in nineteen Member States children are the most at risk of poverty. In accordance with the UNITED Nations Convention on the Rights of the Child, all children should be guaranteed the right to education, health care services, housing, protection and participation in decisions affecting them. Finally, I would like to stress the need for the Commission to invest in public and publicly funded education, designating specific teaching methods for the most vulnerable social groups, because I believe that education can be a key priority in ensuring that children acquire the skills that will enable them to access skilled jobs.

name: David Coburn (EFDD)
text: in writing. ‒ UKIP abstained on this non-legislative and non-binding report because we do not oppose actions to tackle the very serious issue regarding child poverty. However, we do oppose calling for any more EU initiatives and interference as the EU is completely undemocratic and the only people that should decide how we tackle child poverty should be our own elected government, not bureaucrats in Brussels. The EU’s own policy on this is a failure, as they have admitted they are very unlikely to hit their own target by 2020 on poverty and social exclusion. Also, if the UK didn’t pay £55 million a day to the EU, we could do so much more to help children who are in poverty. The EU is one of the problems, not the solution.

name: Carlos Coelho (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 All children must have guaranteed the right to education, health services, housing, protection, participation in decisions affecting them, leisure and free time, a balanced diet and care in the family environment, as stipulated in the UN Convention on the Rights of the Child.  Unfortunately, in the EU, the convention is still far from being fully enforced. A comprehensive policy framework is therefore needed to address child poverty and promote child welfare on the basis of three pillars, including access to adequate resources within the Framework of the European Social Fund, access to inclusive and quality services and children's participation in society and the decision-making process, recognising children as rightholders. In the use of the financial resources of the European Structural and Investment Funds (ESIF) and in the definition of social policies, Member States should pay greater attention to ways of protecting families with children with health problems from poverty. Child support policies should be strongly marked by prevention, containing long-term strategies to combat social inequalities.

name: Jane Collins (EFDD)
text: in writing. – UKIP abstained on this non-legislative and non-binding report because we do not oppose actions to tackle the very serious issue regarding child poverty. However, we do oppose calling for any more EU initiatives and interference as the EU is completely undemocratic and the only people that should decide how we tackle child poverty should be our own elected government, not bureaucrats in Brussels. The EU’s own policy on this is a failure, as they have admitted they are very unlikely to hit their own target by 2020 on poverty and social exclusion. Also, if the UK didn’t pay £55 million a day to the EU, we could do so much more to help children who are in poverty. The EU is one of the problems, not the solution.

name: Lara Comi (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 Child poverty in Europe is experiencing an alarming increase. In numerical terms, between 2008 and 2012, the number of children at risk of poverty or social exclusion in Europe increased by almost one million, an increase of half a million in the period 2011 to 2012 alone. Child poverty prevents millions of children from having access to education, health care services, protection, leisure and leisure, balanced nutrition and a normal family environment. The main drivers of child poverty are the mismanagement of wealth redistribution strategies, the ineffectiveness of state income support measures, the inadequate provision of care services and the precarious work situation of parents. I therefore agree with the rapporteur's proposal to plan important policies to combat this phenomenon, aiming to stem the causes of this poverty and to increase the effectiveness, quantity and scope of social support specifically aimed at children. It will also be necessary to promote labour laws that guarantee social rights and a minimum wage, so as to offer greater security to families and combat precarious work.

name: Therese Comodini Cachia (PPE)
text: in writing. ‒ The number of children living in absolute or long-term poverty is increasing, thereby leading to a higher number of children also experiencing social exclusion and inequality. Poverty for children does not only mean the inability of a family to house and feed children but also takes into consideration the inability of children to participate in sports, culture, educational activities and so on. Recommendations made in this report encourage Member States to promote social rights and labour laws directed at children and their parents that strengthen the fundamental welfare benefits of the child. The report also calls for funds to be re-allocated to food aid programmes. In terms of education, steps must be taken to provide quality education and effective access to such education for all children whether they are impoverished or not. I thus voted in favour.

name: Ignazio Corrao (EFDD)
text: in writing. \u2012 The aim of the proposal is to increase and strengthen support for social rights in terms of quantity, amount and effectiveness, in particular with regard to the condition of children, but also to parents (such as unemployment benefits or increased maternity and paternity rights), promoting labour laws that guarantee social rights and family security and combat precarious work , the illegal recruitment and exploitation of workers, implementing or strengthening universal social benefits for children as an intrinsic right of the child. For these reasons, my vote could only be in favour.

name: Javier Couso Permuy (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. I voted in favour of this report because it places the causes of child poverty in its true structural framework and not in the family sphere, as is often the case in neoliberal proposals. The fundamental role of the right to health, education and social protection, as well as the right to decent work, to combat child poverty is recognized. This highlights the need to build another society, and not just to adopt other policies, to end this serious social problem.

name: Andrea Cozzolino (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 Social inequalities greatly promote the increase in child poverty and, on the basis of recent data, are on the increase in Europe although reducing social exclusion and poverty are among the objectives of the Europe 2020 strategy. The European Parliament, in its resolution, which I voted in favour of, calls on the Commission and the Member States to take urgent measures to address these issues. In particular, we are calling for more investment that will have an effect on children, for example in education and education, including through better use of the European Social Fund, the European Aid Fund for the Most Deprived and the EU Programme for Employment and Social Innovation. In addition, it is considered that children should also be a priority in the planning and implementation of regional and cohesion policies. In order to fully solve this problem, the European Parliament calls on the Commission to create indicators for the analysis of child poverty, with regard to access to education, child care, health services and housing. Only with clear data on the dimension of social exclusion and child poverty will we be able to implement the right policies.

name: Pál Csáky (PPE)
text: Writing. \u2012 According to the UN Convention, all children should have the right to normal living conditions, such as education, health care, rest, balanced meals and the right to a normal family environment. Yet poverty and social exclusion are high in Europe, limiting children's chances of good quality education and health care. The report proposes measures to address these problems, focusing on child poverty and the root causes of related problems. Eradicating child poverty must play a very important role in all Member States, so I voted in favour of this report.

name: Edward Czesak (ECR)
text: I would like to write to the Commission. \u2012 According to Eurostat data, the number of children at risk of poverty and social exclusion in the EU is increasing from year to year. This problem is directly linked to social inequalities, m.in. as a result of inadequate and financially irrational policies for the management of the state, implemented in many Member States. In nine of them, including Poland, even children from high-intensity families are at risk of poverty. More than 20% of EU citizens are under the age of 18, which should in particular motivate action to improve their current situation. First of all, the fight against child poverty should become a priority at the highest political level of the EU, which should consequently translate into the policies of the national governments of the Member States. It is worth stressing that the Europe 2020 strategy aims to reduce the number of people affected by poverty by at least 20 million by 2020, and that the use of structural funds, hitherto rarely earmarked for such purposes, could help to achieve this demand. However, it is essential that the Member States are fully involved in trying to solve this problem, which I believe should be expressed above all in the development of national policies to combat child poverty at central and local level. In the interests of the fate of the youngest EU citizens, I voted in favour of the resolution.

name: Miriam Dalli (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of this report as I believe that children are our present and our future and as politicians we need to do our best to provide them with a safe, healthy and prosperous environment for them to reach their full potential. However the crisis that some Member States face has, together with their austerity policies, contributed to the increase in child poverty levels. As the Commission has avoided developing any proposals in this respect, this report aims at putting forward suggestions to help the EU reduce poverty and inequality in this field and work towards Europe 2020 targets. I supported these suggestions as I believe that we need to offer a future to our next generation by breaking the vicious circle of poverty at the youngest age possible. This means ensuring that every child at risk of poverty has access to free healthcare, free education, decent housing and adequate nutrition.

name: Viorica Dăncilă (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 I support and reinforce the rapporteur's idea that both the European Commission and the European Parliament should use the opportunity offered by the mid-term review of the Multiannual Financial Framework to increase appropriations for the European Social Fund and the Food Aid Programme for the most deprived. It is also important for the European Commission to implement the minimum European income, as supported by Parliament in its 2010 resolution on the role of minimum income in the fight against poverty and in promoting an inclusive society in Europe.

name: Michel Dantin (PPE)
text: In writing. This initiative report proposes measures to eliminate poverty and social exclusion among children, who are increasingly at risk in Europe, according to the UN. Between 2008 and 2012, the number of children at risk of poverty or social exclusion in Europe increased by almost one million. In 2013, 26.5 million children in the EU were at risk of falling into poverty or social exclusion. Focusing on the causes of child poverty and its elimination, the report proposes to set indicators to better assess poverty, social exclusion, discrimination and participation in public life. Supporting the objectives of this text, as well as the emphasis on education and training, I voted in favour.

name: Rachida Dati (PPE)
text: In writing. The number of children at risk of poverty or social exclusion is increasing in the European Economic Area. It is therefore necessary for the Union to act in order to tackle the economic and social causes of child poverty and to develop indicators to better assess this phenomenon. That is why I voted in favour of this report.

name: Isabella De Monte (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 According to the United Nations Convention on the Rights of the Child, all children must be guaranteed the right to education, health services, housing, protection, leisure and growth within a family. However, within the EU, the Convention is far from being satisfied. Child poverty in Europe is on the increase as social inequalities increase. The latter generate intergenerational disadvantages and the negative effects of poverty and social exclusion on children can last a lifetime. Poverty is multidimensional and must be understood not only as a lack of coverage of children's basic needs, but also as a lack of access to education and the inability to participate in recreational activities. I voted in favour of this report because I believe it is essential to offer children the opportunity to live in an environment that allows them to grow and develop cognitive, communication, social and emotional skills that are essential for their future.

name: Marielle de Sarnez (ALDE)
text: In writing. Under-18s are now most at risk of social exclusion. In Europe, too many children today do not have access to education, medical care, a balanced diet and well-being activities. It is essential that the Commission and the Member States mobilise to combat these scourges. This fight will only be effective if sufficient resources are allocated. In this regard, the creation of a European fund specifically dedicated to the reduction of child poverty is a good move.

name: Angélique Delahaye (PPE)
text: In writing. Child poverty and social exclusion are growing with increasing social inequalities: children born in economically disadvantaged neighbourhoods or regions, whose parents have low levels of education or employment, are more likely to have limited access to health services and education. As a result, I voted in favour of the Zuber report on reducing inequality, in particular child poverty. The resolution recommends that Member States increase the amount, amounts, scope and effectiveness of social assistance specifically for children while developing preventive social policies to avoid child poverty. I welcome the adoption of this report, which will provide the necessary support to ensure that all children have the right to health, culture, sport and leisure.

name: Andor Deli (PPE)
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the report adopted today on reducing inequalities and, in particular, on child poverty. In the course of the vote, I followed the People's Party position and agreed with the reporter that job creation is a priority, just as high energy prices and the reduction of overheads contribute to the fight against poverty. Making children's meals free of charge and its more general accessibility are among the first priorities in the report, which supports the hungarian government's correct approach to date. I also share the view that the easing of household debt can also significantly improve and improve people's situation, which has also been a priority of the Hungarian Government in recent years.

name: Gérard Deprez (ALDE)
text: In writing. I supported this resolution calling on Member States to make the fight against child poverty a priority. The UN Convention on the Rights of the Child stipulates that all children should have access to education, health care, housing, recreational activities and a balanced diet. However, 26 million European children are at risk of poverty and social exclusion, or 27.7% of under-18s. The figures vary from one Member State to another: they are mostly high in the Eastern countries. In Belgium, in 2014, 23.2% of children were affected. An increasing number of children are also at risk of malnutrition. The problem is multidimensional. Poverty is not just about money, it is also linked to issues of social exclusion, health and education. Children living in single-parent families are generally more likely to face poverty. Among the recommendations I support in particular is the call for Member States to guarantee all children access to public education, free, open to all and of quality at all ages.

name: Tamás Deutsch (PPE)
text: Writing. – I voted in favour of the report adopted today on reducing inequalities and, in particular, on child poverty. The main elements of the decision were originally based on the proposals of MEP Adam Kósa, which supported the measures introduced by the Hungarian Government in recent years. Nevertheless, the report adopted by the left-wing majority took into account the figures for older statistics and surveys, which significantly distorted the data and trends on the current situation.  In the course of the vote, we followed the People's Party position and agreed with the reporter that job creation is a priority, just as high energy prices and the reduction of overheads contribute to the fight against poverty. Adam Kósa's proposal to make children's meals free of charge and its more general accessibility was one of the first priorities in the report, which supports the correct approach of the Hungarian Government to date. We also share the view that the easing of household debt can also significantly improve and improve people's situation, which has also been a priority of the Hungarian Government in recent years.

name: Mireille D'Ornano (ENF)
text: In writing. The aim of this report was to reduce child poverty worldwide. However, while child poverty is a problem that cannot be overlooked, it is primarily the work of the parents. It is essential to focus on the incomes of parents, who are solely responsible for their children. The European Union does not have to interfere in family relations and structure that fall under the responsibility of single parents. Finally, since gender theory is still wrongly included here, I voted for the other proposal tabled by our group, and I voted against the other proposals.

name: Ian Duncan (ECR)
text: in writing. ‒ Whilst I recognise the urgent need to combat inequalities, including child poverty, I do not consider it a competence of the EU to instruct Member States on how best to deliver policies that are tailored to match the needs of people throughout the UK. I recognise the potential value of the EU as a means to focus attention on the need for action, and for brokering exchanges of advice and assistance for those Member States that need it. This report calls for too many initiatives which go beyond what the role of EU should be.

name: Ангел Джамбазки (ECR)
text: in writing. \u2012 I agree that there is a lot of data and statistics that show that child poverty is on the rise. Bulgaria continues to have the highest child poverty rate in the European Union. Data from the National Children's Network show that about 637 thousand children in our country live at risk of poverty and social exclusion. This is almost twice the EU average. However, measures are needed to solve such a problem, but I do not find this report to offer such concrete measures. This is just exposing the problems in the sector. The proposal for a special fund to guarantee poor children to receive free education, healthcare, clothes, etc. may be a wonderful idea, but utopian. Who do you think will fill this fund and how do I ask Bulgaria to offer such free services when our GDP in 2014 is EUR 5,500 per capita and that of Belgium for the same period is EUR 33,800? Children are our future and offering them health and education is our moral obligation! We have all also signed the UN Convention on the Rights of the Child and it imposes legal obligations on states to provide the necessary conditions for children's rights to be effectively exercised.

name: Γεώργιος Επιτήδειος (
text: NI), in writing. \u2012 In many Member States and especially in Greece the proportion of children living in absolute and long-term poverty due to the economic crisis is increasing. The negative policy measures taken today will have irreparable negative effects on children's lives and society.  The report refrains from recommending changes and cuts to the public services of the Member States, and proposes instead a more coherent policy of increasing and reallocating EU funds. To this end, it is also imperative to repeal the Treaty on Economic Governance and Budget.  The report also supports the necessary subsidies to ensure the right to education, culture, sport and entertainment for all children in order to protect themselves from abuse, violence and neglect.  Finally, the report calls for an increase in the number of staff and specialists in social services in order to increase the medical, psychological and social care of children, which means job creation. For all the above reasons we are voting in favour of report A8-0310/2015.

name: Norbert Erdős (PPE)
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the report adopted today on reducing inequalities and, in particular, on child poverty. The main elements of the decision were originally based on the proposals of MEP Adam Kósa, which supported the measures introduced by the Hungarian Government in recent years. Nevertheless, the report adopted by the left-wing majority took into account the figures for older statistics and surveys, which significantly distorted the data and trends on the current situation. In the course of the vote, we followed the People's Party position and agreed with the reporter that job creation is a priority, just as high energy prices and the reduction of overheads contribute to the fight against poverty. Adam Kósa's proposal to make children's meals free of charge and its more general accessibility was one of the first priorities in the report, which supports the correct approach of the Hungarian Government to date. We also share the view that the easing of household debt can also significantly improve and improve people's situation, which has also been a priority of the Hungarian Government in recent years.

name: Rosa Estaràs Ferragut (PPE)
text: in writing. U2012 Poverty is not just a matter of money. In addition to the inability to access basic needs of children, such as food, clothing and housing, poverty is also linked to social exclusion and lack of access to quality health and education. Therefore, from the EU and under the UN Convention on the Rights of the Child, we must continue to work to ensure that children can access these rights. This week, MEPs overwhelmingly adopted a resolution calling on EU countries to re-develop their efforts to combat child poverty and social inequalities.  And this draft report proposes a series of measures to eliminate poverty and social exclusion among children, therefore being in the right direction to continue to make progress in reducing child poverty as well as its consequences.

name: Bill Etheridge (EFDD)
text: in writing. – UKIP abstained on this non-legislative and non-binding report because we do not oppose actions to tackle the very serious issue regarding child poverty. However, we do oppose calling for any more EU initiatives and interference as the EU is completely undemocratic and the only people that should decide how we tackle child poverty should be our own elected government, not bureaucrats in Brussels. The EU’s own policy on this is a failure, as they have admitted they are very unlikely to hit their own target by 2020 on poverty and social exclusion. Also, if the UK didn’t pay £55 million a day to the EU, we could do so much more to help children who are in poverty. The EU is one of the problems, not the solution.

name: Fredrick Federley (ALDE)
text: Written. \u2012 The resolution contains a number of deeply problematic points. Among other things, it is, in my view, completely wrong that the EU should advocate a statutory minimum wage, it is something for the Member States to decide on and in Sweden wages should be set by the social partners. It is also wrong policy to advocate increased public spending and to advocate that the Commission should refrain from recommending privatisations and more flexible working conditions. A number of Member States, including Sweden, face major structural challenges that require both more flexible working conditions and privatisations. I voted against these errors, but I voted in favour of this resolution. The work on reducing child poverty is a very important issue and this report addresses, among other things, the need for strong protection systems to protect children against violence and the need for prevention to reduce poverty. These are important issues for me that I chose to support in voting in favour of the report. Both efforts to reduce child poverty and work on a more flexible labour market will continue and I look forward to continuing to be a part of that work.

name: José Manuel Fernandes (PPE)
text: in writing. Child poverty is a reality in the EU: 1 in 4 children are at risk of poverty and social exclusion. Under the United Nations Convention on the Rights of the Child, all children have the right to education, health care, accommodation, leisure and a balanced diet. According to Eurostat, in 2014, around 26 million children and young people were at risk of poverty and social exclusion, i.e. 27.7% of all children living in the EU. There are children living at risk of poverty in all Member States. The countries with the highest percentage of children living at risk of poverty are Romania (51%), Bulgaria (45.2%) and Hungary (41.4%). The countries with the lowest percentages are Denmark (14.5%), Finland (15.6%) and Sweden (16.7%). Malnutrition is also growing among European children. According to UNICEF, in Estonia, Greece and Italy, the proportion of children who cannot be allowed to eat meat or fish every two days has doubled since 2008. Member States therefore need to ensure access to education, health and social security for children and their families, and unemployment, promoting job security and parental-educational and social networks, balanced food and adequate housing needs to be addressed. I voted in favour of the report.

name: Edouard Ferrand (ENF)
text: In writing. I voted against this deliberation because the other proposal tabled by a colleague in our group was not taken into account.

name: João Ferreira (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. \u2012 More than a quarter of children in the EU live at risk of poverty or social exclusion. In 2013, 26.5 million children were at risk of falling into poverty and social exclusion. The policies that have impoverished families are the same ones that throw children into poverty, denying them the rights contained in the Convention on the Rights of the Child, including the rights to health, education and social protection. The report recommends that Member States legislate social rights, including an appropriate mandatory minimum wage that respects national practices and collective agreements and provides greater security for families and combats precarious links by promoting work with social rights. The European Commission is urged to refrain from recommending reformulations and cuts in the public administration of the Member States, promoting the flexibilization of labour relations and the privatisation of public services, which have unequivocally led to the weakening of children's social rights. The report argues that poverty prevention policies should ensure universal and free access to public services, particularly with regard to childcare, education, health, housing and leisure activities. It advocates universal social subsidies aimed at children, as their own intrinsic right. This report was required.

name: Raffaele Fitto (ECR)
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted against the European Parliament's motion for a resolution on reducing inequalities, with a particular focus on child poverty. Despite my renewed support for proactive policies for children's rights and household welfare, this proposal contains a programme of 'redistribution of wealth' the wording of which must, in my view, remain national and not European.

name: Monika Flašíková Beňová (S&D)
text: Writing. \u2012 The proposed European Parliament resolution aims to encourage Member States to invest more in children, support their upbringing and development. The number of children directly at risk of poverty in Europe has been increasing since 2008. This negative trend cannot be reversed satisfactorily, despite some degree of economic recovery. The increase in the risk of poverty and social exclusion of children is linked to economic difficulties and the way in which Europe has decided to deal with them in recent years. These are millions of children across the European Union, and the cause is undoubtedly mainly the austerity measures of recent years. They also result in a reduction in social support for young families or a higher threat of unemployment. The threat of poverty to children is increasing along with social inequalities. The lowest proportion of children living in poverty is in the states with the strongest social systems. Examples include scandinavian countries in particular, but also neighbouring Austria.

name: Lorenzo Fontana (ENF)
text: in writing. \u2012 This report cannot be supported because, although the aims are noble and acceptable (the fight against child poverty, children's access to free public education and affordable care), I do not see how they can be achieved by insisting on the failed European governance model.

name: Λάμπρος Φουντούλης (
text: NI), in writing. \u2012 In many Member States and especially in Greece the proportion of children living in absolute and long-term poverty due to the economic crisis is increasing. The negative policy measures taken today will have irreparable negative effects on children's lives and society.  The report refrains from recommending changes and cuts to the public services of the Member States, and proposes instead a more coherent policy of increasing and reallocating EU funds. To this end, it is also imperative to repeal the Treaty on Economic Governance and Budget.  The report also supports the necessary subsidies to ensure the right to education, culture, sport and entertainment for all children, in order to protect themselves from abuse, violence and neglect.  Finally, the report calls for an increase in the number of staff and specialists in social services in order to increase the medical, psychological and social care of children, which means job creation. For all the above reasons I am voting in favour of report A8-0310/2015.

name: Doru-Claudian Frunzulică (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ Considering the alarming increasing levels of poverty and child poverty that the crisis and austerity policies have created in the EU, I believe it is about time to raise awareness about the need to develop policy responses to reduce poverty and inequalities in the EU and work towards the EU2020 targets. I strongly support the introduction, in the report, of the Europe 2020 sub-target on reducing child poverty and social exclusion, to make the reduction of child poverty and social exclusion visible and explicit at all stages of the European Semester, to include in each Annual Growth Survey a specific section with the binding target on fighting child poverty and promoting children’s well-being. It is fundamental that we enhance universal welfare benefits targeting children and that we invest in free, public education. We need to offer a future to our next generation by breaking the vicious circle of poverty at the youngest age possible. This means ensuring that every child at risk of poverty has access to free healthcare, free education, decent housing and adequate nutrition.

name: Kinga Gál (PPE)
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the report adopted today on reducing inequalities and, in particular, on child poverty. The main elements of the decision were originally based on the proposals of MEP Adam Kósa, which supported the measures introduced by the Hungarian Government in recent years. Nevertheless, the report adopted by the left-wing majority took into account the figures for older statistics and surveys, which significantly distorted the data and trends on the current situation.  In the course of the vote, we followed the People's Party position and agreed with the reporter that job creation is a priority, just as high energy prices and the reduction of overheads contribute to the fight against poverty. Adam Kósa's proposal to make children's meals free and its more general accessibility was one of the first priorities in the report, which supports the correct approach of the Hungarian Government to date. We also share the view that easing household debt can also significantly improve and improve people's situation, which has also been a priority of the Hungarian government in recent years.

name: Ildikó Gáll-Pelcz (PPE)
text: Writing. \u2012 In view of the UN Convention on the Rights of the Child, which provides for the right of all children to education, health services, housing, protection, participation in decisions affecting them, leisure activities and free time, a balanced diet and to be raised in a family, I believe that their fulfilment in the EU is unfortunately unsatisfactory. It is worrying that the proportion of children living in persistent extreme poverty (over a three-year period) is increasing. Social inequalities re-generate disadvantages for generations, and the negative effects of poverty and social exclusion on children can last a lifetime. I therefore believe that improper policy measures will have an irreversible negative impact on the lives of these people and on society. I support member states providing the support they need to ensure the right to culture, sport and leisure for all children, with a focus on children with disabilities and migrant children in poverty, remote areas and disabled areas. In order to protect children from abuse, violence and neglect, it is important to strengthen the social rights which the State must guarantee, increasing the number of staff and professionals providing social services with a view to enhancing the medical, psychological and social care of young people.

name: Francesc Gambús (PPE)
text: in writing. I voted in favour of the conviction that, as provided for in the United Nations Convention on the Rights of the Child, all children should be guaranteed the right to education, health services, housing, protection, decisions affecting them, leisure and leisure, a balanced diet and family care. The EU must therefore legislate in order to comply with the provisions of the Convention. We cannot allow child poverty to grow in Europe, as all reports indicate. Social inequalities reproduce disadvantages intergenerationally, and the negative effects of poverty and social exclusion on children can last a lifetime. The EU must therefore do more and better to eradicate the scourge of child poverty and inequalities.

name: Iratxe García Pérez (S&D)
text: in writing. I voted in favour because I find it unacceptable that today, in Europe, one in four children is at risk of poverty and social exclusion and twenty million do not have access to a hot meal a day. It is imperative that we ensure that all children have access to health care, education, decent housing and adequate food.  That is why the Socialists have proposed establishing a child guarantee as part of an integrated European plan to combat child poverty, which also encompasses programmes that provide aid and opportunities for parents to get out of situations of social exclusion and integrate into the labour market. In this regard, we deeply regret that the proposal is not accompanied by a specific guarantee fund, since the European right as a whole has refused to support its creation.  The report also calls on the Commission to make the fight against child poverty a central priority of the new Annual Growth Survey 2016, because investing in children is not only investing in the future of the EU, but is a matter of social justice.

name: Eider Gardiazabal Rubial (S&D)
text: in writing. It is unacceptable that today, in Europe, one in four children is at risk of poverty and social exclusion and twenty million do not have access to a daily hot meal. It is imperative that we ensure that all children have access to health care, education, decent housing and adequate food. That is why I voted in favour of this report. The Socialists have proposed to establish a child guarantee as part of an integrated European plan to combat child poverty, which also encompasses programmes that provide aid and opportunities for parents to get out of situations of social exclusion and integrate into the labour market. In this regard, we deeply regret that the proposal is not accompanied by a specific guarantee fund, since the European right as a whole has refused to support its creation.  The report also calls on the Commission to make the fight against child poverty a central priority of the new Annual Growth Survey 2016, because investing in children is not only investing in the future of the EU, but is a matter of social justice.

name: Enrico Gasbarra (S&D)
text: in writing. – The serious crisis in Europe has inevitably undermined the socio-economic, health and cultural policies of national governments, contributing to the increase in social inequalities and, in particular, to the risk of child poverty: in 2013, according to Eurostat data, 26.5 million children were at risk of poverty in Europe. These numbers are unacceptable to the Eu ropean Union, which should instead be the first guarantor of human rights and those of children in particular, as the United Nations Convention proclaims. This is the time to act: it is up to us MEPs to try to intervene by seizing the opportunity, as suggested in Mrs Zuber's report, which I support, for the mid-term review of the multiannual framework of EU Social Fund appropriations, by promoting a redirect of funds for social inclusion actions and combating the risks of malnutrition, family breakdown, overexposure to chronic diseases of the little ones without the guarantee of free and democratic access to treatment. Europe is allocated its resources and commitments to ensure respect for the fundamental rights of our children.

name: Elena Gentile (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the EP resolution on child poverty because one in four children in the EU is at risk of poverty and social exclusion. A real fight against this profound injustice must be a maximum commitment for the EU and the Member States as well as for other emergencies. The situation in the EU is leopard-print, but the figures that Eurostat gives us are inescapable: as many as 26 million children in 2014 were at risk of poverty and social exclusion, that is, 27.7% of the entire European population, with the aggravating fact that, given their age, children are unable to provide for their livelihood on their own. Child poverty is a multifaceted problem, it is not just a problem of lack of funds or will, it is fundamentally a problem linked to social exclusion, health and education. A poor child is a child who is not fed well, who does not receive adequate education, and will be an adult excluded from the world of work, because he is poorly educated and consequently excluded from vocational training. Investing in children is the best investment society can make. I now give the floor to the Commission, which must do more immediately.

name: Arne Gericke (ECR)
text: Writing. I voted against today the report on reducing inequality, with a particular focus on child poverty, because the non-legislative own-initiative report, despite some good approaches, clearly overshoots its objective in many areas, disregards parents' rights and violates subsidiarity. I fully support the rights of children, but I am at least as convinced that this must be done at the relevant political levels. For this reason too, I am clearly rejecting the S&D Group's proposal to create a 'European Child Guarantee'. Children need action, not words.

name: Jens Gieseke (PPE)
text: Writing. Child poverty is still a sad reality in Europe. This must be consistently counteracted. Children are the future for our ageing society. That is why I welcome this report and continue to work to reduce social inequality and make education accessible to all.

name: Neena Gill (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ Child poverty remains a problem in my constituency of the West Midlands, as in the rest of the UK. UK Government policies, however, perpetuate situations where poverty needlessly affects young people. Labour MEPs have always championed a better quality of life, especially for the most vulnerable in society. I supported this report, which calls for a real commitment from Member States to tackle the factors which are causing child poverty and increase the scope of social support for children. It promotes labour laws that guarantee – amongst other things – a statutory adequate minimum wage and collective agreement, which will provide greater security for families and help us fight precarious employment.

name: Juan Carlos Girauta Vidal (ALDE)
text: in writing. ‒ This report received my support today. Indeed, a special focus should be placed on child poverty and I commend the rapporteur for bringing this to the floor in today’s vote. How is it possible in today’s day and age that one in four of Europe’s children live below the poverty line? We have to do more, much more and invest further in education. In addition, I voted in favour of the introduction of a child guarantee with its specific fund which could have clear objectives at European Level. Furthermore, I supported a specific indicator on children at risk of poverty or social exclusion in the Economic and Monetary Union.

name: Tania González Peñas (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. The report is a progressive text, with a multidimensional approach to child poverty, for which comprehensive solutions are also called for. Among others, it is proposed that Member States adopt policies that promote access to universal, public, free and quality health care, social services and education for both children and families, while ensuring cultural inclusion, democratic participation, balanced food and adequate housing. The report links the situation of poverty and social exclusion of children to that of their parents and stresses that, in order for children to have their children welfare and their children's rights safeguarded, measures must be taken to address unemployment, safety at work, family support or the public development of socio-educational networks. It is important to mention that the text reflects gender aspects. The report does not reflect our rejection of the European Semester or country-specific recommendations but, in any event, its content is positive for reducing inequalities, with particular attention to child poverty, so we voted in favour.

name: Maria Grapini (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted for this report and all the amendments tabled because I believe that there is a need for an intensification of policies to reduce inequality, in particular child poverty. The increase in the number of children at risk of poverty, the large number of more than 25 million children at risk of poverty requires emergency measures to save children from the clutches of hunger, poverty and exclusion. There is a need to invest in policies to reduce early school leaving, education being an equal European right for all citizens. At the same time, there is a need to reduce poverty and to be able to access the health prevention and health insurance system. I consider this report and its provisions appropriate, and I voted for it in the hope that the measures will be implemented.

name: Theresa Griffin (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of this report because child poverty in my constituency remains a problem and the Tories continue to be bent on maintaining a situation where poverty needlessly affects young people. Labour MEPs have always championed a better quality of life, especially for the most vulnerable in society. The report calls for a real commitment from Member States to tackle the factors which are causing child poverty and increase the scope of social support for children. It promotes labour laws that guarantee – amongst other things – a statutory adequate minimum wage and collective agreement, which will provide greater security for families and fight precarious employment.

name: Enrique Guerrero Salom (S&D)
text: in writing. I voted in favour because I find it unacceptable that today, in Europe, one in four children is at risk of poverty and social exclusion and twenty million do not have access to a hot meal a day. It is imperative that we ensure that all children have access to health care, education, decent housing and adequate food.  That is why the Socialists have proposed establishing a child guarantee as part of an integrated European plan to combat child poverty, which also encompasses programmes that provide aid and opportunities for parents to get out of situations of social exclusion and integrate into the labour market. In this regard, we deeply regret that the proposal is not accompanied by a specific guarantee fund, since the European right as a whole has refused to support its creation.  The report also calls on the Commission to make the fight against child poverty a central priority of the new Annual Growth Survey 2016, because investing in children is not only investing in the future of the EU, but is a matter of social justice.

name: Sylvie Guillaume (S&D)
text: In writing. More than one in four children is at risk of poverty in Europe. It's unacceptable. That is why I supported the report, which aims to reduce child poverty. It proposes a comprehensive approach emphasizing the need to create analytical tools and implement policies to combat these phenomena. The policy-advised policies are multidimensional and address the main factors of child poverty, which are not just financial, allowing for a global view and approach to combating it. They concern both parents (through labour legislation, the fight against unemployment, social assistance), children's access and school journey, extracurricular activities, necessary health care, housing and a balanced diet. We also encourage the implementation of monitoring of these policies through relevant tools, in order to pursue long-term and preventive actions that will eradicate social inequalities and child poverty. Finally, this resolution also aims to combat violence against children.

name: Antanas Guoga (ALDE)
text: in writing. ‒ I have voted for the report on reducing inequalities with a special focus on child poverty since this is a very sensitive issue. I strongly believe that all Member States should put their best efforts to combat child poverty. Member States when using European Structural and Investment Funds (ESIF) resources and developing social policies, should devote greater attention to protecting families (especially single-parent families) with children with health problems, against poverty. It is of utmost importance to invest in sensible child—welfare policies that support the development of empowered individuals, capable of integrating into society and into the labour market, rather than focusing on the consequences of their social exclusion and poverty.

name: Jytte Guteland Anna Hedh Olle Ludvigsson Jens Nilsson och Marita Ulvskog (S&D)
text: Written. More than one in four children in the EU is currently at risk of poverty or social exclusion. Between 2008 and 2012, the number of children at risk of poverty or social exclusion in Europe increased by nearly one million, half a million of them between 2011 and 2012 alone. The consequences are many, for example, the proportion of children suffering from malnutrition is now increasing, with the result that diseases that have previously disappeared from the EU (such as rickets) are recurrence. The fight against child poverty urgently needs to be given greater political attention, also in order for the EU to achieve the europe 2020 strategy target of reducing the number of poor by at least 20 million by 2020. We Social Democrats therefore welcome this own-initiative report. However, we would like to stress that children's access to education, health care and social security is primarily a matter for the Member States and national welfare systems. At the same time, the EU can play a major role in supporting the work of the Member States, in particular through the Structural Funds. The EU can also facilitate cross-border cooperation and develop common guidelines and objectives to combat child poverty. Ensuring that the child perspective is included in all relevant aspects of policy-making, including at EU level, is also a successful way of preventing and combating child poverty.

name: Sergio Gutiérrez Prieto (S&D)
text: in writing. I voted in favour because I find it unacceptable that today, in Europe, one in four children is at risk of poverty and social exclusion and twenty million do not have access to a hot meal a day. It is imperative that we ensure that all children have access to health care, education, decent housing and adequate food.  That is why the Socialists have proposed establishing a child guarantee as part of an integrated European plan to combat child poverty, which also encompasses programmes that provide aid and opportunities for parents to get out of situations of social exclusion and integrate into the labour market. In this regard, we deeply regret that the proposal is not accompanied by a specific guarantee fund, since the European right as a whole has refused to support its creation.  The report also calls on the Commission to make the fight against child poverty a central priority of the new Annual Growth Survey 2016, because investing in children is not only investing in the future of the EU, but is a matter of social justice.

name: András Gyürk (PPE)
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the report adopted today on reducing inequalities and, in particular, on child poverty. The most important elements of the decision were based on the proposals of MEP Adam Kósa, which supported the measures introduced by the Hungarian Government in recent years. Nevertheless, the report adopted by the left-wing majority took into account the figures for older statistics and surveys, which significantly distorted the data and trends on the current situation.  In the course of the vote, we followed the People's Party position and agreed with the reporter that job creation is a priority and that high energy prices and the reduction of overheads also contribute to the fight against poverty. Adam Kosa's proposal to make children's meals free and more generally accessible was one of the first priorities in the report. We also share the view that easing household debt can significantly improve and improve people's situation, which has also been a priority of the Hungarian Government in recent years.

name: Τάκης Χατζηγεωργίου (
text: GUE/NGL), in writing. \u2012 The report largely reflects the positions of the Left. It calls on the Member States to make a real commitment to develop policies to combat child poverty that focus on eliminating the factors affecting child poverty. It asks them to increase the effectiveness, quantity, amounts and scope of social support for children, but also for parents who are unemployed.  Reducing inequalities, especially when it focuses on child poverty, is a very sensitive issue for us. All the more so when this report underlines the interconnection of wealth redistribution policies, the effectiveness of income support given by the government, labour policy and the situation of parents in the labour market as the main factors in promoting or combating poverty.

name: Marian Harkin (ALDE)
text: in writing. ‒ I supported this report on reducing inequalities with a special focus on child poverty. More than one in four children in the EU are at risk of poverty and social exclusion and the poverty rate for children is higher than that of any other age group, although this varies across Member States. The report highlights that a number of factors are involved in perpetuating the cycle of poverty, including not only material concerns such as food and shelter but also access to education, healthcare and intergenerational poverty. I supported the call for the Commission to set a Europe 2020 sub-target on reducing child poverty and social exclusion and to include in each Annual Growth Survey a specific section with the binding target on fighting child poverty as well as to include a specific indicator on children at risk of poverty or social exclusion in the social dimension of the EMU. I did not support the call for a child guarantee with a specific fund to be established as I believe that Member States can and should better utilise already—existing EU structural funds to fight the alarming rate of poverty among children in Europe.

name: Brian Hayes (PPE)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted for this report because it proposes a number of measures to help eliminate poverty and social exclusion among children. All children must be guaranteed the right to education, healthcare, housing, protection, recreation and leisure time as well as a balanced diet. As the report on child poverty in Europe shows, children are increasingly under threat of poverty and social exclusion. Poverty and social exclusion not only result in basic needs, such as food and housing not being given, but also generally include access to high-quality education and health services and participation in sporting or cultural leisure activities.

name: Anja Hazekamp (GUE/NGL)
text: Written. 'Child poverty is a serious problem. It is a shame that children are still living in poverty. The Party for Animals stands up for the weakest in our society. But the fight against child poverty by Brussels must not be misused to impose European social and economic policies on Member States. This is at the expense of the sovereignty of the Member States. In the Netherlands, we are very good at defininging our social and economic policies and have good social security standards. We do not need a European reform agenda to undermine this. However, I wholeheartedly support the call from Europe to tackle child poverty.

name: Roger Helmer (EFDD)
text: in writing. ‒ UKIP abstained on this non-legislative and non-binding report because we do not oppose actions to tackle the very serious issue regarding child poverty. However, we do oppose calling for any more EU initiatives and interference as the EU is completely undemocratic and the only people that should decide how we tackle child poverty should be our own elected government, not bureaucrats in Brussels. The EU’s own policy on this is a failure, as they have admitted they are very unlikely to hit their own target by 2020 on poverty and social exclusion. Also, if the UK didn’t pay £55 million a day to the EU, we could do so much more to help children who are in poverty. The EU is one of the problems, not the solution.

name: Hans-Olaf Henkel (ECR)
text: Writing. I voted against Mrs Zuber's own-initiative report on reducing inequality, with a particular focus on child poverty, because, despite some good approaches, the report clearly goes beyond its objective in many areas, disregards parents' rights and violates subsidiarity. I fully support the rights of children, but I am at least as convinced that this must be done at the relevant political levels. For this reason too, I am clearly rejecting the S&D Group's proposal to create a 'European Child Guarantee'. Children need action, not words. Incidentally, I believe that the euro must be abolished because it leads to strife and discord in Europe!

name: György Hölvényi (PPE)
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the report adopted today on reducing inequalities and, in particular, on child poverty. The main elements of the decision were originally based on the proposals of MEP Adam Kósa, which supported the measures introduced by the Hungarian Government in recent years. Nevertheless, the report adopted by the left-wing majority took into account the figures for older statistics and surveys, which significantly distorted the data and trends on the current situation.  In the course of the vote, we followed the People's Party position and agreed with the reporter that job creation was a priority. In addition, high energy prices and the reduction of overheads contribute to the fight against poverty. Adam Kosa's proposal to make children's meals free and more generally accessible was one of the first priorities in the report. This supports the hungarian government's correct approach to date. We also share the view that the easing of household debt can also significantly improve and improve people's situation, which has also been a priority of the Hungarian Government in recent years.

name: Mary Honeyball (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ I represent London, where more than half a million children are living below the poverty line. Worryingly, levels of in-work poverty have grown. Labour MEPs have always championed a better quality of life, especially for the most vulnerable in society. This report calls for a real commitment from Member States to tackle the root causes of child poverty and increase the scope of social support for children. It also promotes labour laws which include a statutory adequate minimum wage and collective agreements. This will provide greater security for families and fight precarious employment.

name: Brice Hortefeux (PPE)
text: In writing. In one of the richest continents in the world, child poverty has increased alarmingly, growing by more than one million children between 2008 and 2012.  These children are denied access to basic services such as education and health and suffer from exclusion, increasing inequality, school drop-out and downgrading. The European Union, always the first to denounce inequality and poverty in the world, should perhaps take stock of its own actions or inactions and assess the effectiveness of the billions of euros spent over decades in cohesion policy, in particular, in the European Social Fund (ESF). The impoverishment of the European peoples is an unacceptable trend which contributes to widening the gap of misunderstanding towards a Europe which proclaims its commitment to the rights and freedoms of European citizens but which, at the same time, fails to demonstrate it. However, the primary responsibility for this failure is not to be attributed to the Union, which is, after all, devoid of powers in terms of social policy and education, but rather to the Member States and the territorial authorities which have failed to respond properly to this phenomenon.

name: Richard Howitt (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ Once again I am forced to speak regretting that Conservative and UKIP MEPs from my region have ignored social need in our constituency, but to say that I am proud Labour has voted for European action for social justice – here specifically to combat child poverty.  More than 30% of children in Great Yarmouth, Luton, Norwich and Peterborough are trapped in poverty, according to the Centre for Research in Social Policy.  Why do the other parties vote against setting the aim of guaranteeing those children better healthcare, education, childcare, decent housing and adequate nutrition – and setting up a small European Union fund to pump prime local actions needed to support this? This is also a report which promotes employment laws that guarantee a statutory minimum wage and collective agreements, which provide greater security for families and fight precarious employment. That is about combating poverty at its roots. The truth is that the Conservatives and UKIP put their ideological hatred of Europe before the love we should all feel for our children. Britain’s ʽSave the Childrenʼ asked us to vote for this report. I did. Labour did. It is for others to explain why they refused to do so.

name: Ian Hudghton (Verts/ALE)
text: in writing. ‒ This report’s call for Member States to make a real commitment to developing policies to fight child poverty is timely. In the United Kingdom we currently have a right—wing Tory government fully intent on slashing millions of pounds from welfare and public bodies. These ideologically—driven cuts are harming families across Scotland and the UK and will only result in the already horrendous child poverty statistics increasing.

name: Cătălin Sorin Ivan (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ Children are at a great risk of poverty in 19 Member States. Women are at greater risk of poverty than men and tackling women’s poverty is not only important in its own right but also of vital importance in efforts to reduce child poverty. In the EU, we must ensure that every child at risk of poverty has access to free healthcare, free education, decent housing and adequate nutrition. Europe will be a better place if we make equal opportunities a reality for all children in Europe. I voted in favour of this report.

name: Ivan Jakovčić (ALDE)
text: Written. ‒ I voted for a report on reducing inequalities with a particular focus on child poverty, as I find the poverty rate among children in Europe increasing and worrying. The economic crisis has contributed to many problems, thus affecting the impossibility of exercising the basic children's rights set out in the UN Convention on the Rights of the Child, concerning health, education and social protection. This topic needs greater political visibility at European Union level, and the work of all Member States to reduce poverty among children, their families, their exclusion from society and the reduction of school leaving, where the figures are extremely devastating.  One of the objectives of the Europe 2020 strategy is to reduce the number of people affected by poverty by at least 20 million by 2020. In order to achieve this objective, it is necessary to act strategically in many areas in all EU countries at local, regional and national level, so I vote for this report in order to improve the current situation regarding the high number of poor children in Europe.

name: Jean-François Jalkh (ENF)
text: In writing. Parliament's motion for a resolution fully takes up the rights already guaranteed by the United Nations Convention on the Rights of Children, namely education, health, housing, protection, recreation, leisure time, nutrition, and care in the family environment. In particular, the Commission is invited to increase the ESF's endowments and to apply the principle of the European minimum income (European Parliament Resolution 2010/2039 INI). For their part, Member States are obliged to generally extend to children free access to the various guaranteed rights, such as education, transport, care, leisure... This proposal focuses on the child, an autonomous atom, to the detriment of the family, which is nevertheless its first development environment, the second being society as a whole. On the one hand, the child's distress is generally directly related to that of his family, which is, on the other hand, indirectly linked to the problems facing our States, which may be anything other than economic. Finally, the proposed measures are illusory to be implemented in the public finances of our states. I voted against this proposal.

name: Diane James (EFDD)
text: in writing. – I abstained on this non-legislative and non—binding report because my fellow MEPs and I do not oppose actions to tackle the very serious issue regarding child poverty. However, we do oppose calling for any more EU initiatives and interference as the EU is completely undemocratic and the only people that should decide how we tackle child poverty should be our own elected government, not bureaucrats in Brussels. The EU’s own policy on this is a failure, as they have admitted they are very unlikely to hit their own target by 2020 on poverty and social exclusion. Also, if the UK didn’t pay £55 million a day to the EU, we could do so much more to help children who are in poverty. The EU is one of the problems, not the solution.

name: Petr Ježek (ALDE)
text: Writing. \u2012 As a member of the MEP's intergroup on children's rights, I had a particular interest in Mrs Zuber's report. Although I did not agree with several unrealistic proposals for this non-legislative document, I decided to support it, together with other Members of the Liberal Faction, in order to tackle the impact of poverty on children and young people at European level.

name: Marc Joulaud (PPE)
text: In writing. I voted in favour of the report of my colleague Inês Cristina Zuber's report on reducing inequality, particularly in the case of poverty affecting children, which is increasing in Europe. Against this aberration, the European Parliament therefore supports the increase in aid specifically directed at children but does not forget the parents. Parliament also calls on Member States to put in place preventive social policies and plans to reduce child poverty, as well as to strengthen social rights and aid in culture, sport and leisure. This report was adopted by a large majority, which I welcome.

name: Philippe Juvin (PPE)
text: In writing. This report envisages a number of measures on reducing inequality, poverty and social exclusion among children in Europe. It focuses on access to education and training. I obviously voted in favour of this report because child poverty unfortunately remains a reality in Europe.

name: Barbara Kappel (ENF)
text: Writing. It is not expected that the creation of new funds and the adoption of European directives will solve the problem of inequality. Similarly, it remains questionable whether the Commission's extension of competences can actually counteract child poverty by introducing this issue into the European Semester. I have therefore abstained from voting on this report. As countries are affected to varying degrees by child poverty, the national competence of the individual Member States should remain, as this is the only way to ensure the efficient and prompt implementation of national action plans to combat child poverty.

name: Rikke Karlsson (ECR)
text: In writing. Yes, we must fight poverty, especially that of children and young adults. By attacking evil at its root, and not just in its effects. However, the Union is really the most ill-placed to claim to be fighting this fight. Despite the miraculous promises of prosperity sold with each new European treaty, mass unemployment has settled almost everywhere in Europe, the middle classes are disappearing and most of our children have indeed been paying socially, psychologically and culturally very expensive for Europe's economic, monetary and institutional choices for more than thirty years. It is by repatriating several essential competences into the hands of our States, as the United Kingdom demands for itself, and by abandoning its obviously failed integration and interference in the privacy of citizens, the European Union will do the best service to the Europeans.

name: Afzal Khan (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ I supported this report. Labour MEPs have always championed a better quality of life, especially for the most vulnerable in society. The report calls for a real commitment from Member States to tackle the factors which are causing child poverty and increase the scope of social support for children. It also promotes labour laws that guarantee a statutory adequate minimum wage and collective agreement, which will provide greater security for families and fight precarious employment.

name: Dieter-Lebrecht Koch (PPE)
text: Writing. I consider this report to be a very important initiative by Parliament. Much more attention needs to be paid to the issue of child poverty. Children in Europe are increasingly at risk of poverty and social exclusion. Statistics show that a quarter of all children in the EU experience poverty and social exclusion. In 2013, 26.5 million children were at risk of poverty or social exclusion, and since 2008 two thirds of EU Member States have experienced increased child poverty. This must be counteracted. Childhood poverty can have lifelong effects. For example, children who grow up in poverty are at greater risk of being poor as adults.
