Every child should have the opportunity to reach their full potential. However, when we uncover and combat the causes of child poverty, we must also be careful not to go too far in our efforts. As much as I welcome the report as a whole, I cannot agree with three sections of the report: in my view, the promotion of the flexibility of industrial relations does not in any way weaken children's social rights (Section 10); I cannot agree to the right to a suitable and appropriate dwelling (Section 18); Nor can I support a guaranteed right of women to sexual and reproductive health (Section 38).

name: Bernd Kölmel (ECR)
text: Writing. I voted against the rapporteur's non-legislative own-initiative report on reducing inequality, with a particular focus on child poverty, because, despite some good approaches, the report clearly overshoots its objective in many areas, disregards parents' rights and violates subsidiarity. I fully support children's rights, but I am at least as convinced that this must be done at the relevant political levels. For this reason too, I am clearly rejecting the empty proposal to create a 'European Child Guarantee'. Children need action, not words.

name: Ádám Kósa (PPE)
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the report adopted today on reducing inequalities and, in particular, on child poverty. The main elements of the decision were originally based on my own proposals, which supported the measures introduced by the Hungarian Government in recent years. Nevertheless, the report adopted by the left-wing majority took into account the figures for older statistics and surveys, which significantly distorted the data and trends on the current situation.  In the course of the vote, I followed the People's Party position and agreed with the reporter that job creation is a priority, just as high energy prices and the reduction of overheads contribute to the fight against poverty. My amendment on the free and more general availability of children's meals was one of the first priorities in the report, which supports the hungarian government's correct approach to date. I also share the view that the easing of household debt can also significantly improve and improve people's situation, which has also been a priority of the Hungarian Government in recent years.

name: Béla Kovács (NI)
text: Writing. - The aim of the report should be clearly supported. His good intentions are beyond dispute, but his solutions can still be improved. It would have been fortunate to build and operate the public boarding school system, which the profession considered best for achieving lasting results, which does indeed have greater investment needs but which pay off from a social perspective. With a fairer tax system that burdens multinationals proportionately, the cover can be easily obtained.

name: Giovanni La Via (PPE)
text: in writing. I have given my positive opinion to this proposal with the aim of protecting the weakest and, in particular, for the protection of children's rights. This measure introduces, along the lines of the United Nations Convention on the Rights of the Child, a set of rules combating child poverty and the social exclusion of children. One of this Parliament's priorities is to guarantee the right to education, health care, housing, protection, recreation and leisure for all children.

name: Patrick Le Hyaric (GUE/NGL)
text: In writing. The report on child poverty makes a clear statement. Between 2008 and 2012, the number of children at risk of poverty increased sharply. As austerity policies have removed entire sections of social protection, there is no longer a safety net to prevent these children and their parents from falling into a situation of severe material deprivation. Despite attacks from the right, which tried to rewrite the report, the rapporteur set out to hijack economic surveillance frameworks to introduce clear objectives to combat poverty and social exclusion. The proposed solutions are the defence of universal and free public services, labour law that protects parents, and the definition of an unemployment benefit and a minimum income for each state. Inês Zuber calls for the creation of social indicators of the same importance as the economic and budgetary objectives that tough up national budgets, but which will be used to push states and the European Union to act against poverty. I therefore welcome the broad adoption of this report, despite the opposition of the most conservative European politicians and the National Front.

name: Marine Le Pen (ENF)
text: In writing. Mrs Zuber's report on the "reduction of inequality, in particular child poverty" is aberrant: it is a mess where she is a mess of gender theory, inequality, European interference and many unachievable hopes. The error of approach is glaring: the child's distress is related to that of the parents, and this distress is often more social than economic. We are talking about household income, not to mention the family. The proposed policy measures are unrealistic in times of structural crisis aggravated by totally uncontrolled migratory pressure. What state can afford to provide such universal and free services, if only to its own citizens? No.

name: Gilles Lebreton (ENF)
text: In writing. FN MPs voted against the report because it is confusing and unrealistic. In addition, he agrees with the theory of gender. It is a pity because the theme of reducing inequality, with the laudable aim of plucking children from poverty, deserved better.

name: Paloma López Bermejo (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. I voted in favour of this report because it places the causes of child poverty in its true structural framework and not in the family sphere, as is often the case in neoliberal proposals. The fundamental role of the right to health, education and social protection, as well as the right to decent work, to combat child poverty is recognized. This highlights the need to build another society, and not just to adopt other policies, to end this serious social problem.

name: Bernd Lucke (ECR)
text: Writing. I abstained from Mrs Zuber's non-legislative own-initiative report on reducing inequality, with a particular focus on child poverty, because, despite some good approaches, the report goes beyond its objective in many areas, disregards parents' rights and violates subsidiarity. I fully support the rights of children, but I am at least as convinced that this must be done at the relevant political levels. For this reason too, I am clearly rejecting the S&D Group's proposal to create a 'European Child Guarantee'. Children need action, not words. At the same time, however, the report also contains many good proposals, which I do not want to put a stone in the way of. That is why I abstained.

name: Krystyna Łybacka (S&D)
text: I would like to write to the Commission. \u2012 I supported the report on reducing inequalities with a particular focus on child poverty. In the context of this report, I pay particular attention to access to quality free education for all as a tool to eliminate social inequalities. Ensuring equal educational opportunities for children and young people reduces the risk of marginalisation, social exclusion and provides an opportunity to improve their quality of life, employment and socio-economic status.  Early school leaving among young people should also be monitored and prevented, which increases the risk of social exclusion and poverty and constitutes a serious barrier to economic growth and employment. While the rate of early school leavers is declining across the European Union, significant disparities remain between countries and regions. In some Member States, we are even seeing a worrying increase in this percentage.  I call on the Member States to increase investment in education and childcare. Increased financial outlays and effective distribution to the areas most affected by child poverty will ensure optimal conditions for their further development and prevent possible social and economic consequences of poverty.

name: Petr Mach (EFDD)
text: Writing. \u2012 Poverty cannot be combated by declarations and non-systemic forwarding of funds. In particular, trade must be freed up and poor countries should be allowed to sell us their goods and also get rich.

name: Ivana Maletić (PPE)
text: Written. ‒ The fundamental rights of the child are guaranteed by the UN Charter on the Rights of the Child relating to education, health care, home, play and balanced nutrition. A fifth of the bloc's population is under the age of 18, and more than a quarter of children are at risk of poverty and social exclusion. It is important to strengthen the social rights that the state must guarantee, and to strengthen the medical, psychological and social welfare of children and young people. Socioeconomic research is also necessary. I supported Inês Cristina Zuber's report because inequality, poverty and social exclusion of children create a vicious cycle that deprives children of opportunities for growth and a secure future and results in more uneducated and unemployed. It is necessary to increase social rights aimed at children, but also on parents. The economy needs to be strengthened so that parents have jobs and can adequately care for children. Croatia leads the way with the unemployment rate, and is full of potential and opportunities for growth and development in relation to eastern European countries.

name: Светослав Христов Малинов (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 My Colleagues in the European Parliament have approved by an overwhelming majority a resolution calling for tackling the problem of child poverty in Europe. Statistics show that in 2014 the average child poverty rate in eu Member States was 27.7%, or 26 million children. In other words, roughly one in four children is at risk of living in poverty. Children are most vulnerable to the consequences of shortages of food, clothing, secure housing, limited access to healthcare and education. Unfortunately, Bulgaria ranks second in these statistics, with a high proportion of children at risk, along with Romania and Hungary. The European Parliament therefore puts the issue on the agenda and insists on greater engagement and adequate policies in the fight against child poverty and its causes. There is no doubt that states play a major role in addressing these difficulties through their social policies. Europe must also invest more in its future through concrete measures aimed at children in unemployed, single-parent and special needs.

name: Vladimír Maňka (S&D)
text: Writing. \u2012 According to statistics, today one in four children across the EU is at risk of poverty or social exclusion. It is also alarming and sad that, in the 21st century, despite the commitments made, the social systems of the EU and its Member States are unable to cope with this problem. This shows a lack of responsibility for all of us, a lack of redistribution of resources, a failure to take into account the needs of the socially dependent and, worst of all, a lack of belonging and compassion. It is clear that statements, challenges and reports do not bring about fundamental changes in this area. However, the solution to this problem can no longer be postponed. It is therefore necessary for the EU to adopt legislation as soon as possible that will identify binding, clear, effective and sanctionable measures to tackle this problem.

name: Νότης Μαριάς (
text: ECR), in writing. \u2012 I abstain from voting in the report on reducing inequalities with particular emphasis on child poverty, because it is not sufficiently documented.

name: Dominique Martin (ENF)
text: In writing. I voted against this motion for a resolution. Our ENF group has also tabled another motion for a resolution to counter the outliers of this text. The whole proposal is based on a masterful error of approach: no displeasure to the rapporteur, child poverty is first and foremost household poverty, and it is therefore towards parents that we must act. The rapporteur elaborates on household income problems by systematically forgetting to talk about families. As for the measures it proposes, a clever mixture of idealism, gender theory and immigrationism, they are absolutely unachievable in times of structural crisis! Ensuring universal, free and good quality services in all areas is a great goal, but no country today has the resources to achieve this dream.

name: David Martin (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ Under the UN Convention on the Rights of the Child, all children should be guaranteed the right to education, healthcare services, housing, leisure and a balanced diet. Yet in Europe things look rather different. According to Eurostat, about 26 million children (anyone under 18) were at risk of poverty and social exclusion in 2014. This represents 27.7% of all children in the EU. This is a disgrace for our society.

name: Fulvio Martusciello (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 I support the report on reducing inequalities with a particular focus on child poverty. Inequalities between countries and the EU's child poverty are on the rise, requiring imminent responses to implement plans to lower the poverty line and set targets for reducing social exclusion. Member States need to guarantee social rights and subsidies, which are necessary to combat the alarming and rising rates of poverty in Europe, to promote their social inclusion and their general well-being.

name: Jiří Maštálka (GUE/NGL)
text: Writing. \u2012 Today we discussed a report highlighting in particular the importance of combating child poverty. We must remember that a fifth of the EU's total population is under the age of 18 and, unfortunately, despite the commitments made, one in four children in the EU is currently at risk of poverty or social exclusion. In the report, we note that we are aware of these phenomena and call on the Member States to make a real commitment to developing policies to combat child poverty, focusing on correcting the factors that make child poverty more effective, the amount and scope of social support specifically targeted at children, but also on parents who are unemployed or working but still at risk of the impact of poverty. We must support labour legislation that guarantees social rights, including a statutory minimum wage that respects national practice, and collective agreements that provide families with greater security and combat precarious employment and promote employment with adequate social rights. I supported the report in the final vote.

name: Georg Mayer (ENF)
text: Writing. The ENF resolution on this issue responds much better to the individual needs of Member States and does not expect new funds and directives to be set up at European level. Furthermore, this report is pushing ahead with an increase in competence, in which it is questionable whether it will really help children living in poverty or at risk of poverty. That is why I am abstaining from voting.

name: Anthea McIntyre (ECR)
text: in writing. ‒ British Conservatives voted against this report. While agreeing that ending inequalities and child poverty is essential, we do not agree that a top—down EU blueprint is the most appropriate solution. Conservatives do not support binding EU targets, nor do we support calls for the EU to interfere in areas where there is no EU competence, including the provision of social welfare, housing and the financing of public services. Conservatives firmly believe in the principle of subsidiarity but agree that there is a role for the EU to provide a platform for Member States to exchange best practice. We recognise the potential value of the EU as a means to focus attention on the need for action, and for brokering exchanges of advice and assistance for those Member States that need it. Member States should be encouraged to work towards the goal of ending child poverty by, for example, taking policy measures that will support families; improve living standards and prevent children in poverty from becoming adults in poverty by raising their education attainment. How the Member States achieve such goals should be left up to the Member States.

name: Jean-Luc Mélenchon (GUE/NGL)
text: In writing. This report provides a damning assessment of the situation of child poverty in the Union. While one-fifth of the TOTAL EU population is under the age of 18, more than one in four children is now at risk of poverty or social exclusion. To address this, the report highlights the role of states through access to quality public services (particularly in childcare, education, health, housing and leisure activities). It also calls for strengthening "the efficiency, quantity, amounts and scope of social assistance aimed specifically at children, but also for unemployed parents or the working poor such as unemployment benefits and adequate minimum income". Finally, it recalls that it is also a question of "promoting labour legislation guaranteeing social rights, including a guaranteed minimum wage in accordance with national practices and collective agreements which will bring greater security to families and combat precarious status". I vote for this progressive text without any illusions as to its consequences.

name: Joëlle Mélin (ENF)
text: In writing. Parliament's motion for a resolution fully takes up the rights already guaranteed by the United Nations Convention on the Rights of Children, namely education, health, housing, protection, recreation, leisure time, nutrition, and care in the family environment. In particular, the Commission is invited to increase the ESF's endowments and to apply the principle of the European minimum income (European Parliament Resolution 2010/2039 INI. For their part, Member States are obliged to generally extend to children free access to the various guaranteed rights, such as education, transport, care, leisure... This proposal focuses on the child as if he were independent, autonomous, outside of any family unit, which is nevertheless his first landmark, his immediate environment. His distress is therefore, in most cases, directly related to that of his family, which is sometimes exacerbated by more global societal or economic problems.  Finally, the proposed measures are inadequate to blend into the public finances of each Member State. That is why I am opposed to the text.

name: Nuno Melo (PPE)
text: in writing. The number of children in poverty and social exclusion was already a major problem in the EU even in the years of economic growth, with high employability rates, even before the recession and austerity programmes began. In 2007, child poverty values reached 26.3% and, in 2011, 26.9%. I agree with the need for policy development to combat child poverty, but also involves the allocation of specific social emergency support, whether in the context of increasing lower pensions or effectively creating jobs and reducing unemployment. I abstained in this report because I disagree dearly for the way in which it was drafted by the rapporteur, moving away from the main objective of the report.

name: Roberta Metsola (PPE)
text: in writing. ‒ This report aims at tackling the worrying trend of the rising number of children at risk of poverty and social exclusion in the EU. These inequalities can affect a child for life as childhood is when socio-economic and cognitive skills are developed. Therefore, I voted in favour of increasing the EU’s appropriation of funds to fighting poverty and social cohesion.

name: Louis Michel (ALDE)
text: Written. – In recent years, child poverty has increased significantly in a number of Member States of the European Union. This increase is one of the undesirable effects of the financial and economic crisis. 1 in 4 children in Europe is at increased risk of poverty. Since such a situation places a particularly heavy mortgage on the further development of a child's cognitive and social skills, any form of child poverty must be quickly and effectively avoided and combated. Firstly, because children must, in all circumstances, have the right to develop into resilient individuals, but also and above all to avoid the transfer of the cognitive and material deficit accumulated from generation to generation.  In order to end permanent and structural poverty among young people, it is therefore appropriate for the Commission and the Member States to set clear objectives and develop instruments to reduce child poverty. The best recipe for social exclusion and generational poverty is to ensure that children, regardless of their current material or social background, continue to have access to decent nutrition, energy, good health care and quality education.

name: Miroslav Mikolášik (PPE)
text: Writing. \u2012 In a situation where one in four children in Europe is at risk of poverty, I consider it important to talk about this subject, so I support reducing inequalities, with a particular focus on child poverty. I agree that the treatment of children in our countries must become a priority for our own development and also our contribution to a global vision of solidarity and a fairer distribution of resources. However, it is important to find the right way to do this, but the rapporteur's proposed one is rather a dead end on some points. Such is the recommended increase in unemployment benefits, for example, which may be disincentives, which will exacerbate rather than eliminate child poverty. On the contrary, Member State governments must create an environment where jobs are created, which provides a solution not only in the short term but also in the long term, as children can see positive role models in their parents. However, I agree that, in the fight against child poverty, attention should also be paid to the position of women caring for them or to family members with special needs and disabilities. At present, it is often because of this that women's pensions are falling. However, the primary governments of the Member States should be responsible for how to change this.

name: Marlene Mizzi (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ I have voted in favour of the report on reducing inequalities with a special focus on child poverty, which aims to raise awareness about the need to develop policy responses to reduce poverty and inequalities in the EU and work towards the EU2020 targets. Europe needs to offer a future to our next generation by breaking the vicious circle of poverty at the youngest age possible. This means ensuring that every child at risk of poverty has access to free healthcare, free education, decent housing and adequate nutrition. Europe will be a better place if we make equal opportunities a reality for all children in Europe. However, I have never supported paragraphs guaranteeing women the right to sexual and reproductive health.

name: Csaba Molnár (S&D)
text: Writing. \u2012 The report of the Committee on Employment and Social Affairs, based on statistical facts and socio-economic contexts, tackles a fundamental problem: the increase in social inequalities, including its most serious consequence, child poverty. It is indisputable that between 2008 and 2012 the number of children at risk of poverty or social exclusion in Europe increased by almost one million, that their number increased by half a million between 2011 and 2012, that the risk of poverty or social exclusion increased from 26.5% to 28% between 2008 and 2012, or that 26.5 million children in the EU-28 were at risk of poverty and social exclusion in 2013. The problem raised in this report is very serious, with which the European Union must undoubtedly do something, even if not all of the specific proposals made seem enforceable, so I voted in favour of the proposal.

name: Bernard Monot (ENF)
text: In writing. The ENF Group has tabled another motion for a resolution which stresses that child poverty is primarily that of parents, and that it is therefore they who should benefit from social policies. It is by getting parents out of poverty (through work or parental wages) that we will get the children out of it. This proposal also removes any mention of gender theory, recalls the responsibility of European austerity policies, and calls for national preference during the implementation of future policies. It also calls for reform of education and health systems to make them more efficient and responsive to the new reality.  Finally, whereever possible, it removes the Commission's involvement and restores decision-making power to the Member States. Its rejection implies our abstention on the original report.

name: Cláudia Monteiro de Aguiar (PPE)
text: in writing. The European reality points to an increase in child poverty and social exclusion, in line with the provisions of the UN Convention on the Rights of children, which states that all children should be guaranteed the right to education, health care, housing, protection, leisure and free time, balanced food and care in a family environment. Europe is currently facing a serious economic crisis which, as a result, affects families and especially children. Existing inequalities go beyond the lack of basic needs, including access to educational and health services, as well as the possibility of integrating cultural, sporting and leisure activities. The definition of public objectives and policies to reduce child poverty should be a priority and measures should be implemented in the context of the European Union as well as in its Member States, such as ensuring access to education. To this end, I support this report, as I consider it essential to protect children's rights through targets to reduce child poverty and social exclusion.

name: Sophie Montel (ENF)
text: In writing. This Zuber report is about reducing inequality and in particular child poverty. Indeed, the latter has increased significantly in recent years due to austerity policies, cuts in health and pension spending, but also the FREE trade policy of the EU for decades, a policy that increases inequality. It should also be remembered that Emmanuel Todd predicted the collapse of the Soviet system in 1976 thanks to these kinds of misguided demographic indicators.  Parliament therefore proposes, very belatedly, to stop budget cuts by abolishing the CSP, to increase the allocations to the ESF and the application of a European minimum income. However, this report is flawed. It focuses on the child, while it is also necessary to look at the environment in which he lives (degradation of the situation of parents, even grandparents, since intergenerational solidarity plays a big part, which makes the case for stopping cuts in superannuation).  Moreover, the proposed measures are mostly utopian. It is totally inconsistent to want to take in more migrants — and therefore to spend more money on this management — while wanting to increase funding to reduce inequality.  So I decided to vote against this proposal.

name: Nadine Morano (PPE)
text: In writing. I voted in favour of this report, which aims to reduce poverty in the EU and in particular improve the living conditions of children who are victims of poverty.  In particular, it calls on Member States to guarantee children universal, public, free and quality health care in prevention, vaccination and primary health care. It also calls on them to introduce minimum housing standards to meet the needs of children and ensure their well-being.  I fully support the measure of this text, which recommends that Member States make better use of the resources of the European Structural and Investment Funds (ESIs) in the development of their social policies, in order to achieve the objective of reducing the number of people facing poverty by at least twenty million.

name: Luigi Morgano (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 Caritas' third report on the impact of the crisis in Europe presents worrying data on the growth of poverty and inequality, where more than one in four children is at risk of poverty or social exclusion. Children's needs are directly linked to the social situation of families, so solving children's problems means, to a large extent, solving the problems of the family. Poverty is multidimensional and must be understood not only as a lack of coverage of basic needs such as food, clothing and housing, but also as a lack of access to quality education and health services and the inability to participate in sports, cultural and recreational activities. I wholeheartedly support the creation of a guarantee for children, with their own specific fund, to allow every child access to free health care, free education, free childcare, decent housing and adequate nutrition. Ensuring these core services is crucial because the negative effects of inequality on children can last a lifetime. Investing in children is not only a moral obligation, but also an economic and social priority, in the knowledge that family-friendly policies have positive long-term effects.

name: Elisabeth Morin-Chartier (PPE)
text: In writing. I voted in favour of the Zuber report to reduce inequality, especially child poverty.  According to the UN Convention on the Rights of Children, all children must be guaranteed the right to education, health services, housing, protection, recreation and free time, as well as a balanced diet and care in a family environment. However, these requirements of the UN Convention in EU countries are still not being met for all children, because according to reports on child poverty in Europe, European children too are increasingly at risk of poverty and social exclusion. Poverty and social exclusion not only lead to inadequate coverage of basic needs, such as food and housing, but also involve, for the most part, lack of access to quality education and health services and the inability to participate in sports, cultural and leisure activities. The draft report proposes a number of measures to eliminate poverty and social exclusion among children, which are far from unanimous in the committee.

name: Alessia Maria Mosca (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 Child poverty in Europe is on the rise as social inequalities increase. Several organisations agree that the main cause of this increase is so-called austerity measures (significant reduction in social support for children and families, increased unemployment, spread of precarious work, increased tax burden). By adopting this report, we intend to call on all Member States to increase the amount, scope and effectiveness of support for not only children, but also parents (e.g. unemployment benefits or increased maternity and paternity rights), while promoting labour laws that guarantee social rights and family security and combat precarious work. , the illegal recruitment and exploitation of workers. It is also up to the Commission to work in line with the recommendations adopted in February 2013, proposing a more cohesive policy of increasing and redistributing EU funds. Children must be seen as a priority in the planning and implementation of regional and cohesion policies, using the European Social Fund to implement measures to reduce child poverty and to set enforcement targets, which should be subject to regular monitoring.

name: Renaud Muselier (PPE)
text: In writing. I have not been able to vote for this report, but I fully support the position of the EPP Group and the French delegation to adopt this report. It provides interesting ways to lift children out of poverty. However, as relevant as it may be, the issue of child poverty cannot be resolved without an overall improvement in the standard of living of people in the least developed countries.

name: Victor Negrescu (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ According to the UN Convention on the Rights of the Child, all children should be guaranteed the right to education, health services, housing, protection, to participate in decisions that affect them, leisure and free time, a balanced diet and to be raised within a family. I have voted for this report that will increase in quantity, amount, scope and effectiveness the support and social rights specifically directed to children but also to parents.

name: Момчил Неков (S&D)
text: in writing. – For more than two years, the Group of the Progressive Alliance of Socialists and Democrats has been calling for the establishment of a "Children's Guarantee". Today, more than ever, we need this mechanism. The challenges facing the EU – the consequences of the terrorist attacks in Paris and the refugee crisis – require us to take action in several directions.  Education and environment are the factors that shape the individual, his views and attitudes towards others and the world. It is poverty and social exclusion that are among the reasons that lead to the encapsulation and marginalisation of some communities in the EU. For these reasons, I believe that a key priority in the fight against child poverty should be to reduce early school dropout rates.  I believe that the establishment of a "Children's Guarantee" will give impetus to measures to ensure that every child receives free access to education and healthcare, a decent place to live and food that meets their needs. It is this potential that drives me with complete confidence and conviction in the cause to support this report.

name: Norica Nicolai (ALDE)
text: in writing. \u2012 I supported this report in my vote today because I believe that the European funds available to the Member States and in particular those scheduled for the period 2014-2020 must be directed much more effectively and massively towards the integration of marginalised communities, with the aim of combating poverty and integrating these communities. It is also very important that there is a clear definition as soon as possible, containing sufficiently clear indicators to be able to determine exactly which communities can be designated as marginalised. At the same time, it is important to consider, when setting these criteria, the flexibility of these communities and the cultural specificity of each country. With regard to women and children in these communities, we must recognise that these categories are much more easily exposed to discrimination, and the lack of funds and strategies to include these communities will only exacerbate these social injustices, intolerable for a European Union of the century in which we live.

name: Péter Niedermüller (S&D)
text: Writing. \u2012 The report "Reducing inequalities, in particular child poverty", emphasises that investing in the well-being and lifting of children from poverty is not only a moral duty, but also a social and economic priority. The Group of the Socialists and Democrats in the European Parliament is calling for the introduction of a child guarantee supported from the European budget in order to end child poverty, which is supported by the DK in the light of data from Hungary.  This guarantee would ensure that all children have free access to health, education, childcare, decent housing and proper nutrition. We believe that this is the only way to break the vicious circle of poverty, because it must be started at the youngest possible age. The Children's Guarantee is a long-term instrument that provides equal opportunities for an entire generation and support for parents in terms of social inclusion and integration into the labour market. I therefore support the adoption of this report.

name: Franz Obermayr (ENF)
text: Writing. I abstained from voting on this report because it is an overstepping of competence and calls for further expansion of competences at the expense of the nation states. While it is good to enshrine child protection in Europe 2020 targets and include them in the EMU, this should be reserved for the Member States.

name: Younous Omarjee (GUE/NGL)
text: In writing. I supported this report, which gives an alarming assessment of the situation of poverty and social exclusion experienced by one in four children in the European Union, and calls for the strengthening of the European policy to combat child poverty. In particular, the report stresses the responsibility of Member States to provide quality public services and more appropriate and strengthened social assistance schemes to combat the risks of isolation, social exclusion or precariousness of children and their families.  I welcome the references to the situation of the outermost regions, which should not be excluded from increasing the efficiency and quality of child protection schemes, as these regions are also particularly affected by poverty-related problems.

name: Urmas Paet (ALDE)
text: Writing. \u2012 I supported. In a situation where statistics show that one in four children in the EU is at risk of poverty and 22 per cent of children in Estonia, it is high time that countries put the eradication of the risk of poverty among their priorities. Children and their parents must ensure access to education, health insurance.

name: Maite Pagazaurtundúa Ruiz (ALDE)
text: in writing. More than one in four children in the EU are at risk of poverty and social exclusion. This number has increased worryingly as a result of the economic crisis and continued social cuts by some European governments, such as the Government of the People's Party in Spain. More importantly, a Unicef report on children in Spain revealed that investment in children fell by 14.6% between 2010 and 2013, i.e. EUR 775 per child was cut, thus turning to pre-2007 figures. This report shows once again Parliament's commitment to combating child poverty, in line with its commitments under the United Nations Convention on the Rights of the Child and the 2030 Agenda for Sustainable Development.  That is why we voted in favour, although we deeply regret that no agreement has been reached for the creation of a specific fund to combat child poverty, which would have enabled greater investment, more efficient use of funds and better monitoring of their use.

name: Rolandas Paksas (EFDD)
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of this report.  Child poverty is a multifaceted social problem and its solution requires special attention. Measures to monitor the implementation and impact of the various policies need to be identified and implemented in order to reduce and prevent child poverty and social exclusion, as well as to promote children's well-being.  It should be noted that, despite economic growth, the percentage of the poor is not decreasing. It is therefore necessary to overcome child poverty as soon as possible, which has long-term or irreversible consequences for the children themselves and for society. Children in poverty are more likely to be in poverty. It is therefore essential to prevent children growing up in poor families from falling into the 'trap' of poverty. They must be able to rise out of poverty on the social ladder above. Children of all ages should receive inclusive and quality public education and training free of charge. We need to eliminate closed circles of poverty, reduce societal fragmentation and social tensions.

name: Κωνσταντίνος Παπαδάκης (
text: NI), in writing. \u2012 The ever-increasing number of children of working-class families experiencing their misery, deprived of access to basic goods, housing, food, essential foodstuffs, public and free education and health, is the mirror of the barbarity of the exploitative capitalist system.  The cause of this impoverishment is hidden by the report supporting the EU's unpopular strategy and the capitalist path of development that is leading to new deadlocks for working-class families.  The report seeks to reconcile the incompatibility, i.e. the fight against child poverty, with the objectives of the Europe 2020 strategy of the European Semester and EMU, the implementation of which presupposes the bankruptcy of workers. Indicatively, the report mentions "affordable and accessible education" by rejecting the right to public and free education for all children.  For poverty and impoverishment there is a culprit and it has a name: it is the monopolies and the policy of protecting their profitability that the EU and civil governments faithfully follow. That is why the people must overthrow them in order to pave the way for a society and economy designed to meet the popular needs of the working class and its children.

name: Δημήτρης Παπαδάκης (
text: S&D), in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the report on reducing inequalities with particular emphasis on child poverty. More than one in four children are currently at risk of poverty or social exclusion in the EU. The EU's objective - and the focus of this report - is to promote the social inclusion of children and their well-being by combating poverty and improving their living conditions. The decent living of the individual, especially in the economic times of EU Member States, is a top objective of Community policy. One of the important points of the report is that the European Commission and the Member States are called upon, in the light of the weakening of public services, to introduce a guarantee for children for which there will be a special fund, so that every poor child has access to free health care, free education, free childcare, decent housing and adequate nutrition, as part of a European integrated plan to combat child poverty.  The universal focus of our policies on tackling child poverty, so that it can be fruitful, can only aim to improve the quality and living conditions of each family.

name: Margot Parker (EFDD)
text: in writing. ‒ UKIP abstained on this non-legislative and non-binding report because we do not oppose actions to tackle the very serious issue regarding child poverty. However, we do oppose calling for any more EU initiatives and interference as the EU is completely undemocratic and the only people that should decide how we tackle child poverty should be our own elected government, not bureaucrats in Brussels. The EU’s own policy on this is a failure, as they have admitted they are very unlikely to hit their own target by 2020 on poverty and social exclusion. Also, if the UK didn’t pay £55 million a day to the EU, we could do so much more to help children who are in poverty. The EU is one of the problems, not the solution.

name: Aldo Patriciello (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 I have learned from eurostat's information on the seriousness of the situation with regard to child poverty. I believe that, at a time of history such as the one we are experiencing, the purely economic or lifestyle issue is not the only one. I am thinking of a more serious social consequence that child poverty can produce, and I am referring to phenomena of exclusion which can lead to feelings of rejection towards society which has not been able to take on the problems of a minority. That is why I believe that providing for the growth, nutrition, education and future prospects of children is a benefit for the whole of society. I very much welcome this text, not only in view of tomorrow's day against violence against women, and I am voting in favour of it.

name: Eva Paunova (PPE)
text: in writing. – I supported the resolution, which urges Member States to reduce inequality and tackle the pressing situation of child poverty across the EU. As a Bulgarian, whose country ranks 2nd in child poverty level in the EU, I believe it is vital for the country’s future to ensure access to education, health and welfare of all children and their families. There is no doubt that reducing, and even abolishing, child poverty should be on top of our agendas. In September 2015, world leaders adopted a new set of sustainable development goals, which will be followed by all countries, including the 28 EU Member States. We cannot achieve true sustainable development without investing in those who will actually support it – today’s children, everywhere.

name: Marijana Petir (PPE)
text: Written. ‒ The right to education, health, housing, protection, recreation and leisure, balanced nutrition and care in a family setting is guaranteed by the UN Convention on the Rights of the Child. Croatia is fifth in poverty in the EU. Parents of more than 17,000 children cannot afford a meal for their children in schools. We were able to remove historical criteria that prevented us from participating in the school milk delivery programme, thus misusing at least a little of the severe consequences of the economic crisis and poverty that affects us where we are most vulnerable – which is children. But that's not enough! No child should be hungry! Poverty in the earliest childhood leaves lasting and indelible consequences on man. A child is a child, regardless of religion, race, nationality and all that sets us apart. Many children are not in the welfare system because their parents work, but they have not received a salary for their work for months. We have to fight it. Children are not to blame for adult decisions or the opportunities they find themselves in.

name: Florian Philippot (ENF)
text: In writing. This Zuber report is about reducing inequality and in particular child poverty. Indeed, the latter has increased significantly in recent years due to austerity policies, cuts in health and pension spending, but also the FREE trade policy of the EU for decades, a policy that increases inequality. It should also be remembered that Emmanuel Todd predicted the collapse of the Soviet system in 1976 thanks to these kinds of misguided demographic indicators.  Parliament therefore proposes, very belatedly, to stop budget cuts by abolishing the CSP, to increase the allocations to the ESF and the application of a European minimum income.  However, this report is flawed. It focuses on the child, while it is also necessary to look at the environment in which he lives (degradation of the situation of parents, even grandparents, since intergenerational solidarity plays a big part, which makes the case for stopping cuts in superannuation). Moreover, the proposed measures are mostly utopian. It is totally inconsistent to want to take in more migrants — and therefore to spend more money on this management — while wanting to increase funding to reduce inequality.  So I decided to vote against this proposal.

name: Tonino Picula (S&D)
text: Written. ‒ Due to the worrying growth in global poverty, in particular that of children, caused, inter alia by austerity policies that have deepened the economic crisis, there has been a need to develop a concrete, hitom-existent proposal that would seek to reduce poverty and inequality in the EU in line with the EU's 2020 targets. Therefore, the S&D Group, in cooperation with the Employment and Social Affairs Committee, has launched an initiative to adopt one such proposal. One of the fundamental postulates of any human rights policy is that every child must be entitled to free education, healthcare, housing and adequate nutrition. Reducing child poverty and social exclusion must be a visible and explicit objective at all stages of the European Semester and a specific section with binding child welfare objectives should be included in each Annual Growth Survey. It is necessary for the Commission to set up a specific guarantee fund for children to subsidise the most basic children's needs, by revising the Multiannual Financial Framework next year. This instrument would also help parents and children integrate more easily into the labour market and get out of social exclusion. Member States and the Commission must make children a priority in the planning and implementation of regional and cohesion policies and invest more in their well-being through the European Social Fund.

name: Andrej Plenković (PPE)
text: Written. ‒ The EU, exercising its rights and exercising its obligations, has a direct impact on Member States and European citizens. It is necessary that the issues it deals with are oriented to all levels of the functioning of civil society. While international relations and financial policy are the most public focus, we must not forget that every society is made up of people first and foremost. There is currently a major migration crisis in our neighbourhood and now more than ever we must show solidarity and care for those in need. Protecting human rights and ensuring basic living needs such as food, water, safe housing, healthcare, education are seen as fundamental ideals and we must work to ensure that they are provided to all. Statistics show that the number of children at risk of poverty or social exclusion has risen by almost 1 million and now stands at 26.5 million children in 28 Member States. The report shows that deepening social inequalities encourages an increase in child poverty and affects the permeation of adverse living circumstances. Also, the consequences of poverty and social exclusion can last a lifetime and continue in future generations. Poverty is a universal problem and we need to take a quality approach to tackling it. I agree with colleague Zauber's proposals for measures and I think that increasing social benefits, auditing labour and social legislation, ensuring access to education and healthcare can respond positively to this situation.

name: Miroslav Poche (S&D)
text: Writing. \u2012 As a Social Democrat, it is of the utmost importance to me that we address not only poverty itself, but above all its causes. Child poverty is a very fundamental issue. We must not only support children, we must invest in children in the first place. Any support must be targeted and effective. At committee level, we have managed to put several key points into the report, such as investing in free public education, providing free healthcare or decent housing for every child. As part of our efforts to make as few children as possible exposed to poverty and social exclusion, we must, above all, make families more secure. One of the first steps must be the creation of labour legislation that ensures social rights and adequate evaluation of the work done, including the statutory minimum wage. We must also focus on the position of women and men who care for children or family members with disabilities and special needs.

name: Salvatore Domenico Pogliese (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 Child poverty is unfortunately also present in Europe. On our continent, one in four children would be exposed to the risk of poverty and social exclusion. According to data provided by Eurostat, in 2013, 26 million children were exposed to the risk of poverty and social exclusion. This is 27.7% of European citizens under the age of 18. According to the United Nations Convention on the Rights of the Child, all children must be guaranteed the right to education, health care, housing, protection, recreation and leisure, as well as a balanced diet and family education. The draft report proposes a series of measures to eliminate poverty and social exclusion among children. I am therefore voting in favour of this resolution, in the hope that the Member States will decide to step up their efforts in the fight against social inequalities, in particular child poverty.

name: Franck Proust (PPE)
text: In writing. I voted in favour of this report because we had to send a clear message, especially to fight child poverty. I stress that we also, unlike some of our colleagues, must also position ourselves in favour of ensuring women's access to sexual and reproductive health rights. It was important to point that out.

name: Paulo Rangel (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 According to the UN Convention on the Rights of children, all children must have guaranteed the rights to education, health services, housing, protection, to participate in decisions affecting them, to leisure and free time, to a balanced diet and to receive care in the family environment. However, even in the EU, the Convention is far from fully complied with. Indeed, the reports point to an increase in child poverty in Europe. This report analyses the causes of child poverty and proposes some measures to combat it. I voted in favour.

name: Julia Reid (EFDD)
text: in writing. ‒ UKIP abstained on this non-legislative and non-binding report because we do not oppose actions to tackle the very serious issue regarding child poverty. However, we do oppose calling for any more EU initiatives and interference as the EU is completely undemocratic and the only people that should decide how we tackle child poverty should be our own elected government, not bureaucrats in Brussels. The EU’s own policy on this is a failure, as they have admitted they are very unlikely to hit their own target by 2020 on poverty and social exclusion. Also, if the UK didn’t pay £55 million a day to the EU, we could do so much more to help children who are in poverty. The EU is one of the problems, not the solution.

name: Frédérique Ries (ALDE)
text: In writing. Child poverty is growing inexorably year after year in Europe. According to Eurostat data from 2013, 26.5 million children in the EU-28 are at risk of falling into poverty and social exclusion and 1.6 million children are already in a state of severe material deprivation.  This is intolerable and far removed from the rights proclaimed by the UN Convention on the Rights of Children. And while there are many reasons to be moved, the means to curb this phenomenon are complicated to implement when the financial windfall from public authorities is limited. However, there are ways in the Zuber report to strengthen "safety nets" and reduce the number of families with children at risk of poverty. First, Member States must continue to ensure a universal, public, free and quality education and health care system. Deuzio, the European Commission and the European Parliament must seize the opportunity for a mid-term review of the multi-year financial framework to increase the endowments of the European Social Fund and the food aid programme for the poorest.  The Juncker Commission would also give a social face to its action by launching a legislative proposal for a European minimum income.

name: Robert Rochefort (ALDE)
text: In writing. I voted in favour of the resolution to reduce inequality, especially child poverty. The number of children at risk of poverty or social exclusion has increased considerably in recent years in Europe, reaching 26.5 million children in 2013. Today, more than one in four children are at risk of falling into poverty or exclusion in the EU. In addition, inequalities are growing between European countries, and the percentage of malnourished children is increasing. That is why we call on the Commission and the Member States to set targets for reducing poverty and social exclusion, and to put in place multidimensional plans to achieve this, with particular attention paid to the most endangered children. Education can play an important role in achieving these goals; it is therefore important to ensure that all children have access to a public education, open to all and of quality at all ages, and to combat school drop-out. There should also be a child guarantee so that these children can benefit from free health care, free education, free childcare, decent housing and adequate food.

name: Liliana Rodrigues (S&D)
text: in writing. According to Unicef, between 2008 and 2013, 1.6 million more children began living in severe material deprivation in 30 european countries. Child poverty is growing on par with increasing social inequalities. The negative effects of poverty and social exclusion on children are prolonged throughout life. It is in the early years of life that cognitive and socio-economic skills are formed, which means that the negative political measures taken today will have irreversible negative impacts on the lives of these people and on society. It is a relative poverty that perpetuates social inequalities. It is essential that MSs increase the amounts and effectiveness of social support for children and parents and promote labour legislation that guarantees social rights and safety for families. The data are clear in the Portuguese: one in four children in Portugal live in households with material deprivation; more than half a million lost the right to child benefit; state support for families is lower than the OECD average. There is no doubt that we need other policies for our country and for the Union.

name: Inmaculada Rodríguez-Piñero Fernández (S&D)
text: in writing. I voted in favour because I find it unacceptable that today, in Europe, one in four children is at risk of poverty and social exclusion and twenty million do not have access to a hot meal a day. It is imperative that we ensure that all children have access to health care, education, decent housing and adequate food.  That is why the Socialists have proposed establishing a child guarantee as part of an integrated European plan to combat child poverty, which also encompasses programmes that provide aid and opportunities for parents to get out of situations of social exclusion and integrate into the labour market. In this regard, we deeply regret that the proposal is not accompanied by a specific guarantee fund, since the European right as a whole has refused to support its creation.  The report also calls on the Commission to make the fight against child poverty a central priority of the new Annual Growth Survey 2016, because investing in children is not only investing in the future of the EU, but is a matter of social justice.

name: Claude Rolin (PPE)
text: In writing. In 2013, 26.5 million children in the EU—28 were at risk of falling into poverty or social exclusion. This figure is unacceptable given the level of wealth created on our continent. In order to carry out an effective policy in this regard, it is important to bear in mind that child poverty is a multidimensional phenomenon that therefore requires a multidimensional response. Of course, employment is a major factor, but not necessarily a determining factor. It does not always guarantee an end to poverty for the families of the children concerned. I believe that in order to fight for the reduction of child poverty, Member States need to devote more resources through their support policies aimed specifically at children, which must be based in particular on prevention.  As far as the Commission is concerned, the fight against poverty must be taken into account in all stages of the European Semester budget process as well as in cohesion policies. Finally, the social dimension of EMU must include a specific indicator of child poverty.  Today, I have decided to vote in favour of the report, which includes the ideas outlined here.

name: Fernando Ruas (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 Based on the UN Convention on the Rights of Children, any and all children have the right to education, health care, housing, protection, access to sport, leisure and culture, among others. However, these rights are not yet fully fulfilled throughout the EU. The increase in child poverty is unfortunately aggravated and, as such, the problems that are associated with it will have an impact on how future generations will develop. I therefore endorse the measures contained in the report concerning the need to curb children's exposure to poverty and social exclusion and the measures envisaged to minimise the consequences of this real social scourge. I also believe that identifying the causes that are the cause of child poverty and combating them effectively and without respite, promoting and ensuring education and the most basic rights of children in the EU, should be the union's designs and, on a broader scale, designs of all governments worldwide, and I have therefore voted in favour of this Report.

name: Tokia Saïfi (PPE)
text: In writing. I voted in favour of this report, which aims to identify the causes and propose certain measures to reduce inequalities, in particular poverty and social exclusion of children. The text recalls that, according to the UN Convention on Children's Rights, all children must be guaranteed the right to education, health, housing or protection. These fundamental rights are not in fact guaranteed to European children. For example, between 2008 and 2012, there was an increase in the number of children at risk in the European Union by one million.  In the face of this alarming figure, this draft report therefore proposes measures to effectively combat the social exclusion of children: the increase in the quantity, amounts, scope and effectiveness of social assistance, the development of preventive social policies and plans to avoid and reduce child poverty or the increase in the endowments of the European Social Fund. These measures would effectively address the serious phenomenon of rising child poverty. The European Union must act urgently.

name: Massimiliano Salini (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the report on reducing inequalities with a particular focus on child poverty, as I believe it is essential for the European Union to work to ensure that all children have the right to education, health services, housing, protection, participation in decisions affecting them, leisure and leisure activities, a balanced diet and growth within a family.

name: Matteo Salvini (ENF)
text: in writing. \u2012 I abstained because the objectives set out in the text are acceptable, but I fear they cannot be achieved by insisting on the failed governance model adopted so far.

name: Lola Sánchez Caldentey (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. The report is a progressive text, with a multidimensional approach to child poverty, for which comprehensive solutions are also called for. Among others, it is proposed that Member States adopt policies that promote access to universal, public, free and quality health care, social services and education for both children and families, while ensuring cultural inclusion, democratic participation, balanced food and adequate housing. The report links the situation of poverty and social exclusion of children to that of their parents and stresses that, in order for children to have their children welfare and their children's rights safeguarded, measures must be taken to address unemployment, safety at work, family support or the public development of socio-educational networks. It is important to mention that the text reflects gender aspects. The report does not reflect our rejection of the European Semester or country-specific recommendations but, in any event, its content is positive for reducing inequalities, with particular attention to child poverty, so we voted in favour.

name: Daciana Octavia Sârbu (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ I give my full backing to this report and the proposal for a child guarantee scheme. More substantial efforts are needed to break the cycle of poverty, poor nutrition, ill-health and underachievement in education. This cycle perpetuates existing inequalities and the disadvantages suffered by vulnerable groups. Strong EU backing, including funding, for a child guarantee scheme could help to ensure that all children have a decent chance regardless of their background.

name: Olga Sehnalová (S&D)
text: Writing. \u2012 The economic crisis and the associated austerity measures have affected all layers of society. The number of European children at risk of poverty has increased by a whopping 1 million. Children affected by poverty are a failure of society as a whole. The issue of poverty and social exclusion affecting children and young people is essential for building a cohesive society. Ensuring affordable education and healthcare must be a priority. I therefore supported the draft report, which deals in detail with this issue.

name: Lidia Senra Rodríguez (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. – I voted in favour of this report because it places the causes of child poverty in its true structural framework and not in the family sphere, as is often the case in neoliberal proposals. The fundamental role of the right to health, education and social protection, as well as the right to decent work, to combat child poverty is recognized. This highlights the need to build another society, and not just to adopt other policies, to end this serious social problem.

name: Jill Seymour (EFDD)
text: in writing. ‒ I abstained on this vote. I do not wish to see the EU get involved in this area, but I do recognise the importance of ending child poverty.

name: Czesław Adam Siekierski (PPE)
text: I would like to write to the Commission. \u2012 The existence of significant social inequalities is a very serious problem in almost every country, not only in Europe, but worldwide. Poverty, lack of access to basic education, medical and transport infrastructure make these inequalities recurring from generation to generation and often even deepen.  In accordance with the UN Convention on the Rights of the Child, 'all children should be guaranteed the right to education, health, housing, protection, participation in decisions concerning them, rest and leisure, a balanced diet and family care'. These are necessary elements to ensure the proper development of future generations, which is why spending to improve the living conditions of the youngest, even if they may seem costly to some, is in fact the best investment in their future.  Increasing member states' efforts to combat poverty, with a particular focus on improving the living conditions and developmental opportunities of children, seems a necessary and urgent issue. This is evidenced by available analyses showing that in the period 2008-2012, the risk of poverty or social exclusion in the EU-27 increased from 26.5% to 28%, and eurostat surveys in 2013 estimated that 26.5 million children at risk of poverty and social exclusion lived in the EU-28 at the time.

name: Siôn Simon (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of this report because child poverty in my constituency remains a problem and the Tories continue to be bent on maintaining a situation where poverty needlessly affects young people. Labour MEPs have always championed a better quality of life, especially for the most vulnerable in society. The report calls for a real commitment from Member States to tackle the factors which are causing child poverty and increase the scope of social support for children. It promotes labour laws that guarantee – amongst other things – a statutory adequate minimum wage and collective agreement, which will provide greater security for families and fight precarious employment.

name: Branislav Škripek (ECR)
text: Writing. \u2012 As parents, we certainly only want the best for our children. It is sad if childhood is marked by poverty and a lack of basic things. At the same time, however, it is the responsibility of the Member States to address social and family policy issues. For this reason, I voted against the proposal tabled in the case of the European Parliament's legislative resolution on reducing inequalities, with a particular focus on child poverty. Officials from Brussels cannot determine what the standard of living of Slovak families should be.

name: Monika Smolková (S&D)
text: Writing. \in 2012 There are 84 million people living below the poverty line in the EU, which is about 16 percent of the European population. It is very worrying that more than 25 million children in the European Union (EU) are at risk of poverty or social exclusion, i.e. one in four children. I regret that the percentage of children living in poverty in the European Union is higher than the percentage of the adult population living in poverty, and child poverty is increasing along with social inequalities. I believe that it is in the interests of all of us that social inequalities and the negative impact of poverty and social exclusion on children should not be spread across generations and have an undesirable impact on the lives of these people and on society. That is also why I voted in favour of the resolution because I believe that reducing inequalities and the treatment of children in our own countries must become a priority for our own development. I also supported the report with regard to respect for human rights, which the EU and its Member States have committed themselves to respecting in international and European treaties, including the UN Convention on the Rights of the Child. I expect that the measures taken will improve the policy to combat child poverty and achieve the Europe 2020 target of reducing the number of people affected by poverty by at least 20 million.

name: Michaela Šojdrová (PPE)
text: Writing. \u2012 The report on reducing inequalities, with a particular focus on child poverty, does not have direct legislative implications, but it is a very strong appeal to the work of the EU institutions. I am glad that it was approved and that, as shadow rapporteur for the PPE, I was able to contribute to its creation. I am glad that we have managed to remove unnecessary bureaucratic requirements for the Commission or the creation of new offices from the report and, on the contrary, to emphasise that child poverty depends on the situation of their parents and families, who need to be targeted and created the best possible conditions for them. Our approach is also that improving their education, especially completing secondary education, is the way out of poverty and towards a better perspective for children. Quality and affordable education is also highlighted in this report as one of the main tools for reducing poverty. In the context of the migration crisis, the report also calls on the Member States to ensure that the childcare of migrants is ensured precisely in the light of the Convention on the Rights of the Child. It is primarily about the lives of children, but it is also about combating their exclusion – frustration and subsequent radicalisation, which is now at the top of the list.

name: Igor Šoltes (Verts/ALE)
text: Writing. Most Member States have so far failed to pay much attention to the use of EU structural funds to combat alarming and still increasing poverty rates among children. To this end, the European Commission has made a recommendation 'Investing in children: break the cycle of disadvantage'. In this report, it proposed a comprehensive policy framework for tackling poverty problems and promoting their well-being on the basis of three pillars. The latter focus on access to appropriate funds under the European Social Fund, access to quality and inclusive services and on children's participation in society and decision-making. The EP has repeatedly called for the implementation of the social investment package and also supports this Commission recommendation. I believe that in the fight against child poverty, it is necessary to have an integration approach of all generations, as this is the only way to break the intergenerational cycle of at-risk-of-poverty. However, I also believe that the EU should pay more attention to the fight against child poverty and, as a result, provide greater visibility. Only in this way will one of the objectives of the Europe 2020 strategy, which aims to reduce the number of poor by at least 20 million, can be achieved. As the report contains, in addition to the commission's good and constructive proposals for an appropriate fight against child poverty, I voted in favour of the

name: Renato Soru (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 In the field of child poverty, we are now witnessing a dramatic gap between internationally sanctioned rights and reality. According to the United Nations Convention on the Rights of the Child, children should have access to education, medical care, housing, recreation and even balanced nutrition. However, alarming Eurostat data show that more than one in four children (26 million young European citizens, almost 30% of the population under the age of 18) would be exposed to the risk of poverty and social exclusion, an unease that has increased as a result of the economic crisis. That is why I voted in favour of the resolution calling on the Member States to do more to reduce social inequalities and to make the fight against child poverty a priority. To this end, I support the proposal that Member States should step up their efforts to improve children's living conditions and create a guarantee for children to ensure that they have access to public education, free of charge, open to all and all ages. Since there is no better investment in a society than in childhood, this guarantee should be seen as a key instrument for the stability and prosperity of the Union.

name: Joachim Starbatty (ECR)
text: Writing. I voted against Mrs Zuber's non-legislative own-initiative report on reducing inequality, with a particular focus on child poverty, because, despite some good approaches, the report clearly goes beyond its objective in many areas, disregards parents' rights and violates subsidiarity. I fully support the rights of children, but I am at least as convinced that this must be done at the relevant political levels. For this reason too, I am clearly rejecting the S&D Group's proposal to create a 'European Child Guarantee'. Children need action, not words.

name: Ivan Štefanec (PPE)
text: Writing. \u2012 Our common interest is to create conditions so that every child has an equal chance to apply in life according to their own abilities and ideas. However, the primary governments of the Member States, not the European institutions, should be responsible for how to achieve this.

name: Helga Stevens (ECR)
text: Written. The N-VA delegation abstained in the vote on this report. Eliminating child poverty should be a priority for N-VA. However, it is up to the Member States to decide how to achieve poverty reduction targets. The report before us does not sufficiently respect the division of powers between the EU and the Member States. In particular, it is also important for Member States to maintain policy autonomy in the design of their social security systems and to continue to focus on a policy to combat (child) poverty. However, the N-VA delegation stresses the positive role that the EU can play in raising poverty issues and encouraging and supporting Member States, for example by facilitating the exchange of 'good practice'.

name: Davor Ivo Stier (PPE)
text: Written. I support this report because I believe that in the 21st century every child regardless of their background, religion or nationality is entitled to health care, education, home, protection and playtime. Not all children have this right in the EU today. Many children in the European Union today do not even have regular daily meals, let alone quality education. A number of children are segregated by the majority community and are prevented from interacting socially with other children. I believe that the European Union, as the leader of the idea of equality for all regardless of any differences or handicaps, must enable all its citizens equal rights, especially the most vulnerable groups including children.

name: Catherine Stihler (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of this report as child poverty in my constituency remains a problem and the Tories continue to be bent on maintaining a situation where poverty needlessly affects young people. Labour MEPs have always championed a better quality of life, especially for the most vulnerable in society. The report calls for a real commitment from Member States to tackle the factors which are causing child poverty and increase the scope of social support for children. It promotes labour laws that guarantee – amongst other things – a statutory adequate minimum wage and collective agreement, which will provide greater security for families and fight precarious employment.

name: Dubravka Šuica (PPE)
text: Written. All children should be guaranteed the right to education, health services, accommodation, protection, participation in decisions affecting them, leisure and leisure, balanced nutrition and care in the family environment. Key services most commonly provided by local and regional authorities include health, education, support for parents and families, housing and protection. Member states are invited to implement the introduction of universal welfare for children, such as the provision of subsidised or free meals, especially for those at risk and poor. The adoption of an active employment measure under comprehensive strategies and policies is necessary to support parents' access to quality jobs and adequate income and access to high-quality public services (in particular in the areas of childcare, education, health, housing and leisure activities).  I support this report because I believe that the fight against child poverty needs to be given greater political visibility at the highest EU political level. The consequences of poverty and social exclusion of children can last a lifetime, and are passed down from generation to generation.

name: Richard Sulík (ECR)
text: Writing. \u2012 I did not support the proposal. Although inequality, especially among children, can be a problem, many of the recommendations presented in the proposal ultimately increase poverty and, in particular, harm those they are supposed to protect. This is mainly due to the emphasis on raising the minimum wage, various social benefits and so on.

name: Patricija Šulin (PPE)
text: Writing. I voted in favour of the report on reducing inequalities with a particular focus on child poverty. As a society, we are responsible for the welfare of children, and it is for all of us to fully exercise the Convention on the Rights of the Child, which places the interests, protection and rights of children at the heart. We have a duty of the Signatory States to ensure that every child is protected from all forms of violence, abuse, neglect, cruel treatment and exploitation. The most effective solution to reduce rising child poverty is in the developing economy, in the rise of economic growth and in tackling unemployment. The economic crisis has an impact on the rise in child poverty and on the exercise of children's rights under the United Nations Convention on the Rights of the Child.

name: Pavel Svoboda (PPE)
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the report on reducing inequalities, with a particular focus on child poverty, as I believe that attention should be drawn to this subject. According to Eurostat or OECD statistics, the number of children at risk of poverty has been increasing in recent years. I am of the opinion that child poverty must be combated above all by adequate family policy, but it is clear that, unfortunately, even an ideal family policy is not a 100% guarantee for the exclusion of poverty from children's lives. These children (families) then need to offer a helping hand to increase their chances of healthy development and future full participation in society. This report is therefore intended to draw attention to the current situation, appealing on a number of points to individual Member States, which is entirely in line with the principle of subsidiarity, which should be applied on these issues.

name: Νεοκλής Συλικιώτης (
text: GUE/NGL), in writing. \u2012 Reducing inequalities, especially when focusing on child poverty is a very sensitive issue for us as a Left. All the more so when this report underlines the interconnection of wealth redistribution policies, the effectiveness of income support given by the government, labour policy and the situation of parents in the labour market as main factors in promoting or combating poverty. The report, largely reflecting left-wing positions, recommends that Member States really commit themselves to developing policies to combat child poverty that focus on eliminating the factors affecting child poverty, as mentioned above.
