It also asks them to increase the effectiveness, quantity, amounts and scope of social support specifically aimed at children, but also at parents who are unemployed. Combat the phenomenon of working poor (through unemployment benefits and an adequate minimum income). Promote labour legislation that guarantees social rights, including an adequate legal minimum wage in accordance with national practices and collective agreements, and that provides greater insurance for families and combats precarious employment, while promoting work with adequate social rights.  For the above reasons we voted in favour of the report.

name: Tibor Szanyi (S&D)
text: Writing. \u2012 The report highlights the need to give all children the right to education, health services, housing, protection, participation in decisions affecting them, leisure activities and free time, a balanced diet and the right to be raised in a family (UN Convention on the Rights of the Child). In the EU, however, compliance with the Convention is far from satisfactory. That is why I supported this report, as child poverty in Europe is on the rise.  In particular, it is regrettable that in Hungary the government has abolished statistics on poor health rather than solutions, even though it is well known that around 4 million people are already living below the living wage and the number of starving children has increased to more than half a million. Unfortunately, the Hungarian government does not take into account the fact that social inequalities re-generate disadvantages for generations, and that the negative effects of poverty and social exclusion on children can last a lifetime. The European Parliament voted to increase the amount, amount, scope and effectiveness of grants specifically for children and parents (e.g. unemployment benefits or extended parental rights). I believe that creating quality jobs and increasing the minimum wage can be a direct and indirect solution to addressing inequalities.

name: Adam Szejnfeld (PPE)
text: I would like to write to the Commission. \u2012 The Europe 2020 strategy aims to reduce the number of people affected by poverty by at least 20 million by 2020. Due to its very ambitious nature, action is needed at all levels: EU, national and regional, in order to combat this problem as effectively as possible. The European Parliament's report points out that more attention must be paid to the use of structural funds to combat alarming and ever-increasing rates of child poverty in Europe.  Parliament also emphasises in its report that Member States provide free and universal education, health care and social security for the poorest. I believe that this document properly emphasises the problems and challenges we face, which is why I decided to vote in favour of it.

name: Dario Tamburrano (EFDD)
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of this report, which sets out very clearly the aspects to be addressed in order to reduce inequalities, with particular attention being paid to child poverty, which is growing as social inequalities increase. It is well known that countries with higher levels of social inequality are also more likely to have higher levels of poverty and child social exclusion. The report stresses, among other things, the need to: 1) better protect low-income families; (2) to provide specific social support for unemployed parents and poor working parents, e.g. through an adequate minimum income; (3) overcoming financial, administrative and other obstacles to the education of children belonging to marginalised groups; 4) increase public expenditure to achieve the objectives of combating child poverty. It is essential to help low-income families who are at risk of poverty, as child poverty stems directly from the economic and social conditions of the family unit of reference. We have a moral duty to ensure that all children have the best possible conditions under which they can best develop their socio-cognitive skills.

name: Claudia Tapardel (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 We have been used to addressing poverty at national, regional and local level. It is true that local authorities are at the forefront of combating poverty among the population, but greater political visibility should be given to this situation at Union level, especially when social inequalities lie at the root of the problem. Unfortunately, children are the segment of the population with the highest risk of poverty in 19 Member States. The statistics are worrying: despite the commitments made by the Member States, more than one in four children now live on the edge of poverty or social exclusion throughout the Union. Under the UN Convention on the Rights of the Child, all children should be guaranteed the right to education, healthcare, housing and protection. The report that We voted on today concerns measures to alleviate child poverty, in particular the creation of a guarantee and a fund to provide free access to healthcare, education, care and improve opportunities in the labour market for parents, especially women. Personally, I am a supporter of better integration of women into the labour market and we have launched a number of actions in this regard.

name: Marc Tarabella (S&D)
text: In writing. We voted this week on a text sounding the alarm about child poverty in Europe. The figures are clear: one in four European children is close to falling into social exclusion and poverty. Insecurity, malnutrition, no access to care: child poverty is taking hold in our countries for a long time.  A proportion of 27.7% of young people, or 26 million European children, are on the brink, victims of a policy of austerity that is too often blind and inhumane, and national policies that are no longer social enough. With its vote today, the European Parliament is sounding the alarm and sheds light on these dramatic figures.  It is up to the European Commission and the Member States to put in place the tools of a much more united policy than the one currently in force so as not to condemn the future of European youth.

name: Pavel Telička (ALDE)
text: in writing. ‒ I supported this report, which underlines that a better use of structural funds can be used to fight child poverty in Europe. Over the past years, child poverty has dramatically increased and more than one child out of four is at risk of poverty and social exclusion, which covers monetary poverty, material deprivation and low work intensity. This report, among other things, encourages Member States and the Commission to agree on EU standards and establish a methodology for determining the cost of raising a child. Resources to prevent and fight child poverty should also be found jointly. For this reason and with respect for the principle of subsidiarity, I opposed those provisions which imposed on Member States a specific solution on national competences, for instance the provision on providing free healthcare.

name: Isabelle Thomas (S&D)
text: In writing. Austerity policies have strengthened the effects of the crisis. We have seen an increase in poverty in Europe. It hits children hard, who are bearing the brunt of the weakening of the welfare state in the name of fiscal orthodoxy and the sacrosanct 3% rule. The Zuber report proposes that the objective of reducing inequality and combating child poverty should be included in the European Union's political priorities. We also stress the need for free and quality education, which must be accessible to all. Finally, we propose the establishment of a guarantee for children that would ensure free education, reimbursed health care, dignified housing and child-friendly nutrition, while allowing their parents to find decent employment to stop being ostracized from society. While the Commission remains inert, we want to force it to propose legislation. Faced with the urgency and social distress experienced by many European families, we cannot stand idly by, we must act and finally lay the foundations for a social Europe in action.

name: Patrizia Toia (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 More than 26 million children in the 28 countries of the European Union are at risk of poverty or social exclusion. These figures are unacceptable. I believe it is essential to make the fight against child poverty one of the specific objectives of the Europe 2020 agenda. We need more investment in social protection, health, education and social housing. In addition to the creation, as requested by the Group of the Party of European People's Party (S&D), we cannot continue to remain helpful in the face of millions of children throughout Europe who are living in uncomfortable situations, who are exacerbated by the current crisis. We strongly call on the European Commission and the Member States to do more to ensure basic services for families and to combat child poverty firmly, including by providing ad hoc resources.

name: Valdemar Tomaševski (ECR)
text: Writing. \u2012 I unequivocally support the report by meme I.C Zuber for several reasons. All the reports refer to the intensification of child poverty in Europe. Between 2008 and 2012, an increase in the number of children at risk of poverty or social exclusion was observed in Europe by almost one million. Dramatic is the percentage of children living in full and long-term poverty (more than 3 years) is growing. Social inequalities recur from generation to generation, and the negative effects of poverty and social exclusion on children can last their entire lives, as cognitive and socio-economic skills are educated in the first year of their child's life, which means that the unfavourable political actions of today will have negative consequences for the lives of these people and society as a whole. Member States should therefore be encouraged to invest more in actions to combat child poverty. We should do this in the light of Europe's Christian roots.

name: Ruža Tomašić (ECR)
text: Written. ‒ This report by the Employment and Social Affairs Committee, as well as previous reports on The Zuber's own initiative, already roughly and unnecessarily encroach on the competences of individual Member States of the Union.  The report contains a number of noble and universal goals to which I give uncompromising and full support; such as increasing effective social support, calling for the creation of proactive and preventive policies aimed at children and parents, guaranteeing universal availability of health care to children, institutionalizing children as a last resort, moving from institutions to family and community-run environments, etc. However, I cannot agree with the parts of the report which are disproportionate to the objective to be achieved, while in breach of the principle of subsidiarity on which European Union legislation is based. Claims that the reduction of minimum national net wages and the reduction of social benefits contribute to the rise of poverty and social exclusion, recommendations for Member States to assume the legal obligation to guarantee unemployment benefits and minimum wages to parents, a renewed call to promote gender ideology through calls for guaranteeing universal, public, free and quality healthcare in the sexual and reproductive rights segment, and many more similar calls. I see such calls as a scandalous and destructive encoding on the exclusive competences of individual Member States of the Union. So I voted abstention.

name: Romana Tomc (PPE)
text: Writing. I supported the report on reducing inequalities, with a particular focus on child poverty, because child poverty is a very big problem, with one in four children living in the European Union living at the poverty or social exclusion threshold. I believe that all children should have the right to education, healthcare and to grow up in a normal and safe family environment. Nor should we allow child poverty to deepen at the expense of the austerity measures that are otherwise necessary.

name: Yana Toom (ALDE)
text: in writing. ‒ In recent years in Europe the number of children at risk of poverty or social exclusion as well as children living in absolute and long-term poverty has increased. In Estonia, the percentage of children who cannot eat meat, chicken or fish two days running has doubled since 2008. The right to free and universal education, health and social security systems is crucial for the efficient fight against child’s poverty. The Commission should make tackling the early school leaving rate an explicit priority.

name: Estefanía Torres Martínez (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. The report is a progressive text, with a multidimensional approach to child poverty, for which comprehensive solutions are also called for. Among others, it is proposed that Member States adopt policies that promote access to universal, public, free and quality health care, social services and education for both children and families, while ensuring cultural inclusion, democratic participation, balanced food and adequate housing. The report links the situation of poverty and social exclusion of children to that of their parents and stresses that, in order for children to have their children welfare and their children's rights safeguarded, measures must be taken to address unemployment, safety at work, family support or the public development of socio-educational networks. It is important to mention that the text reflects gender aspects. The report does not reflect our rejection of the European Semester or country-specific recommendations but, in any event, its content is positive for reducing inequalities, with particular attention to child poverty, so we voted in favour.

name: Ramon Tremosa i Balcells (ALDE)
text: in writing. ‒ All measures taken by the European Union institutions and Member States to improve the lives of the most vulnerable, especially young people, will have my support. It would be good to see which policies are being applied in the countries with less childhood poverty to serve as an example to other European countries.

name: Mylène Troszczynski (ENF)
text: In writing. Child poverty has increased significantly in Europe in recent years, due to rising social inequalities and austerity measures followed by Member States. The social categories most affected are single-parent families, the unemployed, migrants, while the Mediterranean countries are the most affected by this statistical phenomenon. 1. All rights are covered in this proposal, but focusing on the child sometimes overlooks the environment and the family, which should nevertheless receive more attention. 2. The proposed policy measures are unrealistic in times of structural crisis aggravated by totally uncontrolled migratory pressure. 3. On the other hand, ensuring better social protection for the most vulnerable families must meet objective criteria, and protecting them from abuse by financial institutions is a no-brainer. This text is aberrant and there is still the fatal theory of gender. I'm voting AGAINST.

name: Mihai Ţurcanu (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 27.7% of European children are at risk of poverty and social exclusion, and this will have lifelong consequences for them. Unfortunately, the highest share of children living in poverty is in Romania (51%), followed by Bulgaria (45.2%) Hungary (41.4%). The lowest percentage is recorded in Scandinavian countries, with the best situation being in Denmark (14.5%). Given that this situation, aggravated in the years of the economic crisis, seriously affects the basic rights of children and has a severe impact over time in terms of employment and social integration, I believe that effective and coordinated measures are urgently needed to reduce the gaps between Member States and on this sensitive level. I voted in favour of the report on reducing inequalities, in particular child poverty, because there is a need to improve the strategy at European level by guaranteeing access to free and quality public education for children of all ages, providing the basic school materials, nutritious meals and school transport necessary for disadvantaged children, in order to foster school attendance.

name: István Ujhelyi (S&D)
text: Writing. \u2012 All reports indicate an increase in child poverty in Europe. Between 2008 and 2012, the number of children at risk of poverty or social exclusion in Europe increased by almost one million; In 2013, 26.5 million children in the EU-28 were at risk of poverty and social exclusion, according to Eurostat data. In Hungary, 41.4 percent of children and then one in two children are forced to live in poverty. This proves that a tragic social crisis has developed in Hungarian society in recent years. 300,000 children live in extremely poor nutritional conditions, and 50,000 to 60,000 children do not have access to proper food every day. As a European Democrat, I can only support any initiative to eradicate child poverty. I voted yes.

name: Miguel Urbán Crespo (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. The report is a progressive text, with a multidimensional approach to child poverty, for which comprehensive solutions are also called for. Among others, it is proposed that Member States adopt policies that promote access to universal, public, free and quality health care, social services and education for both children and families, while ensuring cultural inclusion, democratic participation, balanced food and adequate housing. The report links the situation of poverty and social exclusion of children to that of their parents and stresses that, in order for children to have their children welfare and their children's rights safeguarded, measures must be taken to address unemployment, safety at work, family support or the public development of socio-educational networks. It is important to mention that the text reflects gender aspects. The report does not reflect our rejection of the European Semester or country-specific recommendations but, in any event, its content is positive for reducing inequalities, with particular attention to child poverty, so we voted in favour.

name: Viktor Uspaskich (ALDE)
text: Writing. – Child poverty is increasing along with the increase in social inequalities. Social inequalities lead to a generational and negative impact on children from generation to generation, and the negative impact of poverty and social exclusion can last for children throughout their lives, as children develop their cognitive and economic and social skills at an early stage of life, which means that the negative policies taken today will have an irreversible negative impact on the lives and societies of these individuals. Poverty is multidimensual and must be understood not only as the inability to meet the child's basic needs, such as food, clothing and housing, but also the lack of access to education and quality healthcare and the inability to participate in sport, culture and other leisure activities.

name: Ivo Vajgl (ALDE)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of the resolution on reducing inequalities with a special focus on child poverty. This topic is extremely important and the resolution acknowledges a lot that has been already said at the UN level, about guaranteeing to all children the right to education, healthcare services, housing, protection, participation in decisions that affect them, leisure and free time, a balanced diet and the receipt of care in a family environment. But it is still necessary that EU countries also make children a priority in their policies. It is crucial that Member States guarantee that all children have access to free, inclusive and quality public education at any age and that Member States make a real commitment to developing policies to fight child poverty that focus on correcting child poverty factors and increase the effectiveness, quantity, amounts and scope of the social support specifically directed at children, but also at parents who are unemployed and the phenomenon of the working poor (such as unemployment benefits and adequate minimum income) and to promote labour laws that guarantee social rights.

name: Ramón Luis Valcárcel Siso (PPE)
text: in writing. We are talking about a report that focuses on the causes of child poverty and how to combat them, paying particular attention to education and the rights of the child and calling for the development of indicators that better measure poverty, social exclusion and discrimination in order to achieve a better understanding of these phenomena. That is why I consider it necessary to vote in favour of that report.

name: Elena Valenciano (S&D)
text: in writing. I voted in favour because I find it unacceptable that today, in Europe, one in four children is at risk of poverty and social exclusion and twenty million do not have access to a hot meal a day. It is imperative that we ensure that all children have access to health care, education, decent housing and adequate food.  That is why the Socialists have proposed establishing a child guarantee as part of an integrated European plan to combat child poverty, which also encompasses programmes that provide aid and opportunities for parents to get out of situations of social exclusion and integrate into the labour market. In this regard, we deeply regret that the proposal is not accompanied by a specific guarantee fund, since the European right as a whole has refused to support its creation.  The report also calls on the Commission to make the fight against child poverty a central priority of the new Annual Growth Survey 2016, because investing in children is not only investing in the future of the EU, but is a matter of social justice.

name: Bodil Valero (Verts/ALE)
text: Written. \u2012 All children should have access to healthcare, education and childcare, but how this is organised in the budgetary terms of the different Member States of the European Union. In Sweden, for example, this concerns, above all, municipal and regional budgets. The Member States should continue to have the right to design this according to their systems, and that is why I am voting against all Member States allocating a specific budget line for this issue.

name: Ángela Vallina (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. I voted in favour of this report because it places the causes of child poverty in its true structural framework and not in the family sphere, as is often the case in neoliberal proposals. The fundamental role of the right to health, education and social protection, as well as the right to decent work, to combat child poverty is recognized. This highlights the need to build another society, and not just to adopt other policies, to end this serious social problem.

name: Derek Vaughan (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of this report because child poverty remains a key problem in Wales and the UK more generally as 28 per cent of children across the country grow up in relative poverty. However, this problem exists across the EU and needs to be tackled. I therefore welcome a report at a European level, particularly as the Tories continue to maintain a situation where poverty needlessly affects young people across the UK. Labour MEPs have always championed a better quality of life for all, but especially for the most vulnerable in society our society. Children need to grow up in an environment where they are giving a decent chance in life. This report calls for a real commitment from Member States to tackle the factors which are causing child poverty and increase the scope of social support for children. It promotes labour laws that guarantee – amongst other things – a statutory adequate minimum wage and collective agreement, which will provide greater security for families and fight precarious employment.

name: Hilde Vautmans (ALDE)
text: Written. 'I voted in favour of the report because we have seen an increase in the number of children in structural poverty in Europe in recent years. This report underlines the urgent need to do more to combat child poverty.

name: Marie-Christine Vergiat (GUE/NGL)
text: In writing. This report by my Portuguese colleague from the PCP shows the increase in child poverty in Europe. Between 2008 and 2012, the number of children at risk of poverty or social exclusion increased by about one million to 26.5 million children.  Child poverty is growing in parallel with social inequalities, and countries with the highest levels of social inequality have the highest rates of child poverty.  Wealth-distribution policies and employment policy, which have been badly undermined in recent years by austerity policies to reduce budget deficits and debt, are major tools for intervention to make a difference in the long run. Social assistance for children and their parents (e.g. unemployment benefits) should be developed, legislation guaranteeing social rights and household security should be promoted, and expenditure to combat child poverty should be included in national budgets. Without a revision of the European rules, this report will remain a dead letter. Nevertheless, I am voting for it.

name: Miguel Viegas (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. \u2012 It is estimated that one billion children live in conflict-affected areas; a quarter of these children are under five years old and are denied the right to education. These are UN numbers. It is also estimated that 65 million children are affected by emergency situations and prolonged crises and that approximately 37 million children of age to attend primary and low secondary education do not.  Much of the emergency situations and prolonged crises are a painful demonstration of the inhuman, exploitative and aggressive character of the capitalist system and have causes and responsible: the processes of destabilization in various parts of the globe and the wars of imperialist aggression, the policy of economic dominance and the collection of natural resources.  While we welcome the call on Member States to contribute to the increase in humanitarian funds for the education of children in emergencies to 4% of the humanitarian aid provided for in the EU budget, we believe that these funds should be channelled into promoting universal access to free and quality public education in all levels of education.

name: Harald Vilimsky (ENF)
text: Writing. The ENF resolution on this issue responds much better to the individual needs of Member States and does not expect new funds and directives to be set up at European level. Furthermore, this report is pushing ahead with an increase in competence, in which it is questionable whether it will really help children living in poverty or at risk of poverty. That is why I am abstaining from voting.

name: Daniele Viotti (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 In recent years there has been a worrying increase in the percentage of children living in absolute poverty. Since 2008, the proportion of children who cannot eat meat or fish for two consecutive days has practically doubled. This has led to an inevitable increase in social inequalities and child social exclusion in many countries. Having the absolute duty to guarantee a future for the new generations and to fight against the vicious circle of poverty, I voted clearly and decisively in favour. Guaranteeing a future for a child means guaranteeing the future of Europe and of the citizens to come.

name: Beatrix von Storch (ECR)
text: Writing. In 2012, 2010 had been an "EU Year for Combating Poverty and Social Exclusion" – except expenses. In order to combat child poverty in the EU, there is no need for any own reporting procedure. Who wants children to live in poverty? Nobody. I don't either. But words are politics and words make politics. That is why, on the pretext of combating child poverty, this resolution contains, above all, those communist elements of society that I do not support in any way. Combating child poverty must not be promoted by the EU through unfair means. These include the far-reaching EU intervention in the wage policy of the Member States or the EU's far-reaching intervention in national social policy with demands to increase substantial social assistance free of charge without consideration. Of course, the right to abortion is not lacking – the children of the poorest are too much for feminists, too. Incidentally, 'self-responsibility' does not occur once in the whole resolution. But is it not more effective to strengthen the role of fathers and mothers and their responsibility for their children, rather than perverting the EU to fall back into state socialism? In the Bundestag, the positions of the old parties on this important issue would be nuanced. In Strasbourg, however, Die Linke votes in unison with the CDU/CSU, SPD, FDP and Greens.

name: Julie Ward (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ More than 1 in 4 children are at risk of poverty or social exclusion in the EU, which is a total of 26 million+ minors. Children living in poverty are at a higher risk of poor health, are more likely not to finish school, experience worse relationships with their peers and consequently are unable to reach their full potential in life. As a children’s rights champion and co-founder of the parliamentary Children’s Rights intergroup, this report was of particular importance for me. Child poverty in my NW England constituency and across the UK remains a problem; the Tories continue to pursue austerity policies that promulgate poverty and have a disproportionate effect on young people. Labour MEPs have always championed a better quality of life, especially for the most vulnerable in society. The report calls for a real commitment from Member States to tackle the factors which cause child poverty, and increase the scope of social support for children. It promotes labour laws that guarantee, amongst other things, collective agreements and a statutory adequate minimum wage which will provide greater security for families and fight precarious employment. For all these reasons I voted in favour of the report.

name: Glenis Willmott (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of this report because child poverty in my constituency remains a problem and the Conservative government has not done enough to help the young people disproportionately affected by their policies. Labour MEPs have always championed a better quality of life, especially for the most vulnerable in society. The report calls for a real commitment from Member States to tackle the factors which are causing child poverty and increase the scope of social support for children. It also promotes labour laws that guarantee a statutory adequate minimum wage and collective agreement, which will provide greater security for families and fight precarious employment.

name: Iuliu Winkler (PPE)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of the report on reducing inequalities with a special focus on child poverty. I agree with the UN Convention on the Rights of the Child stating that all children should be guaranteed the right to education, health services, housing, protection, recreation and leisure time, as well as a balanced diet and to be raised within a family. Different reports on child poverty in Europe show that children are increasingly under threat of poverty and social exclusion. I support that it is essential that Member States and the European Commission to take a number of meaningful measures to eliminate poverty and social exclusion among children. The report focuses on the causes of child poverty and how to tackle them.

name: Jadwiga Wiśniewska (ECR)
text: I would like to write to the Commission. \u2012 The problem of child poverty is a multidimensional phenomenon and strongly requires action to be taken that is guided by the fundamental principle of the best interests of the child for international law. The report contains recommendations that could improve children's financial situation and health care, such as seeking to make social support more effective or ensuring the universality of health care. However, I do not believe that the report has been drafted in a world-neutral manner. It is unacceptable for me to use the plight of children to promote the right to 'sexual and reproductive health'. This wording is unclear in the light of international law and in view of the strong tendency to derive from it the right to decide freely and non-discriminatoryly about its reproduction - and therefore also when to terminate a pregnancy - cannot win my support. I am surprised that the report on improving the situation of children reinforces the claims of those who wish to avoid parenthood. In view of the above, I voted against the report.

name: Anna Záborská (PPE)
text: Writing. \u2012 Every year, on the occasion of the International Day for the Eradication of Poverty, I draw attention to the problem of poverty among families with young children. It is embarrassing that millions of children live in poverty in a wealthy European Union. The approved resolution contains many good proposals, and I am very sorry that I had to abstain in the final vote. The reason for my decision was the ideologically conditional input of sexual and reproductive health into the text concerning the care of the health of pregnant women and mothers. Pregnant women and mothers and their unborn children and newborns need to receive maximum healthcare, but unfortunately the term 'sexual and reproductive health' is often understood to include abortion.  I have also read with interest the alternative resolution of the ENF, but since we have adopted the principle of not supporting any initiatives by French nationalists whose political positions are detrimental to both Europe and Slovakia within the EPP faction, I voted against their amendment.

name: Θεόδωρος Ζαγοράκης (
text: PPE), in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of this vote. Child poverty is a disgrace to the international community and an affront to human nature. There can be no discount on the safeguarding of human rights, particularly children's rights. Combating child poverty must be a priority for every politician at national, European and international level.

name: Pablo Zalba Bidegain (PPE)
text: in writing. In the wake of events such as the economic crisis and, more recently, the migration crisis, large inequalities in the population are being created. I am certainly in favour of taking steps to reduce this situation. In Spain equality has always been a priority, so we have focused on offering a social welfare system that guarantees education and health for all children under the age of 18, as well as an income guarantee. Following the economic crisis we approved the 2013-2016 NAP, mainly focused on the fight against child poverty and its guarantee of well-being. So my position in favour of this vote is clear, I certainly support these measures.

name: Tomáš Zdechovský (PPE)
text: Writing. \u2012 I have decided to support this report defending the rights of children based on the Convention on the Rights of the Child. Children are our wake-up call and need to be protected and given special care. I consider it necessary to do my utmost to ensure that children do not grow up in poverty and social exclusion, because this is the germ of future problems, such as crime and radicalisation leading to terrorism. On the whole, I agree with the report, but I have reservations in some individuals.

name: Jana Žitňanská (ECR)
text: Writing. \u2012 I consider reducing inequalities with a focus on child poverty to be a topic that we should address within the European Union, as there are increasing increases in children who are exposed to poverty and associated social exclusion and, for the most part, because of parental poverty, do not have access to quality education, healthcare or decent housing. In my opinion, Mrs Zuber's report has identified the problems faced by children in the European Union, but I do not agree with the solutions to these problems that have been put on the list. It will not help children from poverty if we propose increasing unemployment benefits or unifying minimum wage values throughout the European Union; Since, as I said, this report also contains positive aspects with which I agree, but also many proposals that I could not support, I abstained in the final vote.

name: Damiano Zoffoli (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 I very much welcome the result of today's vote on the resolution 'Reducing inequalities, with a particular focus on child poverty', in which MEPs, meeting in plenary session in Strasbourg, called by a large majority for Member States to make the fight against child poverty a priority and to guarantee all children access to public education, free of charge, open to all and all ages. This is a strong message that puts us in front of a situation not known by all: child poverty is also a reality in Europe – according to Eurostat, 26 million children would have been exposed to the risk of poverty and social exclusion in 2014, that is, 27.7% of European citizens under the age of 18 – and the austerity policy of recent years has only made this situation worse.

name: Inês Cristina Zuber (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. The policies that impoverishEU families in the EU are the same as those that have thrown children into poverty, denying them many of the rights contained in the Convention on the Rights of the Child, including the rights to health, education and social protection. Therefore, in this report, we recommend that Member States legislate social rights, including an appropriate mandatory minimum wage that respects national practices and collective agreements and provides greater security for families and combats precarious links by promoting work with social rights. We therefore advocate universal social subsidies for children, as their own intrinsic right. We encourage legislation that protects or increases maternity and paternity rights, safeguards women's return to work after pregnancy and maternity leave, and supports single-parent families, which are mostly female. We voted against the parties that were included in the report who believe that this tragedy can be resolved through the European Semester or the rules of economic and monetary union, because we believe that what is largely causing the problem must be tackled and cannot be part of the solution.

name: Milan Zver (PPE)
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the European Parliament resolution on reducing inequalities, with a particular focus on child poverty (2014/2237(INI)) because I agree with the proposed calls for a resolution to actively and fully involve the EU institutions, EU agencies, Member State authorities and other stakeholders in tackling child poverty and social exclusion.  It is necessary to develop and implement integrated systems for the protection of children and young people, especially those with special needs, against violence, abuse, exploitation and neglect.

name: Andrejs Mamikins (S&D).
text: – The European Union's cohesion policy is not simply an instrument by which the different levels of development of the regions of the Member States can be progressively balanced, although this is also a good thing, but it is even more necessary to reduce the degree of social marginalisation. Consequently, I welcome the adoption of this report, as it could provide a positive impetus in the perspective of solving the problem of long-term social marginalisation by more effective synchronisation of the relevant policy between the Institutions of the European Union and its Member States respectively, and of course it will allow us all to increase the quality of information collection in this area, so that it is better understood by a simple person who is in a difficult situation, what the level of complexity is. where it would be necessary to intensify the efforts to resolve the existing problem. Thank you!

name: Stanislav Polčák (PPE).
text: – Madam President, I supported this report by Mrs Reintke, because this report has also undergone some development. In the beginning, it looked like it would all be a hugging message, where in fact each group would be considered marginalized. Fortunately, this report has been modified during the discussions in the Committee on Regional Development, which is why I could really support it in good conscience, also on the grounds that cohesion policy is actually balancing a certain disadvantage, eliminating the unjustified differences that are given in the natural origin of the difference, and it is also part of the defence against social exclusion. In the Czech Republic, communities where we identify social exclusion have doubled in the past five years. This is undoubtedly a negative trend and the Czech Republic must respond to this not only by drawing on European funds for this chapter, but also by its own efforts.

name: Monica Macovei (ECR).
text: – Currently marginalised communities are defined by each Member State on the basis of national indicators: social exclusion, high long-term unemployment, access to education, low levels of education, poor living conditions, high levels of discrimination and social services, excessive exposure to health risks or lack of access to health services. The Commission has accepted partnership agreements that do not include marginalised communities. I voted for this report because it proposes the inclusion of marginalised communities in the processes of preparation, implementation and evaluation of projects. You can't integrate them if you leave them out when you're discussing projects, especially those that concern these marginalized communities. The report also proposes a better connection of regions because people living in cross-border areas are often marginalised because of their geographical position. The Commission must, according to the report, provide explanations of European and national programmes to support entrepreneurs.

name: Daniel Hannan (ECR).
text: – Mr President, the premise behind this report is false. The premise is that the best way to bring marginalised communities into the mainstream is through government action and government spending. I would say the opposite actually: where trade unites, politics divide. Taking money from one place to give it to another stirs up conflicts and disputes, and encourages recipients to start arranging their affairs – consciously or subconsciously – around receipt of the subsidy instead of through their own efforts. Actually, the best way to integrate people is by allowing them to trade freely, one with another, through contract, without intervention. There is no better system than the market, as Milton Friedman once pointed out, for bringing together people who might not otherwise like each other. The opposite is true: that the free market is some kind of atomised individualistic system. There is no other system ever devised by human intelligence that so encourages empathy, that so encourages you to put yourself in the shoes of somebody else, as one where you have to rely for your own welfare on the custom of the people around you.

name: Diane Dodds (NI).
text: – Mr President, I welcome this report, which focuses on ensuring that Cohesion Policy benefits communities that are marginalised for a variety of reasons and in a variety of ways. In Northern Ireland, the Structural Funds have for consecutive programming periods assisted victims of terrorism in my constituency who have historically faced physical, psychological and social barriers to employment, training and inclusion. This has included PEACE and the ESF. At no stage, therefore, should we rest on our laurels when it comes to ensuring that this funding continues to improve peoples’ lives. In Northern Ireland in the current programming period, the managing authority, DEL, has shown complete disregard for the community, voluntary and women’s sectors in the implementation of the ESF, restricting the qualifications they can provide, the tutors they can employ and placing barriers before those who can enrol. These policies ignore the value of community provision and the long-standing benefits of the ESF for marginalised communities. It is high time that the European Commissioner reminded our Minister of this fact.

name: James Carver (EFDD).
text: – Mr President, as the only British Parliamentarian from a Romany background, I am proud to reaffirm my own Gypsy heritage. I support Roma gypsy traveller rights. Indeed, I will be a keynote speaker later this week at the traveller movement conference in London, when I will be championing this worthy cause. Much of this initiative report calls for EU action in this area, and in view of my own political position, I cannot support such action at EU level. Instead, to tackle this issue properly, the mind-set must be challenged at national level, and that is something that I will continue to do. Accordingly, I abstained on this report. However, I voted in favor of Amendment 42 and Recital Q. Both pointed towards racism facing the Roma communities. I was sorry to note that British Conservatives largely voted against this report, but I am hardly surprised – not least bearing in mind that the British Conservative Government’s recent changes to planning regulations which, quite frankly, are prejudicial towards my own country’s travelling community. This, quite frankly, is unacceptable.

name: Jonathan Arnott (EFDD).
text: – Mr President, I abstained on this report and I abstain on many reports, particularly non—legislative ones, in this place. Do I agree that minorities are often treated badly? Of course I do. Do I agree that the Roma people in particular have been treated appallingly in some countries and subjected to conditions that no one should be subjected to? Of course I do. Do I believe that nations should do more to tackle this kind of oppression? Of course I do. But then I look at the report and it suggests, within that report, that integration at European level is the solution. No, integration within those communities, within those nations, is what must be done to deal with this problem. Therefore the report, to my mind, completely misses the point. For that reason I abstained.

name: William (The Earl of) Dartmouth (EFDD)
text: in writing. ‒ We abstained on this vote due to the sensitivity of the issue at hand. UKIP does not believe that the Commission should be creating overarching integrating schemes at all. But we also recognise that ostracising marginalised communities that come from disadvantaged backgrounds is also a negative thing. Therefore we decided to abstain.

name: Isabella Adinolfi (EFDD)
text: in writing. \u2012 The policies of cohesion and integration of marginalised communities have always been the theme and fundamental objective of the European Union. Ensuring better integration into the social, cultural and working fabric of communities considered marginalised on the basis of specific indicators is undoubtedly a natural consequence of the Union's fundamental objectives. The document presented by the rapporteur, Mr Reintke, makes it clear in certain passages that the ERDF and the ESF make a considerable contribution to achieving this objective by supporting and encouraging the integration policies of the individual Member States in the fight against all forms of discrimination and poverty. Increasing employment opportunities, improving housing conditions and raising the level of education are just some of the possible and desirable measures to be taken by the Union and its members. For these reasons, I voted in favour of this report.

name: Clara Eugenia Aguilera García (S&D)
text: in writing. The legislative framework for cohesion policy ensures funding opportunities for marginalized communities in urban and rural areas. The 2014-2020 programming period is committed to the implementation of participatory local development and integrated territorial investments (ITIs) targeting marginalized communities.  With our vote in favour of the report, the Socialists call on the European Commission to adopt a definition of 'marginalized communities', which does not yet exist, with the aim of allowing these EU citizens to benefit even more from the European Structural and Investment Funds. The vote against paragraph 11 of the report is because that text assumes, through an erroneous and widespread approach, that the EU does not have structures for combating corruption and fraudulent use of funds (and existing ones are not responsible, transparent and democratic), and that marginalized communities are excluded from EU funds , which is the wrong assumption. The Socialists have always advocated maximum transparency in existing fund management structures and that marginalized communities continue to benefit from cohesion policy.

name: Marina Albiol Guzmán (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. I voted in favour of this report as it contains positive elements for the effective implementation, through cohesion policy, of the principle of non-discrimination contained in the Treaties. In this regard, the text calls on the European Commission to clarify the concept of marginalized communities; stresses that cuts in public services further complicate the situation of vulnerable groups; visibilizes existing racism and institutional discrimination towards communities such as Roma; calls for Member States to ensure the participation of partnerships working with marginalized communities as well; denounces the multiple discrimination against women, people with disabilities and migrants found in marginalized communities, among other groups. Therefore, and although the report is exclusively pro propositional, I voted in favour.

name: Martina Anderson and Lynn Boylan (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. – We voted in favour of this report. Cohesion policy is one of the strongest instruments the European Union has to fight inequality. This report builds on that, by looking specifically at how the cohesion policy can assist in empowering marginalised communities. Although there is no uniform EU definition of marginalised communities, Martina Anderson of Sinn Féin ensured that the report acknowledged that people in cross-border, rural and isolated areas are often subject to marginalisation due to their geographical situation and should be better taken into consideration by the cohesion policy. The report also acknowledges the needs of women, people with disabilities, migrants, Roma and Travellers, and highlights the importance of an integrated, grass-roots, community-led and inclusive approach to solving the problems faced by these communities.

name: Gerolf Annemans (ENF)
text: Written. In this report, the European Parliament once again excels in an adolescent money-making drive. My group is not a fan of the so-called cohesion policy anyway, but it will be particularly difficult to find 'cohesion' if there is no definite definition of the target public, in this case 'marginalised communities'. They want to help "marginalised communities", but the report itself states that there is no definition of what marginalised communities are. The only result can only be that budgets are again provided and unfathomable money flows arise without any strategy or well-defined goals.

name: Pascal Arimont (PPE)
text: Writing. Cohesion policy aims to promote socio-economic and territorial cohesion and to reduce social inequalities such as poverty and social exclusion. Therefore, during the deployment or preparation of EU programmes, the prevention of segregation and the promotion of equal opportunities for all citizens should be paramount. This includes the most marginalised groups. The exclusion of the Roma population and their living conditions are a particular cause for concern. Given the important role of cohesion policy for the integration of such marginalised groups, I voted in favour of the European Parliament resolution. It calls on the Commission to better define marginalised communities and to involve this target group more clearly in funding opportunities.

name: Marie-Christine Arnautu (ENF)
text: In writing. This report is ideologically very oriented. It once again demonstrates the European Union's desire to impose on Member States its harmful vision of a multicultural society.  Systematically, it defends the "marginalized communities" of Roma, immigrants (legal or illegal) and asylum seekers. They are seen as victims of bad policies. To remedy this, the report recommends the use of European funds, to multiply social and cultural programmes. The presence and behaviour of these communities on the territory is never in question despite rates of incivility, offences and misdemeanours that are well above average. As for immigrants and "refugees", it is enough to see what is happening in the Calais Jungle and elsewhere to understand the exasperation of the residents and more generally of the European peoples. The mass presence of foreigners or persons of foreign origin results in strong communitarianization and territorial segregation often accompanied by a refusal to submit to the habits and customs of the hosts. On the other hand, it should be remembered that the subsidies generously paid to them have so far not yielded anything positive. So I logically voted against this report.

name: Jean Arthuis (ALDE)
text: In writing. I voted in favour of this text because it aims to reduce social disparities, including reducing and eliminating poverty and exclusion, which means combating segregation and promoting equal access and equal opportunities for all citizens, including the most marginalized communities, as well as groups and people of all ages facing poverty and social exclusion and not having access to education. , employment, housing and health care.

name: Petras Auštrevičius (ALDE)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of this report. I believe that the EU has a very powerful instrument at its disposal able to significantly improve the situation of marginalised communities. Therefore, we need to adjust the legislation in the way that it would facilitate the path for using EU structural funds as well to support the empowerment processes of marginalised communities and groups. Only this way we can effectively tackle inequality and ensure territorial and social cohesion in the regions.

name: Inés Ayala Sender (S&D)
text: in writing. The legislative framework for cohesion policy ensures funding opportunities for marginalized communities in urban and rural areas. The 2014-2020 programming period is committed to the implementation of participatory local development and integrated territorial investments (ITIs) targeting marginalized communities.  With our vote in favour of the report, the Socialists call on the European Commission to adopt a definition of 'marginalized communities', which does not yet exist, with the aim of allowing these EU citizens to benefit even more from the European Structural and Investment Funds. The vote against paragraph 11 of the report is because that text assumes, through an erroneous and widespread approach, that the EU does not have structures for combating corruption and fraudulent use of funds (and existing ones are not responsible, transparent and democratic), and that marginalized communities are excluded from EU funds , which is the wrong assumption. The Socialists have always advocated maximum transparency in existing fund management structures and that marginalized communities continue to benefit from cohesion policy.

name: Zigmantas Balčytis (S&D)
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of this proposal, which aims to address the problem of marginalised communities and to support the economic, social and territorial inclusion of these communities. Marginalisation is a social phenomenon where individuals or communities are socially excluded and prevented from participating in social and political processes. The current problems of significant cuts in public spending in the Member States have exacerbated the current problems in the Member States, i.e. increased unemployment, social protection has been reduced, housing has been found and public health services have started to run out. I agree that the problems associated with the integration of marginalised groups must focus on specific target groups without excluding other people in a similar socio-economic situation. It is important to properly implement the Code of Conduct for Partnership, which aims to ensure equal involvement and representation of stakeholders. Funding does not always take into account the real needs of beneficiaries, so it is important to move to quality control in order to achieve long-term and sustainable results through action.

name: Gerard Batten (EFDD)
text: in writing. ‒ We abstained on this vote due to the sensitivity of the issue at hand. UKIP does not believe that the Commission should be creating overarching integrating schemes at all. But we also recognise that ostracising marginalised communities that come from disadvantaged backgrounds is also a negative thing. Therefore we decided to abstain.

name: Nicolas Bay (ENF)
text: In writing. I voted against this report, which stems from the culture of permanent excuses and the deferral of blame on our "forcedly racist" societies: this is precisely what prevents us from developing a sustainable cohesion policy. So there was no question for me of endorsing the irresponsible illusions of Terry Reintke, German Greens MP.

name: Hugues Bayet (S&D)
text: In writing. This report recalls the urgent need to support the socio-economic, societal and territorial integration of marginalized communities and the important role played by cohesion policy in this integration. It is now urgent to act proactively to enable the real integration of these communities by paying particular attention to the situation of children. I have obviously supported this report.

name: Beatriz Becerra Basterrechea (ALDE)
text: in writing. This initiative report is important as it provides solutions and ideas on the role cohesion policies can play in contributing to the inclusion of marginal communities.  Inclusion policies depend heavily on national, regional and local governments, and are therefore at the mercy of the political interest they arouse in the government on duty. In addition, the practice shows that aid is not always aimed at meeting the real needs of these communities. Cohesion policy, therefore, remains one of the strongest instruments with which the EU can combat marginalization while supporting territorial and social cohesion in the EU.

name: Joëlle Bergeron (EFDD)
text: In writing. I voted against the Reintke report. This report, written in an unbearable gibberish, on cohesion policy and marginalised communities is not the first report voted by this Parliament which over-blames Europeans for their alleged discriminatory policies towards "marginalized communities" such as Roma or Travellers. It is in the same vein as the dozens of others that preceded it. Nor will he be the last to glorify self-hatred and the perpetual repentance of us Europeans. The politically correct logorrheas that are unique to this Parliament have accustomed us to it and show - if it were still needed - that our Assembly and its representatives on the left are a thousand miles away from the real concerns of our citizens. I hope that one day a rapporteur in our Parliament will ask the 'marginalised communities' that they thank Europe for the moral, social and financial support they have often found there. Although I'm afraid that hope is science fiction.

name: Izaskun Bilbao Barandica (ALDE)
text: in writing. I voted in favour of this report and I thank the relevant Members of the various committees for their work. It is urgent to address the issue of marginalized communities and the important role of cohesion policy in supporting their economic, social and territorial inclusion. I was shadow rapporteur for my group in the Committee on Women's Rights and Gender Equality, where we work to alleviate the effects that women and girls have on these communities.

name: Dominique Bilde (ENF)
text: In writing. Once again, a report by the European Parliament that gives in the right feeling without worrying about people who are truly socially excluded. In the Reintke report, the REGI Committee seeks to improve the use of European funds - a laudable objective in itself - but to the main benefit of The Roma communities, who would be the main excluded in Europe. Suffice to say that there is no mention anywhere of the difficulties of social integration that can sometimes be encountered by people with disabilities or the homeless. In this text, the European Commission is called upon to adopt a European definition of these groups, to the detriment of the specific reality specific to each sovereign nation. Moreover, the priority seems to be the inclusion of migrants and asylum seekers without reporting for a moment those already in a situation of great social precariousness in Europe. Finally, the climax of inconsistency is reached in the proposal to award a European prize for dedication to the inclusion of marginalized groups: that the Union already learns to use the available funds effectively before awarding first prizes in morality. So I voted against this report.

name: Mara Bizzotto (ENF)
text: in writing. \u2012 Mrs Reintke's report proves to be partisan, unbalanced and completely unrelated to the social dynamics of the integration process that characterize countries such as Italy, where the Roma community does not make the slightest effort to integrate with the local communities that host them. For all these reasons, I voted against this text.

name: José Blanco López (S&D)
text: in writing. The legislative framework for cohesion policy ensures funding opportunities for marginalized communities in urban and rural areas. The 2014-2020 programming period is committed to the implementation of participatory local development and integrated territorial investments (ITIs) targeting marginalized communities.  With our vote in favour of the report, the Socialists call on the European Commission to adopt a definition of 'marginalized communities', which does not yet exist, with the aim of allowing these EU citizens to benefit even more from the European Structural and Investment Funds. The vote against paragraph 11 of the report is because that text assumes, through an erroneous and widespread approach, that the EU does not have structures for combating corruption and fraudulent use of funds (and existing ones are not responsible, transparent and democratic), and that marginalized communities are excluded from EU funds , which is the wrong assumption. The Socialists have always advocated maximum transparency in existing fund management structures and that marginalized communities continue to benefit from cohesion policy.

name: Vilija Blinkevičiūtė (S&D)
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted on this report because cohesion policy is one of the strongest instruments at the disposal of the European Union, which can help to combat inequalities and support territorial and social cohesion in its regions. Societies in all European countries have groups and communities that face structural exclusion and exclusion from most societies and have no access to even basic public infrastructure and services. In addition, they are very often disproportionately exposed to poverty, have no job and are faced with health disadvantages. The current problems of significant cuts in public spending in the Member States have exacerbated, for example, increased unemployment, lack of social protection, difficulties in finding housing and a shortage of public health services. As a result, the crisis has had a direct negative impact on members of marginalised communities. In addition, many municipalities continue to be subject to severe budgetary constraints which prevent them from adequately addressing the problem of social exclusion in society. In spite of everything, member states are mainly responsible for changing the situation of marginalised communities. Although specific national circumstances, needs and solutions vary greatly across Europe, europe is called for a role to play in the implementation of different policies, i.e. marginalised communities.

name: Andrea Bocskor (PPE)
text: Writing. \u2012 There is currently no EU-wide definition of marginalised communities and it is therefore for the Member States to decide on this through their national indicators. There are indicators that are closely linked to marginalisation, such as long-term high unemployment, low levels of education, extremely poor housing conditions, lack of access to healthcare and/or exposure to excessive health risks. The crisis has had a direct negative impact on marginalised communities, further increasing poverty and social exclusion. Cohesion policy plays an important role in supporting the economic, social and territorial integration of marginalised communities. The report raises a number of ideas that are useful for the integration of marginalised groups. It underlines that education and employment are the best antidote to poverty and that projects outside the school system and lifelong learning should therefore be encouraged. The report also stresses the importance of integrated housing, education and employment interventions and the need to improve access to public services. I voted in favour of this report in plenary.

name: Franc Bogovič (PPE)
text: Writing. I supported the proposed report because I agree with the observation that cohesion policy is one of the most powerful instruments available to the EU for greater social cohesion in its regions. Certain communities in our society face structural exclusion and separation from a majority society, often do not even have access to basic public infrastructure and services. They are also more vulnerable to poverty. Action at EU level is therefore essential, and we must follow the examples of good practices from individual countries and also draw attention to the responsibilities arising from so-called positive discrimination. In Slovenia, for example, we face a high level of unemployment in the Roma community, as this workforce is less competitive. Roma find it difficult to enter the labour market, and unfortunately they also reject work too often. The reason is the amount of remuneration, which is often lower than the social support they lose by taking labour.  I support positive discrimination for peripheral communities, which should be implemented primarily in the area and through European funds – structural, regional funds for infrastructure solutions and social funds in the field of health and education. It is essential that children from these communities also start with adequate education, because otherwise we will see another lost generation.

name: Biljana Borzan (S&D)
text: Written. I support the Cohesion Policy Report and marginalised communities. Cohesion Policy aims to reduce inequalities in the EU and calls for a European role to involve marginalised communities. Therefore, the desire is to stimulate the European Commission to present a definition of marginalised communities, which would allow all these EU citizens the opportunity to use the European Structural and Investment Funds embedded in EU cohesion policy.

name: Marie-Christine Boutonnet (ENF)
text: In writing. This report on cohesion policy and marginalised communities aims to encourage Member States and the Commission to create programmes for marginalized communities, mainly Roma. It also includes migrants and asylum seekers in the notion of a marginalized community. No programme will be able to assimilate Roma in the absence of a desire on their part to better integrate and to better respect the rules and customs of the States in which they reside. I therefore voted against this report, being opposed to the use of structural funds for programmes for Roma communities.

name: Renata Briano (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 The marginalisation of social groups – whether caused by different religious opinions or by outdated patriarchal conceptions, homophobia, racism, intolerance, economic discrimination or other causes – undermines social cohesion and the possibility of developing a community and also creates negative repercussions on security, economic recovery and the progress of the territories in which it is implemented. It is well documented that the marginalisation of social groups is also a cultural ground for fundamentalism, organised crime and political or religious terrorism. It is therefore desirable to launch EU projects with long-term funding and perspectives in order to deeply involve the target groups, increasing the effectiveness of the intervention and ensuring that the funds support investment in the real needs of the beneficiaries, with mechanisms to ensure that target groups are reached and that exclusion and marginalisation are addressed. These interventions cannot be separated from careful qualitative assessments and constant control mechanisms. Member States must be an active part in the processes of planning and evaluating funds used for marginalised communities, and their contribution is crucial to solving the key factors of social exclusion: housing exclusion, homelessness, exclusion from education and unemployment.

name: Steeve Briois (ENF)
text: In writing. According to the report, cohesion policy would not benefit marginalized communities sufficiently, which would not be integrated into decision-making structures or project implementation and monitoring. This would make these populations more vulnerable than they already would be. The rapporteur therefore wishes to encourage Member States and the Commission to create programmes for marginalized communities, mainly Roma. In concrete terms, the report proposes to provide funds for their social inclusion. In addition, the rapporteur recommends including marginalized communities in EU funds for the next programming period. No social inclusion programme for Roma will be successful in the absence of a desire on their part to better integrate and to better respect the rules and customs of the Member States of residence. We consider that the factors of the marginalisation of the Roma community are mainly to be sought in its refusal to assimilate into the dominant culture of the Member State of residence as well as in the commission of numerous violations of the laws of the Latter. So I voted against this report.

name: Daniel Buda (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 Cohesion policy is one of the most important instruments available to the European Union to combat inequality and to support territorial and social cohesion in its regions. An integrated approach is therefore needed to combat all types of discrimination faced by marginalised communities. The situation of marginalised communities has worsened with considerable cuts in public spending, generating an increased level of unemployment, poor delivery of basic public services for education, health and social security. Another negative factor that contributed to the increase in the level of poverty and social exclusion of marginalised groups was highlighted following the evaluation of projects from the previous programming period. Thus, it has been shown that, in most cases, funding has not been explicitly used to meet the needs of the target groups, with the implementation of projects being superficial, without the expected results. This report therefore emphasises the importance of taking Member States' responsibility for improving the situation of marginalised communities and provides recommendations on how to overcome the problems encountered in the previous programming period, which is why I voted in favour of this report.

name: Gianluca Buonanno (ENF)
text: in writing. \u2012 The report focuses mainly on the Roma community which, according to the rapporteur, is very often marginalised, a victim of racism and calls for efforts and commitments to improve its living conditions.  Urges and calls for greater coordination and stronger links between national strategies for marginalised communities, including national Roma inclusion strategies, national poverty reduction strategies, strategies for the inclusion of other marginalised or less favoured communities, and gender equality strategies with cohesion policy, and calls on Member States and the Commission to give priority to children in implementing the EU framework for national Roma integration strategies , and reiterates the importance of promoting equal access to housing, health, education and decent living conditions for children (Roma).  It refers to the fact that housing exclusion, homelessness, exclusion from education and unemployment are often key elements of the phenomenon of marginalisation; stresses, therefore, the importance of integrated housing, education and employment measures for marginalised communities. There is a surplus to vote against.

name: Cristian-Silviu Buşoi (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 There are communities and groups across all European societies that face structural exclusion and are marginalised by much of society, lacking access to basic public infrastructure and services. Poverty, unemployment and poor health conditions often disproportionately affect these communities. There is no uniform definition of marginalised communities at EU level, but the term covers a wide range of concepts: disadvantaged neighbourhoods, the most deprived or those with material deprivation, people at risk of poverty and groups in society who are disadvantaged and discriminated against. The concept of marginalised communities was introduced in the ERDF Regulation in 2013, with the aim of combating the consequences of marginalisation. I believe that the EU has a responsibility to pursue and achieve this objective on a permanent basis. I support the EP resolution motion on cohesion policy and marginalised communities, because EU cohesion policy is one of the strongest tools for combating inequalities and supporting territorial and social cohesion. I also believe that an integrated approach is needed to combat all types of discrimination faced by marginalised communities.

name: Soledad Cabezón Ruiz (S&D)
text: in writing. The legislative framework for cohesion policy ensures funding opportunities for marginalized communities in urban and rural areas. The 2014-2020 programming period is committed to the implementation of participatory local development and integrated territorial investments (ITIs) targeting marginalized communities.  With our vote in favour of the report, the Socialists call on the European Commission to adopt a definition of 'marginalized communities', which does not yet exist, with the aim of allowing these EU citizens to benefit even more from the European Structural and Investment Funds. The vote against paragraph 11 of the report is because that text assumes, through an erroneous and widespread approach, that the EU does not have structures for combating corruption and fraudulent use of funds (and existing ones are not responsible, transparent and democratic), and that marginalized communities are excluded from EU funds , which is the wrong assumption. The Socialists have always advocated maximum transparency in existing fund management structures and that marginalized communities continue to benefit from cohesion policy.

name: Nicola Caputo (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted today in favour of the report on cohesion policy and marginalised communities. Cohesion policy aims to strengthen economic, social and territorial cohesion by reducing social inequalities, and therefore has a link with reducing the exclusion of the most marginalised communities as well as groups and individuals of all ages facing poverty and social exclusion. The report stressed the importance of this role of cohesion policy, pointing out that marginalised communities have been introduced as a topic at the heart of cohesion policy measures due to growing concern about social exclusion and commitment to combating it. The legislative framework for cohesion policy 2014-2020 has introduced new elements that extend funding possibilities for marginalised communities. However, the Commission should provide more information on the use of these funds, as well as provide guidance on the definition of marginalised communities, so as to strengthen the effectiveness of cohesion policy. The text contained all these elements, and I have therefore chosen to vote in favour of it.

name: Matt Carthy (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. ‒ Cohesion policy is one of the strongest instruments the European Union has to fight inequality. This report builds on that, by looking specifically at how the cohesion policy can assist in empowering marginalised communities. Although there is no uniform EU definition of marginalised communities, my Sinn Féin colleague Martina Anderson from the Regional Development Committee ensured that the report acknowledged that people in cross-border, rural and isolated areas are often subject to marginalisation due to their geographical situation and should be better taken into consideration by the cohesion policy. The report also acknowledges the needs of women, people with disabilities, migrants, Roma and Travellers, and highlights the importance of an integrated, grass-roots, community-led and inclusive approach to solving the problems faced by these communities.

name: David Casa (PPE)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of this report because there still exist communities, such as the Roma, that experience exclusion and segregation within our society and we need to increase our efforts in helping them to integrate better. I agree that the cohesion policy, despite the recent cuts in public spending, is a very good way of improving the participation of the disadvantaged in our society.

name: Fabio Massimo Castaldo (EFDD)
text: in writing. \u2012 The report addresses the current issue of marginalised communities and the funding they receive through the Structural Funds. The report is very good and, among the particularly worthy aspects, it should be remembered that the budget cuts for public services made in some Member States as a result of the crisis have had the effect of increasing unemployment, worsening social security and, in general, causing the worsening of already difficult situations in terms of housing and health. The result has been an aggravation of the situation for all marginalised and in a situation of serious need. I voted strongly in favour of this report.

name: Nessa Childers (S&D)
text: in writing. – This vote represents a great step towards a change in the way we perceive the use of EU structural funds. Too often, these were spent on infrastructure. Yet we see that if these resources are spent properly to counter the impact of the economic crisis, they can be powerful in their contribution to fight poverty, unemployment and social exclusion, especially at a time when austerity is affecting the most poor and vulnerable. This report rightly emphasises the need to strengthen the role of local authorities and communities to build life-long programmes, to engage with local communities, with appropriate Member State and Commission support. A lack of definition of marginalised communities under the EU Treaties often entails their exclusion from social cohesion policies, because they are not consulted in the process. As a consequence, Roma and traveller communities lose out when these policy tools target discrimination and material deprivation. That is why we urge the Commission to come up with a definition, as a starting point to better tackling social inequalities with EU social policy.

name: Caterina Chinnici (S&D)
