text: in writing. \u2012 Social exclusion is a widespread phenomenon in all Eu ropean Union states; the impoverishment of the middle class, austerity policies, welfare cuts and the difficulty of integrating ethnic minorities into our societies are all factors that contribute to creating marginalised communities, a concept first introduced into cohesion policy by the 2013 ERDF Regulation with the clear aim of promoting their social inclusion. In the coming years, growth and economic recovery are unlikely to reduce the social gap created by the effects of the crisis, which is why the economic instruments available will have to meet the needs of those left on the margins of society. In this scenario, regional policy has an important role to play in supporting real socio-economic cohesion. However, there is a lack of clear guidelines on the actions to be taken. I hope that the Commission will take on the demands made by Parliament for indicators and instruments to be defined to monitor the impact of cohesion policy on marginalised communities and to be involved in the bottom-up phase of the programming of funds in order to identify and define the actions necessary to reduce their discomfort and facilitate their integration. These are the reasons why I voted in favour of this report.

name: Λευτέρης Χριστοφόρου (
text: PPE), in writing. Cohesion policy is one of the strongest tools available to the European Union to combat inequality and support territorial and social cohesion in its regions. In all European societies there are groups and communities that face structural exclusion and separation from the majority of society, and do not even have access to basic infrastructure and services. Beyond that, they are all too often disproportionately affected by poverty, unemployment and health problems. Important report and important issues are being considered.

name: Κώστας Χρυσόγονος (
text: GUE/NGL), in writing. Cohesion policy is a powerful tool of the European Union to reduce inequalities within the regions of the Union and to strengthen economic, social and territorial cohesion. This tool is proving particularly useful for marginalised communities, i.e. for different groups and individuals who are socially excluded and systematically prevented from participating in social and political processes, such as people with disabilities, people living below the poverty line or at risk of poverty, migrants, refugees and others.  The report calls on the Commission to broaden the financial opportunities to support marginalised communities and to ensure that these groups are involved in the overall process, while at the same time highlighting the importance of implementing cohesion policy to tackle poverty and excluding the various marginalised communities.  Particular emphasis is made in the report on the role played by disastrous austerity policies in strengthening the marginalisation of certain social groups and calls for the human rights dimension to be taken into account when planning actions supported by cohesion funds.  For all these reasons I voted in favour of the report.

name: Salvatore Cicu (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of this report. Cohesion policy is one of the strongest instruments available to the European Union to combat inequalities and support territorial and social cohesion in its regions. In all European societies there are groups and communities, such as the Roma community, that address structural marginalisation and segregation from most of society and do not have access to public infrastructure and services, including basic infrastructure and services. In addition, they are very often affected by poverty, unemployment and poor health conditions. The reductions in public expenditure, as a result of the crisis, have led to an aggravation of the problems existing in the Member States, such as unemployment, the lack of social security, a difficult housing situation and the lack of public health services. As a result, the crisis has had a direct negative impact on members of marginalised communities. In addition, many municipalities continue to face severe budgetary constraints which prevent them from adequately addressing the problem of marginalisation in society. Despite differences between Member States and specific circumstances at national level, the objective of social cohesion requires a European role in policies for the inclusion of marginalised communities.

name: Alberto Cirio (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of Terry Reintke's report on the integration of marginalised communities. Cohesion policy is one of the strongest instruments available to the EU to combat inequalities and support territorial and social cohesion in its regions. Heavy reductions in public spending during the crisis have led, in addition to social problems for the inhabitants of the states themselves, to problems in the management of what are marginalised communities. I believe that social cohesion is a basic objective for the EU and we must not ignore this. It is important, as far as possible, to give importance to cohesion policy by finding mechanisms for assessing the quality and control of marginalised communities. In my opinion, there is a need for a transition to quality control so that interventions lead to long-term and sustainable results.

name: David Coburn (EFDD)
text: in writing. ‒ We abstained on this vote due to the sensitivity of the issue at hand. UKIP does not believe that the Commission should be creating overarching integrating schemes at all. But we also recognise that ostracising marginalised communities that come from disadvantaged backgrounds is also a negative thing. Therefore we decided to abstain.

name: Carlos Coelho (PPE)
text: in writing. The EU's cohesion policy aims to strengthen economic, social and territorial cohesion by reducing social disparities and situations of poverty and exclusion, which involves preventing segregation and promoting equal access and opportunities for all citizens, including the most marginalised communities. The effects of the economic crisis and austerity measures have reduced the availability of municipalities and entities providing treatment and assistance to the most marginalised groups, and may increase their exclusion when they are denied or refused participation in social and political processes essential to their social integration. I support the Reintke Report because it considers the use of Union Funds to include these communities to be important, and the suggested recommendations are an opportunity to promote and support greater cohesion of the different European societies.

name: Jane Collins (EFDD)
text: in writing. – We abstained on this vote due to the sensitivity of the issue at hand. UKIP does not believe that the Commission should be creating overarching integrating schemes at all. But we also recognise that ostracising marginalised communities that come from disadvantaged backgrounds is also a negative thing. Therefore we decided to abstain.

name: Lara Comi (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 The concept of marginalised communities was introduced into the ERDF Regulation in 2013, with the aim of combating the consequences of marginalisation affecting individuals and communities, such as linguistic and religious minorities, migrants, refugees, people with disabilities and the elderly. Marginalisation in this case means that, systematically, these people are excluded from social and political processes, or that they do not have access to basic infrastructure and public services. The task of cohesion policy is precisely to intervene in discrimination and try to change the situation, first of all by extending the possibility of funding also to actions and projects aimed at supporting marginalised communities, improving access to public services, setting up responsible, transparent and democratic structures and encouraging Member States to use the ESF to support projects for informal and lifelong learning. , as well as cultural and innovative projects.

name: Therese Comodini Cachia (PPE)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of this report. The cohesion policy of the EU seeks to address disparities experienced by marginalised communities. The report calls for attention to be given to children and women, and for measures to be implemented to address the disadvantages that specifically affect children and women. Member States are also encouraged to use the funds at their disposal in a way that effectively addresses the challenges of social inclusion, poverty and discrimination, including in a manner which is meaningful to the marginalised communities themselves.

name: Ignazio Corrao (EFDD)
text: in writing. \u2012 The report highlights how the economic crisis and budget cuts have worsened the social situation, causing difficult housing and health situations. It should be pointed out that the European Regional Development Fund and the European Social Fund play a specific and important role, with at least 20% of the ESF allocated in each Member State to the specific objective of promoting social inclusion and combating poverty and all forms of discrimination, thus being a crucial instrument in promoting greater inclusion of marginalised communities. Cohesion policy, it is stressed, can and must be an added value to the work already under way in the Member States. By focusing on improving employment opportunities, participation in society and investment in skills, especially in the regions that need them most, cohesion policy should ideally lead, among other benefits, to greater social inclusion and poverty reduction, providing Member States with the appropriate flexibility to implement individualised support in line with local needs and to ensure that funding is used in areas where unemployment is highest and where funding is more necessary. For these reasons, I am voting in favour.

name: Javier Couso Permuy (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. I voted in favour of this report as it contains positive elements for the effective implementation, through cohesion policy, of the principle of non-discrimination contained in the Treaties. In this regard, the text calls on the European Commission to clarify the concept of marginalized communities; stresses that cuts in public services further complicate the situation of vulnerable groups; visibilizes existing racism and institutional discrimination towards communities such as Roma; calls for Member States to ensure the participation of partnerships working with marginalized communities as well; denounces the multiple discrimination against women, people with disabilities and migrants found in marginalized communities, among other groups. Therefore, and although the report is exclusively pro propositional, I voted in favour.

name: Andrea Cozzolino (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 Provide as soon as possible a precise and, more comprehensive, definition of "marginalised communities" and promote a process of protection and integration, aimed at promoting their integration into the European social fabric. At European level, there is no comprehensive definition of a 'marginalised community'. The first step, therefore, is to understand the phenomenon of marginalization by analysing its specific characteristics. It is appropriate to examine the typical and specific situations and needs of different realities and to assess living and working conditions, access to education and health care systems, level of employment and early school leaving. In this scenario, Europe's task is to establish a set of common indicators that will allow us to reconstruct the concept of 'marginalised community' in a uniform and shared way. Cohesion policy thus becomes a driving force for development by supporting the economic, social and territorial inclusion of minorities. The next step is to extend these measures to all minorities that are currently excluded, so that the process of breaking down moral and material boundaries can be implemented. To do this, we need a shared strategy that starts from the common elaboration of the concept of 'marginalised community' in order to arrive at measures that reduce the distance of diversity in the name of equality, formal and substantial.

name: Pál Csáky (PPE)
text: Writing. \u2012 Cohesion policy is one of the EU's strongest tools for strengthening territorial and social cohesion within regions and combating inequalities. Cohesion policy is particularly important for the Member States of Eastern and Central Europe. The fate of groups on the edge of society is made even more difficult by poverty and unemployment. The austerity imposed as a result of the housing crisis exacerbates the difficulties faced by these groups in society. It is the responsibility of the Member States to manage the situation of marginalised communities, but nevertheless the EU must play an important role in this area. However, the opportunities offered by the EU must be best exploited in the Member States in order to ensure that aid is actually delivered to regions in need, without discrimination. I voted in favour of the parliamentary report.

name: Edward Czesak (ECR)
text: I would like to write to the Commission. \u2012 I am aware that the marginalisation of certain social groups is a complex problem, often due to factors other than discrimination. Regardless of the causes of occurrence, this phenomenon cannot be underestimated. Preserving the status quo, i.e. leaving the issue of marginalised communities to local politics without additional financial support, is a short-sighted solution, leading only to a deepening of the problem. It should be borne in mind that, according to criminological studies, factors such as housing, educational exclusion, unemployment and poverty create favourable conditions for demoralisation and pathological behaviour, and often result in high rates of crime among those subjected to these factors. Trying to help and, above all, educate people from marginalised communities will bring mutual benefits, both for them and for society as a whole. I am aware that people in marginalised groups are often unwilving to try to activate them on the labour market and change their habits to live with social benefits. However, this should not be an argument for not trying to help such people function normally in society. A particularly important point of the resolution for me is the call for national poverty reduction strategies to be linked to cohesion policy, which should result in a common strategy at EU level to reduce poverty, unemployment, the exclusion of young people, children and people with disabilities, not only among marginalised groups, but within society as a whole.

name: Miriam Dalli (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ This own-initiative report focuses on putting forward suggestions in order to help address the needs of marginalised communities within cohesion policy. One such suggestion is to specifically define the concept of ʽmarginalised communitiesʼ so that EU citizens falling within this category can benefit from the European Structural and Investment Funds embedded within EU cohesion policy. Marginalised communities face challenges which arise from this reality and for this reason I voted in favour of this own-initiative report.

name: Rosa D'Amato (EFDD)
text: in writing. \u2012 As shadow rapporteur for this report and having been able to contribute actively to its development, my vote can only be positive. Among the things that have particularly pleased me is the analysis of the phenomenon of marginalisation. Marginalisation should be assessed by analysing a number of indicators such as social exclusion, high unemployment, low education, poor housing conditions, a high level of discrimination, excessive exposure to health risks or lack of access to health care.  The tragic events of recent weeks only confirm the importance of measures to reduce those inequalities and conditions of cultural, social and economic isolation which in many cases are one of the predisposing factors of radicalisation and crime. Cohesion policy is of fundamental importance in this respect. We cannot afford, as we have repeatedly pointed out, that, precisely where austerity measures have hit the most, cohesion policy funds are not being used or are being used with projects of dubious use. The quantity and quality of projects and the real application of the partnership principle matter, now more than ever, if we do not want the cohesion objectives to become just empty declarations of intent with no practical effect on our regions.

name: Viorica Dăncilă (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 I would like to stress the important role that social entrepreneurship, cooperatives, mutual aid houses and alternative enterprises can play in empowering women in marginalised communities, and I believe that cohesion funds, in particular the European Social Fund, must support investment in this area with a strong gender perspective.

name: Michel Dantin (PPE)
text: In writing. This initiative report proposes a series of measures to support marginalized communities through the mobilization of the instrument of social cohesion. Every European society has groups and communities, victims of structural exclusion and segregation and who do not have access to the most basic public infrastructure and services. Cohesion policy is one of the EU's main instruments to combat these inequalities and support territorial and social cohesion in its regions. In support of these objectives, I voted in favour of the report.

name: Rachida Dati (PPE)
text: In writing. I voted in favour of this report on cohesion policy and marginalized communities. Cohesion policy is indeed one of the Union's instruments for combating, in parallel with national policies, in a relevant way against inequalities and the marginalisation of certain communities.

name: Isabella De Monte (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 Cohesion policy is one of the strongest instruments available to the European Union to combat inequalities. In all European societies there are groups and communities that do not have access to basic infrastructure and public services and are very often affected by poverty, unemployment and poor health. Heavy reductions in public spending during the crisis have led to an aggravation of the problems existing in the Member States, negatively and directly affecting members of marginalised communities. I voted in favour of this report because I believe that, despite the specific circumstances, national needs and solutions vary considerably across Europe. In addition, the objective of social cohesion requires a European role in policies for the inclusion of marginalised communities, as well as an integrated approach in order to respond to all different forms of discrimination.

name: Andor Deli (PPE)
text: Writing. \u2012 There is currently no EU-wide definition of marginalised communities and it is therefore for the Member States to decide on this through their national indicators. There are indicators that are closely linked to marginalisation, such as long-term high unemployment, low levels of education, extremely poor housing conditions, lack of access to healthcare and/or exposure to excessive health risks. The crisis has had a direct negative impact on marginalised communities, further increasing poverty and social exclusion. Cohesion policy plays an important role in supporting the economic, social and territorial integration of marginalised communities. The report raises a number of ideas that are useful for the integration of marginalised groups. It underlines that education and employment are the best antidote to poverty and that projects outside the school system and lifelong learning should therefore be encouraged. Furthermore, the report stresses the importance of integrated housing, education and employment interventions and the need to improve access to public services. I voted in favour of this report in plenary.

name: Mireille D'Ornano (ENF)
text: In writing. This report on marginalized communities aims to improve the use of EU funds, as part of cohesion policy, by promoting the social inclusion of marginalized communities. By favouring Roma and migrants, but also by wanting to award an award to docile and lax countries on immigration, this report is totally disconnected from the reality and concerns of the peoples of Europe. The security and safety problems posed by the constant and inordinate installation of illegal immigrants are important enough that the European Union does not have to spend more in order to make them dream of an integration process that will never succeed. Opposed to the subsidy of mass immigration and the flight of public spending, I therefore voted against this report.

name: Ian Duncan (ECR)
text: in writing. ‒ Although I can support some positive elements of this report, such as the call for more detailed information on ESIF take-up (para 5), the horizontal principles of quality and non-discrimination (para 8) and support for training and SMEs (para 46), I reject the call for Commission guidance on an EU-wide definition of marginalised communities and the suggestion that it is the EU’s responsibility to tackle social disparities, poverty and exclusion in Member States. Social, health, employment, education and housing and planning policies are areas of Member State competence and should remain so. I would also contest the suggestion in this report that measures to tackle Member State economic deficits have had a purely negative impact on marginalised communities and fiscally—responsible measures to reduce public spending following the economic crisis led to higher unemployment, a lack of social security and housing and health problems.  An explanation of vote will be provided and roll call, separate votes used to highlight aspects of the report that the UK delegation can support.

name: Ангел Джамбазки (ECR)
text: in writing. \u2012 I cannot support and have never supported policies based on the presumption of privilege. This report calls for just that – give more to the marginals. And what is the effect – none. You've practically proved yourself for so many years. There will be no cohesion policy as long as it repeats itself: racism, xenophobia, sexism are to blame. These are mantras and spells. Why doesn't anyone say that marginal communities themselves are massively resisting and insisting on receiving generous sums but living as they know it. When will we recognize that this model of integration is impossible? When are we going to admit that what they've been pushing us for so many years has failed? I urge you to stop this hypocrisy. The outpouring of hundreds of millions into nothing-bearing programs changed nothing. This policy of tolerance and reconciliation is untenable. I do not support such policies that promote social parasitism. That's exactly what this report suggests. No thank you.

name: Γεώργιος Επιτήδειος (
text: NI), in writing. \u2012 This report supports the participation of women belonging to ethnic minorities, immigrants, refugees, mainly Roma, etc., in all EU-funded programmes, initiatives and actions; On the basis of the above, we are voting against the report as the rights and values of European citizens are being flattened in relation to minorities and immigrants, who espouse different cultures.

name: Bill Etheridge (EFDD)
text: in writing. – We abstained on this vote due to the sensitivity of the issue at hand. UKIP does not believe that the Commission should be creating overarching integrating schemes at all. But we also recognise that ostracising marginalised communities that come from disadvantaged backgrounds is also a negative thing. Therefore we decided to abstain.

name: José Manuel Fernandes (PPE)
text: in writing. The use of EU funds for the inclusion of marginalised communities can become a great opportunity to promote and support greater cohesion of European societies. Cohesion policy is one of the strongest instruments that the European Union has at its disposal to combat inequalities and support territorial and social cohesion in its regions. In all European societies there are groups and communities that face structural exclusion and segregation of the majority of society and do not even have access to basic public infrastructure and services. However, in many cases, marginalised communities do not benefit from European cohesion policy and are not included in decision-making structures or project implementation and monitoring processes. I voted in favour.

name: Jonás Fernández (S&D)
text: in writing. The legislative framework for cohesion policy ensures funding opportunities for marginalized communities in urban and rural areas. The 2014-2020 programming period is committed to the implementation of participatory local development and integrated territorial investments (ITIs) targeting marginalized communities.  With our vote in favour of the report, the Socialists call on the European Commission to adopt a definition of 'marginalized communities', which does not yet exist, with the aim of allowing these EU citizens to benefit even more from the European Structural and Investment Funds. The vote against paragraph 11 of the report is because that text assumes, through an erroneous and widespread approach, that the EU does not have structures for combating corruption and fraudulent use of funds (and existing ones are not responsible, transparent and democratic), and that marginalized communities are excluded from EU funds , which is the wrong assumption. The Socialists have always advocated maximum transparency in existing fund management structures and that marginalized communities continue to benefit from cohesion policy.

name: Edouard Ferrand (ENF)
text: In writing. I voted against this deliberation because it does not require the people concerned to integrate into our way of life.

name: Laura Ferrara (EFDD)
text: in writing. \u2012 As legislators we have a duty to keep our eyes peeled in the face of situations of poverty and discrimination that reduce some communities in our society to marginalization. This situation runs counter to the fundamental principle of human dignity, the cornerstone of the Charter of Fundamental Rights of the European Union, which we are called upon to respect and guarantee. The austerity policies of recent years have even worsened the situation in many countries of the Union. The European Union has a duty to change course and to use all the resources at its disposal, starting with cohesion policies, to combat poverty and marginalisation. This includes the need to establish, at European level, that is to say in every State of the Union, a minimum income of citizenship, which restores dignity and dignity to the life of every citizen without work and without the minimum means of subsistence.

name: João Ferreira (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. The report calls for greater use of EU cohesion funds to support marginalised communities. Such support would be provided through the promotion and development of public health, education and social security services, the promotion of employability, cultural inclusion, gender equality and the participation of these communities in the definition of policies that affect them (political inclusion, participation and partnerships with representative organisations). We generally support the report and its objectives, despite some shortcomings and limitations. The big issue – which the report does not highlight – is the smallness of the EU budget with regard to cohesion, alongside the dynamics of divergence that the capitalist nature of the integration process generates and drives. More than two decades ago, the then President of the European Commission, Jacques Delors, said that in order to effectively comply with the principle of cohesion, the Community budget would have to at least double. Since then, successive enlargements have taken place (to countries with below-eu levels of development), while the budget has always been shrinking. No eggs, no omelets. Thus, cohesion will be nothing more than dead letter in the treaties. And in well-meaning reports like this.

name: Raffaele Fitto (ECR)
text: in writing. \u2012 Considering Mrs Reintke's following report, I believe that we need a policy of cohesion and integration of marginalised communities. However, the proposal includes mechanisms for implementing programmes with potential costs associated at European level, as well as mandatory application of the partnership principle by the Member States, which is why I voted against it.

name: Monika Flašíková Beňová (S&D)
text: Writing. \u2012 Cohesion Policy is an important instrument and has an important role to play in the European Union. The main responsibility for the situation of marginalised communities, which often face exclusion and segregation in majority society, lies with the Member States. Nevertheless, I believe that the objective of social cohesion requires an EU-wide approach to a policy aimed at integrating marginalised communities. In particular, it is an integrated approach to addressing the differentiated forms of discrimination faced by these communities. They must be included in decision-making structures as well as in the process of implementing and monitoring projects. Nato is fundamentally affected by the proper implementation of the Code of Conduct for Partnership.

name: Lorenzo Fontana (ENF)
text: in writing. \u2012 This noblely titled report has obviously ended up becoming yet another politicised report that focuses obsessively on behalf of the Roma.

name: Λάμπρος Φουντούλης (NI)
text: Writing. \u2012 This report supports the participation of women belonging to ethnic minorities, immigrants, refugees, mainly Roma, etc., in all EU-funded programmes, initiatives and actions; On the basis of the above, I am voting against the report as the rights and values of European citizens are being flattened in relation to minorities and immigrants who espouse different cultures.

name: Doru-Claudian Frunzulică (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ Cohesion policy is a way of bringing regions closer to the Union and to ensure solidarity between Member States. Its implementation must tackle the crucial challenge of poverty and exclusion of young people and children, adults and people with disabilities. I believe that, in order to reduce disparities in the EU, we absolutely have to call for a European role in policies for the inclusion of marginalised communities. The Commission must come up with a definition of marginalised communities in order to allow all these EU citizens to benefit from the European Structural and Investment Funds embedded in the EU cohesion policy. I would like to express my strong support to the reference, in the text, to the need to fight ‘anti-Gypsyism’, as the Roma people are one of the most socially excluded communities. The Commission should provide detailed information about the take-up of funding opportunities for marginalised communities and develop an analysis that allows the drawing of appropriate conclusions and the identification of obstacles that might prevent further take-up.

text: Writing. Cohesion policy is one of the Most Effective Tools of the European Union in combating inequalities and supporting territorial and social cohesion in different regions. In addition, in many cases they are characterised by disproportionate poverty, unemployment and poor health. Cohesion policy can play a very effective role in changing these circumstances.  In my opinion, it is clear from the above that there is a need for quality evaluation and monitoring mechanisms. A shift towards quality supervision is needed in order to ensure that interventions deliver long-term and sustainable results.

name: Francesc Gambús (PPE)
text: in writing. I voted in favour of the motion for a resolution convinced that cohesion policy is one of the most effective instruments available to the European Union to combat inequality and promote territorial and social cohesion in its regions, with particular attention to groups and communities suffering from structural exclusion. There is no doubt that cohesion policy can be an essential element in changing this reality.

name: Elena Gentile (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the European Parliament resolution on cohesion policy and marginalised communities because I supported the request to the Commission for a precise and shared definition, allowing dedicated measures to be included in the next programming, while promoting clarity of scope and rationalisation of measures, also taking into account those already provided for by the ESF. In fact, new developments are already envisaged in the legislative framework for the Structural and Investment Funds. They include, for example, the fund to combat social exclusion and promote poverty reduction, to which Member States must reserve at least 20% of the entire ESF amount. According to Commission data, Member States have already allocated 25.6% of the entire ESF amount (€21 billion) to measures to combat social exclusion, including measures in favour of Roma communities.  The promotion of social inclusion and the fight against poverty and discrimination are one of the eleven thematic objectives of EFSI. According to this goal, marginalized communities can receive support through a dedicated priority investment. Therefore, states need to do more than already planned (EUR 1.5 billion) under this priority.

name: Arne Gericke (ECR)
text: Writing. I voted against the non-legislative own-initiative report on cohesion policy and marginalised social groups today, as such a document makes no sense when it appears less than a year after all the EU's long-standing financial plans have been set. In addition, the report sets the wrong tone on many points: the EU cannot and must not try to solve everything by gaining more and more power. Many problems, particularly in cohesion policy, call for adapted rules at national, regional and local level. That is subsidiarity.

name: Jens Gieseke (PPE)
text: Writing. Cohesion policy is one of the most important European instruments for reducing social inequalities in different regions of Europe. The problem of social exclusion has increased in the wake of the economic crisis. It is unacceptable that individual population groups still do not have sufficient access to existing infrastructure and sanitation. I therefore welcome the fact that this report advocates greater social cohesion.

name: Neena Gill (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ Together with my EPLP colleagues I voted in favour of this report as I believe that the EU cohesion policy can be a powerful tool in addressing problems that marginalised communities face, such as unemployment, difficult housing conditions, low access to public services, notably health services, multiple forms of discrimination and social, cultural and economic exclusion and similar issues. I particularly welcome the report’s call for more and genuine involvement of representatives of marginalised communities in the development, implementation and management of EU funds and projects in this field, as I strongly believe that programmes and policies are most effective when those concerned are actually involved in the decision-making and management processes.

name: Juan Carlos Girauta Vidal (ALDE)
text: in writing. ‒ Cohesion policy is one of the strongest EU instruments to fight inequality and support economic, social and territorial cohesion in its regions. I supported today this report that sets up recommendations on how to use EU structural funds for a better inclusion of  marginalised communities in view of the future cohesion policy programming period, while taking into account the specific national and regional needs and solutions that vary across Europe.

name: Michela Giuffrida (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of this report because the fundamental objective of cohesion policy is to remove obstacles in order to ensure that all regions and territories of Europe grow and develop. In the same way, territorial cohesion cannot ignore social cohesion. The Structural Funds must fall fully into the contexts in which they act to reduce inequalities. The involvement of all parties in the definition of programming objectives is fundamental.

name: Sylvie Goddyn (ENF)
text: In writing. This report illustrates a constant drift in the European Union's cohesion policy. Originally designed to improve economic, social and territorial cohesion within the Union, cohesion policy tends to divert the European Regional Development Fund (ERDF) and the European Social Fund (ESF) from their goals. These funds are increasingly being used to meet the needs of so-called marginalized communities, but not all of them actually fit that definition. Indeed, by marginalized communities, the rapporteur mainly mentions Roma and migrants. It is therefore a matter of once again spending public money, without asking for reciprocity from the people who are helped. Assimilation and compliance with the law are not among the European Union's priorities vis-à-vis Roma as well as migrants. In the end, what is most deplorable about this report is that genuinely marginalized communities, such as the disabled, the homeless or the unemployed, are victims of the priority given by the European Union and the Member States to Roma and migrants.

name: Tania González Peñas (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. We voted in favour of this report aimed at increasing the social protection of minorities in Europe because we understand that all policies aimed at increasing social cohesion are positive, recognising the very existence of minorities and putting in place measures to improve the living conditions of the millions of people currently living at risk of social exclusion.

name: Sylvie Guillaume (S&D)
text: In writing. Cohesion policy is crucial in terms of social integration, which is why I voted in favour of this initiative report which reflects my concerns about the lack of integration of communities living on the margins of society. This is a reminder that the key challenges of this cohesion policy are in particular to combat poverty and exclusion of young people, adults and people with disabilities. It is with this in mind that we call on the European Commission to take measures to facilitate the inclusion of marginalized communities in the development, implementation and evaluation of projects as an instrument for the emancipation of the communities concerned. We also stress the importance of implementing urban renewal and rehabilitation programs for disadvantaged neighbourhoods. In addition, we call on Member States to develop a disease prevention strategy for marginalized communities. Finally, I supported the inclusion in this report of anti-Roma discrimination as part of a systematic exclusionary process, with Roma remaining one of the most marginalized groups in Europe.

name: Antanas Guoga (ALDE)
text: in writing. ‒ I have voted for the report on cohesion policy and marginalised communities because the economic crisis has increased poverty and social exclusion in the regions and we should combat that with cohesion policy which is aimed at enhancing economic, social and territorial cohesion, reducing social disparities, including the reduction and eradication of poverty and exclusion, which calls for the prevention of segregation and for the promotion of equal access and opportunities for all citizens, including the most marginalised communities as well as groups and individuals of all ages facing poverty and social exclusion and lacking access to education, employment, housing and healthcare systems.

name: Τάκης Χατζηγεωργίου (
text: GUE/NGL), in writing. \u2012 This is a fairly in-depth report that adequately analyses the issue of marginalised communities. The reference to marginalisation as a social phenomenon stemming from economic inequalities within societies and exacerbated by budget cuts and austerity measures puts the issue on the right track. The report also proposes a number of social measures and generally has a socially oriented understanding of how to tackle social inequalities. There are no particularly negative elements in the report although there are some contradictions. Because of the fairly satisfactory analysis and the proposed measures, we are voting in favour of the report.

name: Marian Harkin (ALDE)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of the Cohesion Policy and Marginalised Communities report as I believe cohesion policy is a powerful tool in tackling the existing problems of marginalised communities. While the inclusion of marginalised communities mostly depends on the strong political will of local and national authorities on the ground, the EU cohesion policy remains one of the strongest instruments with which the EU can fight different types of marginalisation inside Member States and support territorial and social cohesion in EU regions.  The existing problems of unemployment, absence of social security, difficult housing situations and lack of public health services, just to name a few, continue to be faced by many municipalities alongside with the severe budgetary constraints which prevent them from dealing adequately with marginalisation in society. In the past, EU structural funds have not always taken full account of these communities. The current 2014-2020 cohesion framework puts forward new measures with the scope of improving the situation of such groups, including investment priority targeting marginalised communities.

name: Brian Hayes (PPE)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted for this report as while specific national circumstances, needs and solutions vary greatly across Europe, the aim of social cohesion calls for a European role in policies for the inclusion of marginalised communities. Cohesion policy is one of the strongest instruments the European Union has at its disposal with which to fight inequality and support territorial and social cohesion in its regions. The crisis has had a direct negative impact on members of marginalised communities, leaving many groups and communities without access to basic public infrastructure and services.

name: Roger Helmer (EFDD)
text: in writing. ‒ We abstained on this vote due to the sensitivity of the issue at hand. UKIP does not believe that the Commission should be creating overarching integrating schemes at all. But we also recognise that ostracising marginalised communities that come from disadvantaged backgrounds is also a negative thing. Therefore we decided to abstain.

name: Hans-Olaf Henkel (ECR)
text: Writing. The own-initiative report recommends changes within the framework of EU cohesion policy. This EU policy area accounts for more than a third of the total EU budget and aims to reduce economic and social inequalities in Europe, thereby strengthening social cohesion. The report calls for even greater attention to be paid to supporting marginalised communities in society, in particular Roma communities and the needs of women. Thus, there is still no uniform definition of marginalised social groups, and in particular in the case of so-called partnership agreements, too little attention is given to the needs of these marginalised groups. As the report itself points out, the legal bases on cohesion policy already set out a number of requirements for supporting marginalised social groups. In line with the principle of subsidiarity, it is up to eu Member States to implement these requirements within the framework of operational programmes. Further centralised regulation is not necessary, as it would unduly influence the policies of the individual EU Member States and create further bureaucratic hurdles for approving projects. I have therefore voted against the report. Incidentally, I believe that the euro must be abolished because it leads to strife and discord in Europe!

name: György Hölvényi (PPE)
text: Writing. \u2012 There is currently no EU-wide definition of marginalised communities and it is therefore for the Member States to decide. There are indicators that are closely linked to marginalisation, such as long-term high unemployment, low levels of education, extremely poor housing conditions, lack of access to healthcare and/or exposure to excessive health risks. The crisis has had a direct negative impact on marginalised communities, further increasing poverty and social exclusion. Cohesion policy plays an important role in supporting the economic, social and territorial integration of marginalised communities. The report raises a number of ideas that are useful for the integration of marginalised groups. It underlines that education and employment are the best antidote to poverty and that projects outside the school system and lifelong learning should therefore be encouraged. Furthermore, the document emphasises the importance of integrated housing, education and employment interventions and the need to improve access to public services. I voted in favour of this report in plenary.

name: Mary Honeyball (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ Together with my Labour colleagues I voted in favour of this report as I believe EU cohesion policy is a powerful tool to address the problems that marginalised communities face. These include unemployment, poor housing conditions and low access to public services. They also experience multiple forms of discrimination and social, cultural and economic exclusion. I welcome the report’s call for genuine involvement of representatives from marginalised communities in the development, implementation and management of EU funds and projects in this field. As a member of the Women’s Rights and Gender Equality Committee, I particularly welcome the gender perspective taken in this report.

name: Richard Howitt (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ I am proud that I and my fellow Labour MEPs supported the amendment in this report in favour of ‘anti-Gypsyism’. My own East of England constituency has the highest number of authorised traveller pitches of any UK region – nearly one-in-four of the UK total. Even so, Britain’s Equalities and Human Rights Commission said our region was joint highest for the number of new pitches needed. Moreover, the brutal and avoidable destruction of the Dale Farm site by the Conservative Council in Basildon in my constituency remains a scar on Britain’s reputation, being rightly condemned by the United Nations Special Rapporteur. Discrimination must be fought in all its forms and that against the Roma continues to be an endemic problem in Britain and Europe-wide. The only way to stop unauthorised encampments is to provide sufficient authorised sites. The only way to achieve that is to confront anti-Traveller prejudice, and thus overcome local opposition which prevents local sites from being established. Our proposal in this report represents a real effort to do this, making a commitment to combating discrimination against travellers a condition for receiving this important European funding. We are right to do this.

name: Cătălin Sorin Ivan (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ Cohesion policy is one of the strongest instruments of the European Union and it must be used in order to fight inequality and support territorial and social cohesion. The term ‘marginalised’ covers a broad range of concepts, such as the most deprived or materially deprived people, people at risk of poverty, and groups in society that are disadvantaged or discriminated against. We must have a definition of marginalised communities in order to allow all these EU citizens to benefit from the European Structural and Investment Funds which are embedded in the EU cohesion policy.

name: Ivan Jakovčić (ALDE)
text: Written. I voted for the proposal for a Resolution of the European Parliament on Cohesion Policy and Marginalised Communities, since as a shadow rapporteur I actively worked on the preparation of this document, but also that as a former prefect of Istria County from 2001 to 2013 I actively worked on solving the issues of particularly the Roma community in Istria, and in this regard I have a great experience that I tried to transfer to the Resolution.  It is known that the Roma community is also recognized at european level as one of the most vulnerable groups of European society, but what is missing from European regulation is a clear definition of the term marginalized groups or criteria that define that one group of society would be determined in this way. This would also greatly facilitate the definition of measures to improve the social and economic conditions of these groups of society.  It is important to stress that cohesion policy, through its instruments, can play a significant role in better addressing these problems, and I am of the opinion that, along the lines of some other separate European programmes, a separate programme could be clearly defined in this respect in the future programming period.

name: Jean-François Jalkh (ENF)
text: In writing. This text once again demonstrates the European Union's desire to impose on Member States its harmful vision of a multicultural society. It systematically defends the so-called marginalized communities of Roma, immigrants (legal or illegal) and asylum seekers. They are seen as victims of bad policies. To remedy this, the report recommends the use of European funds, to multiply social and cultural programmes. The presence and behaviour of these communities on the territory is never in question despite rates of incivility, offences and misdemeanours that are well above average. The mass presence of foreigners or persons of foreign origin results in strong communitarianization and territorial segregation often accompanied by a refusal to submit to the habits and customs of the hosts. On the other hand, it should be remembered that the subsidies generously paid to them have so far not yielded anything positive. I voted against it.

name: Diane James (EFDD)
text: in writing. – My fellow MEPs and I abstained on this vote due to the sensitivity of the issue at hand. UKIP does not believe that the Commission should be creating overarching integrating schemes at all. But we also recognise that ostracising marginalised communities that come from disadvantaged backgrounds is also a negative thing. I therefore decided to abstain.

name: Marc Joulaud (PPE)
text: In writing. I voted in favour of the Reintke report on the consideration of marginalized communities as part of cohesion policy. Indeed, while cohesion policy is an investment instrument for growth, it is also intended, as the name suggests, to support territorial and social cohesion in the regions. However, all European societies have groups that do not have access to the most basic infrastructure and public services and are disproportionately affected by poverty and unemployment. The text voted is the result of compromises between political groups. While some political groups have supported "catch-all" and unrealistic provisions, the EPP has worked to improve the text. In addition, the scope of the report has been broadened in relation to the unilateral focus on Roma communities originally proposed by the rapporteur. This text was adopted by a large majority, which I welcome.

name: Philippe Juvin (PPE)
text: In writing. I voted in favour of this report, which aims to include marginalized communities in the cohesion policy of the European Union. This powerful instrument must help reduce inequalities and support territorial and social cohesion in regions facing these problems of marginalized communities.

name: Jarosław Kalinowski (PPE)
text: I would like to write to the Commission. \u2012 Cohesion policy is the most important and costly policy currently implemented by the European Union. It aims to compensate for the differences between Europe's most developed and least developed regions. I would remind you that Poland is currently the largest net beneficiary of the Cohesion Fund among all EU countries. The objective of cohesion policy is the comprehensive development of regions not only economically but also socially. This applies primarily to 'marginalised communities', i.e. Roma minorities, but paradoxically there is currently no clear definition of such communities in European legislation. On the other hand, it is a fact that there is still discrimination on ethnic, cultural, religious and disabled grounds within the EU. However, it appears that this is the area for cohesion policy to act – to contribute to the eradication of all forms of persecution through an integrated approach in the economic and social sphere. The key to success is integration, which must come from both minorities and member states' authorities. Partnership and mutual understanding activities are needed.

name: Barbara Kappel (ENF)
text: Writing. I do not agree with the report on cohesion policy and marginalised social groups, as this report makes it possible to arbitrarily declare each group a marginal group when it is proving to be politically opportune.

name: Rikke Karlsson (ECR)
text: In writing. This report is concerned with support for certain so-called "marginalized" communities or groups, such as Roma communities, refugees and asylum seekers, victims of racism or even women, all curiously aligned as in a catalogue. I voted against it. Equal rights and solidarity are essential values for us. If the intent is laudable, the presentation and proposals may be questionable. There is no definition of what a "marginalized group" is in the sense of the Union. Nor is it clear that the added value of European centralisation is added in the definition of these funded programmes, as is any so-called 'European' expenditure by the Member States.

name: Afzal Khan (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of this report as I believe that the EU Cohesion policy can be a powerful tool in addressing problems that marginalised communities face, such as unemployment, difficult housing conditions, low access to public services notably health services, multiple forms of discrimination and social, cultural and economic exclusion, etc. I particularly welcome the report’s call for more and genuine involvement of representatives of marginalised communities in the development, implementation and management of EU funds and projects in this field, as I strongly believe that programmes and policies are most effective when those concerned are actually involved in the decision-making and management processes.

name: Bernd Kölmel (ECR)
text: Writing. The own-initiative report by Terry Reintke (Greens) recommends changes to EU cohesion policy. This EU policy area accounts for more than a third of the total EU budget and aims to reduce economic and social inequalities in Europe, thereby strengthening social cohesion. The report calls for even greater attention to be paid to supporting marginalised communities in society, in particular Roma communities and the needs of women. Thus, there is still no uniform definition of marginalised social groups, and in particular in the case of so-called partnership agreements, too little attention is given to the needs of these marginalised groups. As the report itself points out, the legal bases on cohesion policy already set out a number of requirements for supporting marginalised social groups. In line with the principle of subsidiarity, it is up to eu Member States to implement these requirements within the framework of operational programmes. Further centralised regulation is not necessary, as it would unduly influence the policies of the individual EU Member States and create further bureaucratic hurdles for approving projects. I have therefore voted against the report.

name: Ádám Kósa (PPE)
text: Writing. \u2012 There is currently no EU-wide definition of marginalised communities and it is therefore for the Member States to decide on this through their national indicators. There are indicators that are closely linked to marginalisation, such as long-term high unemployment, low levels of education, extremely poor housing conditions, lack of access to healthcare and/or exposure to excessive health risks. The crisis has had a direct negative impact on marginalised communities, further increasing poverty and social exclusion. Cohesion policy plays an important role in supporting the economic, social and territorial integration of marginalised communities. The report raises a number of ideas that are useful for the integration of marginalised groups. It underlines that education and employment are the best antidote to poverty and that projects outside the school system and lifelong learning should therefore be encouraged. Furthermore, the report stresses the importance of integrated housing, education and employment interventions and the need to improve access to public services. I voted in favour of this report in plenary.

name: Stelios Kouloglou (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. ‒ The cohesion policy is one of the strongest instruments in order to fight inequality and support territorial and social cohesion. This report aims to fight exclusion of marginalised communities (such as migrants, indigenous peoples, persons with disabilities) and granting them better access to healthcare and education and employment. I support this report, because it focuses on targeted groups, to address their situation. Through EU funds, we will be able to overcome the problem of exclusion of marginalised communities and establishing greater cohesion in European societies. I voted in favour of this report.

name: Giovanni La Via (PPE)
text: in writing. I support terry reintke's report. The social consequences of the economic and financial crisis which has hit Europe in recent years require serious reflection. Many citizens are in poverty or marginalisation, and one of the main priorities of this Parliament is economic recovery, with the objectives of growth and employment in Europe. I believe that the recommendations included in this proposal can help maximise the benefit of using EU funds for the inclusion of marginalised communities, the use of which is a great opportunity to promote and support the development and cohesion of European societies.

name: Patrick Le Hyaric (GUE/NGL)
text: In writing. Cohesion policy brings together all the structural funds that are used to rebalance the wealth gap between European regions. They are endowed with 351 billion euros for the period 2014-2020. This policy allows the construction of infrastructure to open up and energize certain regions. It is also accompanied by social actions for training and the fight against discrimination. The opinion report on cohesion policy and marginalised groups, including Roma, makes recommendations on targeting actions within the European Union to improve their lot. Giving an anti-discrimination objective to this policy is important as these groups are also present in richer regions normally neglected by cohesion policy. The fight against discrimination against Roma requires the proper use of structural funds as they are an effective instrument against poverty and social exclusion. I have, of course, supported this report, adopted by a large majority, despite the opposition of the populists of Eastern Europe, joined by the elected representatives of the National Front.

name: Marine Le Pen (ENF)
text: In writing. I voted against the report on cohesion policy and marginalized communities. The rapporteur has clearly decided to favour Roma. It proposes to provide funds for their social inclusion (improving their living conditions, cultural assistance programmes, etc. No social inclusion programme for Roma will be successful in the absence of a desire on their part to better integrate and to better respect the rules and customs of the Member States of residence. We consider that the factors of the marginalisation of the Roma community are mainly to be sought in its refusal to assimilate into the dominant culture of the Member State of residence as well as in the commission of numerous violations of the laws of the Latter. That is why I am opposed, in these circumstances, to the use of structural funds for projects and programmes for Roma communities.

name: Gilles Lebreton (ENF)
text: In writing. FN MEPs voted against the report because it blames roma for the lack of "social inclusion" on states. However, nothing will be possible without a real willingness of the Roma to integrate.

name: Juan Fernando López Aguilar (S&D)
text: in writing. The legislative framework for cohesion policy ensures funding opportunities for marginalized communities in urban and rural areas. The 2014-2020 programming period is committed to the implementation of participatory local development and integrated territorial investments (ITIs) targeting marginalized communities.  With our vote in favour of the report, the Socialists call on the European Commission to adopt a definition of 'marginalized communities', which does not yet exist, with the aim of allowing these EU citizens to benefit even more from the European Structural and Investment Funds. The vote against paragraph 11 of the report is because that text assumes, through an erroneous and widespread approach, that the EU does not have structures for combating corruption and fraudulent use of funds (and existing ones are not responsible, transparent and democratic), and that marginalized communities are excluded from EU funds , which is the wrong assumption. The Socialists have always advocated maximum transparency in existing fund management structures and that marginalized communities continue to benefit from cohesion policy.

name: Paloma López Bermejo (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. I voted in favour of this report as it contains positive elements for the effective implementation, through cohesion policy, of the principle of non-discrimination contained in the Treaties. In this regard, the text calls on the European Commission to clarify the concept of marginalized communities; stresses that cuts in public services further complicate the situation of vulnerable groups; visibilizes existing racism and institutional discrimination towards communities such as Roma; calls for Member States to ensure the participation of partnerships working with marginalized communities as well; denounces the multiple discrimination against women, people with disabilities and migrants found in marginalized communities, among other groups. Therefore, and although the report is exclusively pro propositional, I voted in favour.

name: Bernd Lucke (ECR)
text: Writing. The own-initiative report by Terry Reintke (Greens) recommends changes to EU cohesion policy. This EU policy area accounts for more than a third of the total EU budget and aims to reduce economic and social inequalities in Europe, thereby strengthening social cohesion. The report calls for even greater attention to be paid to supporting marginalised communities in society, in particular Roma communities and the needs of women. Thus, there is still no uniform definition of marginalised social groups, and in particular in the case of so-called partnership agreements, too little attention is given to the needs of these marginalised groups. As the report itself points out, the legal bases on cohesion policy already set out a number of requirements for supporting marginalised social groups. In line with the principle of subsidiarity, it is up to eu Member States to implement these requirements within the framework of operational programmes. Further centralised regulation is not necessary, as it would unduly influence the policies of the individual EU Member States and create further bureaucratic hurdles for approving projects. I have therefore voted against the report.

name: Petr Mach (EFDD)
text: Writing. \u2012 Poverty cannot be combated by making non-systemic plans and promises, we need to focus on the reasons why citizens are poor and how the state and its policies are to blame.

name: Ivana Maletić (PPE)
text: Written. ‒ In all European countries, we encounter communities that are excommunate from society. Cohesion Policy is one of the European Union's main instruments in tackling inequality. The economic crisis in the Member States leads to deeper problems. Restrictions on public expenditure affect rising unemployment, lack of social security, and lack of available health services.  I supported MP Terry Reintke's report because it contains essential recommendations on how to reduce problems affecting marginalised groups and discrimination. In this context, I believe that the use of EU funds to involve marginalised groups is how the cohesion of European society is implemented in order to achieve greater support between Member States.

name: Vladimír Maňka (S&D)
text: Writing. \u2012 Cohesion policy is a pillar of solidarity in the EU. It implements objectives in the areas of economic growth and competitiveness, job creation and, ultimately, improvement of quality of life. For its implementation, the EU has allocated €352 billion for 2014-2020, almost a third of the EU budget.  The effects of the public spending reduction crisis have mainly affected weaker sections of the population. It is therefore essential that cohesion policy resources are used effectively precisely to address marginalised groups, so as to ensure adequate housing, health and social care and, above all, employment by encouraging investment. Sensible investment support will have beneficial effects on the economy and economy of each Member State. At the same time, flexible mechanisms need to be established to control the management of earmarked funds, from project creation to completion, as well as a system of effective and, above all, timely sanctions and measures for misuse or misuse of funds.

name: Νότης Μαριάς (
text: ECR), in writing. \u2012 I am voting in favour of the report on cohesion policy and marginalised communities because it is complete and documented.

name: Dominique Martin (ENF)
text: In writing. I voted against this report. Its aim is to "improve" the use of European funds to promote the social inclusion of marginalized communities. The rapporteur believes that marginalized communities, especially Roma, do not benefit sufficiently from cohesion policy because they are not sufficiently integrated into decision-making structures, in the implementation and monitoring of projects, which increases their vulnerability. We oppose this report because, not to the displeasure of the rapporteur, who is too naïve, the lack of integration of Roma communities does not come from a lack of support, but from the categorical refusal of these populations to integrate. All expenses to these populations will be unnecessary until they voluntarily seek to integrate.

name: David Martin (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ I welcome this report, which highlights that the implementation of the cohesion policy must tackle the crucial challenge of poverty and exclusion of young people and children, adults and people with disabilities, including the transition from institutional to community-based care and services; urges the Member States concerned to take appropriate action and measures to develop and implement strategies towards this end, applying the integrated approach.

name: Fulvio Martusciello (PPE)
text: in writing. Cohesion policy is one of the key instruments available to the European Union to support economic, social and territorial inclusion and to reduce disparities and the gap between regions. Marginalised communities do not always benefit from European cohesion policy, they are not included in decision-making structures or in project implementation and monitoring processes. Europe urgently needs to address the issue of marginalised communities. Therefore, specific measures should be taken in the context of the implementation of marginalizing communities and in particular in the management of EU funds to promote and support greater cohesion in European societies.

name: Jiří Maštálka (GUE/NGL)
text: Writing. \u2012 Marginalized communities pose a significant problem. Individuals in these communities often do not have access to education and employment and face social exclusion. The economic crisis has contributed to a cut in funding to combat this phenomenon, and the consequences are particularly on women from marginalised communities, who suffer multiple and more intense discrimination, and their employment levels are far lower than those of men in these communities and for other women. I am glad that we have been able to discuss this issue and stress the importance of cohesion policy instruments in this area. We draw the Commission's attention to the needs of each of the possible target groups in order to promote their socio-economic inclusion and stress that the implementation of cohesion policy must address the key challenges caused by poverty and exclusion, in particular for young people and children, but also for adults and people with disabilities, including the transition from institutional care and services to community-based care and services. We also urge the Member States to take appropriate action and to take steps to develop and implement strategies to this end, using an integrated approach. I voted in favour of this report.

name: Emmanuel Maurel (S&D)
text: In writing. Cohesion policy is, thanks to the structural funds that support local projects in all European territories, the most concrete embodiment of European solidarity. It most directly meets the objective of equality of territories which is to the principle of European integration.  However, we know that territorial inequalities persist and sometimes increase under the combined effect of metropolisation and globalization. Disadvantaged neighbourhoods, precarious housing spaces, rural or mountain communities are the first to be affected by this centripetal logic. That is why the Reintke report, which focuses on the effective use of cohesion policy for these marginalized communities, is welcome.  The complexity of the european funding procedure requires a strengthening of the administrative capacity of local managers, particularly in the new cohesion policy programming that decentralises the management of structural funds. I also welcome the fact that the European Semester, a blind instrument of fiscal consolidation, is being the subject of proposals to be enriched. It could contain recommendations on cohesion policy projects for these troubled areas. I therefore voted in favour of this text.

name: Georg Mayer (ENF)
text: Writing. The report leads to a further marginalisation of the majority society and the possibility of declaring all groups deemed politically opportune to be marginalised. It is completely incomprehensible why women, who make up more than 50 percent of the world's population, should be considered marginal. I am therefore voting against this report.

name: Jean-Luc Mélenchon (GUE/NGL)
text: In writing. The term "marginalized communities" refers to different groups of people such as minorities, Roma, people with disabilities, migrants, refugees and socially excluded groups. I deeply regret the preference of the term "marginalized communities" to "marginalized populations" that opposes republican construction. This is the vision of the Union to divide peoples according to "places" of origin, religions or ethnic groups. How do the poor or the disabled form a community? Not in fact, not in rights! The report strongly condemns austerity, including "cuts to the public services budget [which] have led to an exacerbation of the employment situation, the absence of social security, housing problems and health problems" and calls within the framework of cohesion policy to guarantee access to public services: health, education, housing, employment... Unfortunately, this will remain fine words as long as the Commission still dictates the same policies for cuts in national budgets. Parliament supports these transfers, particularly for the European Social Fund, which itself has suffered from the same evil, because of the 'macro-economic conditionality'. So I can't condone this vicious circle. I abstain.

name: Joëlle Mélin (ENF)
text: In writing. This is a highly ideologically oriented report that takes the side of funding, with European funds, multiple social and cultural programmes for so-called marginalized communities. It is really about buying social peace and promoting multiculturalism. The implementation of such policies has never produced the desired results, so I am opposed to this report.

name: Nuno Melo (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the report on cohesion policy and marginalised communities. The relevant role of cohesion policy in supporting the economic and social inclusion of marginalised communities and combating inequalities, promoting greater cohesion of European societies, is underlined.

name: Roberta Metsola (PPE)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of this report as it calls for the use of EU funds for the inclusion of marginalised communities which will promote and support greater cohesion in European societies.

name: Louis Michel (ALDE)
text: In writing. "No one can live on himself, no one can live for himself" said Paul Hymans. The crisis has become social and moral. It is a crisis of humanity's drift in the face of immediate needs and the ideal of enrichment, deepening inequalities and undermining social cohesion. Globalization certainly produces technological revolution, political will and open markets, and is a real opportunity for all if it is humanized. It goes hand in hand with the ethics of consciences and intelligences, leading to the sharing of goods and resources in order to help the development of humanity. That is why the vote on such a resolution aimed at an integrated but not exclusive approach reinforces my feeling that Europe is an example of successful globalisation at the regional level.

name: Miroslav Mikolášik (PPE)
text: Writing. \u2012 The European Union Structural Funds are one of the important instruments that can help to address the plight of marginalised communities, but they are very often not benefiting from European cohesion policy.  I therefore welcome the fact that the present report on cohesion policy and marginalised communities also draws attention and warns against the possibility that, although promoters may meet the criteria for inclusion on paper, they do not have to invest in what the beneficiaries really need and may not achieve the target groups. Thus, the real improvement in the situation, according to many who move on the subject, is often not directly proportional to the amount of money spent on this. Waste, on the other hand, has the opposite effect, namely a deterioration of the situation without further prospects. Not to mention that this is an extremely complex problem, for example in the case of the Roma community. If we are talking about the phenomenon of poverty in these communities, we must also talk about debts that these people will never be able to repay in their lives. While impending executions disincentive them in their pursuit of employment, as the main and most important route to integration into society.

name: Marlene Mizzi (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ I have voted in favour of the report on cohesion policy and marginalised communities, which aims to raise awareness about the need to develop policy responses to reduce poverty and inequalities in the EU and work towards the EU 2020 targets.

name: Csaba Molnár (S&D)
text: Writing. \u2012 The Report of the Committee on Regional Development is about groups and communities living in structural exclusion and segregation of European societies, with no access even to basic public infrastructures and public services. In many cases, these groups are characterised by disproportionate poverty, unemployment and poor health. The report notes that the large reduction in public expenditure during the crisis has caused an exacerbation of existing problems (e.g. unemployment, lack of social security, difficult housing conditions and lack of public health services) in the Member States. As a result, the crisis has had a direct negative impact on marginalised communities. The report proposes to avert these negative consequences. I supported the adoption of this report.

name: Bernard Monot (ENF)
text: In writing. The resolution calls for improving the use of EU funds in the framework of cohesion policy, by promoting the social inclusion of marginalized communities, mainly Roma, but also migrants and asylum seekers. No social inclusion programme aimed at Roma will be successful in the absence of a desire on their part to better integrate, i.e. to stop their mafia activities of exploiting women, children and the elderly, as well as theft. The main reasons for the marginalisation of Roma are to be sought in their refusal to assimilate into the dominant culture of the Member State of residence, as well as in the commission of numerous violations of roma's laws. That is why we are resolutely against the use of structural funds for projects and programmes for Roma communities.

name: Cláudia Monteiro de Aguiar (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 The economic crisis has had a major negative impact on the territorial and social cohesion of the regions of the European Union, due to restrictions on public expenditure in the Member States, especially affecting marginalised communities. In response, cohesion policy plays a relevant role in establishing social equalities, with the aim of combating social exclusion and more recurrent problems such as poverty, employment and health problems. Accessibility to public infrastructure or lack of living conditions may also arise as some of the problems affecting marginalized communities, which include various groups of people, such as disadvantaged neighborhoods, the most deprived, people at risk of poverty, among others. There is a growing need to create actions and programmes at European level that intervene in the field of this, through the use of EU funds, taking a key role with regard to cohesion policy. I am in favour of the recommendations in this report, in that it benefits marginalised communities by improving their living conditions by combating social inequalities and promoting European social cohesion.

name: Sophie Montel (ENF)
text: In writing. This report on cohesion policy and marginalized communities aims to improve the use of EU funds in the framework of cohesion policy by promoting "social inclusion of marginalized communities", a Europeanist term for Roma populations, migrants and asylum seekers. It also condemns the fact that the European Commission has accepted partnership agreements that do not place sufficient emphasis on the inclusion of these 'marginalised communities'. Finally, it proposes the creation of a European prize for exemplary dedication to the integration and inclusion of marginalized groups. It is totally illusory to see these programmes of "inclusion" of Roma in the lack of will of these populations but also of the countries of origin. That is why I am opposed to the idea of providing more funds to meet this utopian objective. So I voted against it.

name: Nadine Morano (PPE)
text: In writing. I voted in favour of this report on the Union's cohesion policy and marginalised communities. The text calls on Member States to help those most in need to integrate socially and economically, including combating long-term unemployment, school drop-out and health risks. It encourages them to make better use of European structural and investment funds to achieve this result.
