In particular, I support the measures in this report which aim to strengthen entrepreneurship and develop employment, which are real factors in the fight against marginalisation.

name: Elisabeth Morin-Chartier (PPE)
text: In writing. I voted in favour of the Reintke report for cohesion policy, which is one of the most powerful instruments at the disposal of the European Union to combat inequalities and support territorial and social cohesion in its regions. All European societies comprise groups and communities - such as the Roma community - who are victims of structural exclusion and segregation by the majority of the population and who do not have access to the most basic public infrastructure and services. In addition, they are very often affected by poverty, unemployment and poor sanitation in a totally disproportionate way. Significant declines in public spending during the crisis led to a worsening of existing problems in the Member States, such as unemployment, lack of social security, housing difficulties and a lack of public health services. Many municipalities continue to face significant budgetary constraints that prevent them from responding adequately to the phenomenon of marginalization in society. While national contexts, needs and solutions vary widely in Europe, the objective of social cohesion requires action at European level in the inclusion policies of marginalized communities.

name: Alessia Maria Mosca (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 We are voting positively for this resolution, which has become particularly necessary in recent days. This, in fact, goes in the direction of reducing disparities within the European Union and, above all, focuses on the vital need for something serious to be done to integrate the marginalised groups in our society. Marginalisation is an unfair phenomenon and, above all, a cause of resentment on the part of the communities that suffer from it. It is therefore important for the European Commission to follow the guidelines that are the subject of this measure, which ask it to draw up a serious and comprehensive definition of what marginalised groups are. This could, in fact, enable these European citizens to benefit from the European Structural and Investment Funds, as provided for in the European Union's cohesion policies.

name: Renaud Muselier (PPE)
text: In writing. I was not able to vote for this report, but I fully support the position of the EPP Group and the French delegation to adopt this report. Marginalised communities in the EU must have access to structural funds, even if it means putting in place specialized tools. It must not be forgotten or overlooked, however, that it is first and foremost the responsibility of States to take charge and promote the development of communities on their soil that it is incumbent on these same communities to be dynamic in this process.

name: Victor Negrescu (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ Cohesion policy is one of the strongest instruments the European Union has at its disposal with which to fight inequality and support territorial and social cohesion in its regions. In all European societies there are groups and communities that face structural exclusion and segregation from the majority society and do not have access to even basic public infrastructure and services. I have voted for this report that will instate quality evaluation and monitoring mechanisms so that interventions lead to long-term and sustainable results. Using EU funds for the inclusion of marginalised communities can become a great opportunity for promoting and supporting greater cohesion in European societies.

name: Norica Nicolai (ALDE)
text: in writing. \u2012 I support this report with my vote today because I believe that the European funds available to the Member States and in particular those scheduled for the period 2014-2020 must be better used for the integration of marginalised communities and to combat poverty in these communities. It is also very important that there is a clear definition as soon as possible, with an amount of indicators clear enough to designate certain communities as marginalised but at the same time flexible enough to be applied to the specificity of each Member State. With regard to women and children in these communities, we need to understand that these categories are subject to multiple discrimination, and in the absence of funds and strategies to include and lift these communities to a normal standard, we will not be able to combat the long-term effects of this situation.

name: Péter Niedermüller (S&D)
text: Writing. \u2012 The greatest value of the report on cohesion policy and marginalised communities is to draw attention to the inefficiencies in EU funding reaching marginalised communities. It emphasises that the Roma population is the largest such group in Europe, highlights the importance of education in inclusion and that women are even more affected by the exclusionary situation than men. The report calls on the Commission to define marginalised groups precisely, to report on the resources allocated to support such groups, to analyse the data and to draw the necessary conclusions. It also calls on the Commission to consistently check whether NGOs are involved in the control of resources. Overall, the report contributes to more EU support for the most disadvantaged European citizens.

name: Franz Obermayr (ENF)
text: Writing. I voted against this report. It ultimately leads to a further marginalisation of the majority society and to the unfair possibility of declaring all groups that appear politically opportune to be marginalised.

name: Younous Omarjee (GUE/NGL)
text: In writing. I voted in favour of this initiative report which calls for reaffirming the European Union's responsibility in the fight against the marginalisation of certain communities, and in particular by reintroducing this objective into cohesion policy. The segregation and marginalization of migrant communities, indigenous peoples and people with disabilities must be tackled, and cohesion policy must provide areas particularly affected by these problems with sufficient means to eradicate them effectively. The report stresses the need for a better assessment of the real needs of vulnerable populations so that the financial instruments available are mobilised promptly and effectively. In particular, I welcome the references made to the special role played by austerity policy and budget cuts in deepening inequality, also calling on the Commission to react quickly to find lasting solutions to these problems.

name: Urmas Paet (ALDE)
text: Writing. \u2012 I supported. The involvement of communities is often not sufficient only formally, and a substantive contribution is also needed to unite society and promote tolerance. The channelling of EU funds for this purpose provides an opportunity to promote coherence in substance.

name: Maite Pagazaurtundúa Ruiz (ALDE)
text: in writing. This initiative report is important as it provides solutions and ideas on the role cohesion policies can play in contributing to the inclusion of marginal communities.  Inclusion policies depend heavily on national, regional and local governments, and are therefore at the mercy of the political interest they arouse in the government on duty. In addition, the practice shows that aid is not always aimed at meeting the real needs of these communities. Cohesion policy, therefore, remains one of the strongest instruments with which the EU can combat marginalization while supporting territorial and social cohesion in the EU.

name: Rolandas Paksas (EFDD)
text: Writing. \u2012 In particular, the EU must have a uniform definition of marginalised communities in the EU. Marginalised communities must become active and inclusive.  Therefore, initiatives that arise and promote their well-being in these communities need to be encouraged and supported and helped to implement them. Cohesion policy, which is a highly effective tool, plays a particular role in this area. However, very often marginalised communities cannot benefit from European cohesion policy. This does not guarantee the accessibility and efficiency of services, their financial stability and their autonomy.  In order to ensure the inclusion of marginalised communities, there should be clear, transparent and democratic structures aimed at combating corruption and the fraudulent use of funds. Proper implementation of the Code of Conduct for Partnership, which aims to ensure equal involvement and representation of stakeholders, is essential.

name: Margot Parker (EFDD)
text: in writing. ‒ We abstained on this vote due to the sensitivity of the issue at hand. UKIP does not believe that the Commission should be creating overarching integrating schemes at all. But we also recognise that ostracising marginalised communities that come from disadvantaged backgrounds is also a negative thing. Therefore we decided to abstain.

name: Aldo Patriciello (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 I am always particularly attentive to developments in European cohesion policy, especially in this period of 2014-2020 objectives where "less developed regions" have been placed among the priorities. Coming from the Mezzogiorno, I am sensitive to the needs of the regions most in need and I believe that the same modus operandi should be applied to marginalised communities. Social inclusion and non-discrimination are the values that the EU boasts and implements with a profusion of efforts. That is why I enthusiastically approve the text we are debating and voting on in this House and I am voting in favour of it.

name: Eva Paunova (PPE)
text: in writing. – Cohesion policy is probably the strongest EU instrument to fight inequality and support sustainable territorial development in its regions. I support the report and the current 2014-2020 cohesion framework that puts forward new measures for improving the situation of marginalised communities, such as the investment priority. I believe it could have a positive effect on the situation with the marginalised Roma communities in my home country, Bulgaria.

name: Alojz Peterle (PPE)
text: in writing. ‒ Member States, under the charter of fundamental rights of the EU, should feel encouraged to ensure equal treatment of all its citizens, with special attention on the most marginalized groups. In present times, creating environments of integration is of key importance for the prevention also of radicalisation phenomena. Ministries at national level should take into account these groups when working on cohesion policies.

name: Marijana Petir (PPE)
text: Written. ‒ Marginalised groups include not only minorities but also people with disabilities, people at risk of living below the poverty line or already living below that limit, then migrants, refugees and socially excluded groups in society. More than 510,000 people with disabilities (12% of the total population of the Republic of Croatia) live in Croatia, according to data up to January 2014. Of these, more than 52% are of working age. About 65% of people with disabilities, according to available education data, do not have completed primary school or have only primary education.  In particular, the population in rural areas, as well as mountainous areas and border areas preserved and cultivated by the area is particularly marginalised, while the role of the rural woman for the family and society as a whole is underestimated and under-recognised. Further efforts need to be made to include all these groups in society and to give them hope that progress can be made even when the situation seems hopeless. This means not only improving living conditions and standards, the availability of schooling, but also ensuring jobs, increasing the presence in social and political life, as well as better access to the media.

name: Florian Philippot (ENF)
text: In writing. This report on cohesion policy and marginalized communities aims to improve the use of EU funds in the framework of cohesion policy by promoting "social inclusion of marginalised communities", a Europeanist term for Mainly Roma populations, migrants and asylum seekers. It also condemns the fact that the European Commission has accepted partnership agreements that do not place sufficient emphasis on the inclusion of these 'marginalised communities'. Finally, it proposes the creation of a European prize for exemplary dedication to the integration and inclusion of marginalized groups.  It is totally illusory to see these programmes of "inclusion" of Roma in the lack of will of these populations but also of the countries of origin. That is why I am opposed to the idea of providing more funds to meet this utopian objective.  So I voted against it.

name: Tonino Picula (S&D)
text: Written. ‒ People and groups of people who are on the margins of society are the ones most in need, and unfortunately the most common and least accessible. In this regard, the effort to include marginalised communities in cohesion policy is a commendable progress towards addressing their poverty, unemployment, poor health conditions and poor access to basic public services and infrastructure. It is important to introduce a uniform definition of marginalised communities, so that their protection can be consistently included in a number of regulatory areas, but at the same time it is important to ensure that intersections of different bases and identities are recognised where people are discriminated against and excluded. In doing so, it is necessary to deal not only with substantive conditions such as access to public services, but also in various forms of discrimination and rejection. Two mechanisms are particularly important in this sense: the first is the involvement of members of marginalised communities in decision-making structures and the implementation of projects, and the second is stricter supervision of the implementation of projects that are intended to improve the living conditions of these communities.

name: Andrej Plenković (PPE)
text: Written. ‒Cohesion Policy is the cornerstone of the common progress of the entire EU area. A strategic approach to vulnerable marginalised communities, including Roma, requires an integral approach to development. This is supported by the new elements included in the legislative framework for cohesion policy for the period 2014-2020, which relate primarily to the extension of the scope of the activities financed. In order to specifically define a marginalised group, it is important to approach the problem individually and "bottom-up". Therefore, addressing the vulnerability of marginalised groups is not sufficient to encourage profitable projects, but it is essential that funding in this regard monitors the appropriate development of the availability of public services. In this regard, I agree that the implementation of this programme is guaranteed only with the use of funds in a more integrated way, which would mean that projects should be financed comprehensively from multiple funds. Such an approach would be "local development" (CLLD – Community led – local development), which is a prerequisite for identifying and solving specific problems and is made possible by the Common Provisions Regulation. In order to fully apply it, it is important to achieve synergies with funding instruments at EU and Member State level as soon as possible in order to fully apply it.

name: Salvatore Domenico Pogliese (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 The reduction in public expenditure due to the continuing economic crisis has led to an aggravation of some of the problems already existing in the Member States. In many European societies, in fact, there are groups and communities that are affected by structural exclusion and do not have access to basic infrastructure and public services. In addition, many municipalities continue to have to comply with strict budgetary constraints that prevent adequate tackle of marginalisation in society. Cohesion policy is one of the strongest instruments available to the European Union to combat inequalities and support territorial and social cohesion in its regions. The use of EU funds for the inclusion of marginalised communities can become a great opportunity to promote and support greater cohesion in European societies. That is why I am voting in favour of this report.

name: Tomasz Piotr Poręba (ECR)
text: I would like to write to the Commission. \u2012 The report is intended to give rise to a discussion on the future programming period with a view to improving the living conditions of marginalised communities. Ultimately, however, the inclusion of marginalised communities will depend on the strong political will of local and national authorities. The report points out that the implementation of cohesion policy must address the most important challenge of poverty and exclusion of young people and children, adults and people with disabilities. That is why I supported the report.

name: Franck Proust (PPE)
text: In writing. It was important, in my view, that we make a clear study of the inclusion of communities marginalized by cohesion policy. It is a necessity, and we had to speak out on it. That is why I have spoken in favour. However, to want to say too much, to want to detail too much about communities, to want to impose too much political correctness, political groups of the left have unfortunately drowned some messages and almost made the text illegible. I'm sorry, I'm sorry. Our mission is to send short, precise and concise messages to our fellow citizens. I believe that the text voted today does not bring together all these criteria.

name: Paulo Rangel (PPE)
text: in writing. Cohesion policy is one of the strongest tools that the European Union has at its disposal to combat inequalities and support territorial and social cohesion in its regions. In all European societies, there are groups and communities that face structural exclusion and segregation of the majority of society and do not even have access to basic public infrastructure and services. Despite the fact that the main responsibility for changing the situation of marginalised communities rests with the Member States, the truth is that the objective of social cohesion requires European intervention in the policies for the inclusion of marginalised communities. Cohesion policy can play an important role in changing the situation, not only in overcoming challenges in the housing sector or in accessto public infrastructure, as is already the case within the ERDF, but also by adopting an integrated approach to combating all forms of discrimination that marginalised communities face. The point is that the necessary adjustments are made and qualitative monitoring and evaluation mechanisms are introduced so that interventions can achieve sustainable and long-term results. I voted in favour.

name: Julia Reid (EFDD)
text: in writing. ‒ We abstained on this vote due to the sensitivity of the issue at hand. UKIP does not believe that the Commission should be creating overarching integrating schemes at all. But we also recognise that ostracising marginalised communities that come from disadvantaged backgrounds is also a negative thing. Therefore we decided to abstain.

name: Robert Rochefort (ALDE)
text: In writing. Regional policy aims to promote the economic, social and territorial cohesion of the European Union. Integration and equal opportunities for all citizens, especially marginalized communities, are an integral part of this policy, especially since we know that the economic crisis has led to a worsening of the situation of poverty and social exclusion. New progress and improvements are therefore needed in this area, and this text proposes several, notably in terms of the involvement and accountability of actors and different levels of power. I think these measures are necessary. That is why I voted in favour of this text.

name: Liliana Rodrigues (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 Strong reductions in public spending during the crisis have led to a worsening of problems in the Member States, such as unemployment, lack of social security, the difficult housing situation and the lack of public health services. The crisis had a direct negative impact on members of marginalized communities. Many municipalities continue to face serious budgetary constraints that prevent them from adequately combating marginalisation in society. Cohesion policy can play an essential role in changing this situation, not only in overcoming challenges in the housing sector or in accessing public infrastructure, but also by adopting an integrated approach to combating all forms of discrimination that marginalised communities face.

name: Inmaculada Rodríguez-Piñero Fernández (S&D)
text: in writing. The legislative framework for cohesion policy ensures funding opportunities for marginalized communities in urban and rural areas. The 2014-2020 programming period is committed to the implementation of participatory local development and integrated territorial investments (ITIs) targeting marginalized communities.  With our vote in favour of the report, the Socialists call on the European Commission to adopt a definition of 'marginalized communities', which does not yet exist, with the aim of allowing these EU citizens to benefit even more from the European Structural and Investment Funds. The vote against paragraph 11 of the report is because that text assumes, through an erroneous and widespread approach, that the EU does not have structures for combating corruption and fraudulent use of funds (and existing ones are not responsible, transparent and democratic), and that marginalized communities are excluded from EU funds , which is the wrong assumption. The Socialists have always advocated maximum transparency in existing fund management structures and that marginalized communities continue to benefit from cohesion policy.

name: Claude Rolin (PPE)
text: In writing. Marginalized communities in Europe, including Roma, often suffer from a lack of integration. For a very long time, this Parliament has been calling for better living conditions for these communities. However, the European Union has a good tool to combat this lack of integration, the cohesion policy.  The report discussed at this plenary session of the European Parliament deals with several elements. First of all, the Commission is being asked to publish guidelines on the definition of marginalised communities for which, I recall, there is no definition at European Union level. The Commission is also asked to provide detailed information on how to benefit from funding opportunities for marginalized communities. The Commission must also facilitate the inclusion of marginalized communities in the development, implementation and evaluation of projects as an instrument for the emancipation of these communities. Finally, it is important that recommendations on them be presented in the context of the European semester. In line with all these proposals, I voted in favour of this report which I hope will improve the integration of marginalized communities.

name: Fernando Ruas (PPE)
text: in writing. Cohesion policy has in recent decades played a major role for the regions of the European Union, notably in strengthening the instruments at its disposal of asymmetries and in supporting the territorial, economic and social cohesion of its regions. However, many groups and communities are still the target of social exclusion resulting from the deprivation of access to basic infrastructure and services, such as housing, education, employment, social security or health services. This reality stems from a complex series of circumstances which have marked existing social and economic problems, in particular in the most disadvantaged and socially disadvantaged communities (and unfortunately prevailing in several European regions). Given these facts, this report argues that cohesion policy must therefore and also provide for measures to include these marginalised communities. In this way, and because I think that concrete measures should be taken at European level to meet this need, I have voted positive for this report.

name: Massimiliano Salini (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of this report because I believe that cohesion policy is an indispensable instrument for combating the social inequalities that still exist in Europe. Member States must work together to help and integrate the most marginalised communities and must be able to implement social, economic and territorial inclusion policies.

name: Lola Sánchez Caldentey (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. We voted in favour of this report aimed at increasing the social protection of minorities in Europe because we understand that all policies aimed at increasing social cohesion are positive, recognising the very existence of minorities and putting in place measures to improve the living conditions of the millions of people currently living at risk of social exclusion.

name: Daciana Octavia Sârbu (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ EU funds can be a powerful lever to alleviate inequalities and improve the lives of people in marginalised communities. I fully back the call in this report to ensure that marginalised communities are better served by accountable and transparent use of EU funds. The Commission should look closely at how marginalised communities can be identified and defined so that funding can be properly directed on the basis of clearly established guidance. We must make all the necessary efforts to combat discrimination and social exclusion and ensure that marginalised groups are integrated into a diverse, tolerant and fair society. This will bring benefits to all.

name: Olga Sehnalová (S&D)
text: Writing. \u2012 In the context of this report, there has been a debate about which groups they are and whether they can also be determined on an ethnic basis. In the context of the debates on migration and integration of refugees, ghettos and socially excluded sites as a shoal for radicalisation have become more vocal. There is a consensus that if people do not feel like full-fledged in society, they are marginalized, where they create parallel worlds that are governed by their own rules and laws. It is therefore necessary not only to continue to encourage and explain, but, in particular, to prove on a daily day that the same rules and obligations apply to all and are all measured by the same metre. If this is not the case, sooner or later the conflict in various forms will surface. In the worst-case scenario, it is also a conflict between the majority society and that minority, which, on the contrary, is perceived as the privileged one, leading to even greater alienation. That is why I am not only against discrimination, but also against inclusion. I see the overall concept of this report as divisive in this regard, and although I can agree with many individual points, I did not support the report as a whole.

name: Lidia Senra Rodríguez (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. I voted in favour of this report as it contains positive elements for the effective implementation, through cohesion policy, of the principle of non-discrimination contained in the Treaties. In this regard, the text calls on the European Commission to clarify the concept of marginalized communities; stresses that cuts in public services further complicate the situation of vulnerable groups; visibilizes existing racism and institutional discrimination towards communities such as Roma; calls for Member States to ensure the participation of partnerships working with marginalized communities as well; denounces the multiple discrimination against women, people with disabilities and migrants found in marginalized communities, among other groups. Therefore, and although the report is exclusively pro propositional, I voted in favour.

name: Jill Seymour (EFDD)
text: in writing. ‒ I abstained on this non-legislative report because it calls on the Commission to undertake work to integrate communities. I believe this should be completed by nation states, not the EU.

name: Siôn Simon (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ My Labour Party colleagues in Parliament and I voted for this report, believing that the cohesion policy of the EU can be and ought to be a powerful tool in addressing problems which communities on the margins face. These problems may include things like unemployment, unsuitable or difficult housing conditions, poor access to public services – especially healthcare – and the multiple forms of discrimination which disproportionately affect members of this group. The report calls for more and genuine involvement of representatives of marginalised communities in the development, implementation and management of EU funds and projects in this field. I truly believe that programmes like this are most effective when those concerned are genuinely involved in the decision-making and management processes.

name: Branislav Škripek (ECR)
text: Writing. \u2012 Cohesion policy aims to strengthen economic, social and territorial cohesion, as well as to reduce social disparities, including poverty reduction and eradication and exclusion. I therefore consider the use of EU funds under this policy to integrate marginalised communities to be an important part of the tools needed to address the Roma issue in Slovakia as well as in the EU. However, I cannot agree with the desire to coordinate and link national strategies for marginalised communities more strongly with gender equality strategies, which is why I abstained when voting on the legislative resolution on cohesion policy and marginalised communities.

name: Monika Smolková (S&D)
text: Writing. \u2012 Although the main responsibility for tackling marginalised communities lies with the Member States, I consider cohesion policy to be one of the strongest instruments available to the European Union to combat inequality and promote territorial and social cohesion in its regions. I supported the resolution because I believe that the growing poverty and social slump of marginalised groups is reason enough to change our approach where necessary and create better conditions for improving access to employment opportunities, adult education and training and the promotion of self-employment. I believe that better education and the integration of marginalised communities into the labour market in individual Member States should therefore be a priority. I also expect cohesion policy aimed at integrating marginalised communities to bring more flexibility and flexibility, promote territorial development and help reduce regional disparities. In this context, I consider it important that cohesion policy should give even stronger support to small and medium-sized enterprises, which help to preserve jobs.

name: Igor Šoltes (Verts/ALE)
text: Writing. Peripheral communities are increasingly placed at the centre of cohesion policy measures due to concerns and efforts to combat social exclusion. I agree that the issue of peripheral communities urgently needs to be addressed, but cohesion policy plays an important role in supporting their economic, social and territorial integration. In 2010, funding opportunities for peripheral communities were introduced into the European Regional Development Fund. However, the problem of the lack of identification of peripheral communities has arised, which is why the report calls on the Commission to draw up guidelines to identify peripheral communities, in which it would determine the nature of the characteristics and characteristics of the peripheral groups. The European Social Fund benefits people, including disadvantaged groups such as the long-term unemployed, people with disabilities, migrants, ethnic minorities and people of all ages at risk of poverty or social exclusion. The report calls on the Member States to implement operational programmes that will be able to benefit European funds to support peripheral communities, as well as provide detailed guidance on the preparation, implementation and monitoring of these programmes. I believe that there is an urgent need to establish a proper link between peripheral communities and to benefit from European funds under cohesion policy. For all the reasons set out above, I voted in favour of the report.

name: Joachim Starbatty (ECR)
text: Writing. The own-initiative report by Terry Reintke (Greens) recommends changes to EU cohesion policy. This EU policy area accounts for more than a third of the total EU budget and aims to reduce economic and social inequalities in Europe, thereby strengthening social cohesion. The report calls for even greater attention to be paid to supporting marginalised communities in society, in particular Roma communities and the needs of women. Thus, there is still no uniform definition of marginalised social groups, and in particular in the case of so-called partnership agreements, too little attention is given to the needs of these marginalised groups. As the report itself points out, the legal bases on cohesion policy already set out a number of requirements for supporting marginalised social groups. In line with the principle of subsidiarity, it is up to eu Member States to implement these requirements within the framework of operational programmes. Further centralised regulation is not necessary, as it would unduly influence the policies of the individual EU Member States and create further bureaucratic hurdles for approving projects. I have therefore voted against the report.

name: Davor Ivo Stier (PPE)
text: Written. ‒I support this report because within the European Union there are still various separate groups of people who are prevented from using their rights. A situation in which a certain group of people is segregated and separated from various processes in their community leads to further divisions and separations in society. It is important to involve these people in community action and to enable them to have all the rights enjoyed by the majority population of the European Union, the way to prevent further segregation and any negative consequences of this effect. I also support this report, as the consequences of the economic crisis and cuts to public services have led to a deterioration in the situation of women within marginalised communities.

name: Catherine Stihler (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ Together with my Labour colleagues I voted in favour of this report as I believe the EU cohesion policy can be a powerful tool in addressing problems marginalised communities face, such as unemployment, difficult housing conditions, low access to public services notably health services, multiple forms of discrimination and social, cultural and economic exclusion, etc. I particularly welcome the report’s call for more and genuine involvement of representatives of marginalised communities in the development, implementation and management of EU funds and projects in this field, as I strongly believe that programmes and policies are most effective when those concerned are actually involved in the decision-making and management processes.

name: Dubravka Šuica (PPE)
text: Written. ‒Cohesion Policy aims to reduce the gap between the different regions and the backwardness of the most disadvantaged regions. Marginalised communities have become the centre of cohesion policy measures. Concerns have grown about social exclusion and its involvement in suppressing it, including the situation of Roma and the long-standing need to improve their living conditions. Projects financed by EU funds must be of a long-term character in order to be effective and the funds must support investment in the real needs of beneficiaries with mechanisms to ensure that they reach out to the target groups. A proactive and participatory monitoring mechanism for Member States' measures on the planning process and assessment of funding used for marginalised communities is needed. I support this report, as cohesion policy is an important tool on the road to results-based policymaking that would effectively deliver smart and sustainable growth in the regions where it is most needed.

name: Richard Sulík (ECR)
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted against. The problem with cohesion policies is not their specific setting, but that, as a matter of principle, these policies already do more harm than good, after all, as well as other efforts to raise people's living standards through redistribution. The prosperity of people, marginalised communities, not including those, would be most helped by the complete abolition of cohesion policies and not just by endless changes in their parameters, with the ever-increasing volume of funds being redistributed.

name: Patricija Šulin (PPE)
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the report on cohesion policy and peripheral communities. I agree that european cohesion policy needs to be changed, while pursueing the objective of including peripheral communities. There are still too many people in the Member States who are overlooked and overheard, and we must therefore offer them equal opportunities and access to health, education, employment. Civil society must also play its part in this. I would particularly like to stress the importance of education and the problem of the rapid abandonment of further education.

name: Kay Swinburne (ECR)
text: in writing. ‒ Whilst I am able to support a handful of positive elements in this report, such as the call for more detailed information on ESIF take-up (para 5), the principles of equality and non-discrimination (para 8), prioritising the needs of children (para 14) and support for training and SMEs (para 46), I reject the suggestion that it is the EU’s responsibility to tackle social disparities, poverty and exclusion in Member States. It is not. Social, health, employment, education, housing and planning policies are areas of Member State competence and should remain so.

name: Νεοκλής Συλικιώτης (
text: GUE/NGL), in writing. \u2012 The report emphasises the social role and objectives of cohesion policy in marginalised communities. Among EU citizens, there are groups and communities that face structural exclusion and separation from the rest of society and have limited access to basic infrastructure and services.  Social inequalities, as the report says, have been exacerbated by the current economic crisis, budget cuts and austerity measures and have become huge social problems that cannot be addressed by limiting national policies to support marginalised communities. We voted in favour of the report as it proposes a series of measures to strengthen and integrate marginalised groups socially and calls on the Member States to make use of the funding of European structural investment funds and to focus on creating new jobs and participation in society in order to combat poverty and social exclusion. The report also mentions the need to combat xenophobia and racism.

name: József Szájer (PPE)
text: Writing. \u2012 There is currently no EU-wide definition of marginalised communities and it is therefore for the Member States to decide on this through their national indicators. There are indicators that are closely linked to marginalisation, such as long-term high unemployment, low levels of education, extremely poor housing conditions, lack of access to healthcare and/or exposure to excessive health risks. The crisis has had a direct negative impact on marginalised communities, further increasing poverty and social exclusion. Cohesion policy plays an important role in supporting the economic, social and territorial integration of marginalised communities. The report raises a number of ideas that are useful for the integration of marginalised groups. It underlines that education and employment are the best antidote to poverty and that projects outside the school system and lifelong learning should therefore be encouraged. Furthermore, the report stresses the importance of integrated housing, education and employment interventions and the need to improve access to public services.

name: Tibor Szanyi (S&D)
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of this report because I agree that cohesion policy makes a significant contribution to increasing economic, social and territorial cohesion and reducing social inequalities. However, I believe that the opportunities offered by cohesion policy need to be further deepened and further assistance can be given to Member States to alleviate and eradicate poverty and exclusion. I agree that there are groups and communities in all European societies that live in structural exclusion and segregation from mainstream society and do not even have access to basic public infrastructures and public services. As a result, they are in many cases characterised by disproportionate poverty, unemployment, violence and poor health.  The situation of marginalised communities, including the Roma, can also be improved by means at European level, while it is primarily up to the Member States to change the situation of these communities. This cannot be solved by semblance of politicisation, which is why the European Commission's guidelines can contribute to concrete action. Thanks to this report, the European Commission will provide detailed information on the effective use of funding opportunities for marginalised communities and on the effective application of the European Code of Conduct (e.g. as regards the partnership principle and the involvement of civil society). I believe that accountable, transparent and democratic structures should be established to ensure the integration of marginalised communities in order to combat corruption and fraudulent use of resources.

name: Adam Szejnfeld (PPE)
text: I would like to write to the Commission. \u2012 Cohesion policy aims to strengthen economic, social and territorial cohesion, reduce social inequalities, including poverty reduction and eradication and exclusion. Existing EU funds, both the European Social Fund and the European Regional Development Fund, are very important tools for wider inclusion of marginalised communities.  Parliament, in its document, pointed not only to the issues that have been widely examined so far, but also pointed to little-discussed issues such as the marginalisation of Roma or other ethnic and national minorities living in the European Union. Furthermore, I also agree with the call for a coherent and common definition of marginalised communities, which is included in this report.

name: Claudia Tapardel (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 Cohesion policy is the most effective instrument for economic, social and territorial consolidation. Experience in managing social disparities shows us that we need action at European level in terms of reducing and eradicating poverty and exclusion, preventing segregation and promoting equal access and equal opportunities for all citizens, including the most marginalised groups. In complementing actions taken at Union level, I believe that multi-level governance and coordination play a key role in the preparation and implementation of programmes for the integration of marginalised communities. The most exposed are women from marginalised communities. In addition to the low employment rate, they are subject to multiple and severe discrimination. Another issue that the report takes into account is the need for a definition of marginalised communities. Why do I think this is needed? Member States must retain responsibility for developing their own national indicators on the basis of which to develop a definition, but I believe that we need a number of guidelines from the Commission to harmonise the process.

name: Marc Tarabella (S&D)
text: In writing. Cohesion policy is one of the most powerful instruments at the disposal of the European Union to combat inequalities and support territorial and social cohesion in its regions. All European societies have groups and communities that are victims of structural exclusion and segregation by the majority of the population, and these groups do not have access to the most basic public infrastructure and services. In addition, they are very often affected by poverty, unemployment and poor sanitation in a totally disproportionate way. To vote for this text is all but logical.

name: Pavel Telička (ALDE)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of this resolution, which addresses social exclusion of marginalised communities, including the situation of the Roma. I believe that cohesion policy can be a useful tool in supporting the inclusion of marginalised communities, both in the economic, social and territorial senses. The resolution presents two key demands to the Commission. Firstly, to issue guidance on the definition of marginalised communities and, secondly, to provide detailed information on the funding opportunities. The resolution appeals also to the Member States to improve access to public service. Regarding the funding programmes, the resolution calls for integrated using of funds and stresses the importance of programmes for deprived neighbourhoods and isolated areas. It calls for proactive monitoring of EU-funded projects and for inclusion of women in the process.

name: Isabelle Thomas (S&D)
text: In writing. Cohesion policies aim to combat inequalities and disparities within the European Union. As an essential tool for social and regional harmonisation in Europe, they must help to put an end to discrimination against certain communities and promote their integration. In this report, we urge the European Commission to propose more precise and effective legislation to direct funds to stigmatized populations and groups. In particular, we fought to demand a clear definition of what a marginalized community is. Only in this way can we have effective mechanisms, able to fully realize the potential of cohesion policies, which must be a powerful vehicle for social integration. No, let us stress the need for swift and appropriate action towards Roma and Gypsy populations, who suffer from many discriminations. This is a strong signal that we are sending, as racist and xenophobic groups are making progress in Europe. We will be uncompromising on our values and will not accept any discrimination, no stigma of any kind on our continent.

name: Patrizia Toia (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 The proposals in this report are particularly interesting and very topical. The European Union's cohesion policy to eliminate inequalities and support territorial and social cohesion in its regions plays a major role in combating poverty and the social inclusion of the most vulnerable. The crisis has exacerbated inequalities, which is why Parliament insists that key areas, such as education, training and basic health, should be placed at the heart of all regional policies. We cannot allow groups and communities in all European societies to continue to exist that address exclusion and segregation. Only through an integrated approach to policies to support marginalizing communities can we overcome all the different forms of discrimination underlying the cultural, social and economic isolation that, unfortunately, we still see.

name: Valdemar Tomaševski (ECR)
text: Writing. \u2012 The main objective of cohesion policy must be to support territorial development and reduce regional disparities. It is therefore necessary to adopt specific horizontal measures in order to achieve this objective. The European Social Fund should be a key instrument for the implementation of the Europe 2020 strategy in the field of employment, labour market policy, mobility, education and training and social inclusion. In this way, the ESF would contribute to economic, social and territorial cohesion. The European Structural and Investment Funds should promote research and analysis aimed at creating an understanding of the real living conditions of marginalised communities. And cohesion policy should be an important tool used to shape performance-based policies in order to effectively create smart, sustainable economic growth in the regions where this is most needed. And it's all in order to keep jobs in the countryside and in remote areas. Such assumptions are worth supporting in the report.

name: Ruža Tomašić (ECR)
text: Written. ‒As a member of the Regional Development Committee, I support parts of the report that underline that the implementation of cohesion policy must focus particular attention on the key challenges of poverty and exclusion of young people, children and people with disabilities.  I also fully agree with the parts of the report on the bottom-up approach, namely the aspiration that EU funds, at the implementation stage, should be used in an integrated way through new territorial development instruments in cohesion policy 2014-2020: Integrated Territorial Investments (ITU) and Community-Led Local Development (CLLD), as they also highlight the important role that civil society can play in this segment. However, I believe that the protection of rights and the allocation of funds should not depend on certain subjective and utterly ideological factors such as belonging to arbitrarily selected groups, but solely on objective and above all measurable criteria that must be the same for all. So I voted abstention.

name: Romana Tomc (PPE)
text: Writing. I supported the report on cohesion policy and peripheral communities because I believe that a strong cohesion policy is very important in combating inequality. Marginal groups are often victims of discrimination and poverty and do not receive basic living goods, so cohesion policy must prevent this and involve marginal groups in society and enable them to live more decently.

name: Estefanía Torres Martínez (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. We voted in favour of this report aimed at increasing the social protection of minorities in Europe because we understand that all policies aimed at increasing social cohesion are positive, recognising the very existence of minorities and putting in place measures to improve the living conditions of the millions of people currently living at risk of social exclusion.

name: Ulrike Trebesius (ECR)
text: Writing. The own-initiative report by Mr Reintke (Greens) recommends changes to EU cohesion policy. This EU policy area accounts for more than a third of the total EU budget and aims to reduce economic and social inequalities in Europe, thereby strengthening social cohesion. The report calls for even greater attention to be paid to supporting marginalised communities in society, in particular Roma communities and the needs of women. Thus, there is still no uniform definition of marginalised social groups, and in particular in the case of so-called partnership agreements, too little attention is given to the needs of these marginalised groups. As the report itself points out, the legal bases on cohesion policy already set out a number of requirements for supporting marginalised social groups. In line with the principle of subsidiarity, it is up to eu Member States to implement these requirements within the framework of operational programmes. Further centralised regulation is not necessary, as it would unduly influence the policies of the individual EU Member States and create further bureaucratic hurdles for approving projects. I have therefore voted against the report.

name: Ramon Tremosa i Balcells (ALDE)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of this report as it is my belief that reducing the marginalisation of communities like the Roma should be a key priority for EU cohesion funds in those Member States where there are clear obstacles to their social and economic integration.

name: Mylène Troszczynski (ENF)
text: In writing. No social inclusion programme for Roma will be successful in the absence of a desire on their part to better integrate and respect the rules and customs of the Member States of residence. We consider that the factors of the marginalisation of the Roma community are mainly to be sought in its refusal to assimilate into the dominant culture of the Member State of residence as well as in the commission of numerous violations of the laws of the Latter. That is why we are opposed to the use of structural funds for projects and programmes for Roma communities.  I am voting against the adoption of this text.

name: Mihai Ţurcanu (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 The concept of 'marginalised communities' refers to various groups and individuals in society, such as minorities, Roma, people with disabilities, people living below the poverty line or at risk of poverty, migrants, refugees and socially excluded groups. The economic crisis and its budgetary cuts have repeatedly led to serious budgetary problems for municipalities and have led, in the Member States, to aggravation of existing problems such as unemployment, lack of social security and a lack of public health services. Moreover, it has led to a reduction and even a lack of action on marginalised groups aimed at improving their integration. The report underlines the need for a mobilisation of cohesion policy funds to improve living conditions and facilitate access for marginalised communities to education, housing, healthcare, jobs, childcare and social services. Furthermore, the need for a long-term perspective to be effective, as well as the mobilisation of mechanisms to guarantee impact on target groups and to address exclusion and marginalisation, is highlighted. I therefore voted in favour of the report on cohesion policy and marginalised communities.

name: István Ujhelyi (S&D)
text: Writing. \u2012 Marginalised communities have been placed at the heart of cohesion policy measures because of growing concern about social exclusion and a commitment to combat it. Including the situation of the Roma and the long-demanded improvement of their living conditions. The proposal calls on the Commission to provide guidance on the definition of marginalised communities, defining all the characteristics and characteristics of marginalised groups, taking into account the specific situation, challenges and needs of each potential target group in order to promote their socio-economic integration. I voted in favour of this proposal.

name: Miguel Urbán Crespo (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. We voted in favour of this report aimed at increasing the social protection of minorities in Europe because we understand that all policies aimed at increasing social cohesion are positive, recognising the very existence of minorities and putting in place measures to improve the living conditions of the millions of people currently living at risk of social exclusion.

name: Ivo Vajgl (ALDE)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of the resolution on cohesion policy and marginalised communities because I think the cohesion policy is one of the strongest instruments the European Union has at its disposal with which to fight inequality and support territorial and social cohesion in its regions. There are a wide variety of discriminatory structures in place, including sexual orientation and gender identity as well as different cultural, religious or ethnic backgrounds. Many people face different forms of discrimination at the same time, especially within Roma communities, which are very often marginalised within European societies. I agree that cohesion policy can play a powerful role in changing these realities. Not only when looking at challenges in housing or access to public infrastructure, as is already happening in the framework of the ERDF, but by providing an integrated approach to tackling all the different forms of discrimination that marginalised communities face. The resolution proposes different measures and recommendations to tackle this challenge to make our national and European societies more inclusive.

name: Ramón Luis Valcárcel Siso (PPE)
text: in writing. The report rightly highlights the importance of regional development funds for the integration of marginalized communities, especially after the impact of the economic crisis in recent years. Further promotes social cohesion, strengthens social inclusion and thus contributes to the objective of reducing at least 20 million people at risk of poverty and social exclusion in the EU, in accordance with the 2020 Strategy. This report is an important element of reflection on these issues, so I think it is necessary to vote in favour.

name: Elena Valenciano (S&D)
text: in writing. The legislative framework for cohesion policy ensures funding opportunities for marginalized communities in urban and rural areas. The 2014-2020 programming period is committed to the implementation of participatory local development and integrated territorial investments (ITIs) targeting marginalized communities.  With our vote in favour of the report, the Socialists call on the European Commission to adopt a definition of 'marginalized communities', which does not yet exist, with the aim of allowing these EU citizens to benefit even more from the European Structural and Investment Funds. The vote against paragraph 11 of the report is because that text assumes, through an erroneous and widespread approach, that the EU does not have structures for combating corruption and fraudulent use of funds (and existing ones are not responsible, transparent and democratic), and that marginalized communities are excluded from EU funds , which is the wrong assumption. The Socialists have always advocated maximum transparency in existing fund management structures and that marginalized communities continue to benefit from cohesion policy.

name: Ángela Vallina (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. I voted in favour of this report as it contains positive elements for the effective implementation, through cohesion policy, of the principle of non-discrimination contained in the Treaties. In this regard, the text calls on the European Commission to clarify the concept of marginalized communities; stresses that cuts in public services further complicate the situation of vulnerable groups; visibilizes existing racism and institutional discrimination towards communities such as Roma; calls for Member States to ensure the participation of partnerships working with marginalized communities as well; denounces the multiple discrimination against women, people with disabilities and migrants found in marginalized communities, among other groups. Therefore, and although the report is exclusively pro propositional, I voted in favour.

name: Derek Vaughan (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ Together with my EPLP colleagues I voted in favour of this report as I believe that the EU cohesion policy can be a powerful tool in addressing problems that marginalised communities face.  These issues range from unemployment, difficult housing conditions, low access to public services notably health services, as well as multiple forms of discrimination, social, cultural and economic exclusion, etc. and it is vital that we tackle them. I particularly welcome the report’s call for more and genuine involvement of representatives of marginalised communities in the development, implementation and management of EU funds and projects in this field, as I strongly believe that programmes and policies are most effective when those concerned are actually involved in the decision-making and management processes. This is a cornerstone of building a more effective Europe.

name: Hilde Vautmans (ALDE)
text: Written. I voted in favour of this resolution which seeks to address the issue of social exclusion of certain marginalised communities, such as the Roma. I believe that a cohesion policy can help to remove obstacles to better social and economic integration of such communities more quickly.

name: Marie-Christine Vergiat (GUE/NGL)
text: In writing. The term "marginalized communities" covers many concepts: disadvantaged social categories, people in situations of material deprivation, victims of discrimination (migrants, indigenous peoples, people with disabilities, etc.). Cohesion policy should play a leading role for these populations in providing financial assistance to governments to combat the consequences of marginalization. But in reality, this is not the case. This report calls for greater stakeholder participation and advances measures such as networking communities that address integration issues.  The ENF group, of which FN MPs are mainly members, has tabled amendments to remove all mentions of integration of migrants, Roma, access to funds for marginalized communities... and obviously voted against the text as a whole.  I, of course, voted for it, even if it is only a declaration of good intentions.

name: Miguel Viegas (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. \u2012 What is at stake in this report focuses on greater use of EU cohesion funds to support marginalised communities. Such support would be provided through the promotion and development of public health, education and social security services, the promotion of employability, cultural inclusion, gender equality and the participation of these communities in the definition of policies that affect them (political inclusion, participation and partnerships with representative organisations). It should be noted that the report is tended to seek an extended definition (of the EU context) of the concept of marginalised community, which presupposes a standardisation. The report, focusing on the use of the Structural Funds, also fits into the EU's objectives. These federalizing and revenue-making references to "one size fits all" are not, however, comprehensive in the report.

name: Harald Vilimsky (ENF)
text: Writing. The report leads to a further marginalisation of the majority society and the possibility of declaring all groups deemed politically opportune to be marginalised. It is completely incomprehensible why women, who make up more than 50 percent of the world's population, should be considered marginal. I am therefore voting against this report.

name: Daniele Viotti (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour because I am convinced of the importance of cohesion policy as an instrument for reducing social inequalities and eliminating poverty and exclusion. Cohesion policy has played a decisive role in promoting policies that promote social inclusion and equal opportunities for European citizens and combat the marginalisation of communities and groups of individuals who do not have access to education and health.

name: Udo Voigt (NI)
text: Writing. I voted against the draft European resolution on 'cohesion policy and marginalised social groups', because it seems to me to be a mockery of wanting to pursue minority policy, while the asylum crisis has left the peoples of Europe with their backs to the wall. The EU must first concern the preservation of Europe, its cultures and its peoples, and not any minorities whose members are de facto wealth-wealth emigrants, for example, in the case of many so-called 'refugees'.

name: Beatrix von Storch (ECR)
text: Writing. The European Parliament acts here as an 'announcement body'. A whole resolution deals with political guidelines on cohesion policy in favour of exclusively marginalised groups. However, the same resolution states at the outset that there is no definition of the term 'marginal social group'. For example, the first paragraph calls on the European Commission to come up with guidelines for the definition of 'marginalised social groups', which do not yet exist. This is a parliamentary shambles that wastes taxpayers' money and does not provide practical solutions to problems. That is why I rejected this resolution. If there are indeed problems with social marginalised groups that have not yet been defined in regions of the Member States, then these regions of the Member States are also best placed to find and implement suitable solutions – but not the EU.

name: Julie Ward (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ Together with my EPLP colleagues I voted in favour of this report, for which I was also the S&D shadow rapporteur, as I believe that the EU cohesion policy can be a powerful tool to address problems faced by marginalised communities, such as unemployment, poor housing conditions, limited access to public services, notably health services, multiple forms of discrimination and social, cultural and economic exclusion. I particularly welcome the report’s call for more and genuine involvement of representatives of marginalised communities in the development, implementation and management of EU funds and projects in this field, as I strongly believe that programmes and policies are most effective when those concerned are actually involved in the decision-making and management processes. The main achievement of the report is a strong unified call from MEPs for the Commission to provide guidance for a common definition of ‘marginalised communities’.

name: Iuliu Winkler (PPE)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of the report regarding the EU cohesion policy and marginalised communities. The crisis has had a direct negative impact on members of marginalised communities in the EU, in addition also many municipalities in the Member States still continue to face severe budgetary constraints which prevented them from dealing adequately with marginalisation in society. The main responsibility for changing the situation of marginalised communities lies with the Member States, but also the EU cohesion policy can play a powerful role in providing an integrated approach to tackling all the different forms of discrimination that marginalised communities face. Using EU funds for the inclusion of marginalised communities can become a great opportunity for promoting and supporting greater cohesion in European societies.

name: Anna Záborská (PPE)
text: Writing. \u2012 The present report repeatedly mentions the term 'gender', in most cases in relation to women's empowerment in marginalised communities and in recommendations aimed at supporting women in the use of cohesion budgets. At the same time, however, 'gender equality' also appears in contexts from which it is not clear whether it is equality between men and women in terms of labour policy, social policy and so on, or the requirement to recognise people's specific requirements, which are based on the different identities with which they share. Until these two planes are distinguished, the result will be confusing measures and pointless statistics that will do nothing to help marginalised communities or women in them.

name: Θεόδωρος Ζαγοράκης (PPE)
text: Writing. \u2012 I supported the rapporteur's view by voting in favour of this report, which was sufficiently discussed both in the committee responsible and during the plenary session.

name: Pablo Zalba Bidegain (PPE)
text: in writing. I totally agree with these policies. In particular, I will highlight the European Aid Fund for the Most Disadvantaged (FEAD), which is part of the EU cohesion policy and includes the free purchase, management and delivery of basic consumer goods to the most disadvantaged. FeAD, in part, replaces the food aid fund and redirects it to social support, so that food aid is linked to social accompaniment that helps marginalized communities overcome their situation. Moreover, I believe that we must not forget the Roma community, whose discrimination is a reality in the EU that must be dealt with from all its angles. I therefore support these policies focused on promoting cohesion and social inclusion in order to achieve the EU poverty eradication target, which seeks to reduce the number of people in the EU at risk of poverty and social exclusion by at least 20 million.

name: Tomáš Zdechovský (PPE)
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of this report because I am in favour of efforts to integrate all marginalised, i.e. minority and excluded, groups into society. These excluded and separated groups often do not have access to public infrastructure and services. That is why, in my opinion, it is necessary to target and use EU funds well, which cohesion policy does.

name: Jana Žitňanská (ECR)
text: Writing. \u2012 I supported the report on cohesion policy and its importance in relation to marginalised communities. Cohesion policy, in its full use in the Member States, can act as an important tool to combat inequality and to support communities facing exclusion and segregation in the European Union and suffering from poverty and unemployment, or poor access to public services, as well as to the finances provided by European Union funds. The report proposes solutions aimed at marginalised communities based on strong political will and an integrated approach, aiming in particular at improving these people's access to education, public services and their better information, for example to programmes aimed at promoting entrepreneurship. And since I can see that marginalisation in Slovakia is also a serious problem, not only with regard to ethnic minorities, but also, for example, people with disabilities, who tend to be denied access to quality education, actively finding solutions is, in my opinion, an important step forward.

name: Damiano Zoffoli (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 I find today's vote on cohesion policy and marginalised communities very important, two issues that intertwine and that politics cannot ignore or treat superficially. The cohesion policies and the funding that we are going to approve today will enable us to move more and more towards an inclusive Europe with solidarity, even with those who live on the margins of society. Avoiding the marginalisation of individual citizens, or even entire communities, is also important from the point of view of social security and the life of our cities.

name: Inês Cristina Zuber (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. The report focuses on greater use of EU cohesion funds to support marginalised communities. Such support would be provided through the promotion and development of public health, education and social security services, the promotion of employability, cultural inclusion, gender equality and the participation of these communities in the definition of the policies that affect them. We voted for it.

name: Milan Zver (PPE)
text: Writing. I voted for the European Parliament Resolution on Cohesion Policy and Peripheral Communities (2014/2247(INI)) because it calls for measures to remedy the situation, particularly for marginal groups and individuals of all ages, who face poverty and social exclusion and do not have access to education, employment, housing and healthcare systems. I believe that the integration of a peripheral community into society, such as the Roma community, requires, above all, the socialisation of children in the age of childcare and primary school.

name: David Campbell Bannerman (ECR).
text: – Mr President, I voted against this dangerous report, as it represents yet another EU power grab to usurp the sovereignty of democratic, elected Member State governments. This is all part of ʽever closer unionʼ and EU empire-building. Its call for ʽreform of the Security Council that would ensure a permanent seat to the EUʼ would force Britain and France to surrender their seats as permanent members of the UN Security Council. It would spell the end of Britain being at the heart of international security at the very time when the world faces such an unprecedented ISIS threat. This is a hostile attack on Britain’s and France’s sovereignty and one we must resist and reject. We have already had to give up our seat at the World Trade Organization, and we cannot do our own trade deals. We must not now give Brussels our seat on the Security Council.

name: Jiří Pospíšil (PPE).
text: – Mr President, I voted in favour of this report because I believe that the reform of the UN Security Council and the United Nations bodies in general must be addressed. It is clear at these times, when the security situation in the world, in Europe, is deteriorating, that the Security Council and the UN institutions in general are not able to act quickly and effectively enough. This means that if this report, which we have adopted today, will be another impetus for the Member States of the European Union to press the other UN Member States to implement the reform, then I personally will be satisfied. I think that there is also a logic to the fact that the European Union should have one seat on the Security Council, but I leave room here to have a debate on how the UN Security Council should be reformed in the future. But the current situation is not good, there is a need for change, and perhaps this report can contribute to that.

name: Andrejs Mamikins (S&D).
text: – Lately, the European Union has been positioning itself as something much bigger than a 10-strong transnational community or a supranational organisation. Today, it is already an integral part of the world's governance structure and institutes. And the European Union often positions itself as one of the most active in the world of the un-guiding principles in terms of the fight against global warming, conflict resolution, ending discrimination, cultural exchanges and so on. Although, because of conflicts and inserity between its Member States, the UN has not always been effective, which is also the case today, since the end of the Second World War, this major organisation has been one of the most important actor in international relations since the end of the Second World War. This leads to the logical conclusion that the European Union, even though its Member States are one of the main funders of the UN institutions, must play an active role in and influence the work of the UN. Thank you!

name: Deirdre Clune (PPE).
text: – Mr President, the role of the EU within the UN allows us to act in a forum that is designed to tackle global challenges. The Lisbon Treaty recognised the EU as one such partner when it was established. In times of international crisis and in the face of global challenges, it also allows the EU to participate, particularly through its High Representative for Foreign Affairs and Security. As we are speaking in times of global challenges, I think we should remind ourselves of what the UN was established for: to maintain international peace and security, to promote the peaceful settlement of disputes, to promote and protect human rights and fundamental freedoms, and to promote economic and social development. The EU, in conjunction with the UN, has a key role to play in addressing these challenges. Ireland joined the United Nations in 1955 – 60 years ago – and its membership of the UN allows it to progress its foreign policy objectives. I supported the report. I am happy to do so and happy to continue to participate in discussions as we evaluate the EU’s role in the UN.

name: Jill Seymour (EFDD).
text: – Mr President, the United Nations is a pretty self-explanatory organisation, with the key word being ‘nations’. The EU is not a nation, even though some in this place desperately want it to be. Is this another cynical plot for the EU to take over our UN seat? I hope not. The EU is not a nation and therefore has no place at the UN.

name: Seán Kelly (PPE).
text: – A Uachtaráin, arís vótáil mé i bhfabhar na tuarascála seo agus táim sásta leis, go háirithe ós rud é gur mise an rapóirtéir a bhí ag EPP don tuarascáil. So certainly this is a very important report, and I welcome the fact that we want greater cooperation and coordination with the United Nations, particularly when you think that the EU and its Member States are the biggest contributors to development and humanitarian aid through the United Nations. This is a very important facet. Often it is difficult to reconcile, particularly nowadays, that the EU itself is being targeted. We saw what happened in Paris, the threats in Brussels, by countries to whom we are giving a lot of help. This highlights the fact that we have to work harder in coordinating our efforts here, but also with the United Nations, to try and help these countries develop so that peace can be established and the terror comes to an end.

name: Daniel Hannan (ECR).
text: – Mr President, we keep hearing that federalism has peaked and that we are having a more loose, flexible approach, and that we have a new Commissioner who is trying to pass fewer regulations. Then we have these debates demanding a single EU seat at the United Nations. It is the supreme definition of statehood that you sit as a sovereign entity. My objection is not that it is the British and French seats which are being given up – of course I do object to that, but I do not expect vast sympathy from the rest of the House. It is to the idea that we are building a state and government without any underpinning sense of nationhood. There is no European public opinion, there is no European demos, there is no sense of community of identity in Europe in the way that there is in Sweden or Portugal or Hungary. So purely from bureaucratic fiat, we think that we can create a flag, put a state behind it and get people to fall in line. It does not work. Human nature is always stronger than bureaucratic plans. Nations exist because they are cohesive units. The European Union is not.

name: Diane Dodds (NI).
text: – Mr President, at a time of uncertainty and concern encompassing Europe in the aftermath of the callous terrorist attacks in Paris, it is hugely disappointing that this report on the role of the EU and the UN chooses to focus on integration and a single representative mandate for Europe rather than promote better national cooperation and coordination to the betterment of all our citizens. Instead of pursuing a seat for the EU on the UN or giving sound bites about the importance of Europe’s apparatus within the UN, attention should turn to how Europe can act as a liaison for national voices rather than purport to be the voice that trumps everything else. The DUP has believed – and always will believe – that governments elected by the people of the United Kingdom, and the armed forces that bravely defend our nation, are best placed to represent our interests on the world stage. We need no other voice. What we do need is better coordination, common-sense cooperation and, as in the statement given by Mr Cameron and President Hollande this week, a better awareness and knowledge of how we can work together nationally to face down the terrorist threat that faces many countries across Europe.

name: Jonathan Arnott (EFDD).
text: – Mr President, the UN is the United Nations. The European Union is not a nation, should never be a nation and cannot replace the nation. I hope, therefore, it is clear that the EU should have no role in the United Nations.

name: Diane James (EFDD).
text: – Mr President, the United Kingdom is one of two European Union Member States within the United Nations that have a permanent veto-holding status, France being the other. I will not support any European Union proposal that undermines, subverts or diminishes the UK’s position as a key United Nations member. The European Union may well have delusions of grandeur to supplant individual Member States on this important decision-making body, but I will never ever support that European Union objective. Therefore I voted against all of the key votes on this subject.

name: Bill Etheridge (EFDD).
text: – Mr President, well this is the easiest explanation of vote I will ever make, and it is quite simple. UN – United Nations. The EU is not a nation. The UK is a proud, sovereign, independent nation.
