It will always remain that way, I hope to God, and I shall certainly never play any part in that being changed, so I will always vote against measures like this, and I hope to goodness that we always maintain our independence, our sovereignty and our own individual place at the UN.

name: William (The Earl of) Dartmouth (EFDD)
text: in writing. ‒ UKIP voted against this report. The UK’s place on the UN Security Council, and our ability to act independently on the Security Council in the interests of the British people, is a corner stone of British security and of our position on the global stage.  This report seeks to impede that ability, primarily with the ultimate goal of giving the EU a permanent seat on the Security Council and by the assertion that, until this goal is reached, the UK must represent EU common positions decided by the High Representative and other Member States on the Security Council. UKIP believe that the British Government is elected by the British people to defend their interests on the global stage, not those of the European Union.

name: Marina Albiol Guzmán (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. In the face of the rise of wars and armed conflicts, I am fully convinced that, now more than ever, it is urgent to lay the groundwork for a new international order through UN reform, so that it has effective mechanisms in place to defend international law, human rights and multilateralism on a global scale. While I agree with the report on the need for UN reform that strengthens its legitimacy and gives it a more transparent and democratic functioning, I do not share the rapporteur's approach to this reform. It proposes to strengthen cooperation between the United Nations, the World Bank and the International Monetary Fund in order to increase the submission of States to organizations of the capitalist system at the international level. In addition, the report argues that the EU currently plays a role in promoting peace and preventing conflict and crisis management in the world, so it should have a permanent seat on the Security Council. This would undoubtedly be a downstop in the sovereignty of EU Member States. For these reasons I voted against it.

name: Martina Anderson and Lynn Boylan (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. – We voted against this report as it sought to call and support for the EU as a single entity to have a more significant role in dictating foreign policy, whilst decreasing the influence of Member States.

name: Pascal Arimont (PPE)
text: Writing. The EU's role in the UN is a key issue, given the growing global challenges and the forthcoming UN climate conference in Paris. I welcome this own-initiative report, which advocates, among other things, the establishment of an EU seat on the Security Council and calls for improved cooperation and coordination between Member States. This is the only way for the EU to be more focused on its joint efforts with the United Nations, particularly in terms of ensuring world peace, security, development aid and the protection of human rights.

name: Marie-Christine Arnautu (ENF)
text: In writing. In order not to change, this report is in the direction of an increasing abandonment of the sovereignty of States. Indeed, it proposes to force Member States, including those that have a veto in the Security Council, to coordinate their action. Furthermore, it promotes an alignment of the position of the Member States with the interests of the European Union, by proposing the creation of a seat of the Union on the Security Council, and the obligation for States to defend the Union's positions in the Security Council, as well as to keep informing other Member States of their intentions and positions. Thus, the Member States of the Union are asked to speak with one voice. Moreover, this report is ideologically worrying. It shows Brussels' ambition to shape the world in its image by imposing the recognition of a myriad of rights to LGBTI communities, the end of the death penalty everywhere, etc.  Finally, the text makes a provision which in itself sums up the nonsense of this report: the introduction of the climate refugee principle into international law.  I naturally voted against this text.

name: Jean Arthuis (ALDE)
text: In writing. I voted in favour of this report because it reiterates the european Union's (EU) commitment to effective multilateralism within the United Nations. This commitment is rooted in the belief that, in order to successfully respond to global crises, challenges and threats, the international community needs an effective multilateral system based on universal rights and values.

name: Zigmantas Balčytis (S&D)
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted on increasing the ROLE of the EU at the UN. The EU's security environment is becoming more unstable and volatile due to the large number of old or emerging security problems. The EU is actively involved in the work of the UN system in a number of ways and in various forms, but these efforts should be more visible. In order to better achieve its treaty-based foreign policy objectives, the EU should strive to strengthen global governance within the UN system and to increase its influence within itself and its Member States. The EU must actively support the comprehensive reform of the UN system in order to strengthen its legitimacy, regional representation, transparency, accountability and effectiveness in response to today's challenges. It is also important to revitalise the work of the General Assembly.

name: Gerard Batten (EFDD)
text: in writing. ‒ UKIP voted against this report. The UK’s place on the UN Security Council, and our ability to act independently on the Security Council in the interests of the British people, is a corner stone of British security and of our position on the global stage.  This report seeks to impede that ability, primarily with the ultimate goal of giving the EU a permanent seat on the Security Council and by the assertion that, until this goal is reached, the UK must represent EU common positions decided by the High Representative and other Member States on the Security Council. UKIP believe that the British Government is elected by the British people to defend their interests on the global stage, not those of the European Union.

name: Hugues Bayet (S&D)
text: In writing. I have endorsed this resolution, which stresses that the Union's foreign policy objectives will be better met within the framework of the United Nations. One example is the issues related to peace, security, development and respect for human rights that the Union faces and which must be answered on a global scale.

name: Beatriz Becerra Basterrechea (ALDE)
text: in writing. I voted in favour of this report because of the urgent need to strengthen the European Union's role at the UN, with the aim of achieving more satisfactorily the objectives of our foreign policy. The most important reform, defended with my work from the Committee on Development, is the development of the current Economic and Social Council in a Sustainable Development Council. This Council will ensure that UN agencies have a more political approach, and that coordination between them improves. Finally, I would like to highlight my positive vote in Amendment No 1, in which I urge the EU to support the strengthening of coherence, synergies and complementarities between the oversights of peace operations, the structure for peacebuilding of the United Nations and UN Security Council Resolution 1325 on women , peace and security. In addition, the amendment includes a revision of humanitarian aid policy, which now states that international humanitarian law and human rights legislation could justify offering women victims of war violations the possibility of unsused abortion.

name: Izaskun Bilbao Barandica (ALDE)
text: in writing. I voted in favour of this report to make better use of existing cooperation mechanisms to ensure that Member States in the UN Security Council defend the EU's common positions. Within this strategy to improve the EU's presence in the UN system there are also other proposals, such as revitalizing the work of the General Assembly and reforming the Economic and Social Council. I thank my teammate for the effort made.

name: Dominique Bilde (ENF)
text: In writing. I strongly opposed this text, which seeks to undermine the sovereignty of nations for the benefit of a world government and in total opposition to respect for democracy and the will of the peoples. The European Union, with its claims of a federal state and yet has already largely failed — the dramatic recent terrorist attacks remind us — in its objective of maintaining security and peace, thus seeks to break the voices of Member States at the United Nations, especially those who, like France, have a veto in the Security Council. The report also dares to take the most serious part of the world to self-congratulate itself on the "peace actions" carried out by the Union in the world, without taking the measure of its responsibility in the current destabilization of the Middle East and the Middle East.  Meanwhile, the report urges Member States to applaud with both hands the EU's irresponsible positions at the UN (see paragraph 6 of the report). The proponents of European federalism no longer even hide their desire to subserce European nations to the institutions of the Union (paragraph 14). Any patriot who has the peace, security and freedom of European nations at heart must therefore reject this text.

name: Mara Bizzotto (ENF)
text: in writing. \u2012 Although it is a report with content that is only partially acceptable, there are still passages that I consider controversial and contradictory, so I voted to abstain.

name: Malin Björk (GUE/NGL)
text: Written. I've dropped my voice. The report has many positive aspects. I appreciate, for example, the wording on work on human rights and gender equality, as well as the wordings on poverty reduction. It is also positive that Parliament is speaking out in favour of the next Secretary-General of the United Nations being a woman. However, the report also has a keynote that supports the idea of an EU-federal state, for example by aiming for a place for the EU in an enlarged UN Security Council. I am opposed to a common foreign and security policy and an EU federal state, which is why I choose to abstain.

name: José Blanco López (S&D)
text: in writing. I voted in favour of this report on the EU's position on reforms that can be carried out at the United Nations to strengthen the organisation and better achieve the EU's foreign policy objectives. I support the reform of the UNITED Nations system as a means of strengthening the efficiency of the organisation and better promoting the EU's foreign policy objectives. The EU must play an active role within the organisation, project its values, and contribute to effective multilateralism to provide global solutions to global problems. In this regard, we join the EU's request for a permanent seat in the Security Council. The Socialist amendments have enriched the report with references to human rights, gender equality, LGTBI rights, non-proliferation, the responsibility to protect and the moratorium on the death penalty. We also call on the EU to participate actively in the debate on the legal definition of the term "climate refugee" and express our wish that the next person elected to the post of Secretary-General of the United Nations be a woman.

name: Vilija Blinkevičiūtė (S&D)
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted on this report because the European Union, in full compliance with the provisions of the Charter of the United Nations, has a unique opportunity to mobilise the resources of various diplomatic, security, defence, economic, development and humanitarian instruments. The EU also plays an important role in concluding bilateral and multilateral trade agreements and has developed active trade policies to promote economic growth, poverty reduction and the protection of the environment and natural resources. In addition, the EU is one of the most committed defenders and promoters of human rights, fundamental freedoms, cultural values and diversity, democracy and the rule of law; whereas the provisions on these principles are included in all EU bilateral partnership agreements and have an important role to play in eu multilateral policies; whereas the EU has always been very active in international justice. The EU therefore plays an important role in supporting UN operations in areas of mutual interest, in particular in protecting civilians affected by armed conflict, in particular women and children. The European Parliament welcomes the EU's significant contribution to development aid and humanitarian aid worldwide. It is also important to stress that the EU, together with its Member States, contributes mainly to development aid and humanitarian aid in the world.

name: Andrea Bocskor (PPE)
text: Writing. \u2012 The Union's action at international level is based on the principles of democracy, the rule of law, equality, solidarity and the universal and indivisible nature of human rights and fundamental freedoms and respect for human dignity, as enshreined in Article 21 of the Treaty on Union. The report adopted today recalls that the principles and objectives of EU foreign policy are closely linked to the UN's objectives. It underlines that the challenges facing the EU require global solutions and global problems require EU action. It therefore needs global partners to achieve its objectives, namely peace and security and preventing the spread of terrorism.  The EU should therefore continue to strive to strengthen global governance within the UN. With regard to the migration and refugee crisis plaguing Europe, I voted in favour of this report, which calls, inter alia, on the EU and the UN to work more closely together to tackle the crisis and, among other things, to help remedy the economic situation in the countries where migration is based and to develop them sustainably. In view of the forthcoming UN Climate Change Conference in Paris, I also voted in favour of the EU and the UN stepping up their efforts to reach a legally binding agreement at this summit.

name: Franc Bogovič (PPE)
text: Writing. I agree with the report on the EU's role in the UN, which draws attention to shortcomings in the functioning of the ENTIRE EU-wide UN as the main global forum for improving the world order. The UN is undoubtedly the best forum for promoting the EU's values and interests by transferring them to a global level. However, there are many problems in the UN system of operation, which, in my opinion, go to the detriment of the EU. Indeed, the EU cannot act as a single entity within the UN, as the UN's action is directed at individual countries and not so much interstate organisations such as the EU. The EU itself also has problems with a patchy foreign policy, which is why it does not play the most important role in international relations. The interests of individual Member States play a significantly greater role here, and the interest of the EU as a whole is often sidelined, as it is often difficult to identify, let alone defend. Therefore, in tackling the current global challenges within the EU, unity, criticality and determination are needed, which must also be shown at UN level. Countries must stop thinking egotistical and defending their interests at all costs, but they must face the challenges side by side.

name: Simona Bonafè (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 The challenges facing us today require a global response and the main forum within which international governance can be strengthened and the interests of the European Union can be promoted remains that of the United Nations. The European Union's contribution to the international stage in the field of diplomatic and security action, in the field of humanitarian and economic aid, as well as its concrete commitment to promoting ambitious and sustainable environmental policies, place it at the forefront of the United Nations as well. However, in order to make the most of this potential and to ensure that its international action has real and effective value, the Union must act as united and united as possible. This is, for example, by making its voice heard on issues of fundamental importance, such as the reform of the United Nations system, and by expanding its influence, especially in areas where it has the tools and capabilities to take the lead, such as action for sustainable development.

name: Biljana Borzan (S&D)
text: Written. ‒ I support the UN Role Report.  I support the reform of the UN system as a means to strengthen the efficiency of the organisation and better promote the EU's foreign policy objectives.  I agree that the EU must play an active role within the organisation, preserve its values and contribute to effective multilateralism with a view to providing global solutions to global problems. I am also pleased that this report sends a strong message about the need to reform the Security Council with the hope that it will soon be possible to see a woman serving as Secretary-General of the United Nations.

name: Renata Briano (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 The European Union has a great responsibility to the world, both as a major macro-regional player and as a rich and developed reality that is a virtuous example of democracy, peaceful coexistence between different cultures and stability. The EU can and must play a leading role in the protection of human rights, in promoting a model of sustainable and inclusive development, in supporting democracy and civil liberties, in encouraging the fight against climate change, in spreading knowledge and knowledge, in advancing towards a fairer and more cohesive world, in combating dictatorships and international terrorism. But Europe can only do this if it speaks with one voice: it is necessary to throw one's heart over the obstacle and take the step forward. To initiate a federal constituent phase that equips the Union with a genuine European government with exclusive competences in defence, foreign policy and international emergencies. Only in this way will the voice of european citizens be even more authoritative and respected. Only in this way will the EU's contribution to the UNITED Nations be more useful and more effective.

name: Daniel Buda (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 The future of the European Union is linked to the peace, security, development and human rights situation worldwide, thereby clearly seeing the need for cooperation with the UN. The challenges facing the EU require global solutions, and global problems implicitly also require European action. Due to the close correlation between the principles and objectives of the European Union's foreign policy, which are enshrined in Article 21 of the Treaty on European Union and those of the UN, as well as the fact that Article 21 TEU explicitly calls for respect for the principles of the UN Charter and international law, the future of both organisations is intrinsically linked and their proper functioning also depends on how they manage their collaboration and actions. Given that the EU is already actively participating, under the auspices of the UN, in promoting peace, security and progress, it is necessary to strengthen the role of the Union and the Member States within the UN in all areas of external interest, including crisis management, prevention of atrocities, strengthening the rule of law, humanitarian crises and humanitarian aid. The EU cannot address these threats alone, but needs the support of international partners, which is why I voted in favour of this report, considering the collaboration between the EU and the UN as fundamental.

name: Gianluca Buonanno (ENF)
text: in writing. \u2012 Abstention vote because, although the report's comments on the current administrative management on the internal functioning of the United Nations and decision-making processes, spending commitments and activity reporting appear to be positive, they appear to be too opaque and effective. However, the EU's mere 'greater presence' in UN bodies would legitimate it too much as a political entity capable of representing the demands of the peoples of Europe. Therefore, within a necessary and urgent process of reform of the United Nations, greater decision-making weight of the individual Member States should be pursued.

name: Cristian-Silviu Buşoi (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 The EU needs global partners to achieve its foreign policy objectives, particularly in areas such as peace and security, organised crime, terrorism, regional conflicts, failed states and the proliferation of weapons of mass destruction. Article 21(1) TEU stipulates that the EU and its Member States share the values and principles of the UN Charter. The EU's security environment is increasingly unstable due to the large number of security challenges. Conflicts such as the one in Ukraine, Syria, Iraq, the rise of the terrorist organization ISIS, the crisis in Libya and the terrorist threat in Africa (Sahel, Libya and the Horn of Africa) are serious threats that require global response. I support the EP resolution proposal on the EU's role in the UN. I believe that in achieving its foreign policy objectives (as set out in the Treaty), it is important for the EU to work towards strengthening global governance within the UN system and to increase the extent of its influence within this system, all in the context of the EU's commitment to actively support a broad reform of the UN system, with the aim of strengthening its legitimacy, transparency and , regional representation, responsibility and effectiveness with which it responds to today's complex and multidimensional challenges.

name: Nicola Caputo (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the report on the 'ROLE of the EU in the United Nations', because the European Union is actively involved, under the aegis of the UN, in promoting peace, security and progress through its common foreign and security policy. The EU and its Member States therefore play a crucial role in promoting the principles and objectives of the UN and in solving humanity's common problems.  The UN must remain a strategic point of reference for the European Union's external action and the European Union, taking all its Member States into account, is the main net contributor to the world organisation's budget. Strengthening the EU within the UN is a step in the right direction, not least because it consolidates some of the most important achievements introduced by the Treaty of Lisbon.

name: Matt Carthy (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted against this report as it sought to call and support for the EU as a single entity to have a more significant role in dictating foreign policy, whilst decreasing the influence of Member States.

name: James Carver (EFDD)
text: in writing. ‒ UKIP voted against this report. The UK’s place on the UN Security Council, and our ability to act independently on the Security Council in the interests of the British people, is a corner stone of British security and of our position on the global stage.  This report seeks to impede that ability, primarily with the ultimate goal of giving the EU a permanent seat on the Security Council and by the assertion that, until this goal is reached, the UK must represent EU common positions decided by the High Representative and other Member States on the Security Council. UKIP believe that the British Government is elected by the British people to defend their interests on the global stage, not those of the European Union.

name: David Casa (PPE)
text: in writing. ‒ Although the rapporteur is right to point out the great involvement of the EU within the UN, our shared rights and numerous commitments, I voted against the report because it also seeks to justify abortion, which is against my beliefs and my conscience, and I could therefore not agree with it.

name: Fabio Massimo Castaldo (EFDD)
text: in writing. \u2012 Mr Väyrynen's report supports a UN reform process that will allow the EU to take on greater prominence both in the Security Council (CdS) and in the General Assembly, also taking into account all the powers guaranteed to the Union within the UN framework and referring to the proposal for an EU seat in an enlarged Security Council. Proposals are being made for the reform of the UN on three sets of measures: greater representativeness and a stronger role for the General Assembly, accompanied by a reform of the CdS that will increase its responsibilities as a world government; greater transparency and respect for gender equality for all UN institutions, starting with the Secretary-General; the transformation of the Economic and Social Council – or ECOSOC – into a body responsible for sustainable development. On the proposals for reform of the CdS, and in particular on the institution of the veto, permanent members are invited not to veto in cases of genocide or crimes against humanity. As far as the secretary-general is concerned, it is hoped that the next one will be a woman, which would be unprecedented in the history of the United Nations. My vote on this report was positive.

name: Nessa Childers (S&D)
text: in writing. – As part of a progressive agenda, I support the reform of the UN system as a means of strengthening the efficiency of the organisation and to better promote the EU’s foreign policy goals. The EU must play an active role within the United Nations and contribute to effective multilateralism with a view to providing global solutions to global problems. This report sends a strong message about the need to reform the Security Council and our Socialist Group wishes the next elected Secretary-General of the United Nations to be a woman in order to tackle gender—based discrimination in this opaque process of selection.

name: Caterina Chinnici (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 The European Union is one of the main regional organisations. Its work is fully in line with the principles of the UN Charter: in accordance with Articles 3 and 21 TEU, the Union defines and implements common policies and actions to ensure a high level of cooperation in all areas of international relations, and places among the objectives of its external action, peace, security, development and global human rights.  These are interrelated challenges that can only be addressed through strong and coherent action by the entire international community. The role of the Union's foreign policy as a unitary and authoritative player in the United Nations system can be decisive in this respect. This is particularly true of the defence of peace and security, the resolution of regional conflicts and the 'malfunctions' of states and, of course, the fight against terrorism, organised crime, the proliferation of firearms, explosives, and weapons of mass destruction. A reform of the UN system would therefore be useful in order to give the Union a permanent seat on an enlarged Security Council. With a view to moving in this direction, I voted in favour.

name: Λευτέρης Χριστοφόρου (
text: PPE), in writing. \u2012 The report calls on the EU to promote and support compliance with the principles of corporate social responsibility of the UN Global Compact.  The EU is called on to promote in UN forums the adoption of trade policies that provide effective incentives to respect these principles. For example, by establishing conditions for public procurement. The EU is also called upon to strengthen its role and participation in the regulatory working groups of the UN institutions. The content of the report is very important and we are treating it positively.

name: Salvatore Cicu (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the report on the EU's role in the UN. The European Union and its Member States share and promote the values and principles of the United Nations Charter (Article 21(1) TEU). The European Parliament therefore welcomes the EU's important contribution to development and humanitarian aid around the world and recalls that the EU has become a genuine international player with the status of 'privileged observer' at the UN and that the EU has committed itself to actively supporting an overall reform of the UN system, in order to strengthen its legitimacy and regional representation. Parliament stresses in particular its belief that the Security Council needs to be reformed and the EU's important long-term objective of having a seat on an enlarged Security Council. The European Parliament reiterates its call on the VP/HR for foreign and security policy to seek common EU positions on security council matters and supports the objective of establishing an investment protection regime at multilateral level.

name: Alberto Cirio (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of Paavo Väyrynen's report on the EU's role in the UN as I am in line with what is explained and analysed in the report. The EU's objectives and strengths lie in security and peace, which are linked to the development of global human rights. In this context, it must be borne in mind that the EU's strength lies precisely in its potential to mobilise resources across the full range of diplomatic, economic and humanitarian development areas. The European Union in international relations should be able to guarantee integrity and mobilization in favour of peace in accordance with the principles of the 1975 United Nations Charter. Against this background, the EU and its Member States play an active role and contribute to the work of the UN system in different formats and ways.

name: David Coburn (EFDD)
text: in writing. ‒ UKIP voted against this report. The UK’s place on the UN Security Council, and our ability to act independently on the Security Council in the interests of the British people, is a corner stone of British security and of our position on the global stage.  This report seeks to impede that ability, primarily with the ultimate goal of giving the EU a permanent seat on the Security Council and by the assertion that, until this goal is reached, the UK must represent EU common positions decided by the High Representative and other Member States on the Security Council. UKIP believe that the British Government is elected by the British people to defend their interests on the global stage, not those of the European Union.

name: Carlos Coelho (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 The United Nations system is the world's leading forum for global governance and is a stage for the promotion of the values and interests of the European Union and its Member States. The Union's new challenges and problems are inextricably linked to the UN's desiderates and system, as they lack global responses, and global problems also need European responses. Instability in EU security (conflicts in Ukraine, Syria, expansion of IS), development and humanitarian aid problems, challenges in the environment and climate change are not solvable in themselves, without a global response, with the support of the international community, under the auspices of the UN. However, the place due to the EU, in the panorama of major international actor, does not have its recognition due in the UN governance system, and it should aspire to its strengthening and increase of its own influence and that of its Member States.  Reforms in the rationalisation of its structures, working methods, budget and even the power of its Security Council must be carried out, and its blockade in situations of genocide and crimes against humanity is regrettable. To stress the importance of greater cooperation between the EU and the UN humanitarian aid agencies.

name: Jane Collins (EFDD)
text: in writing. – UKIP voted against this report. The UK’s place on the UN Security Council, and our ability to act independently on the Security Council in the interests of the British people, is a corner stone of British security and of our position on the global stage.  This report seeks to impede that ability, primarily with the ultimate goal of giving the EU a permanent seat on the Security Council and by the assertion that, until this goal is reached, the UK must represent EU common positions decided by the High Representative and other Member States on the Security Council. UKIP believe that the British Government is elected by the British people to defend their interests on the global stage, not those of the European Union.

name: Lara Comi (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of this important report which is gaining even more value today because of the situation we are experiencing, generated by the recent terrorist attacks. I agree with the proposals that have been made. Firstly, we need to reform the UN, both internally and in terms of objectives and instruments. Furthermore, it is essential for the Union to gain more weight within this system, coordinating more closely with the Member States and increasing its influence through its role as a privileged observer. I also believe it is important to improve early warning instruments to strengthen prevention, as well as to strengthen the role of the International Criminal Court.

name: Birgit Collin-Langen (PPE)
text: Writing. I voted in favour of the report because, in view of the existing and new security challenges (refugee issue, IS), we cannot find solutions in the EU alone and in isolation. A common solution is needed for all states. Only together with the United Nations will we be able to promote peace, security and progress in the world and in Europe. The EU must therefore play a more important role within the General Assembly.

name: Therese Comodini Cachia (PPE)
text: in writing. ‒ The EU and its Member States play an important role in continuing to foster peace, security, good governance and human rights. The EU is committed to the support of a comprehensive reform of the UN system to strengthen the institution, also through measures such as enhanced mediation capabilities, early warning tools, and achievable mandates for peacebuilding and peacekeeping operations. The amendment introducing paragraph 22a is however symptomatic of how reports include positions on issues which are within State competence, such as that of abortion on which I voted against. It was only because this amendment passed that I also voted against the report.

name: Javier Couso Permuy (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. In the face of the rise of wars and armed conflicts, I am fully convinced that, now more than ever, it is urgent to lay the groundwork for a new international order through UN reform, so that it has effective mechanisms in place to defend international law, human rights and multilateralism on a global scale. While I agree with the report on the need for UN reform that strengthens its legitimacy and gives it a more transparent and democratic functioning, I do not share the rapporteur's approach to this reform. It proposes to strengthen cooperation between the United Nations, the World Bank and the International Monetary Fund in order to increase the submission of States to organizations of the capitalist system at the international level. In addition, the report argues that the EU currently plays a role in promoting peace and preventing conflict and crisis management in the world, so it should have a permanent seat on the Security Council. This would undoubtedly be a downstop in the sovereignty of EU Member States. For these reasons I voted against it.

name: Andrea Cozzolino (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the resolution on strengthening the EU's role in the UN system because I believe that many of the problems facing the European Union in terms of peace and security, the environment and sustainable development, immigration and human rights, international trade and economic growth need global solutions. Therefore, I believe that the EU must work through effective and coordinated activities that strengthen its influence and that of the Member States within the UN system, which is the main global forum for improving global governance and is the best forum in which to promote the EU's values and interests.

name: Pál Csáky (PPE)
text: Writing. \u2012 The principles and objectives of the European Union's foreign policy are laid down in Article 21 of the Treaty on European Union and are closely linked to the objectives of the United Nations. Article 21 TSI explicitly provides for respect for the principles of the UN Charter and international law The EU makes a significant contribution to development and humanitarian aid around the world; recalls that the EU and its Member States are collectively the world's largest donors of development and humanitarian aid. As the report points out that, in order to better achieve the foreign policy objectives set out in the Treaty, the Union should seek to strengthen global governance within the UN system and increase its own and its Member States' influence, and whereas it recalls the Union's commitment to support the comprehensive reform of the UN system in order to strengthen the legitimacy, regional representation, transparency, accountability and ability to respond to today's complex, multifaceted challenges, I supported the report.

name: Miriam Dalli (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ The report in question deals with the European Union’s specific role within the United Nations, as a separate entity to its Member States. The report aims at putting forward suggestions to better the EU’s foreign policy in these aspects – at a crucial point in time where the EU must take on a central role in international affairs. I support such changes as I believe that the EU must play an active role within the organisation by projecting its values and contributing in providing global solutions to global problems. I am also satisfied that the report sends a strong message about the need to reform the Security Council and that it expresses its wish to see a woman elected as Secretary-General of the United Nations.

name: Daniel Dalton (ECR)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted against this report because it calls for a single, permanent European Union seat on the United Nations Security Council. Two Member States of the European Union, France and the United Kingdom, already have permanent seats on the United Nations Security Council and I do not believe either country should be forced to give up its seat to the European Union. The Security Council is entirely composed of sovereign nation states and there is no precedent or purpose in a supranational body taking up a seat on the council.  For myself personally, and the British Government, it is of fundamental importance that the United Kingdom, a founder member of the United Nations, retains its permanent seat on the Security Council. With its strong commitment to upholding international law, the United Kingdom has led moves for reform to make the UN more effective and efficient in delivering peace and security. The UN desperately needs reform and undermining the national sovereignty of key UN members will only hinder significant positive progress.

name: Viorica Dăncilă (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 I fully support the initiative to persuade the European Union to support a woman for the post of UN Secretary-General, an initiative which states that the EU will support a woman in the next elections for the post of UN Secretary-General. In this way we could witness a world premiere by choosing a woman for a prestigious and global position.

name: Nicola Danti (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 The European Union is a central pillar of the UN system and has already amply demonstrated over the years the positive contribution it can make to the activities of the United Nations. The convinced and constant cooperation between the European Union and the United Nations has succeeded in recent years in strengthening the principles of multilateralism in the world. The need for greater cooperation with the UN and the strengthening of the EU's voice in the UN has been repeatedly stressed within the EU institutions. Also in the light of the new global crises and the many challenges of global governance, the EU must work to further strengthen UN action and make the decision-making process of the entire UN system more effective, making the most of partnerships with UN agencies, funds, programmes, committees and specialised committees and playing a more coordinated role within the General Assembly.

name: Michel Dantin (PPE)
text: In writing. This initiative report underlines the importance of the Eu's role as an observer at the United Nations, as well as the various rights that the statute grants it, such as proposing texts and amendments or raising procedural motions at assemblies.  This text first of all recalls the commitment of the Union and its Member States to the values and principles of the Charter of the United Nations, which they have the role of defending in the context of external action. It also recalls the Union's role as the main contributor to development and humanitarian aid. The report's proposals focus on the reform of the Security Council, whose composition and functioning no longer reflect the balance of the current powers, with a view to improving the UN's prevention and early warning instruments. The report aims above all to promote a common European position through the action of the Vice-President and High Representative of the Union. For these reasons, I supported this text.

name: Rachida Dati (PPE)
text: In writing. I supported this report because it is important that the Union can play a greater role, alongside the Member States, in the UN General Assembly. The Union, which defends democracy and human rights and promotes peace and security, is indeed a key contributor to humanitarian and development aid within the framework of UN programmes.

name: Marielle de Sarnez (ALDE)
text: In writing. In the face of armed conflict, regional instability and global ecological or health scourges, there is a need to improve the internal functioning of the United Nations. In particular, why not imagine that when it comes to crimes against humanity, there should be no veto or blockage. There is also a need to improve collaboration between powers such as the United Nations and the European Union. To do so, the European Union's presence in international for a must also be strengthened and, if possible, it must speak with one voice on international issues.

name: Andor Deli (PPE)
text: Writing. \u2012 The Union's action at international level is based on the principles of democracy, the rule of law, equality, solidarity and the universal and indivisible nature of human rights and fundamental freedoms and respect for human dignity, as enshreined in Article 21 of the Treaty on Union. The report adopted today recalls that the principles and objectives of EU foreign policy are closely linked to the UN's objectives. It underlines that the challenges facing the EU require global solutions and global problems require EU action. It therefore needs global partners to achieve its objectives, namely peace and security and preventing the spread of terrorism.  The Union should therefore continue to strive to strengthen global governance within the UN and reform the Security Council in order to better reflect the new world situation. With regard to the migration and refugee crisis plaguing Europe, I voted in favour of this report, which calls, inter alia, on the EU and the UN to work more closely together to tackle the crisis and, among other things, to help remedy the economic situation in the countries where migration is based and to develop them sustainably. In view of the forthcoming UN Climate Change Conference in Paris, I also voted in favour of the EU and the UN stepping up their efforts to reach a legally binding agreement at this summit.

name: Mark Demesmaeker (ECR)
text: Written. – The N-VA delegation voted in favour of this report. We have to be realistic, the European Union will not be given a seat on the Security Council in the near future. Nevertheless, we are firmly in favour of a greater role for the Union within the United Nations. Our delegation therefore believes that the European Parliament and other EU institutions should, in the long term, seek an EU seat on the Security Council. After all, the highest UN body must become more representative so that the reality of the beginning of the 21st century is better reflected.

name: Tamás Deutsch (PPE)
text: Writing. – The Union's action at international level is based on the principles of democracy, the rule of law, equality, solidarity and the universal and indivisible nature of human rights and fundamental freedoms and respect for human dignity, as laid down in Article 21 of the Treaty on Union. The report adopted today recalls that the principles and objectives of EU foreign policy are closely linked to the UN's objectives. In view of the forthcoming UN Climate Change Conference in Paris, I also voted in favour of the EU and the UN stepping up their efforts to reach a legally binding agreement at this summit.

name: Ian Duncan (ECR)
text: in writing. ‒ I will vote against this report due to the inclusion of a demand for a single EU seat on the United Nations Security Council. This is a red line issue given the United Kingdom’s permanent status on the UNSC.

name: Ангел Джамбазки (ECR)
text: in writing. \u2012 I did not support this report because I do not believe that it is directed in the right direction, namely international cooperation and coordination. Whether the EU should have a place in an enlarged UN composition is the question posed here and the rapporteur believes that such a place should be allocated to our Union. However, I believe that this is a Union that must cooperate based on the idea of peace, but not become a federal state that has its own governance. Member States' sovereignty must be maintained, which means that the EU is not and cannot be a country and cannot be represented as a full member of the UN Security Council, but can definitely work towards coordination between Member States and international cooperation.

name: Γεώργιος Επιτήδειος (
text: NI), in writing. \u2012 Abstention, because while in many of its articles, it gives the EU the power to implement its foreign policy, on the other hand there are important negative points that show that ultimately its participation in this game is not what it should be, in order to be the most important factor of influence for the global political and geopolitical changes that are taking place, since it is once again tied to the US chariot.

name: Norbert Erdős (PPE)
text: Writing. \u2012 The Union's action at international level is based on the principles of democracy, the rule of law, equality, solidarity and the universal and indivisible nature of human rights and fundamental freedoms and respect for human dignity, as enshreined in Article 21 of the Treaty on Union. The report adopted today recalls that the principles and objectives of EU foreign policy are closely linked to the UN's objectives. With regard to the migration and refugee crisis plaguing Europe, I voted in favour of this report, which calls, inter alia, on the EU and the UN to work more closely together to tackle the crisis and, among other things, to help remedy the economic situation in the countries where migration is based and to develop them sustainably. In view of the forthcoming UN Climate Change Conference in Paris, I also voted in favour of the EU and the UN stepping up their efforts to reach a legally binding agreement at this summit.

name: Rosa Estaràs Ferragut (PPE)
text: in writing. The EU and its Member States share the values and principles of the Charter of the United Nations and play a crucial role in promoting these principles, as well as the objectives of the United Nations. The EU and its Member States also play an active role and contribute to the United Nations in different forms and formats, contributions that should be more visible. In this regard, as a member of the EP Framework for the Implementation of the United Nations Convention on the Rights of Persons with Disabilities, I have the opportunity to contribute to this EU relationship with the United Nations, as well as to gain a first-hand view of important aspects that can help and energize this collaboration. Specifically, and in the area of the application of CRDPs in the EU, the United Nations Committee presented its "Final Comments" in September. They continue a constructive dialogue in which the parties identify the various issues to be improved by the EU in order to adapt their policies and measures to the CRPD. This dynamic of collaboration is representative of how the EU and the United Nations can take advantage of their synergies.

name: José Manuel Fernandes (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 The design of the European Union is linked to peace, security, development and human rights on a global scale and the challenges it faces need global responses which, in turn, lack European action. The EU promotes an international system based on strengthening multilateral cooperation and good global governance and is committed to authentic multilateralism, with the United Nations at its centre. This is based on the conviction that, in order to respond effectively to global crises, challenges and threats, the international community needs an effective multilateral system based on universal rights and values. In order to better achieve its foreign policy objectives, the EU must aspire to strengthen global governance within the UN system and to increase its own influence and that of its Member States in that system. I voted in favour.

name: João Ferreira (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. \u2012 This report is unacceptable, for its content, for its objectives.  Only a very skewed reading of the Charter of the United Nations can you consider that the European Union shares its values and principles, as this report does. What then about the direct participation in the military aggressions carried out against sovereign countries, violating their independence and territorial integrity, as happened in the cases of Iraq, Libya or Syria, among others? This report carries an unacceptable view of how the EU should act within the UN and, in particular, within its General Assembly – a body of which the EU should not even be a part, given the nature of both the body and the EU itself.  We cannot accept the proposal that the EU be part of the Security Council, nor for changes to be made to the UN institutional framework to align it with the EU's interests (i.e. the powers that command it) in foreign policy matters. It is unacceptable to attempt to force sovereign states to submit to previously determined EU positions in discussions at the UN.  This report is an exponent of the most disjointed federalist jumps within the EU. Obviously we voted against it.

name: Luke Ming Flanagan (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. ‒ I reject the approach of this report which believes the EU should use the UN for achieving its foreign policy goals. Therefore I voted against.

name: Monika Flašíková Beňová (S&D)
text: Writing. \u2012 The European Union upholds the values of the protection of human rights, security and acts to preserve peace, prevent conflicts and strengthen international security, in accordance with the principles of the UN Charter as well as the objectives of the Charter of Paris for a new Europe. At the same time, we are a leading actor in the various policy areas that are interconnected. We strive for environmental sustainability, strengthen the basis of social cohesion and believe that humanity brings together common values and interests. We respect the UN system as the main global forum for improving global governance and as the most effective form for promoting the values and interests of the European Union.

name: Lorenzo Fontana (ENF)
text: in writing. \u2012 The EU's role in the UN needs to be completely reviewed. I hope that some Member States will be able to denounce this hypocrisy, the scandals and the power games that have been made. How the whole IS case has been handled is proof of this.

name: Λάμπρος Φουντούλης (
text: NI), in writing. \u2012 I am voting here on the report on the role of the EU within the United Nations, in order to better achieve the EU's foreign policy objectives, because while in many articles it gives the EU the power to implement its foreign policy, on the other hand there are significant negative points that show that ultimately its participation in this game is not what it should be in order to be the most important influence factor for global policies and geopolitical changes taking place, since once again it is tied to the U.S. chariot.

name: Doru-Claudian Frunzulică (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ Today we are called to face unforeseen, dramatic events that are already changing the world forever. The number of humanitarian emergencies has never been higher and the refugee crisis represents the ultimate test for the cohesion of the European Union. In order to deal effectively and successfully with these transnational issues, it is fundamental that we strengthen cooperation with the UN institutions, making sure that our values are promoted, our ambitions are commonly shared and our engagements are mutually respected. We should therefore push for the establishment of a high-level dialogue on the implementation of the Sustainable Development Goals. In order to achieve them, further cooperation is required in the areas of education, health, climate action, food and nutrition, water, sanitation and hygiene, child protection, gender equality, social inclusion, humanitarian aid, migration, human rights, non-discrimination on all ground, good governance and democracy building. In particular, I would like to underline that one of our main priorities should be the protection of children and of women, whose protection is crucial for the achievement of sustainable and equitable development for all.

name: Kinga Gál (PPE)
text: Writing. \u2012 The Union's action at international level is based on the principles of democracy, the rule of law, equality, solidarity and the universal and indivisible nature of human rights and fundamental freedoms and respect for human dignity, as enshreined in Article 21 of the Treaty on Union. The report adopted today recalls that the principles and objectives of EU foreign policy are closely linked to the UN's objectives. It underlines that the challenges facing the EU require global solutions and global problems require EU action. It therefore needs global partners to achieve its objectives, namely peace and security and preventing the spread of terrorism.  The Union should therefore continue to strive to strengthen global governance within the UN and reform the Security Council in order to better reflect the new world situation. With regard to the migration and refugee crisis plaguing Europe, I voted in favour of this report, which calls, inter alia, on the EU and the UN to work more closely together to tackle the crisis and, among other things, to help remedy the economic situation in the countries where migration is based and to develop them sustainably. In view of the forthcoming UN Climate Change Conference in Paris, I also voted in favour of the EU and the UN stepping up their efforts to reach a legally binding agreement at this summit.

name: Ildikó Gáll-Pelcz (PPE)
text: Writing. \u2012 I welcome the active participation and contribution of the EU and its Member States in various ways and forms to the work of the UN system, which should be made more visible. Furthermore, the EU's significant contribution to development and humanitarian aid around the world; recalls that the EU and its Member States are collectively the world's largest donors of development and humanitarian aid. I think it is important to point out that the Union has become a genuine international player and that, accordingly, it has a high-profile observer status at the UN. In order to better achieve EU foreign policy objectives within the UN, the Union must play a strengthened role with greater visibility and political influence, enabling it to better implement its international obligations in line with the General Assembly Resolution of 3 May 2011. In my opinion, the role of parliaments and regional assemblies within the UN system should also be supported.

name: Francesc Gambús (PPE)
text: in writing. I voted in favour of the report fully convinced of the need to move towards further integration of European foreign policy. The EU already has the status of "privileged observer" at the United Nations, with the right to intervene in General Assembly meetings, but Member States must coordinate more and better to convey to the world the EU's common foreign policy. The EU must act as a true global player within the United Nations and must continue to strive to increase its influence and visibility on the international stage.

name: Enrico Gasbarra (S&D)
text: in writing. The European Union is the most successful historical example of regional integration and cooperation in the world. The ideal and concrete contribution to world peace that Europe can make must be strengthened by all means, especially in view of the many global crises that are open today. I therefore agree with the structure of Mr Vayrinen's report, which, on behalf of the Committee on Foreign Affairs, Has presented a very ambitious text with points of great interest. I think it is important to reiterate, as the resolution does, that the EU should seek to strengthen global governance within the UN system and increase its influence and that of the Member States within that system. The European Union must actively support a comprehensive reform of the United Nations system in order to strengthen its legitimacy, regional representativeness and transparency, accountability and effectiveness in responding to today's complex and complex challenges. I am sure that the work of high representative Federica Mogherini will live up to this important objective.

name: Elena Gentile (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted strongly in favour of the resolution on the role of the European Union in the United Nations – how best to achieve the Union's foreign policy objectives, because I believe that the EU is a key player in the international context and plays a predominant role in ensuring and supporting global peace, stability and security processes.  Indeed, there is no doubt that the objectives of the EU's external policy are closely linked to those of the UN and that the UN is the EU's most important forum for global governance and conflict and dispute resolution.  The international picture is now becoming increasingly unstable and hotbeds of tension, if not real conflicts, are occurring in various parts of the world. The situation in eastern Ukraine, the civil war in Syria, the advance of terrorist organisations such as ISIS or Boko Haram represent global threats that must be addressed and resolved under the aegis of the UN. Finally, I believe that the problem of environmental sustainability is a serious problem for future generations and can no longer be put off. I therefore hope, at the UN Climate Conference (COP21), for fruitful cooperation between the EU and the UN in order to ensure that a binding and universal agreement is reached.

name: Arne Gericke (ECR)
text: Writing. I voted today against the non-legislative own-initiative report on 'The role of the EU within the United Nations: how can the EU's external objectives be better achieved?' because I believe that the approach adopted there is wrong to strengthen the EU's role in the UN. I am convinced that we need more pragmatic action rather than ideological positions in order to achieve more worldwide.

name: Jens Gieseke (PPE)
text: Writing. Many European challenges need to be solved internationally. That is why we must continue to work closely with the United Nations in the future. This requires a stronger EU position within the United Nations. Comprehensive reforms are also needed to meet the new challenges of a changing world view.

name: Neena Gill (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of this report given that the EU needs to play a more significant and coherent role within the UN. States should honour their promises to provide humanitarian aid and a coherent and coordinated approach should be adopted across EU and UN institutions to the refugee crisis. These and other recommendations detailed in the report are crucial to strengthen the organisation and achieve EU foreign policy goals.

name: Juan Carlos Girauta Vidal (ALDE)
text: in writing. ‒ The EU and its Member States share the values of the UN Charter and play a crucial role in promoting these principles and the Millennium Goals. In an increasingly unstable security environment, EU needs global partners to achieve its foreign policy goals, in particular in the fight against organised crime, human trafficking, terrorism and regional conflicts, but also to improve access to education, healthcare and the promotion of human rights.  I therefore welcome this resolution that recalls the commitment of the EU in supporting a comprehensive reform of the UN system to strengthen its legitimacy, regional representations, effectiveness and accountability and that puts forwards recommendations in order to better achieve EU foreign policy goals within the UN.

name: Tania González Peñas (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. I abstained in the vote on this report on the EU's role within the United Nations. The report contains positive references to the importance of the United Nations in addressing international problems in a range of areas, from humanitarian aid to security and peace to global public goods. However, the report calls for strengthening the EU's role in the United Nations, which we consider contradictory to the principle of multilateralism and democratic representation of all States within the organisation, a principle that is one of its core values.

name: Theresa Griffin (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ Together with my EPLP colleagues, I support the reform of the UN system as a means of strengthening the efficiency of the organisation and to better promote the EU’s foreign policy goals. I voted in favour of this report because I believe that the EU must play an active role within the organisation, project its values and contribute to effective multilateralism with a view to providing global solutions to global problems. I am confident that this report will send a strong message about the need for reform in the Security Council and, importantly, I believe that we need to see women elected to the post of Secretary-General of the United Nations.

name: Françoise Grossetête (PPE)
text: In writing. I voted in favour of this report because it aims to strengthen the role of the European Union (EU) in the United Nations. In addition to its 28 Member States, including France, which is a member of the Security Council by law, the Union enjoys the status of "privileged observer" at the United Nations. This status gives its High Representative for Foreign Affairs the opportunity to speak at the General Assembly, submit proposals and amendments, present motions of order and disseminate documents. I regret, however, that the EU, for lack of a real common strategy on defence and international relations, is no more asserting itself within the United Nations and is not more visible in it. However, there should be a clear leadership position on migration or security crises, or on the situation in the Middle East. I am indeed very concerned about the passivity of the United Nations in the face of the current crises in our continent, which concern not only Europe but the entire international community.

name: Antanas Guoga (ALDE)
text: in writing. ‒ I believe that in order to better achieve its foreign policy goals the EU should strengthen global governance inside the UN system and to increase its own and its Member States’ influence within that system. Also, the EU should play enhanced role in the General Assembly.

name: András Gyürk (PPE)
text: Writing. \u2012 The Union's action at international level is based on the principles of democracy, the rule of law, equality, solidarity and the universal and indivisible nature of human rights and fundamental freedoms and respect for human dignity, as enshreined in Article 21 of the Treaty on Union. The report adopted today recalls that the principles and objectives of EU foreign policy are closely linked to the UN's objectives. It underlines that the challenges facing the EU require global solutions and global problems require EU action. It therefore needs global partners to achieve its objectives, namely peace and security and preventing the spread of terrorism.  The Union should therefore continue to strive to strengthen global governance within the UN and reform the Security Council in order to better reflect the new world situation. With regard to the migration and refugee crisis plaguing Europe, I voted in favour of this report, which calls, inter alia, on the EU and the UN to work more closely together to tackle the crisis and, among other things, to help remedy the economic situation in the countries where migration is based and to develop them sustainably. In view of the forthcoming UN Climate Change Conference in Paris, I also voted in favour of the EU and the UN stepping up their efforts to reach a legally binding agreement at this summit.

name: Τάκης Χατζηγεωργίου (
text: GUE/NGL), in writing. \u2012 Within the Committee on Foreign Affairs, reports and discussions have recently attempted to promote the idea of the EU as a global player at political level. This report is part of this framework. The presentation of the problems facing the region promotes on the one hand the need, as the report understands it, to coordinate the action of EU Member States within the UN and, on the other hand, the position of the EU seat on the Security Council, positions with which we disagree. The report also promotes the idea that the High Representative should have the responsibility of coordinating the Member States and that they should be placed on the basis of the EU's foreign policy and interests. The report also has several positive points, such as criticism of the selection of the Agency's General Staff, but also the presentation of issues requiring global solutions and cooperation between all.  Given the positive and negative elements in the report, we will abstain.

name: Marian Harkin (ALDE)
text: in writing. ‒ Focusing on the role of the European Union within the United Nations system and on how to better achieve EU foreign policy goals within the UN, I voted in favour of this report as it contains a number of excellent recommendations and objectives in line with the stated foreign policy objectives of the EU. The report paves the way for an annual process in which the European Parliament can address the global challenges in a more meaningful and comprehensive way, as it calls on us to organise its work in the same way as the Commission, encouraging all committees whose remit covers policies that have an external and global dimension to forward their opinions to the Committee on Foreign Affairs, which has responsibility for the VP/HR report.

name: Brian Hayes (PPE)
text: in writing. ‒ I decided to support this report due to the fact that the EU and its Member States have a crucial role to play in promoting the shared values and principles of the UN, as well as the goals of the UN, through the external action of the European Union. The EU is committed to actively supporting a comprehensive reform of the UN system in order to strengthen its legitimacy, its regional representation and its transparency, accountability and effectiveness. It is important to improve preventive and early-warning tools and enhanced UN mediation capabilities, with coherent and achievable mandates for peacebuilding and peacekeeping operations.

name: Roger Helmer (EFDD)
text: in writing. ‒ UKIP voted against this report. The UK’s place on the UN Security Council, and our ability to act independently on the Security Council in the interests of the British people, is a corner stone of British security and of our position on the global stage.  This report seeks to impede that ability, primarily with the ultimate goal of giving the EU a permanent seat on the Security Council and by the assertion that, until this goal is reached, the UK must represent EU common positions decided by the High Representative and other Member States on the Security Council. UKIP believe that the British Government is elected by the British people to defend their interests on the global stage, not those of the European Union.

name: Hans-Olaf Henkel (ECR)
text: Writing. The own-initiative report aims to clearly define the role of the European Union within the United Nations. Reference is made to Article 21 of the Treaty on European Union, which lists the maintenance or promotion of democracy, the rule of law and fundamental rights as common foreign policy objectives of the EU Member States, as well as compliance with the other principles set out in the Charter of the United Nations. The report rightly states that the Security Council urgently needs to be reformed in order to maintain a good capacity to act, since, in its current composition, it does not represent a geographically balanced representation of interests, but still reflects the geopolitical conditions of 1945. For example, I am in favour of A permanent seat for Germany on the Security Council, because today Germany, as the third largest contributor to the United Nations, has considerably less influence over the United Nations and, in particular, the Security Council than the five veto powers. Further reforms of the United Nations are also needed. However, the report calls for a permanent EU seat on the Security Council, even though the EU is not a state but an international organisation and as such cannot be a member of the United Nations under current rules. That is why I rejected the report. Incidentally, I believe that the euro must be abolished because it leads to strife and discord in Europe!

name: György Hölvényi (PPE)
text: Writing. \u2012 The Union's action at international level is based on the principles of democracy, the rule of law, equality, solidarity and the universal and indivisible nature of human rights and fundamental freedoms and respect for human dignity. This is also laid down in Article 21 of the Treaty on Union. The report adopted today recalls that the principles and objectives of EU foreign policy are closely linked to the UN's objectives. It underlines that the challenges facing the EU require global solutions and global problems require EU action. It therefore needs global partners in peace and security and in preventing the spread of terrorism in order to achieve its objectives.  The Union should continue to strive to strengthen global governance within the UN and reform the Security Council in order to better reflect the new world situation. With regard to the migration and refugee crisis plaguing Europe, I voted in favour of this report, which calls, inter alia, on the EU and the UN to work more closely together to tackle the crisis and, among other things, to help remedy the economic situation in the countries where migration is based and to develop them sustainably.

name: Richard Howitt (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ Labour MEPs voted for this report, reflecting our deep commitment to supporting multilateralism in the world, and to back an active European Union role in the United Nations in pursuit of objectives for conflict resolution, human rights, international development and the fight against climate change. However, the European Parliamentary Labour Party voted against the sentence which suggested there should be a single EU seat in the UN Security Council. We strongly support UN reform – including of the Security Council – to reflect today’s reality and to support a fairer balance between developed, emerging and developing countries. But we do not believe that has to be achieved at the expense of the loss of my own country’s permanent seat, which British Labour has always sought to use for the very same objectives which we support for the European role. Euro-sceptics in Britain want to mislead our public by saying that we have to choose between promoting our own country’s interests and our country’s enthusiastic participation in the European Union.  The UN is just one example of where this is a false choice. We can do both.

name: Ian Hudghton (Verts/ALE)
text: in writing. ‒ This House is voting on this report at a time of great tension internationally. The ongoing civil war in Syria is directly linked to events in Paris and Brussels and today’s downing of a Russian jet will only heighten tensions. The United Nations remains a vital part of international diplomacy and it is crucial that the EU and all its Member States continue to engage through the UN as situations develop.

name: Cătălin Sorin Ivan (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ I support the reform of the UN as a means of strengthening the efficiency of the organisation. The EU must play an active role within the organisation, project its values and contribute to providing global solutions to global problems.

name: Ivan Jakovčić (ALDE)
text: Written. ‒ I voted for the UN Report on the ROLE of the EU – how to better achieve the EU's foreign policy objectives, as this is a very important topic especially in a situation where major changes, instability and uncertainty are happening in the European environment that also affect the security situation within the EU. It should be noted that the principles and objectives of EU foreign policy are enshrined in Article 21 of the treaty on European Union and are closely linked to the principles and objectives of the UN.  The UN-sponsored EU actively participates in promoting world peace, security and progress through a common foreign and security policy and a common security and defence policy. The EU and the Member States make the greatest financial contribution to the general BUDGET of the UN and its provision of humanitarian and official development assistance and peacekeeping operations. In order for the EU to better achieve its foreign policy objectives as outlined in the Treaty, work needs to be done to strengthen global governance within the UN system and increase its influence there.  It is necessary to reiterate the Union's demand that the UN simplify its structures, budget and working methods, then reform the UN Security Council in order to better reflect the world's reality and better address security challenges.

name: Jean-François Jalkh (ENF)
text: In writing. This report is a continuation of the abandonment of Member States' sovereignty. On the one hand, it proposes to force Member States, including those that have veto power in the Security Council, to coordinate their action. On the other hand, it promotes an alignment of the position of Member States with EU interests, by proposing the creation of an EU seat on the Security Council, and the obligation for states to defend EU positions in the Security Council, as well as to keep other Member States informed of their intentions and positions. Ultimately, the EU must speak with one voice at the United Nations. The report also aims to "make the world a remake" from Brussels. Indeed, when its provisions do not require the next Secretary-General to be a woman and to fight discrimination among UN staff, they expressly call for the Security Council to take more account of LGBT rights, or to impose zero tolerance for the death penalty worldwide.  Finally, the text makes a provision that sums up the nonsense of this text: the introduction of the climate refugee principle into international law.  I voted against it.

name: Petr Ježek (ALDE)
text: Writing. \u2012 I supported this report because of the need to strengthen the Role of the European Union in solving global problems. There is no doubt about the indispensableness of the United Nations' genuine involvement in addressing the current migration crisis and in the fight against terrorism. It is therefore desirable that a united and decisive voice of the European Union be heard on its soil, for which this report also proposes concrete steps.

name: Marc Joulaud (PPE)
text: In writing. I voted in favour of my colleague Paavo Vayrynen's report on the role of the European Union in the United Nations. The text recalls the commitment of the European Union and its Member States to the principles of the United Nations Charter on the international stage. It also calls for a reform of the United Nations system in which the Union participates as a privileged observer. This reform is necessary to strengthen the legitimacy, accountability and effectiveness of the United Nations. This report was adopted by a large majority, which I welcome.

name: Josu Juaristi Abaunz (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. ‒ EH Bildu supports multilateralism and in particular international cooperation within the framework of the UN. We support the efforts within the UN for a reform which should focus on democratising the existing structures, such as reform of the UN Security Council, the establishment of a less opaque process for selecting the UN Secretary-General, and gender mainstreaming within UN bodies, and to make clear the role of the EU in the UN.  We welcome some contributions introduced in the report, such as the promotion of equity and non-discrimination, the first UN Security Council Meeting on LGBTI rights, which is a significant step toward the consecution of it, and the inclusion of the safeguard of the right to asylum. However, we reject the approach of the report according to which the EU should use the UN to achieve its foreign policy goals. Moreover we do not agree with maintaining the decision-making structures of the World Bank and the IMF. Therefore EH Bildu abstained on the final vote of this report.

name: Philippe Juvin (PPE)
text: In writing. I voted in favour of this report, which recalls the key role that the Union plays in the UN system, sharing the values and objectives of this organisation. In particular, this report recalls the EU's major contribution to humanitarian aid and development around the world. He insists on the European Union's support for an overhaul of the United Nations in order to achieve a more legitimate, responsible and effective system.

name: Barbara Kappel (ENF)
text: Writing. I do not agree with the report on 'The role of the EU within the United Nations: how can the EU's external objectives be better achieved?'. Although there are some positive aspects to the report, it must be rejected in its entirety. The aspirations recorded therein are incompatible with the political guidelines and ideals of our group and our party.

name: Rikke Karlsson (ECR)
text: In writing. Once again, the Union is gradually trying to take the place of sovereign states in an international organisation, as it did in the WTO in particular.  The EU does not actually have its own foreign policy, it is not a state and does not have to become one, although it has the legal personality, for lack of a single European people. Europe is a continent rich in its twenty-eight nations, which, until proven otherwise, do not intend to merge into one, but to cooperate as much as possible with respect for their respective identities.
