In both the United Nations General Assembly and the Security Council, only the representatives and diplomats of our nations have a legitimate place.

name: Afzal Khan (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ I supported the report, as it inter alia analyses and sets out the EU approach to the role of the EU within the UN, detailing reforms to be carried out within the UN with the aim of strengthening the organisation and better achieving EU foreign policy goals. It also calls for the EU to play a more significant and coherent role within the UN, for states to honour their promises to provide humanitarian aid and for a coherent and coordinated approach across EU and UN institutions to the refugee crisis.

name: Bernd Kölmel (ECR)
text: Writing. The own-initiative report by Paavo Väyrynen (EPP) aims to clearly define the role of the European Union within the United Nations. Reference is made to Article 21 of the Treaty on European Union, which lists the maintenance or promotion of democracy, the rule of law and fundamental rights as common foreign policy objectives of the EU Member States, as well as compliance with the other principles set out in the Charter of the United Nations. The report rightly states that the Security Council urgently needs to be reformed in order to maintain a good capacity to act, since, in its current composition, it does not represent a geographically balanced representation of interests, but still reflects the geopolitical conditions of 1945. For example, I am in favour of A permanent seat for Germany on the Security Council, because today Germany, as the third largest contributor to the United Nations, has considerably less influence over the United Nations and, in particular, the Security Council than the five veto powers. Further reforms of the United Nations are also needed. However, the report calls for a permanent EU seat on the Security Council, even though the EU is not a state but an international organisation and as such cannot be a member of the United Nations under current rules. That is why I rejected the report.

name: Ádám Kósa (PPE)
text: Writing. \u2012 The Union's action at international level is based on the principles of democracy, the rule of law, equality, solidarity and the universal and indivisible nature of human rights and fundamental freedoms and respect for human dignity, as enshreined in Article 21 of the Treaty on Union. The report adopted today recalls that the principles and objectives of EU foreign policy are closely linked to the UN's objectives. It underlines that the challenges facing the EU require global solutions and global problems require EU action. It therefore needs global partners to achieve its objectives, namely peace and security and preventing the spread of terrorism.  The Union should therefore continue to strive to strengthen global governance within the UN and reform the Security Council in order to better reflect the new world situation. With regard to the migration and refugee crisis plaguing Europe, I voted in favour of this report, which calls, inter alia, on the EU and the UN to work more closely together to tackle the crisis and, among other things, to help remedy the economic situation in the countries where migration is based and to develop them sustainably. In view of the forthcoming UN Climate Change Conference in Paris, I also voted in favour of the EU and the UN stepping up their efforts to reach a legally binding agreement at this summit.

name: Stelios Kouloglou (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. ‒ The UN is the first level for putting international relations on a legal base. The report gives a strategic orientation for the participation of the EU within the UN system. The EU should actively support a reform of the UN in order to strengthen its legitimacy, accountability and effectiveness. Another positive aspect of the report is the will to reform also the UN Security Council. However, the questions of an EU seat and EU peace enforcing operations remain unsolved. Therefore, I abstained from the vote on this report, since I cannot fully support it.

name: Илхан Кючюк (ALDE)
text: in writing. \u2012 I supported this report because the European Union is a global actor and must play a leading role in safeguarding world peace, security, development and human rights. The European Union, with its unique structure, has a serious set of tools that can be implemented within the UN to set the global agenda. I believe that we must continue to be a leading global player in the fight against poverty, promote the sustainable economic, social and environmental progress of developing countries, because this is a guarantee of lasting peace and stability. We need to continue to have a leading position to support UN operations in areas of mutual interest, in particular in the protection of civilians, especially women and children affected by armed conflicts. All of these objectives can only be achieved when the EU has solid partners on the world stage with which to cooperate closely to address global challenges.

name: Gabrielius Landsbergis (PPE)
text: Writing. \u2012 The European Union does indeed have the great and not yet fully exploited potential of a global actor. The EU plays an important role in promoting democratisation, the defence of human rights and freedoms, economic, political and social reforms in various parts of the world. With strong leadership, a strong defence of international rights and norms in the 28-member community is a great value in the modern world. It should be noted that reform of the United Nations Security Council is necessary, starting with the abolition of the right of veto to those members who are aggressors in violation of international law. Knowing that aggression against the sovereignty and independence of other states automatically deprives the aggressor of obstructing the resolution of the conflict and the restoration of justice would act as a serious prevention. Nor should the right of veto be applied to matters of crimes against humanity and war crimes prohibited by international law and which do not have a limitation period.

name: Giovanni La Via (PPE)
text: in writing. I voted in favour of this important motion for a resolution on the EU's role in the United Nations. Given the growing challenges on the international stage, I believe that dialogue between the EU and the United Nations is of fundamental importance. In this context, this rule proposes means of relaunching the role of the General Assembly and reforming the United Nations Security Council. In particular, this proposal calls for improved international instruments that can be activated and used under the aegis of the United Nations in the field of early warning and peace keeping operations. For its part, the EU, taking into account also the recent atrocities and human rights violations perpetrated by certain extremist and terrorist groups, must offer concrete support to peace-building and maintenance operations and strengthen its mediation efforts in conflict resolution.

name: Constance Le Grip (PPE)
text: In writing. I voted in favour of the report on the role of the European Union in the United Nations. Indeed, I believe it is important to increase the Union's international influence by coordinating the external policies of the Member States more effectively and by strengthening cooperation between the Union and the United Nations. However, I abstained on paragraph 14 of the report, because I believe that a possible reform of the UN Security Council through the establishment of an enlarged Security Council with a seat for the European Union can only be envisaged in the long term and without the presence of France and the United Kingdom as permanent members being called into question.

name: Marine Le Pen (ENF)
text: In writing. I voted against the resolution on the role of the European Union in the United Nations. Firstly, as the name suggests, the United Nations is a forum where nations are represented, not supranational organisations such as the European Union.  The fact that the EU has become an actor in the UN General Assembly is in itself rather paradoxical. It is therefore difficult to take seriously the desire expressed in paragraph 14 of the report to obtain a seat on an enlarged Security Council. In addition, the report wants to force Member States to defend the positions of the European Union in the Security Council, which goes against national sovereignty.

name: Paloma López Bermejo (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. In the face of the rise of wars and armed conflicts, I am fully convinced that, now more than ever, it is urgent to lay the groundwork for a new international order through UN reform, so that it has effective mechanisms in place to defend international law, human rights and multilateralism on a global scale. While I agree with the report on the need for UN reform that strengthens its legitimacy and gives it a more transparent and democratic functioning, I do not share the rapporteur's approach to this reform. It proposes to strengthen cooperation between the United Nations, the World Bank and the International Monetary Fund in order to increase the submission of States to organizations of the capitalist system at the international level. In addition, the report argues that the EU currently plays a role in promoting peace and preventing conflict and crisis management in the world, so it should have a permanent seat on the Security Council. This would undoubtedly be a downstop in the sovereignty of EU Member States. For these reasons I voted against it.

name: Bernd Lucke (ECR)
text: Writing. The own-initiative report by Paavo Väyrynen (EPP) aims to clearly define the role of the European Union within the United Nations. Reference is made to Article 21 of the Treaty on European Union, which lists the maintenance or promotion of democracy, the rule of law and fundamental rights as common foreign policy objectives of the EU Member States, as well as compliance with the other principles set out in the Charter of the United Nations. The report rightly states that the Security Council urgently needs to be reformed in order to maintain a good capacity to act, since, in its current composition, it does not represent a geographically balanced representation of interests, but still reflects the geopolitical conditions of 1945. For example, I am in favour of A permanent seat for Germany on the Security Council, because today Germany, as the third largest contributor to the United Nations, has considerably less influence over the United Nations and, in particular, the Security Council than the five veto powers. Further reforms of the United Nations are also needed. However, the report calls for a permanent EU seat on the Security Council, even though the EU is not a state but an international organisation and as such cannot be a member of the United Nations under current rules. That is why I rejected the report.

name: Krystyna Łybacka (S&D)
text: I would like to write to the Commission. \u2012 I supported the report on the role of the European Union in the UN. The Committee on Culture and Education has prepared an opinion for this report. As a member of this Commission, I have highlighted education as an important instrument for achieving EU foreign policy objectives, such as peace-building and stability in the world, long-term development, intercultural dialogue and the fight against poverty both within the EU and worldwide. In this context, it is essential to increase cooperation between the EU and the UN to support education for all, improve access to education, improve its quality and strengthen education systems worldwide.  The report should also be followed by cooperation between the EU and the UN on education in the framework of rescue programmes in the event of a humanitarian crisis, armed conflict or natural disasters.

name: Petr Mach (EFDD)
text: Writing. \u2012 The European Union cannot have any role in the UN because it is not a state and it is not supposed to speak for the states that are already represented here.

name: Ivana Maletić (PPE)
text: Written. ‒ The future of the European Union is closely linked to world peace, security and the development and respect of human rights. The challenges we face require global solutions and greater support from international organisations and partners.    The EU-UN relationship is currently not satisfactory, although Member States are allocating large funding to the general UN budget, their peacekeeping operations, as well as the provision of humanitarian and development assistance. In addition, the EU is a signatory to more than 50 multilateral agreements and the UN Conventions as the only non-state participant. For this reason, the EU has earned special status within the UN, in order to gain greater importance in foreign policy, and to position itself as a single international stakeholder.   I supported Paavo Väyrynn's report, as I believe that better EU-UN cooperation would contribute to achieving the EU's foreign policy objectives, in particular with regard to the fight against terrorism that Europe is currently facing. The UN's unanimous adoption of the French Resolution on Combating Terrorism is a step forward in international cooperation, to create a secure Europe and preserve European values.

name: Vladimír Maňka (S&D)
text: Writing. \u2012 Since 1974, the EU has been a permanent observer at the UN General Assembly. It has observer status in most specialised UN agencies.  This increases the interdependence of the policies of both actors and their value objectives, in particular in the areas of security, peace and human rights protection. At the same time, the EU, together with its Member States, is the UN's largest financial contributor. The events of recent months, the conflict in Ukraine, the situation in the Middle East, Syria, Islamic State terrorism and other global challenges require a rethink and strengthening of the European Union's position vis-à-vis the UN, as well as a reform of the UN itself. It must become an action and flexible organisation with transparent bodies and their choice, with transparent policies, transparent funding and close scrutiny by the EU and all Member States.

name: Vladimír Maňka (S&D)
text: Writing. – The provision of assistance to EU Member States must be transparent, comprehensible, as simple as possible, and at the same time controllable and monitorable rules. For aid to be effective, it must be timely and flexible. I support the adoption of measures to simplify rules that will strengthen legal certainty both on the PART of the EU and on the part of beneficiaries, Member States, towns, municipalities and small and medium-sized enterprises.

name: Νότης Μαριάς (
text: ECR), in writing. \u2012 I am voting against the report on the ROLE of the EU within the UN - ways to better achieve the EU's foreign policy objectives, because it is not complete and documented.

name: David Martin (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ I welcome this report and would stress the view that free and fair trade in itself is the most useful tool in helping developing countries to help themselves. It points out the major impact that trade and investment can have on the sustainable development of least advanced poor countries and on fighting poverty and combating human rights violations where it is tailored accordingly, carried out with long-term objectives, clearly targeted, framed within clear performance rules, and connected with counterbalancing measures for transition periods, for instance through specific programmes for trade preferences, trade sanctions, regulation of trade in certain goods which could be used for capital punishment, torture, inhuman or degrading treatment and punishment, and certification systems regulating trade in conflict minerals. It calls, therefore, for the EU to develop ambitious, efficient and active trade policy measures for promoting the UN’s Sustainable Development Goals (SDGs) and the Millennium Development Goals (MDGs); believes, with regard to the conclusion of the Doha Development Round, that the UN can use its unique position in the multilateral agenda to ensure that those talks are a success for developing countries.

name: Fulvio Martusciello (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 The report on the 'role of the European Union in the United Nations – how best to achieve the Union's foreign policy objectives' is favourable to me. The UNITED Nations system aims to improve global governance and is the best forum where we can promote the values of the European Union. In turn, the European Union shares and promotes the values and objectives of the UN Charter, for example by promoting peace, security and progress (think of the common foreign and security policy – CFSP – and the Common Security and Defence Policy – CSDP), promoting economic, social and environmental progress in developing countries, combating social and food inequalities and poverty, and providing humanitarian assistance. In addition, the Union, together with its States, is the main financial contribution from the UN general budget. It is therefore appropriate to increase joint efforts between the EU and the UNITED Nations, promoting shared values and supporting governments, civil societies and populations in the poorest countries. Greater and more intensive cooperation between the EU-UN will facilitate the participation of civil society in the political process, improve the lives of future generations and ensure fair and sustainable development for all.

name: Emmanuel Maurel (S&D)
text: In writing. Like France, the European Union is one of the most loyal allies of the UN system. In the face of the current crisis of multilateralism, the Vayrynen report puts forward both proposals for UN institutional reforms and welcome statements on EU foreign policy. At the institutional level, the text takes up a long-standing position defended by France: the right of veto should not be used by the members of the Security Council in the event of genocide or crimes against humanity. On the merits, the report is in favour of a moratorium on the death penalty and better implementation of the Nuclear Non-Proliferation Treaty. Moreover, at a time when population displacements linked to climate change are increasing (rising waters, droughts, etc.), the text opens the door to the drafting of an international definition of "climate refugees". Finally, on the commercial front, I have ensured - as rapporteur of the Socialist Group on this text in the INTA committee - that the report supports the end of private arbitration of investor-state disputes and that Parliament commits itself to a public international court.

name: Georg Mayer (ENF)
text: Writing. The report contains some positive points. However, the report seems to want to push further centralisation of the EU. Moreover, it is questionable whether the countries represented so far can retain their seat if the EU were to have its own seat. I therefore reject this report.

name: Jean-Luc Mélenchon (GUE/NGL)
text: In writing. This annual report on the EU's role at the UN proposes some reforms to make the global organization more "transparent", including the appointment of its Secretary-General. The main aim is to strengthen the EU's place in the UN system in terms of its 'contribution to world peace and security' and ultimately to secure a seat for the EU like that of the Member States. Proposals that are completely hypocritical and very meagre in view of the current issues, when it would have been possible to commit, for example, to support the peoples in the fight against Daesh. The report even calls on France to comply with the EU's wishes in the Security Council. It advocates the integration of the WTO, the IMF — and the future international arbitration court of the draft transatlantic agreement (GMT) — into the UN without changing their oligarchic functioning, which would only maim the legitimacy of the United Nations and invite more multinationals to the negotiating table. I vote against and I denounce the vote of the French Members who participate in this weakening of the international organization for peace.

name: Joëlle Mélin (ENF)
text: In writing. This report is a continuation of the EU-orchestrated abandonment of the sovereignty of Member States. On the one hand, it proposes to force Member States, including those who have veto power in the Security Council, to coordinate their action, on the other hand, it promotes an alignment of the position of Member States with EU interests, by proposing the creation of an EU seat on the Security Council, and the obligation for states to defend EU positions in the Security Council , as well as keeping other Member States informed of their intentions and positions. Ultimately, the aim is for the EU to speak with one voice to the United Nations. In line with her political line, the Member naturally votes against this report.

name: Nuno Melo (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the European Parliament's motion for a resolution on the importance and role of the EU within the UNITED NATIONS.  Sharing values, principles, objectives, the EU and the United Nations share challenges that cannot be addressed without a global response.  Ways are defined for the EU to achieve foreign policy objectives within the UN, either in terms of visibility, in terms of strengthening the political weight, or through more effective coordination with UN agencies.

name: Louis Michel (ALDE)
text: Written. – In this report, the European Parliament calls for the special partnership shared by the EU and the UN to be extended and strengthened in a number of areas. We face a number of global challenges, such as increasing insecurity, climate challenges, epidemics, migration and the safeguarding of human rights, all of which require a strong, agreeable, global and collective response. In order to anticipate these current and future challenges better and more effectively, the UN, as a world organisation, must not avoid a number of reforms, including the reform of the UN Security Council.  It is still composed on the basis of the geostrategic balances of just after the Second World War. In the meantime, the balance of power has changed, new economies have emerged, major nations have disintegrated, other multinational organisations have gained importance. A recast of the UN Security Council on the basis of these new geostrategic balances is therefore desirable and a permanent representation of the EU in this body has been recommended. A modern UN Security Council will also need to act more quickly, more alertly and more politically in the case of conflicts and security problems.

name: Miroslav Mikolášik (PPE)
text: Writing. \u2012 Given that the future of the European Union is linked to global peace and security, I welcome the report on the EU's role within the UN, because I consider it necessary to consider how to better meet the EU's foreign policy objectives. In a situation where the Union's security is threatened as a result of a large number of long-term or emerging security challenges, I consider it a priority, above all, to clearly name the primary objectives. And these are undoubtedly, after the current events in Paris and other threats across the EU, especially the conflicts in Syria and Iraq and the rise of the terrorist organisation ISIS, as well as the conflict in eastern Ukraine. These are serious global challenges that require a global response where the Union needs the support of international partners. Without peace, it will not be possible to achieve any other, however important, objectives. It is therefore all the more important for the future to support prevention within the UN system so that early warnings are turned into immediate action, which presents a real chance of preventing atrocities against the population, thus aiding the Union's commitment to defending respect for humanitarian principles, human rights and refugee rights.

name: Marlene Mizzi (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ I have voted in favour of this report, which states that the EU must play an active role within the organisation, project its values, and contribute to effective multilateralism with a view of providing global solutions to global problems. The report sends a strong message about the need of reforming the Security Council and expresses its wish to see a woman elected as Secretary-General of the United Nations. However, I have never supported paragraphs guaranteeing women the right to sexual and reproductive health and safe abortion.

name: Csaba Molnár (S&D)
text: Writing. \u2012 Report of the Committee on Foreign Affairs proposes to promote the achievement of the EU's foreign policy objectives within the UN. Given that I endorse the EU's foreign policy objectives and I consider the report's proposals to enforce them to be reasonable, I supported the adoption of this report.

name: Cláudia Monteiro de Aguiar (PPE)
text: in writing. The Principles and Objectives of the European Union on foreign policy are enshrined in Article 21 of the Treaty on European Union and have a close relationship with the principles and objectives of the United Nations. It is important to safeguard that the future of the European Union is related to peace, security, development and human rights on a global scale, and Europe should actively contribute to building global responses. I welcome this report with a view to better achieving the strengthening of global governance within the UN system and increasing its own influence and that of its Member States in that system.  I also believe that the EU should play a more significant role at the General Assembly and that it will be necessary to reform the Security Council in order to better reflect the new global reality and respond more effectively to current and future security challenges.

name: Sophie Montel (ENF)
text: In writing. This report on the role of the European Union in the United Nations is a new blow to the sovereignty of member states. Indeed, he believes that global issues must call for a coordinated European intervention by increasing the EU's influence, notably in the UN General Assembly and the Security Council, where there is talk of the adoption of a single EU seat. Thus, there is a mechanism to compel Member States, including those that have veto power in the Security Council, to coordinate their action. It also wants to force permanent or non-permanent Member States to defend EU positions in the UN Security Council. The report recalls that the ECHR is an example for the progress of human rights even though, according to the Commission, it no longer applies in Greece as it is under the influence of the memorandums. It also introduces the principle of "climate refugee" into international law.  In short, this text is an alignment of pearls more Europeanistic than the other. So I voted against it.

name: Nadine Morano (PPE)
text: In writing. I voted in favour of this report on the role of the European Union in the United Nations. I support the measures in this text which call on the Union to strengthen its role in this international forum, in particular to promote economic growth, reduce poverty and protect the environment. The report recalls that the EU is the largest contributor to the budget for humanitarian aid, official development assistance and UN peacekeeping operations. It calls for a thorough reform of the UN system to strengthen its legitimacy, accountability and effectiveness.

name: Alessia Maria Mosca (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 Given the importance of the United Nations as the most important and comprehensive assembly for the improvement and definition of global governance, I can only welcome a proposal that aim to improve its functioning. The recent events in Paris, the drift of the Situation in Syria and the continuing serious instability in the Middle East make it clear that there is a need for an effective multilateral approach to global issues under the aegis of the UN.  A stronger and more efficient model of international cooperation is, in fact, consistent with European foreign policy and would facilitate its achievement of its objectives. Given the primary role played at international level, especially with neighbouring countries, I support the provision of a permanent EU seat in a reformed Security Council. With this in mind, bearing in mind the provisions of Chapter VII of the United Nations Charter on the promotion and inclusion of regional organisations, we call for a strengthening of the role of the European Union and its counterparts both within the UN and in the more general global governance. Given my political commitment, the personal battles that have been fought in this area and the consistency with the values of the European Union, I share the hope that the next UN Secretary-General will be a woman.

name: Renaud Muselier (PPE)
text: In writing. I was not able to vote for this report, but I fully support the position of the EPP Group and the French delegation to adopt this report. It stresses that the Union and its Member States share the values and principles of the UN Charter and play a key role in promoting these principles and the objectives of the United Nations.  The report welcomes the fact that the Union and its Member States are actively involved and contributing to the work of the UNITED Nations system in different ways and in different forms, while believing that they should be more visible. It also serves as a reminder of the EU's major contribution to humanitarian aid and development around the world, and reminds us that the Union and its Member States are jointly the world's leading provider of humanitarian and development aid.

name: Victor Negrescu (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ I have voted for this report that should improve the EU’s prosperity, better protect its security and ensure that its governments comply with global rules, not only to safeguard Europe’s prosperity and security but also with the intention of spreading respect for democracy, human rights, and the rule of law.

name: Момчил Неков (S&D)
text: in writing. – Culture is an important element in the EU's external diplomatic relations because it has the merit of stimulating dialogue and mutual understanding. I stand by the position that it must be an essential component of political dialogue with third countries and be systematically integrated into development projects and programmes.   The refugee situation and the Paris attacks make it all the more obvious that cooperation between the EU and the UN is strengthened. I therefore defend the view that culture needs to be given a more visible and bright place in the Millennium Goals for Sustainable Development and post-2015. I believe that we need to lay the foundations for a permanent dialogue and deepen cooperation in the field of education and culture in the long term. That is why I have called for the establishment of a high-level annual structural dialogue in order to be able to meet common challenges in a more sustainable way.

name: Liadh Ní Riada (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. ‒ We voted against this report as it sought to call and support for the EU as a single entity to have a more significant role in dictating foreign policy, whilst decreasing the influence of Member States.

name: Norica Nicolai (ALDE)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of this report as it highlights some major points concerning the current nature of the United Nations Organisation which I think, if reformed, would be beneficial to the EU in particular and the whole world in general. The fact that, taken together, the Union is a major economic, political and military actor in the world, with two nuclear powers, a large population and immense political power, reflects, I believe, the outdated nature of the UN Security Council. The UN needs a deep and comprehensive reform, streamlining the UNSC, but also the rules of the UNGA, the coordination between its bodies, more tools for its key tasks (for example preventing genocides) and better accountability and transparency of its institutions to its members. The EU needs to be an integral part of this reform, if not an outright leader.

name: Luděk Niedermayer (PPE)
text: Writing. \u2012 I supported the report on the EU's role within the UN, which, among other things, recalls the EU's long-term objective of obtaining a seat on the enlarged Security Council and calls for a Pan-European debate on this reform. In a context of increasing security risks, there is an urgent need to look for ways to ensure stability on a regional and global scale and a stronger role in these stabilisation efforts. It is therefore in our interest to seek a common EU position on matters falling within the competence of the Security Council and to improve existing cooperation mechanisms in order to ensure that EU Member States that are members of the Security Council defend the EU's common positions in this forum.

name: Franz Obermayr (ENF)
text: Writing. The report contains a number of positive points, but in the end I refused to approve it. It is unacceptable to assign even more powers to the European Union at international level and to further reduce the influence of nation states (especially at UN level).

name: Urmas Paet (ALDE)
text: Writing. \u2012 I supported. The UN must be a world peace promoter and problem solver, and the EU must work to make its voice clearer at the UN.  At the same time, it is important to carry out the reform of the UN Security Council, to find a solution to the excessive use of the veto for crimes against humanity and to make the election of the UN Secretary-General more transparent so that the UN can be a place where crises can actually be solved.

name: Rolandas Paksas (EFDD)
text: Writing. \u2012 The Role of the European Union must be strengthened by the UN as it is the most reliable partner in defending the principles of the United Nations, human rights and development objectives. The EU-UN strategic partnership is deep and has taken important steps in recent years working together on world peace and security.  In order to address current and future security problems more effectively, I believe it is appropriate to reform the Security Council. The new challenges and increasing challenges require the UN to take on new functions and the conditions for the management and funding of this organisation should therefore be reviewed. It should be noted that the EU should be given a seat in the enlarged Security Council. The coordination of EU action and its role and participation in the UN organ regulatory working groups need to be strengthened. The European Union, together with its Member States, is the main donor of financial assistance to the UN budget. It is therefore essential to ensure greater visibility of EU action and support in all multilateral for a and locally.

name: Margot Parker (EFDD)
text: in writing. ‒ UKIP voted against this report. The UK’s place on the UN Security Council, and our ability to act independently on the Security Council in the interests of the British people, is a corner stone of British security and of our position on the global stage.  This report seeks to impede that ability, primarily with the ultimate goal of giving the EU a permanent seat on the Security Council and by the assertion that, until this goal is reached, the UK must represent EU common positions decided by the High Representative and other Member States on the Security Council. UKIP believe that the British Government is elected by the British people to defend their interests on the global stage, not those of the European Union.

name: Aldo Patriciello (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 President Schulz, at the ceremony commemorating the victims of Paris held at the European Parliament in Brussels, said that Europe needs to be united now more than ever in the name of its values, first and first and for all peace, its greatest success. For this to happen, its credibility and its weight at international level must be given priority. We all want the EU to play an important and decisive role in the United Nations. Only in this way can we overcome global challenges such as terrorism, migration and the construction of a solid international balance. I am voting in favour and I would ask you to do the same.

name: Eva Paunova (PPE)
text: in writing. – I voted in favour of the role of the EU within the UN report, because it is an important step towards enhancing the ongoing cooperation between the two bodies. The EU and its Member States play an essential role and contribute to the work of the UN system in various ways and formats and this role needs to be strengthened further.

name: Alojz Peterle (PPE)
text: in writing. ‒ The foreign affairs perspective of the EU should not be the weakest link in the Union. In the current crisis, the Union should endeavour a truly functioning common foreign affairs policy aimed at ensuring security, empowering internal cohesion, the EU’s global identity and effectively developing our neighbourhood as well as driving democracy, peace and mediation processes around the world. In this sense, a stronger impact of EU decisions should be well reflected and integrated into UN’s global role.

name: Marijana Petir (PPE)
text: Written. ‒ The European Union and the UN share the common values enshrined in the Charter of the United Nations and the EU Treaty. Preserving international peace and security is crucial at a time when we are witnessing tragic terrorist attacks, both in the European Union – recent in Paris and the Middle East and North Africa.  The latest developments in Syria and Iraq, with millions of refugees and the migrant crisis showing that it is important to have a system based on universal rules and values that can respond to global crises, challenges and threats and that its work must also be coordinated with international assistance.  We are responsible for jointly combating human trafficking and combating the spread and financing of terrorist groups by preventing and disabling the recruitment, organisation, transport and equipping of terrorist fighters and the financing of their travel and activities. Despite the EU and the Member States making the greatest financial contribution to the GENERAL BUDGET of the UN and its delivery of humanitarian and official development assistance and peacekeeping operations, the EU and the UN need to focus more strongly on eradicating poverty, which poses a major challenge to the sustainable development of the whole world. Economic, social and environmental sustainability contribute to peace and security. Efforts to eradicate the exploitation of workers, in particular women and children, need to be strengthened.

name: Florian Philippot (ENF)
text: In writing. This report on the role of the European Union in the United Nations is a new blow to the sovereignty of the Member States. Indeed, he believes that global issues must call for a coordinated European intervention by increasing the EU's influence, particularly in the UN General Assembly and the Security Council, where there is talk of the adoption of a single seat for the EU.  Thus, there is a mechanism to compel Member States, including those that have veto power in the Security Council, to coordinate their action. It also wants to force permanent or non-permanent Member States to defend EU positions in the UN Security Council. He recalls that the ECHR is an example for the progress of human rights even though, according to the Commission, it no longer applies in Greece as it is under the influence of the Memorandums.  It also introduces the principle of "climate refugee" into international law. In short, this text is an alignment of pearls more Europeanistic than the other. So I voted against it.

name: Tonino Picula (S&D)
text: Written. ‒There are two fundamental objectives of this report: to identify the importance of the Union's unique role within the United Nations and the importance of further strengthening and reforming the UN as a fundamental global space for multilateralism and joint problem solving. The European Union cannot act independently and without partners in a modern world facing risks such as terrorism, organised crime, the proliferation of weapons of mass destruction, etc. In this regard, efforts towards more active cooperation and participation of the Union in the work of the UN as well as the union's long-standing progress in terms of establishing an international reputation and forming a unique and recognisable identity as an international actor are commendable.  The EU must strengthen the promotion of its own foreign policy interests within the UN by insisting on its reform towards revitalising the work of the General Assembly, reforming the Security Council, increasing transparency, effectiveness and legitimacy, etc. Particularly important are the successes of the report to include important human rights issues, gender equality, non-proliferation of weapons of mass destruction and a moratorium on the death penalty. However, further progress is necessary in protecting the right to safe abortion for victims of war rape and protecting women's rights in general.

name: Andrej Plenković (PPE)
text: Written. ‒ The EU's position within the United Nations is certainly important to achieve the european union's foreign policy objectives. Both international bodies share the same fundamental principles and common values that should form the basis of the actions of each of these institutions, but also their joint action. First of all, it should be noted that these are institutions sui generis and the complexity of their institutional structure is characterized by their relationship and the possibility of cooperation. The European Union has a special monitoring status at the UN, the right to participate in discussions, submit proposals and amendments. This aims to achieve better connectivity and the creation of a truly common foreign and security policy so that the Role of the Union is given greater importance in foreign policy. It is important to point out that EU member states collectively contribute the most to the UN budget financially, but also by making human capital and technical knowledge available, thus achieving the Single Implementations initiative (one leader, one budget, one programme). A strong and stable EU-UN partnership is essential for the WORK of the UN under all three pillars (peace and security, human rights and sustainable development), as well as the EU's role as an active global stakeholder.

name: Miroslav Poche (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ I am pleased by the result of the vote on the report for how the EU can better achieve it foreign policy goals within the UN. It is important to recognise that the two organisations share many of the same values and principles, and that the Member States of the EU can help to promote the goals. However, I do agree that the UN should publish regular overviews of compliance with obligations in order to help ensure that UN member states honour their humanitarian aid promises. In addition, I also call on the EU and the UN to increase their efforts to reach an ambitious and legally binding agreement at the Paris Climate Conference. With these two small steps, I believe that our two great organisations can accomplish great things in the near future, and that we can all continue to make the world a better place.

name: Salvatore Domenico Pogliese (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 The EU is committed to multilateralism focused on a strong and effective UN Organisation. This commitment is based on the conviction that, in order to be able to respond to global crises, challenges and threats, the international community needs an efficient multilateral system, based on universal norms and values. In order to better cooperate with the UN, the EU should seek to strengthen its influence. In the General Assembly, for example, the EU should play a stronger role in achieving greater visibility and political authority. The European Parliament, through this report, wishes to stress the importance of relaunching the work of the General Assembly and is convinced that the Security Council must be reformed. Parliament also called for an improvement in early warning instruments and a greater capacity for mediation by the United Nations, with coherent and achievable mandates for peacekeeping operations. I hope that the European Union will have a single common representative on the Security Council, and I therefore voted in favour of this resolution.

name: Franck Proust (PPE)
text: In writing. In this report we recall that the European Union, on the one hand, and its Member States, on the other, play an essential role within the United Nations and its bodies.  France in particular, through its activities, its budget or the values we share. We want a thorough reform of the UN system to make it more effective. All of this led me to vote in favour.

name: Paulo Rangel (PPE)
text: in writing. The rapporteur believes that the European Union (EU) security environment is increasingly unstable and volatile due to the high number of security problems. To this end, the EU needs global partners to achieve the objectives of its foreign policy, including peace and security, terrorism, organised crime, regional conflicts, state collapse and proliferation of weapons of mass destruction. The UN system is the world's leading forum for improving global governance and as such represents the best forum for promoting eu values and interests. This framework stipuorders that, in order to achieve its objectives, as enshrined in the Treaty, the EU must aspire to strengthen global governance within the UN system and to increase its own influence and that of its Member States. The position adopted in this report reaffirms the importance of revitalising the work of the General Assembly in general and the work of the EU under the auspices of the United Nations in particular. Having said the above, I voted in favour.

name: Julia Reid (EFDD)
text: in writing. ‒ UKIP voted against this report. The UK’s place on the UN Security Council, and our ability to act independently on the Security Council in the interests of the British people, is a corner stone of British security and of our position on the global stage.  This report seeks to impede that ability, primarily with the ultimate goal of giving the EU a permanent seat on the Security Council and by the assertion that, until this goal is reached, the UK must represent EU common positions decided by the High Representative and other Member States on the Security Council. UKIP believe that the British Government is elected by the British people to defend their interests on the global stage, not those of the European Union.

name: Dominique Riquet (ALDE)
text: In writing. The initiative report on the role of the European Union in the United Nations and the best ways to meet the Union's foreign policy objectives sets out ambitious proposals to strengthen our clout in this world body.  The report stresses the need to strengthen the role of the European Union in the UN General Assembly, and in particular in the Economic and Social Council, including, among other things, environmental issues. Remaining convinced that the links between the European Union and the United Nations must be strengthened, now more than ever, in an unstable global context, I voted in favour of this text.

name: Robert Rochefort (ALDE)
text: In writing. I supported this resolution. The European Union and the United Nations face common challenges: the search for peace and security, the prevention of conflict, the fight against terrorism, the promotion of human rights, action for sustainable development, the defence of an international system based on multilateralism. Therefore, the Union must make its contribution through its foreign policy to solving these challenges, while promoting its interests and values. The Union must, for example, act in favour of the development of global governance within the United Nations and increase its influence and that of its Member States within that system. It must obtain a seat on an expanded Security Council. It must work to strengthen the mediation capacity of the United Nations and call for peacekeeping missions to be based on coherent mandates. It is the Union's responsibility to live up to the role it intends to play, because it must be understood that if the Union fails in the face of this imperative, it will be its very model that will be jeopardised.

name: Inmaculada Rodríguez-Piñero Fernández (S&D)
text: in writing. I voted in favour of this report on the EU's role within the United Nations and the reforms that can be undertaken to strengthen this organisation and better achieve the EU's foreign policy objectives. I support the reform of the UNITED Nations system as a means of strengthening its efficiency and promoting the EU's foreign policy objectives. The EU must play an active role within the organisation, promote its values and contribute to effective multilateralism to provide global solutions to global problems. In this regard, we join the request for the EU to have a permanent seat in the Security Council. The Socialist amendments have enriched the report with references to human rights, gender equality, LGTBI rights, the non-proliferation of nuclear weapons, the responsibility to protect and the moratorium on the death penalty. We also call on the EU to participate actively in the debate on the legal definition of the term 'climate refugee' and express our wish that the next person elected to the post of Secretary-General of the United Nations be a woman.

name: Claude Rolin (PPE)
text: In writing. In this report I voted yesterday, Parliament reminds us that the Union and its Member States share the values and principles of the UN Charter and play a vital role in promoting its principles and objectives within the framework of the Union's external action.  The adopted text also welcomes the fact that the Union and its Member States are actively involved and contribute to the work of the United Nations system in different ways and forms, while believing that they should be more visible. He also welcomes the EU's major contribution to humanitarian aid and development around the world, pointing out that the EU is the world's leading provider of humanitarian and development aid. The text also recalls that the Union has become a genuine international player and therefore enjoys the status of "privileged observer" at the United Nations. Finally, it recalls that the Union is committed to actively supporting a thorough reform of the Un system in order to strengthen its legitimacy, regional representation, transparency, accountability and effectiveness.

name: Fernando Ruas (PPE)
text: in writing. As an important global player, the EU has an extremely important role within multilateral organisations and should therefore contribute to ensuring peace, security, development and the fulfilment of human rights worldwide. The EU's problems need global responses to the extent that global problems lack concrete European action. The EU and the UN have worked together to address key aspects that not only ensure the present but also protect future generations. In this context, there is an example of strengthening work in developing countries and of various international companies that also contribute to this, the fight against violence, gender equality, the fight against corruption, climate change and the proper management of refugee vacancies. However, I also support the rapporteur's considerations on the need to revitalise the General Assembly and reshape the UN Security Council. I therefore consider it essential to maintain and strengthen dialogue and cooperation between the EU and the UN, so that the objectives outlined by the Union in terms of foreign policy can be achieved, and i therefore voted in favour of this report.

name: Tokia Saïfi (PPE)
text: In writing. I supported this report, which suggests ways for the European Union to better meet its foreign policy objectives within the United Nations. As Article 21, paragraph 1 of the EU Treaty, states, the European Union and member states share the values and principles of the UN Charter. It is necessary to remember that the European Union is an active contributor to the work of the United Nations; and this is thanks to the rights that flow from his privileged observer status. While the European Union is able to speak at all UN meetings, but also to propose amendments and submit resolutions, the UNION's institutions in the UN system enjoy very low visibility. I supported this report, too, because it recalls that the Union is committed to actively supporting a reform of the United Nations system in order to consolidate its legitimacy and effectiveness and to strengthen its authority.

name: Massimiliano Salini (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the report on the role of the European Union in the United Nations in ensuring and improving the security and defence of all European citizens. I agree with the European Union's desire to play an increasingly important role in the processes of peace and democracy in the world. With this text, the European Parliament reaffirms that the Union as a whole claims to be making a thorough reform of the UN system in order to strengthen its legitimacy, regional representation, transparency, accountability and effectiveness. Parliament stressed in particular that the work of the General Assembly should be relaunched and members should be persuaded to reform the Security Council.

name: Matteo Salvini (ENF)
text: in writing. \u2012 I abstained because I believe that, within a dutiful and urgent process of reform of the United Nations, greater decision-making weight should be granted to the individual Member States and not to the European Union as such.

name: Lola Sánchez Caldentey (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. I abstained in the vote on this report on the EU's role within the United Nations. The report contains positive references to the importance of the United Nations in addressing international problems in a range of areas, from humanitarian aid to security and peace to global public goods. However, the report calls for strengthening the EU's role in the United Nations, which we consider contradictory to the principle of multilateralism and democratic representation of all States within the organisation, a principle that is one of its core values.

name: Lidia Senra Rodríguez (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. In the face of the rise of wars and armed conflicts, I am fully convinced that, now more than ever, it is urgent to lay the groundwork for a new international order through UN reform, so that it has effective mechanisms in place to defend international law, human rights and multilateralism on a global scale. While I agree with the report on the need for UN reform that strengthens its legitimacy and gives it a more transparent and democratic functioning, I do not share the rapporteur's approach to this reform. It proposes to strengthen cooperation between the United Nations, the World Bank and the International Monetary Fund in order to increase the submission of States to organizations of the capitalist system at the international level. In addition, the report argues that the EU currently plays a role in promoting peace and preventing conflict and crisis management in the world, so it should have a permanent seat on the Security Council. This would undoubtedly be a downstop in the sovereignty of EU Member States. For these reasons I voted against it.

name: Siôn Simon (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ I and my Labour colleagues and sister parties support the reform of the UN system as a means of strengthening the efficiency of the organisation and to better promote the EU’s foreign policy goals. I voted in favour of this report because I believe that the EU must play an active role within the organisation, project its values and contribute to effective multilateralism with a view to providing global solutions to global problems. I am confident that this report will send a strong message about the need for reform in the Security Council and, importantly, I believe that we need to see women elected as the Secretary-General of the United Nations.

name: Branislav Škripek (ECR)
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted against the Väyrynen report because of my cooperation with my British colleagues, whose permanent seat on the United Nations Security Council would be jeopardised, and I am also of the opinion that the rapporteur has pushed the report beyond the framework originally set out in the committee negotiations.

name: Monika Smolková (S&D)
text: Writing. \u2012 Since the adoption of the Treaty of Lisbon, the EU has started to participate actively in the work of the UN. The position of High Representative for Foreign Affairs and Security Policy was also created for the purpose of the EU being able to speak with one voice in international for a. I therefore agree with the conviction that the EU should continue to be a model of effective multilateral governance, to which the UN Reform Agenda should also be directed. It should be stressed that the strong partnership between the two international organisations has long been built on three pillars – peace and security, human rights and sustainable development. It is these areas in which the EU and the UN can complement each other.  Culture, intercultural and interreligious dialogue are also an integral part of the UN's remit. The EU should therefore give culture a more strategic role in its external relations, as it is also one of its fundamental values. It is in for a such as the UN that the EU should promote activities aimed at preserving endangered cultural heritage or combating the illicit trade in cultural goods. I therefore welcome the strengthened cooperation between the EU and UNESCO, which could lead to joint action beyond financial assistance and joint project management. We cannot forget that the cultural dimension is essential for successful development policies supporting the building of sustainable societies.

name: Igor Šoltes (Verts/ALE)
text: Writing. Due to the increasing global interdependence, cooperation between the EU and the UN is of the extreme importance. The report further analyses this cooperation and notes that the EU and its Member States respect the values and principles set out in the UN Charter. In addition, Member States also play a key role in promoting the PRINCIPLES AND OBJECTIVES of the UN, in particular through international cooperation and relations. I agree that the EU needs partners at global level to help it achieve its foreign policy objectives, in particular in the areas of peace and security, terrorism, organised crime, regional conflicts, states' failure to fulfil their obligations and the proliferation of weapons of mass destruction. The report recalls that, in order to better achieve the objectives of its foreign policy, the EU should work to strengthen global governance within the UN system and to increase its influence in the international context. I believe that the EU and its Member States should play a central role in the post-2015 development agenda and work with the UN and all other stakeholders to make ambitious commitments to achieve future Sustainable Development Goals. As I am aware that the future of the EU is linked to world peace, security, development and human rights, and that we must always strive for the best possible international cooperation, I voted in plenary to adopt the report.

name: Joachim Starbatty (ECR)
text: Writing. The own-initiative report by Paavo Väyrynen (EPP) aims to clearly define the role of the European Union within the United Nations. Reference is made to Article 21 of the Treaty on European Union, which lists the maintenance or promotion of democracy, the rule of law and fundamental rights as common foreign policy objectives of the EU Member States, as well as compliance with the other principles set out in the Charter of the United Nations. The report rightly states that the Security Council urgently needs to be reformed in order to maintain a good capacity to act, since, in its current composition, it does not represent a geographically balanced representation of interests, but still reflects the geopolitical conditions of 1945. For example, I am in favour of A permanent seat for Germany on the Security Council, because today Germany, as the third largest contributor to the United Nations, has considerably less influence over the United Nations and, in particular, the Security Council than the five veto powers. Further reforms of the United Nations are also needed. However, the report calls for a permanent EU seat on the Security Council, even though the EU is not a state but an international organisation and as such cannot be a member of the United Nations under current rules. That is why I rejected the report.

name: Ivan Štefanec (PPE)
text: Writing. \u2012 The UN, as a global organisation based on the principles of global peace, security and human rights, also represents a space for promoting the EU's values and interests. The Union must also fulfil its role at the UN, as we all have a shared responsibility for respect for international law and world development.

name: Jaromír Štětina (PPE)
text: Writing. \u2012 I supported this report because, in an increasingly unstable world, it is important that the EU use all the mechanisms and means at its disposal to ensure its defence and global stability. The UN is the most important international organisation, but the EU does not have full membership here. Representation on the UN Security Council by France and the United Kingdom, two EU Member States, is not ideal. At a time when the EU is facing an imminent threat from both the east and the south, we cannot afford a disunited European foreign policy, let alone with different accents. EU Member States are not strong enough to face threats from Russia or IS on their own. Our joint efforts, which have the same objectives, must be coordinated and harmonised into one European voice that cannot be ignored. That is why we must focus mainly on reforming the UN Security Council, where the EU should be represented. The EU should also have a higher status in the UN General Assembly than observer status. For the time being, at least through the EU High Representative Mogherini, it is necessary to ensure that the Member States of the Union cooperate as much as possible at the UN.

name: Davor Ivo Stier (PPE)
text: Written. ‒I support this report reminding Parliament that the EU and its Member States share the values and principles of the United Nations Charter, as set out in Article 21 (1) of the UEU and play a key role in promoting these principles as well as the OBJECTIVES of the UN, through union external action. The report acknowledges the fact that the EU and its Member States play an active role and contribute to UN work, development and humanitarian actions worldwide. In order to better achieve its foreign policy objectives in the form outlined in the Treaty, the EU needs to work to strengthen global governance within the UN system and increase its influence in the system as well as the Member States' system. The EU's commitment is to actively support a comprehensive reform of the UN system to strengthen its legitimacy, regional representation, transparency, accountability and effectiveness in responding to the complex and multilayered challenges of today.

name: Catherine Stihler (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ I supported this resolution, which has the aim of strengthening the UN and better achieving the aims of EU foreign policy. I support the call for the EU to play a more significant and coherent role within the UN, and for states to honour their promises to provide humanitarian aid. However, I opposed the enlargement of the Security Council.

name: Dubravka Šuica (PPE)
text: Written. ‒ The future of the European Union is closely linked to global peace, security, development and human rights. However, the challenges facing the European Union require global solutions and greater support from international partners.    The relationship between the European Union and the UN is currently not at an enviable level, although the Union and the Member States make the greatest financial contribution to the general UN budget, peacekeeping operations, as well as the provision of humanitarian and development assistance. In addition, as the largest trading bloc in the world, the European Union plays a major role in bilateral and multilateral trade agreements and UN conventions, as the only non-state participant. For this reason, the European Union needs a special status within the UN. It is important to bear in mind that the UN system is the world's main forum for improving global governance and is the best forum for promoting the values and interests of the European Union. I fully support the Council's position, as I believe that better cooperation between the European Union and the UN would contribute to the achievement of the union's foreign policy objectives, in particular with regard to peace and security, terrorism, organised crime, regional conflicts, state failures.

name: Richard Sulík (ECR)
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted against the proposal as I do not agree with some of its challenges, such as the call for ambitious climate targets, nor do I agree with highlighting the EU's 'significant contribution' to development and humanitarian aid in the world.

name: Patricija Šulin (PPE)
text: Writing. \ u2012 I voted in favour of the report on the role of the European Union in the United Nations – how to better achieve the EU's foreign policy objectives. As an alternate member of the Committee on Budgetary Control, I voted in favour of the initiative, which highlighted the need to improve the efficiency, accountability, performance and transparency of the United Nations, particularly with regard to the use of EU funds. The initiative also underlined the need for the EU to make EU funding more visible. The European Union and the Member States are the largest financial donors in the United Nations budget.

name: Pavel Svoboda (PPE)
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the report on the EU's role within the UN: how to better achieve the EU's foreign policy objectives, as it is important nowadays to reflect the role and capabilities of the EU as a whole in the UN. The EU shares the same values with the UN and participates in the achievement of UN objectives in a fundamental way, often as a guiding factor, such as in the area of humanitarian aid contributions, but this does not mean that the EU's role in UN structures cannot be strengthened. Above all, however, this strengthening presupposes that the EU will be able to reach a clear consensus within its common foreign and security policy, which will then also spread uniformly and allow the High Representative to present and represent this position.

name: Νεοκλής Συλικιώτης (
text: GUE/NGL), in writing. \u2012 The report discusses the ROLE of the EU within the UN system and its potential for upgrading, with a view to achieving the formation of a common foreign policy and promoting the EU's leading role on the global chessboard.  The effort developed in the report to strengthen the EU in the way it is set out finds us vertically opposed as it entails weakening the sovereignty of its Member States. Unfortunately, what is being sought is for the EU to become an expression of the foreign policy of all Member States, where it will define and limit the policies of the Member States at the same time. Having the coordinating role of foreign policy, the EU will be responsible for the "compliance" of Member States with its guidelines.  The EU's position on key issues such as Ukrainian and Russian sanctions, the Palestinian and trade agreement with Israel, and in particular the regressions on the Cyprus problem and Turkey's accession path, makes us certain that the development of a common foreign policy within the current EU means driving the sovereignty of the Member States and extending intra-imperialist contradictions. We cannot therefore support such an approach. However, we did not vote against the report as we consider it particularly important and necessary to promote EU cooperation with the UN on all issues.

name: József Szájer (PPE)
text: Writing. \u2012 The European Union's action at international level is based on the principles of democracy, the rule of law, equality, solidarity and the universal and indivisible nature of human rights and fundamental freedoms and respect for human dignity, as enshreined in Article 21 of the Treaty on European Union. The report adopted today recalls that the principles and objectives of EU foreign policy are closely linked to the UN's objectives. It underlines that the challenges facing the EU require global solutions and global problems require EU action. It therefore needs global partners to achieve its objectives, namely peace and security and preventing the spread of terrorism.

name: Tibor Szanyi (S&D)
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the adoption of this report because it supports the need for the European Union to finally take a place in the UN, both in terms of its organisational structure and global activities, in terms of its actual international weight and importance. I believe that it is time, as the report points out, for the EU Member States, with the help of the European External Action Service, to assert their positions and the Union's interests more uniformly and strongly on the most important issues of international life. To this end, I agree with the need to speed up the operational and organisational reform of the UN, even in the cold war conditions, in particular with regard to the reform of the Security Council, including the elimination of the possibility of abuse of veto power, in particular in cases of violation of universal human rights.  I trust that the EP's resolution will also help the EU to take its place in an enlarged BT in the longer term. In drafting my opinion, I also took into account as an important virtue of the report the need to increase women's equality in the functioning and organisation of the World Organisation, including the principles and practices of electing the Secretary-General. I also felt it was important to urge the EP, in the context of this document, to be able to play the same weight as the Commission in shaping the EU's global role.

name: Adam Szejnfeld (PPE)
text: I would like to write to the Commission. \u2012 The future of the European Union is linked to the global peace, security, development and human rights guaranteed by the United Nations. For several years now, the Union has not only been able to articulate its needs and concerns through its Member States, but also to articulate its own needs and concerns, as well as to table proposals and amendments in the UN General Assembly. However, this law requires EU countries, especially those on the Security Council, to coordinate their positions within the UN. This is particularly important now that the conflict in Ukraine, Syria or the growing terrorist organisation ISIS pose a serious threat to the security of our continent and the globe.  Moreover, it is important that the EU and its institutions make a clear and decisive call for global solutions to global problems, as no country alone is able to cope with emerging threats in the current world. That is why I have chosen to vote in favour of the European Parliament document on the role of the EU in the United Nations.

name: Claudia Tapardel (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ The EU and its Member States are collectively the single largest financial contributor to the UN system, with contributions amounting to 35% of the UN regular budget, and 36.8% of the UN peacekeeping budgets. Moreover, the EU and its Member States provide about half of all the voluntary contributions to UN funds and programmes. Based on these figures I believe that the EU needs to play a prominent role in reforming the UN system to make it more democratic, efficient and transparent. I welcome the proposals in the current text. I particularly support the call to reform the UN security system with the objective of granting the EU a permanent seat. That will give the EU the opportunity to play an active role within the UN in a way that reflects our soft power. I also welcome the support of my colleagues for my initiative to promote gender equality within the UN system, by asking the EU to support a female candidate for the role of the UN Secretary General in the upcoming elections.  This comprehensive text will help us define the role that the EU can play, by leading a systematic reform of the UN system. Therefore I voted in favour of it.

name: Marc Tarabella (S&D)
text: In writing. To better meet its foreign policy objectives, the EU should strive to develop global governance within the framework of the UN system and to increase its influence and that of its Member States within the system.  The Union is committed to actively supporting a thorough reform of the UN system with a view to strengthening its legitimacy and regional representativeness, as well as improving the transparency, justification and effectiveness of the action taken to address today's complex and protean challenges!

name: Pavel Telička (ALDE)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of this report which focuses on better achieving the EU foreign policy goals within the UN and sets out certain recommendations. I think that under the current circumstances, we cannot afford fragmented security across the EU, and therefore actions must be taken consistently at EU level. In this perspective, I supported provisions which emphasise that the EU must play an enhanced role in the General Assembly of the UN and in the Security Council, reaffirming the long—term objective of an EU seat. In order to be more active within the UN, I also supported provisions calling on Parliament to be more proactive as regards its cooperation with the VP/HR and carefully communicate all positions having an external or global dimension.

name: Patrizia Toia (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 I believe that, in order to achieve all the ambitious foreign policy objectives, the European Union should seek to strengthen global governance within the United Nations system, increasing its influence and that of the Member States within that body. A Europe that speaks with one voice, even in international for a, is stronger and can make a decisive contribution to resolving the many conflicts affecting various parts of the world. There is a need to actively support a comprehensive reform of the UN system in order to strengthen its legitimacy, regional representativeness and transparency, accountability and effectiveness in responding to today's complex and complex challenges. All this involves revitalising the role of the General Assembly and reforming the Security Council, which is still too unrepresentative of the geopolitical changes taking place.

name: László Tőkés (PPE)
text: Writing. \u2012 The Union's action at international level is based on the principles of democracy, the rule of law, equality, solidarity and the universal and indivisible nature of human rights and fundamental freedoms and respect for human dignity, as enshreined in Article 21 of the Treaty on Union. The report adopted today recalls that the principles and objectives of EU foreign policy are closely linked to the UN's objectives. It underlines that the challenges facing the EU require global solutions and global problems require EU action. It therefore needs global partners to achieve its objectives, namely peace and security and preventing the spread of terrorism.  The Union should therefore continue to strive to strengthen global governance within the UN and reform the Security Council in order to better reflect the new world situation. With regard to the migration and refugee crisis plaguing Europe, I voted in favour of this report, which calls, inter alia, on the EU and the UN to work more closely together to tackle the crisis and, among other things, to help remedy the economic situation in the countries where migration is based and to develop them sustainably. In view of the forthcoming UN Climate Change Conference in Paris, I also voted in favour of the EU and the UN stepping up their efforts to reach a legally binding agreement at this summit.

name: Valdemar Tomaševski (ECR)
text: Writing. As is known, the EU and its Member States recognise the Charter of the United Nations. However, the principles and external objectives of EU policies are closely linked to the principles and objectives of the UN, and Article 21 of the Treaty on European Union explicitly calls for compliance with the principles of the Charter and international law. Member States shall also make the largest financial contribution to the general budget of the United Nations and to the assistance of UN humanitarian aid, official development assistance and peacekeeping. This data should oblige the EU to play an important role in this key international organisation. The report contains a record that has led to my support for the opinion given by Mr Väyrynen. He recalls the need to coordinate and strengthen UN efforts to combat the exploitation of workers, in particular women and children, and to the eradication of social dumping, which threatens social development. In today's world, this is a very important thing.

name: Ruža Tomašić (ECR)
text: Written. ‒ The rapporteur focuses on the idea of reforming the Structure of the United Nations by formalising the dual governance structure - on the one hand the Security Council and on the other the Council of Sustainable Development, which would coordinate all areas of Action of the United Nations, except security.  While this proposal is disproportionate to the topic of the report (which does not focus on reforms within the United Nations system itself), the fact is that the European Union and the Member States make the greatest financial contribution to the general budget of the United Nations. In light of the recent terrorist attacks and security threats facing Europe on a daily basis, the Union needs the support of international partners more than ever; I therefore hold justified the rapporteur's call for the European Union and the Member States to step up their political influence in the structures of this organisation, as this process would also allow for better fulfilment of international obligations. I also support the rapporteur's call for simplification of structures, budgets and working methods within the United Nations organisation, in particular the reform of the dysfunctional and often criticised Economic and Social Council; towards economic, social, environmental and development efficiency. So I voted in favor.

name: Romana Tomc (PPE)
text: Writing. - I supported the report on the role of the European Union in the United Nations – how to better achieve the EU's foreign policy objectives, because I believe that closer EU-UN cooperation would have more beneficial consequences. The most crucial is certainly ensuring peace, so it is important to strengthen such efforts both at home and more broadly.

name: Estefanía Torres Martínez (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. I abstained in the vote on this report on the EU's role within the United Nations.
