The report contains positive references to the importance of the United Nations in addressing international problems in a range of areas, from humanitarian aid to security and peace to global public goods. However, the report calls for strengthening the EU's role in the United Nations, which we consider contradictory to the principle of multilateralism and democratic representation of all States within the organisation, a principle that is one of its core values.

name: Ramon Tremosa i Balcells (ALDE)
text: in writing. ‒ The EU and its Member States share the values and principles of the UN Charter as stated in Article 21(1) of the Treaty on European Union and have a crucial role in promoting those principles as well as the goals of the UN, through the external action of the European Union. The EU needs global partners if it is to succeed in achieving its foreign policy goals, notably in the fields of peace and security, terrorism, organised crime, regional conflicts, state failures and the proliferation of weapons of mass destruction. The EU within the UN system must be reinforced and the EU should speak more often with one voice, especially in these days where the EU is confronted with crucial and fundamental international challenges that know no borders.

name: Mihai Ţurcanu (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the Report on the EU's role in the UN, as the UN is the world's leading organisation for improving global governance and the optimal framework for promoting EU values and interests. The principles and objectives of the European Union's foreign policy are closely linked to those of the UN, which are based on respect for the principles of the UN Charter and international law. In an increasingly unstable context, due to the large number of security challenges to the EU, such as the conflicts in eastern Ukraine, Syria and Iraq and the rise of the terrorist organisation ISIS and the terrorist threat in Africa, global responses are needed, as the EU cannot solve these threats on its own, but needs the support of international partners. Therefore, in order to better contribute to the achievement of its foreign policy objectives, the EU must work towards strengthening global governance within the UN system and increase its influence and that of its Member States within that system. In this regard, the report underlines the need for extensive reform of the UN system in order to strengthen the legitimacy, accountability and effectiveness of the EU in this framework.

name: István Ujhelyi (S&D)
text: Writing. \u2012 The future of the European Union is linked to global peace, security, development and human rights. The challenges facing the Union require global solutions and global problems require EU action. That is why I supported the proposal.

name: Miguel Urbán Crespo (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. I abstained in the vote on this report on the EU's role within the United Nations. The report contains positive references to the importance of the United Nations in addressing international problems in a range of areas, from humanitarian aid to security and peace to global public goods. However, the report calls for strengthening the EU's role in the United Nations, which we consider contradictory to the principle of multilateralism and democratic representation of all States within the organisation, a principle that is one of its core values.

name: Viktor Uspaskich (ALDE)
text: Writing. – Calls on the EU Member States to step up their support for peace-building and peacekeeping operations and for the EU to step up its mediation efforts to resolve conflicts, in the light of recent atrocities and human rights violations by some extremist and terrorist groups. The UN should strengthen its activities on all issues relating to human well-being

name: Ivo Vajgl (ALDE)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of the resolution on the role of the EU within the UN – how to better achieve EU foreign policy goals – because I agree that in order to better achieve its foreign policy goals as enshrined in the Treaty the EU should strive to strengthen global governance inside the UN system and to increase its own and its Member States’ influence within that system. The resolution recalls the EU’s commitment to actively support a comprehensive reform of the UN system in order to strengthen its legitimacy, its regional representation, and its transparency, accountability and effectiveness in responding to the complex, multi-faceted challenges of today and stresses in particular the importance of revitalising the work of the General Assembly. As I am also a member of the AFET Committee in the European Parliament, the role of the EU in foreign policy is one of my main topics of interest and this is another reason for supporting this resolution.

name: Ramón Luis Valcárcel Siso (PPE)
text: in writing. The report highlights that the EU and its Member States share the values and principles of the Charter of the United Nations, enshrined in Article 21 OFR. In this report, Parliament also welcomes the fact that the EU and its Member States play an active role and are the biggest contributors to the United Nations system. The report highlights the EU's growing importance within the United Nations and the desire for comprehensive reform of the EU. That is why I have considered it necessary to vote in favour of that report.

name: Ángela Vallina (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. In the face of the rise of wars and armed conflicts, I am fully convinced that, now more than ever, it is urgent to lay the groundwork for a new international order through UN reform, so that it has effective mechanisms in place to defend international law, human rights and multilateralism on a global scale. While I agree with the report on the need for UN reform that strengthens its legitimacy and gives it a more transparent and democratic functioning, I do not share the rapporteur's approach to this reform. It proposes to strengthen cooperation between the United Nations, the World Bank and the International Monetary Fund in order to increase the submission of States to organizations of the capitalist system at the international level. In addition, the report argues that the EU currently plays a role in promoting peace and preventing conflict and crisis management in the world, so it should have a permanent seat on the Security Council. This would undoubtedly be a downstop in the sovereignty of EU Member States. For these reasons I voted against it.

name: Hilde Vautmans (ALDE)
text: Written. 'I voted in favour of this report because it is my belief that the EU's position within the UN must be strengthened and that people in Europe should speak with one voice more often at international level. This is all the more true in these uncertain times when we in Europe are faced with global challenges that we can only solve if we come up with a unified European response.

name: Marie-Christine Vergiat (GUE/NGL)
text: In writing. Since 2011, the EU has enjoyed the status of "privileged observer" within the United Nations as such and is no longer only represented through its Member States.  This resolution therefore intends to provide guidance on participation.  Some avenues for reform are interesting, such as the reform of the process of appointing the Secretary-General, which has so far been too opaque; the questioning of the veto power of the members of the Security Council in cases of genocide and crimes against humanity or the establishment of a binding instrument on multinationals in human rights, as proposed by Ecuador. On the other hand, establishing an investment protection regime in the UN system — the infamous "arbitration mechanisms" of TTIP or CETA — or the establishment of coordination between the WTO and the UN to "promote a trade and investment strategy" have no place in the multilateral forum based on universal rights and values. , and are part of a well-known ultraliberal drift. I therefore abstained on this report.

name: Miguel Viegas (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. \u2012 This report is based on a principle which is at least dubious, and which consists in the idea that the European Union shares the values and principles of the Charter of the United Nations. But then, what about the military aggressions actively promoted and carried out against sovereign countries, violating their independence and territorial integrity, as happened in the cases of Iraq, Libya or Syria, among others? On the other hand, this report does not address key issues where the EU could play a relevant role in the United Nations. We quote two examples. First, the discussion on the establishment of a Multilateral Framework for the renegotiation of sovereign debt, an issue of the utmost importance for several EU Member States. What is the EU doing? Boycott the discussion and its outcome. Second, the resolution on the right to water and sanitation, seen as a human right. What is the EU doing? It boycotts the resolution and persists on the path of water privatisation, which has been pursued in several countries, in some cases as a result of eu-own impositions.

name: Harald Vilimsky (ENF)
text: Writing. The report contains some positive points. However, the report seems to want to push further centralisation of the EU. Moreover, it is questionable whether the countries represented so far can retain their seat if the EU were to have its own seat. I therefore reject this report.

name: Daniele Viotti (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 The European Union has a primary responsibility to promote peace and security through its security policy and plays a decisive role within the United Nations. However, it is becoming increasingly clear that there is a need for reform that will allow the organisation to act effectively to project its values to the new global scenarios. That is why I voted in favour of this report.

name: Udo Voigt (NI)
text: Writing. The report weakens the voice of European Member States at the United Nations in favour of non-worldly EU institutions. High positions in the EU must not be allocated through quota rules, where only performance and qualification can apply.

name: Beatrix von Storch (ECR)
text: Writing. Why the moon is flying? The European Parliament is an 'announcement body'. That is why I am opposed to this resolution. The EU is already represented within the United Nations by a wide range of actors: the President of the European Council, the EU Foreign Minister, the European Commission. Member States have their Permanent Representatives, two of whom (France and the United Kingdom) are also permanent members with the right of veto in the Security Council. In addition, the Treaties already oblige Member States to coordinate their positions and activities in all international for a. In doing so, they have already effectively abolished their own foreign policy responsibilities and the shape of their relations in the UN system. I reject the objective that the EU should speak and decide instead of the 28 Member States so far and even replace France and the United Kingdom in the Security Council in the medium term. This concern is an empty booking and a potential fissure of the Member States.

name: Jarosław Wałęsa (PPE)
text: in writing. ‒ I have voted in favour of the report on the role of the European Union within the United Nations in regard to how to better achieve EU foreign policy goals. Due to the fact that the future of the EU is highly dependent on human rights development, security and global peace, I think it is important to strengthen the EU role within the UN. The UN is indeed a forum in which we can promote our biggest interests and values.  The report lists several ways on how to contribute to the UN work system so that it can have a positive impact on our society. The first interesting idea that brought my attention is to reform the Security Council. The reason for it is that such a reform will contribute to the better reflection of the new world reality and will cause the SC to be more effective in overcoming future challenges. Moreover, provisions of the report focus on enhancing both EU coordination and cooperation in fields such as humanitarian aid and development. All of the above will hopefully strengthen our position in UN and therefore globally.

name: Iuliu Winkler (PPE)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of the report on the role of the EU within the UN. In this report, Parliament recalls that the EU and its Member States share the values and principles of the UN Charter (as stated in Article 21(1) TEU) and have a crucial role in promoting those principles as well as the goals of the UN, through the external action of the Union. Parliament welcomes the fact that the EU and its Member States play an active part and contribute to the work of the UN system in different ways and formats. The report recalls the EU’s commitment to actively support a comprehensive reform of the UN system in order to strengthen its legitimacy, its regional representation, and its transparency, accountability and effectiveness.

name: Anna Záborská (PPE)
text: Writing. \u2012 It is certainly right that the European Union is represented in the STRUCTURES of the United Nations. However, I have some doubts as to whether the Commission's great diplomatic ambitions, also supported by a majority in this House, are premature.  If there were agreement among the Member States that they wanted to merge in one large federation and become part of a larger national whole, then of course it would be logical to create a diplomatic apparatus to represent it. However, while there is no such consensus, we will have to constantly ask, in specific situations, whose interests European diplomacy is actually pursuing in an international forum.  We put on our coats, even though the pants are still hanging on the hanger. We are not happy that it is a very nice and warm coat, because without the pants in it we will end up cold anyway.

name: Θεόδωρος Ζαγοράκης (
text: PPE), in writing. \u2012 I contributed to the drafting of the opinion of the Committee on Culture and Education to the Committee on Foreign Affairs of the European Parliament. Of course I supported this own-initiative report.

name: Tomáš Zdechovský (PPE)
text: Writing. \u2012 I supported this report because it clearly portrays the EU's position as a strong and important player in the UN system, which I completely agree with. The positions of individual Member States, including the Czech Republic itself, are also strengthened through the EU's strong position. In my opinion, the report also rightly identifies the need for UN reform towards greater legitimacy, transparency and effectiveness, to which the EU is committed to helping.

name: Inês Cristina Zuber (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. The imperialist aspect of the EU and the aspirations to play a dominant role in the global political context are well evident in this report. In an absolutely abject way, we seek a collage of the principles and values of the EU to those of the United Nations. The pursuit of peace is proclaimed, omitting the aggressor and bellicose nature that the EU and many of its Member States have assumed, promoting war in countries such as Iraq, Libya, Syria or Afghanistan. It is proclaimed the contribution to the eradication of poverty and the promotion of democracy, when we are well known that support is often enshrined in a framework of imperative alignment, i.e. imposition, with the EU's political strategies and "democratic" values. It proposes, without shame, the eu's greatest preponderance as a body within the UNITED NATIONS, its influence and role in global governance within the UN system, in particular in the General Assembly, and to take place in the Security Council, which we reject. The document essentially sets up a strategy to take over the United Nations and to make it an instrument of EU foreign policy. We voted against it.

name: Presidente. –
text: Explanations of vote are closed.

name: President. –
text: I want to inform the House that tomorrow, 25 November 2015, is the International Day for the Elimination of Violence Against Women and Girls. The United Nations started the initiative to illuminate landmarks in orange all over the world to raise global awareness for this important issue. The European Parliament is proud to take part in this initiative and will light up in orange starting tonight until tomorrow midnight. In this way we, as the European Parliament, want to stand up against violence against women and girls. This violence is one of the most cruel violations of women’s rights and therefore we need to unite efforts to eliminate it. In this context, I would like to pay tribute once again to last year’s Sakharov laureate, Dr Mukwege: to his exceptional work as a doctor, but also to his strong message, speaking out against violence and impunity and calling every day for justice and the protection of Congolese women. The European Parliament and in particular the Committee on Women’s Rights and Gender Equality (FEMM) has organised a series of activities for tomorrow, in cooperation with the Commission and the Council of Europe. You are all invited to attend and to participate in these events.

name: President. –
text: The next item is the debate on the report by Elisa Ferreira and Michael Theurer, on behalf of the Special Committee on Tax Rulings and Other Measures Similar in Nature or Effect, on tax rulings and other measures similar in nature or effect [2015/2066(INI)] (A8-0317/2015).

name: Elisa Ferreira
text: Rapporteur. – Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, if you were to be told now that this year you would pay a tax rate on your income of only 5 %, none of you would believe it, even though we are so close to Christmas. Well, that is the reality of most large multinational companies operating in Europe that pay effective rates of 5 %, sometimes even lower than that amount, even in countries where the nominal tax rate is around 30 % and more.  This situation has very serious consequences. The first is that the tax burden that feeds our collective expenditure on health, education, unemployment support, infrastructure, focuses almost solely on two types of taxpayers: small and medium-sized enterprises and natural persons, that is, the ordinary citizen.  The second consequence is that, at a time when so many exceptional sacrifices are being asked for by the population, which include giving up public services and social benefits, including some that have been solemnly contracted with the state, such as pensions, while the worsening tax burden rises to impossible levels, this situation is totally unfair. An injustice that becomes unbearable.  How does this explain itself? Strangely, although the rules of the internal market and the single currency have evolved to the creation of a level playing field across Europe, the European Union has always maintained, as regards direct taxes, the capital principle that it is sufficient for any Member State to object to an evolution in this area to be immediately blocked. This would perhaps be tolerated during the period of the founding of the European Union, when the three major countries, France, Germany and Italy, turned a blind eye to more or less open tax competition on the part of the three small Benelux countries. But today, with the European Union extended to 28 countries, and when the movement of capital is more important than the movement of goods, the distortion of competition in the internal market, coupled with this principle of unanimity, requires us to a very serious reassessment of our collective functioning. A year after the Lux Leaks scandal, the European Parliament is now producing its first major report on direct taxation in Europe. This report must be a factor capable of triggering the structural change that is needed. We all work seriously and intensely, we listen to hundreds of people, and we hope that our conclusions will enable this Parliament to take a solid, strong front in the face of the Council and the Commission, in defence of the interests of the citizens, who are also taxpayers.  Our proposals, it should be noted, do not want tax harmonisation in the Union, but rather to ensure that direct taxes on corporate profits are calculated according to common methods, that multinational companies publicly report on key information in each of the countries where they operate, that tax administrations, and in particular the European Commission, will have access to the terms of the tax agreements anticipated between administrations and large companies , that there is a much greater transparency regime at European level on how these issues are dealt with at Member State level, in particular in the framework of the Code of Conduct. We must also move towards a European definition of what tax havens are, assuming zero tolerance for them, and to create clear rules for the protection of alert launchers. It is also necessary to manage the conflicts of interest of those who advise tax on multinationals and at the same time advise the States and the European institutions. I'd like to leave one last note, and I'm done now, Madam President, and this note is that this work is not done. We have to keep working and get the information we haven't obtained so far, but that doesn't mean going backwards. We must quickly move forward this week with a continuation of our work, with a clear mandate to obtain what we have not achieved so far, but to move forward in monitoring the Commission and the Council in implementing what we are now recommending.

name: President. –
text: I was being kind because you are the rapporteur. My kindness will probably cease after we have the next speech from the co-rapporteur.

name: Michael Theurer
text: Rapporteur. Madam President, I would like to thank the president for her Equal treatment for all is the central issue, not only on the issue of speaking time, but also, of course, on the issue of tax payments. We note that there is no fair tax competition. Unfortunately, the revelations a year ago that brought investigative journalists to light in the wake of the LuxLeaks scandal have led us to find that some – and not just a few, but above all international – corporations are able to exploit tax loopholes. They have aggressive tax avoidance models that greatly reduce their tax burden. The figures on the table here are worrying when, for example, Disney can reduce its tax burden to 0.3% on a multibillion-dollar profit, if, conversely, it is clear to the House of Commons, for example, that Facebook paid only 5,000 pounds in corporation tax in 2014, less than the average Facebook employee earning 26,500 pounds and paying 5,393 pounds in income tax in return. , including insurance. That is unfair. Above all, the competitive disadvantage for small and medium-sized enterprises is significant. Scientists have calculated to us in committee that small and medium-sized enterprises have a disadvantage of 20-25% compared to large corporations. It was therefore necessary for this Parliament to set up the special committee, as I also proposed here a year ago. We worked hard. We were there in Luxembourg, Belgium, the Netherlands, Ireland, but also in the UK and outside the EU in Switzerland.  We have also invited representatives of so-called tax havens. We spoke intensively with NGOs and tax experts from independent institutes, universities, and we also wanted to listen to the corporations. Unfortunately, it took a very long time for the international groups Facebook, Google, Amazon, HSBC and Barclays to even be prepared to come to our Parliament. We should agree on this: such contempt for Parliament must not be repeated in the future. This is where we have to stand together. We have drawn up a whole series of proposals on how we can achieve fairer tax competition in the future. Our central insight is that the combination of 28 national tax laws leads to the loopholes that a few – especially large international corporations – have been able to exchange.  That is why it is now necessary to create a common European legal framework. This should include: the automatic exchange of information – we are grateful to the Commission for the legislative proposal. I repeat at this point that what has now been concerted does not meet our expectations. The exchange of information should have gone further. We also propose a common consolidated corporate tax base. We propose that the OECD recommendations in the BEPS project be implemented in a common EU directive as a way of making this binding.  If it were to be implemented nationally, loopholes would probably be inevitable in the end. Then it should be ensured that no profit leaves the EU without being taxed – here the double taxation agreements must be considered. We are calling on the Commission to clearly define the economic substance, and we call for a reform of the Code of Conduct working group, which needs political responsibility. Ladies and gentlemen, we have made good progress with this report, but there is still much to be done. The issue of political responsibility has not yet been finally resolved, and it is a major scandal that documents are still being withheld from this Parliament by the Member States and the Commission. That is why I can only call on us to take democratic control seriously.  We, as a directly elected Parliament, should now have full access to the requested documents. That is why I am also calling for the work of the TAXE Committee to continue.

name: Pierre Moscovici
text: Member of the Commission. Madam President, Madam and Mr rapporteurs, ladies and gentlemen, it is a real satisfaction for me to be present for this presentation of the final report of the TAXE Committee. It is a quality report and I want to put this to the credit of the two rapporteurs, Mrs Ferreira and Mr Theurer, as well as that of all the participants in this committee. I want to take the time to extend my sincere congratulations to them. We both want to make taxation more transparent, fairer and more efficient. This is a priority of the European Commission. It's expected by our citizens. This is one of the major thrusts of my action. I have already wanted to move fast and hard in 2015 and I want to maintain this momentum in 2016 with the support of the European Parliament. You know the two fundamental principles that drive my action and which are part of the most basic sense of justice. First, taxes must be levied where profits are made. This is called the principle of effective taxation. Second, everyone, including multinational firms, must pay their fair share.  This is an ambition which, I know, is shared by the TAXE Committee, which irrigates the report and explains why on many points, in reality, our views are converging. I will go back to a few of them, but I will go back to the quality of our cooperation with the TAXE committee.  I noted what Mr Theurer said at the end of his speech: the need for information. We have tried to find pragmatic arrangements to allow as many documents as possible to the different groups. There is still progress to be made. You know the limits that exist. They do not come from the Commission. I want to say it with a lot of force.  This year, the Commission presented two major initiatives to radically change the corporate tax system in Europe: the tax transparency package , it was last March, and the action plan on corporate taxation in June. These are two initiatives that lay the groundwork for substantial reform of the corporate tax framework, which covers a wide spectrum, ranging from transfer prices to preferential regimes, through pre-tax agreements, tax havens, conflict resolution and the reform of the code of conduct.  Many of these initiatives are the subject of specific recommendations from your committee. I want to get back to the main ones quickly. First, we heard the European Parliament's message on country-by-country reporting. I had the opportunity to say this in one of my hearings, because I had two before you, the Commission keeps the tempo on this initiative. We will finalize our impact study in the first half of 2016, accompanied by an initiative, which we will calibrate. You know my personal preferences, but we must also take into account, in the definition of the public to which we are addressing, the need to preserve the investment. That is where the Commission will set its point of view. It is in the Commission's work programme for next year, which gives you the measure of our commitment. Believe that mine, all personal, is strong on this issue.  With regard to the proposed Consolidated Joint Corporate Tax Base - ACCIS - the Commission wants to revitalize this issue, which has been in the Council for too long. This is a desire that has been clearly marked, again, in the Commission's 2016 work programme. We will withdraw the current proposal, not because it is bad, but because it is blocked. We will replace it with proposals for a two-step approach, starting with an agreement on a mandatory tax base. This will improve the single business market while filling in the gaps and ensuring that every business pays its fair share of tax. This is the key element of the overhaul of corporate taxation so that it is finally in line with the European dimension. I mean, however, that I am not giving up on consolidation. I know that is what is expected, but it seems to me that first proceeding to the creation of a common base is the way to convince those who are reluctant and, I regret, to move towards consolidation. I am pleased to see that we agree on these key instruments in the fight against tax evasion and on the establishment of a fair taxation system within the European Union.  With regard to the work carried out by the OECD, the Commission is totally in line with your recommendation. Now that the G20 - held in Antalya a few days ago - has approved the final measures of the BEPS project, this must effectively become the rule of the European Union. This must be implemented in a way that is compatible with the treaties. A patchwork of national approaches would split our single market, obstruct the freedoms guaranteed by the Treaty, and weaken Member States' efforts against tax evasion. Therefore, a coordinated approach to BEPS is essential and the Union has already taken the lead on this point. For example, the Commission's proposal to increase transparency on the early decision-making process in tax matters was adopted in a record time frame, only seven months after it was proposed, and I had the opportunity to come and defend this proposal for a directive. Here I once again welcome the very high quality of the work of the European Parliament. I would have liked, as you, ladies and gentlemen, to go a little further, but I think the compromise we have reached is, let us say, quality. We must move faster if we are to protect the taxable bases of all Member States and safeguard our common competitiveness. We must also ensure that our own instruments are consistent. Parliament calls on us, and I quote, to 'address in depth the problems related to corporate taxation, including harmful practices and their impact in the case of the European Semester'. The Commission is of course ready to continue to use all the instruments at its disposal to combat tax evasion, including in the context of the European Semester. So I'm responding favourably. Where the rules and practices that make tax systems vulnerable to aggressive tax optimisation are already being examined, they need to be more so. With regard to the external dimension of tax evasion, the Commission fully shares the opinion of the TAXE Committee that the Union must raise its level of play.  Last June, we published a pan-European list of third countries identified for tax purposes. It was the first time. This is an important step towards a more coherent approach to good fiscal governance in these countries. I am aware of the criticisms that may have come here or there. It was a potpourri or a best of. We must now move towards a much more coherent and common strategy. We must have a real external strategy in tax matters, which must be based on a common mechanism within the European Union, to deal with external threats to the member states' tax bases. On this point, again, our views converge. The Commission also shares the European Parliament's expectations for combating the misuse of legal structures such as corporations and trusts. We will therefore pay particular attention to the implementation by Member States of their obligations under the Fourth Anti-Money Laundering Directive.  With regard to the tax council, I would like to point out that new rules, which are already being implemented within the European Union and which apply to the auditing of the accounts of certain entities, will allow, among other things, to regulate the joint provision of audit services and tax advice to limit, as you wish, the risk of conflict of interest. They will apply from June 2016. Finally, a word about the control of state aid in the tax field. The Commission thanks the European Parliament for its support on this subject, which is obviously major. Aid control is an important tool to combat the illicit benefits that businesses get from Member States and helps to strengthen the fiscal fairness of our union. As my colleague Margrethe Vestager said, with whom I work in the best conditions, each in her field and in respect, of course, for the competences of the other, legislation on the one hand, implementation on the other, particularly through procedures that are at its disposal, she is continuing investigations on behalf of the Commission. It is making progress in its analysis of the information received from all the Member States on the report on tax rulings and you know that it has been led to take quite courageous steps with the college which, like you, I fully support. Ladies and gentlemen, when I was appointed, with this College, Commissioner of Taxation, a little over a year ago, I promised to make fair and effective corporate taxation a top priority. The pace and breadth of the Commission's business tax reform initiatives presented this year are proof, in addition to my personal commitment, of the Commission's commitment to go faster, stronger, further than any Commission has done so far. But 2015 is coming to an end and my work in this field has barely begun. Of course, it will continue at the same pace and with the same ambition in 2016 and beyond.  I want to tell you my conviction, which is also that of the Commission and its President, that the European Parliament has a crucial role to play. This is the role of deliberation. It is also, let us say, to maintain political pressure because you and I know what the tax rule is. It is restrictive, difficult and even limiting. That is the rule of unanimity, at twenty-eight. So we also have to be able to turn to the Member States. I do it, you do it, we do it together. I am sure that our institutions will continue to work hand in hand to advance these joint initiatives, and I believe that this report and the work of your contribution are an essential contribution to this.

name: Danuta Maria Hübner
text: on behalf of the PPE Group. – Madam President, we do need changes in the way tax systems, tax policies and tax practices work in the European Union. What we have right now does not fit the European reality of the 21st century and the principle of fairness. We all share the view that reform of tax systems is about making them fair, which entails ensuring that taxes are paid where value is created, and this is a common-sense principle. We also need to end the de facto double standards between SMEs and multinationals, which can use sophisticated strategies to escape taxes. A wide range of recommendations are made in this report, but let me use my one minute to insist on one point – the call for an improvement in the mechanism to solve tax disputes. This system is very weak in Europe and we need a good quality arbitration system, both globally, and this is a task for the OECD, and within the European Union. Let me conclude by saying that the unacceptable shortcomings we found should not conceal the fact that most companies are honest taxpayers, creating growth and jobs and serving our economies, and we need to be mindful of that and act in a proportionate way. (The speaker agreed to take a blue-card question under Rule 162(8))

name: João Ferreira (GUE/NGL)
text: It asks according to the procedure "blue card". – Ms Hübner, the question I would like to ask you is whether your Group, the EPP, is willing to support the coming of this committee again by Mr Juncker, President of the European Commission, and the President of the Eurogroup, with a view to the need to find out much better and in a much clearer way what their participation in all these processes , in particular with regard to this genuine patent box scandal.

name: Danuta Maria Hübner (PPE)
text: blue-card answer. – I could respond, but that is a question for the coordinator of our Group. I am sure, though, that both Mr Juncker and Mr Dijsselbloem and all other political leaders have already participated in all the meetings that we requested, so I hope that, if there is such a need, then this will be discussed in the Special Committee on Tax Rulings and Other Measures Similar in Nature or Effect and decided jointly. We do not believe we have a monopoly on these things, so we will be very happy to discuss and decide together with you on those issues.

name: President. –
text: There is another blue card, but I am going to take one blue card rather than two or three at any one time because it will delay our debate.

name: Peter Simon
text: Mr President, I would like to make a mifful son, mr President, I would like to make a ido to the S&D Group. Madam President, I would like to thank the president for her I would like to begin by thanking our two rapporteurs, Mrs Ferreira and Mr Theurer, but also our committee chairman, Mr Lamassoure, for discussing today a report that has brought together the breadth of Parliament in its different starting points to an outcome that is impressive in terms of how prepared this Parliament is to take up the fight against state-organised tax dumping, to support the Commission's fight against it. , that individual Member States give unjustified competitive advantages over multinationals, which give them advantages over small enterprises, over medium-sized enterprises, over the ordinary taxpayer. We want to continue to work on this on the basis of this report, which we will vote on tomorrow in plenary. We want to see that the Member States do not shy shoulder to shoulder responsibility. We want them to share with the Commission the things we are asking for, such as an automatic exchange of information on tax rulings to multinational companies. The European Commission is the guardian of the Treaties. The European Commission must be able to fulfil this task. We support the Commission in this, but we also expect the Commission to support us in our future work on this. Therefore, with regard to the work of the coming months, I would like to point out once again that there are a number of documents that we have not yet seen, that there are a number of documents where we know that there is still a dispute as to how much we are entitled to this. I am grateful for the constructive attitude in the past. We hope for one in the future as well. This Parliament does not yet see its task as over. The fight against state-organised tax dumping is only just getting started! (The speaker agreed to answer a question on the 'blue card' procedure under Rule 162(8) of the Rules of Procedure)

name: President. –
text: We do have another blue card from Mr Carthy. I do have to say that I cannot take a blue card after every speaker. I am going to allow this one if Mr Simon will accept.

name: Matt Carthy (GUE/NGL)
text: blue-card question. – Can I ask Mr Simon if, in light of the fact that there is a six-month extension, he has a view as to the real work that the committee can undertake during that six months, and particularly whether or not the committee will be in a position to carry out that work if Mr Juncker and Mr Dijsselbloem do not attend, and whether he has a personal view as to whether both of these gentlemen should attend the hearings over the next number of months?

name: Peter Simon (S&D)
text: Answer to a question about the "blue card" procedure. – Over the past six months, this committee has shown that it knows how to demand everything that is necessary for its work, as regards the collection of materials, including the participation of individuals in terms of the participation of companies. We will do the same over the next six months. We are committed to the cause, nothing else.

name: Ashley Fox
text: on behalf of the ECR Group. – Mr President, my Group is against tax evasion and aggressive tax avoidance. These global problems need global solutions, and I am pleased that the British Prime Minister has pushed tax matters to the forefront of the G20 agenda. The G20 OECD work in this area has provided a clear global framework, and we want Member States to implement the BEPS country-by-country reporting template. We believe that transparency of tax rulings and exchange of data are also sensible. Unfortunately, this report has missed the point; instead of uncovering proof of tax rulings being used as illegal state aid, the report goes too far in calling for tax harmonisation. It is another unwanted call for more Europe, which seems to be this House’s response to every question it faces. It also fails to provide clear definitions. There is no definition, for example, of aggressive tax planning as opposed to ordinary legal tax planning; no distinction between legal tax avoidance and illegal tax evasion; no recognition that tax rulings are normally made to clarify overly—complex tax laws. There is no recognition in this report that low tax rates are good for economic growth. Tax competition between states is good. Taxation is a Member State competence; long may it remain so. We need cooperation between states on a global level, not a power grab by the European Union.

name: Sylvie Goulard
text: on behalf of the ALDE Group. Madam President, Commissioner, I think it is always surprising to hear people are in favour of something at the global level when it is certain that this will not happen right away and accommodate the lack of action where it would be possible to act. I think that's a nice excuse.  For my part, I am rather here to welcome the work of the two rapporteurs, Mrs Ferreira and Mr Theurer, that of Alain Lamassoure and the whole Commission, who have tried to work on a subject which is anything but obvious, where definitions are not so easy to establish since there are grey areas, that is, things that are lawful but which are , by their magnitude, end up becoming totally and morally unacceptable. Looking to the future, Commissioner, I would like to stress two points. First, we would like you to continue to help us. You have done that, but we would like to go further in the search for documents. What for? Because this Parliament is the place of democracy and you know how much in our country, at the moment, we insist that Europe does nothing on a number of issues, that Europe is not up to the task. "What is Europe doing?" Here we have the opportunity to put the Member States before their responsibilities, because without them there is no European action possible. The second thing relates to what you said about the text on the consolidated common base. I was one of the shadow rapporteurs, we did our best. You consider it your responsibility to remove the text. It is not to defend a job, but let us just make sure that we are not accused, after the fact - as we are doing now with respect to the NRP - of having braked. Our intention is not to slow down, and I do not think it is the Commission's, but to succeed as soon as possible. The paradox is that most of the companies, the multinationals we have heard have told us clearly: "If you don't want tax rulings and evasion, give us a level playing field, let's make sure we have the same rules all over Europe". Last but not, of course, we will have to focus on applying the OECD rules as much as possible.

name: Fabio De Masi
text: Mr President, I would like to like to sanendour sto -- on behalf of the GUE/NGL Group. Madam President, I would like to thank the president for her A year ago, a young courageous man, Antoine Deltour, made LuxLeaks and the tax deals of corporations with Luxembourg public. Deltour now faces five years in prison, while Juncker became President of the European Commission. But Juncker is right: LuxLeaks should actually be called EU leaks. We lose up to hundreds of billions of euros a year through these tax tricks, while the sponsors of the tax cartel, Mr Juncker or Eurogroup chief Dijsselbloem, are flooding the EU population with austerity diktats.  And it is also true that in tax havens banks also launder the money of criminals. Nor does the Islamic State park its oil billions under pillows in Syria. Neither the Commission nor the Council could say whether any of the measures required by the United Nations to dehydrate terrorist financing in the EU had been implemented in practice. The dehydration of tax havens and sanctions against banks that aid money laundering and tax evasion are therefore not only a requirement of justice, but also of security. The committee – we would have liked a real committee of inquiry – came across an omerta, a wall of silence. Documents have been refused or blackened by the Commission and Member States. That is why my group will be bringing an action before the European Court of Justice. The public has a claim to the truth. We have new insights into how Juncker and Dijsselbloem defended the tax tricks in patent boxes to the teeth for Luxembourg and the Netherlands. They can no longer hide behind small officials. Nor the finance ministers of the large Member States – like my own, Germany – who remained silent about this because domestic corporations benefited. Juncker also told Parliament the untruth on a secret side of the Krecké report. They must now be accountable to the people here. Are you ready to re-invite Juncker and Dijsselbloem: Yes or no?  The former chief of staff of the U.S. Senate Permanent Investigation Committee told me how they grilled the Goldman Sachs board for eight hours. She was disturbed by how weak the European Parliament was towards corporations. We too need a permanent committee of inquiry with instruments of sanctions against corporations. My group has been able to enshrine many positive elements in the report; for example, the impact of the cuts on tax enforcement, the extension of the list of tax havens also to INCLUDE EU Member States in country-by-country reporting and so on and so on. But that is not enough. The exchange of information on tax rulings must be as public as in the UNITED States and even in Belgium.  After all, the finance ministers have been penning and looked away. Corporate profits must be determined immediately across the EU for corporation tax. Profits must not continue to be pushed across borders. Every village policeman knows that you cannot write an investigative report until all the evidence has been assessed and the perpetrators have also been named. That is why my group regrets that, despite many positive elements, we must abstain on this report. The information work must go further. Taxpayers in Europe are entitled to this. (Applause)

name: Philippe Lamberts
text: on behalf of the Greens/FTA group. Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, it is little to say that the delivery of the special committee TAXE was laborious and that the baby was not really desired by everyone, and certainly not outside the walls of this chamber. And, of course, when this baby is only a few months old and some would already like to shorten his life, it will be extended anyway, and he will receive a respite on Thursday and I am delighted. In any case, I would like to thank all those who collaborated in the drafting of this report, Elisa Ferreira, Michael Theurer, but also Alain Lamassoure, who I think shares our collective indignation at the way in which the tax war that the Member States are waging is in fact damaging to all our citizens and ultimately only benefits the shareholders of big business. I therefore welcome this consensus and it is true that this report is encouraging. It re-publishs country-by-country, mandatory and public information, and re-reports on a common and consolidated corporate tax base. I am proud to say that this is a first step, Mr Fox, towards greater harmonization, which does not mean one size fits all - to speak your language - corporate tax. He also talks about the protection of whistleblowers, all of which is there. But it should not be left unheeded now.  I see that those who block the most in this case are absent. Where is Pierre Gramegna to represent the Council? I'm speaking here to an empty chair. Of course, this is no coincidence, since everyone knows that this tax war was waged by the Member States and that they do not really want to make amends; that is what Commissioner Moscovici was referring to earlier when he said that it was not easy. That is true, Mr Moscovici, you are right, it is not easy. Nevertheless, I think the Commission can do one or the other thing: the first, if you want us to be pressured, give us access to the documents. Because, frankly, the way you have given us access to it is unworthy of a democracy: behind closed doors, with a ban on talking about it and using them; it's a big joke! As far as publishing country-by-country information, you started your process, that's very nice. We now have an ongoing negotiation on the Shareholder Rights Directive and I expect the Commission to simply support Parliament's position; it's as simple as that. It does not require an impact assessment, a consultation, and I do not know what else. Take action, that is what you will be judged on.

name: Marco Zanni
text: Mr President, president, ladies and gentlemen, i.e. the european Union, the European Union and its Member States are Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, exactly a year ago in this House I called for Mr Juncker's resignation for his involvement in the LuxLeaks affair. Today, my request does not change: it is confirmed by the months of difficult work of the TAXE Committee. Mr Juncker has not yet clarified the issue of the missing page of the Krecké report and continues to deny any direct involvement by Luxembourg. Unfortunately, the reality is quite different, and those of us who have been able to see the documents have been able to see how Luxembourg has always opposed any decision by the group on the code of conduct to eliminate tax distortions within the EU. I am addressing the Luxembourg Finance Minister directly, who obviously had better things to do today: if you have nothing to hide or fear, why do you not make public all the documents relating to the group's meetings on the code of conduct since its inception? It is clear that everyone is trying to do their own business, but we cannot accept lessons and have confidence in those who have endorsed and encouraged these practices to the detriment of our European partners. This applies not only to Mr Juncker in Luxembourg, but also to the President of the Eurogroup, who is an active part of this scandalous affair.  The citizens of Europe want transparency! Transparency, which was denied to the members of this special committee, who received few documents late and with many secret parts. What is Europe afraid of? The truth, perhaps? However much we want to continue with fiction and deceit, when it is clear that this Union, based on mutual falsehoods and improprieties, does not actually exist. If we want to be credible, we must first of all shed light on the past, on the political responsibilities of those who have allowed all this. And then move forward towards country-by-country reporting in public, a full CCCTB right away, a central register for public tax arrangements and finally also intervene in the fundamental role that banks play in this business.  That is essential! The rest are just words in the wind of mean people unfit to represent the citizens of Europe.

name: Bernard Monot
text: on behalf of the ENF group. Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, the REPORT of the TAXE Committee has the merit of kicking the anthill of Mr Juncker, the great helmsman of the unfair scheme in the heart of Europe. The practices of many multinationals seeking to avoid tax through aggressive schemes have led to scandalous situations at a time when austerity is being demanded of Europeans. For too long, nothing has been done. Companies such as Starbucks, Google or Facebook make considerable profits on the backs of citizens and pay almost no taxes to Member States. For France in and cases, the damage to public finances was 15 billion euros per year. What were you doing in Bercy all these years, Mr Moscovici? The tax response is necessary and delicate, we support the harmonization of the corporate tax base, the ACCIS plan, the exchange of information, the publication of information by country, in order to tax profits where they are made.  But we patriots categorically reject the prospects of a fiscal union and a harmonization of rates. If the report of the TAXE Committee goes in the right direction, on the other hand, we will remain very vigilant and critical of the feedback from the Council and the European Commission.

name: Burkhard Balz (PPE).
text: Madam President, I would like to thank the president for her First of all, I would like to thank the rapporteurs and, in particular, our committee chairman, Alain Lamassoure, for the work they have done over the last 12 months. I would like to start by saying very clearly that the PPE-DE is no longer understanding whether to tolerate tax evasion and tax fraud. That is not possible! The European Parliament is calling for a louder voice on European tax coordination, and quite rightly so. It is not acceptable for micro-enterprises and small and medium-sized enterprises to pay their full tax rate for the common good, but large corporations to spend their money only on tax advisors. The Member States – and I would also have liked a Council representative to be here today – have not done their homework in recent years. They have exchanged little or no information and have only thought of their own control pot. It is therefore absolutely overdue that the Commission should now start new attempts on these issues. Above all, it is important to harmonise the corporate tax base here, and we welcome the fact that the Commission intends to act swiftly in this area. We must also keep an eye on the international level. The OECD is doing immensely important and helpful work here. It would certainly not be a good thing for Europe if we were to impose requirements and reporting obligations on European companies, which do not have to meet their global competitors to a similar extent. In any case, therefore, we should continue to support the work of the OECD.

name: Anneliese Dodds (S&D).
text: – Madam President, my thanks go to colleagues who have already spoken to support this report. I am enormously pleased that our Parliament looks set to approve six measures which, if enacted, would radically reduce the possibility of tax dodging across Europe. As colleagues have said, the measures are: first, making public the profits and taxes paid by multinationals in every country where they operate; second, fixing a common tax base for corporate tax so companies and governments cannot fiddle around by playing definitions off against each other; third, creating a robust European definition of tax havens with sanctions for those who use those havens; fourth, protecting whistle-blowers like Antoine Deltour who act in the public interest; fifth, ensuring tax advisers provide a clean service that does not involve conflicts of interest; and finally, making sure countries share information properly and quickly about sweetheart deals concluded with multinationals. I am particularly pleased to see these measures command support across all of the parties – certainly all of the Groups – within this House. In fact, when it comes to country-by-country reporting for multinationals and making that public, Parliament has already shown its support – emphatically – and I am very pleased that it looks like we will be doing that again in the days to come. The same applies when it comes to measures within this report to protect whistle-blowers, where it is excellent to see so much agreement within this House. However, I have to say that I have been disappointed before and I was disappointed again today – although sadly there appear to be no UK Conservatives left in the Chamber at the moment – that they continue to be against the consensus of this Parliament for European action against tax dodging. In 2013 David Cameron said that when taxes are not collected, the poor suffer, but his measures have been described by Conservative peers themselves as purely political gestures. I would hope they might have changed their tune, and I will continue to lobby for them to change their tune before the vote on this report. (Applause)

name: Bernd Lucke (ECR).
text: Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, I would like to thank the rapporteur for her excellent report and for the way in which she has been rapporteur for Before the law, before the law, all are equal.  However, through the work of investigative journalists, we have established that there are also companies in the European Union that do not get the right that everyone should get equally, but their individually adapted tax law. They get the interpretation of tax law in such a way that they can reduce their tax burden, in some cases downto a minimum, while other companies have to bear the normal full tax burden. This obviously leads to a distortion of competition.  This is a concern for the internal market, and it is right that the European Union, the European Parliament, has taken action here and, in the form of this committee of inquiry, has tried to shed light on this darkness and into this confusion. The Committee of Inquiry itself, it must now be said, was a weak committee of inquiry. I hope that he will have more instruments in the extension than what he has had at his disposal so far. The way in which we were able to question the representatives of companies and representatives of tax administrations or parliaments was weak and almost a farce. The example that has just been mentioned is that you grill a representative for eight hours is what we should also remember. However, we must also please ensure that the Commission makes use of the instruments it itself has at its disposal. Of the more than 500 tax cases now known by investigative journalists in Luxembourg alone, hardly any have been investigated – a total of just 65 cases since 1991. That is far too little. We have competition law as the Commission's sharp sword. The Commission should also take advantage of this. If it cannot use it, it should be strengthened in terms of personnel.

name: Philippe De Backer (ALDE).
text: First of all, I would also like to thank the rapporteurs for their work in the context of this very important report. We can no longer tolerate tax fraud and illegal tax evasion. It cannot be the case that companies pay less tax than citizens on the lowest incomes, and it certainly cannot be the case that SMEs have to pay more tax than multinationals. It's hurting our economy. I am therefore pleased that this report makes proposals on these crucial points to establish a fair and transparent tax system in Europe. Member States must ensure that tax legislation falls within the principles of the internal market. Member States' fiscal policies must not distort competition, and at the same time it is important that fair tax competition should continue to exist in order to attract businesses. We need economic diversity in Europe and fair competition will make it economically easier for certain countries to attract investment.  I am also very pleased that the report tackles the overcomplexity of national tax systems and also proposes to address this overcomplexity in order to close loopholes in the tax system.  I think it is a very important report and I hope that the Commission will do everything in its part to turn the balance we have found into legislation in the near future.

name: Marisa Matias (GUE/NGL).
text: – Madam President, I would like to begin by thanking the rapporteurs, the shadow rapporteurs and the Chairman of the TAXE Committee for the work done, even though the mandate is so short. But I want to say that we have arrived here only at the end of a first phase and that everything or almost everything is still to be done. Tax havens, tax fraud, tax evasion and tax avoidance, favours for multinationals take billions of euros from public accounts, health, education in each of the countries where multinationals operate, produce their profits but do not pay their taxes every year. It is that in fact for multinationals it is Christmas every day, but it is not Christmas every day for workers and for small and medium-sized enterprises, which see their taxes increase every day, to address this fraud. In 2011, Portugal's foreign direct investment abroad grew by 134% compared to the previous year, with the Netherlands as its main destination. The reason was the transfer of tax residence of 19 of the 20 companies registered on the Lisbon Stock Exchange in Portugal to one of the European tax havens that granted it a secret tax agreement. Special agreements are unfortunately the rule in 23 of the 28 countries of the Union. The European Commission, which has presented transparency as its main flag, cannot be satisfied with what has been done. We need it and we want all the information. Those who should not fear, and it is not acceptable that among the 13 countries that have not provided information is Luxembourg and the Netherlands. There is a lot of work to be done and no one should be free of responsibility – I will end, Madam President – not even, not even Mr. President of the Commission, Mr Jean-Claude Juncker. The responsibility when you're born is for everyone.

name: Sven Giegold (Verts/ALE).
text: Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, I would like to thank the rapporteur for her excellent report and for the way in which We have presented a strong and good report here, and the best thing about it is that it is, in the broad agreement of this House, that we need strong measures. Despite all the differences on many issues, a long list of possible measures has now been presented here, both for the Member States and for the EU as a whole. We have to say that Parliament has been strong in proposing the necessary common tax policies. Until now, Parliament has been weak on who is actually responsible for this tax scandal. This responsibility must still be established. There must be no pressure here, but the citizens of the EU have a right to know who bears political responsibility for hundreds of billions in tax losses. Those who bear the responsibility, both in the Member States and in the Commission, must declare their responsibility here before this Parliament. It also contains interesting proposals, Commissioner Moscovici. There is now the new line of tax havens saying: we are now implementing BEPS, but please do not take a step further in the EU! You said that you wanted to go further. I think there are two particularly exciting proposals. On the basis of Article 116, legislation can be made against market distortions in the majority procedure. Propose such a directive, as the report calls for! Last but not least, make sure that no income can go untaxed under the bilateral tax treaties!

name: Steven Woolfe (EFDD).
text: – Madam President, this taxation committee arose out of the Lux Leaks scandal, which has established that President Juncker was in government when corporations gamed the system to a huge extent. Instead of censure of politicians like Mr Juncker, who were involved in allowing corporations to extract exceedingly large profits from the ordinary citizens of Europe, the EU has done what it normally does: it has created a sneaky trick to get ever closer union on taxation through the front door, rather than the back door, for a single EU tax policy. Here I agree with Mr Fox from the Conservative Party. We oppose tax evasion and aggressive tax avoidance, but we believe tax competition is positive. As Winston Churchill once said, we ‘contend that for a nation trying to tax itself into prosperity is like a man standing in a bucket and trying to lift himself up by the handle’. This is the policy of the Labour Party as exposed by Ms Dodds on the other side.

name: Mario Borghezio (ENF).
text: Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, the action of the strong and hidden powers, financial but also political, which even prevent the Commission from working, is very clearly visible, requiring those responsible – Mr Moscovici, I am talking about you – to give the TAXE Committee the documents to investigate. And then there are the scandalous behaviour of the large multinationals, such as Walmart, Fiat – which does not even respond to the invitation to appear, but which is always praised by the President-in-Office of the Council as an example! This is a fine example of Fiat refusing to examine the TAXE Committee! –, the enormous damage to the system of enterprise and small and medium-sized enterprises. Not forgetting the troika, which was so harsh on the weak (Greece, Portugal) and very weak when it had the power to prevent the causes of this crisis, preventing such enormous advantages in favour of a part of the economy to the detriment of the interests of the real economy and therefore of the peoples and therefore of the workers and therefore of the real producers.  The king is naked: the Commission is showing all the compromises it has been able to make. We are in the hands of your strong powers and your masters.

name: Alain Lamassoure (PPE).
text: Madam President, the creation of the TAXE Committee was the political response to the scandalous revelations of LuxLeaks. Our investigations have shown that for at least two decades, some Member States have engaged in a real covert overbid to the tax advantages offered to multinationals. If the other states let it happen, it is because in reality, each side had its own niches and managed to be someone else's tax haven. This is no longer acceptable and I congratulate our rapporteurs on their recommendations.  Thanks to whistleblowers and the media, thanks to the European Commission - its tax arm and its competition arm, and I thank Commissioner Moscovici for the past and future cooperation - thanks to the OECD and the G20 and thanks to the political pressure that this Parliament has maintained for the last nine months and needs to maintain, a change of mindset is beginning to take place everywhere. Everyone is beginning to realize that tax competition can no longer be done in opacity, disloyalty and injustice. That time is over! As for companies themselves, having admitted for some time that they have a social responsibility, that they have an environmental responsibility, they must begin to understand that they also have a civic responsibility, which is to contribute to the fair financing of public services in the countries where they work, in proportion to their activity. In the financial world, there has been a before and after Lehman Brothers, it is up to us, that in tax matters, there is a before and after LuxLeaks.

name: Hugues Bayet (S&D).
text: Madam President, Commissioner, as you have said, tax justice is obviously fair taxes for all of us, because it is normal to pay taxes and it is normal for us to contribute according to what we earn.  I would like to remind you what taxes are for. They are used to finance social security, our hospitals, our schools, our public transport or all the infrastructure that depends on it. More broadly, I would like to make it clear that public investment is an essential element in promoting economic development, if not who will build our airports, ports, industrial zones, multimodal platforms?  Public investment is also essential for social cohesion, for urban development, for work in neighbourhoods and for the necessary security of our citizens. All here, as well as all the citizens who watch us or listen to us, we know what more could be achieved in our Member States with an additional EUR 1 trillion per year. A whole series of multinationals had forgotten this and, fortunately, whistleblowers broke the Swiss scandal and the LuxLeaks scandal. In response, as you know, the European Parliament has worked conscientiously for several months to understand and trace the flow of tax-exempt money.  I would also like to thank our two rapporteurs because in this report there is a whole series of measures which may not be able to limit tax evasion to 100%, because the inventiveness of tax advisers seems to be limitless, but which will allow us, in any case, to put a brake on this kind of drift. This aspect represents the glass half full. The glass is half empty, of course, that Parliament does not decide alone. For the measures we are proposing to have an impact, it is essential that the Commission and the Council also decide to be ambitious. The European Commission, pushed a little by our work, seems to be on the right track. On the other hand, the Council is more resistant to change, and I think it is at this level that our next fight is.  If we have identified the problems and proposed ambitious solutions, we must obviously manage to convince the Council to follow us, which is why I support the extension of the TAXE committee. This will allow us to continue the fight and convince the strong reluctance to introduce a tax justly distributed.

name: Zdzisław Krasnodębski (ECR).
text: – Madam President, i voted in favour of the report by Mrs Schwab It is not only the practices of the companies revealed by investigative journalists that are scandalous in this case. This must be emphasised that it is not disclosed by the European institutions, not by the European Parliament, not by OLAF, but by investigative journalists. But it is also scandalous that this kind of practice took place in Luxembourg when Jean-Claude Juncker, the prime minister of luxembourg, convinced a great European, the current President of the European Commission, who spares us many speeches here in this House about European solidarity. We must ask our parliamentarians whether this is really the right person in the right place, in a Commission that is supposed to uphold European law and treaties?  But the reason these corporate practices, these unfair practices, has been and is the powerlessness of states against large corporations and advisory firms, not vice-versa. Unfortunately, one of the main demands of the report is to open the way to tax harmonisation in the Union, i.e. to further restrict the sovereignty of the Member States and their ability to pursue economic policies. I don't think that's the right way to go.

name: Ramon Tremosa i Balcells (ALDE).
text: – Madam President, last year we discovered that about 340 multinationals secured privileged deals with Luxembourg in order to avoid paying taxes on their activities in Europe. Other Member States have done similar deals. Our committee has made several proposals to fight the situation, taking into account the weak state of our finances. Dear colleagues, what multinationals do not pay, SMEs should not compensate with a higher tax burden. Simplification of tax systems, a common corporate tax base to ensure fair competition and much higher transparency are all fundamental reforms we need. It is disappointing that some Member States like Spain have been so reluctant to make public tax rulings and multinational privileges. We Catalans also want a new state to lead in this fight for a more fair and reformed tax system that does not give privileges to multinationals against SMEs and citizens, putting at risk our welfare state.

name: Miguel Viegas (GUE/NGL).
text: – Madam President, tax fraud and tax evasion is a widespread practice for virtually all European States and has been known to all the governments of the European Union for decades. These practices aimed at controlling national tax authorities in order to drain profits to territories where they are not taxed or tax havens are deeply linked to the current process of European integration, which has in the free movement of capital one of its main cross-beams and globalisation as its main consequence. Were it not for the disclosure of successive tax scandals at a time when the European peoples suffer the effects of austerity, we would probably still be living with these crimes in total impunity. It was therefore the indignation of public opinion that propelled this whole plan of good intentions. The report under discussion today is incomplete. We have fought in recent months against the various obstacles. We still have no access to documents of great importance for a correct assessment and clearance of facts. Every day new elements emerge involving senior European officials and requiring an extension of the mandate of the TAXE Commission. As an incomplete report, we abstain, in the conviction that work will continue, confronting the European institutions with their responsibilities and also with their action plan announced in June and that little or nothing has progressed.

name: Eva Joly (Verts/ALE).
text: Madam President, Commissioner, ladies and gentlemen, one year after the LuxLeaks scandal, it is clear that Parliament, despite some reluctance, has carried out a high-quality work. I will begin by praising the work of our co-reporters who have completed this report, which I hope will serve as a roadmap for the other European institutions that are too frail. I also want to salute the work of our President Alain Lamassoure. This report sets a course for the future, it also helped to outline the responsibilities of those who allowed fiscal injustice to become the norm. This work, it is necessary to extend it by six months. (The President interrupts the speaker) Parliament has been able to assert itself with multinationals, but must now strengthen its muscles in hearing and investigation. We will also have to re-audition President Juncker and Minister Dijsselbloem, whose past actions deserve a minimum of clarification. Finally, the extension will send a clear message to the Commission and to the Member States. Parliament wants to control the action of the executive, access to documents remains the priority. To date, we have received only a tiny percentage of what we have requested and that is not acceptable. Colleagues, we are on the right track, let us not give up.

name: Luděk Niedermayer (PPE).
text: – Madam President, what we are debating today is important, and I believe it should not be the end: it should be just the beginning. Better collection of taxes and elimination of unfair market-distorting practice by some Member States and firms or countries in the world should be eliminated. It should be one of our key priorities: the priorities that should deliver the result. I believe that this report, together with the work programme of Mr Moscovici and the report by the Committee on Economic and Monetary Affairs (ECON) which will follow, will come with reasonable and good priorities that we should implement. Firstly, we should quickly and without hesitation implement the BEPS recommendation – a project that was initiated by the G20, including ourselves, and was endorsed by the OECD. We should set an example for other countries to implement these measures. Secondly, we should ensure that Member States of the EU will give the green light to the CCCTB project. CCCTB will be able to eliminate most of the problems of aggressive tax practice within the European Union. Last but not least, we should also implement the other measures in the area of coordination like improving the function of the work of contact. I believe that this will not be a simple issue. We will be facing a lot of obstacles, but I hope that Parliament will play an important decisive role in promoting progress in this important area.

name: Jeppe Kofod (S&D).
text: Madam President! Commissioner! Every citizen is cheated on average in the EU a year because of organised tax fraud. That money was supposed to go to our hospitals, schools and nursing homes. Instead, these many billions are vaging secret accounts in tax havens.  There must be consistency and harsh penalties for countries, companies and individuals who commit tax evasion. That is why the Socialist Group is also making clear and concrete proposals: companies that systematically commit tax evasion should be able to be stripped of their business licences. They simply should not be allowed to do business in the EU. Anyone who opposes tax fraud has to back down. Even those countries that profit from tax evasion must be punished considerably more severely. As the rules are today, tax cheats can only be required to collect the difference between the illegal low tax rates they have offered some companies and the tax rates that apply to all of us. This will entice tax-cheat countries to set up large companies in their country, they will be lured to jobs, and then when the Commission judges the tax agreements illegally, their penalty will be to recover the tax due.  So tax-cheating countries get both new businesses and more jobs and a handsome extra tax revenue. It's not a penalty, it's a Kinder's egg, three good things in a little fine package, and of course it has to be stopped. That is why we are also proposing that the tax due should go not to the tax-cheating country, but to the other Member States that were cheated of jobs and tax revenues.

name: Pirkko Ruohonen-Lerner (ECR).
text: – Mr President, it is important to remember that the decisions of the EU and the Member States are also felt outside the Union's borders. In this regard, it is great that the proposal for an amendment focusing on cooperation between the Ministries of Development and Finance and the Tax Administrations has passed.  On the other hand, it is regrettable that many good proposals were eliminated in the votes in committee. One such proposal was for the Commission to examine, in the next round of reforms of the Procurement Directive, whether it would be possible to increase the use of tax transparency and accountability criteria in public procurement. For example, construction companies engaged in aggressive tax planning, tax evasion, could be thought of excluded from public works contracts. This could be a very discretionary matter as things are further developed.

name: Marian Harkin (ALDE).
text: – Madam President, in one minute I can only refer to a few important points. First of all, let me say that I am very pleased that I was one of the original signatories requesting the setting up of this committee, and I fully support its extension. Secondly, I agree with Michael Theurer. We do not have fair tax competition.
