At EU and at global level we have to find a way to ensure that multinationals pay their fair share of tax and that SMEs and ordinary taxpayers do not continue to shoulder a disproportionate share of the tax take. In this context, however, we also need to ensure that the EU itself remains competitive. It is not just Belgium or France competing with Germany or the UK, but it is also that the EU itself must compete with Singapore or India. Thirdly, I do not support trying to change the unanimity rule with regard to the tax rate. Member States must continue to have the right to decide on that. This proposal has the potential to split the Union. We should not do that; we should work with the instruments at our disposal. Finally, we need to implement the OECD stance on BEPS. We need to ensure public country—by—country reporting, and it is essential that taxing rights are lined up with economic activity. (The speaker agreed to take a blue-card question under Rule 162(8))

name: Tibor Szanyi (S&D)
text: Blue card question. – Madam President, you have also mentioned the responsibility of the companies, but I do think that there are two fairs here. Tango requires two. Here are the Member States, the governments of the Member States. Do you see an opportunity here, either in this Parliament, or by any other means, to persua the Member States to be constructive on this matter?

name: Marian Harkin (ALDE)
text: blue-card answer. – Thank you, Mr Szanyi. I do agree with you. I think Member States have a responsibility and that they should not just be encouraged – it should be stronger than that; they should take a responsible attitude. I believe that, through the BEPS project that the OECD is proposing, we can make real progress. I think we have to recognise that we have a mismatch when it comes to tax systems in different Member States. So I do think Member States have a responsibility, and I think this report contains a lot of proposals that will help to ensure they discharge that responsibility.

name: Paloma López Bermejo (GUE/NGL).
text: – Madam President, we welcome the view that this report sets a clear position against tax avoidance and its devastating effects. It is the workers who suffer the cuts, despite paying the taxes that large fortunes and multinationals avoid. But a clearer position is needed on the political responsibilities of the Commission and the Council, which is well justified by the extension of the TAXE Commission's mandate, in line with the public commitment of this Parliament on Monday. Today we know that Mr Juncker and Mr Dijsselbloem had to know and protect fraudulent practices from their governments. That is why it seems to us that their tax proposals seek to silence the scandal and not really correct the accounting traps and regulatory holes through which taxpayers' money escapes. We already have examples of the counterproductive attitude of some governments, such as mine, Spanish, and European institutions, in the areas of greater transparency and better protection of whistleblowers, cuts imposed on Treasury inspections or their taste for tax amnesties. That is why it is necessary to expand and overwhelm their approaches in order to build a just system.

name: Markus Ferber (PPE).
text: Madam President, Commissioner, ladies and gentlemen, I would like to thank the rapporteur for her excellent work and for the work she has said. First of all, I would like to join the ranks of those who want to thank my fellow Members, especially the rapporteurs, for the work that has been done. However, I would also like to say critically, of course, that many of the things that were formulated in the mandate have not been achieved in this way. It was a question of checking whether everything was going right here in the European Union and where there were mistakes. And there are a number of mistakes. I find it regrettable that the committee also essentially took care of a country, even though there are many sinners on the way here in the European Union. Why, for example, has the Dutch Finance Minister never been consulted, why never the Irish, why only the former Luxembourg, to describe a problem? I also ask the Commission: what has the Commission done in recent years – we have now introduced new legislation on tax rulings – that the non-functioning system that was adopted is even brought to life? That, too, is a question to which an answer has never been given. On the other hand, we are now looking at whistleblowers and the like more, and we must be careful not to overburden small and medium-sized enterprises with false regulation. So I really wonder whether we have fully fulfilled our mandate. I hope, however, that when it comes to extension, we will be able to really take up the points that are worth picking up. We need to look a little deeper than just what we have been given so far.

name: Sergio Gaetano Cofferati (S&D).
text: Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, Commissioner, the debate we are having is very important because, as you know, Europe needs to grow. In order to do this, it must have an economy that is able to compete in the global market. Competition is at the heart of the debate and the acts to accompany the debate we are having.  What is competition today? We have rushed as you know from Jacques Delors' very high exhortation to compete on knowledge and quality at LuxLeaks. Not paying taxes or proposing tax ruling solutions outside any rule is not only an element of social injustice, both for businesses and for citizens of their communities, but it is also an improper and wrong way, to compete between states.  That is why I believe that the content and proposals made in the taxe committee's report, those relating to transparency and the coordination of tax rulings, those on the common tax base, those on the protection of whistleblowers, the one on country-by-country, are very important. We have opportunities that must be taken in a positive way. One is to give the committee a mandate to continue and complete its work. The other concerns the European Commission. I believe that if the Commission were to accept the proposals contained in the report and in the proposal for the shareholders' directive, we would be taking an immediate step in the right direction.  I look to see concrete action.

name: Peter van Dalen (ECR).
text: – Many multinationals, such as Starbucks, Facebook and Philip Morris, are deliberately involved in tax avoidance. The Special Committee on Tax Rulings has brought this to light again. My own country, the Netherlands, made this possible with secret agreements that were on the edge of the law. I call that unethical. After all, all these companies benefit from social services such as infrastructure, vigilant police forces and trade treaties, but do not pay for them.  Businesses, consumers and governments must ensure that corporate social responsibility becomes a reality for these multinationals. Fair tax policy is based on the principle that income tax is paid there, where the profits are made. Taxation is and will continue to be the core competence of the Member States and competition between Member States in the area of taxation helps governments to remain sharp and slim. I do not want European tariffs, but in terms of transparency and definitions, we can strike a major blow here in Europe.

name: Nils Torvalds (ALDE).
text: – Mr President, we often talk about solidarity in this Chamber. However, the practice turns out to be a little different. We remember from the past that before the snake in the tunnel and other animals were invented, member states devalued against each other very aggressively. To this end, an EMU system was invented and thought or the most childish of us thought it was in order and taken care of. However, it turned out that this aggressive action against other Member States continued. The history of Luxembourg is quite interesting in this respect. Sometimes they used to make steel and coal there. When this proved unprofitable after the energy crisis, there was a move to steal tax revenue from other Member States. This is a bad road, it leads to greater unfriendliness and disoliidacy among the Member States.

name: Othmar Karas (PPE).
text: Madam President, Mr President-in-Committee, ladies and gentlemen, I would like to thank the rapporteur for her excellent work and for the work she has said. The report is good, but it does not solve the problems, and it is therefore urgent that we continue with our work. The damage from tax avoidance is glaring. In OECD countries, 5% of current corporate tax revenues are lost annually. In the European Union, around EUR 1 000 billion of potential tax revenue is lost every year – through tax fraud, tax evasion and tax avoidance. And it is true that each country is a tax haven from the point of view of another country, that probably even the various measures and the practice to date are mostly legal, but in any case unethical, because distorting competition, unjust and unfair.  That is why we demand that taxation take place where economic activity also takes place. We need more transparency, hence country-by-country reporting, cross-border information. We need automatic transmission of tax rulings, harmonisation of tax bases, elimination of unanimity and implementation of the G20 decisions. We need to go further in depth in order to strengthen the package of demands.

name: Emmanuel Maurel (S&D).
text: Madam President, there was an expectation on the part of European citizens, who had been legitimately outraged by the revelations of the LuxLeaks affair. The report, which we are discussing today, is part of the answer to that expectation. I say this in part because I think it is a job worth being welcomed, but hailed as a first step towards what might be called the Union's fiscal awakening. Much remains to be done, as has been said, but it must be repeated.  In this report, we can clearly see the shameful behaviour of multinationals that are implementing very sophisticated tax optimization strategies. It is a report that also demonstrates the very negative effects of this unfair competition between states from a tax point of view and which results in huge shortfalls. Mr Bayet has talked about EUR 1 trillion, and that is the amount of money. Finally, it is a report, we must stress this, which shows the unequal treatment between multinationals that sometimes evade tax and small businesses that pay full pot. So there are recommendations that go in the right direction and, of course, at the heart of the project is the ICSA, this consolidated corporate tax base.  Commissioner Moscovici presented the Commission's proposal. This is a step in the right direction, but I think we should not stop from looking further and going faster. I think there is this or that aspect that is interesting, for example, the protection of whistleblowers and the prevention of conflicts of interest. After, we can regret the absence of certain points. I am thinking in particular of a minimum corporate tax rate.  Overall, this is a good move. This is a first step in this long and necessary march towards fiscal justice.  (The speaker agrees to answer a "blue card" question (Article 162, paragraph 8, of the regulation))

name: Gianluca Buonanno (ENF)
text: Blue card question. I wanted to ask my colleague: I have been here a short time ago, I was a Member of Parliament in Italy before and I am mayor in Italy. But in your opinion, since you are talking about multinationals, and according to all the Members who are here, but you are not hypocritical to talk like this, given that there are possible and imaginable lobbies in here of multinationals, which come to break the boxes for everyone in the committees, to say 'do this and do the other' and many Members are subsidised by the multinational lobbies.  So what are you doing? You want the drunk wife and the barrel full?

name: Emmanuel Maurel (S&D)
text: "blue card" answer. I am not sure how the Social Democratic Group would defend lobbies or multinationals; I don't see the connection. It is true, however, that when the multinationals finally acceded to our request to appear before the TAXE Committee chaired by Mr Lamassoure, they showed a casualness which was, to say the least, distressing. I note that on both the right and the left, there is a touching unanimity in favour of condemning these practices, and I think we will all agree that we must move from this touching unanimity to action. That is what we are proposing in this report.

name: Sander Loones (ECR).
text: – Imagine that there would be only one airline in the entire European Union and only one electricity company. Prices would be higher and services lower. We all know that. That is why we do not like monopolies. Competition depresses prices and keeps businesses on their toes. The same logic applies to governments, to Member States of the European Union.  One large European government would cost more and would offer us a lower service. Tax competition keeps Member States on their toes and keeps taxes low, although this is even better. My group will not be voting in favour of this report, because it is precisely this report that is pointing the finger at those Member States who are doing the necessary and want to share information, but also because this report is constantly responding to this tax competition and because it does not focus enough on those issues that it really should be about: unfair state aid and ensuring that this transparency is finally thoroughly guaranteed.

name: Esther de Lange (PPE).
text: – Perhaps in addition to what the previous speaker said. I am not known in this House as someone who is averse to a bit of competition, but if that competition means that we are all engaged in a race to the absolute zero rate, I do not think that is wise.  So I, on the other hand, absolutely welcome the work that this committee has done. I believe that this committee - and I would like to thank the rapporteurs and chairman - has worked to a large extent on the same basic attitude and that is honesty. How fair is it when citizens pay taxes, when SMEs pay off neatly and then large companies cross the border into the dance? Yes, the political groups differ when it comes to what is needed next. What is proportional? What should you do, what not to do? But we largely agree in this House that the solution, despite the fact that taxation is a national matter, must also be in Europe. And the report gives some very useful suggestions for this, which I would like to wholeheartedly support.  This gives the European Commission a very important task, namely to put them together, to fit together 28 national pieces of the puzzle. Also the responsibility, dear European Commission, to dare to take action if necessary. That has failed in the past. And I miss that in the debate, i may have to agree with the previous speaker when it comes to competition. Of course, we don't operate in a vacuum. The European Union is in a global context and I miss the story: are we looking at competitiveness enough? Not from one individual country, but from the whole of the European Union as a whole. This is a good start. And get on with it.

name: Paul Tang (S&D).
text: – Thanks to the rapporteurs and the Chairman of the Special Committee on Tax Rulings. There is an excellent report which shows that a large financial, legal complex has emerged, which allows large companies, the very richest ones, to siphon off their profits and withdraw their assets from the tax authorities. As a result, honesty is far to be sought. The inequalities are very, very big. The coffee house can't compete fairly with Starbucks. The ordinary man or woman does not have the opportunities that the very richest have, and that affects tax morale. Developing countries have it checked. They see the much-needed tax dollars disappearing across the border. Those are the victims.  There are also perpetrators, and those perpetrators should actually better identify the report. The perpetrators are the big companies that say they are socially responsible but have no difficulty in creating tax structures. The perpetrators are also the tax advisers who advise the big companies or the tax havens that help to save profits or make the assets disappear. And the perpetrators are also the Member States, here in Europe, which are a portal of these tax havens, including Member States such as Luxembourg and the Netherlands. It is these countries that need to take the lead. I agree with Esther de Lange that the Commission now has an important role to play. It must come up with initiatives and encourage the Member States, because these practices must be stopped. Let this report be the beginning of the end.

name: Frank Engel (PPE).
text: Mr President, Commissioner, ladies and gentlemen, I would like to join all those who congratulated the rapporteurs and the chairman of our special committee for the work of the last few months, one in terms of drafting, the other in terms of the political leadership of a committee whose task was not easy.  We now have a report that tells us, on an impressive number of pages, what is wrong. And that's not going well for a very good reason. This is not for the simple reason that all Member States, and some, including mine, more than others, but also other parts of the world are participating in a global competition to attract the headquarters of large companies. They engage in this competition by means that they find to be fair and adequate, means which, alas, do not always correspond to the highest ethical precepts.  Mr President, as we are about to extend our work by six months, I would like to know whether the Commissioner could not conceive of extending the status of what we already have, European society, in the future by a fiscal dimension, so that the European Union becomes an actor in this global competition to attract headquarters , by practising a European community tax rate in the EU, which further increases the EU budget as its own resource.

name: Pervenche Berès (S&D).
text: Mr President, Commissioner, this committee exists because, in the end, the Member States have allowed multinationals to abuse them for too long and use them to organise competition that undermines the foundations of our social contract. We are now at a time when all Member States need to put an end to this deadly tax competition, which prohibits internal and external solidarity from taking place at a time when we so desperately need it.  So I believe that the work of this commission is essential when, first of all, it is said that the tax base of multinationals must be rebuilt. I am told, here or there, that ultimately the tax-free amounts would not be as large as that. That is why we are so focused on the consolidated nature of this tax base because otherwise there is indeed a lot that we do not understand. Whistleblowers must be protected, and finally, this momentum must be kept from pressure organised by this European Parliament to support the Commission and to encourage Member States to finally move from words to action and to cooperate in tax matters to prevent multinationals from escaping tax justice.

name: Ildikó Gáll-Pelcz (PPE).
text: – Mr President, on the one hand, the practices of tax evasion and avoidance made public, and on the other hand, the need for fair tax payment and burden-bearing have led us to work more harmonisedly. And that's fine. I would also like to join those who thanked the report-takers for their work, and I would also like to thank Mr President for his work. This report has come to a very important conclusion. I can also say that what's in the report is as good as it got into it. What's not in it, however, we still have the opportunity to put in it if we dig deeper into this subject. I am pleased that we have been able to make it clear that the tax burden on multinationals should not be less than the tax burden on SMEs.  I am also pleased that we have made it clear that tax should be paid where income is raised. When I think of the hundreds of billions of hidden incomes, I must say that there is a legitimate need to reveal these incomes. The majority of companies, on the other hand, are safe to say that they are decent taxpayers. But now we have taken one step towards being even fairer and more decent taxpayers. It is very important that, towards the end of the work, multinational companies as well as the Member States have shown much greater willingness to cooperate with these companies. It would be good news if we could extend this circle of cooperation to a global level.

name: Ramón Jáuregui Atondo (S&D).
text: – Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, it has emerged from the TAXE Commission as the main conclusions which many companies pay little and pay poorly in Europe, and that there is also competition between the States. A number of very important conclusions have come out, I would say a long-term roadmap. Now, the question is: Who's going to launch it? When? How?  And I would like to warn this Parliament, ladies and gentlemen, that there will most likely be great difficulties in implementing the measures in this roadmap, of this extraordinary report drawn up by the rapporteurs, because the Member States do not accept the work of the Commission or accept the work of this Parliament either because they claim that this issue is national sovereignty , claim that this issue is the responsibility of the States and that it is legitimate to have jurisdiction between them.  I believe that this is what we have to avoid and this Parliament needs to be very aware of what is happening in order to implement these measures.

name: Eva Kaili (S&D).
text: – Mr President, this report is an important step forward, as it sets the legislative framework for sanctions against those who promote and implement unacceptable tax avoidance and tax planning practices, and also because it deprived all of us of the pretence that we did not know what was going on. A year ago, many were pretending that tax havens did not exist within the EU, so I guess it was difficult to believe how easily they who demanded the increased competitiveness of the countries of Southern Europe are actually the ones who undermined the competitiveness of the EU with their well-hidden fiscal practices. Now we know that we have to do something, and we know what to do: we have the road map to do it. It is paramount to keep pushing for more transparency and more tangible results, especially in the workings of the Code of Conduct Group, the willingness of which to cooperate remains questionable. So it is not addressed enough in this report, but we expect the Council to stop sabotaging the work of the European Parliament and the Commission on taxation issues. The momentum is already accelerating for a more transparent fiscal environment in the EU, and we must assure those who put resistance and obstacles in our way that there is no way to stop us.

name: Ivana Maletić (PPE).
text: - Mr. President, I welcome the Commissioner, we are not seeking a single tax policy at European Union level, but states would have to meet the minimum requirements of clearly setting tax rules that must be simple, accessible to all and fair.  Tackling tax fraud and tax evasion must be part of our joint efforts to strengthen the single market. An important step is the insistence on transparent and well-defined tax rules that are not subject to a number of additional interpretations due to different exemptions and derogations from the general rule. Tax competition must not be a tax war because it will never benefit citizens.  That is why I support the work of the Tax Committee and think it is important to continue sending messages from the European Parliament on how important fair competition is and that fair tax policy is one of its key elements.

name: Nicola Caputo (S&D).
text: Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, in my question of November 2014, I pointed out that the lack of tax harmonisation between Member States leads to tax competition and dumping that seriously alter economic competition and the proper functioning of the single market. The Commission's response highlighted the problems created by the coexistence of 28 different corporate tax regimes and the difficulty of harmonising the corporate tax base. The LuxLeaks scandal has also highlighted the lack of awareness of the secret agreements of 300 multinational companies but, clearly, the figure is structural and refers precisely to the Member States and to the lack of harmonisation.  The proposal for a directive and the report, with which I agree, respond to these and many other demands, aware of the need to eliminate asymmetries between tax systems as soon as possible and to improve cooperation within the European Union, as these problems are a burden on other taxpayers, namely SMEs and citizens. Confidence must also be restored in tax matters if we are to be able to operate in a truly integrated and competitive single market.

name: Ruža Tomašić (ECR).
text: – Mr. President, the fight against tax evasion is a noble goal because allowing such practices would be unfair and discriminatory against those who do business conscientiously and in accordance with laws and rules. However, I cannot support a report promoting, under the auspices of this struggle, a repressive tax system and the introduction of a common consolidated tax base for the entire European Union. Such initiatives, as if they wish to penalised those Member States which, through the introduction of incentive tax policy, have become more competitive and thus taken a share of the revenues from those who have stifled entrepreneurship. In my view, such practices should not be penalised but rewarded and thus encourage all Member States to become more competitive and attractive for investors and entrepreneurs by reducing taxes and administrative barriers.  We will not reduce tax avoidance by further stifling entrepreneurs, increasing the powers of tax administrations or punishing tax advisers, corporations, but only by a more sensible and stimulating tax policy.

name: Κώστας Χρυσόγονος (
text: GUE/NGL). Mr President, the report we are debating today reveals the absurdity of building a single market in capital, goods and services between the Member States of the European Union without a single tax regime. The result is that transnational competition is being created to attract companies motivated by lower tax rates and associated tax exemptions. Moreover, large multinational enterprises benefit from their inherent potential for over-invoicing or undercutting in intra-group transactions and exploit national preferential arrangements to avoid paying taxes with legitimas.  All this results in almost zero effective tax rates for multinational capital and a burden on ordinary citizens and small and medium-sized enterprises.  We need uniform tax rules and their implementation in practice if we want a Europe that promotes the well-being of its peoples and not the promiscuity of large capital.

name: Ernest Maragall (Verts/ALE).
text: – Mr President, the Ferreira-Theurer report of the TAXE Special Commission is the best argument for what may result from a committee of inquiry, as proposed by the Verts/ALE Group: an experience full of positive lessons and disappointing findings. What is surprising is not to see multinationals divert their profits where they can pay less tax, but to discover the necessary complicity of some Member States and to see how the Commission protects each other, preventing this Parliament from accessing documents that compromise them. We were talking about the fact that the number that multinationals stop contributing to public coffers is a figure close to the Union's own budget, a nonsense that we will only be able to tackle if the States of the Union cease to compete unfairly with each other, that is, if we move forward in harmonising our tax systems; indeed, if we convert to European taxation the profit of those companies that benefit most precisely from the single market, that is, those operating in all the States that make up it: first, the taxation of the digital business, a case in which the concept of paying taxes where profits are generated only corresponds to the whole of the Union.

name: Marco Valli (EFDD).
text: Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, I basically agree with much of what is written in this report. The fundamental question now is: where is the political will? Where is the European Council? Where is the representation of Luxembourg, one of the countries at the centre of this investigation and the one that also led to it.  We are now with Juncker, who is the President of this Commission and a member of the Eurogroup who represents another state that has been protecting strong interests for years. But where is democracy represented here? People would like a Europe that is democratically represented and that Europe should take care of the interests of these citizens.  Most European citizens have small businesses and small businesses close because they pay too much tax. The big multinationals do not pay taxes, as we have seen, and we are represented by the defenders of this system. This is precisely the hypocrisy of this Europe that we are trying to combat in every way. And while this Parliament can be spent on producing good texts, the political will is very little. (The speaker agreed to answer a blue card question (Rule 162(8) of the Rules of Procedure)).

name: Frank Engel (PPE)
text: Blue card question. Mr President, this is not a question, but I too wondered why the Luxembourg Presidency was not here. I was assured that the European Parliament had decided not to invite you. This seems to me to be extremely strange, but I wanted to share this information with you.

name: Marco Valli (EFDD)
text: Answer to a blue card question. It is not really a question, but it is essential that the Luxembourg Presidency is represented here because, I repeat, it all resulted from the LuxLeaks scandal and we decided to set up this committee from there.  At the beginning it was supposed to be a committee with inspection powers; in truth, it has been impoverished with a committee without these powers. Without the Luxembourg representation and without the political will of that country and of countries such as the Netherlands or Ireland – or anything else – it will be impossible to pursue anything concrete, however much Parliament spends in this direction.

name: Barbara Kappel (ENF).
text: Mr President, Commissioner, I would like to thank the commissioner for her work and for the work she has The TAXE Special Committee has not only highlighted a great deal of harmful tax practices in Europe. Corporations such as Facebook and Apple were named today, Starbucks and Fiat have been convicted by the European Commission, and further lawsuits are pending. No, that wasn't all. The Committee initiated a study, which was subsequently commissioned by the European Parliament, which showed that the Member States of the European Union are missing up to EUR 190 billion a year through profit shifting, special tax arrangements, inefficient tax collection and similar practices – funds that are lacking in the budgets of the nation states in terms of budgetary consolidation. In view of the large volume of tax loss and the great tax injustice – please remember that the average corporate tax rate in the European Union is 23.5% and these groups have often paid less than 1% – the fight against aggressive tax planning has taken on a new place in the European Union. The mandate of this committee has been extended. That is a good thing. The committee and the proposals must ensure greater tax justice and transparency in the tax system.

name: Romana Tomc (PPE).
text: – I have followed closely the developments in this committee, and I am also a co-signer of the amendments.  Like many have so far, I would like to make it clear that more political will is needed to condemn the conduct of Member States that have not cooperated with the committee. This cooperation is crucial. But if it is not respected by corporations, how can we expect it to be respected by the Member States?  I would like to highlight three important points, which I believe should always be repeated. Firstly, taxes should be paid where economic activity is generated and where added value is generated. Secondly, harmonisation of tax basics is necessary. As there are differences between Member States in these bases, companies are taking advantage of this. And thirdly, we must do everything we can to ensure that additional measures do not put even more strain on businesses with bureaucracy, especially small and medium-sized ones.

name: Ana Gomes (S&D).
text: – Mr President, the Ferreira-Theurer report is the result of the crucial research carried out by the TAXE Commission to lift the veil of opacity in which multinationals operate in the European Union and the world, paying less and less tax, while burdening citizens and SMEs, and the captured rulers claim there is no money for the welfare state, nor to invest in the economy and job creation. The data of Portugal are acabrunhantes in this matter, not only for the Portuguese governments, but also for the institutions that integrated the troika. Now our governments continue to pursue whistle-blowers, which should be protected, and continue to limit the transparency of tax agreements and exemptions, benefits and other immoral and unfair tax practices to maintain the tax dumping they have embarked on. This Parliament should not accept in codecision an agreement that does not oblige companies to publish their accounts of accounts country by country, as banks already do, without prejudice. The TAXE Commission must continue to investigate, for transparency, the scrutiny of multinational tax policy and the end of the scandalous complicity of European governments against the interests of citizens and the Union.

name: Νότης Μαριάς (
text: ECR). Mr President, most Member States of the European Union are affected by tax evasion and avoidance and the main protagonists in this type of practice have been multinational companies. In particular, tax avoidance by multinationals results in zero tax revenues for profits in European jurisdictions and erosion of the national tax base. Moreover, these companies, through intra-group transactions, avoid paying taxes on their profits, thus creating social inequalities and negatively affecting the budgets of the States.  However, in the face of tax rulings, all Member States of the European Union are called upon to take measures to stop multinationals turning to tax havens and avoid tax avoidance in the Netherlands or Luxembourg, as has become known through luxleaks.  Finally, the profits of multinationals should be taxed where they are made.

name: Stanislav Polčák (PPE).
text: – Mr President, I was very shocked by the scale of the Luxleaks scandal and I must say that the scale was so surprising to me that I considered myself supporting the provisions of this committee. I admire my colleagues in my political group who have found the courage to do so even against the opinion of even the majority of my political group. However, the conclusions made by the Committee are very inspiring and I think that in this case it is really about preventing tax dumping. De facto unfair tax competition, because that is what threatens Europe far more than a single tax system. I'm not in for a single tax system. And I must say that I am not yet convinced that a common tax base should be established at the level of European law. On the other hand, it is not possible for us to continue to tolerate practices that only multinational corporations really favour, and in this sense I will certainly support the committee report that has been tabled here.

name: Pierre Moscovici
text: Member of the Commission. – Mr President, thank you very much for this high-quality debate. I would like to show – of course, with the normal differences between Groups and MEPs – consensus on the objectives that we want to obtain together. A few comments on this debate. Firstly, tax evasion and avoidance cannot be tolerated any more. Tax fairness is supported by all political Groups, and for that you will have the full support of the Commission. Secondly, we need to build a tax system for the 20th century. That is exactly what we want to do together. Thirdly, implementation by Member States needs to be ensured, not only within the EU – that is about tax rulings – but also more widely, and globally, at the level of the G20 at least, on the automatic exchange of information. Of course, I will advocate for the fast adoption of the CCCTB – and I mention the three Cs and not just the two. There, we must pursue a level playing-field, reduce complexities for our companies and eliminate aggressive tax practices. Fourthly, on the EU action on BEPs: yes, I want the EU to be in the leadership. I fully support the remarks made here for an EU which is law-compliant and your concern with preventing 28 different approaches. We need to have only one common approach. Fifthly, on a country-by-country report: yes, we will have a complete impact assessment. I want this to be public, of course, but at the same time the Commission will also think about protecting EU businesses’ competitiveness, as called for by several Member States. Everything must be looked at. But again, this is not against my personal preference, which is well known. When we talk about publicity, there is ‘public’ in it, and we must do as much as possible in that field. Sixthly, on access to documents: the Commission has already given access to 350 working documents of the code of conduct since 1998. By virtue of the inter-institutional agreement between Parliament and the Commission of 2010, we need to have the formal agreement of Member States in order to share more. I did all that I could, and I am very willing to cooperate even more. We discussed that with the President of the committee, and you may be sure that the Commission is not a reluctant part of it. But of course I understand your concerns, and I will try to find an even better solution. On the extension of taxes mandate, the Commission has already cooperated with the committee so far and will continue to do so. The committee’s political pressure is of high importance to achieve progress, and I see that positively, not as a constraint or as criticism (criticism is part of democracy) but really as positive pressure. Seventhly, on an external dimension towards third countries and a definition of tax haven: the Commission is looking into this in the framework of its June planned follow-up. I said in what spirit I would advance on that, and we all agree on that. Eighthly, unfair tax competition is to the detriment of all, except certain multinationals. Tax competition, as mentioned, should not lead to tax war. Many of you said that, and I fully share that view. Ninthly, and lastly, improved dispute resolution mechanisms following the June action plan. We have started to work on that, and we will continue to do that together. I would like to finish by once again congratulating the TAXE committee for the work that has already been done. I look forward to further cooperation with Parliament and to bringing forward our agenda for a fairer, more transparent and more efficient tax system for Europe’s citizens and businesses. We, on our side, will continue our work with determination, conviction and ambition. Mais une dernière réflexion, peut-être, après vous avoir tous écouté. J'ai eu la chance, dans ma vie politique, de siéger dans les trois institutions. J'ai été membre de ce Parlement pendant six ans, y compris vice-président du Parlement. J'ai été au Conseil pendant sept ans, y compris deux ans dans le conseil ECOFIN et maintenant je suis à la Commission. Je connais par cœur les jeux de rôles qui peuvent nous regrouper ou nous séparer: je ne confonds pas le Parlement, la Commission et le Conseil, chacun est à sa place.  Mais si nous voulons avancer sur ces sujets délicats, pour le bien-être de nos citoyens, ne nous opposons pas les uns aux autres. C'est vain et il n'y a pas, dans cette affaire, les bons et les méchants. C'est seulement si la Commission prend des initiatives fortes, c'est seulement si le Parlement met en place des pressions fortes et intelligentes que les États membres – qui ont le pouvoir de décider en la matière – lèveront eux aussi certains blocages. Et donc par tempérament, sans doute, mais aussi par expérience, je vous invite davantage à la coopération qu'à la confrontation, une coopération qui peut être virile ou qui peut être forte, pardon je ne veux pas apparaître sexiste, et qui est la condition pour faire avancer la cause que nous défendons tous ensemble.

name: Elisa Ferreira
text: Rapporteur. – Mr President, Commissioner, ladies and gentlemen, we need broad support for this Parliament to be able to have enough political weight to overcome the habits and interests of taxation. Finally, I would like to thank a group of people and a group of entities: firstly, the Chairman of the TAXE Special Committee, Mr Lamassoure, who has always been able to use great diplomacy, great elegance, but has never lost the right direction; I would like to thank my colleague Michael Theurer for the fact that we have together managed to converge on the diagnosis of problems and also on solutions; I would like to thank the shadow rapporteurs and the members of the TAXE Committee; and I would also like to thank, in particular, all those who have come here to give their testimony on tax competition in European matters, especially journalists, warning launchers - who took very particular risks - and the international consortium of journalists, which launched Luxleaks, without whom we probably would not have had all this activity and all this debate; and, finally, to our personal secretariats and to the secretariat of the TAXE Commission, which have been insignificant in supporting the members of this Parliament. With regard to the Commission, the Commission can count on a very demanding Parliament, but also with a Parliament capable of supporting in this fight that interests us all. And I end by saying that of course Parliament does not accept the absence of elements on which we are probably, hopefully, to take decisions later this week: to continue to know more, to investigate further, not only to know, but to prevent the blockades that have prevented progress in the past in the future in relation to the agenda that we will adopt tomorrow , I hope, by a large majority. Thank you all very much, but I think we are actually making european history.

name: Michael Theurer
text: Rapporteur. Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, I would like to thank the rapporteur for her excellent report and for the way in which I would also like to express my sincere thanks: first of all, to the co-rapporteur Elisa Ferreira. A Liberal author, a Social Democrat, has presented a text which was a good basis for discussions with the shadow rapporteurs of the other groups. We would like to thank the suggestions that have also been made clear in the debate today. Yes, we need better protection for whistleblowers. That was the most moving moment when the poor people were with us on the committee, who have suffered personal disadvantages for representing the common good here. This must change in the future. A simpler tax system, as recommended by the OECD – at low rates – is also included in the report, including the binding implementation of the OECD recommendations. It is not true that the European Parliament or the Commission would have prevented the Member States from combating tax avoidance. No, the Member States have not been able to solve it on their own in the past. That is why we need a European solution. Dispute resolution is also proposed. These are all correct and important proposals.  However, we need more time. The consultation of the corporations came too late – too little time for it. The interrogation procedure is also wrong. We should do the hearing as we did in the Commissioner's hearings. The documents are also incomplete and full access to the file was not possible. Three hours for 800 pages, many of them blackened. This is not a way of working, Parliament should not allow itself to be allowed to do so. We are directly elected, we have to carry out democratic control. Citizens were concerned after the revelations of the LuxLeaks affair and they are awaiting clarification from this Parliament. This is where we should stand together. Together we can make a difference, and that is why I hope that tomorrow we will also get a broad, cross-party majority for our report, so that we can then go out with a strong signal and say: Member States, you are called now, let us have fair tax competition in Europe! Let us abolish tax dumping once and for all!

name: Preşedinte. –
text: The debate has been closed. The vote will take place on Wednesday, 25 November 2015. Written declarations (Article 162)

name: Λευτέρης Χριστοφόρου (
text: PPE), in writing. – We stress our clear position that we are opposed to tax evasion and avoidance wherever these unacceptable acts take place, which are absolutely reprehensible. Also, unfair and illegal tax practices are hell-hard and should not be tolerated by anyone.  However, this in no way justifies a leveling-off in all tax matters which will ultimately probably create injustices and problems, even distortions and damage to certain States.  A typical case, the attempt to level the tax issues and in particular corporation tax. Until now, the obvious has been true, i.e. each country has the possibility to set its own tax rates for corporation tax, VAT and excise duties.  We therefore consider it non-negotiable to keep tax policies in the Member States, which will be able to define their tax policies and manage their own economy. In the name of the resolution of tax matters, certain States cannot be undermined and stripped of the basic right of the free economy to determine their tax policy.

name: Ian Hudghton (Verts/ALE)
text: in writing. – I welcome the recognition in this report of the fact that Member States remain fully competent to set their respective corporate tax rates. The report also points out that the current opacity in the international tax system allows MNCs to avoid taxes, circumvent national tax laws and shift their profits to the most favourable location for minimising the payment of tax. I am aware that there may be a need to restore the link between taxation and economic substance, and to ensure that taxes are paid in the countries where actual economic activity and value creation takes place. Our constituents should not be the ones to suffer from austerity policies while MNCs are able to avoid contributing to the Member States through fair taxation.  This report offers many constructive suggestions aimed at reducing the scope for blatant tax avoidance, but I cannot support amendments and paragraphs which seek to enhance the EU’s role over Member States’ tax policies and rates. I recognise the potential benefits which could arise from increased transparency and the sharing of information between Member States but I remain of the view that the Member States should continue to exercise full competence in this field.

name: Evelyn Regner (S&D)
text: Writing. – The TAXE Committee has produced a very good report and proposed effective measures to make tax competition fairer so that workers and SMEs do not continue to bear the tax burden in the EU for the most part. Our demands include a common harmonised corporate tax base, the public reporting obligation, the automatic exchange of information – as we recently adopted here in the European Parliament in the Shareholders' Directive, and not the 'light version' of ECOFIN – and a binding anchoring of the OECD recommendations on BEPS. We can no longer stand by and see profits leave the European Union without being taxed. This is where the Member States must pull together and implement these demands. Only in this way can state-organised tax dumping be put to an end! Profits must be taxed where they are generated. Although there are very good elements in this report, the task of the committee is not yet over. There are still many unanswered questions, many documents and minutes of meetings in which we were not allowed to access. I therefore call for the mandate of the TAXE Committee to be extended.

name: Theodor Dumitru Stolojan (PPE)
text: in writing. – It is a shame that today, in the European Union, some Member States have refused to make available to the Special Tax Commission the required documents on tax comfort letters granted to transnational companies. In enough cases, such letters of tax comfort have given transnational companies the opportunity to transfer profits from the countries where they are made and should be taxed in other countries where simple mailboxes operate. These tax practices must cease immediately, and the Council, the Commission, the European Parliament and the Member States bear full responsibility to the citizens for this cessation to happen.

name: Preşedinte. –
text: The next item is the debate on the report by José Manuel Fernandes and Gérard Deprez, on behalf of the European Parliament's Delegation to the Budgetary Conciliation Committee on the European Union's joint draft general budget for the financial year 2016 approved by the Conciliation Committee in the framework of the budgetary procedure (11706/201514195/2015 - C8-0274/2015 - 2015/2132(BUD)) (A8-0333/2015).

name: Jean Arthuis
text: Chairman of the BUDG Committee. Mr President, Madam Vice-President, ladies and gentlemen, I welcome the agreement reached by the budgetary reconciliation and I would like to express my satisfaction and gratitude to all those who have joined forces to achieve this: the Presidency of the Council in the person of Pierre Gramegna, Minister of Finance of the Grand Duchy, whom I am pleased to welcome. , the Commission, in the person of its Vice-President, Kristalina Georgieva, our rapporteurs, José-Manuel Fernandes and Gérard Deprez, but also Eider Gardiazàbal Rubial and Jens Geier and, more generally, all members of our delegation. I think I can say that, in a particularly constrained context, Parliament has fulfilled its mission well.  We wanted this budget to be for growth, for jobs, and to meet the challenges of migration and refugee reception, but we must not pay words. Locked in a multi-year financial framework adopted in December 2013, our budget leaves us destitute as soon as a major crisis occurs. Faced with exceptional circumstances, we of course dream of exceptional resources and measure our impecuniousness as quickly. Subterfuge will no longer be able to mask reality. Many of the ads will look in vain for funding the means they call for in the budget we are about to vote on. This is so true that other sources, including direct contributions from Member States, must be sought to provide trust funds for Africa and Syria. Moreover, with regard to payments, a test of truth for all our commitments, the current appeasement is only the consequence of inertia and postponements in the launch of programmes. In other words, from 2017, unpaid bills will once again pile up on the Commission's desk at unsustainable levels. The situation has become crucial. At this stage, we must remember that Parliament's agreement on the 2014-2020 financial framework was only agreed on the condition of a mid-term review, a post-election review. I am counting on the Commission, which is described as the "Last Chance Commission" in the words of its President Jean-Claude Juncker. Yes, I am counting on the Commission to submit a project to us that is up to the challenges that we must assume, in line with the tasks that the Member States have already entrusted to the European Union in the European treaties, and those to come.  I remain confident in expressing the hope that the two branches of the budgetary authority, the Council and Parliament, can approach this meeting with seriousness, lucidity and courage. Your Committee on Budgets is preparing for this under the leadership of our colleagues Isabelle Thomas and Yann Olbrycht. Of course, I have no doubt that the Commission will provide expert assistance. May the Council show the same provisions of mind as those which prevailed in our successful conciliation. Be congratulated, Minister. Ladies and gentlemen, beyond the 2016 budget, which I encourage you to vote on, let us prepare to reframe our budgetary perspectives to convince Europeans that the Union, in an age of globalisation, has the ambition to assert its power and that our duty is to give it the means to do so.

name: José Manuel Fernandes
text: Rapporteur. – Mr President, I would like to greet the Commissioner, also greet the Presidency of the Council, Minister Pierre Gramegna, and greet all colleagues and colleagues. I would like to thank the rapporteurs, I would like to thank Gérard Deprez for his work excellence and also jens Geier, who is the permanent rapporteur for the agencies, and congratulate him on the work and results achieved, as well as Mrs Gardiazabal. We are a team, accompanied by all the shadow rapporteurs, which I also want to welcome. I would also like to greet all the councillors, all the political advisers, all the political groups, all those who participated in this negotiation, the secretariat and obviously greet, in a very special way, the Presidency of the Council and say that it has done a competent job. I do not think there has been unanimity in the Council on the budget for many years and I would therefore like to congratulate the Presidency of the Council and the Vice-President of the Commission, Commissioner Georgieva. I think we are all to be congratulated: we have an agreement that is positive, which responds to the challenges, which responds to the challenges, which is in line with the priorities we have set and Parliament's priorities.  We've brought this deal to the limit of our way. We used the flexibility instrument, EUR 1 530 million above the margins in its entirety, and we exhausted the margin of heading 1a, heading 1-B, heading 3 and heading 4; finally, we have exhausted the margins for growth, for employment, for social and territorial cohesion and also for internal and external solidarity to help solve the refugee crisis.  If we look at the first draft budget in relation to the appropriations for authorisation, we increase these authorisation appropriations by EUR 2 800 million, reducing the Council's cuts. Also in payment appropriations, if we look at the draft budget before amending letter 1, there are 2 151 million payments in appropriations that we also obtained. We can say that this is the employment budget and the solidarity budget.  In addition, it should be noted that we have succeeded in getting the Youth Employment initiative to be a priority for the institutions and continue after an assessment to be made in 2016. On the crisis affecting farmers, we have reinforced the amount by EUR 500 million, also to deal with this problem. And on employment, we do not forget to strengthen Horizon 2020 for innovation and research, Cosme for small and medium-sized enterprises and Erasmus+ for youth. On migration and refugees, the external side is well present: we mobilise all possible tools to solve this problem internally, but also to act at the source, and this package, where we include agencies, cooperation and development instruments, I am sure it will also bring more security to the European Union and help refugees.

name: Gérard Deprez
text: Rapporteur. Mr President, Madam Vice-President of the Commission, Mr President of the Council, I too will start with the thanks because I am afraid that I will not have time to do so at the end of my speech. I would like to begin by thanking my fellow rapporteurs, starting with my colleague and friend José Fernandes, who has done a remarkable job, our colleague Gardiazabal Rubial, and the one who has had arguably the most thankless work, Mr Gahler for the agencies. I would also like to thank all our staff: those of the secretariat and political groups, as well as our personal collaborators for the hard work they have done. I would like to congratulate the Vice-President, in particular, who has succeeded in its first real budget for 2016, and the Commission delegation. Finally, and in particular, I congratulate the President of the Council, Pierre Gramegna, our friend, for his perfect knowledge of the issues, his sensitivity to priorities and his remarkable spirit of conciliation. The success of conciliation on time owes him a great deal. I obviously share everything that my colleagues, President Jean Arthuis and the rapporteur-general José Fernandes, have said before me, and as rapporteur for the other sections, I will limit myself to what is my responsibility, that is, the other sections, and I will start with the European Parliament's budget for 2016. First of all, I will tell you, ladies and gentlemen, that this is a rigorous budget. With the exception of an exceptional endowment of EUR 15,000 to improve the security of buildings and the security of computer systems, which is much needed today, you will agree, the European Parliament's budget for 2016 is only increasing by 1.6% compared to 2015. Secondly, this budget is all the more rigorous because it has been calculated on the basis of a wage adjustment of 1.2%, whereas under the application of the provisions of Article 65 of the Statute, this adjustment will in fact be exactly double what was the basis for the development of our proposals. We agreed in conciliation that this adjustment, which concerns all EU institutions, would not be financed by additional appropriations, but by spending cuts on certain items and internal transfers. For example, for the European Parliament, this will represent an additional effort in 2016 of almost EUR 10 million. Third, this rigorous budget, which I should say is doubly rigorous, is also a reform budget. These reforms are primarily concerned with the organisation of a better system of supervision and control of local assistants attached to parliamentarians. As a result, and through this reform, the excesses, if not the real abuses, to which the current system has given rise will no longer be able to occur or will in any case be detected and better controlled. Other reforms, including the parliamentary system, are currently under consideration and will soon be implemented. Fourthly, this doubly rigorous reform budget, as I said, is also, Mr President of the Council, Madam Vice-President, a budget of institutional loyalty. This loyalty is particularly relevant to the European Parliament's commitment to reduce its workforce by up to 5%, like all institutions, a commitment made under the 2014-2020 Financial Outlook Agreement. The European Parliament is obliged, very precisely, to achieve this reduction by 2019, according to a specific timetable starting in 2017 and completing the operation in 2019. I stress, however, forcefully, that the European Parliament will make the requested effort by excluding temporary posts from political groups from the scope of this reduction obligation. Political groups, their capacity to work, their dynamism, their confrontation, their capacity to compromise are the very essence of the dynamics of the European Parliament. To reduce the capacity of political groups to act by reducing their numbers would be a miscalculation which would only reinforce the bureaucracy and technocracy that are often too intrusive, if not sometimes arrogant, of certain European institutions. For the other institutions, the Court of Auditors, the Committee of the Regions, the Court of Justice, etc., we have essentially aligned ourselves with the Commission's initial proposals, which we felt were properly formulated. In the end, the Council, which had initially been much more restrictive, agreed to join our position. A regret, however, which concerns - I have already had the opportunity to say this - the European Court of Justice. We have certainly secured, for her, the creation of seven additional posts for strengthen security in the processing of classified documents, as well as the security of buildings, but it will nevertheless have to eliminate twenty posts, which will severely affect the logistical and linguistic support services necessary for the Court's activity, at a time when the number of judges will be doubled. In conclusion, you will understand that while the 2016 budget is not the new wonder of the world, it is a good transitional budget before the necessary revision of the financial outlook next year. I confess, in any case, that I am relieved to have finished.

name: Pierre Gramegna
text: President-in-Office of the Council. Mr President, honourable Members of the European Parliament, Madam Vice-President of the Commission, ladies and gentlemen, it is a great honour for me to represent the Luxembourg Presidency of the Council today, here in the European Parliament's Assembly, for this discussion on the 2016 budget. The agreement that the two branches of the budgetary authority, the European Parliament and the Presidency, have managed to conclude thanks also to the help of the European Commission, which has played an excellent role as an honest broker, is a very good end-of-the-road result for everyone, for all the institutions and, above all, a very good result for Europe. I will never forget the conciliation session on the evening of 13 November when we were in the process, thanks to the spirit of openness of each other, to reach a compromise, to finalise the last texts when we received the tragic news of the terrorist attacks and the barbaric acts that were committed in Paris.  We have a common momentum decided to make a minute's silence and I remember the words I uttered and the words that were uttered by the President, Jean Arthuis, at this moment of great sadness and mourning. The minute's silence, which we shared together, reinforced our will to succeed, which was already very present, and I believe that we have, through the agreement we have managed to find, proved the unity, solidarity and efficiency of the European Union.  Let me emphasize the effectiveness because we were able to complete four days before the end of the period. I believe that much credit goes to President Jean Arthuis, who wanted to put the final proposals on the table as much as I did, as did the committee, as soon as possible. This saved us time and money. I take a few figures from this budget: 155 billion commitment appropriations; 153.89 billion payment credits and then four other figures that seem fundamental to me and which are the cardinal points of this exercise. First of all, we have doubled the amount available to refugees, from two billion euros in the original budget to four billion euros for actions both internally for refugees and at borders, at border crossings or even in countries of origin. Secondly, we have spent $19 billion on growth and jobs, including $18 billion for what I have just named and then $1 billion, in particular, on the youth-employment action that is so dear to everyone around these benches. Thirdly, we have provided the necessary funds to reduce the delays, the backlog, the arrears of payment which will increase next year from 17 billion to 2 billion, a figure that is actually extremely small. The fourth amount I would like to quote is the 800 million budget margins that prudence has prompted us to forecast. I conclude by saying that we also had the wisdom to increase funding for the Homeland Security Fund; what had just happened in Paris, at the same time, proved to us that it was the right direction. I will stop there, Mr President, I will thank you instead in my second speech. I would just like to conclude by saying that this budget was keen to strike a balance between three constraints: the first is, of course, growth and investment on the one hand; the second, emergencies and priorities around refugees, what could be called solidarity; as for the third, it is the budgetary constraints that we have both in the European Parliament and in most of the Member States of the European Union. There is a consistency here that I wanted to emphasize.

name: Kristalina Georgieva
text: Vice-President of the Commission. – Mr President, on behalf of the Commission I very much welcome the successful conclusion of the work of the Conciliation Committee for the 2016 budget and would like very sincerely to thank Parliament’s delegation led by the Chair, Mr Arthuis, as well as Mr Fernandes and Mr Deprez, but also Ms Gardiazabal Rubial for the work on Amending Budget 2015, and Mr Geier for what he has done to have a very good decision in the end on agencies. It has been a privilege to work with the Luxembourg Presidency, with Minister Gramegna, who has contributed enormously to a spirit of conciliation rather than confrontation. We have finished with a very strong sense of unity. Minister Gramegna reminded us of the sober setting in which negotiations were completed. But it was not only the fact that we faced the security concerns stemming from the Paris terror attack that was a determinant of how we worked. We face unprecedented humanitarian and refugee crises; the necessity – and, I would add, urgency – of supporting a fragile economic recovery in the European Union. We face market difficulties for many of our farmers and the debt crisis in Greece, and in that context we have come to a decision on the 2016 budget that is sound, focused on priorities and also makes use of the flexibility that has been built into the new multiannual financial framework (MFF), to a great degree thanks to Parliament. Let me very quickly give a presentation of the key points of this budget. With regard to commitments: with the EUR 155 billion we are some EUR 101 million above what we had proposed from the Commission. I am stressing this fact: that we actually went slightly above the proposal. This is a 3.2 increase compared to 2015. The two main blocs in commitments are support for investment growth in jobs, including for youth employment, and addressing the refugee crisis, where we have tripled funds for the Asylum Migration and Integration Fund, increased by 15% funds for the Internal Security Fund and increased significantly, by 20%, humanitarian aid as well as funds for the Neighbourhood Instrument. With regard to payments, it is very important to stress that we are working on implementing the payment plan agreed by the institutions and at the same time, directing the limited capacity for increase to where it matters the most. In terms of amounts, we have EUR 143.9 billion. This is an increase of 1.8% compared to the 2015 budget, and there we have an 11% increase for Heading 1a - Competitiveness for growth and jobs; a 57% increase for Heading 3 – Security and citizenship; and a 36% increase for Heading 4 – Global Europe. In other words, this is a budget where we walk our talk when we address priorities. Let me stress that there is a very strong commitment on the side of the Commission to monitor implementation, use money wisely and any possibility that might arise during the year to direct to priorities as they emerge. Finally, a word on margins. We have retained in this tight budget EUR 2.3 billion in commitments and EUR 1.9 billion in payments. Facing the uncertainties of tomorrow, we ought to have space to act. Finally, I want to recognise the staff of the Directorate-General for the Budget (DG BUDG) and other Commission services, Parliament’s staff who work on budgetary affairs, and also those who work on the budget in the Council. Thank you for all your hard work.

name: Paul Rübig
text: Mr President, i.e. the Group of the European People's Party (Christian Democrats) and European Democrats Mr President, I would like to thank the I would like to thank the Commissioner very much, but also the Presidency, very much for the fact that the negotiations were very well prepared. We have, of course, suffered from the multiannual programme, with a 5% reduction in posts and a general saving of 4%, and it is, of course, a great challenge to implement this in the face of increased requirements. We are now below 1% of Europe's gross domestic product, and we are now at 0.9. In fact, in recent years, we have always reduced payments accordingly, even though we have had a financial crisis and some of it still have, even though we have re-received the refugee crisis, terror has been very busy in our negotiations at midnight and, of course, the problem of unemployment in Europe has still not been resolved. On the other hand, there have also been good things: the new group, which was formed here in this House and can thus also move closer to European democracy and can learn how democracy can work between 28 Member States, will get 43 new posts and 3.5 million. I hope that this will also significantly improve cooperation. I believe that, ultimately, it is also a question of us seeing that, for example, the European Economic and Social Committee has had the slightest increase of all the other institutions and the European Court of Justice the most. I see that the priorities here are absolutely right, and I would like to thank the rapporteurs once again for the really excellent cooperation.

name: Eider Gardiazabal Rubial
text: on behalf of the S&D Group – Mr President, Vice-President Georgieva, Minister Gramegna, in recent years budget meetings between the three institutions could have been described as anything but conciliation.  But I have to say that these negotiations have been exemplary and, therefore, I would like to join all the thanks that have been heard here today to the Commission, to the Presidency and, of course, to the other Members of the European Parliament, because I believe that we have achieved a good agreement which puts in extraordinary resources to deal with extraordinary situations such as the refugee crisis , but which also continues to invest in research and development policies and which also serves our agricultural and livestock sector, so affected by the Russian veto or the dairy crisis.  And in addition to this, we have achieved a commitment to evaluate the Youth Employment Initiative and decide together what we need to do in the coming months, although it is also true – and it is a shame – that we have not been able to include a larger increase in payments for 2016 or a political commitment by Member States to use extraordinary income and finance their share of the European Agenda on Migration.  Although, as I said, it is a good agreement, I do not think we can fall into complacency, because in the future we have to address the structural problems that the budget has. And, if I may say so, one last thought because, as Minister Gramegna said, I cannot help but think that, during last Friday's meeting, 13 while we were negotiating, terrorists killed 130 people in Paris. It wasn't easy to keep working in those conditions, but we did it because neither their bombs nor their guns are ever going to end our ideas.

name: Bernd Kölmel
text: Mr President, I would like to like to take back from the ECR Group. Mr President, I would like to thank the Following the negotiations in the Conciliation Committee, the budget approach now provides for commitment appropriations of EUR 155 billion and payments of EUR 144 billion. The cuts proposed by the Council were thus avoided.  Many colleagues from the other groups see this result as a great success. I do not share this assessment. It is true that the draft provides that we have an increased budget approach to the unmistakable migration and refugee crisis – and that is right and important on the one hand. More importantly, however, we should finally develop a coherent approach in this area, which the Member States will then adhere to. In this way, we simply provide for more money without knowing how we can solve these problems in a sustainable way. We must work to help the people who live in Europe, but also those who want to come to us. We need a concept for this. Only with money alone will we solve these problems, we will not solve this crisis. My party has developed a comprehensive approach here, and we should work together on this basis to find a solution.  Irrespective of this, it has fallen short if we respond to crises only by wanting more money. Crises are also ideal times to pause and review a budget. What has proved its worth, what has not worked?  Take cohesion policy. It is intended to improve regions' competitiveness. We must also ask: has this result been adjusted? And if we see from the example of Greece that this is not the case, then we must also draw the right conclusions from it, but not simply always leave the budget lines as they are. In this way, the budget will increase through any crisis. That is why we must counteract this, and we can clearly see this here: the euro is damaging Europe, it is not uniting Europe, it is dividing it.

name: Nedzhmi Ali
text: on behalf of the ALDE Group. – Mr President, first of all I would like to congratulate rapporteurs Fernandes and Deprez and Commissioner Georgieva for their contribution to achieving the political priorities of the 2016 budget. The EU budget for next year started with political guidance based on the three highest priorities: employment, enterprises and entrepreneurship. It is time to make the final assessment on whether the priorities have being followed correctly regarding the entire job done in the respective committees, plenary sessions and interinstitutional negotiations in the context of the existing economic situation and refugee crisis. In the 2016 budget, the overall level of commitment appropriations is set at EUR 155 billion, and payment appropriations at almost EUR 143.9 billion. This does not completely match Parliament’s position on the budget. Nevertheless, it is a step in the right direction, because we reversed some cuts made by the Council. Furthermore, in implementation of the political priorities, we have achieved a budget that is even better in comparison with the draft proposed by the Commission. The increased appropriations and the mobilised EUR 1.5 billion within the flexibility instrument ensure more funding for migration, humanitarian aid, Horizon 2020, small and medium enterprises and Erasmus+. The Youth Employment initiative will be kept on as a high and shared political priority. We should continue to work in order to phase out the backlog of outstanding payment claims, and on the upcoming mid-term review of the MFF. A serious debate for the full introduction of performance-based budgeting should be linked to the prevention of the subjective financial programme cuts in the Member States.

name: Younous Omarjee
text: on behalf of the GUE/NGL group. Mr President, Madam Vice-President, Minister, in relation to the Council's initial proposals, objectivity obliges us to say that Parliament's conciliation has made a number of progress. This is the maintenance of budgets for Erasmus, budgets for research programmes, and the creation of a mechanism for farmers to cope with the Russian embargo.  But having said that, we see how much the psC's constrained framework now weighs heavily when it comes to having a budget to meet the challenges we face. And this is how the IEJ will be stopped in its rise to power. Just as we know that the problem of unpaid debts is not solved, that it is before us and that it will arise with even more seriousness, as President Arthuis said, from 2017.  This means that, at the time of the mid-term review, we will have to have this debate on own resources and the debate on the financial transaction tax, which is the only way to provide the European Union with a real budget to deal with new challenges.

name: Ernest Maragall
text: verts/ALE Group. – Mr President, congratulations and thanks, of course, but let me make this clear: it is a budget still far from the optimal one, both on the income side, insufficient and still dependent too much on the contributions of States, and on expenditure, where the allocation between States is still predominantly in the face of European policy itself. Why, then, have I asked for a yes vote in our group? Because all of you — rapporteurs, Mrs Georgieva, Mr Gramegna — have worked well; because it contains some of the main demands of this Parliament; because it rushes almost all available margins; because it is the first budget of the new Commission, and neither the Commission nor Parliament are responsible for the narrow margin allowed by the current financial framework. We recorded some good news: the recovery of funds for H2020, COSME and Erasmus; contribution to international cooperation under heading 4; visible effort, but I fear that it is still insufficient, in the programmes for the refugee issue; with two unknowns that we must follow closely: the political commitment made to give maximum attention to the Youth Employment Initiative and the commitment to avoid reproducing the immense volume of late payments. This budget allows us to get closer to the two horizons we have raised to work a new budgetary logic for the European Union: the revision of the multiannual financial framework and the report of the working group which will give us results around the concept of 'own resources', a concept which now appears as sarcasm if we consider it from a European point of view. We must address these scenarios with three objectives: to have revenue from most of our own resources ("No taxation without representation"; move from programmes to policies with a spending budget in which the general interest dominates the distribution; and approach a global amount proportionate to the challenges we really face: open conflicts, migration, climate change, aging, social inequalities, and an increasingly endangered democracy.

name: Jonathan Arnott
text: on behalf of the EFDD Group. – Mr President, this latest budget builds upon the work which went before it, carefully and methodically laying more paving slabs. The problem is that it is the road to hell which is being paved. I could respond in one of two ways to the current proposal. I could tinker around the edges and talk about space programmes or ridiculous political propaganda, issues which could be better done at national level than European level. There are so many things I could talk about. But I think, perhaps, it is better to respond in the other way and to actually address the elephant in the room – the extra EUR 1.5 billion for dealing with the migration crisis, frontloaded over the next couple of years, and which actually may well end up kicking the can down the line to a future budget at a time when resources are going to be even more stretched and creating more problems for the European Union. We are spending this money and it is leaving all sorts of contortions in other areas; we are spending it on a policy which fundamentally misunderstands the current crisis. It is a global problem which we are treating as a European problem. We warned back in April that a Commission change of policy would lead to the mass migration of people. And guess what? It has led to the mass movement of people. It has led to people trafficking, it has led to migrant deaths, and it has caused the problems in the Schengen area and security issues. Instead of bringing people ever closer, it is dividing still further.
