It is a policy which purports to be humane but actually leaves millions of the most vulnerable – the elderly, women and children – in refugee camps. Other countries are failing to follow Britain’s lead in helping in those camps in countries like Jordan, Lebanon and Turkey. Frankly, even Britain should be doing more. Finally, let us remember this: you cannot have liberté, fraternité, égalité without sécurité.

name: Marie-Christine Arnautu
text: on behalf of the ENF group. Mr President, this 2016 budget is light years away from the challenges facing people. The Union plays arsonists. Faced with the crises it has caused itself, it is now forced to urgently release additional funds so as not to lose face. That farmers, for example, suffer from the aberrant Brussels policies and the Russian embargo, as a result of the sanctions imposed on Russia by the European Union, whatever, European taxpayers will pay the bill. As for immigration policy, the failure of the European Union is clear. Control at the external borders is not assured and the paltry budget extensions to remedy it will do nothing about it. It is not with an additional EUR 710 million planned for 2016 that the millions of immigrants who are preparing to come to our continent in the coming years will be contained. Unfortunately, your immigrationist ideology is very comfortable with it, but the peoples of Europe are opposed to it every day, urging their government to close their national borders.  Yes, this 2016 budget shows once again, I am sorry to tell you, the inability of the European Union to address the immense dangers facing our peoples and it is high time that this stopped.

name: Ελευθέριος Συναδινός (
text: NI). Mr President, the results of the conciliation on the 2016 Budget show the hypocrisy of the heads of the institutions of the European Union. It is a mockery when they are supposed to disagree with each other in order to reach a final agreement concerning the increase of EUR 101 million in commitment appropriations and the reduction of EUR 571 million in payment appropriations to a total of EUR 155 billion and EUR 144 billion, respectively.  A budget which, while proclaiming growth, entrepreneurship growth and job creation, reduces in relation to 2015 the appropriations for regional convergence of the least developed regions, but also the appropriations for the youth employment initiative. A budget which restricts the financing of the European Agricultural Guarantee, Maritime, Fisheries and Regional Development Funds, but at the same time increases the appropriations to be given to the Turkish occupying forces of the territory of the Republic of Cyprus and indirectly finances the increase in the number of illegal immigrants on the territory of the old continent, cannot be classified as European.  Don't let your pro-money interests guide the fate of Europe and its countries. Change direction now that you have time. It'll be too late soon.

name: Marian-Jean Marinescu (PPE).
text: – Mr President, Commissioner, President of the Council, 2016 is the third year of the 2014-2020 MFF. The implementation of the 2014-2016 budget should be the basis for the budgetary correction required by the MFF. The current challenges - the overdue payments, the refugee crisis, now the terrorist attacks - have created a lot of pressure on the 2016 budget. It is the merit of the European Parliament, the Commission and, for the first time in a long period of time, the Council that a compromise has been reached which can ensure that policies are implemented and crisis-overed at the same time. All the facilities provided for by the MFF have been used to the fullest. It should be noted, however, that if the Member States had given up the unexpected income and the unspent amounts, an even better situation could have been reached. It is important to minimise the amounts outstanding in cohesion policy, that part of the funds taken over for ESI from Horizon 2020 are recovered, that due importance is given to the Youth Initiative. The data shows that the new European policies have started very slowly. An evaluation of the new rules, strategies, partnership agreements is needed in order to be able to schedule the implementation of the 2017-2020 budget. The budgetary correction must contain the will of the European institutions and the Member States to create added value for every euro invested at European level. The effectiveness of the implementation of European funds must be based on the evaluation of results on the basis of pre-established indicators.

name: Jens Geier (S&D).
text: Mr President, I would like to thank the Madam Vice-President Georgieva, Minister Gramegna, I would like to welcome you in particular. You have just been very missed in this circle in the last debate on the special committee's report on LuxLeaks. Ladies and gentlemen, I agree with the general words of thanks. Personally, I would also like to congratulate Mr José Manuel Fernandes and Mr Deprez on the excellent reports.  Quite a few government officials have called for the European Union budget to do more to tackle the refugee crisis. I believe that we have now done almost everything that the EU budget can do. In category 4, in foreign policy, we have mobilised all the money up to the ceiling of the medium-term financial framework in order to eliminate the causes of flight. In category 3, in domestic politics, the same. In addition, we have gone beyond the ceiling by mobilising the flexibility instrument. This is a measure that the Council has so far shied away from, like the devil, holy water.  The Presidency has supported us, but the Council of Finance Ministers has unfortunately not been so much. On the one hand, call for more commitment in the European Council, but on the other hand, in the Council of Finance Ministers, they oppose it – I call this policy schizophrenic.  I am sure we now have a good 2016 budget. That is why the Socialist Group will be approving the budget.

name: Richard Ashworth (ECR).
text: – Mr President, this budget responds to the immediate needs for additional security, migration and border control, as well as meeting the problems of the agricultural sector. I believe it does it in a manner that is both timely and appropriate. That is welcome, but I want to make two comments. First, it is important that we focus spending on areas that deliver true European added value. We should not forget here that the single most important thing that this budget can do for European citizens is to deliver jobs and growth. Second, we have to operate within the limits of the agreed multiannual financial framework (MFF). When we are faced with the conflicting pressures of a growing demand for spending, of paying down debt, and a strictly limited budget, the key going forwards will have to be discipline and prioritising spending to those areas that deliver best value for money.  (The speaker agreed to take a blue-card question under Rule 162(8))

name: Maria Grapini (S&D)
text: Question put in accordance with the 'blue card' procedure. – Dear colleague, I have taken note from you that you have appreciated the budget but consider it important to create jobs. Do you think that in the context of the 2016 budget being built, and we have seen consensus here between the three institutions, more funds could have been allocated for 2016 for small and medium-sized enterprises? Or do you think it's the optimal value that could be secured through the 2016 budget, because jobs ultimately give people the security of people's lives?

name: Richard Ashworth (ECR)
text: blue-card answer. – I certainly do agree. I pointed out earlier the priority of creating jobs and growth. I was impressed earlier when the Commissioner spelt out how much additional funding would be put towards jobs and growth. You should agree with me that that is a great effort within the constraints of a difficult budget. You also need to understand that the European Fund for strategic investment is a valuable tool here which has been leveraged out of this budget, and I wish it every success. It has had a good start, and it is vitally important to this European Union and to the people of Europe that it does succeed.

name: Indrek Tarand (Verts/ALE).
text: – Mr President, honourable colleagues. First of all I would like to express my gratitude for the excellent team of the European Parliament delegation led jointly by nos trois mousquetaires, Messrs Arthuis, Fernandes and Deprez. Bravo!   Secondly, I would like to thank Madam Georgieva, who presented such a decent compromise. More than being just an honest broker, she attached something like almost motherly love towards the quarrelling kids of hers, the Council and the Parliament, and of course – in my opinion – Parliament behaved better. Four points.  I praise the 274 MEPs who voted for the Greens’ amendment asking for greater transparency regarding the use of a general expenditure allowance. In my country, this is public information and no harm has been done, except to those who abused the funds. Secondly, the cuts to ITER were a bit too modest for our liking. This project, in my opinion, is a total waste of taxpayers’ money, and the money should be used elsewhere. Where, I will tell you in 30 seconds. Thirdly, although the medium-term payment challenges were recognised and the institutions have committed themselves to ensuring that the massive payment backlog seen in the recent past are indeed something that belongs to the past, it is not getting any easier, and therefore we need to make sure that we are flexible enough to fight back against whatever comes our way. Finally, taking into account the present and looming crises – refugees and migrants, including climate migrants – and the fight against terrorism, the EU security and defence policy area is still under-financed. It is common sense to take money from ITER to develop this.

name: Marco Zanni (EFDD).
text: Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, in the middle of stat virtus, the Latins said, and this is what emerged from the final agreement on conciliation, halfway between the Council's proposal and that of the European Parliament. Everyone seems to be satisfied with this agreement, but I believe that the possibility of making the Union's budget more concrete and rational has been lost on this occasion too.  Parliament has managed to achieve a cosmetic victory, particularly with regard to the increases in heading 1a, which has been hit by EFSI cuts, while the Council has managed to get its line of limiting payments through. Parliament has not, however, been able to identify some negative priorities, as requested by the Council, but it is perhaps the biggest culprit in not wanting to honour the commitments it has made. I therefore confirm our opposition to an agreement which solves neither the very serious problems of european citizens nor the structural imbalances that the Union's own budget has been carrying for years.

name: Monika Hohlmeier (PPE).
text: Mr President, Commissioner, Minister, ladies and gentlemen, I would like to thank the rapporteur for her excellent work and for the work she has done. First of all, I would like to thank the Commissioner and her team very warmly for their excellent cooperation and, above all, for their openness, including on the subject of agencies – major changes on the subject of fee-paying agencies – or for making a difference to the other agencies, which are not funded by fees, and for finding solutions for the future too. so that we do not affect our economy in terms of competitiveness. For the first time, thank you very much for this, also for this open-mindedness and openness. Secondly, a thank you to the Presidency of the Council for coming to a good common conclusion. Everyone still has wishes left on their side. But I think we have a respectable result here that we can really compete with in public. I would also like to thank the rapporteurs, especially Mr Fernandes, and Mr Deprez, who have done a great job over many months. If I have any wishes, then I say them quite openly, I say them openly. In the end, firstly, they concern the agencies with the competitiveness of our industry, which I mentioned – and we must ensure that this is the case. Secondly, the Horizon 2020 programme. If I look at how successful the research programmes are in a number of areas, it would be good for us – having also set ourselves the goal of supporting growth, jobs and innovation – to be even more active in this area, or to focus on this in the MFF. And the third point will be on the issue of security and migration, on which we have certainly not yet reached the end, but must engage in an intensive dialogue with each other, including development aid, as we embed in the budget in the medium term and place it sensibly in the MFF.

name: Vladimír Maňka (S&D).
text: – Together, we negotiated the best possible, achievable compromise. However, if we want to come very close to what the people of Europe need, the revenue component of the budget must be more independent. The question is whether we can kick-start and sustain growth and jobs.  The ambition of the Juncker Investment Plan is therefore to create a positive impetus. Euro funds must also be added. The larger the effect, the higher the added value of the projects. On the other hand, the accumulation of unpaid invoices owed by the European Union for projects already implemented creates a negative impulse. It goes against growth, against employment, against the absorption of EU funds. The migration crisis brings further risks. It may soon trigger a demand that we seek the necessary funding at the expense of cohesion policy. That is why some Member States must stop looking egotistically at the world, and for all of us, too, there is a commitment under the Treaties of Rome to create a viable system of own resources.

name: Zbigniew Kuźmiuk (ECR).
text: – (2) Mr President, I would like to begin by As a result of the negotiations between the Council and Parliament, commitments in the 2016 budget were finally set at €155 billion and payments of €144 billion. This is a slightly higher level of expenditure than the Commission and the Council wanted, but it is significantly lower than parliament proposed in its budgetary amendments on 28 October. In the end, therefore, in the 2016 budget, commitments are more than 4% lower and payments are only 2% higher than those in the 2015 budget, which means that the reduction of outstanding bills will not be as previously promised. It is also uncertain whether priorities such as youth employment, support for small and medium-sized enterprises or the implementation of programmes such as Horizon 2020 and Connecting Europe will have sufficient funding.  I would also like to take this opportunity to express my hope that the financing of the so-called immigration and counter-terrorism crisis in 2016 will not come at the expense of cohesion policy funding resulting from next year's review of the 2014-2020 financial framework.

name: Jan Olbrycht (PPE).
text: – Commissioner, i would like to thank you very much for your Minister, i would like to thank you for your comments. First of all, I would like to congratulate and thank you for your efforts with regard to this budget for 2016. We all know that this was not the case every year, and that was not the approach to the annual budget.  However, I would like to draw attention to one very characteristic element. Both during the negotiations on the 2016 budget and in any other debate today, all the representatives of the European institutions – Parliament, the Council and the Commission – refer to the budgetary revision, i.e. they say in such a way that we will do it in the revision, exactly at the review, we will do it with the review. This would indicate that there is a wonderful measure that will come up, and then we will do all the things that are not done today. I would like to point out that in the 2016 budget we have already exhausted all the flexibility options and that, in fact, our discussion will be about very difficult actions, and it will not be possible to deal with all the issues when revising the MFF. But the 2016 budget is encouraging that we will have a constructive approach to this.

name: Daniele Viotti (S&D).
text: Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, of all the things that have already been said in this debate, the only ones I will repeat are the thanks to our rapporteurs, the Vice-President of the Commission and Minister Gramegna, who have done an extraordinary job, accompanying us to the adoption of this budget. I would like to make three very brief points in addition to what has already been said. The first is that overtime is marked above all by the fact that, with an instrument as complicated as the European Union budget, it has also been possible to put in place a little solidarity. What has been done about migrants, the so-called refugee and refugee crisis, shows that there is still a modicum of solidarity. The second is that I am in my second year of conciliation and budgetary analysis. The third is that this Commission – and this Europe – will have to carry out as many reforms for next year as it calls for from the Member States, especially on the budget.

name: Λευτέρης Χριστοφόρου (
text: PPE). Madam President, the fact that we are discussing the budget today, the fact that an agreement has been reached on the budget is primarily due, without any exaggeration, to our two rapporteurs, Mr Fernandes and Mr Deprez, as well as to the wise and effective guidance of the chairman of our committee, Mr Arthuis, without downplaying the important contribution of Mrs Georgieva's Vice-President and the European Council. We have proved that by joining forces within the European Union we can succeed.  This budget can be recorded in the history of the budgets and of the European Parliament, as the budget which, under adverse economic conditions, with enormous emergencies arising from the refugee crisis, from Greece and other factors, has managed to preserve its social and development character, has managed to rescue programmes which are particularly accessible to European citizens, to the Member States. , businesses such as HORIZON 2020, Connecting Europe Facility, COSME. It has actually succeeded in balancing this budget with all the needs that have arisen, in order to make a proper allocation and in giving a truly successful project which I believe will be recorded as a great and important success.  But I must stress that what is a permanent enemy for the European Parliament is bureaucracy. We must finally prove that every euro that leaves the budget finally goes where it needs to go. And one final point, Madam President. With regard to emergencies, we must decide that when similar needs arise, there must be another fund, one-off, which the European Central Bank must also see, which will help the European Parliament to cope with these difficult economic emergencies.

name: Isabelle Thomas (S&D).
text: Madam President, Commissioner, Minister, first of all, a big thank you for the excellent conduct of this budgetary reconciliation, the result of which will enable us to provide a number of responses to the migration crisis. I regret, however, that the commitments on the initiative against youth unemployment were interrupted in 2016 and that this programme is reduced to a promise, a French proverb that promises only engage those who listen to them. As a co-leader on the revision of the multi-year financial framework, however, I assure you that Parliament will continue the pressure. However, as you know, since or more accurately during the conciliation, there have been the attacks in Paris. The Council of Ministers of Justice and Home Affairs met on Friday and announced a series of measures to combat terrorism: coordination of intelligence missions, perhaps in the form of agencies, border guards. But the 2016 budget does not give the means and we have already used almost all the instruments of flexibility.  So how do the Council and the Commission approach these new expenditures? How do they plan to fund them? And, above all, has the Council of Justice and Home Affairs met, even once, with ECOFIN?

name: Siegfried Mureşan (PPE).
text: – Madam President, I would also like to extend my thanks to Parliament’s rapporteurs for the way in which they conducted their work, and I would also like to thank the Commission Vice-President and Minister Gramegna for the way in which they have fulfilled their missions. In my short intervention, I would like to focus on the importance of continuing the Youth Employment initiative, be it in its current form or in a revised form. My view is that it is crucial to send a signal to the European youth that they are still a priority for decision-makers at European level. Especially in these times, when we see that the lack of education and little prospect for jobs leads to radicalisation, we have to use all available instruments to secure a future for young people in Europe. In this sense I urge the Commission, as stated in the final conciliation text, to analyse the results of the Youth Employment initiative and to propose changes, if needed, so that this programme can continue until 2020. Youth unemployment still exists in Europe. The job is not yet done. The young people of Europe still need our help. Very briefly on migration: I very much welcome the fact that we succeeded in ensuring an adequate budget in Headings 3 and 4. I now urge the Member States to acknowledge the risks ahead and act by ensuring that the EU Trust Funds for Africa and Syria are adequately financed. (The speaker agreed to take a blue-card question under Rule 162(8))

name: Bill Etheridge (EFDD)
text: blue-card question. – Thank you for accepting the blue-card. I noticed that you said youth unemployment can lead towards radicalisation. Surely the youth of Europe would be better advised, as someone once said in the UK, simply to get on their bikes and look for work, and for them to be enabled to do that by having a more controlled flow of immigration into the EU so that there are more jobs suitable and available for young people to start off on the ladder?

name: Siegfried Mureşan (PPE)
text: blue-card answer. – What was the question? I would like to say that my observation is valid, whether we are referring to young refugees, migrants to Europe or to citizens who were born, have grown up and are educated in Europe. It is a valid fact that, no matter where these people come from, unless they have a job, a good education and prospects, there are risks, including the risk of radicalisation. That is why I think that high—quality education, jobs and so on are important, irrespective of whether these people have just emigrated to Europe or were born here.

name: Janusz Lewandowski (PPE).
text: – Madam President, i voted in favour of the report by Mrs Schwab How pleasant it is to join all those congratulations that we have heard in this House that all sides of the concite deserve. Concciliation deserves the word conciration. It deviated completely from the ten concications in my climate, which I remember from my budget biography.  But if so, I would like to follow in Jan Olbrycht's footsteps a little in the future. Namely, many of the political announcements, built up with budget money, were made at the beginning of this financial perspective. The Juncker Plan, the Youth Employment Initiative– a bottomless barrel in the form of a response to the migration crisis. This is called front loading – borrowing in the future – and that has implications for the budget in the future. A great challenge becomes review or revision. The sheer difference in vocabulary can be worrying. Reviewing or revising this perspective will decide whether we will accidentally survive this budgetary drama, which I remember in 2012-2014, which was linked to the maturation of multiannual programmes and at the same time a large lack of funding for them. So to a cautionary tale, without spoiling this holiday, which is indeed a great concivion about the budget of 2016.

name: Inese Vaidere (PPE).
text: – Dear colleagues, i would like to thank the rapporteur for his excellent work. First of all, thank you, Mr Fernandes and Mr Deprez, for their hard work in drawing up the budget, especially in the negotiations with the Council, which are always very difficult. It is gratifying that regional policy, which is a key instrument in the development of the new Member States, is also a priority for next year. Citizens can expect jobs, support for science and innovation. I am pleased that 500 million are allocated to milk producers. Mobilising funds to tackle the refugee crisis through the instrument of flexibility is to be welcomed, as the terrorist attacks in Paris repeatedly show that Member States must join forces to protect citizens who, unfortunately, cannot feel safe at the moment. It can be seen that the 'open door principle' declared by some countries is discourseable. It is necessary to carry out immediate identification and return of immigrants if they do not qualify for refugee status. The protection of the European Union's external borders is now very important in order to prevent illegal immigration. The capacity of Frontex needs to be significantly strengthened. This must be one of our long-term priorities, which is also fores to be expected in the multiannual budget. Increasing funds for foreign policy is to be welcomed. However, care must be taken to ensure that these funds fall into the right hands, improving the quality of life and resolving conflicts in third countries. At the same time, however, we also need to think about saving money by reducing the cost of administration to the European institutions. Thanks for the attention!

name: Tomáš Zdechovský (PPE).
text: – Madam President, first of all, let me thank and congratulate my colleagues Fernandes and Deprez and the entire Committee on Budgets on the excellent result they have achieved in negotiations with the Commission and the Council. Compared to last year, this is a success and this is not only a success for the European Parliament, but for the entire European Union. I am also very pleased with the fact that the security budget has been increased to its maximum, which is also the historical maximum of this heading. I am glad that we are finally all aware that it is not possible for Europe to cope with the migration crisis if it lacks the resources to do so, both financially, personally or materially. In particular, EUROPOL, FRONTEX and EASA are, from my point of view, the ones that need these funds most. They can't do without them. However, we got to the edge of our capabilities, mobilizing everything that could be mobilized. Now the question is: What next? Where will the European Union get more money to finance this crisis? In my opinion, the 2016 budget is an excellent first step in the revision of the 2014-2020 Multiannual Financial Framework. This must undergo a major restructuring in order for Europe to be able to respond to current threats.

name: Ivana Maletić (PPE).
text: - Madam President, I welcome the Commissioner, and I thank the rapporteurs who have worked really this important report.  The 2016 budget was adopted in exceptional circumstances. In addition to providing funding for innovation, investment, entrepreneurship, youth that we need to recruit and retain in our countries, education and research, the 2016 budget was also meant to meet other challenges: from the migrant crisis, through the turmoil that has started to occur in the worst form within our borders, plus the crisis in Greece, the crisis in the agricultural sector and everything else. That is why the process of agreeing on the items took a long time and I am glad that it resulted in an increase in items of employment, education and solidarity.  However, with the 2016 budget, another important issue remains unresolved, namely the payment of all applications for cohesion policy programmes from 2007 and 2013, which should be of particular care.

name: Victor Negrescu (S&D).
text: – We have a European budget focused on growth, on investment, on policies to meet the latest challenges at European level, even if it is limited by the multiannual financial framework. It is proof that the era of austerity has set, that both the Commission and the Council have understood that we need to have a development-focused budget that supports our common policies. We have allocated additional funds for young people, for employment, for farmers, for innovation and for security, and we must continue. I hope that the new government of Romania, which is now working on the new budget, will understand that the European budgetary logic has changed. We need to spend public funds effectively in the interests of the citizen, and this involves public investment, protecting the categories affected by the various crises – I am talking here about young people, farmers, officials, pensioners, and mechanisms for the development of the local economy. This European budget once again indicates that through political dialogue and the consideration of our different political visions we can build a European budget that reflects the public interest and the public interest.

name: Ruža Tomašić (ECR).
text: - Madam President, the migration wave that has lashed Europe has long since taken on the hallmarks of a genuine humanitarian and security catastrophe, and the mobilisation of flexibility instruments at the moment only confirms that we have welcomed the crisis unprepared. Unfortunately, this is just further evidence that the Commission is not thinking long-term, but is coming from error to error, which is then paid dearly by European taxpayers. The war in Syria did not start yesterday, and refugees have been leaving the country for a very long time. It was clear from day one that Turkey, Lebanon and Jordan could not receive millions of people forever and that if we did not stop the war, the columns would move towards Europe.  Now that it is clear that terrorists have arrived in these columns and that crisis management is costing us hundreds of millions of euros in taxpayers' money, I want to ask the Commission if it has concrete plans on how to stop the crisis at its source or plans to spend more and more money year after year on the care of migrants we have received in this wave.

name: Miguel Viegas (GUE/NGL).
text: – Madam President, in a context of major budgetary constraints in national contributions to the Union budget, some concerns need to be noted. Firstly, we draw attention to the eur 11 million cut, which will directly affect budget lines dedicated to the protection, detaining and control of plant and animal pests. This cut, in a framework where climate change provides the emergence of several epidemic crises, leaves us at least apprehensive. There is talk of a significant increase in youth employment programmes, but we have to realise that Erasmus+ represents a minimal part of the budget and that this 30% increase is unlikely to have much impact.  We also note that the European Parliament is committed to reducing around 179 jobs by 2019, 60 as early as next year.  Finally, one last word on the strengthening of immigration funding: it could be a good thing if it were not for the deliberate purpose of promoting persecutory solutions that will contribute to further increasing the problem, rather than solving it with a genuine policy of solidarity and development support.

name: Gianluca Buonanno (ENF).
text: Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, I wanted to highlight a fact concerning the budget: once again we are giving Turkey money, even more money. This country, which has obtained EUR 10 billion for pre-accession from Europe in recent years, will still take EUR 4.6 billion by 2020, and what is the result? That they are 90% Islamic and that today they shot down a Russian plane, just because for 17 seconds it entered their airspace.  But do they want to come to Europe? They can't come to Europe. This 'No Europe' flag means that Turkey cannot enter Europe because it is a disgrace. Turkey remains where it is, because it is a friend of Islamic terrorists.  That is what has happened with Russia today and they should be ashamed. Instead of giving money to the Turks, let us give the money to our companies or our people, not to the Turks! Because that's shameful! Because we give money to those who do not love Europe and to those who help Islamic terrorists!

name: Zoltán Balczó (NI).
text: – Madam President, we are talking about the adoption of the budget as a serious instrument for the European Parliament to enforce its will in the debate between the institutions. Well, that's not true of the annual budget. For the seven-year squad, the playing field is minimal. Let me give you an example. Next year's payments amount to the EU's aggregate national income: the Commission proposes 0.98%, the Council goes down slightly to 0.97%, Parliament wants more 1%, the agreement is 0.98, which the Commission has tabled, and this is typical of each of the main lines, except for the issue of security and citizenship. So let's move a little further and see what the multiannual framework we're implementing is? Two data: a 4.5% reduction in real terms in the seven-year framework, which has never been the case, an 8.4% reduction in the Cohesion Fund and a further widening gap between the centre and the peripherals.

name: Petri Sarvamaa (PPE).
text: – Madam President, I had a meeting with another Commissioner and I am sorry about that. It seems that the time of miracles is not over. Or maybe it was not a miracle, but an excellent rapporteur that we had. I offer my congratulations once more. Common sense prevailed. We have a budget that focuses on employment, enterprises and the young people of Europe. Last but not least, we also have a budget that takes account of reality and change in the real world. That, of course, is the huge challenge that the migration flows present us with. It has to be said that, for the first time that I can remember, Parliament managed to restore all the cuts that the Council wanted to have in the draft 2016 budget. Therefore, the result that we have is promising. But I would like to finish by saying that, when we have really exceptional circumstances, they call for exceptional measures. By no means can we see an end to these exceptional times. So it is time to start talking seriously about a full revision, because the budget is really stretching its limits.

name: Kristalina Georgieva
text: Vice-President of the Commission. – Madam President, I would like to thank all who have spoken. Three points in closure. Firstly, it is very important at a time of increased uncertainty that we have a budget that is agile, has a clear focus on priorities and is oriented towards impact and how to give the people the best value for the money they entrust us to manage on their behalf. That would require us to take the forthcoming mid-term review very seriously. This is our chance to strengthen the agility, focus and capacity of our budget, and also to look to the future as regards the kind of budget we would like to have next time around. Secondly, many of the speakers expressed a very understandable concern about the limited flexibility we have. But we still have some flexibility for next year; that is the contingency margin, if needed, of no more than EUR 4 billion. We have the contingency margin and, of course, we will only be using it if that is necessary. We will have the possibility towards the end of the year to use a global transfer; in other words, money that is not put to the best use. We should not rush headlong into using this option; we should try to keep it as a kind of cushion. Last but not least, we now have a chance to receive funds from our Member States, as assigned revenues for priorities that we all recognise are best addressed together. For this we have the Syria Trust Fund and the Africa Trust Fund, and we, the Commission, are proposing to provide the platform for addressing priorities in that manner. Thirdly, there was a question addressed to me: what is the Commission going to do in the long term to deal with the challenge of migration? This is one question that is not going to disappear. It was mentioned that climate change is upon us. The projections of the IPCC tell us that by 2025 there may be 100 million climate refugees. So, we have to direct our resources at tackling the problem at source and tackle the root causes that are causing the problem here in Europe. For this reason, we have refocused our development funds more on fragility – I also want to praise Prime Minister Cameron of the UK, who has recently announced that 50% of DFID funds will go to fragile countries. I think we need to do more where it matters the most: for the people affected, but also for our own security. Of course, we will have to invest more in the security of Europe. The Commission has promised to come up with a proposal on how we can strengthen external border controls, and that is an area where I believe that collectively we have a better chance to be successful than acting alone. Let me finish by thanking those who have made this budget miracle possible, and may we have it repeated next time around.

name: Pierre Gramegna
text: President-in-Office of the Council. Madam President, I would first like to thank all the speakers for their comments and contributions. I have registered a lot of support and I am delighted. I have also taken note of the criticisms and there have been a few, some of which were constructive and can be taken into account, it seems to me, I was going to say in next year's budget. But in fact, it's too late, I think it takes more agility. As the chair of the committee said, the first step will be to take into account the constructive criticism and emergencies that lie ahead in the coming weeks and months. As I did not do in my introductory speech, I would like to thank the key people in this negotiation. I will start with Jean Arthuis, who has shown great civic sense and a sense of priorities, and I thank him for that. I would like to thank Mr Fernandes, the rapporteur, José Manuel, who showed unwavering enthusiasm and was contagious. I would like to thank Gérard Deprez, who has shown humour and tenacity, to thank Mrs Gardiazabal, who has shown great pragmatism and, last but not least, Mr Gahler for his patience with all the agencies. Of course, Ms. G HYPERLINK "https://www.google.com/search?rls=com.microsoft:en-GB:IE-Address&biw=1920&bih=934&q=georgieva+kristalina&spell=1&sa=X&ved=0ahUKEwiIqOrY56nJAhXCvQ8KHaNfChMQvwUIGSgA" eorgieva Kristalina, Vice President, key figure, who has implemented much of her energy and talent. At the same time, I think it has innovated in terms of the method used, showing a lot of transparency about its objectives and the numbers. As a result, we have been able to accelerate the negotiation and I think it has set the stage for an excellent precedent for years to come. I would not like to forget all those who work behind the scenes, whether in the Commission, in the European Parliament, as well as in the Presidency, our ambassador, permanent representative Christian Braun, and to my right, Amir Motahari, who had done a superb job of preparing in the budget committee. Thanks to all of you, we have been able to obtain, for the first time since the Lisbon Treaty, the unanimity of the Member States on this budget, which is very good news. I also hope that tomorrow, but it is up to you to decide, of course, we will see a large majority adopt this budget. That would be the greatest gift you could give to the chair, who has done a lot of work on it.  I will not go back to the priorities of the budget, we talked about it, and the three axes of the triangle that are solidarity on the one hand, employment and growth on the other, and thirdly, of course, fiscal prudence and the necessary room for manoeuvre. This is the magic triangle that we have managed to solve.  The atmosphere here seemed very good, I must say that it was excellent also in the conciliation committee. Since Mr Gahler asked me why I was not with you in the previous debate, I would just like to explain myself. You know that I wanted it very much because I was in the antechamber, but I was informed that you cannot win parliament and that you have to be invited. As I was not invited, I did not want to break with the courtesy and good habits as they exist. However, I would like to say to Mr Gahler and the other interested parties, that I have followed the debates very carefully, that the Luxembourg Presidency has done everything in its power to promote the work of the TAXE Committee. I myself received the TAXE Committee in Luxembourg in June, and she invited me to come and see her as President of the Council, which I also did in October, I even sent her written documentation and answers to her questions.  I understand that the work will continue, we are also available for that. A simple word, as President, on this subject: Luxembourg has made the issue of international taxation and the challenges in this area one of the priorities of its Presidency and on 6 October this year, at the Ecofin Council, we reached a political agreement on the automatic exchange of tax rulings, which was one of the main topics. Luxembourg has therefore tried to work in the interests of the European Union; Luxembourg is part of the solution, not part of the problem. Last point, and I end with the good atmosphere that prevailed among us, I welcome what Gérard Deprez has stressed, namely that we have succeeded in strengthening institutional loyalty by reaching an agreement on the reduction of staff in all institutions. We have found a compromise that seems to me to be perfectly acceptable, perhaps even unexpected. This I hope that it will continue, to strengthen itself in the months and years to come, and in this sense this budget could be a happy precedent which I hope will serve you in the many challenges that lie ahead, which are described with great enthusiasm and truthfulness by both The European Parliamentarians and the Commissioner.

name: Elnök asszony. –
text: Thank you, Minister, for your reply, and also for remittances to the hearing of a previous report, where you did miss Mr Minister, and your response here was reassuring.  Next up is our last commenter, the Chairman of the Committee on Budgets. I give the floor to Mr. Arthuis.

name: Jean Arthuis
text: Chairman of the BUDG Committee. Madam President, I want to welcome Minister Gramegna's recent words on competition and tax optimisation.  In your opening remarks, Minister, you recalled the circumstances of the evening of Friday the 13th. We have since seen multinational corporations express their compassion. I would like to say to those companies that practice tax optimisation to what I consider excessive, that the taxes they could pay here in Europe would no doubt help us to mobilise the necessary means to fight terrorism.  Having said that, at the end of this debate, I would like to thank again and express my compliments to the three institutions: to you, Minister, for the way in which you have led the conciliation, to you, Madam Vice-President, who have been firm on your expertise and the lucidity you have shared with us, to our rapporteurs and to all the members who have participated in the conciliation. But I want to involve all of our employees. They showed a lot of competence, a lot of availability. They have been at the level of excellence and have allowed us to succeed. I would simply like, in conclusion, to express a hope, a dream and a call.  The hope is that we can get our fiscal framework out of its rigidity. We can see that this rigidity exposes Europe to the risk of impotence when unusually serious events occur. Also, let's not pay any more words, the gap between our commitments and our payments cannot last. Commissioner, you will see large sums of money coming to your desk in the coming years in the next few years in bills that may remain unpaid.  My dream is that Europe will participate in the effective fight against youth unemployment. Of course, we have not received the funding we had hoped for to continue the youth employment initiative, but an assessment will be made and we will draw the consequences immediately. This budget also includes pilot projects and I am pleased that one of them gives us the opportunity to accompany apprentices and allow them mobility as well as students. Youth unemployment is an offence for Europe. It darkens our future.  As for the appeal, since this morning the Council unanimously approved the conclusions of the conciliation, ladies and gentlemen, I call on you to vote tomorrow on our budget for 2016.

name: Elnök asszony. –
text: The debate is over. Voting will take place on Wednesday, 25 November 2015. Written declarations (Article 162)

name: Nicola Caputo (S&D)
text: in writing. – The 2016 budget resulting from conciliation is primarily aimed at identifying the financial means necessary to meet the challenges of the moment, namely to stimulate growth, create jobs and tackle the migration crisis. I appreciate the commitments for research and development and therefore for Horizon 2020. I regret, however, the too weak measures taken in support of European farmers. The EUR 698 million envisaged will not be sufficient to respond to the extension of the Russian embargo on imports of certain agricultural products from the EU and to the very difficult situation, particularly in the dairy and pigmeat sectors. Well the commitment for young people. The reduction of youth unemployment must remain a political priority and, to this end, the available budgetary resources must be made the best use of, in particular through the Youth Employment Initiative.  Finally, I welcome the rigour of Parliament's budget, even though I think that something more and better could and should have been done to reduce the costs of administering the European institutions.

name: Tamás Deutsch (PPE)
text: Writing. – EU funds for Hungary were also provided in 2016. Attempts to link the payment of cohesion funds to the implementation of the rules on quotas for the relocation of migrants have been averted. It is an outstanding achievement that we have raised the budget lines contributing to the migration crisis by EUR 2 billion. Most of the additional resources, in line with the Hungarian Government's position, are spent in countries that are on the front lines of the migration crisis and contribute to the management of conflicts that reinforce the wave of immigration on their site, in the non-EU regions where they were created.  It is a success for Hungarian Ps to reverse the reduction of the Pre-Accession Fund as previously proposed by the Council, as these instruments have a decisive impact on the accession aspirations of the candidate countries, such as Serbia and the Hungarians in Vojvodina. In addition to real financial support, we are convinced that maintaining the level of the Pre-Accession Fund also sends an important political message and encourages candidate countries.  With the final vote, the EU budget for 2016 can provide the resources for the EUR 500 million milk rescue package, thus clearing all obstacles to the timely granting of EUR 2.9 billion to Hungarian dairy farmers. We also support the joint project "Diverse Europe" by Pál Csáky and Kinga Gál. In this context, €1 million will be available to applicants to finance minority programmes to combat discrimination.

name: Андрей Новаков (PPE)
text: in writing. – 150 billion euro. hundreds of pages of numbers and text, three institutions, months of negotiations. These things we know the people who were involved in the process. Tonight, however, I want to talk about values. The budget equals priorities and investments in the service of each of the more than 500 million euro. Citizens. It puts people, businesses and their needs at the center. The 150 billion euro are a bridge to our goals for a better tomorrow. Young people, Horizon 2020, Erasmus+, COSME, infrastructure, entrepreneurship, innovation and education – these are our values as the European Parliament. These are also European values measurable with visible results. Despite differing positions and challenges, the institutions sat around the table and achieved a result because we had one thing in mind - a stronger European Union in tomorrow. The budget is Europe.

name: Pavel Poc (S&D)
text: Writing. – I am very glad that the representatives of the European Parliament have managed to agree with the Council and the European Commission on the shape of the European Union budget for 2016 at such a rapid time. The experience of the past year, as well as the initial approach of the representatives of the Member States, did not at all indicate that the Council would see Parliament as an equal partner in the negotiations this time. It is gratifying that my colleagues have managed to negotiate in the vast majority the level of commitments as presented by the Commission. It is impossible to think that Europe will make progress in the fields of growth, competitiveness and employment unless sufficient resources are allocated to support research and development, innovation, SMEs and education. On the other hand, as Vice-President of the Committee on the Environment, Public Health and Food Safety, I have considerable reservations about the decision to reduce the level of commitments in the budget chapter 'Food and feed safety' by more than EUR 11 million. The reduction may have a detrimental effect on the level of protection and health of animals and plants in the Union, the early detection and eradication of harmful organisms and the provision of effective and reliable controls. I am also concerned that the Council did not respect the level of the means of payment proposed by the Commission and insisted on a reduction of EUR 570 million. If the Union defaults in the future, it is clear who is the culprit.

name: Elnök asszony. –
text: The next item is the debate on rachida dati's report on the prevention of radicalisation and recruitment of European citizens by terrorist organisations on behalf of the Committee on Civil Liberties, Justice and Home Affairs (2015/2063(INI)) (A8-0316/2015)

name: Rachida Dati
text: Rapporteur. Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, the attacks of 13 November have plunged Europe and the world into astonishment. I hope that we will have a thought for the victims and the families of the victims on the eve of the national funeral. Today, more than ever, we must be, we must act, we must respond to the level of our responsibilities and the confidence that European citizens have given us.  The report, which we are debating this evening, should not divide us but should lead us to a consensus; not a soft consensus, not a consensus of ease but a consensus on the necessary awareness to fight firmly against the barbarism and terrorism that is now in our midst.  The measures proposed in this report help to tighten the net, to close the noose on barbarians who take advantage of our rule of law and our universal values that they know so well, since they were born in Europe and lived in Europe, and which they absolutely wish to destroy.  No excuse, no mitigating circumstances, no good feeling should actually take place in the face of these criminals. Failing that, we will have to answer to our countrymen for our weakness and cowardice. The main measures proposed, which were adopted in the committee on 19 October, are, first of all, the criminal responsibility of the internet giants. The Internet has become the first virtual training camp for these radical terrorists with videos and quasi-Hollywood sites inciting hatred, barbarism, terrorism and crime. Prison, another place of radicalization on which we have for too long turned a blind eye, thinking that those who were radicalized turned to the faith. Yes, they turned to the faith of horror. This blindness led to the training, the recruitment of barbarians, thus preparing them to become time bombs, once released. Fighting terrorism also means fighting against its financing. Today, we must denounce all those foreign countries that pour their money without control or transparency in favour of structures, places of worship, unofficial or official, associations, for the benefit of self-proclaimed imams, all on the territory of the European Union. Gradually, they destroyed our values, deconstructed individuals who became the enemies of our countries, where they were born and where they lived. The enemy today is no longer external, it is inside and we were responsible for the creation of these monsters.  Secondly, with regard to the control of the movements of individuals reported, monitored or radicalised, the European PNR as an intra-European is now necessary. The terrorists of the Paris attacks could have been more easily located and we could have known the extent of their network that led them to commit the carnage last Friday; as indeed, but this is not enough, the systematic checks at the European Union's borders which must be put in place quickly; such as the return of the jihadists, who must be arrested, detained as soon as they return.  These measures are not exhaustive and your amendments, ladies and gentlemen, of course are welcome. But even if adopted, this report will only have an effect if the European Commission and the Council agree to implement these measures. Then take responsibility. The european citizens are watching us and expect a lot from us. Let's live up to their expectations, otherwise we'll pay a lot more. In this respect, I call the attention of our Socialist colleagues, since irresponsible amendments - and I am weighing my words - have been tabled, such as the refusal of control at the borders of the European Union to avoid the control of migrants even though terrorists have infiltrated as migrants. If we falter in the face of this, if we do not put this control in place, it will be an insult to the memory of the victims of the attacks of January and November 13.

name: Dimitris Avramopoulos
text: Member of the Commission. – Madam President, in the aftermath of the tragic events in Paris and the developments in Brussels, we are all more than concerned. Our society is appalled by the terror that extremists are trying to poison us with. While we are still grieving for the innocent people who lost their lives in Paris, we cannot allow this to turn into a general psychosis. We cannot allow fear to prevail, because fear is also a threat. We cannot allow the terrorists to demoralise us and win, because terrorists target innocent people, but they also target our values and our way of life. We have been through this before, and we know that our strength is our unity and our resilience. Our only way forward is to act to prevent these actions from happening and to ensure the security of our citizens and our democracies. This report could not be more timely for our collective response to fighting terrorism and radicalisation. In these challenging times for Europe it is of crucial importance that the institutions of our Union see eye to eye on the way ahead. The European Agenda on Security, adopted in April this year, set out the principles and key actions in this area. This agenda is the reason why we are not just reacting to events now. We are implementing and accelerating the actions we already had in the pipeline to strengthen our resilience to terror. An important example of one such action is the crucial new rules to control firearms that we proposed just last week. I will very soon come forward with an action plan on their trafficking as well. However, let me start with our work on prevention. Our strongest partner and guarantor for the delivery of effective preventive measures is the Radicalisation Awareness Network (RAN). More than 2 000 local practitioners with different backgrounds from all over Europe are working on addressing the root causes of radicalisation. Since the year 2011, the RAN has produced policy recommendations as well as practical guidance and training material to better prevent and address radicalisation, on schools and the prison and probation environment, on the foreign terrorist fighter phenomenon, and on the development of counter-narratives. The RAN has now been reinforced with a centre of excellence, which has been up and running since 1 October 2015 and which will support the RAN and help it expand its reach further, even to priority third countries such as the Middle East, North Africa and the Western Balkans. Many of the perpetrators of these vicious acts are EU citizens, born and bred in our societies. This means that our work has to start right here in our countries, in our societies and in our neighbourhoods. Let me now refer to the abuse of the internet and social media for terrorist purposes. We have started our engagement with the industry, and I will formally launch the EU Internet Forum on 3 December. I can inform you today that I will personally invite the Chairman of the Committee on Civil Liberties, Justice and Home Affairs (LIBE) to attend. I expect this partnership with the industry to lead to concrete outcomes in preventing and countering radicalisation leading to violent extremism. One of the key goals of this forum is to improve our cooperation in removing terrorist material that may push our youth towards radicalisation. The EU Internet Referral Unit, established within Europol, is instrumental and very helpful in this regard. It can build on the expertise of the European Cybercrime Centre within Europol, which has many years of experience in dealing with illegal content. So we are by no means starting from zero. In this context, I welcome the call to reinforce the mandate and resources of the European Cybercrime Centre to enable it to face these new challenges. Our inter-institutional discussions to finalise the Europol reform will also touch on this. The second priority is to support the development of effective counter-narratives. There is progress in this area, through initiatives such as the Syria Strategic Communication Task Force, which supports EU countries in developing messages and carrying out targeted communication campaigns. The Commission is both financially and politically supporting the continuation of this project. Today’s report touches on several other important elements that we are working on. We are working to improve evidence and intelligence-sharing across the European Union, in full respect – as is obvious – of fundamental rights. As a matter of priority, we will look into all available options to strengthen our tools against terrorist financing. This includes measures for freezing terrorist assets. I will very soon propose a directive to strengthen our framework on the criminalisation of terrorist offences, particularly travel with a terrorist purpose and terrorist financing. This is how we will tackle the problem of foreign terrorist fighters. I will also soon report on the implementation of the Commission’s Communication on the prevention of radicalisation. I hope that we will continue our constructive dialogue on matters of security and, more specifically, the pending proposals and envisaged initiatives. We will need your full support and engagement on the difficult way ahead. Europe needs to be united and to defend its values with the necessary rigour. You are well aware of the ongoing work on different counter-terrorism measures. We will discuss this in detail tomorrow and will have other opportunities to do so. Today, our discussion has focused on counter—radicalisation. It has focused specifically on one of the root causes of the problem, and this is where the solution should come from as well. This report will serve as a basis for a continued exchange of views about our prevention policy. I would like to express my thanks to the rapporteur, Ms Dati, and I look forward to a very useful and constructive discussion tonight.

name: Charles Tannock
text: rapporteur for the opinion of the Committee on Foreign Affairs. – Madam President, the events in Paris serve as a reminder to us of the very real threat that Islamist terrorism poses to our peace, security and social cohesion. Ensuring citizens’ safety and security is the primary duty of the state. Increasingly – perhaps fooled by the belief that Europe had truly entered into a time of a perpetual peace – it appears that some of our governments are beginning to fail to live up to these primary duties. Addressing this problem will require tough and difficult decisions from Member States. The Dati report offers a balanced and sensitive approach to what is a very divisive and politically charged subject. Whilst commitments in the report to initiatives such as the EU PNR Directive are welcome, a more robust and all-encompassing overall strategy is clearly now needed as well. There is a growing sense, especially as many of the factors affecting radicalisation are often outside of the control of the state, that there is a need to move away from the ideal of preventing radicalisation and instead towards a proactive security policy of managing radicalisation, including asking difficult questions on the financial role played by countries such as Saudi Arabia and Qatar.

name: Elnök asszony. –
text: I would like to ask my fellow Members, on the one hand, to keep the timeframe and, on the other hand, to speak a little slower, because there are difficulties in translating.

name: Ангел Джамбазки
text: rapporteur for the opinion of the Committee on Culture and Education. – Dear Colleagues, many things can and will be said on this undeniably most up-to-date topic, but without urgent measures, we will not achieve any visible results. Yes, we have undoubtedly produced a report on the subject, proposing to the Commission how to work on this issue. However, immediate action is needed. All organizations associated with Islamic State and suspicious activity, detailed analyses of their actions, their prohibition and, where necessary, checks of the educational materials and content of books and information that are available on the world's networks are needed. Over the past few weeks, all of us European citizens have witnessed the consequences of the radicalisation of European citizens who do not fit into the European Communities and their recruitment by terrorist groups and organisations. I have long warned, and it is no secret, about this problem and its dangerous spread throughout the European Union. Immediately, dear colleagues, we must open our eyes that this problem has already far exceeded its regional character and is not regional. Europe is facing war and I fear that if we continue to close our eyes to the problem, it will be too late.

name: Monika Hohlmeier
text: Mr President, i.e. the Group of the European People's Party (Christian Democrats) and European Democrats Madam President, Commissioner, ladies and gentlemen, I would like to thank the rapporteur for her excellent work and for the work she has When we are dealing with the issue of radicalisation, we need to take the many factors that contribute to radicalisation in an overall view. As a consequence, this means that the so-called soft factors must be taken into account in the same way as tough measures. For me, the so-called soft factors include essential things such as interreligious dialogue, intercultural dialogue. I also say it quite frankly to us: invite Muslims so that they are not excluded, so that young people who are Muslim feel at home and are integrated here. On the other hand, however, it must also be clear that hate speech and calls to crime – such as the chastisement of women, which is nothing more than beating women, which is a violation of human rights – or calls for murder and manslaughter, or then the websites or the dangers or Salafist scenes that captivate and indoctrinate young people, , so that they no longer feel any empathy, no longer have any sense of what their environment is ... We must protect young people from being banned by such perpetrators and extremists. We also need more research to do this. There is far too little research into how young people can be banned from such dangers in the first place.  In any case, it is not only poverty that is the reason, but it was engineers among them, they were people who came from the best of society and nevertheless became dangers and terrorists and went to Syria. We need to address these factors, even if we want to avoid radicalisation.  (The speaker agreed to answer a question on the 'blue card' procedure under Rule 169(8) of the Rules of Procedure)

name: Sajjad Karim (ECR)
text: blue-card question. – Madam President, ‘one—in—five British Muslims have sympathy for jihadis’ was the headline of The Sun newspaper yesterday. Now this really should alarm us all, if it were true.  What is actually alarming about this is that it is completely untrue. Even the survey company does not support or endorse the interpretation used by The Sun newspaper – the largest circulation press in the United Kingdom. But The Sun does not care a damn what this House thinks... (The President cut off the speaker)

name: Monika Hohlmeier (PPE)
text: Answer to a question about the "blue card" procedure. I have decided that I have understood the question. I wouldn't follow every headline that spreads significant nonsense. It is essential that we work with serious data and facts. That is why I have just spoken about research. It is also essential that we do not simply denigrate Muslims in general and in general, but know how to distinguish very precisely between the Muslim faith and the terrorists who use Islam as a headline. In other words, we must draw very clear differences and make them clear in our reasoning towards those who are potentially at risk.

name: Ana Gomes
text: on behalf of the S&D Group – Madam President, Commissioner, this report could not be more relevant after the heinous terrorist attacks in Paris on 13 November. It is the result of intense collective work, in cooperation with the author, Rachida Dati, which I welcome. Thousands of young Europeans have left for Syria and Iraq to fight in the ranks of Daesh, which is neither state nor Islamic. But it is not, as some deceptively beckons, with the closing of borders or with a PNR directive that we will be able to stop their radicalisation and recruitment.  The fight is also political and ideological, and it is fought right here in Europe, within our societies, because the attackers in Paris - in January, as in November - were European, French and Belgian. And so it is essential that we fight back to fight inequalities, discrimination and social exclusion particularly acutely felt by migrant communities in neighbourhoods that we have left to turn into ghettos of despair and resentment, with 60% unemployment, like Molenbeek, in the heart of Europe, Brussels, now besieged by fear. Our collective security requires ending the destructive policy of blind austerity, which also explains why instead of having human resources and other enhanced means, police, intelligence services and magistrates are struggling with disabilities, and explains that prisons have become centres of radicalisation rather than rehabilitation of offenders. We need unity in the fight against the transnational terrorist threat. We need a political union, where our States share security information and police and judicial cooperation, and make joint planning and joint security risk assessment. We need a common foreign policy, European security and security and defence policy, as Syria, Iraq and Libya highlight.  Member States of the European Union must coordinate and attack arms trafficking, terrorist financing and organised crime, associated with the capacity of organisations such as Daesh and al-Qaeda, and cannot continue in "business as usual" mode with regard to governments and states where Daesh and al-Qaeda have found financiers and facilitators. International trade, including arms, and oil cannot be worth our silence.  The lesson to be learned from the attacks in Paris is that our governments must coordinate to stop the terrorist threat and understand that this is a coherent and European strategy. And that it will not be at the expense of fundamental rights and freedoms that we will overcome terrorism. Without rights we will never have security. Make no mistake who argues otherwise to drop data protection, citizens' privacy and other fundamental guarantees, or those who try to stigmatise Muslims and even refugees, who suffer at the hands of terrorists and therefore seek to flee here, where there are rights freedoms and guarantees. And that is our moral strength not to stand in front of the terrorists and not play their game, who want to destroy freedoms and democracy.  (The speaker agrees to answer a "blue card" question pursuant to Article 162(8) of the Rules of Procedure.)

name: Kazimierz Michał Ujazdowski (ECR)
text: question asked by raising a "blue card". – The measure of responsibility is the concern for the safety of citizens and the European Parliament would do very well if it were in agreement on the protection of our external borders and the implementation of initiatives such as the PNR Directive. I am very surprised that you are protesting these initiatives and I would like to ask: why are the Socialists opposed to this? Is this your personal opinion or the entire political group? I am very surprised by this.

name: Ana Gomes (S&D)
text: blue-card answer. – No, we do not oppose PNR. We voted for PNR. But PNR is only a tool and not the ‘magic bullet’ that will solve the problem. Yes – and also in reply to Mrs Dati – we are in favour of border controls, but we are not in favour of the abuse of controls to allow racial profiling and ethnic profiling in order to prevent migrants and refugees from coming into Europe. I recall that, when we had borders, more than a million of the citizens of my country, Portugal, crossed those borders illegally to work in France.

name: Timothy Kirkhope
text: on behalf of the ECR Group. – Madam President, over 5 000 EU citizens are currently thought to be foreign fighters and radicalised; these are our own citizens. Often they are third- or fourth-generation Europeans, often educated and often with loving families. Understanding why this is the path they have chosen is one of the greatest challenges we face today, and it requires a comprehensive response. Law enforcement, civil society and governments need to work with communities and their leaders, with schools and with prisons. We need to work with internet providers to reduce the dangerous hate-filled and exploitative propaganda on the internet today. We need to better implement existing laws and to reduce loopholes. But I am afraid that today, more and more people are being exploited by criminals. But solutions are never found by pointing the finger of blame at each other, or indeed by the demonisation of entire communities, religions or groups of people. I would like to support the remarks made by my honourable friend Dr Karim a few minutes ago regarding the appalling way in which the media in the UK and elsewhere has reported such dangerous falsehoods – particularly only days after Paris – which undermine all of what we are working towards for the security of our citizens. Solutions are found through cooperation, through actions and a willingness to acknowledge that these most difficult challenges are both complex and nuanced.  They can only be solved by reason, by good sense, by calmness but firmness, and by working together to resolve them. (The speaker agreed to take a blue-card question under Rule 162(8))

name: William (The Earl of) Dartmouth (EFDD)
text: blue-card question. – Mr Kirkhope, you supported Mr Karim’s critique. It was meant to be a question of The Sun newspaper. Does this mean that in future you and Mr Karim, and for that matter the entire Conservative Party, will decline to be supported by The Sun newspaper in forthcoming elections?

name: Timothy Kirkhope (ECR)
text: blue-card answer. – Lord Dartmouth, that is a very peculiar question you asked. I believe in the freedom of the press, but I also believe in responsible journalism and facts. Unlike you – and thank you for your usual intervention whenever I speak – I also happen to trust the people. I trust the people, all the people, of the United Kingdom. I believe that they are all people who have a contribution to make in different ways to our society without being demonised in an unfair and improper way.

name: Maite Pagazaurtundúa Ruiz
text: on behalf of the ALDE Group. – Madam President, out of respect for every victim of terrorism we are obliged to be effective in the fight against terrorism and in preventing fanatical and violent radicalisation. Effectiveness, legality and proportionality should be our practical guides. Out of respect for victims, in defence of our right to life and freedom, we must be effective in preventing and detecting violent fanaticization early.  This report was already a comprehensive approach to defeating the killers' strategy and linking all public authorities against global terrorism. There's no one left. We all need to.  We defend our democracy, that is, our right to live and live freely. Following the Paris attacks, this report should also be transformed into an urgent gesture from Parliament for citizens to trust their institutions. Liberals and Democrats are here to seek consensus, to overcome small national or group selfishness because we are aware of our historical responsibility.  Neutralizing terrorist funding makes recruitment difficult. Being effective in avoiding recruitment, through social media and the internet, is our obligation in a digital and globalized world. Also in prisons. Limiting crimes, ensuring legality and judicial review are our responsibility.  It is key to be effective in preventing and detecting early detection in communities so that no more neighbourhoods such as Molenbeek in Brussels are repeated. Let's avoid the environmental oxygen of the fans. I know this well because I was born and raised in a small town in the Basque Country, where there were neighbors who called for the death of those who did not think like the terrorists and where the fear that favored recruitment reigned. Prevention is critical, I can assure you.  We must provide all instruments adapted for real border control needs, such as criminal transit detection, all ensuring proportionality and judicial control.  Above all we must have courage, democratic sense and patience to overcome them. We'll make it. We have no choice.

name: Barbara Spinelli
text: Mr President, president, ladies and gentlemen, i.e. the european Union, we must not Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, I would like to thank Rachida Dati, who has often heard voices other than his own. The attacks in Paris have exacerbated the differences between us. The attack on the Socialists seems to me to be a bad sign.  The safety of citizens is essential, but there is also security from abusive state intervention. The post-September 11 american is a lesson not to be imitated. Terrorism must be combated by the rule of law: we should never imitate Blair who said about torture in 2003: 'the rules of the game have changed'.  What drives so many young people to join Isis? Three reasons that are not sufficiently thorough: anti-terrorist wars; most foreign fighters belong to the generation of the anti-ground war, a war that created chaos and Isis, ruining the reputation of democracies. Nor can we fill Saudi Arabia and Qatar, the main financiers of terrorism, with weapons.  Banlieues: no investment has been made to reduce ghettoisation. Sarkozy's decision to take money away from the local police was tragic.  Internet and prisons where you recruit the most. Increasing state control on the Internet is no use and it is dangerous to blindly apply segregation in prisons.

name: Jean Lambert
text: on behalf of the Verts/ALE Group. – Madam President, I also wanted to say that I appreciate the work that has been done on this report. Through working together, we have found much to agree on on this report as it is tabled, even if we disagree on some elements – and that is not surprising. But we know we have to work within the framework of the democratic values that we espouse and which are under attack, and not only from one direction – and I do not mean the pop group. The report makes it clear that terrorism is not the prerogative of any single religion, nationality or civilisation, and we also have to recognise at the moment that it is an international phenomenon. We can all agree, for example, that we need to radically improve the use of the intelligence information that we have, to tackle arms trafficking, and to track and disrupt terrorist financing. We will not all agree, it is clear, on the use of PNR. My Group’s concerns are well-known, and we feel that the millions of euros to be invested in the system could be better and more effectively spent, for example, on joint investigation teams within Europol, on delivering on the effective resourcing of EU agencies – as called for in Madam Dati’s report – such as CEPOL, EUROJUST and EUROPOL itself, or on offering further support to the RAN network. Parliament thoroughly agrees with the evaluation of the Commission there. We need to strengthen local capacity to combat violent extremism. In terms of prevention within our own communities, London’s Police Commissioner at the time of the London underground bombings recently said that national security depends on neighbourhood security. Community policing depends on trust from communities, so that people feel able and know how to report the unusual, the worrying and the suspicious. This is not going to happen when everyone from a particular social group is treated as a suspect and an outsider, or if every teacher and social worker is turned into a potential spy. The roles and responsibilities need to be clear and the funding streams different. Social cohesion is essential, and those who increase social division and push a style of community collective guilt for terrorist acts are certainly not providing solutions. We also recognise what was said in the report about the internet as a potential vehicle for grooming for the purposes of violent extremism. We need clear rules on how we deal with that. (The speaker agreed to take a blue-card question under Rule 162(8))

name: Tibor Szanyi (S&D)
text: Blue card question. – Madam President, you have made a very impressive list of how much should be done, but do you agree with me that the financial channels should be cut first? After all, European companies, European people buy stolen oil, stolen art, and Europeans often pay chunky ransoms. Do you agree that this is the solution to holding them back?

name: Jean Lambert (Verts/ALE)
text: blue-card answer. – I think we can agree on that, and I think there are some very helpful additional amendments from various Groups in the House which are also pushing on the issue of having to dry up funding. Certainly when you are looking at the large-scale developments within Syria and Iraq, or whether in Nigeria or elsewhere, it is clear that there is a stream of arms coming in there.
