I think, as people have said, we also have to look at what we do to try and provide a different vision, because it is that vision of the future – a distorted one, I think – which is also creating many of the problems.

name: Kristina Winberg
text: On the other: The EFDD Group. Madam President, I would like to begin by thanking Theresa May for I would like to begin by giving a thought to the victims and their families who were the victims of the terrible attack that happened in Paris the other week. I am deeply concerned about the terrorist attacks that we see around us today. I'm even so worried that I try to avoid places with a lot of people. I prefer to stay inside my apartment instead of going out to a restaurant when I'm in Brussels. I'm worried about the whereabouts of my children. In my country, Sweden, we are very vulnerable to future attacks. With mass immigration, especially from countries with many IS supporters, we are at greater risk of being subjected to these horrific attacks. Especially since we barely know who we let into our country. This is because you decision-makers in here have only seen you blind to freedom of movement and an open Europe. With the migration that is now taking place to our countries, how can you even believe that we will be able to integrate all these people? After all, we cannot even give them a roof over their heads, let alone give them hope of a better life, with access to work and housing. This, my friends, leads too many of them to a life of exclusion, hopelessness and despair. It is precisely in situations like this that many of the young men are attracted to becoming radicalised. Now the rapporteur is talking about prevention – deradicalisation, investigations, etc.m. Perhaps the rapporteur should bear in mind that we are at an urgent stage. What should be done is to prevent more and more of these scum from entering European soil as quickly as possible. There is no secret in is is to send jihadists with the boats across the Mediterranean. (Now I don't have time anymore.) (The speaker agreed to answer a question ("blue card") in accordance with Rule 162(8) of the Rules of Procedure)

name: Gilles Lebreton (ENF)
text: "blue card" question. Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, I thank you for your intervention. I was very sensitive to the few words you had for the victims of Paris, as a Frenchman. You spoke only, quite rightly, about Islamist radicalization, which is the main danger today. However, the Dati report mixes this very disturbing phenomenon with other forms of violence that are less worrying, such as separatist violence. Do you agree with me that this report is not devoted exclusively to Islamist radicalisation?

name: Kristina Winberg (EFDD)
text: answer ("blue card"). In this case, I think we are talking about terrorism wherever it comes from, because what is happening in our countries is that we are facing a terrible, distressing fear. I also say that a lot of people are coming with the refugee flows. No matter what kind of terrorists it is, we have to fight it, and now.

name: Vicky Maeijer
text: on behalf of the ENF Group. – In Paris, Islam has once again brutally shown its true face, the face of evil. That makes me sad but above all angry. Angry, because I wonder how many more victims have to fall before the eyes of the road watchers are opened. Angry, because I wonder when you stop looking for excuses for Islamic terrorism. The problem is not the economic crisis, unemployment or not feeling at home in school.  The west is under attack head-on and you are coming up with proposals to fight terrorism with awareness campaigns, education in schools and tea drinking with imams. Radicalization doesn't solve you with cuddling. You can't solve that with millions of deradicalization projects. You can't solve that by sticking your head in the sand about the dangers of Islam. The only anti-radicalization drug is de-Islamization, the preventive capture of potential terrorists. Jihadists returning, not treated as traumatized youth but as persona non grata. And if you want to go to Syria, go, but don't come back.  Finally, national states must close their borders and defend the freedom and security of their inhabitants.

name: Marina Albiol Guzmán (GUE/NGL).
text: – Madam President, it is at least the third time in this debate that we have heard a xenophobic speech, which criminalizes millions of European citizens, which links migration and terrorism. These are hate speeches. I call on the Bureau of Parliament to take appropriate measures, to sanction Members, not to allow any more speeches that threaten human rights. How long will the apology of violence, xenophobia and fascism continue to be allowed in this House?

name: Zoltán Balczó (NI).
text: – Madam President, this report has been exceeded by time and events. Today it is not just that there is a significant terrorist threat in the EU, it is actually a war on Europe. And who will become terrorists in Europe? Those who don't feel part of society, the report says. And the hundreds of thousands who are arriving now, without qualifications, without language skills, from other cultures? The naïve expectation is that religious leaders will profess European values. According to the report, "the fight against terrorist radicalisation" should be based on a common value "aimed at ensuring an open Europe." I repeat: open to ensuring a Europe against terrorism. No comment.

name: Milan Zver (PPE).
text: – The report is certainly important, especially after the last brutal terrorist attack in Paris. It brings about some concrete measures, such as the deletion of terrorist content from the internet, the exchange of all relevant information between Member States and Europol, as well as the withdrawal of travel documents, the freezing of finances, special surveillance and the up-to-date maintenance of the jihadist blacklist. These are the main measures that concern only around a few thousand, perhaps tens of thousands of citizens, at the moment.  However, when we talk about young people at risk of exposure to radicalisation, we can talk about a multimillion-dollar figure. In this case, long-term, comprehensive and preventive approaches are needed in Europe. The aim is to integrate this vulnerable population into society, in the field of work and schooling, as well as spending their free time.  In the long term, europe's still being anonynony about open societies requires an education for active and responsible citizenship and democracy.  Dear Sirs, if we do not equip young people with values and competences that will guarantee them functional integration into European society, we have fallen not only on the task of deradicalisation of young people, but also in the construction of the European Union. If we are not successful, we will be facing enduring cultural collisions, social and political tensions and conflicts instead of dialogue, parallel societies instead of open societies, and terrorism will become our daily routine.

name: Die Präsidentin. –
text: Mr Frunzulic' has asked for a 'blue card'. However, you will have heard that my colleague first said that she no longer takes 'blue cards'. I agree, because we have already exceeded the timetable. This means: no more "blue cards" from now on.

name: Josef Weidenholzer (S&D).
text: Madam President, I would like to thank the president for her I welcome this own-initiative report, not again because it is being debated at a time when we are following the terrible attacks in Paris. This report proposes concrete and considered measures to deal with one of the most serious threats to our freedom. Nothing is sacred to the Da'esh terrorists. Their death cult is aimed at destroying our civilisation, at destroying our democracy. Their crimes must be punished without ifs and buts. But it is not enough just to react, we must take preventive action against these terrorists, to deprive them of the breeding ground once and for all, because this phenomenon also has its roots in us. But what has grown over the years cannot be conjured away with a single act of strength, nor is there the miracle cure that we all hope for. We need unity, determination, prudence and, above all, patience. This report contains many good proposals, and it is a comprehensive strategy for preventing radicalisation and the recruitment of EU citizens. It offers support structures such as the RAN, the work in prisons is addressed, accompanying measures as well as an efficient and offensive confrontation on the Internet, and finally it is also about the elimination of financial support.

name: Helga Stevens (ECR).
text: – After the Paris attacks, strong answers are needed. The NVA delegation therefore supports this report. More than that, the report contains a number of measures decided by the Belgian Government, including the immediate detention of returning combatants. The fight against terror on the Internet is also a priority. The report calls for penalties against internet companies if they do not comply with a court or administrative order to remove jihadist content. In this way, freedom and security are aligned, of course with appropriate guarantees for freedom of expression. I hereby call on my colleagues in this Chamber to show political decisiveness and to put dogmas aside. For example, with regard to privacy and data protection, we must look for a good balance, but we also need to move forward. Finally, I would like to call for a sense of reality. Refugees are not necessarily terrorists, of course, but several terrorists appear to have entered Europe as asylum seekers. That's what the Paris attacks prove. Unfortunately, there is a security risk and that is why we now need to make real work on data collection and exchange at the external borders. No registration, no rights.

name: Cecilia Wikström (ALDE).
text: – Madame la Présidente, avant de parler du rapport Dati, permettez-moi d'adresser mes plus sincères condoléances aux victimes des attaques du 13 novembre dernier, à Paris, et à leurs proches. Ces attaques sont des attaques contre nous tous et contre nos valeurs européennes. Sachez que l'on fera tout pour combattre ensemble ces meurtriers. Madam President, I would like to begin by congratul The DATI report, however, we should remember, is not an action programme drawn up in response to the Attacks in Paris. Nor is it a report on anti-terrorism, but a report on how to combat radicalisation in europe. We must strengthen the work of our Member States to prevent weak, young people from being lured into these murderous sects. It is a question of identifying risks and measures early on, for example in prisons and prisons. Prisons should help people back into society, not push them into the arms of terrorists. We must also reduce the chances of terrorists and other radicals gaining followers of their sick ideology over the internet. What we have to do now, first and foremost, is to realise that we are living in a time when darkness is casting long shadows over Europe. But we must now remember that after the darkest night it will finally be morning, just as the light must return in Paris, in Brussels and elsewhere. Together we must affirm the good – and the belief in the future.

name: Marie-Christine Vergiat (GUE/NGL).
text: Madam President, thousands of young Europeans have gone to fight in Syria and Iraq. How many are they now ready to go there or commit massacres, here or elsewhere? Let me express my solidarity with Tunis, which has just been hit again by an attack. So yes, we must do everything to prevent these young people from taking action, but we must also know how to take care of those who return. They are 90% according to a French survey and they can be valuable allies. Their profiles differ more and more: middle classes, working-class backgrounds or even highly advantaged backgrounds. And, not to the displeasure of some here, yes they are Muslims for many of them, but often converted and recently converted, and they are also atheists, even Catholics and Jews. Their backgrounds are increasingly differentiated, they are marginalized and psychologically weak, but also perfectly integrated.  So yes, repression is necessary, but it is not enough and it must more than ever be done in accordance with the law, avoiding widespread stigma and suspicion.

name: Judith Sargentini (Verts/ALE).
text: – In 2004, the filmmaker Theo van Gogh was murdered in Amsterdam. I was a member of the Amsterdam City Council at the time. He was murdered by a radical Muslim, an extremist. I was there. Fortunately, I was not there at the time, but I was there when we started worrying in Amsterdam about how to deal with extremists. It turned out that this extremist was being bugged at home by the secret service and that they knew he was being radicalized. It was an Amsterdam boy with a Dutch passport. And in the years that followed, there were the attacks in London, in Madrid, in Brussels, in Paris and Toulouse, again and again people with European passports on the retina of the secret services. What we need to realise is that countering terrorism in Europe means understanding why our boys are radicalising and that means being in the neighbourhoods and not cutting back on policing and investigations.

name: Gerard Batten (EFDD).
text: – Madam President, this report completely fails to acknowledge the cause of the current terrorist threat, which is ideological. That ideology is fundamentalist Islam. From its creation, Islam has been propagated by force and violence. President Hollande has said that we are at war. The first casualties in this war must be appeasement and political correctness. We face one of two choices: we can accept eventual submission to the ideology of an ever-increasing Islamic population, or we can take the first step in resistance and end any more mass immigration from Islamic countries. Only then can we start to address the difficult issue of integrating the existing Muslim population. The EU strategy is to deny the existence of the real problem, while at the same time importing millions more people from Islamic countries. Your ideological opponents regard you as fools; history will judge you as traitors.

name: Janice Atkinson (ENF).
text: – Madam President, I too would like to express my sympathy with the French people. These recent terror attacks prove that we have been sleepwalking into a hotbed of the worst of multiculturalism. British values are abhorrent within many of these self-segregated communities. Sadly, multiculturalism is overwhelmingly where the seeds of hate are sewn. Since 2012, over 4 000 people have been referred to the UK’s anti-radicalisation programme PREVENT. Half of them were under the age of 18 years old. But for those who have put their radical ideas into action, we cannot have any compassion or show any mercy. Jihadi John came from a middle-class family and could enjoy a wonderful British life. But like hundreds of other radicals, he turned against our society, watching porn, using drugs, abusing the freedoms of our society to spread hate and terror. In their nirvana, they would not be allowed to do this. Anyone who preaches hatred and calls for violence should be prosecuted. If they are non-British, they must be directly expelled from the UK. We are at war. We have to fight for our values. We must address multiculturalism and fight for our western liberal democracy, our very identity, our culture and our children’s future.

name: Diane Dodds (NI).
text: – Madam President, from my experience of communities living under threat in Northern Ireland, I can tell Members of this House that there is no number of bombs, bullets, or callous acts of terrorism that can hope to uproot democracy or destroy a free and fair way of life. Like the Provisional IRA in my constituency, ISIS can and will be defeated. The starting point in the fight against radicalisation should be everyone, in each of our societies, coming together to call out these barbarians for what they are. We should be unequivocal in our condemnation. There are Members of Sinn Féin in this Parliament. Only last week, their party colleague in Northern Ireland openly said that he did not consider ISIS to be terrorists. Shameful. In the aftermath of the Paris attacks, I would call on the Sinn Féin MEPs in this House to apologise to our French colleagues for the offence caused by these despicable comments. We must aim to combat radicalism via the internet and support agencies on a national and a pan-national basis with adequate resources and budgets to combat this evil. Moreover, the EU must put in place every safeguard to ensure that the road to radicalisation is not nurtured by directly supporting revisionism. In my own constituency we witnessed the complete misuse of European peace funds by the Tí Chulainn Centre in South Armagh, where children were photographed in terrorist garb and holding imitation weapons. That is wrong; it ought not to happen and it is important that it should never happen again.

name: Lars Adaktusson (PPE).
text: Madam President, I would like to begin by thanking Theresa May for The terrorist attacks in Paris show that we must open our eyes. We must break with the naivety that has so often characterised the view of militant Islamism. The fact that the terror sect IS is at war with Europe and the free world must now guide the action required. Both politics, legislation and public debate must focus on action and on the protection of Europe's citizens. The time for relativization of militant Islamism is over. A shift in the climate of conversation and recognition of the actual threats we face are central to getting the necessary measures in place. Political processes that are under way but are moving too slowly need to be implemented quickly. The Socialists, Liberals and Greens will hopefully take their share of the responsibility and stop delaying the PNR issue. Making the pnr data of airlines available to the police is of the utmost importance. It is also with tighter surveillance of external borders and more effective coordination of the work of the security services in Europe. With this, I would like to thank my colleague Mr Dati for an excellent resolution which I hope a large majority of this House will support.

name: Péter Niedermüller (S&D).
text: – Madam President, we are not even quite over the horrors of Paris, and we are already faced with politicians trying to take advantage of this situation. The Hungarian Prime Minister, for example, found that all immigrants, all terrorist immigrants. But he knows it, we all know there's no direct link between immigration and terrorism. We know that the perpetrators of the horrific Paris attacks were French and Belgian nationals. People who were born in these countries, grew up here, socialized here. We cannot consider these people immigrants, because if we consider them immigrants, this is just proof that we still consider them strangers. Not those who belong to this society, they belong to European societies.  I find it infinitely sad and dismal that many people in Europe are still pursuing policies of fencing, exclusion, stigma, fear and hatred. We know that this policy leads nowhere but further radicalisation. Instead, we should strive to understand and address the political and cultural logic of radicalisation. We must make it clear that social inclusion does not mean the surrender of cultural identity, it does not mean violent cultural assimilation. We must also accept these young people in a way that will find a future, a home and security in Europe.

name: Monica Macovei (ECR).
text: – Madam President, the 5 000 European citizens who have left to fight alongside terrorist organisations in Iraq and Syria are certainly our failure. We need to look at the cause and we need to prevent this figure from rising. At this point, however, we must first stop any threat and terrorist attack on us, and as such, some urgent measures are needed: the rapid adoption of the Directive on the European Air Passenger Register, the PNR Directive. The breakdown of terrorist groups must also be done in particular by combating illicit financing. The International Financial Action Task Force blacklisted Afghanistan, Pakistan, Iran, Iraq. These are just a few of the countries that fund terrorism. Terrorism is funded by money produced by organised crime, corruption and money laundering networks. Money produced by black money that is laundered must become a crime, money laundering must become a crime in every country and must be strictly enforced. Financial institutions must stop opening anonymous accounts and must identify the beneficial owners of companies.

name: Gérard Deprez (ALDE).
text: Madam President, I welcome Mrs Dati's report in its current form, which is a good synthesis of her initial proposals and the proposals, additions and adjustments of the political groups. It is an excellent basis for working to combat radicalisation. Having said that, Madam President, I would like to take this opportunity to say a few more personal words. I am Belgian and you know that our country is going through a particularly difficult time at the moment and we very much appreciate the solidarity of other European countries. But I am, I must tell you, somewhat exasperated by what I read and what I hear about my country and, in particular, the municipality of Molenbeek. I recognize the weaknesses of my country, I even acknowledge its faults, especially in Molenbeek and not only in this commune, but we must not make the only commune of Molenbeek the single European centre for the production of jihadists. The perpetrator of the only attack that has been carried out so far on Belgian territory was not a citizen of Molenbeek, he was a French national. The people who carried out the Paris attacks, two or three of them, at least, are not from Molenbeek, they come from Syria and they have other nationalities. It was not people from Molenbeek, Madam President, who killed in New York, Madrid or elsewhere.  Crime is a multinational and we have to fight this multinational everywhere.

name: Barbara Spinelli (GUE/NGL).
text: Madam President, I have a point of order about what Mr Dodds said.  Is it possible to accuse of complicity with ISIS/Islamic State group, an entire delegation of this parliament, namely Sinn Féin?  And, if that is not possible, what steps can be taken to ensure that such an outrageous and implausible assertion is provided?

name: Die Präsidentin. –
text: Thank you Mrs Spinelli. We will look at the exact choice of words and then come back to it.

name: Eva Joly (Verts/ALE).
text: Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, our security depends on an unprecedented mobilization against terrorism. Alongside judicial, police and military actions, a battle of the imaginations must be waged to prevent young Europeans from turning into jihadism. Our enemies have propaganda, we have culture and education, which are the formidable weapons of democracy against obscurantism.  No fight against terrorism will be victorious if we do not also fight against what engenders it. For environmentalists, this fight against radicalisation does not involve the stigmatization of Islam or the adoption of the European NNP and its ever-increasing collection of data. It involves understanding the mechanisms and preventing the transition to radicalism and violence of young Europeans of all backgrounds, cultures and social classes. It involves combating inequality, frustrations, which provide an overly convenient narrative to the islamic State's murderous manipulators. Our enemies dream of embracing all the left-behinds in our societies and turning them against us. Our social cohesion will be our best bulwark.

name: Ignazio Corrao (EFDD).
text: Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, Commissioner, I believe that the debate on this report on radicalisation comes at the wrong time, because it is clear that there is a strong emotional boost after the events in Paris and what happened in the following days, which takes the subject of the debate somewhere else. We believe that, while sharing the concerns and seriousness of the situation, with regard to radicalisation, it is wrong to think that the problem can be solved through a repressive system, rather than by prevention. That is what we have seen from this report. Furthermore, when we talk about repression, we risk compressing personal freedoms and, therefore, in order to obtain more freedom, we risk restricting our own. I do not believe that the reaction of the states has been intelligent in this case, because, for example, the attacks in Afghanistan have produced only further terrorism and more problems.  We learn from history to be more forward-looking and to react in another way.

name: Sophie Montel (ENF).
text: Madam President, the report before us is characteristic of this dogmatic and ineffective Europe that you have been building for decades.  You are thinking only of strengthening obscure European agencies and giving them ever more sovereignty. But these agencies are all like FRONTEX. Supposedly created to solve a problem, they only organize its development.  Europe has deprived France of the means to ensure its security. Inside and outside the Schengen area, murderers were able to move freely and kill 130 innocent people. You see massive Eurobeate propaganda as the only response to jihadist propaganda. You want to rule the internet with an iron glove worthy of China and continue not to attack the roots of evil. On the contrary, you advocate the development of communitarianism, whereas it is he who makes Molenbeek a breeding ground for Islamists.  What the young people of our country need is the love of their homeland. The French people must be able to take advantage of the freedom and security guaranteed by secure national borders, a national identity assumed with pride and above all an exhilarating national destiny.

name: Γεώργιος Επιτήδειος (
text: NI). Madam President, the measures we are proposing to prevent the recruitment of young Europeans by terrorist organisations I fear will not have any significant results. This is because they only address the results and not the causes of the problem.  We hesitate to teach our children to love their country so that we are not seen as nationalists and extremes.  We do not educate our children with the principles of Christianity so as not to be considered conservative and bigoted. We do not care to teach the history of our country, the principles and values of the European Union and European culture, so as not to be seen as racist and xenophobic. We tolerate and choose to be ruled by incompetent and corrupt politicians who destroy the economy, destroy democracy, de-impoverished the peoples of Europe and create armies of unemployed young people. That's how we make our children easy victims of jihadist propaganda.  Because how is it possible that the European young people do not hate this callous state? Not wanting to punish a society that is hostile to it and takes away all right to hope in the future.  So let us give our children ideals, let us eliminate these causes and then we will see how capable, pro-progress the young people of Europe are and above all indifferent to jihadist propaganda.

name: Barbara Kudrycka (PPE).
text: – Madam President, i voted in favour of the report by Mrs Schwab I think we all agree that the European Union now has to deal with sophisticated campaigns of disinformation, radicalisation that are spreading online, but also in schools or prisons. The cross-border nature of terrorism and the constant development of technology enable fanatics around the world to communicate with each other instantly and recruit to their structures. It is therefore good that the European Commission proposes to improve existing methods and develops new Community tools to counter radicalisation and terrorism. But in order to effectively counter radicalism, it is also necessary to combat effectively the hate speech that floods the internet. And in this case, we must also find legal limits that will determine what is hate speech and what is not, and what measures to counter it. I am therefore pleased that the Commission wants to increase cooperation with the online sector and to remove terrorist and extremist content from their platforms. The police, on the other hand, should draw absolute legal consequences for those who promote violent extremism. Member States should, in turn, cooperate better in areas such as the exchange of information and intelligence, in order to allow for the effective application of the new measures proposed by the Commission.

name: Tanja Fajon (S&D).
text: – Terrorists are successful where there is mistrust between people of different faiths and backgrounds, where we build stereotypes, hatred and xenophobia. Perverted abuse of religion is one of the reasons for radicalisation. As well as exclusion from society. More than 5 000 young Europeans have joined terrorist organisations. We need a clear fight and a plan against recruitment for terrorism. We need an effective exchange of best practices, the exchange of information between law enforcement authorities on radicalisation in Europe and the fight against the illegal arms trade. It is essential to prevent radicalisation in European prisons, on the Internet, and the role of education and social inclusion must be strengthened. However, we need a specific strategy to deal with young returnees who have been let down by their cooperation with Islamic State. The Socialists and Democrats have published a brochure with key priorities in the fight against terrorism, which emphasises not only the security response, but also tackling the causes that spread terrorism, war and violence in third countries. I agree that we need to strengthen, increase the effectiveness of the control of our external borders, but I do not agree with the actions of some European governments, which are profiling migrants and refugees on the basis of racial or ethnic origin through tighter border checks. Hungarian Prime Minister Orban's declaration that all terrorists are migrants is a threat to our democracies.

name: Beatrix von Storch (ECR).
text: Madam President, I would like to thank the president for her Mrs Dati has presented a report on the radicalisation and recruitment of terrorist organisations. Do you know what it's like when you get up in the dark, don't see your hand in front of your eyes, and yet you're too comfortable to turn on the light? This is also a bit of a story with this report. He talks about education, about Internet surveillance and terrorist financing. But one thing is missing: the light is not turned on. The report does not even mention that the West is also fuelling radicalisation because it has been intervening in the Islamic world for many years. Every bomb we throw off there incites more hatred! ISIS and its followers are monsters, but the West has also brought them up. We must not be comfortable. We have to turn on the light. We cannot talk about radicalisation without also talking about Western interventions in the Middle East.

name: Javier Nart (ALDE).
text: – Madam President, I have resolution 2014/ 2843 here with me, paragraph 18 of which mentions that the European Union must criminalise, penalise and prosecute all persons and institutions that trade, finance and logistically support the Islamic State. I submitted two questions on 14 January 2015 to the Commission asking what had been done, what investigation existed, which companies had been investigated and criminalised. The answer is a disgrace, because it's nothing. And when I ask again, I'm still waiting for an answer. Let's move on to a second part: how do militants get to the Islamic State? They arrive through Turkey by the passage from Karkamo to Jarabulus. And my question is this: if we are unable to comply in the European Union with the decisions of the European Parliament , on the part of the Commission , how can we ask Turkey to prevent the passage of militants, in number of more than 5,000, to become Islamic State fighters?

name: Bodil Valero (Verts/ALE).
text: Madam President, I would like to begin by thanking Theresa May for I think we are forgetting a very important factor, or we are talking too little about it, and that is that there is one person behind every terrorist, or behind every person who has been radicalised. In most cases, the terrorists we have seen in Europe have grown up here with us. They were born and adults in Europe, but they have not found meaning in their lives here in Europe. If we have a lot of people around who don't find meaning in life, who might even find that death is more meaningful than life, then we have a big problem. Because you're looking for meaning, you're looking for a community with others. Then it is easy to end up in groups with strong loyalties, strong communities and fighting for something: the good. In these cases, whether it are far-right groups or whether they are Islamist groups or some others, they mean that they stand for the good. We have an enormous responsibility to really look at why people are being radicalised. Why do you choose to believe in death more than in life?

name: Georg Mayer (ENF).
text: Madam President, I would like to thank the president for her We need to recognise where our weaknesses and our cowardice lie, the rapporteur has said. Madam rapporteur, I can help you a little. Because as long as you are not even prepared to identify the heart of the problem, because you seem to be blind to that eye, you will probably not be able to fight the causes for so long. I say this very clearly is not about condemning a religion in generalis. If you are aware of the declaration of the terrorists in Paris – I assume that the rapporteur will know this – then it is particularly naive not to start from a religious background to these terrible acts, but to blame a lack of integration. Ladies and gentlemen, you do not seem to want to deal with the religious core of this problem. What happens next after these attacks in Paris? I assume the timetable will be the same as after Charlie Hebdo. Affected faces will be shown, anointing speeches will be made – and nothing will change.

name: Bruno Gollnisch (NI).
text: Madam President, I hope that Mrs Abiol Guzman will not ask that I be punished by Mr Bush, as she did for a previous speaker. But I would like to join what Mr. Mayer said; we are blind, we do not see that there is indeed a religious dimension in these heinous crimes and it is said that there is no connection with Islam. If, of course, there's a connection. Of course, not all Muslims are terrorists, fortunately! But the current terrorists claim Islam and the reading they make of their sacred book, unfortunately, does not deny their criminal actions.  It must also be said that our responsibility is great to have destroyed the only political force that could oppose radical Islamism, that is, the Arab nationalism that the West and the United States of America destroyed in Iraq, Libya and were about to destroy in Syria. We then see with astonishment, in this void, an identification being constructed that attracts of course the young people of our cities and our suburbs. It has been said that they are French, they probably should never have become French, but that, Mr Niedermoller, is another problem.

name: Tomáš Zdechovský (PPE).
text: – Madam President, Commissioner, after the terrorist attacks in Paris and the current terrorist threat across Europe, now is the time to say frankly that our policy of integration and security is failing. We must no longer close our eyes to the failed integration of migrants, whether they are first, second or third generation migrants. Unmanageable migration is the reason for the radicalisation of these people as well as the reason for their departure from terrorist organisations. I am very happy for this initiative by the European Parliament and I congratulate my colleague Dati for such a comprehensive report, which, in my opinion, contains all aspects of the fight against radicalisation and extremists. Clearly, there is one thing that is clear from this report. Only by working more closely, exchanging information, cooperating with third countries and involving everyone, including our citizens, can we be successful in this fight. The current situation clearly shows us that we are already one step behind. I think 5,000 European citizens on the side of terrorist organisations are sufficient evidence.

name: Iliana Iotova (S&D).
text: Madam President, I am convinced that all of us in this plenary would like this discussion not to be so painfully topical. The report must become an urgent basis for a Commission legislative initiative. The external borders of the Union and, I stress, of the European Union and not only of the Schengen area, must be strengthened in terms of finances and resources. This measure does not deprive citizens of their rights, quite the contrary, since it provides a guarantee of their security.  Secondly, we need road controls for foreign fighters travelling to and from the Middle East, including concrete commitments for joint actions with third countries and especially with Turkey. Emergency measures do not repeal the prevention of radicalization. We can no longer only see that in our own countries, in our own societies, there are lost generations, isolated ghettos, poor without perspective who easily become the victims of radical movements. Do we really have the courage to break stereotypes and have real integration? We must give these young people a future and the confidence that they belong to our world. That's the way to have them by our side. Let us also hope that the efforts of the last few days to form a genuine international grand coalition against Daesh can finally destroy the source of evil as soon as possible.

name: Kazimierz Michał Ujazdowski (ECR).
text: – (Onset of occurrence incomprehensible for technical reasons).  ... cultural issues, in matters of our civilization and courage in working for security. Our christian culture-based civilization is under attack and attacked not by abstract force, but by radical Islam. This must be made clear and not because anyone is discriminated against. Civilizations collapse when they no longer believe in their own values. Please note that in Central Europe, where the model of social life is based on Christian culture, there are no grounds for terrorism.  Finally, the second point: we need the courage to act on security. I call on the Socialists to change their position. We need border control, we need the PNR Directive, but also extraordinary measures, including the expulsion of our own citizens who are responsible for terrorist acts, because citizenship is not the right to destroy society.

name: Laurenţiu Rebega (ENF).
text: – Madam President, after the Paris attacks, a press article has been around the world and reveals the hideous face of terrorism practiced for religious purposes. Specifically, that article presented the revelations of a European citizen of Islamic fundamentalist faith, in the second generation in Europe, who was tired of waiting for a suicide mission.  In his revelations, he accuses the Saudis of favouring their relatives by fronting them for suicide missions. Recall, the character is one born, raised in Europe, who was indoctrinated in fundamentalist communities and turned against the society that welcomed his parents with open arms. Words are superfluous. In this context, I appreciate that the measures required by this report are ones that need to be implemented as a matter of urgency. I believe that it is time for Europe, but also the Member States, to have two packages of essential laws as a matter of urgency to prevent the phenomenon. The first is that of an internet traffic control with the strict aim of identifying and blocking access to the virtual environments that make the propaganda fundamentalist. A second package of laws, with strict addressability, would be necessary to prevent European citizens from accessing the masked financial transfers of funds that ISIS fundamentalists maintain in Europe.

name: Λάμπρος Φουντούλης (
text: NI). Madam President, many people are talking today about how to prevent the recruitment of young people by terrorist organisations. They are the same people who at every opportunity promoted the rise of Islamism, criminalised any reaction and stigmatised those who dared to say the obvious.  The perpetrators of the recent attacks were neither unemployed nor marginalised. One of them even worked in a public service in Belgium. Unemployment and marginalisation cannot in any way be a cause for what has happened. If that were the case, Greece, with almost 60% youth unemployment, would be nothing more than a huge terrorist camp.  These people chose to adopt extremism. The real reason is the acceptance of the sermons of extreme Islamism and the indation that takes place in some mosques, operating with or without the permission of the various governments of Europe, as well as the strong support of Saudi Arabia, which has the doctrine of ouachabism as its official religion.  If you really want to prevent the recruitment of new terrorists in Europe, close down any mosques that embrace such ideas. Also, stop the neo-colonial attacks on countries in the Middle East and the whole world.

name: Barbara Matera (PPE).
text: – Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, I would like to congratulate Mrs Dati, who has worked a complex text that seeks to embrace the articulated aspects of this absurd phenomenon: violent extremism and intolerance are often children of marginalisation and poverty. But these reasons can never justify this violence.  The approximately 5,000 European citizens who have become foreign fighters have demonstrated the failure of integration policies. I do not want to fall into the trivial temptation of the mathematical equation 'refugee = terrorist' but it is essential that in order to enter Europe controls must be strictly strengthened and that all people who migrate to our continent are registered. There can be no security waivers. To this I would add more stringent measures for the processing of online data, the closure of the PNR trialogue with the inclusion of intra-European flights, closer cooperation with social media companies and, not least, the swift conclusion of the reform of Europol. I will end by quoting Article 3 of the Universal Declaration of Human Rights of 1948: 'Everyone has the right to life, freedom and security of his or her person'. Without security there is no freedom. But the opposite is not true.

name: Marju Lauristin (S&D).
text: – I would like to emphasise that this fight, which is currently under way, is, after all, a struggle between values. European culture is being attacked, European values are being attacked, not Christianity, but those European values that come from the French Revolution - freedom, brotherhood and equality - are being attacked, those principles that come from Kant's philosophy, ethics, universal ethics, freedom of choice, and all this is done, yes, under the cover of religion, but it is the same fundamentalism that Europe has even seen.  We remember Nazism, we remember communism, and they were all specifically about the brainwashing of young people, all those terrorist means, etc. We shouldn't be surprised, we should think about the historical experience of how young people are brainwashed. It is easy to beat young people who yearn for the values of others, or who feel bad in their own society, in their own homes, easy to beat with brainwashing. And that is why we should think precisely about how European education, how european media, how to shape relations between us, to make them convincing, trustworthy and honest.  And here I would also like to say that the first victims of this same fight can be ourselves here if we are going to fight each other with the same methods, if we start using these same stereotypes against each other. And that is why I have to say that I was very sad when I saw this campaign, which was started here by one of the parties here against others, in order to win democracy for itself. Democracy can then be won by our own party, democracy wins if we are all allies here, in solidarity with each other, fighting terrorism.

name: Marek Jurek (ECR).
text: – (2) Mr President, I would like to begin by Man is a free being and we are unable to change someone else's thinking. Man, unfortunately, can choose evil. We are able to reduce this phenomenon, and therefore any form of glorification of ISIS activities, glorification of terrorism, justification should be met with a strong legal response. If imams who preach an ideology that supports ISIS are foreigners, they should be expelled immediately, and if not, we should ask ourselves: should people who preach hatred of the society in which they live be treated as its citizens. This is a serious question that we must answer.  On the other hand, we can change the future of our children, but we will not really change it by calling for censorship, as Albiol Guzmán said, for people who criticise the consequences of migration. Or by criticizing politicians who have the courage to defend us, like Prime Minister Orban for example.

name: Gianluca Buonanno (ENF).
text: Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, I apologise, but on my mobile phone I read that there was an attack on Roubaix, probably of Islamic origin, and there are hostages, including children. I just wanted to inform the House.

name: Die Präsidentin. –
text: Thank you for the information. We will see what actually happened and who the authors are.

name: Nicolas Bay (ENF).
text: Madam President, the report presented by Mrs Dati deals with the prevention of radicalisation and the recruitment of EU citizens by terrorist organisations. Our debate today comes ten days after the heinous attacks that bloodied Paris, ten months after those that hit the Charlie Hebdo newspaper and the Hyper Cacher supermarket. In the preamble to this report, you say that radicalization should not be associated with a particular ideology or religion. Yet it is Islamist fanaticism that generates terrorism in Europe and bloodied France. Alas, this denial of reality is characteristic of the blindness of our so-called elites. The French Minister of the Interior said a few months ago, and I quote, that "it is not a crime to advocate jihad". And what a benevolence towards the Islamist gangrene when our Foreign Minister believes that the Al-Nusra Front - that is, Al-Qaeda - is doing a good job, when the report we are debating today calls terrorists combatants or when our colleague Eva Joly believes that they should be given a second chance. It is time to put an end to this angelism, the fight against Islamism cannot be done with green numbers or psychological follow-up sessions! It is time to take the necessary measures: close Salafist mosques and ban Islamist organizations; stripping dual nationals involved in jihadist networks of their nationality; give back real human and material resources to our police, our army, our customs and our intelligence services.  Finally, Commissioner, after a previous debate on terrorism in Europe, you dared to say: 'Schengen is not the problem, it is part of the solution'. Yet it was your sieve Europe that enabled the attacks in Paris; from the island of Lesbos to the enclave of Molenbeek, whether they were born in Europe or not, Islamists circulate freely on our continent. We must therefore start by freeing ourselves from the immigrationist ideology of the European Union and regain control of our borders!

name: Francesc Gambús (PPE).
text: – Madam President, Commissioner, France and Europe have been attacked. In the face of the great threat looming over us, there is no other possible response than the unity of the European Union. We must respond jointly and seamlessly to the attack we have all suffered in Paris, Bamako, Beirut, Nigeria, Tunisia and, this very afternoon, in Roubaix. We must work together with the international community to find a solution to the "uncivil" conflict in Syria and the rest of the region to restore security and peace in Syria, rooting out ISIS terrorism.  Clearly, we must work tirelessly to prevent the radicalisation of citizens living in the European Union, using the necessary and essential integration measures as the first line of prevention as a priority, and the Dati report is moving forward with a decision in this area.  But it is also necessary and inevitable to have a joint structure, to deepen police cooperation, and for this to lead us to a European federal police that can be eligible for a European penal code, which is already provided for in the Lisbon Treaty, and, in the same sense, we must be able to make further progress on common policies, such as the common asylum policy or the common immigration policy , and give a true sense of state to the policy of cooperation and development. Throughout our history, Europe has had to battle barbarism and nonsense on many occasions, but Europe has always managed to remain, evolving as far as we are today.  Let us make it clear, once again, that they will not defeat us; we will fight against all those who threaten our security and freedom. Europe and democracy will endure; not the terrorists.

name: Juan Fernando López Aguilar (S&D).
text: – Madam President, Commissioner, you said that this is a timely debate, and it is. What is not appropriate is to mix it with a debate about aliens, immigration or refugees. No: it is a debate about what Europe can do to prevent European citizens from being recruited by terrorist organisations. And the added value is that we learn to intervene the contents in the network that instiment violent extremism; where we learn to intervene also the socialization of terror in prisons; where we learn to prevent not only arms trafficking, through these sophisticated means, but the financing of such indoctrination in terrorism; and freeze their assets, and do so on European scale. But also that we learn to cooperate police to share information about those 5,000 Europeans who have entered and left after being trained for terrorism somewhere abroad; but also that we report that austerity and the collapse of education, inclusion and integration policies in marginalized and particularly vulnerable neighbourhoods have made many young Europeans, many European-born citizens, willing to embark on this crazy spiral of destructive and self-destructive violence, and declare themselves willing not only to kill but to die killing. This is the challenge we have to solve and I hope that the Dati report will bring European-scale added value to this more necessary European response than ever before.

name: Pál Csáky (PPE).
text: – I welcome this document, even though I did not think it would become up-to-date so quickly. We must also be aware of the fact that the European Union has only limited opportunities to operate in various areas, as key areas such as the judiciary, the enforcement of punishment, the protection of the EU's external borders, internal security, as well as the implementation of educational programmes fall within the competence of the Member States. I would like to highlight the main moment, which I think is most important in terms of the success of these activities: the need for sincere and effective cooperation between the Member States and the Union institutions. We have to realize that we are reliant on each other. Any individual games can only reduce the level of success of the whole. The current situation wants us to have flexible systems for exchanging information between security forces, including information services. Europol's powers must also be strengthened and information from their system provided to the national authorities. It is necessary to actively speak out against aggressive preachers, and I also agree with the idea that every foreign fighter should be brought under adequate supervision upon returning to his country on the basis of a court decision. We must also not forget about effective educational projects. We have a significant delay in this area. Finally, financial flows for international terrorism must finally be made impossible.

name: Ismail Ertug (S&D).
text: Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, I would like to thank the rapporteur for her excellent report and for the way in which she has been rapporteur for her excellent report and for the First of all, I would like to express my regret that the inhuman racists on the right here in our House equate 1.7 billion Muslims with terrorists. This is not only factually wrong, but also extremely shabby. This is the debate on the prevention of radicalisation, and I believe that we should certainly be mindful of the mistakes of the past, but also think about the future. I think that an important aspect – and I will call it social empathy – is ultimately crucial and means that we must also be recognised and accepted by those members of society in their individuality.  Appreciation of the cultural background is, in my view, crucial. The society that ultimately cannot do so automatically excludes it, and a strong society must be able to do without prohibitions. That is why we must take a strict approach to hostility – both against the terrorists and against the racists – and all the points that have already been mentioned are good steps in the right direction. But we should not forget that we are dealing with people who, with the increasing empathy of the majority society, will again regard these countries, where they grew up and grew up, as their own.

name: Christine Revault D'Allonnes Bonnefoy (S&D).
text: Madam President, in the face of the tragic terrorist attacks in the European Union and beyond, we must take strong measures to ensure the safety of Europeans. But we must also address the roots of violent radicalisation affecting young Europeans of all social backgrounds.  This is the purpose of this report and the group of the Progressive Alliance of Socialists and Democrats has contributed greatly to this. We call for the development and financing of preventive and long-term policies, first at school, in neighbourhoods, but also on the Internet, with a mobilization of all. Actors on the ground, such as associations and educators, must be provided with resources, training to work with the populations most sensitive to hate speech and to detect signs of violent radicalisation as soon as possible. It is also important to help families, especially through telephone reporting and listening platforms. Finally, internet companies must commit to doing more to erase hate messages inciting terrorism.  But let's be responsible and avoid dangerous amalgams. On the one hand, it is the misrevoising of religion and never religion itself that can lead to violent radicalization and, on the other hand, refugees are not guilty of terrorism, they are the first victims.

name: Caterina Chinnici (S&D).
text: – Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, the terrible events in Paris, the events in France this evening and the events currently involving Brussels must lead us to carefully analyze the causes that lead certain European citizens to join terrorist organisations. The bombers were young people with European passports. It is therefore essential to undertake a thorough reflection on the policies of socio-cultural integration if we are to prevent such incidents. Prevention, in fact, is a word that has in itself the idea of arriving earlier and we must arrive first: before social exclusion, before radicalization, before hatred, before further tragedies occur.  There is also no doubt that cooperation between judicial authorities and Eurojust must be strengthened at European level in order to speed up the detection of terrorist suspects, just as the speed of the exchange of information between national law enforcement authorities and Europol must be improved.  Mr Dati's report basically emphasises the need to act and act together, without division, in order to initiate a constant dialogue on the prevention of radicalisation and for a concrete sharing of information to combat the recruitment of young citizens by terrorist organisations.

name: Bogusław Liberadzki (S&D).
text: – Madam President, i voted in favour of the report by Mrs Schwab Radicalism, terrorism are not entirely new. In history, we've seen this. Now it is done on an extremely large scale, using, of course, modern technologies. Our core values are at stake, that is tolerance, as well as freedom of movement, and finally technological achievements. Let us remember that among the terrorist bombers are mainly citizens of the European Union, living here. Those who shot in Paris did not ask who is Muslim, who is a Christian. They were just shooting at everyone who was within their reach.  Preventive action is crucial: not to tolerate incitement to radicalism, to control the network, to strengthen citizens' awareness and their propensity to cooperate with the police. Key issues: eliminate or limit the funding opportunities for radicalism. Here's the problem. Finally, we simply need more Union, more Community method.

name: Die Präsidentin. –
text: We now come to the catch-the-eye procedure. I will proceed in such a way that I take one person from each group, especially those who have not spoken in this debate or before. Catch-the-eye procedure

name: Michaela Šojdrová (PPE).
text: – Madam President, it is our duty to ensure security and to combat all causes of violence and hatred. At European Union level, we must learn from the risks of a multicultural society. The risks of ghettos, excluded localities, poorly educated and unemployed generations of young people who do not have a life perspective and who are at great risk because they are disappointed are looking for the content of their lives. That is why we are proposing a number of practical measures against radicalisation in prisons. Better internet control, better education and work with vulnerable youth. We need more effective work by Eurojust, linking internal and external security instruments.  But I don't think any of this will be enough if there are more people frustrated and disappointed, who are then easy prey to a radical sect. But Europe is built on Christian foundations, and we should not give up our values. We should insist on a combination of freedom and responsibility, solidarity and security.

name: Hilde Vautmans (ALDE).
text: Many people have said it here today: the timing of this debate cannot be more topical, a week after Paris and at a time when we in Belgium and in Brussels are facing a very great threat. I would like to repeat Mr Deprez's question: not all focus is on Brussels and Molenbeek. Every EU country is confronted with radicalised young people. So please let's not be a black man, let's take action.  Frankly, as a mother of two small children, it is very difficult for me to understand why these Young Europeans are going to Syria to go to war there that is not theirs. So let us focus on prevention. Let us intervene. Let us give more resources to local authorities. Let us step up the fight against racism and discrimination, and penalise young people who have returned very severely. They belong in prison. Only in this way, with more European cooperation, can we live in freedom and without fear.

name: Nicola Caputo (S&D).
text: Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, today's debate takes on particular significance following the attacks in Paris. Indeed, the tragic events of the last few days have put Europe even more dramatically in the face of the problem of the recruitment of citizens by terrorist organisations and the need to prevent radicalisation. These are men, women and, above all, young European citizens of all social origins who have in common a feeling of break with society and who pose a threat to security in Europe as elsewhere. But the phenomenon of radicalisation and subsequent recruitment must be combated, in addition to repression, with effective prevention policies, establishing an intercultural dialogue with the different religious communities, strengthening the exchange of information between countries of the Union and aiming to target money laundering that finances criminal and terrorist networks. Extremism, radicalisation and the recruitment of terrorists within the Union can only really be defeated if we are able to balance an uncompromising policy of combating terrorism with the implementation of an effective strategy of integration and social inclusion with those who are not terrorists.

name: Νότης Μαριάς (
text: ECR). Madam President, jihadist terrorism in Europe needs both political and ideological treatment. The close relationship between Daesh and Turkey is confirmed daily, as there is a growing number of reports in the international press demonstrating Turkey's support for the jihadists, not only in Syria, but also in Libya.  At the same time, Turkey's involvement in Syria exacerbates the crisis, because under the pretext of dealing with Daesh it is finally bombing the Kurds. It is worth noting that the jihadists have coverage from Turkey's secret services as it has been viewed by a video channel showing Turkish MIT doing business with the jihadists.  In conclusion, Madam President, I would like to point out once again the recent confirmation of Turkish involvement in the ship, loaded with weapons and bullets, heading for a jihadist enclave in Libya, having sailed from the Turkish coast until it was stopped by the port authorities of Crete.  In order to deal effectively with Daesh, the European Union must stop blinding Turkey.

name: Javier Couso Permuy (GUE/NGL).
text: – Madam President, in these matters we must not respond with hot blood: shortcuts are not worth it. The 11-M we learned in Spain: 193 dead; 1,858 wounded.  In Europe, military exits are not worthwhile in the face of asymmetric threats; it's not worth xenophobic or Islamophobic simplification. We must remember: ending the destabilizing agendas that were used in places like Iraq, Libya and Syria. We must review the alliances on the ground: with the Gulf countries, which finance or transmit Wahhabi or Takfirí hatred, and with Turkey, which allows smuggling.  We must not abandon the rule of law in the face of intelligence failures. We also need to combat asymmetry on the other side of the Mediterranean and also in our own neighbourhoods, because only with stability and justice will there be security.

name: Bill Etheridge (EFDD).
text: – Madam President, recently I attended an interfaith event in Birmingham in the West Midlands of England, which is within my constituency. The heading for the event was ‘Love for all, hate for none’, and it was organised by the Muslim community there, but there were Sikhs, Hindus, Jews, Christians and some of no faith, all coming together to unite behind civilised values, to respect the rule of law, to respect democracy, to love the country in which we all live and to actually stand up for something decent and good. There is no need for any one particular section of the community to be generalised as being the problem here. Judge people on their merits. If you find that people are good, that is great. If you find that they support the barbaric evil of ISIS, they must be fought; they must be beaten and stopped in their tracks for good.

name: Gianluca Buonanno (ENF).
text: Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, I wanted to update my fellow Members: it seems that what is happening in Roubaix is a robbery. But I wanted to stress one thing about this debate, Mr President. How can we in Europe make the more than 500 million inhabitants of our continent believe that we are so attentive to Islamic terrorism? But look at this House, you look at that! Is this Europe's way of discussing Islamic terrorism? What is happening on this continent where European policies are destroying our civilisation? As far as the Islamists are concerned – of course we must not all put on an equal footing, we would miss something else – those who behave well are welcome. But those who behave badly, those who do not want to abide by our rules, our civilisation, must leave! Turkey is a country that cannot come to Europe. These people who learn Isis are bastards and they all have to die!

name: Dimitris Avramopoulos
text: Member of the Commission. – Madam President, I would like to express my thanks for the fruitful discussion we have had in this House at a very timely moment. It has focused on one of the root causes of the problem – not on everything – and where the solution should come from as well. In our collective effort to address this issue and to fight radicalisation, we must by all means avoid stigmatising any community, any ethnicity or origin, whether they are Muslims, refugees or migrants. As I said, and as many of you repeated, almost all the perpetrators of the recent attacks on European soil were home-grown, and religion – any religion – has nothing to do with their acts. Radicalism has. Fanaticism has. Hate has. Relating terrorism to migration is stirring up hatred and leads to a vicious circle. I am really glad and proud to participate in a discussion in a Parliament where Members from the whole democratic spectrum defend our values of respect, tolerance and acceptance. I would also like to praise Mr Kirkhope’s intervention. I hope that common sense will prevail in our working together to face the common threats. To do this we have different means, on which the Commission has been working for months, to put at the disposal of all Member States: exchange of information, closer cooperation among law enforcement authorities and agencies, a stronger legal framework against terrorism and detection of terrorist threats, effective management of the external borders, stricter rules on firearms, and targeted cooperation with key third countries. But the basis of an effective response is addressing its roots, and that is the central subject of today’s debate: countering radicalisation, both in the real world and the virtual world, both by legislation and through schemes of cooperation with the private sector, both at local level and with the exchange of best practices among Member States – and all this calmly and firmly, without demonising anybody. Madame la rapporteure – pouvez-vous lui transmettre ce que je viens de dire? –, chers collègues du Parlement, je vous remercie pour ce débat.  Notre travail n'est pas encore terminé, mais nous sommes unis dans notre lutte contre la radicalisation et ses conséquences.

name: Die Präsidentin. –
text: Briefly for information. Mrs Dati informed us that she had to leave. She used up her six minutes at the beginning. She had to leave because she had to look after her daughter. That is why she is no longer here. The debate is closed. The vote will take place on Wednesday, 25 November 2015. Ladies and gentlemen, before I get to the next item on the agenda, let me say briefly that I hope that the hostage-taking that is currently taking place in Roubaix – according to information we have from the media – will come to a good end, that there are no more wounded and hopefully no more dead, and that this situation will soon come to a safe end and hopefully there will be no new attack by ISIS or anyone else. Written declarations (Article 162 OF the CRP)

name: Hugues Bayet (S&D)
text: In writing. The tragic events in Paris require a plural response that is both safe and preventive. This report addresses several important aspects in this regard. In terms of prevention, it stresses the need for internet service providers to work together with the authorities, but also on the role of education, social policies and actions in neighbourhoods. It also stresses, both preventive and repressive, the absolute need to increase Member States' cooperation in the collection and exchange of intelligence, including tools such as SIS II, VIS or ECRIS. States must feed these databases in order to maximize the effectiveness of combating these barbaric acts. I also supported the amendment calling, in view of the current situation, for the urgent strengthening of controls at the external borders of the Schengen area. This reinforcement and the exchange of information are essential if we are to maintain the Schengen area and ensure the security of our citizens.

name: Κώστας Χρυσόγονος (
text: GUE/NGL), in writing. – The report entitled 'Preventing the radicalisation and recruitment of European citizens by terrorist organisations' we have discussed today suggests conceptual confusion, since there is a commonly accepted definition of terrorism. Moreover, the interpretation of the term radicalisation as an antechamber of terrorism is a denig of radicalism, i.e. differentiation from traditional political attitudes.  The real problem is the willingness of a few thousand fanatics to murder massively and indiscriminately political opponents and unsuspecting civilians to intimidate and subjugate entire societies to their paranoid ideology. In the long term, the effective way to combat jihadism is not to censor the internet, but to show constant respect for international law, especially by large Western countries.  The starting point for the creation of the "Islamic State" was the intervention of the "alliance of the willing" in Iraq in 2003 in violation of the UN Charter and the "radicalisation" of the Sunnis. It is therefore a question of stigmatising illegal violence in all its manifestations so that we can hope to gradually de-confess it to people's consciences and ultimately to end it.

name: Mireille D'Ornano (ENF)
text: In writing. The development of Islamic terrorist organisations is the main cause of concern for European judicial and intelligence services on the territory of the Union. However, this report hides its face and refuses to name the main danger today for the safety of our citizens. The fight against radicalisation is above all the closure of the channels that fuel terrorism: uncontrolled borders allowing the free movement of malevolent individuals and weapons on our territory and foreign financing sometimes by powers with which the Union is allied. In this context, the European Union is acting as an arsonist and the report before us is not up to the challenge. Judicial laxity, the resignation of elites in culture, education and social cohesion, and the reckless encouragement of communitarianism are the factors of tension that lead to confrontations within the youth of Europe. How many more young people will go to Syria to wage jihad, massacre Christians and then return to Europe to finish their work? How many more families will be torn apart before the European political class wakes up?

name: Kinga Gál (PPE)
text: Writing. – The terrorist attacks in Paris have made it clear that the European Union must act in the fight against terrorism and to prevent the radicalisation of EU citizens. While the fight against radicalisation remains primarily a matter for the Member States, a coordinated European approach is needed. It is estimated that more than 5 000 European citizens have travelled to Iraq and Syria with the aim of undergoing training by terrorist organisations. This poses a real security threat to the whole of Europe. The Paris attacks have shown that the immigration and integration policy so far is bleeding from multiple wounds as second- and third-generation immigrants leave for Syria and become radicalized. These young people grew up and grew up in the heart of Europe's big cities, Paris, Brussels.  All this questions the western European model of education and integration and shows their failure. Punitive measures alone are no longer sufficient. The EU needs a new strategy based on prevention. According to information provided by European law enforcement authorities and intelligence services, effective prevention of radicalisation should start where recruiting appears.

name: Philippe Juvin (PPE)
text: In writing. We will vote on this report on the prevention of radicalisation in a period that requires concrete and urgent action by Member States in a coordinated way to prevent radicalisation and combat terrorism. To this end, the report proposes the establishment of a blacklist of jihadists, better judicial control of foreign fighters, administrative detention upon their return to Europe and the confiscation of passports and the freezing of the financial assets of potential foreign fighters. With regard to borders, mandatory and systematic control must be put in place at the EU's external borders as well as an exchange of information between states and with Europol concerning suspected terrorists. Finally, the report stresses the need to address the prevention of the spread of extremism, including separating radicalized prisoners from other prisoners in prisons.

name: Marlene Mizzi (S&D)
text: in writing. – We were all shocked at the tragic attacks on the 13 November in Paris. These terrorist attacks aim at dividing our society and planting the seed of fear. And it is fear that stops us from living and upholding our values. And those values are liberty, equality and fraternity.  The fact that all the terrorists were European citizens has painfully demonstrated once again the immediate security threat deriving from radicalisation and recruitment of EU citizens by terrorist organisations and ‘foreign fighters’. Europe is facing a different kind of threat – the phenomenon of ‘home-grown’ radicalisation. The increasing number of European terrorist ‘foreign fighters’, with more than 5 000 young Europeans being part of terrorist organisations, highlights the immediate need to reinforce policy measures against radicalisation and religious fundamentalism, but also the need to understand this new phenomenon. Therefore, I ask: what went wrong and why have radicalisation and religious fundamentalism succeeded in turning young Europeans into weapons?  Radicalisation is a serious threat to internal security and the fight against it requires a common long-lasting strategy from the international community, EU-wide cooperation networks and coordination between Member States.

name: Krystyna Łybacka (S&D)
text: I would like to write to the Commission. – Preventing radicalisation is one of the key challenges of modern Europe. Social inequalities, the marginalisation of certain social groups, social exclusion or lack of access to quality education and training foster radicalisation and recruitment of European citizens by terrorist organisations. Young people with a need to identify and belong are particularly vulnerable to extremist rhetoric, so it is very important to focus their efforts on supporting young people in building their sense of value and community and to gain greater understanding for a multicultural and multinational society. We must help young people, through education and in cooperation with their families and teachers, to develop critical thinking skills, to distinguish facts from propaganda, to understand the methods of operation of terrorist organisations. Greater emphasis should also be placed on lifelong training and informal and non-formal learning programmes, which can both help prevent radicalisation as well as deradicalisation. It is necessary to implement prevention and counter-radicalisation programmes for parents whose children may be vulnerable to recruitment and for professional groups such as m.in. teachers, educators, police officers and prison officers who have direct contact with persons at risk of radicalisation.

name: Urmas Paet (ALDE)
text: Writing. – European societies must be able to avoid panic and not let their daily lives be overly affected, despite the increased terrorist threat. Today's state of emergency in Brussels is a problematic example of how criminals manage to correct the agenda of millions of people.  The biggest problem with Europe's internal security is the criminals who are EU citizens who have been involved in ISIL's activities in the Middle East and their like-minded associates. EU countries must provide in their law as a serious criminal offence to travel for the purpose of planning or implementing an act of terrorism. Foreign fighters who are european citizens who move to and from ISIL are a major security risk to Europe, as at some point some of these people will return to Europe with new connections, skills and radical extremist ideas. It is time to finally stop looking past this problem and cannot let these people disturb the peace of millions.

name: Claude Rolin (PPE)
text: In writing. How many bereaved families, how many minutes of silence, broken by the sound of bombs, will we still have to respect, before the end of this global guerrilla war founded by terrorism is put to an end? On Friday, November 13, Paris, a city of light, lived through dark times. Paris, a symbol of love and freedom, was touched in the heart, once again, echoing the other places of the world struck by the blind and absurd hatred of a terrorist organization that has no state and Islamic but the name it has given itself. Faced with the pool of violence, in the East as in the West, in the face of fear-in-the-run people, the time is now more than ever for unity. Europe must unite to uproot the radicalism that is sweeping through some of our homes. If information sharing and coordinated actions are to be the rule, if this sad era is to signify the emergence of a genuine and necessary European defence, the answer cannot be content to be safe, because the breeding ground of fanaticism is interfering in all the gaps, social, cultural, economic, that our society reveals on its soil. In the name of freedom, fraternity and equality, dear to France and humanists alike, we will stand.

name: Die Präsidentin. –
text: The next item on the agenda is the joint debate on – the report by Edouard Martin on behalf of the Committee on Industry, Research and Energy on the development of a sustainable European industry of base metals (2014/2211(INI)) (A8-0309/2015) and the Commission statement on anti-dumping measures and their impact on the EU steel industry (2015/2978(RSP)).

name: Edouard Martin
text: Rapporteur. Madam President, Commissioner, ladies and gentlemen, we are indeed approaching this report in an extremely complicated context, since, as you all know, Europe is the victim of a massive importation of steel, in particular from Russia and especially from China, at prices that defy all competition. That is one of the questions I will ask the Commissioner later.  To put this debate in the current context, I recall that, in eleven months, the price of the slab has been halved. So you can imagine that some countries are now able to produce steel below cost prices. The report deals with the sustainable development of base metal production, and I wanted to give it this title to cut short all the fantasies of each other, and those who told us that we had to choose between industry and respect for the environment. I am very keen, through this report, to demonstrate that both are possible: to keep the industry strong on European territory, the production of base metals, while respecting the environment, of course. But to do that, you need the means, you have to invest. Since the 2008 crisis, However, Europe has suffered from a lack of investment, which has, in fact, an impact on competitiveness but also on the environment.
