This is what I would like Europe, which the European Parliament, on the eve of COP21, to be able to defend through urgent decisions, although Europe is the continent that continues to defend both the environment and industry.  I would just like to point out, to give you an idea, that to produce one tonne of steel in Europe, we emit two tonnes of CO2. The same tonne of steel produced on average in China emits three tonnes of CO2. Therefore, this is not about protectionism, it is just about fairness. Today, the situation is very serious. It is all the more serious because it can sound the death knell for our industry. I say it can sound the death knell for our industry. Today, if we look at the figures for China, we see that china has 350 million tonnes of steel production overcapacity. European consumption is equivalent to 170 million tonnes. Therefore, you can imagine that with the decline of the Chinese economy, this country will try, indeed, through a much more offensive policy, through dumping and public aid, to sell this overcapacity of steel production. The consequences, we know them: it is the closure of Redcar in Great Britain, it is several thousand job cuts at Tata Steel, it is several measures of partial unemployment announced all over France, Spain, Italy, etc.  The real substantive question that is being asked collectively to each other and which I am asking you, Mrs Bie-kowska, and I thank you for being here this evening, is: "Do we still want an industry at European level?" Because I'm telling you, it's a matter of life and death and you have to move very fast. It can go very fast. We don't have to wait six months or three months anymore, we have to take action as of January 1, 2016 if we want to keep this industry.  To sum up some of the strengths of my report, I do advocate using trade defence instruments in a somewhat more offensive way against anti-dumping measures, anti-subsidy measures. This measure of fairness is carbon adjustment at the borders, because there is no question of charging the right to pollute only European industrialists and turning a blind eye to all imports that come to us from elsewhere. When I say elsewhere, it is China, Russia and Brazil. This is not just a target against Chinese steels. That is the possibility - because here too the industrialists tell us that they need visibility, especially in terms of energy contracts - that can be given to them to sign long-term contracts. Then, it is actually compensating for the indirect costs of CO2.  I would remind you that this report is not just that of Edward Martin, even though it bears my name. We visited ten European countries. Each time, we have met with business leaders, local elected officials, trade union organisations and NGOs and, with a few exceptions, everyone agrees that it is time for Europe to defend its industry more firmly today through these measures, which are shared by the collective as a whole. As recently as last week, IndustriAll, the European Federation of Metallurgical and Steel Trade Unions, effectively validated its support for the report.

name: Elżbieta Bieńkowska
text: Member of the Commission. – Madam President, thank you very much again for giving the Commission the opportunity to address Parliament on this extremely important topic of the European steel industry, which is also extremely important for us and for me personally. Let me start with the own-initiative report by Mr Martin on developing a sustainable European industry in base metals. The Commission welcomes the interest of the European Parliament and the work that has already been done. The report offers a very interesting perspective for the current debate on how to support the sector, something that is really vital for our economy. The report also highlights fundamental issues that have been at the centre of the Commission’s report. These include energy – including both energy supply and the design of the energy market – fair trade and climate policy, with a view to reducing emissions while taking competitiveness into account. It also gives some interesting proposals, and I can assure you we will think about them and try to come back to you with some solutions. These policy areas are also among the Commission’s top priorities and are included in our main initiatives like the Energy Union, the follow-up to the Trade and Investment Strategy and fostering a stronger and high-performing industrial base. The Commission created a high-level group on energy-intensive industries to tackle challenges together with all the stakeholders and Member States concerned. We look forward to continuing the dialogue with the European Parliament on the topic of the metal industries as well as on many related policies, which are also extremely important. I also wanted to mention that the Luxembourg Presidency has paid great attention to the metal industries and called an extraordinary Competitiveness Council on 9 November to discuss the specific situation of the steel industry. Let me now address the use of the trade defence instruments in the steel sector, which are the competence of Commissioner Malmström, but I am also very much involved in finding solutions in this area. To address the current crisis facing the European steel sector, the Commission is willing to use the trade defence instruments to the full legal extent. We will open an investigation into every product on which we received a complaint with sufficient evidence of dumping and subsidisation causing injury to our industry. In this context, the Commission is also willing to consider opening investigations based on the threat of injury. However, the legislative requirements for a case based on threat of injury are really demanding. There has only ever been one case in which measures were imposed on this basis, a case currently subject to court proceedings. The Commission is also ready to begin the registration of imports in investigations with a view to the retroactive application of duties where this is warranted and the legal standards are met. The registration of imports could ensure that the situation of the European industry does not further deteriorate. As regards opening cases, there is nothing to be gained from this time-wise, as it still requires the existence of sufficient evidence, and this can only be furnished by the industry. Trade defence action is triggered by applications from industry. This should remain the case, given that only industry is in a position to know the state of the market and the effects of imports. With regard to imposing measures more quickly, the most important step will be the agreement by the co-legislators on the Commission’s modernisation proposals, which are already on the table. Given that this is a legal process subject to scrutiny not only by the Member States but also by the courts – and in some instances the WTO – time is needed to ensure that any action taken is in line with the legislation and our international obligations. I am looking forward to your remarks.

name: Krišjānis Kariņš
text: Mr President, Commissioner, ladies and gentlemen, i would like to thank the – Madam President, Commissioner, i would like to begin by congratulating the rapporteur on her excellent work. In Europe, we have set a very noble, correct target of reducing CO2 emissions. At the same time, however, we are aware that in Europe we are in a world of competition, and perhaps this objective that we have set is somewhat at odds with our need to maintain our competitiveness in the world.  I will talk specifically about one industry: the steel industry. We know that the steel industry is not from clean industries. We know that. However, our steel industry employs a total of around 300 000 people in Europe, and in general we are the world's second largest producer after China. So if this industry becomes uncompetitive, we will also use steel when buying it from elsewhere.  The car industry, shipbuilding, building construction – steel is absolutely everywhere in our lives. So there is a request to the Commission, looking at what you are doing, particularly with the emissions trading scheme, to carefully weigh up the target of reducing CO2 emissions, as well as the need to keep European industry in Europe. Driving out will not reduce its output, but will only increase unemployment in Europe. Thanks for the attention!

name: Dan Nica
text: on behalf of the S&D Group – Commissioner, I congratulate our colleague, Édouard Martin, and the shadow rapporteur on his work in drafting this report on the European base metals industry. I believe that we all agree on the timing and importance of this document, both in the context of the current situation in the Member States and in the case of the revision of the ETS. High prices in Europe and dumping by third countries result in rapid deindustrialisation of the steel sector. The employment rate in this area decreased by 20% compared to 2007, and demand for steel produced in the European Union decreased by 28%. Ironically, Commissioner, many decades ago those who built the foundation of the European Union started with coal and steel. We risk very quickly, perhaps even during your term of office, to talk about steel that is no longer produced in the European Union and about coal that has already become history. The State aid compensation scheme for indirect costs has given rise to a new source of unfair competition in the European Union single market between producers whose activity is based on the massive use of electricity. I believe that this compensation should be harmonised and granted at European level in order to ensure a level playing field against global competitors and European producers, and to also ensure effective protection against carbon restresses. Steel is not, moreover, the only sector facing significant problems, several industrial sectors in the European Union are suffering from global overproduction, low prices and behaviour that distorts honest walking. In view of the situation in the steel industry at European level, but in particular the urgent situation in some Member States, the Commission should explain why existing anti-dumping measures are not properly applied and why they are not effective. Finally, I stress that the European Union needs a strong, competitive industry and quality jobs. That is my message to you, Commissioner.

name: Ashley Fox
text: on behalf of the ECR Group. – Mr President, the steel industry is important for our economy, providing employment for thousands of our constituents. Demand for steel is still 25% below pre-crisis levels, yet Chinese exports have risen by 28% this year alone. Excess supply has flooded our markets, often sold at a loss. Many countries around the world have reacted to this threat, including the United States, India and Brazil. Sadly, the EU has not. This month’s meeting of EU Ministers, called by the UK Business Secretary Sajid Javid, showed strong agreement on the need to take concrete action. These problems also extend beyond the steel sector. Since 2007, despite rising demand for aluminium, 11 of the 24 smelters in the EU have shut down. EU climate policies are at fault here, hurting competitiveness, raising prices and ultimately driving industry out of Europe. I do not believe the Carbon Border Adjustment Mechanism proposed by Mr Martin in his report is the answer. I fear it will invite retaliation and encourage protectionism around the world. I suspect it would be as successful as extending the ETS to the airline sector proved to be. The steel sector now needs action, not proposals that have no prospect of success. I would ask the Commissioner to explain what she is going to do to support the industry and combat the anti-competitive practices it faces.

name: Angelika Mlinar
text: Mr President, I would like to like to take a iendled with the ALDE Group. Mr President, I would like to thank the First of all, I would like to stress the importance of this report and thank you for the good cooperation, especially with the rapporteur. The base metal industry in Europe, especially the steel industry, is in a very critical state. A variety of factors contribute to the further decline in the competitiveness of this sector, while costs continue to rise. We must be aware of the seriousness of the situation and create a competitive environment for this sector in Europe. These include, in particular, driving the modernisation of industry in Europe, facilitating access to new markets, bringing about the completion of the Energy Union and using and modernising trade policy instruments. However, one of the most important challenges in the near future will be the reform of the European emissions trading system, which we are currently dealing with in Parliament. Here we face two difficult tasks: on the one hand, the fight against climate change and the transition to a low carbon economy, on the other hand, the competitiveness of the global market and the viability of our industry. However, I believe that we need to see these problems in a broader context and also to resolve them. In our view, this report is not the right instrument for this. We are currently at a critical stage with regard to ETS in particular. Firstly, the global climate summit in Paris begins next week, which I hope will finally lead to a breakthrough at international level. Secondly, the legislative process for reforming the fourth stage of the ETS is under way in Parliament. I therefore see major problems with a report such as this, which both contains detailed reform proposals for ETS and calls for alternative instruments such as CO2 frontier levies, although these are clearly not desired by industry. Instead of creating even more confusion in an already difficult situation, we should concentrate on the essentials: the legislative implementation of a functioning ETS reform in a separate report and the strengthening of competitiveness for the industry of base metals.

name: Paloma López Bermejo
text: GUE/NGL Group. – Mr President, thank you to the rapporteur for the work and cooperation we have been able to maintain. The metal industry is a strategic sector whose problems are those of the European industry as a whole. We need an industry that minimizes its environmental impact, that dumps territories and is capable of generating quality employment. To this end, the European Union must develop a real industrial policy that does not take competition policy as dogma but implements it in favour of the cohesion and employment objectives set out in the Treaties. Public investment and planning are necessary for European regions to maintain their industry and not to be abandoned to seasonal and speculative sectors. It is also essential for emission reduction that a global regulatory framework be developed and environmental dumping is fought, and that mass deind industrialization of traditional production areas in Europe be prevented from being used for production expansion in countries with lower emissions and labour rights standards. The metal sector is central to Europe and has a great future ahead of it with the right technological innovation, which makes us the cleanest industry in the world, the development of recycling and the circular economy in reconversion industrial areas, and improvements in energy efficiency. Only a real future-oriented economy can help overcome the present crisis and create quality jobs. This report is a small step in supporting this sector, which must not fail to be the true heart of European industry.

name: Claude Turmes
text: au nom du groupe Verts/ALE. – Monsieur le Président, je remercie d'abord M. Martin pour son rapport et je crois personnellement que l'instrument d'ajustement aux frontières est un bon instrument. Frankly, neither climate policy nor the general electricity prices in Europe are a problem today for the steel industry. British prices for electricity are twice as high as in Germany and in Scandinavia: twice as high. This has much more to do with splendid isolation and the fact that the British market is not interconnected with Europe, because in Scandinavia and in Germany power prices are much lower. So we should stop blaming the European climate and energy policy. The problem we have in Europe with steel is that demand has broken down. That has to do with the Lehman Brothers crisis and our overstretched austerity politics in Europe. When people buy fewer goods, when we underinvest in infrastructure, then we do not create a steep demand for steel, and that is the problem. We have to have a reinvestment strategy for Europe. The second issue is then, of course, how we deal with China and its huge overcapacity. The question to the Commission, but also I think to our British colleagues, is: who is advocating giving China market economy status? The Commission wants to give it, Cameron wants to give it, but then the question is: how do we organise anti-dumping if we give market status to the Chinese economy?

name: David Borrelli
text: Mr President, president, ladies and gentlemen, i.e. the european Union, the European Union and its Member States are Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, I should like to begin by thanking the rapporteur, Mr Martin, for his work and for his commitment to the drafting of the report on the European base metals industry. I am pleased to see in the final text the reference to harmonisation of indirect costs at European level. I am also pleased with the reference to environmental protection, compliance with occupational safety and hygiene directives and increased attention to local populations.  However, the European steel industry is asking us to take immediate action, especially to take measures against imports from China which, with a production overcapacity of 340 million tonnes, is invading the European market at rock-bottom prices. The conclusions of the Competitiveness Council of 9 November are not satisfactory. That is also why I have tabled an oral question to the European Commission asking what it intends to do in the immediate future and whether it is considering taking timely action, such as implementing countermeasures based on consumption and the actual amount of CO2 emitted during production. These measures would be fully compatible with European industrial, trade and climate policies and could immediately ensure greater global competitiveness. It must be clear that the European Parliament is seriously concerned about the devastating consequences that any recognition of China's market economy status would have on European industry, particularly manufacturing industry. We talk about steel, wood, glass, chemistry, textiles, footwear, ceramics, paper, bicycles and more. I therefore call for the Committees on Industry and International Trade to be regularly involved in this debate from now on. We are opposed to unconditional and automatic recognition, because it is clear that China does not meet the five criteria laid down by the European Union, such as the absence of state intervention in business privatisation operations and the existence of a state-independent financial sector.  We believe that, faced with such a serious choice, one year after the deadline, the citizens should be able to know a clear position of the European Commission, which, at the moment, is only confused and late.

name: Barbara Kappel
text: Mr President, I would like to like to take a iendled with the ENF Group. Mr President, Commissioner, I would like to thank the commissioner for her work and for the work she has done. The president of the World Steel Association, the Austrian Wolfgang Eder, who is also the CEO of Austria's largest steel company, spoke out last weekend about why Austria's steel production site is wobbling. Voestalpine has an annual turnover of 11.2 billion euros, employs 47,500 people, 23,000 of them in Austria, and has already invested 550 million euros this year in the construction of a direct reduction plant in Texas. A further 25 billion euros will be invested in new locations in the USA and Asia by 2020. In other words, strategic growth has long been taking place outside Europe. And here Voest is representative of many steel companies in Europe. The Chairman of the Board of Management gives clear reasons. These are: excessive climate and energy policies in the EU, high energy costs and high labour costs. As recently as September, a study by the renowned Economic Policy Institute showed that up to 3.5 million jobs are at risk as a rising number of jobs from the deindustrialisation of Europe. High energy and labour costs, increasing shortages of skilled workers, a weak economy in Europe and highly subsidized Chinese cheap steel are endangering Austria's production location. I call on the Commission to take all measures to improve the values it has now raised, all the instruments ... (The President cut off the speaker)

name: Massimiliano Salini (PPE).
text: – Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, Commissioner, this evening we are debating – and for this I thank Mr Martin, the rapporteur for this initiative – an absolutely central issue for the development model that we want to give, from an economic point of view, to our continent. The rapporteur, in my view – and here we overcome the differences, which sometimes block the dialogue between parties – has given a useful and correct reading of the problem of the base metal industry in Europe. We have a looming threat, and we are reacting to it in an absolutely timid way. The threat is spread across several fronts. We have a way of thinking about work and industry that is very different from how it is conceived outside our continent. We have an idea of treating workers that is very different from the idea they have outside this continent. We have very different energy costs from those incurred outside this continent and, let me tell you, we have much better environmental performance than we do outside this continent. Our priority today is to defend a development model that has seen a point of absolute excellence in our industry. This report on energy, indirect costs, compensation, the harmonisation of these compensations, the idea of developing ETS and, within a debate which, as has been said, must protect us from the risk of Recognition for China of market economy status . (The President cut the speaker off)

name: Kathleen Van Brempt (S&D).
text: I think this is an extremely important debate, because we are in danger of ending up in the worst of both worlds rather than in the best of both worlds. We are in danger of losing the steel industry on European soil, while we are working very an industry that is clean, that emits less CO2 and that ensures that the people who work there do so under good conditions. We are replacing our steel with steel, which is often produced in China and elsewhere under poor working conditions and in a polluting way. In other words, that is not the way forward.  I am therefore very pleased with Mr Martin's report, which manages to strike a particularly important balance between the future of industry - and I believe very strongly in a European Union with a strong industry - while meeting very ambitious climate targets.  I am particularly disappointed that this debate is being used to attack climate policy, a week before the very important decisions we have to take in Paris. Because that is not what we are about for the sake of clarity. To date, the steel industry has mainly made money from the ETS system rather than being paid for it. What we need is a comprehensive economic European policy with great environmental ambitions and that means a real anti-dumping policy, Commissioner. I would ask you to show a great deal of ambition and not to wait for complaints from individual companies, but to be very active in the anti-dumping policy and at the same time to be very ambitious with regard to climate policy and energy policy. What is important is an energy union in which we ensure that electricity prices across the Union are level playing.

name: Evžen Tošenovský (ECR).
text: – Mr President, let me first thank the rapporteur, My colleague Martin, for the great energy invested in the report. But above all, for pointing out the strategic importance of the base metals industry for Europe. Steel and other metals are a key raw material for the construction, automotive and many other industries. There is enormous pressure on the metals industry and it cannot bear such a burden in the long term. They face high energy prices, the risk of losing competitiveness on a global scale, carbon leakage and job losses. However, the report contains some problematic points. We should address the issue of emission allowances in the context of the Commission's new proposal on the ETS, and not here. We also reject regulatory measures at the border. Firstly, there is the issue of an insensitive step in the context of the forthcoming negotiations in Paris, but also the risk of breaching the rules of international trade, which could actually harm the entire EU. Unilateral protectionism at the border is always dangerous. On the contrary, these rules allow us to actively defend ourselves against dumping, namely, in particular, unfair commercial practices by certain Chinese producers. And we should set up a state aid system more flexibly. We should create a favourable regulatory environment for businesses and encourage investment in research and development of new technologies.

name: Fredrick Federley (ALDE).
text: Mr President, I would like to begin by congratulating Mr To begin with, I would like to say that it is very important that we have a good debate and a good discussion on Europe's steel and metal industries. They have meant an enormous amount to us historically and they will mean a great deal to us for the future as well. What I think is a pity about the report is a number of things. Firstly, as Mr Tošenovský said at the outset, we are getting a wrong focus. We will soon start working on a review of the ETS and that is where that discussion fits better. I also think it is a pity that we did not wait for the outcome of the Paris climate summit before we start discussing these consequences. It would have given us a better analysis and it would have given us better time to assess the competitive situation and what it will look like in the world around us. I also think it is a pity that in this report we are forgetting to look at how we get a better picture of energy prices in Europe through a better energy union and how we increase competition by having better education and by having better innovations. So the report could have been much better, but it is good that we are discussing industry.

name: Eleonora Forenza (GUE/NGL).
text: – Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, I would like sincerely to thank the rapporteur, Mr Martin, for the work he has done and for taking up a challenge, which I believe is the challenge we face when we talk about steel, namely not to divest a fundamental production sector but, at the same time, not to subordinate maintenance, definition and, I hope, following Paris to anything. , the implementation of those environmental standards that must be a pillar of the construction of the Union. We are talking about a system that is collapsing: I am referring to my country, Italy, where factories such as those in Terni and Piombino are experiencing a huge crisis, which we have also talked about in this House. I also think that we must bear in mind – and here I am still referring to Italy – that there are situations such as taranto, which I hope can be visited as soon as possible by the ENVI Committee of this Parliament, in which people still die.  Here's what can't happen and that there are people who die.... (The President cut the speaker off)

name: Reinhard Bütikofer (Verts/ALE).
text: – Mr President, we want the European steel industry to have a sustainable future, but it is obviously just not good enough for the Commission to say it will try to come back with some solutions, without even mentioning the core fact that we have vast overcapacity in Europe in the steel sector. We need to deal with that. It would be counterproductive – in fact the steel industry would be biting one of the few hands that can feed it – if it were seduced by certain conservatives to go against climate policy, because only investment in infrastructure and the transformation of our economies can provide new uses for steel. The austerity policies are much more destructive than energy prices. Finally, we can have anti-dumping measures that are compatible with World Trade Organization rules, but it is unbelievable that some who are now whining about Chinese dumping are promising market economy status for China, without mentioning that this would only ... (The President cut off the speaker)

name: Bill Etheridge (EFDD).
text: – Mr President, I started work for British Steel Stainless Stockholders in 1990. During a 20-year career in the steel trade I saw a fairly spectacular contraction in demand. We are at the point now where we have got top-quality, high—tech clean manufacturing in Europe and the UK that is being driven out by excessive regulation, excessive energy costs and by totally uncompetitive dumping from China. The UK steel industry is 42% smaller than in 1990. There were 60 000 job losses in Europe between 2007 and 2012. The European Steel Association recently wrote that they were looking for policymakers to act. Many of the policymakers have never been near a steel plant and got their hands dirty, so I will give them a couple of ideas. First of all, combat the dumping by China. Secondly, look at the electricity prices, which will be up 47% by 2020, and immediately rethink the persecution of our manufacturing in the name of green dreams. European manufacturing is the cleanest in the world. Manufacturing matters. It is vital that European policymakers realise this and get on with setting our manufacturers free, so that we can once again lead the world in manufacturing.

name: Jean-Luc Schaffhauser (ENF).
text: Mr President, mr President, mr. Colleague, your report is good in the sense that, in fact, it underlines the importance of heavy industry, which is the source of products, goods, but also the tertiary industry.  On the other hand, you are not proposing a good solution, dear colleague. Your carbon protection will not work and will not be effective. Go to the end of your logic; the logic is protectionism. We must protect ourselves from dumping, we must protect ourselves because there is a problem of security, independence, the environment and jobs. There is no shame in protecting ourselves, the problem is the Commission which, by a bad view of the market, builds energy insecurity and also builds insecurity in terms of jobs and industry.  Get out of your ultraliberal conception, look at the interest of Europe, work for Europe!

name: Antonio Tajani (PPE).
text: Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, in order to emerge from the crisis and build jobs for us, Europe needs a real industrial policy and without industry there is no growth and there is no industrial policy without a steel industry. It is a steel sector that is facing a very difficult challenge, especially with China, a country that does not respect environmental rules and plays a game of unfair competition. And it is not just China: we must also look with concern at Belarus and Turkey. what to do? Firstly, we call on the Commission to present an annual report on the implementation of the steel action plan approved two years ago. Secondly, I believe that we also need new competition rules to enable European industries to compete in the world. Thirdly, precisely because this is a global market, all trade defence instruments, especially anti-dumping measures, must be applied consistently. Today, the procedures are too long and take away the effectiveness of the instruments. We call on the Commission to reduce the duration of the investigation and to ensure that interim measures are imposed in good time.  That's not all! Europe cannot recognise China's market economy status, because China does not meet the five criteria of EU legislation to recognise market economy status. Any recognition of China would lead to the lapse of anti-dumping measures necessary to protect our industry and would have dramatic consequences, not only in the steel sector, but also in the mechanical engineering, chemicals, ceramics, bicycles and paper industry. A negative impact on growth and social cohesion, which the European Commission cannot and must not accept.

name: Jude Kirton-Darling (S&D).
text: – Mr President, by letting the blast furnace and the coke ovens at Redcar go cold on 12 October, the UK Government oversaw the end of steel-making in my region after 175 years, with the loss of 2 000 direct jobs and many more in the supply chain. Labour MEPs fought it, but today we do not want to see the same happening in Scunthorpe or South Wales. Let us make no bones about it. The European steel sector is in crisis. Sites are closing, with thousands of well-paid highly-skilled jobs lost. It is worse than when Lehman Brothers crashed. I know; I led steelworkers at that time. We have had enough summits; we have had enough high-level meetings. Now we need to see action from the Commission and from national governments. It is clear that the global steel market is saturated with overcapacity, especially from China, driving down prices to unsustainable levels. We need to modernise and strengthen our trade defence tools to make them more effective: acting quicker, tackling social and environmental dumping, and opening them up to give the workforce the ability to initiate complaints. Edouard Martin’s report offers long-term solutions to this crisis, and if implemented correctly it could put European steel on the path to a sustainable future. It should be supported when it comes to plenary. Today I am calling on the UK Government to stop hiding behind their excuses for inaction, to stop blocking the vital reform of EU trade defence measures and to recognise that steel is a strategic foundation industry on which all of our manufacturing is based. Other countries have supported their industries within EU state-aid rules; other countries believe in industrial policy. But we have a Secretary of State who refuses to say the words. We in Britain like to think that we are different from the rest of Europe. But this is a difference which is killing our industries and communities like my own. It is too late for Redcar steel workers. Let us not let it be too late for other communities across Europe. Save our steel.

name: Emma McClarkin (ECR).
text: – Mr President, like UK steel, my time here is running out. We urgently need to have this debate, but more than that we urgently need the Commission to take rapid action to make sure that we are using all the anti-dumping measures that the Commission and the EU have at their disposal. We are seeing the effects of this on the UK market. Incredibly, thousands of jobs have been lost. They have been lost in places in Motherwell and in Teesside, and jobs are under pressure in places near my constituency, in Scunthorpe. That action needs to be taken now, and I am calling on the Commission to do so in order that we can have a UK steel industry that we can be proud of. We are proud of our UK industry, but we also need to make sure we can retain the skills that we have and also be able to compete in the marketplace. So I ask the Commissioner: please can you speed up the process and make sure you are using everything at your disposal to make sure that British Steel can keep competing?

name: Rosa D'Amato (EFDD).
text: Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, steel plants in the world produce 1.8 tonnes of steel, but we only consume one and a half tonnes. We have three hundred million excess production capacity. The excess increases but the market is unable to absorb supply. In 2030, the European Union's share will fall to 9% of world production; China will stand at 51%. Of the top 50 producers in the world, at least 30 will be Chinese, european producers will be only 4. However, we must also assess the availability of the planet's iron reserves, which are estimated to be 65 years. Reserves are also running out in the steel raw materials sector. In order to churn out more steel, do we naturally need to inflate global economic demand, for example through major unnecessary works and the production of more useless cars?  We are called upon to propose alternatives to this economic and ecological failure. We need to understand how much steel we really need and produce it with respect for safety, health and the environment. This also implies the closure of obsolete factories and investing in research aimed at sustainability, encouraging conversion into the green economy and the circular economy.

name: Gianluca Buonanno (ENF).
text: Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, in this area too, we see how little Europe counts for and fails to do what it should. It does not defend the steel industry and let the Chinese and the Turks do what they want. The rules that Europe has are not those that China has, nor turkey, and the only ones that really defend themselves with their teeth are the United States. But why can't we copy the things that others can do well? For example, the United States is making sure that China cannot afford to do what it wants there! And why are we going to let him do it here? And then we complain with crocodile tears because we lose jobs, because we do not have industry, because there are major problems in England, as there are also in Italy and also in other countries of Europe, with the result that Europe counts less and less in this field, counts less and less against Islamic terrorism, it counts less and less on alternative energies , counts less and less on everything. The end result will be that Europe is going further and further behind and the others are moving further and further ahead.

name: Francisco José Millán Mon (PPE).
text: – Mr President, first of all, I would like to congratulate the rapporteur, Mr Martin, on his report on the basic metals industry, to which I have personally contributed amendments which I tabled with several Members of my group. The metal industry sector is very important in Europe – particularly in some European regions, such as mine, Galicia – but this sector is currently facing serious threats to its competitiveness. I highlight, among them, the price of energy, generally higher in European countries than on other continents.  Other factors affecting this industry include the flight or relocation of industrial investments to third countries or, as has been said above, unfair competition from third countries through dumping or export subsidies. But we cannot afford for this base metals industry to disappear from Europe: the prosperity and employment of Europeans would be badly undermined.  I therefore welcome the development of Mr Martin's report as a series of measures aimed at making it easier for the metallurgical industry to remain in Europe and competitive. I ask you, Commissioner, to examine with the greatest attention, to analyse this proposal, this battery of measures from the report which we will adopt tomorrow.  Of course, the price of energy is a key sector. I am thinking, for example, of the production of aluminum. I know very well that it demands a very high consumption of electricity and Europeans, of course, we have to make it possible for the electro-intensified industries to remain on our continent, generating jobs and wealth.

name: Patrizia Toia (S&D).
text: Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, I believe that the future of the European Union depends not only on its political leadership and security, but also on its economic strength and industrial weight. Europe cannot be a continent dependent on external production. It would be weak without its excellence and fragile, because it is at the mercy of the external powers.  We have already known the process of deindustrialisation and relocation. It has affected us, it has impoverished employment and productivity, it has reduced our GDP. Now is the time to open our eyes and react, leading a new process of defence and equity of the sustainable production system in the global reality, starting with the most complex and strategic sectors such as steel, and I thank Mr Martin very much for this work. Increasing and often unfair non-European competition, I would sometimes like to say with illegal practices, lack of investment in innovation and production, lack of access to raw materials, rising and anticompetitive energy prices and environmental sustainability are the main challenges for the sector.  If we want to talk to each other clearly, the things to do are quite obvious, and also the things not to do. Europe must be proud of its steel industry: it must defend it with innovation measures, with energy policies for supply and prices, but also with stronger trade policies. Martin used a brave word "aggressive": I would also like to say aggressive. There is unfair competition from some countries from China, which has enormous overcapacity – the figures have been provided – and practises dumping with lower prices in Europe than in China.  That is why we are extremely opposed – and I say this to the Commissioner, who is very sensitive, to refer it to the whole College – to the granting of market economy status to China and also against half-hearted responses, which break the response, that is, which say yes to certain sectors and no to others, because that would be a flaw, a hole with very dangerous consequences. We call on the Commission to work with us on this dossier, as has already been said, and we will not accept a proposal that passes on Parliament's head.

name: Vicky Ford (ECR).
text: – Mr President, it is clear from listening to tonight’s debate that colleagues from all over Europe are concerned about the crisis in the steel industry, and I would like to thank the UK Government for calling the emergency meeting to see what more we can do to help. Yes, this is partly due to overcapacity in the global market, but decisions we take now in this sector have long-lasting consequences, because moth-balling is not viable. You cannot just switch a blast furnace back on. So we need to make important decisions and we need to make them quickly. Commissioner, please can you fast-track your investigations on unfair trade allegations and use all your trade tools? And, as regards energy-intensive industries, some Member States want to give more support but they need to have state-aid clearance. I am not asking you to bend or break competition rules, but rather to make the decisions quickly please, Commissioner. Competitiveness in this industry is key, but we need to use all the tools in our toolbox and to act together quickly.

name: Theodor Dumitru Stolojan (PPE).
text: – Mr President, strategically Europe is becoming increasingly dependent on the import of steel and aluminium, losing jobs and security. The European steel and aluminium industry is becoming uncompetitive, not because of technologies, but because of dumped imports and its own European climate and energy policy. What's going on? It happens that basic metallurgical processes are moving from Europe to emerging countries along with greenhouse gas emissions, emerging countries that are not subject to European standards. In contrast, countries in Europe are increasingly importing intermediate steel and aluminium products, reporting reductions in greenhouse gases. We need more balance in European climate and energy policies, and we need strong action against dumped imports.

name: Martina Werner (S&D).
text: Mr President, I would like to thank the First of all, I would like to thank my colleague Edouard Martin very warmly. It is not only with his report that he has repeatedly brought the issue of the steel industry into the parliamentary debate. I think we need to have this debate right now. 328,000 jobs are directly linked to this industry and they are at massive risk. The crisis in the sector can be summed up almost in one word: overcapacity. When up to 350 million tonnes of mainly Chinese cheap steel enter the world market, there is little room for competition.  In order to support the European steel industry, we need to use three levers. Firstly, industry needs a reliable legal framework. That is why we must ensure clarity at the highest speed with regard to the reform of emissions trading and the design of the carbon leakage list.  Secondly, China is not a market economy. As long as the People's Republic does not meet the five criteria set out in the EU definition, it cannot be recognised as a market economy. Article 15d of the WTO Accession Protocol also supports this argument. Thirdly, the crisis must not lead to a downward spiral – with a one-sided focus on austerity and plant closures. If know-how emigrates and no longer invests in innovation, we have no chance of competing in global competition. The EU can support this by applying a set of measures, some of which were also addressed by the Competitiveness Council on 9/11: the EFSE, the exploitation of the revised aid guidelines, the rapid development of the Energy Union and the consistent application of modernised procurement law for the purchase of sustainable steel. The EU sector may have lost importance in recent years, but it remains of great importance for European industry. It is the basis for dozens of industries, and for thousands of people it is an employer. That is why it is at the heart of our attention.

name: Jarosław Wałęsa (PPE).
text: – Mr President, we need to maintain effective anti-dumping tools to be able to react to known challenges, like those currently faced by the steel sector and others. The challenges of trading with countries that are not members of the market economy global community, like China or Belarus, demonstrate that the EU must be able to react adequately but also effectively. We should not deal with the problems in the sector only by going from crisis to crisis. We should apply a more systematic approach. Horizontal sectoral industrial policy should be permanently included in the Commission’s annual work programme. Despite the cutting of all possible costs, the steel sector’s competitiveness is weakened by high energy prices, uncertainties connected with the Emissions Trading System (ETS) and the growing massive steel imports from Belarus – and we know what happens there, how those prices are nationally regulated and how the sector is subsidised. We have to take full advantage of our trade defence instruments (TDI) legislation that allows us to impose protective measures that can counteract these threats. We have to remember that, by allowing imports from Belarus, we are creating a very difficult situation for our own sector. This is a threat that can lead to the reduction, or even the liquidation, of production in our Member States. I doubt that this is something that we want to see in the future. So the Commission should take advantage of all available solutions to protect EU industry.

name: José Blanco López (S&D).
text: – Mr President, thank you to Mr Martin for his excellent report. Spain is the fourth largest steel-producing country in the European Union. 80,000 families depend on it and since 2007 domestic production has fallen by 30%. Closures and relocations multiply in the Union. To social and environmental dumping and our high energy costs is now added a global overproduction and the granting of market economy status to China, and the same threats that hang over other industries, such as aluminum, very important in Spain and uniquely in my region, Galicia. Faced with this limit situation, we cannot continue to promote unfair competition in the European Union with the State compensation aid system. While Spanish producers received 5 million euros in 2013-2015, the Germans received 756 million euros. We need a harmonised aid system already; and we need to establish a border carbon adjustment to subject importers to the same climate demands as European producers and renewed and effective anti-dumping instruments. Otherwise, we will have more relocations, more deind industrialization and more unemployment. And the European Union cannot fly the flag of reindustrialization while allowing European steel and aluminium industry to fall because of the lack of fair and adequate protective measures.

name: Paul Rübig (PPE).
text: Mr President, I would like to thank the We know that the raw materials industry imports raw materials and that we import energy in Europe, about 400 to 500 billion energy, about 200 billion raw materials. It will therefore be very important how we shape international competition here, and a cross-border tax would once again make it more difficult for our industry to be competitive. We simply need the best conditions in this value chain, in this supply chain, and import is one of them, so that we can buy cheaply, and that is where exports are part of it, so that we can strengthen purchasing power in Europe. This ultimately also creates employment, and employment restores purchasing power. That is why it is a question of us now seeing the WTO round as a priority, that we focus above all on trade facilitation, Aid for Trade, accordingly, taking advantage of the opportunities for developing countries, because the truth is that, of course, we do not live in an eco-paradise in Europe. I believe that we must ensure that the daily products and services we provide remain competitive. We are helping you, Commissioner. We support you, and we now believe that we must become much more active here in the future in order to achieve our target of 30% GDP production in Europe.

name: Adam Gierek (S&D).
text: Congratulations to Mr Martin. His report is as timely as possible. Commissioner, i would like to thank you very much for It is precisely the excessive cost of CO2 emissions, including the technological carbon dioxide resulting from the reduction of iron in blast furnaces, that really threatens to shock the competition and move the steel industry out of Europe. The result will be further deindustrialisation of Europe, loss of experience and professionals, and the abandonment of advanced scientific research, and yet steel blanks, anti-corrosion-coated thin sheets, thick sheets, wires and rods are the basic material material of all material production – that is, the production of cars, washing machines, refrigerators, etc. It is also worth considering the rapporteur's proposal to respond already at The Union's borders to dumped prices of metallurgical products, as the ways so far are insufficient.  On the other hand, the Commission's assumption that the smelting of steel scrap can replace primary metallurgy is extremely naïve, due to a lack of technological knowledge. Steel contaminants, especially copper, increase with each melt cycle. High-quality steel products require a full production cycle in one process string, and also the so-called process heat is saved, which cannot be done when importing raw steel ingots. Europe must not make the high quality of its competitive industrial production dependent on imported steel. This would be an unforgivable mistake.

name: Pilar Ayuso (PPE).
text: – Mr President, Commissioner, this report is very important because it addresses the competitiveness of sectors as important as aluminium and steel, and I would like to talk about them. From a political point of view, it is very important that measures are taken to ensure that these sectors remain competitive and that plants are no longer closed in Europe or moved or relocated to other places (to produce in China, to pollute in China and then to pollute to bring steel to Europe). Their income depends primarily on energy costs and the prices they have to pay for the purchase of allowances.  As the report points out very well, there are three issues that are a priority.  Firstly, to reach a binding agreement at the Paris Conference so that we all have the same levels of competitiveness. I know it's hard, but it would be necessary.  Secondly, a border adjustment mechanism, so that metals produced in countries without emission reduction targets are subject to some tax figure that balances the costs that it entails to produce in the European Union with those of the rest of the world.  And thirdly, harmonisation in the European Union of compensation for indirect costs for the purchase of allowances and, in addition, adequate monitoring of the different national support systems.  In short, these industries need a regulatory framework to develop their activity that allows them to compete with third countries and between the countries of the European Union themselves.

name: Claude Rolin (PPE).
text: Mr President, the report by our colleague Édouard Martin comes at a crucial time for the future of the steel and employment sector in Europe. The previous European Commission took the measure of the challenge with intelligence, launching its action plan for steel. In recent years, many production units have been closed and cocooned. However, the steel sector remains highly strategic in Europe with many jobs. Contrary to what many think, it is a high-tech industry, incorporating many innovations and relying on a skilled workforce.  The European Commission must be able to rely on the high-level conference and social partners to support the development of the sector. The steel industry must be protected from unfair competition from countries such as China. Faced with a Chinese economy characterized by strong state involvement and aggressive trade policy, the potential damage to our economies and jobs is considerable. China is not a market economy, it would not be acceptable to grant it this status until it meets the five technical criteria, which are far from being met. We must defend our model of a socially regulated market economy, and the future of our economies and jobs is at stake.

name: Der Präsident. –
text: This brings us to the catch-the-eye procedure. I'm not going to be able to take everyone in, but we're trying to do as many as we can. Catch-the-eye procedure

name: Stanislav Polčák (PPE).
text: – Mr President, I would like to point out on this subject that the crisis in the steel industry is undoubtedly linked to a number of market factors, such as overproduction, but I think it is repeatedly important to stress that it is also linked to non-market factors. And this is compliance with certain standards, whether it is the protection of workers, favorable working conditions, a favorable environment. This means how much specific states and specific manufacturers comply with compliance requirements for even the most environmental standards. Protectionism, that is, illegal support from the state, these are all issues that are related to this subject, and I believe that we should not resign from them when, for example, we evaluate China as a country with respect to these standards.

name: Maria Arena (S&D).
text: Mr President, I am the daughter of a steelmaker and I have seen since my childhood the steel industry mutate, transform and it can be said today that the steel industry in Europe is a cutting-edge sector. It is a vital sector for Europe because it feeds the other industrial sectors that are now our flagships at European level. So I think this steel industry, we have to defend it by being responsible in terms of the investments we can make in this sector. We must also ensure that it defends the environment, that it is a clean industry and an industry with protected social rights. We must also be consistent and I call on the Council to be able to modernise trade defence instruments because by blocking these instruments we can no longer defend our industries, all our industries.  Last point on coherence, I also ask the Commission not to recognise China's status as a market economy, which is overcapacity in the steel industry and which will destroy the whole sector.

name: Νότης Μαριάς (
text: ECR). Mr President, the steel industry in Greece and the rest of Europe is facing huge problems as the economy has been hit by the recent financial crisis. Forty million tonnes of steel have been closed in the European Union in recent years. Sixty thousand direct jobs and 100,000 indirect jobs were lost.  The competitiveness of the European steel industry is further undermined by China's illegal dumping practices. This continues to deindustrialise in the steel industry, which will only stop if measures are taken, particularly in the field of anti-dapig, and this is something that I have repeatedly pointed out here in Parliament.  In Greece, steel mills, as well as nickel-producing LARCO, have an ominous future. Measures are therefore needed to support employment and modernise the various Greek steel industries, as well as LARCO and the other energy-intensive common metal industries.

name: Izaskun Bilbao Barandica (ALDE).
text: – Mr President, Commissioner, I believe that the conditions of the steel market require the European Commission to apply existing legislation to protect our steel industry from the effects of Chinese overproduction and the slowdown in its economy. It is no receipt that a higher quality steel, produced under environmental and social conditions much worse than the ones we demand here, is ruining our industry. We have already done it with granulated stainless steel and now we have to extend it to all steel production. I am pleased that an investigation like the one that led to these measures is opened, but I ask for speed and forceful action because the sector, more to say, has been shouting for months that we are facing an obvious case of dumping with immediate consequences on employment which, in very industrial areas, such as the Basque Country, we are already noticing. Other uncertainties must also be eliminated. Today, the Chinese economy does not meet the conditions that characterize market economies. If we want our industry to survive and in the future to continue investing in innovation and technology, it needs legal certainty and stable expectations in the medium and long term. Please, Commissioner, let us react.

name: Tiziana Beghin (EFDD).
text: Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, if, at the end of 2016, the Commission considers China to be a market economy, metallurgy will be hit hard. China has an immense steel surplus, which it obtains by subsidising production and selling it with unfair trade practices. On its own, it produces 50% of all world production, i.e. one billion and six hundred million tonnes, which are waiting for nothing more than to be poured into our market and which they will be able to do so if the Commission does not oppose it.  Ladies and gentlemen, with steel works already in crisis, this will be the final blow! That is why I understand an agreement that recognises Chinese dumping, sector by sector, thus protecting the steel sector. But I think it would be much better to reason product by product. Let me give you an example on other areas: China is the subject of an anti-dumping proceeding on tiles, but not on the entire ceramics sector. If we think by sector, we will not be able to continue to protect our tile manufacturers, and that applies to thousands of other products.  So, please, let us not let the Commission sell off our production in this way.

name: Elżbieta Bieńkowska
text: Member of the Commission. – Mr President, thank you all very much for your interventions. Firstly, I want to say very strongly that we need strong European industry. We need a strong European steel industry. We need strong, modernised and innovative European industry, and this is the basis for all of our actions. Of course, the steel sector that we are talking about today is a really broad economic issue. It has to be tackled both on the national and the European level. You are right that price differences are really extreme in the Member States. However, Member States have to deal with energy taxation, and what some of you were mentioning is true. Industry needs stable energy prices, and we are working on this not only in the energy market union strategy but also in all of the documents and actions that I am taking. I also agree that we need a massive effort to support the modernisation of European industry. Everything shows that we really must not – and it would be stupid if we did – become dependent on steel from outside of the EU. We need a much stronger anti-dumping policy, but I also have to mention that we are today using trade defence instruments – for example, steel anti—dumping and anti-subsidy measures, registration of imports, threat of industry – but we have to be very much stronger and very much focused on this. I am quite sure that if the steel industry – or any other industry – disappears from Europe, then research, development and innovation expenditure will follow, and then the services will follow. So we have to do all that we can, together with the Member States, to keep them in Europe. As regards giving China free market status, I know that the issue is very sensitive and that we have to be very careful about it. This topic is now under legal analysis. The debate in the college has not started yet. I repeat: I will be very careful about it. I am fully aware that it will have a major negative impact on industry in all sectors, so we will have to carefully balance, in the College, geopolitical considerations with our industrial interest. We are currently implementing a lot of measures from the steel action plan. We will keep you updated on this, but we are also analysing the state of implementation in the context of the High Level Group. The next meeting of the High Level Group on Energy-Intensive Industries is foreseen for 18 December – in a few weeks’ time – and it will be an occasion to discuss the issues raised today during the debate and by Mr Martin’s report on the base metals industry, as well as the use of the trade defence instruments. We really have to study very carefully the proposals included in the report, and we will do so. I also want to mention our finishing work on the circular economy package. I am responsible for this, together with Commissioner Vella. Adoption by the College is foreseen for 2 December. One of the actions will concentrate on secondary raw materials. I think it is important to let you know that we also have a lot of things related to the steel industry in this package. We have to make more use of our secondary raw materials, and we have to make full use of recycled metal. This, I hope, will help our industry to produce at lower cost. In line with the conclusions of the Extraordinary Competitiveness Council on Steel of 9 November, I will convene a special high-level stakeholder conference. We should address at this conference, with all of the stakeholders, the very critical issues such as investment – including the role which the investment plan will play in these sectors – energy, the circular economy package, trade and, last but not least, research and development, in order to secure the future of our industry. I am very eager to use all possible tools that we have. I will try to coordinate the use of them. Of course, not all of them are my responsibility, but I will try to coordinate all of the measures that can be taken for the future of the European steel industry.

name: Edouard Martin
text: Rapporteur. Mr President, Commissioner, ladies and gentlemen, I thank you for this very rich debate. I will try to speak softly, but I would have to be given a few more seconds, please.  I've heard some some implausible things. I would just like to point out that, since 2008 - and it is not Mr Tajani who will contradict me - Europe has paid a heavy burden on the steel crisis. We have closed the equivalent of 40 million tonnes of production. Forty million tons! I repeat: "Do we still want to keep the 170 million tons?"  But in this report we are not just talking about steel, even though we are facing a steel crisis, it has been pointed out; we are talking about aluminum, copper, zinc, etc. These are all metals that are essential to our economy. I was also surprised to hear a few colleagues, including Mr Fox- it is a pity, he has already left - saying that carbon adjustment at borders was not a good answer. Others said that it was almost a protectionist measure and therefore did not want it. I will be very clear: if we do not accept carbon adjustment at borders, we will indeed take protectionist measures, but we will protect others. We will protect India, China, Russia, Brazil, etc. Because what is carbon adjustment at borders? It is not a tax, it is the idea of the polluter pays. Can you imagine, a few weeks before COP21, we Europeans are going to send the following message: will pollution only be paid for by European productions? Polluters outside the European Union will be exempt from paying for their pollution as well. That is the message we are sending.  Do we want to take it collectively? I don't!  I will conclude by simply saying that now the ball is in the court of my colleagues, of the rest of us. We will be voting very soon. Therefore, everyone will have to take responsibility and choose their vote. I am speaking to you, Commissioner, be courageous, do not be persuaded by people and structures that defend special interests. Do as we do, defend the public interest because the public interest is the defence of an industry at the service of 500 million Europeans.

name: Der Präsident. –
text: The debate is closed. The vote will take place at a meeting of the December II part-session. Written declarations (Article 162 OF the CRP)

name: Monika Smolková (S&D)
text: Writing. – I find it unacceptable that the European steel sector, with its 60 000 direct jobs and another 100 000 indirect jobs, is currently facing the biggest crisis in its history at a time of peace. I expect this report to take measures that will create re-growth for the base metals sector and regain global competitiveness. Despite the fact that the steel sector has been losing more than 40 million tonnes of steel production capacity since 2008 and in 2014 there has been a lower demand of 40 Mt compared to 2007, I believe that this industrial policy will create the necessary tools and means for the base metals sector to achieve a successful transition to a low-carbon economy. As an MEP from Slovakia, I see this area all the more because I come from the city of Košice, where there is a metallurgical company that employs more than 10,000 employees and I know what can happen if there is no demand for its products. I expect the base metals sector to adapt strategically to the new climate, economic and social situation by setting an example in terms of efficient and efficient energy consumption, as well as raw materials, and not disappearing from the industrial world of the future.

name: Владимир Уручев (PPE)
text: in writing. – Dear Colleagues, the steel sector that launched European integration is now experiencing the worst crisis in its peaceful history. For the last 5-8 years, more than 40 million capacity has been closed. hundreds of thousands of jobs have been lost. Such is the crisis in the non-ferrous metals and metal alloys sector, facing strong competition from countries that do not have Europe's strict standards. At the same time, policies to decarbonise the economy impose a burden of additional carbon costs and high energy prices, which worsens the competitiveness of this industry. Taking into account the huge production overcapacity in third countries and the dumping of foreign players, the trends become even more gloomy. Decisive action is needed to prevent a new EU external dependence on steel and base metals. The fight against climate change must be crowned in Paris by establishing a common environmental regime to reduce emissions in order to prevent the phenomenon of carbon emissions shifting outside the EU. Free emission allowances from sectors at risk of loss of competitiveness should be maintained, innovation and efficiency in the industry encouraged. It is necessary to systematically apply trade defence instruments against unfair competition, including caution in recognising market economy status.

name: Der Präsident. –
text: The next item on the agenda is the debate on the report by Ole Christensen on behalf of the Committee on Employment and Social Affairs on the EU Strategic Framework for Health and Safety at Work 2014-2020 (2015/2107(INI)) (A8-0312/2015).

name: Ole Christensen
text: Rapporteur. Mr President! Occupational safety and health is one of the areas where the EU makes a noticeable and positive difference to ordinary people across Europe. There is a need to address both new and existing risks. Every year, more than 150 000 people die as a result of work-related illnesses and accidents, and millions of people suffer from musculoskeletal disorders, mental health problems, the consequences of asbestos and a sea of suffering as a result of their work. This is not a good situation for workers, businesses or the slunks of the Treasuries. In the process of debating the report, I have also seen a very positive attitude towards all these rules across political divides in this House. I would therefore also like to thank all the shadow rapporteurs for their very good cooperation on this report. There are many good reasons to be ambitious when it comes to the working environment. In the long run, there is no doubt that we all win through an ambitious approach. Workers are becoming more productive, which is obviously beneficial to themselves and to the companies they work for. Older workers are not involuntarily forced out of the labour market because of ill health and national social security systems are becoming more sustainable. And last but certainly not least, we can help the millions of European workers who suffer from a poor working environment. In fact, I think that the Commission has done a good job of identifying a large part of the risks that we need to address. However, if these risks are to be addressed, concrete action is of course necessary. On the other hand, I think that the Commission has been a little more restrained in recent years. However, To my great satisfaction, I have also noticed that Mrs Thyssen has a strong focus on the importance of this area.  First of all, there is a need for much better protection for European workers against exposure to carcinogens. That is why we want more binding occupational exposure limit values to be added so that we can reduce the number of work-related cancers. Secondly, it is necessary to present a proposal for a comprehensive action on musculoskeletal disorders, so that we ensure a more effective prevention of the causes of these disorders. We also need to start paying more attention to the changing forms of work and new technologies that characterise the European labour market. In particular, we know that precarious work is too often associated with negative consequences for the working environment of employees, just as posted workers are too often treated worse than their counterparts in the countries in which they will work. That is why more needs to be done and for the kinds of precarious work that we cannot be served by to be put to an account. Unfortunately, asbestos is still a major problem in Europe. To take a frightening example, we now see in Denmark, where I come from, women who have washed their spouse's work clothes are now suffering from mesothelioma. It is hardly clear how important it is that we ensure that these fates do not affect another generation in Europe. One final point I would like to highlight is the need to address psycho-social risks, which can, for example, result in stress, burn out and depression. The human consequences are enormous and the actual cost has just been made up.  It is said that it actually costs EUR 600 billion a year in Europe if expenditure on absenteeism, productivity losses and other expenditure on social services and treatment were included. It really is a huge amount! As I said, there are many important points on which action should be taken, but I must stop here.

name: Marianne Thyssen
text: Member of the Commission. – Mr President, I welcome Parliament’s clear and constructive feedback on the EU Strategic Framework on Health and Safety at Work 2014-2020. In particular, I would like to thank the rapporteur, Mr Christensen, for putting forward such a rich and balanced report. This will definitely contribute to the successful implementation of the EU occupational safety and health (OSH) strategic framework. The Commission shares Parliament’s views on the importance of strengthening risk prevention policies and promoting a culture of prevention in all companies across Europe, irrespective of their size or area of activity. This is indeed about fundamental rights as well as competitiveness. In the Commission work programme for 2016, adopted on 27 October, we committed to reviewing the existing occupational health and safety legislation based on a detailed ex-post evaluation. Our ambition is to improve the efficiency and effectiveness of the European legislative framework for protecting workers while making the rules simpler and reducing regulatory burden and red tape, in particular for small and micro-enterprises. In addition, we need to enhance the protection of workers’ health and safety and reflect recent scientific advances. I share your sense of urgency on the fight against work-related cancer. We cannot stand by whilst hundreds of thousands of people per year die from work-related cancers. There are substances for which a decade ago we did not know yet that they cause cancers, but now, with what we do know, we need to act and to protect workers from being exposed to excessive doses at work. Mid-next year I intend to table a legislative proposal to extend the list of substances for which there are occupational exposure limits in place. European Union policy in this area, of course, goes beyond tabling new legislative initiatives. The report draws attention to a number of issues and formulates a number of recommendations on which I would like to comment in particular. First, I do share Parliament’s view on the importance of improving the implementation record of European and national occupational health and safety legislation, as only effective results on the ground can make a real difference for people in their daily working life. The report highlights the role of the EC Senior Labour Inspectors Committee as a platform for the exchange of information and collaboration between Member States and the importance of sufficient resources for labour inspectorates, but effective implementation and workplace compliance with OSH regulation and legislation is not only a responsibility of enforcement bodies. It is in the first place a common responsibility of employers and employees, and social partners too have an important role to play in the design and implementation of preventive measures. The tripartite European Occupational Safety and Health Agency is in Bilbao and is doing excellent work in promoting health and safety campaigns and supporting implementation through user-friendly tools, in particular for SMEs. I welcome Parliament’s support for this work. Secondly, I endorse the impetus that the report gives for more awareness of gender issues in health and safety, in line with the ILO Decent Work Agenda. The European Strategic Framework acknowledges that specific risks affecting women deserve particular attention and require targeted action. In this area also, the Bilbao Agency promotes the identification and exchange of good practice on ways to improve OSH conditions for women. Thirdly, I share your concerns about psychosocial risks in the workplace, including stress and depression. Report after report points to stress and depression as a growing cause of absenteeism and of what one has started to call ‘presentism’, a physical presence at work but sub-optimal output because of stress-related factors. The human and economic costs are enormous. One of the priority actions foreseen in the European OSH Strategic Framework is the identification and dissemination of good practice on preventing mental health problems. The Commission has recently published a new study on mental health in the workplace which provides practical guidance for workers and employers on how to deal with this issue. The European Agency for Safety and Health at Work is active in this area, for example, with its pan-European awareness campaign on stress and psychosocial risks carried out in 2014 and 2015. The emergence of new risks does not mean that we should not continue to pay attention also to traditional health risks, such as the prevention of work-related muscular-skeletal disorders. We will pay particular attention to this in the context of our ongoing ex-post evaluation of the European legislative acquis and possible subsequent initiatives. As I have underlined before, my aim is to provide maximum protection on the ground in the most sensitive and sensible way. Last but not least, I would like to thank Parliament for its efforts to conclude the trilogues on the platform for the fight against undeclared work. I welcome the agreement found by the co-legislators and I do hope that the platform can start its work as soon as possible next year. As Parliament’s report on health and safety recalls, undeclared work unfortunately often brings with it also precarious health and safety conditions. Fighting undeclared work will thus also help us tackle some of the most dangerous and unhealthy working conditions. Let me assure you once again of the Commission’s commitment to high health and safety standards for workers in the European Union and to modernising and simplifying the rules with a view to adapting them to new developments and better implementation on the ground. I really do appreciate your support in this endeavour.

name: Biljana Borzan
text: Rapporteur for the opinion of the FEMM Committee. – Mr. President, as a occupational health specialist, I have often encountered poor working conditions. The economic crisis has worsened working conditions and it is important to include gender differences in the strategic framework for the coming period so that employers also take this dimension into risk management activities.  In society, there is a stereotype that women do less risky jobs resulting in fewer preventive measures. However, precisely because of their psychophysical peculiarity, role in society and household, women often get sick, primarily from musculoskeletal diseases.  The second most common problem is stress, often associated with sexual harassment. It is behind almost half of the working days lost each year, and its cost to society is valued at €240 billion a year. It also concerns the health of pregnant women and mothers in addition to dangerous chemicals for which there are no prescribed limits yet in the EU. I thank the rapporteur, I am sorry that there is no maternity leave directive in the text ... President cut speaker off

name: Georges Bach
text: Mr President, i.e. the Group of the European People's Party (Christian Democrats) and European Democrats Mr President, Commissioner, I would like to begin by thanking the rapporteur for her excellent work and for the work she has done on this report.
