Allow me to start by pointing out the good cooperation with the rapporteur and with the shadow rapporteur. We have produced a good, balanced report, and I am pleased that you, Commissioner, are incorporateing the report into the work of the Commission. It was important for us that the same standards apply to all employees, regardless of the individual sector and regardless of the size of the company. It was also important to address the specificities of small and medium-sized enterprises and to support them with practical tools and guidelines. Above all, however, clear rules are needed. The labour market is changing, and that is why we must also adapt health and safety standards. The new challenges have already been highlighted. We need additional data on psychosocial risks such as stress, depression, burnout, but also on new technologies such as nanotechnology and biotechnology, as well as on digitalisation and demographic change. However, we must not neglect the risks that exist, the existing problems, for example in the case of asbestos, where clearly existing regulations and requirements are still not being implemented. Better cooperation between labour inspections – Commissioner, you have also pointed this out – and with regard to REFIT, simplification of legislation, but not deregulation.

name: Jutta Steinruck
text: Mr President, I would like to make a mifful son, mr President, I would like to make a ido to the S&D Group. Mr President, I would like to thank the I think that the Commission has made a very good analysis in its strategy. But what is missing is actually what is to happen in concrete terms. The world of work is changing and we really need a strategy. We have new phenomena that are getting stronger and stronger, such as depression. One in ten workers in Germany, for example, is missing each year due to depression or musculoskeletal disorders. 19% of workers in Germany say they suffer from chronic back pain as a result of their work. Or, as has already been said, carcinogenic substances: hundreds of thousands of people die every year across the EU as a result of occupational cancer, and the numbers are rising. We need to act. What we need are really concrete measures for all workers, and it must make no difference whether someone works in a large or small company.

name: Anthea McIntyre
text: on behalf of the ECR Group. – Mr President, we have to simplify European health and safety legislation and we have to find a way to remove administrative burdens while maintaining protection for workers. We need a simplified legal framework that helps SMEs to comply. I believe that by removing complexity we will increase compliance. Currently we have 24 separate directives making up the occupational health and safety (OSH) acquis. In the UK, the Health and Safety Executive claims that simplification could help lift the admin burden on 220 000 SMEs, with no impact on health and safety protection. So action at EU level must be based on clearly identified risk and must be proportionate to that risk. We cannot eliminate risk altogether but we can manage it. If we wanted to eliminate risk, we would never cross the road – but by educating people and putting in crossings we can successfully manage that risk.

name: Renate Weber
text: on behalf of the ALDE Group. – Mr President, colleagues, a healthy, functional society needs healthy people. Employees working in a safe and healthy environment will enjoy not only their lives but also their work, and thus they will be more productive. Therefore, investing in safety and health at the workplace is a win-win situation for both the employers and the employees. To achieve this we need clear and simple legislation and its enforcement. Today we have 24 directives which regulate this subject, yet the number of accidents and work-related diseases is extremely high. This discrepancy is mostly the result of red tape inherent in a heavy, overlapping and burdening legislation. It is undeniable that there are many work-related risks, both traditional and emerging, but I strongly believe that the focus should not be on adding new pieces of legislation to the pile of existing ones, thereby overloading the employers and resulting in the end in a very low level of compliance. 85% of European jobs are created by SMEs, yet they are the most encumbered by the legislation as it is today. Compliance requires allocation of resources, financial expertise and time—wise ones while trying to stay competitive and generate jobs. This status quo is counterproductive. Our emphasis as legislators should be on elaborating a simplified and efficient framework that is easy to understand and implement, that does not necessarily involve great financial costs for employers, and that is ultimately beneficial for employees, the economy and society as a whole. (Applause)

name: Νεοκλής Συλικιώτης
text: on behalf of the GUE/NGL Group. Mr President, for the Left, health and safety at work is above all an inalienable right to work which cannot be understood without the active and substantial contribution of workers. For us it is inconceivable that more than four thousand workers die in the Union every year as a result of accidents at work.   The participation of workers cannot therefore be limited to declarations, but must be ensured at all levels of decision-making, from the level of the undertaking to the level of the State, levels at which workers' unions and social partners have direct and active participation.  New forms of work must also be taken seriously in the health and safety debate, in order to ensure that jobs are of quality and ensure both health and safety at work, as well as workers' social security, their permanent employment and their participation in collective bargaining and collective agreements.  Finally, we consider it a very positive development that Parliament's report makes no reference to the interconnection of life expectancy with work, which is unfortunately highlighted in the Commission's report. As a Left we will not tire of fighting against this anti-labour measure, which takes away the right of workers to enjoy their old age and pension as they wish.

name: Davor Škrlec
text: on behalf of the Verts/ALE Club. – Mr. President, the right to work and health is the right of every citizen and citizen of the European Union. Aware of the challenges of the economic crisis, the ageing workforce and the strong link between job security and the general benefits to society, we are obliged to provide a legal framework for the realisation of a sustainable working environment. The new strategic framework must therefore contribute to improving working conditions while further consolidating national strategies, stronger enforcement of laws and measures, removing unnecessary administrative burdens and providing practical support, in particular to small businesses in meeting health protection rules. In particular, I underline the importance of occupational health and safety measures addressing the specific challenges and risks faced by women in the workplace, including sexual harassment.  I therefore call on the Commission and the social partners to ensure a balance between the representation of men and women in all social dialogue procedures and to take into account the gender equality dimension as part of the revision of the 2016 Strategic Framework on Safety and Health at Work. I call on the Commission to develop a European strategy to combat violence against women in the workplace and to assess the revision of Directive 2006/54 as part of this process in order to expand its scope of action to cover new forms of violence and harassment.  I call on Member States to implement The Commission Recommendation 92/131 to raise awareness of sexual harassment and other forms of sexual bullying in the workplace.

name: Laura Agea
text: Mr President, president, ladies and gentlemen, i.e. the european Union, the European Union and its Member States are – Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, we congratulate Mr Christensen on having welcomed and included in his document, which comes out of this Parliament strong, some of our suggestions: the simplification of obligations for small and medium-sized enterprises, which does not mean reducing protection for workers, but simply giving the possibility of applying simple, clear and certain rules. , and the stimulation of greater social dialogue that makes workers and employers sensitive to the importance of health and safety at work. Above all, we welcome the fact that the issue of asbestos is being strongly included in this document: too many deaths that not only need compensation but must be applied with truly clean-up policies and therefore economic resources must be used to carry out the clean-ups that are still needed.  We therefore support Mr Christensen's document and thank him for his cooperation.

name: David Casa (PPE).
text: – Sur President, iva hemm ħafna sfidi importanti li qegħdin jiffa大大jaw dawk li jħaddmu u l-ħaddiema stess fil-qasam tas-saħħa u s-sigurtà, u fuq nota partikolari nsemmi ġeneru ta' riskji ġodda bħalma huma r-riskji psikoso大jali li żgur ma jistgħuxġ jiu injorati. Dawn ġew introdotti inevitabbilment minħabba l-introduzzjoni ta' element teknoloġiħi ġodda li għalkemm kultant jgħinu lill-kumpannijji jespandu u jginu lill-produttiħà, però fl-istess ħin, qegħdin ikollhom impatt negattiv fuq il-bilan大 ġenerali tal-benessere tal-ħaddiema. U allura nemmen li dawn ir-riskji għandhom jiġu mmaniġġjati b'mod sistematiku sabiex inkunu nistgħu nissalvagwardjaw is-saħħa tal-ħaddiema b'mod aktar effettiv. U allura naqbel ma' dak li qalet il-Kummisssarju li l-Kummissjoni għandha taħdem fuq program ta' monitoraġġ u sapport għall-ħaddiema affettwati u tirrakkomanda linji ta' gwida sabiex tikkumbatti dawn ir-riskji. name: Siôn Simon (S&D).
text: – Mr President, I would also like to congratulate my Socialist colleague, Ole Christensen, on his excellent report, and I would also like to congratulate, as I did in the Committee, the Commissioner for her announcement that the list of substances in the Carcinogens and Mutagens Directive will be updated. That is the kind of concrete, common-sense politics that I think these institutions are good at. But I would also like to slightly chide my Conservative colleagues for always talking, when they talk about health and safety, about the burden on business, as though the one and the other go hand in hand and are the same things. Health and safety is not red tape, it is life and death. That is what we need to be stressing over and over again and not, every time the subject comes up, saying that we must ensure health and safety while also reducing burdens on business.

name: Inês Cristina Zuber (GUE/NGL).
text: – Mr President, this report has a variety of positive aspects. For example, it refers to the harmful effects on the health and safety at work of precarious employment or that precarious employment excludes workers from access to training and health and safety services at work, and is also associated with mental stress. All this would be even more positive if the European Union always acted in coherence and in accordance with the principles invoked in the strategy. For example, it was important to understand what kind of work the European Union finances under the Youth Guarantee programme, when today it is known that a large part of the jobs covered by this type of programme are forms of labour exploitation of young people. For example, it would be important to understand whether the European Union does not finance with structural and cohesion funds companies that violate these rights, in particular in terms of safety and health at work rules. It is that we are aware daily of many companies that do so and that have already received funding.

name: Danuta Jazłowiecka (PPE).
text: – (2) Mr President, I would like to begin by Dear! The issue of health and safety at work is of paramount importance not only for workers themselves, but also for the eu market as a whole and for the competitiveness of European companies. In this situation, it is worrying that some Member States have still not ratified International Labour Organisation Convention 187 or are delaying the implementation of EU legislation in this area. To address these other problems, the European Commission has developed a strategic framework for health and safety at work for the period 2014-2020. Unfortunately, I am afraid that this strategy may not bring about a significant improvement in health in terms of accidents at work or health diseases, and these – I would like to remind you – cause the deaths of almost 20 000 Europeans a year.  If we want to achieve the europe 2020 targets and promote active ageing, real and effective action is needed. Without these measures, we cannot expect people over the age of 60 to continue to be able to function effectively in the labour market. Specific initiatives need to be taken at Union level in order to avoid that less protection of workers' health becomes an incentive to maintain the competitiveness of businesses in some Member States. Health and safety at work is also a major challenge in the context of flexible forms of employment, as so-called atypical forms of employment allow entrepreneurs to react efficiently to changing economic conditions and are an essential element of a modern economy. However, in this situation, employers are obliged to ensure adequate safety for workers when it comes to... (The President received the speaker's vote)

name: Marita Ulvskog (S&D).
text: Mr President, I would like to begin by congratulating Mr Thank you, Commissioner, for being here! Poor working environments cost lives and quality of life, but they also cost in terms of lower productivity and less competitiveness. I am therefore very pleased that we have finally got a report in place stating that all workers have the right to the highest possible level of health and safety at work, regardless of whether the employer is a large or a small company. The truth is, of course, that a small company has a harder time coping with a situation where a worker is injured and has to be replaced by another completely new person. It is extremely important that all companies are covered. But also regardless of the type of work you do, regardless of the contract on which the employment is based or the Member State in which you are employed. Thanks for this! I will do everything I can to make this a reality.

name: Jérôme Lavrilleux (PPE).
text: Mr President, Commissioner, dear Marianne Thyssen, the rapporteur, ladies and gentlemen, I would like to thank the rapporteur for his work, which highlights the two characteristics which should lead us to revise our policies on occupational health and safety. It is about the evolution of tasks as well as the aging of the workforce.  Remember, every year workplace accidents cause more than 4,000 deaths and probably more than 150,000 life-threatening illnesses. In the face of these staggering figures, let us not give in to the temptation and ease of responding to our turn with other figures, that is, standards and quotas that would be added to those already existing. The results have shown that this policy is disconnected from reality and therefore ineffective. Some policies put in place by Member States are proving to be more job-destroying than protective of workers. Indeed, certain rules are unenforceable and represent a brake on entrepreneurship and thus on the economy and employment. I will cite the French example of the penalty account, a real gas plant that cannot be worked. In conclusion, yes, we must find solutions to ensure that workers have the best possible working conditions, but realistic and effective solutions in the 21st century. I am convinced that we can combine competitiveness and well-being at work, without one being a burden to the other, and I would like to say to my Socialist colleague that we have never seen health as a bureaucratic burden; it is bureaucracy that is a bureaucratic burden.

name: Agnes Jongerius (S&D).
text: – Good health and a decent working environment are fundamental social rights in Europe. Despite all the fine words and appointments, too many people still get sick from work. An ambitious policy on health and safety in the workplace contributes to the productivity of businesses and thus also contributes to the sustainability of our social security systems, while the costs of the absence of such a policy are very high. In short, there is no excuse for not protecting workers.  In any case, it is positive that the Commission discussed new rules for carcinogens during the presentation of its plans for 2016, but there is more work to be done. I would ask the Commission to ensure that the study of precarious work also looks at the effects on working conditions of precisely this precarious work.

name: Jeroen Lenaers (PPE).
text: – 4000 workers die each year as a result of a workplace accident. Three million people can't work for three days or more because of a workplace accident. 25% of Europeans believe that their safety or their health in the workplace is at risk. All in all, there are plenty of reasons to have this debate here this evening and thank commissioner Thyssen very much for her clear statement on this point. I think three priorities that she has set out are very important. These are the support of SMEs - as Mrs McIntyre has already said - the simplification of European rules, but above all the enforcement of the rules we have. Marianne Thyssen spoke of the labour inspectorates which have a fundamental role to play in this, and I sometimes wonder whether all labour inspections in Europe are adequately equipped to fulfil that role. I would like to hear her thoughts on this and also how we could possibly improve it.  And finally, Marianne Thyssen also spoke about this and it is something that is very important to me: the position of people with chronic pain, the position of people with neurological disorders and the position of people with muscle disorders. People who often suffer from a double burden, not only because of the disease, but also because they face stigma and problems in the workplace, whereas those problems in the workplace are often avoided with simple adjustments. I also ask, above all, to continue and to pay close attention to it.

name: Brando Benifei (S&D).
text: – Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, I would like to spend a few seconds expressing my heartfelt congratulations to my colleague Ole Christensen, for his report, a brilliant compromise work between the political groups, which has not, however, watered down its high political and technical value. Thank you, therefore, for your work.  In my opinion, the text puts an absolutely central element in black and white, namely the worrying correlation between the economic crisis and its social impact, the precariousness and the very dangerous lowering of the quality of the health and safety standards associated with them. In no way can we accept that work in Europe should be created by renouncing these rights. This would do enormous damage to the EU's own economy.  Making a social Europe for its citizens also means paying the utmost attention to this issue, which cannot be sacrificed to the doctrine of simplifying legislation, to cutting the so-called bureaucratic red tapes which, hearing some comments, would seem to be sinking businesses. The resolution is also clear on this point: the European Commission is sensitive to the health and safety of workers, particularly in its entirety as a legislative refit. Being competitive cannot mean renouncing our principles.

name: Sofia Ribeiro (PPE).
text: – Mr President, in the process of producing the expected effects of this strategic framework, we need to see five objectives met. More social dialogue, a key element for the development, adequacy and implementation of health and safety policies at work, both at national and European Union level, because there is only a real commitment between all parties involved that we will have guarantees of success in local implementation. More business support tools. Certain sectors have specific needs and we cannot ignore the particular case of SMEs. In this sense, practical instruments and guidelines need to be developed to support and facilitate and improve compliance by them and their workers with health and safety requirements at work. Increased effort and coordination at the level of the European Union and its Member States. The European Commission should set up a database of national health and safety organisations in order to facilitate access to national plans, fostering the sharing of best practices and helping to fill their policy gaps in this area. Greater capacity to adapt to new challenges of safety and occupational health. New emerging risks in the workplace, such as psychosocial risks and burn-out, among others, need a swift and adequate response. Finally, increased awareness among workers and working entities of the benefits arising from the implementation of these measures. Such as, for example, the reduction of error, motivation, greater individual and collective well-being, contributing to the increase of workers' productivity and reducing risks for companies.

name: Claude Rolin (PPE).
text: Mr President, Commissioner, if there is one issue on which the three-way social A desired by the President of the Commission depends, it is that of the health and safety of employees.  Indeed, every year in Europe, thousands of workers lose their lives in order to earn a living, tens of thousands die from work-related diseases. These figures cannot be ignored. Behind these numbers are human tragedies. However, we have the tools to reduce the number of accidents and occupational diseases. The first is certainly prevention in the workplace, the second is social consultation. Who better than the actors on the ground can define the right policies? Finally, in Europe, we have remarkable tools to support these policies, including the European Agency for Safety and Health at Work in Bilbao and the European Foundation for the Improvement of Living and Working Conditions in Dublin. These are vital works to support policies to improve living and working conditions, to support health and safety policies.  Finally, if it is necessary to simplify, to give more intelligence to our regulations, there can be no question of doing so at the expense of the health and safety of employees. Let us not forget, better working conditions, fewer accidents, fewer diseases, they are more competitive enterprises, healthier social security systems and above all human tragedies avoided. It is priceless.

name: Marianne Thyssen
text: Member of the Commission. – Mr President, improving health and safety at work is of the utmost importance, in particular taking into account the growing demographic challenge and changing work patterns. Good occupational health and safety at work will not only contribute to longer, healthier, safer and more sustainable working lives but will also have a positive impact on the European Union’s productivity and competitiveness, and indeed on the sustainability of our social security systems. I thank, once again, the rapporteur, Mr Christensen, and the shadow rapporteurs and other Members of the Committee on Employment and Social Affairs and the Committee on Women’s Rights and Gender Equality for their valuable input. The Commission will carefully analyse your suggestions on old and new risks and take them into consideration for its future work. This is about the effective protection of workers while, where possible, making the rules more user-friendly and less burdensome for enterprises, and specifically for SMEs and micro-enterprises. I am convinced that these two goals can be reached simultaneously, and I hope this will help in achieving our AAA rating, which we need, as well as in terms of economic growth and social progress. This is what we will work on next year.

name: Ole Christensen
text: Rapporteur. Mr President! I would like to thank you for a very good debate and thank you for the great support that is being given to the broad lines of the report. It is great to see, and I am sure, that a good common ground can be found in the most important areas. This is especially true, of course, because we all have something to gain from doing even better than we do today. I am very excited to see how the Commission intends to translate the comprehensive evaluation of the European health and safety rules which has just been completed. It is clear to me that there is no doubt that there is a need for new legislation and revision of existing rules in certain respects. It is important that all workers are entitled to the best possible protection regardless of the size of the company. Thank you very much for today's debate.

name: Der Präsident. –
text: The debate is closed. The vote will take place on Wednesday, 25 November 2015. Written declarations (Article 162 OF the CRP)

name: Vilija Blinkevičiūtė (S&D)
text: Writing. – I agree with Parliament's position on the EU Strategic Framework on Safety and Health at Work proposed by the Commission for the period 2014-2020. All workers, irrespective of the size of the employer, the Member State of employment or the nature of the employment contract under which they were hired, shall be entitled to the highest level of health and safety protection at work. As the Commission points out in the EU Strategic Framework for Safety and Health at Work, effective management of occupational safety and health for micro and small enterprises remains a challenge. We therefore need to take action to promote compliance of these companies with the requirements and effective management of the safety and health of workers. Labour inspectorates play an important role in the effective application of occupational safety and health legislation at national level. Companies can benefit from the assistance provided by labour inspectorates and information on preventive measures and legal requirements, and it is therefore necessary that labour inspectorates are given more staff and resources to carry out their duties. If we want to implement successful risk prevention in the workplace, it is important that social dialogue is established, workers are represented and company leaders make appropriate commitments. We can also do more at Member State and EU level to provide and encourage the use of health and safety training.

name: Viorica Dăncilă (S&D)
text: in writing. – According to European statistics, every year more than 4 000 workers lose their lives in accidents at work and the number of cases of deadly occupational diseases amounts to more than 150 000 annually. In the current context, it is essential for Europe to promote a safe and healthy working environment for all workers throughout the working cycle. We must not forget that the labour market in Europe is changing. The number of precarious jobs is increasing, as is the number of women occupying these jobs. In addition, new forms of employment are emerging, and new technologies have brought new challenges in terms of job security. For all these aspects, viable solutions are needed, as well as an appropriate process for collecting comparable data on occupational diseases and exposures, precisely in order to identify best prevention practices. The economic costs of accidents at work and occupational diseases are significant and the particularly complex nature of many new and emerging risks requires immediate action at EU level.

name: Igor Šoltes (Verts/ALE)
text: Writing. – I believe that the European Commission's strategy on health and safety at work 2014-2020 is absolutely necessary and very important for the entire eu working population, as it directly affects every individual. In addition, health and safety at work is also in the interests of businesses, as this improves the productivity and competitiveness of the company. Improving health and safety at work across the EU can contribute to economic recovery. A healthier lifestyle would allow more people to stay in the labour market until they actually reach the prescribed retirement age. It is necessary to raise awareness for businesses that administrative burdens and costs for complying with and enabling health and safety policies that promote well-being, a quality working environment and productivity are significantly less than the burdens and costs resulting from occupational and occupational accidents.  I believe that all workers must actually be entitled to the highest level of protection of health and safety in the workplace. It must be provided regardless of the size of the undertaking, type of work, type of work contract or Member State. Preventing occupational diseases and accidents creates added value for workers and society as a whole. At the same time, there is a need to further support companies promoting OSH.

name: Valdemar Tomaševski (ECR)
text: Writing. – Every year, more than 4000 people die as a result of accidents at work, and the number of deaths from occupational diseases exceeds 15 000 per year. The right to good health is a fundamental right in Europe, but despite improved performance at work, the most serious threats to workers' health and safety have still not been able to be addressed. The labour market in Europe is changing. The growth in the popularity of unsecured employment practices has been observed, and new forms of employment, similar to new technologies, have brought new challenges in the area of health and safety that need to be tackled. Let us remember that job insecurity is one of the biggest problems, especially in the new Member States of the European Union, which has a negative impact on occupational safety and the rules associated with it. The European Commission needs to draw attention to the increased number of workers with chronic and long-term illnesses and are disabled in order to ensure an accessible and safe workplace. Measures to integrate and rehabilitate persons with disabilities should also be encouraged. It is for these reasons that the European Parliament should show more initiative on this important issue. All workers, irrespective of the employer, shall be entitled to the highest level of health and safety at the workplace, irrespective of the law in which they are employed, irrespective of the employer, from the state in which they are employed.

name: Romana Tomc (PPE)
text: Writing. – Health and safety at work is in the interests of the employee, the employer and the company as a whole. Too often, investing in a healthy working environment is only seen as a cost. Companies that only aim for short-term profits avoid this cost. However, those companies that operate in the long run and are aware of social responsibility know that they also benefit from a healthy employee. A healthy and satisfied worker is more efficient at work, and this also has a good impact on the company's productivity and competitiveness. Healthy employees are also in the interest of the company as a whole, as they represent a lower cost in terms of medical expenses and can work until retirement age. It is therefore right that all stakeholders contribute to achieving the best possible result. First, the employee must take care of himself and avoid harmful habits and dangerous behaviours, the employer must ensure that he is constantly investing in the development of a healthy working environment, and the state must support the efforts of both. Building and maintaining a healthy and safe working environment are processes that are never completed.

name: Der Präsident. –
text: The next item on the agenda is the debate on the Commission statement on preventive measures to address the gender pension gap in the EU (2015/2971(RSP)).

name: Marianne Thyssen
text: Member of the Commission. – Mr President, honourable Members of Parliament, when we took office one year ago, this College of Commissioners put social fairness at the heart of its work. In this respect, I agree with you that a gender pension gap of 40% is entirely unacceptable. With a range from 4% to 46% in different countries across the European Union, it is clear that policies do make a difference. We must reform, and we must pursue equal-opportunity policy goals in several fields long before people reach pensionable age. We are already doing this, and I will take further action to that effect. Before the end of this year, we will present a strategic engagement on gender equality. This will establish an overall platform for European initiatives aimed at improving gender equality, including by addressing the underlying causes of the gender pension gap. As you know, in 2016 the Commission is to present a ‘new start for working parents and care-givers’ initiative to address the challenges of work/life balance and women’s under- representation in the labour market. We believe that such a new approach can bring benefits for all: for working parents and other care-givers who seek a better balance in their work and life commitments, and also for women in terms of supporting their participation in the labour market, allowing for greater sharing of care responsibilities between women and men, and strengthening gender equality. The consultation with the social partners and the open public consultation on these issues have been launched. Beyond improvements in leave arrangements, the initiative should aim to promote flexible work arrangements and affordable, good-quality care services, while removing tax and benefit-system disincentives for women to work. By addressing women’s lower labour-market participation and career breaks due to care responsibilities, the ‘new start’ initiative should also help to address the gaps in pension coverage and opportunities to build pension entitlements between women and men. The Commission is also undertaking a number of policy and awareness- raising measures to address the gender pay gap. In 2016, it plans to allocate EUR 4 million to Member States, under the Rights, Equality and Citizenship Programme, in order to raise awareness about the gender pension gap and its underlying reasons. As regards measuring the pension gap, we will continue our monitoring of gender differences in pension outcomes and pension adequacy. We have already agreed with Eurostat that the figures on the gender pension gap will be updated regularly. We will also continue our work with the Member States in the employment and social protection committees on methodologies, in particular to assess the extent of gender differences in pensions, and we will, of course, use various estimates and indicators of gender difference in our work on the European Semester. Here we will look at other key indicators such as the gender gap in old-age poverty. Data on the so-called gender pension gap derive from an indicator which the Commission asked its network of academic experts on gender equality to develop. The most recent data, based on an improved methodology, have been used in the 2015 Pension Adequacy Report, prepared with the Social Protection Committee. The pension gap indicator measures how prior gender differences in employment, pay, working hours and length of career have influenced the gender differences in current pension entitlements. To some extent, pension systems can alleviate the full impact of past gender differences in employment: care crediting, minimum and guaranteed pensions and survivor’s pensions all offer extra pension protection to women – and, of course, without these extra protection schemes, the gaps and the exposure to risks of poverty would be larger. Therefore, beyond improving gender equality in employment, we also need to preserve and improve these safeguards. To conclude on a positive note, I want to stress that, as a result of the steady increase in female employment rates in most Member States over the past three decades, the wider gender gaps in many countries are set to reduce, in some cases substantially. Yet unless we manage to eradicate gender differences in employment, they will continue to show up as gender gaps in pension provision. The Commission will therefore not merely continue to address the gender pension gap but will intensify its efforts.

name: Agnieszka Kozłowska-Rajewicz
text: On behalf of the PPE Group. – (2) Mr President, I would like to begin by Commissioner, i would like to thank you very much for It is extremely unfair for women to work out decent pensions unless they sacrifice their private lives. That is why I am very pleased, thank you for talking about the pension gap today. I would also like to thank you for all your declarations and initiatives that have already been taken, as well as those that are planned. Because the pension gap is a cumulative indicator of the inequalities that women experience in relation to their working lives as a result of their participation in the labour market. And as such, the cumulative inequality indicator is very good for assessing the effectiveness of equality policies and can, in my opinion, also be used in the European Semester.  The pension gap should be addressed by looking at its causes and not at the symptoms. And these reasons lie in women's participation in the labour market, because retirement is the result of seniority and earnings, so I would not look for reasons in pension systems, but would absolutely focus on women's participation in the labour market. And if we want higher pensions for women, then we need to enable women to work out such pensions, and I am not just thinking about reconciling roles, this work-life balance, but also the issue of educational pathways, so that they do not lead to sectoral segregation later on the labour market, as well as to the promotion path. I am very pleased with the announcement of the strategy, the strategy for investigating the pension gap in general, because this is a problem for all Member States and should therefore also be addressed at European Union level.

name: Jutta Steinruck
text: Mr President, I would like to make a mifful son, mr President, I would like to make a ido to the S&D Group. Mr President, I would like to thank the The fact that you are a man or a woman in Europe determines access to the labour market, working conditions and, above all, earnings. As we all know, women in the EU earn around 16% less than men, and this is, of course, reflected in later pensions. As you said, Mrs Thyssen, the Commission is now planning to tackle this problem. I hear that childcare should become better and more affordable, working hours should become more flexible and men should be given more incentives to participate in care, in family work. That's nice, but it doesn't solve the basic problem. Indeed, it is about wage differentials. We need to fix them. We also have to turn on other adjusting screws. We need binding action plans for equality between women and men in the labour market, we need reports on equal pay, and these must also be compulsory for employers. The Commission – as you said, you are planning – must regularly collect data on the gender pay gap and also promote gender-neutral job evaluation. This is the only way to achieve income transparency and also to reduce income disparities. That is the basic prerequisite for ending the pension gap in Europe.

name: Marian Harkin
text: on behalf of the ALDE Group. – Mr President, I would like to thank the Commissioner for her response. The figures on the gender pay gap and the pension gap are really a cause for huge concern. In my own country, Ireland, the gender pay gap is just over 14%, the overall earnings gap between men and women is almost 35%, and the pension gap is 40%. Now those are shocking statistics, and I suppose the questions that we must answer here this evening are, first of all, how can we narrow the current pension gap and, secondly, what can we do to ensure that the pensions of those now in employment are adequate and sustainable? I was very pleased to hear you mention a number of possible solutions. For example, you mentioned survivors’ pensions and also the idea of minimum pensions or some kind of minimum income for those past retirement. I fully support those proposals. Earlier we had a debate on healthy workplaces and healthy workers, and we need to ensure that we maintain those workplaces, promote a good work-life balance and try to ensure flexible arrangements within working time so that, if people want to stay on working longer, they can. You specifically referred to credits for some kind of involuntary absence from work, whether that be for illness or for caring duties. I think we have a very fundamental question to answer at EU level and national level, and it is this: is it acceptable that those who take time off to care for those who need care will be condemned to a much greater risk of poverty in old age? In my view it is not acceptable, because society, as we have constructed it, relies on family and unpaid carers. Health systems would collapse without them and social security systems would be unsustainable. Therefore, as a society, we have to integrate caring responsibilities into our social security and pension systems.

name: Lynn Boylan
text: on behalf of the GUE/NGL Group. – Mr President, as my colleague said, the gender pension gap in my home state of Ireland has increased since the economic crisis began. The result is that many women are denied economic independence, and the dignity that comes with it, in their retirement. We know the pension gap results from the cumulative impact of factors, including the pay gap, but we must also acknowledge when we talk of preventative measures and tackling the gender pension gap that austerity policies are exacerbating, rather than reducing, this inequality. Policies implemented by successive Irish governments since 2008 have worsened the situation for women in Ireland. The government reduced pension entitlements for new employees in the public service, and specific sectors dominated by women – teaching and nursing – have been targeted by other measures, reducing their salaries and pensions. We also have one of the highest levels of low-paid jobs in the developed world, after the US, and more than 60% of low-paid jobs are held by women, a trend that we see across the European Union. Yet childcare costs are among the highest in the world, and more than 40% of the average wage in Ireland. This has the effect of entirely excluding some women from participating in the productive economy and forcing others into precarious low-paid jobs that prevent them from paying into any sort of pension scheme. There are many steps we can take to tackle the gender pension gap, but first we must acknowledge the disastrous impact of austerity policies on women and immediately reverse them.

name: Maria Arena (S&D).
text: Mr President, Commissioner, I thank you for your presentation. It is true that the pension gap is not something that happens at age 65. It's something that's built up throughout the career, I'd say even before the career. This is a bit of what is attributed to us as a traditional role of woman, already at the time we choose our studies because we see, for example, that the less qualified you are, the greater the pension gap and therefore there is already this discrimination.  There is, as you said, discrimination in employment as soon as you enter the labour market, there is the issue of part-time work, which is not compensated at the time of the calculation of the pension, there are careers, which are related to maternity leave with maternity leave, but also parental leave which is not accessible in the same way for men , and so there are these inequalities. There are difficulties in reconciling private and work life, which require withdrawal from the labour market. There are also the women's sectors called poor sectors. We talked about the wage gap, but there is also the fact that in women's sectors there is no second and third pillars of pension that are constituted, so all of this actually leads to a situation where there is an impoverishment of women. You have mentioned a number of avenues, and I will give others, which have been voted on by this Parliament as part of the equality plan that was carried out by Mrs Noichl. I will return to paternity and parental maternity leave, which must be paid leave, services to families, which must be appropriate services, and also a first pillar of pension that must be properly fed. This is not what we are going through today in Europe, where we tend to move towards a reduction of the first pillar of pension.

name: Lidia Senra Rodríguez (GUE/NGL).
text: – Mr President, the peasants who are active in family farms in Europe have had and continue to have a lot of difficulty in accessing social security. Sometimes for legal reasons, sometimes for economic reasons, and sometimes for cultural reasons, but in all cases on a basis of discrimination that we women suffer.  At the end of the twentieth century there have been significant and significant struggles on the part of the Austrian peasants to obtain the right to a pension and also by the peasants of Galicia who were married to men who had other professions and who, like their husbands earned more than them in agriculture, were denied the right to pay social security. This meant that today too most peasants have lower pensions than peasants. Mrs Thyssen, I ask you, when analysing these priorities to reduce the pension gap, to take peasants into account. And this goes through the full recognition of the rights of peasants.

name: Danuta Jazłowiecka (PPE).
text: – (2) Mr President, I would like to begin by Dear! We have been fighting for many years in Europe against existing inequalities between women and men. However, there is still a dramatic difference in the amount of pension benefits received. It is enough to realize that the pay gap is more than 16% and in pensions close to 40%. If we can talk about a problem in the case of salaries, we are even in a crisis situation in the area of pensions. It has been emphasised for years that the main source of this state is inequality in the labour market. While we have achieved the Europe 2020 target for male employment, there is little progress for women, as only 63% of them are employed and still work largely part-time or under worse conditions. Of the total number of women, about a quarter have never worked in the official labour market and therefore have trouble acquiring pension rights. It is they that we should be interested in in the first place, because they are often in a dramatic situation, especially in the case of divorce.

name: Inês Cristina Zuber (GUE/NGL).
text: – Mr President, there are no better preventive measures to prevent gender discrimination in pensions than to close the gender pay gap. And to do so it is necessary to respect collective bargaining, preventing salaries from being negotiated individually. It is necessary that workers are not afraid to report situations of discrimination and, therefore, that justice protects them. It is necessary to provide the labour inspection authorities with appropriate means. Sanctions must be imposed on companies that do not comply with the law. It is necessary to defend maternity rights so that women are not harmed in terms of pensions because they have been mothers during their working lives. These are some of these measures, but also their fulfilment, together with the defence of public, supportive and universal social security systems, which will safeguard decent ageing for women.

name: Marianne Thyssen
text: member of the Commission. I would like to thank you very much for your support, so that we can work together on this. It is indeed unheard of that there is a pension gap of 40% and that, after all these years, we are still in a pay gap of more than 16% on average. We have to do something about that. Together we can work on that. We're going to have to focus on the work itself. What does women's careers look like? What sector do they work in? Do they work full-time, part-time? How well are they paid? I think we need to look at the rules here on equal pay, equal pay for equal work. We have rules, but the question is: are they sufficiently enforced and respected? A second thing is that we need to look at the pension schemes themselves, the pension systems, the specific approach and the specific rules therein. I just mentioned a few. Credits for people who take on caring responsibilities can, for example, provide a good correction here. I think that, as Mrs Arena has said, we should also look at the second pillar for women. In our report on the adequacy of pensions, it is clear that if we want not only sustainable pension systems, but also if we want pensions to be adequate, that is to say, have sufficient cover to keep pensioners' standard of living at a certain level, then we will have to develop and expand that second pillar of retirement. We must certainly look at this from a gender point of view and ensure that women and sectors in which women are active also have access to that second pillar of pensions. As you know, we have a fresh new start - that is what we have called it - as an alternative to the maternity protection proposal that we have withdrawn. There are many possibilities in this area that can also provide a solution to this problem. So let's work on that together.

name: Der Präsident. –
text: The debate is closed. Written declarations (Article 162 OF the CRP)

name: Anneli Jäätteenmäki (ALDE)
text: Written. "The pension gap between women and men is due to wage differences during working life. An equal situation with regard to pensions requires equality in wages. But the development is worrying. Let me take the situation in my country, Finland, for example. Unfortunately, it can be seen that, among young age groups, the pay gap between women and men is not narrowing, but, on the contrary, is widening in the private sector and at all levels of education. Young women work part-time and fixed-term work more often than young men. Even among younger generations, she is still the one who bears greater responsibility for home and children. This will all affect pay and, sooner or later, pensions. Equality between women and men must be thought of as a life cycle issue. I appeal to the Member States to intervene in earnest in the gender pay gap so that today's young people can enjoy an equal pension in decades' time.

name: Ivo Vajgl (ALDE)
text: Writing. – Usually, when it comes to fair pay, the issue of discrimination against women is raised in public and parliaments only around the eighth of March, a day dedicated to women. It is therefore right that colleagues have put the Commission on the delicate task of ing the situation and proposing solutions to this well-known injustice.  I would like to highlight in particular the most vulnerable group of women with the lowest incomes or pensions. They're housewives and peasant women. Since in the past their status has not been properly regulated in transition countries, many today live below the poverty line. Countries' austerity measures during the economic crisis have also deprived them of so-called state pensions, which have at least partially recognised their contribution to society' benefit. Today, their material situation depends on social assistance. It is an unacceptable situation for women, who have made a significant contribution to the well-being of family and society through motherhood and farm work. It would be right and fair to improve the social status of impoverished older women. This, too, should be open to the Commission.  Finally, I would like to draw attention to a fact which in itself speaks eloquently of the treatment of housework, since even by statistical criteria, domestic work is not work (in the case of unemployed and retired, housewives and women farmers fall into the category of 'other inactive women'), which is offensive and unacceptable.

name: Henna Virkkunen (PPE)
text: Written. – It is very good that the Commission has raised the issue of gender inequality, which will only increase as older people retire. The lower labour market position of women than men, the years spent at home with children and, in the over-64 age group, the lower level of education has also led to lower levels of pension than men. It is also a question of narrowing women's self-determination. When your own income is low, the possibilities also narrow. As we age, the need for care increases, but financial opportunities also restrict access to services in many Member States. Unfortunately, in addressing the pension gap, the Commission's and Parliament's tools are scarce. I encourage the Commission and the Member States to continue the debate on promoting equality between women and men. The best remedy is to address gender inecompetents in education. Family leave and family services also play an important role in enabling women to work – if day care is not arranged or expensive, it is natural that it is natural that it does not seem attractive to families to continue working for a mother after having a child. However, this is not in the interests of the mother, the child or society. An ageing Europe needs more manpower. The best abilities must be introduced into the labour market, regardless of gender. For example, the World Bank has calculated that restricting the participation of women in the labour market and in companies will slow down global economic growth. According to the report, italy and Greece, for example, have a GDP 15 % behind the level at which it could be if women's participation in the labour market were at a level similar to that of men. Unfortunately, until the obvious shortcomings of the labour market have been rectified, there will be no improvement in pensions either.
